In this project, we will improve scalability and efficacy of In2Books based on measurement obtained through high-quality assessments and evaluation. We will identify the elements of In2Books design that have the greatest impact on student learning through rigorous evaluation, preserve and enhance the qualities of the program that make it so effective, and sustainably implement those design principals at scale. The expected outcome of this program is to improve efficacy and scalability of In2Books for the purpose of increasing the magnitude of its effect.Target Number of Students. We will implement the program starting with 200 classrooms in year 1 growing to 1,300 classrooms by year 4.Partners. ePals, Inc., a for-profit company will supply 20% matching funds as in-kind contribu-tions in technology and services. We have seeded our school consortium with partner elementary schools in Georgia, Iowa and Montana."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Initiative for Family Engagement and Culturalliy Responsive Education Centers of Excellence
Project Description: "Every Person Influences Children with Official Partners New York City Department of Education (NYCDOE),Indiana Partnerships Center and the Mid-Atlantic Equity Consortium, Inc., propose to implement the Centers ofExcellence for Culturally Responsive Family Engagement (CRFE), an innovation that will transform teachereffectiveness and improve student achievement in NY, IN, and MD. This five year Development Project willeffectively engage low-income, culturally diverse families as partners and key stakeholders in the education oftheir children to improve student achievement. Through a collaborative Think Tank, the Project will use theexpertise of the Harvard Family Research Project, nine universities, three State Education Agencies, and eightlocal education agencies, including Official Partner NYCDOE, the largest and most diverse District in thecountry, to design competencies, learning objectives, and measurements in cultural competency and familyengagement for Pre-/in-service. Based on these universal competencies and objectives, university partners willdevelop and provide undergraduate/graduate and professional development courses to 180 pre-service teachers,support 757 in-service teachers, serving a total of 937 teachers. Pre-/in-service teachers will have multipleopportunities to develop knowledge, disposition, and skills through CRFE training, and to apply competencies inthe classroom to increase communication, and strengthen relationships with low-income and culturally diversefamilies as an innovation for effective student instruction. Teachers will serve over 36,040 students in theirschools through CRFE, partnering universities will mandate curricula to their education students, and thecapacity of the partners will sustain and scale up this innovation. To ensure proper implementation of allcomponents, CRFE?s formative and summative evaluation will focus on all aspects related to project scope,implementation, and quality and impact of services."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Utilizing Culturally Relevant Classroom Libraries to Accelerate Reading Development and
Support Social and Emotional Competence
Project Description: "Expanding on the results of a St. Louis-based pilot study, this development project includes 72 Chicago PublicSchool teachers and approximately 2700 students in kindergarten through 5th grade. Teachers in fourintervention schools will participate in professional development to support their development of high-qualityclassroom libraries and their utilization of trade books as a key component of the literacy curriculum. A controlgroup of twenty-four teachers will receive children?s books and other resources for their classrooms withoutthe added training or support around text selection or utilization. Classroom observations will be conductedthree times each year to assess teachers? progress in building, organizing, and utilizing the classroom library inconjunction with the core reading curriculum. A range of standardized and informal outcome measures will beused to assess students? engagement with texts, their attitudes toward reading, and their reading developmentover time. Researchers will examine children?s growth in reading skills and social/emotional development as afunction of the types and frequency of reading materials utilized in professionals? instructional practice.Hierarchical linear modeling will be used to explore the relationship between classroom instructional effectsand growth in reading accuracy, fluency, and comprehension, including whether effects may vary for studentsat different developmental levels (primary vs. upper elementary). Motivational and behavioral variables thatmay mediate growth in reading will also be explored. Anticipated outcomes include improved teacherknowledge of the characteristics and uses of high-quality classroom libraries, improvements in students?attitudes toward reading and positive engagement in school, increased frequency of independent reading, andaccelerated student growth in reading accuracy, fluency, and comprehension."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
Achieving High Standards for Pre-K-Grade 3 Mathematics: A Whole Teacher approach to
Professional Development
Project Description: "Erikson Institute proposes a five-year initiative that addresses Absolute Priority 3 and Competitive Preference Priority 5 via an Investing in Innovation Development grant. The initiative will help Illinois? students reach or exceed state Learning Standards for Mathematics by designing and implementing an innovative professional development (PD) program for teachers who serve high needs children in prekindergarten through third grade (PK-3). The program?s objectives are: (1) teachers will understand how concepts represented by the standards develop in children?s thinking; (2) teachers will demonstrate increased skill in implementing instruction that addresses the standards; (3) teachers will report a greater sense of comfort and competence in mathematics and math teaching; (4) the performance of students from high-need schools on standardized assessments of mathematics achievement, including the Illinois Standards Achievement Test (ISAT), will significantly improve; and (5) children?s school readiness, as evidenced by math and literacy assessments, will increase.  Hierarchical Linear Modeling will be used to evaluate effects on teachers and on children?s learning. This conceptually and operationally unique approach to PD will serve 4,512 children at 8 Chicago Public Schools over 5 years. Providing both off- and on-site services in individualized, small-group, and large-group formats, the project addresses teacher attitudes, practices, and knowledge and creates within-school mechanisms to sustain excellent math teaching beyond the intervention. The project includes the publication of training materials that address the Illinois Learning Standards for Mathematics and are suitable for replication. The Chicago Public School System is our LEA, and our official partner and independent evaluator is SRI International."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Ready Students, Ready Communities in Cuyahoga County
Cuyahoga County Pathway to College
Project Description: "The framework for the Cuyahoga County Pathway to College Program is based on the 2009 What Works Clearinghouse document entitled, Helping Students Navigate the Path to College: What High Schools Can Do.  Its core objectives are intended to meet the needs of 10,000 high school students and approximately 50 teachers in three Cuyahoga County school districts or five high schools.  The objectives, strategies and action steps of the program are listed in Table 1 below, which support the overarching goal which is to align and embed multiple evidence-based strategies and initiatives that are customized to meet student needs within the participating school districts to develop a pathway for all students to successfully navigate towards industrious post-secondary education options."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: MOBILE LEARNING IN HAND
Project Description: "The innovative strategy of this program is to apply technology developed for personal entertainment, in the form of an iPod touch, in public elementary classrooms where these Mobile Learning Devices (MLDs) completely revolutionize teaching and learning. At the Escondido Union School District, we have surveyed research and piloted this program concept with remarkable preliminary results.The Mobile Learning in Hand program trains teachers to use a class set of iPod touch devices to address all aspects of learning -- from recording student reading practice and assessments, to learning long division, to writing responses to literature, to taking virtual field trips.  We propose expanding our successful pilot program incrementally, beginning districtwide for all 4th grade, adding 5th grade in year two and 3rd grade in the third program year.This bold, collaborative use of technology enables our district to address our highest priority goals: improving academic achievement and engagement across the entire student body. Similar transformation of hard and soft skills for participating teachers amplifies the value of this program over time. In this proposal we lay out the remarkable outcomes we have been able to document in 4 years of program development. These outcomes are not only dramatic for students on an individual level, but also for teachers, and for the district as a whole. It has already gained national and international attention and motivated replication. The potential student achievement breakthroughs, galvanizing of teacher enthusiasm, cost savings and more all add up to tremendous potential for Mobile Learning in Hand.We are eager to partner with the Department of Education and our matching donors to further explore an approach, which is more than a promising practice. Our proposal is about rapidly bringing elementary education up to speed with the digital world our children already live in. We are excited to present this proposal for your consideration."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Espanola Public School District I3 Reading Intervention Study
Project Description: This project will study the efficacy of technology based reading intervention porgrams onhigh need students whoare reading significantly below their expected grade level.
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Prime Time for Reading:  Development and Evaluation of an Early Literacy Program for Limited English Proficient Hispanic Children
Project Description: "As aDevelopment Grant, the proposed project  addresses one Absolute Priority and two Competitive Preference Priorities.  It comparison to national rates, the school dropout rate of Hispanic youth in the Cleveland Metropolitan School District (CMSD) is estimated to be an alarming 76% -- that is three times the national average.  Given the 'academic emergency' and 'academic watch' status of manyCMSD schools, a sweeping overhaul of the school system has inevitably arose.  As the only non-profit organization dedicated to the educational needs of Hispanic youth in CMSD, Esperanza, Inc., is in a strong position to work with its official partner (CMSD) toward improving the academic success of this high-need population, especially during the critical early elementary years.  The Prime Time for Reading program, which is one of many programs that Esperanza has provided to thousands of students, is naturallyaligned with the Academic Transformation Plan that is being implemented throughout CMSD.  For Hispanic children, this need is urgent, as Hispanic children have a 50% failure rate on state mandated reading tests.  Prime Time is a supplemental literacy program which can significantly help reduce the risk of academic failure for Hispanic youth with limited English proficiency, and in turn serve to help close the achievement gap.  The purpose of the project is twofold:  (a) to further develop and revise the model of quality programming that has been used in Prime Time through innovative practices that are shown to hold promise for improving the language proficiency of high-need LEP Hispanic students, and (b) to use a longitudinal, quasi-experimental design as a means of testing the effects of the newly revised program based on reasonable hypotheses derived from the positive outcomes gained from similar types of programs.  The project will last 5 years: one for planning, three for implementation, and one for a final report.  Quantitative and qualitative methods will be used."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: ICE(3): Industry and Career Education Empowering Excellence
Project Description: "The ICE3 (pronounced Ice Cubed) project?s ultimate goal is to better prepare our students to be successful in the workforce of the 21st century.Built around Kansas? Career Fields and Clusters Model, students in participating districts will receive guidance to help them make choices in preparation for future careers. In each district, two staff members will be trained by project staff to serve as Life Planning Facilitators within their districts. Two staff members will always be trained to assure the integrity of the project even with staff turnover in uncertain budgetary times. Facilitators will:? Provide comprehensive career exploration and decision making support to help students determine their individual career interests using a variety of career decision making tools featured on the ICE3 website.? Develop an individual career plan with students that extend beyond high school.? Increase student awareness of career pathway course opportunities beyond the face-to-face options in their local district? Assist students as they select and enroll in virtual or face-to-face classes aligned with their individual plan of study.This strategy will provide students with more choices?especially our students in rural districts. It is also more cost efficient when considering that rural district currently employ staff members who serve relatively few students within their own district, but who could serve many students in the participating district. For example, a Marketing course might have only 3 students interested in this field in her home district but 25 students in schools participating in the ICE3 project. By enrolling students in low-level college courses or in high school courses offered by teachers who have been trained in online instruction delivery, districts can reduce the number of staff needed while fulfilling their students? needs. In particular, this project will assist in meeting the needs of the healthcare, STEM, and education fields."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Evansville Vanderburgh School Corporation Performance Management System
Project Description: "To enhance a previously implemented alternative licensure and staff development initiative called the LearningLeadership Cadre, the Evansville Vanderburgh School Corporation (EVSC), in partnership with BrownUniversity, local government, area businesses and community organizations, and other key partners, seeksfunding for a development grant under Absolute Priority 2 of the Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) GrantProgram. Specifically, we propose implementation of a data-driven performance management system aligneddirectly with the EVSC strategic plan. Core elements of this system include: (a) weekly forums to present anddiscuss student academic data and identify action steps; (b) clearly defined and measurable performanceindicators tied to the district strategic plan; (c) data warehouse (i.e., automatic collection and distribution ofstudent performance data); (d) professional development utilizing ?Data Wise,? a method for using assessmentresults to collaborate and create action plans for improvement; (e) coaching model that focuses on data use andcollaboration; and (f) external professional development for emerging teacher and district leaders in areas ofdata use, engagement, collaboration and leadership. Objectives of the project include (a) increasing academicperformance and engagement, (b) increasing transparency and accountability in the use of data, (c) increasingcapacity in the use of data, (d) increasing collaboration among educators and families, (e) increasingknowledge and practical application of collaboration, data use, leadership, and engagement, (f) improvingteacher and principal efficacy, (g) implementing action research projects to impact student achievement."

Project Title: EVSC Equity Schools: An Innovative Model of School Turnaround
Project Description: "The Evansville Vanderburgh School Corporation (EVSC) seeks funding for a development grant under AbsolutePriority 4 of the Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Grant Program to implement an Equity Model in three of itshighest poverty and lowest performing schools. The Equity Model includes an innovative combination ofresearch-proven strategies and is designed to serve high-need student populations by completely transformingthe schools that they attend. This model involves implementation of the following core strategies: (1) replacingthe principal, (2) developing and increasing teacher and school leader effectiveness through a requiredprofessional development academy, (3) instituting comprehensive instructional reforms through new curricularofferings and instructional approaches, (4) increasing learning time and creating community-oriented schoolsthrough new schedules with additional instructional days, (5) providing flexibility and sustained supportthrough self-governance, and (6) implementing financial incentives (i.e., innovative team-based pay-forperformanceplans). Objectives of the model include (1) improving academic performance among K-8 students(e.g., improvement on standardized assessments), (2) increasing student and family engagement (e.g.,increases observed on behavioral, affective, and cognitive engagement indicators), (3) increasing the use ofcollaborative practice, data-driven decision-making, and high-yield instructional strategies among teachers, (4)recruiting and retaining high-performing educators, and (5) increasing levels of functioning of core schoollevel leadership teams. Across the three schools, a total of 1,219 students will be directly impacted annually. Indeveloping this model, the EVSC has developed strong partnerships with the Evansville Teachers Association(ETA), local government, area businesses and community organizations."

Project Title: Pathways and Partnerships for College and Community Success
Project Description: "Everett Public Schools? Investing in Innovation (i3) development grant proposal, Pathways and Partnerships forCollege and Community Success, is an opportunity to significantly increase college and career access andsuccess for students by developing pre-K-16 data systems, by developing comprehensive plans to preparestudents for the rigor of postsecondary institutions, providing early access to college courses, assisting studentsin the application and transition to postsecondary and providing follow-up to students during the early stagesof postsecondary experience.This project will target 12,000 Everett Public Schools students over the course of the next five years throughpartnerships with Everett Community College, the City of Everett, Everett Public Schools Foundation, and theRotary of Everett, in addition to many other local colleges, universities, governments, and organizations.Goals of the project include:1. 85% of Everett Public Schools? students will graduate with at least 15 credits of college before they leave highschool2. 30% of those students will graduate from high school with at least 45 credits3. 85% of Everett Public Schools? students will complete two years of postsecondary educationThis project is part of a strategic plan to help Everett students successfully complete college and to help ourcommunity build a skilled and educated workforce."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Expeditionary Learning Student Engaged Assessment Strategies
Project Description: "Expeditionary Learning (EL) proposes to scale an implementation framework for student-engaged assessment practices to 17 EL schools, for eventual use in 165 EL network schools and schools beyond the network. Studies have shown significant gains in student achievement and college attainment in EL schools currently using these practices, particularly with high-need students. Those schools will be mentor schools in this project.Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: Project Objectives:1.  Document best practices in successful mentor schools to create easily transferrable dissemination tools for schools across and beyond the EL network to implement these practices. 2. Study the effect of implementation of those practices on student achievement.Expected Student Achievement Outcomes: In the 17 treatment schools: statistically significant gains compared to district in test score performance, graduation and college acceptance, with disproportionately strong gains for high-need student sub-groups.Target Number of Students Served: The grant will serve 7,650 students in identified project schools. It will be scaled in part during the course of the grant to the full EL network of 47,000 students, and at completion fully to the broader EL network and to schools beyond the network. Special Project Features: Impacts district and charter schools; urban, rural and suburban; K-12; spread nationally in clusters. Utilizes an unparalleled national archive of exemplary student work to establish high standards, created over 17 years with Harvard Graduate School of Education.Official Partners: University of Massachusetts Donahue Institute - EvaluatorUnofficial partners: Harvard Graduate School of Education; Midcontinent Research for Education and LearningOther partners: Impact (software developer) "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Expeditionary Learning: A New Direction for Turnaround Success
Project Description: "Expeditionary Learning (EL), a school transformation organization with proven experience across a broad array of settings and proven results, offers an exceptional and significant solution to the challenge of turning around persistently low performing schools. EL offers districts seeking to turn around low performing, high poverty schools its capacity to transform schools from the classroom out by joining a vision of transformational learning for students, teachers, and school leaders to a rigorous, data-driven, continuous improvement methodology. Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: Project Objectives: to implement EL's Turnaround Leadership model in 17 persistently low-performing schools and evaluate the degree to which students improve both in traditional measures of student achievement (grades, test scores) and in college and career readiness.  Expected Outcomes: significant student improvement gains; a turnaround model ready for national implementation.Target Number of Students Served: 7,650Special Project Features:  Scalable nationally; uses a consortium of EL Mentor Schools - high performing schools serving mainly high need students - to anchor clusters of turnaround schools in particular geographic areas.Partners: Official Partners: Northwest Evaluation Association (NWEA),Tutors for All, MDRC, Consortium of 29 schools        Other Partners: IMPACT"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Experience in Action dba Experience Corps
Project Title: Experience Corps Investing in Innovation
Project Description: "Experience Corps, in partnership with seven of its local affiliates, is submitting a request to the U.S. Department of Education?s Investing in Innovation Fund, Absolute Priority 4: Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools, for a Validation Level grant. Experience Corps?s goal is to help high-need K-3 students in low-performing schools improve their academic performance and close achievement gaps in reading. We will do so by placing teams of well-trained older adults in classrooms to provide small group and one-on- tutoring to high-need students in 37 low-performing schools. Experience Corps has a long-standing commitment to research and evaluation. The innovation posited in this proposal is validated by two rigorous experimental research studies conducted by Washington University and Johns Hopkins University. Recently, the U.S. Department of Education?s What Works Clearinghouse recognized the Washington University study as ?consistent with What Works Clearinghouse evidence standards,? and as a ?well-implemented randomized controlled trial.? The study concludes, among other things, that the Experience Corps program improves reading comprehension and sounding out new words skills by 60%. It also concludes that the program works for any student, regardless of race, gender or geography. The American Institutes for Research (AIR) will conduct the impact evaluation of the Experience Corps Investing in Innovation program. This study will assess the effects of Experience Corps on student reading achievement in kindergarten and elementary grades 1 to 3. The evaluation will be designed as a multisite cluster randomized controlled trial.Experience Corps has a highly sustainable and scalable model for serving high-need students during the five-year grant period and beyond. Experience Corps has established a partnership with AARP, which has over 40million members who are age 50 and older. AARP will assist with recruiting and retaining new volunteers du... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"

Project Title: Integrating English Language Development and Science: A Professional Development Approach
Project Description: The Exploratorium Institute for Inquiry (IFI) in San Francisco, in partnership with the Sonoma Valley Unified School District (SVUSD) in California, proposes a five-year Integrating English Language Development (ELD) and Science project that addresses the need to increase the percentage of elementary teachers who are highly effective in supporting the education of limited English proficient students."The Exploratorium Institute for Inquiry (IFI) in San Francisco, in partnership with the Sonoma Valley Unified School District (SVUSD) in California, proposes a five-year Integrating English Language Development (ELD) and Science project that addresses the need to increase the percentage of elementary teachers who are highly effective in supporting the education of limited English proficient students. 	The framing hypothesis for this project is that strategically designed professional development focused on integrated ELD and science will increase the percentage of highly effective teachers, as measured by both teacher performance and student achievement in English language development and in science. 	This project is based on the results of a recent two-year pilot project in one school that showed measurable gains in student achievement using an integrated ELD and science approach. Scores of fifth grade Hispanic students on the California Standards Test for science increased from basic to proficient. Student scores on the California English Language Development Test increased from intermediate to early advanced proficiency. 	The project is supported by research that indicates the great potential of synergy between ELD and science learning. 	The project will first work with 24 teachers from the pilot project school to refine the professional development approach and then work with two cohorts of 30 teachers each from the remaining four elementary schools (90% of the district elementary school teachers) in a series of workshops, study groups, and leadership activities. 	This developmental project is designed to study the introduction of integrated ELD and science to an entire district to better understand the issues of scale and dissemination. Inverness Research Incorporated and the Research, Evaluation, and Assessment Center (REA) will evaluate the project and distill findings. IFI will develop a professional development guide and disseminate the results."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Explore Schools: Creating, Evaluating and Disseminating a Model for School Turnaround
Project Description: "Title:  Explore Schools: Creating, Evaluating and Disseminating a Model for School TurnaroundType of Grant Requested:  Development, Priority 4 - Innovations That Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing SchoolsExplore Schools will create a proof point for a school turnaround model that can be built in different regions, stand up to rigorous evaluation, and be widely and systematically disseminated to impact the lives of hundreds of thousands of children in low-performing schools throughout the U.S.  The objectives and expected outcomes of this project are to:I.	Prove the possibility of school turnaround by growing and replicating high-quality turnaround schools.  Explore Schools will turn around seven persistently low-performing schools in New York City and Washington, D.C. over the next five years.  II.	Implement, study and codify an approach to school turnaround planning, implementation and assessment through partnership with well-respected external evaluators.  This process will create a strong model for replication and a pipeline for highly-qualified education professionals.  III.	Increase organizational capacity to positively impact persistently low-performing schools through dissemination of our turnaround model, the sharing of best practices, and training of turnaround leaders in partner districts and beyond.Explore Schools' turnaround sites will serve 2,700 students during the five-year project period and, ultimately, hundreds of thousands of students across the country as additional leaders are trained and implementation of the turnaround model occurs in schools beyond Explore Schools' sites.Explore Schools partners in this project are:  New York City Department of Education, District of Columbia Public Schools, SchoolWorks and 102 Group.  Explore Schools has also secured support from Mass Insight, Public Impact, Teach for America and the New York City Charter School Center."

Project Title: North Carolina Data-Driven Literacy Initiative
Project Description: "Quality Teaching and Learning will partner with 4 North Carolina districts to close the achievement gaps and raise writing performance.  In addition to introducing technology tools that will work across disciplines with district-created content, QTL will provide a model of integrated assessment and instruction through with Wireless Generation's writing program, a data-driven, fully differentiated innovation for improving outcomes in writing achievement. In this way, these four districts will take an instructional lead in a state that is moving toward adoption of the Common Core Standards and a new emphasis on writing."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Mississippi Quality Teaching and Learning (QTL)
Project Description: "Mississippi QTL engages LEAs to achieve state standards by turning the information from assessments into classroom practices that meet the needs of all students, including high-need students. The project will assist teachers in creation and use of formative assessments and develop school leaders' support of assessment-informed instruction . Measurable objectives:1. Increase teachers' use of assessment tools and data to inform instruction.2. Increase teacher?s implementation of research-based instructional practices based on assessment data to support stronger student outcomes, including improved outcomes for high-need students.3. Build leaders' skills that support and reinforce teacher implementation of assessment data to accomplish state standards and increase student achievement.4. Increase student academic achievement in all grades through the use of assessment data that informs instructional practice.QTL programs have shown significant impact in individual schools and groups of schools. This grant proposes working with entire districts to improve student achievement in all grades. The process occurs in three phases: Leadership Development ? administrators and other school leaders become better able to support teacher efforts to improve student outcomes.; Teacher Development ? Three summers of professional learning to understand and practice research-based instruction. During the school year action research examines student data to determine critical needs, design and deliver instruction aimed at meeting those needs, while integrating ongoing assessments to help teachers monitor student growth and respond to gaps in learning.Professional Learning Community ? Teachers meet regularly in collaborative groups during the school year to reflect on their practices and maintain the action research cycle with a clear focus on using assessment and appropriate instructional practice to clearly focus on student needs.Five poor, rural LEAs 9800 students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Five Star
Project Description: "ExplorNet d/b/a The Centers for Quality Teaching and Learning, an educational non-profit, in partnershipwith five eastern North Carolina school districts (Brunswick County Schools, Edgecombe County Schools,New Hanover County Schools, Onslow County Schools, and Roanoke Rapid Graded Schools) and WirelessGeneration, Inc. proposes an Investing in Innovation Program validation grant focused on Absolute Priority 2?Innovations that Improve the Use of Data, as well as Competitive Preference Priority 5 ? Innovations forImproving Early Learning Outcomes and Competitive Preference Priority 8 ? Innovations that Serve Schoolsin Rural LEAs. The purpose of this grant is to increase the achievement high need students by implementingintervention instruction bolstered by data conversations and the cycle of continuous improvement.The North Carolina Partnership will implement an innovative solution that blends knowledge from the?science of reading? and knowledge from effective schools, Five Stars: Dynamic Data Discussions DriveDelivery (Five Stars). This innovation incorporates the following elements requisite for promoting the successof high needs students: an intervention program, Early Intervention in Reading (EIR)?, related assessments,high quality professional development, and routine data.The NC Partnership?s Five Stars will seek to accomplish four goals:1. Improve data conversations within and across grade levels;2. Increase teachers? and administrators? effective use of formative assessment and student data to supportinstructional decision-making;3. Improve teacher implementation of research-based instructional practices to support stronger studentoutcomes; and4. Increase student academic achievement in grades K-4.This research-based initiative will improve the use of data to drive evidence-based intervention and a cycle ofcontinuous improvement to promote improved student outcomes for our most at-risk pre-k through fourth gradestudents."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Empowering Dual Language Teachers to Bolster the Academic Achievement of LEP Students
Project Description: "PROJECT DESCRIPTION-FACE CONSORTIUM Project Title: 'Empowering French Dual Language Teachers to Bolster the Academic Achievement of LEP Students' Type of Grant Requested: Development Grant Brief Project Description: This program hypothesizes that dual language teachers trained in bilingual education, who have immediate access to appropriate classroom resources in both languages and opportunities for collaboration with colleagues, are most effective in bolstering student achievement, specifically the growth of LEP students. Through six unique interventions, the FACE Consortium aims to increase teacher effectiveness and thereby improve LEP student achievement. Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: By focusing on data-driven instruction with an innovative online tracking tool, collaboration, leadership opportunities, bilingual teacher training, and targeted professional development, the project seeks to demonstrate a positive correlation between an increased number of highly effective bilingual teachers and increased successful outcomes for LEP students. The Consortium defines a successful outcome to be at least 75% of Francophone LEP students who remain in French dual language programs for four or more years meet or exceed grade-level standards in reading and writing in French, and /or at least 65% of Francophone LEP students who remain in French dual language programs for four or more years meet or exceed grade-level standards in reading, writing and math. Target Number of Students to be Served in the Project: 1160 Official and Other Partners: FACE (French-American Cultural Exchange); EFNY (Education Fran
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: FACE - Foundation to Advance Childhood E
Project Title: 3-to-3 Data Pathway Project
Project Description: "The 3-3 Data Pathway Project builds on current projects in Ohio and New Mexico and will create a district/prek/community system to improve age 3 to Grade 3 children?s learning outcomes. The project addresses how thesystem - including the school and other cooperating institutions - can facilitate the transition between preschooland kindergarten and become better able to support the child?s maximum growth and development, notonly academically but socially, emotionally, cognitively, and physically. The 3-to-3 Data Pathway has beendesigned to support the ?ready school? concept as a backbone that runs through a student?s schoolingexperiences from preschool to Grade 3 providing the structure for transition and alignment of expectations,assessments, and instructional practices.The 3-to-3 Data Pathway design focuses on the following: (1) Continuity: Consistency and time in learningenvironment- focus on transitions; (2) Organization: Structural features to increase intensity, length, andquality - focus on leadership; (3) Instruction: Coordination and interpretation of curriculum & teachingpractices - focus on standards, instruction, and assessment; and (4) Family Support Services: Comprehensiveservices to promote smooth transitions - focus on home-school-community connections.The project will create a strong systemic foundation to implement, evaluate, institutionalize, sustain, disseminate,replicate and scale up the 3-3 Data Pathway Model; provide training and support to build capacity of theDistrict-Community and Local (school-pre-K) Data/Leadership teams to improve age 3 to grade 3 programs;create the 3-3 Data Pathway of programmatic and individual student data and use the data for continuousimprovement; and conduct dissemination and replication activities and plan for scale-up."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Facing History and Ourselves National Foundation, Inc.
Project Title: Developing Teachers, Engaging Students: A Partnership between Facing History and Ourselves, Boston Public Schools, and Jefferson County Public Schools of Louisville, Kentucky
Project Description: "Facing History and Ourselves, in partnership with Boston Public Schools (BPS) and Jefferson County Public Schools (JCPS), is submitting an Investing in Innovating (i3) application for a Development grant of $7.3MM ($5.0MM of Department of Education funds and $2.3MM in matching funds) for the next five school years, starting in fall 2010. The proposed project addresses the i3 Absolute Priority #1 of increasing the number and percentage of highly effective teachers by dramatically expanding its professional development and teacher support services within its partner districts, thereby increasing student achievement, graduation rates, and college readiness. The project also addresses the i3 Competitive Preference #6 of promoting college access and success by keeping students academically engaged and by fostering critical thinking skills. The project targets two large, urban school districts that serve a significant majority of ?high need? students, as measured by the percentage of students who are living in poverty, attending high-minority schools, over-age for grade, or at risk of not graduating on time.Through this project, Facing History will provide intensive training and support to approximately 250 total teachers, reaching an estimated 60,000 middle and high school students over the course of five years. Facing History will also build its internal staff and technological capacity to provide more intensive professional development to all Facing History teachers within the partner districts and to support and sustain the program beyond the grant period. In partnership with Abt Associates, Facing History will conduct a Difference-in-Differences (DiD) design study to quantify the impact of this program on teacher effectiveness and student achievement, using multiple measures of student growth as a core component. This proposal builds on previous research of Facing History programs to create a scalable model that can be replicated across the country."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Facing History and Ourselves National Foundation, Inc.
Project Title: Developing Teachers, Engaging Students: A Partnership between Facing History and Ourselves and Chicago Public Schools, Boston Public Schools, and Memphis City Schools
Project Description: "Facing History and Ourselves, in partnership with Boston Public Schools (BPS), Chicago Public Schools (CPS), and Memphis City Schools (MCS), is submitting an Investing in Innovating (i3) application for a Validation grant for the next five school years, starting in fall 2010. The proposed project addresses the i3 Absolute Priority #1 of increasing the number and percentage of highly effective teachers by dramatically expanding its professional development and teacher support services within its partner districts, thereby increasing student achievement, graduation rates, and college readiness. The project also addresses the i3 Competitive Preference #6 of promoting college access and success by keeping students academically engaged and by fostering critical thinking skills. The project targets three large, urban school districts that serve a significant majority of 'high need' students, as measured by the percentage of students who are living in poverty, attending high-minority schools, over-age for grade, or at risk of not graduating on time. Through this project, Facing History will provide intensive training and support to approximately 1,000 new teachers, reaching an estimated 200,000 middle and high school students over five years. Facing History will also build its internal staff and technological capacity to provide more intensive professional development to all Facing History teachers within partner districts and to support and sustain the program beyond the grant period. In partnership with Abt Associates, Facing History will conduct a rigorous randomized control trial (RCT) to quantify the impact of this program on teacher effectiveness and student achievement, using multiple measures of student growth as a core component. This proposal builds on previous research of Facing History programs to create a scalable model that can be replicated across the country to promote teacher effectiveness, increase student achievement, and close the achievement gap."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Latino Education Pipeline
Project Description: "Fairleigh Dickinson University in collaboration with its partner local education associations located in Bergen County, Essex County, Hudson County, Morris County, Passaic County and Union County New Jersey, proposes to expand the outreach efforts of the Latino Education Pipeline by providing student, parent and school administrator support programs and workshops to increase the academic achievement of Latino students in the northeast region of New Jersey."

Project Title: Creating Connections for Safe Schools
Project Description: "The proposed project will provide teachers and principals in the Pomona Unified School District with training and support in the use of Conscious Discipline, an innovative social-emotional curriculum and classroom management system.  Based upon past promising results and evidence within the body of research, the project presupposes that the implementation and systematic inclusion of this curriculum will improve classroom management and thus lead to improved student achievement for approximately 30,000 students (early childhood - 12th grade) in the at-risk community of Pomona, California.  The Fairplex Child Development Center (FCDC), a non-profit organization, will provide the leadership and implementation of these trainings, in partnership with the Pomona Unified School District (PUSD), a local educational agency, and the University of La Verne (ULV).With a focus on providing educators with the tools to increase student learning outcomes through more effective classroom management, the project is requesting funds under the Development category and addressees Absolute Priority #1, 'innovations that support effective teachers and principals' and Absolute Priority #4, 'innovations that turn around persistently low-performing schools.'The overall goals of this project are 1) to decrease aggressive behavior, 2) to increase social skills, and 3) to increase academic achievement of students whose teachers and school administrators have been trained in the Conscious Discipline program, especially those from persistently low-performing schools.  The main project activity lies in the training sessions, and the impact of these trainings will be evaluated through classroom assessments and student data measurements."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Falcon School District 49 K-12 STEM Education/Workforce Pipeline Initiative
Project Description: "The Falcon School District 49 K-12 STEM Education/Workforce Pipeline Initiative is a new approach to STEMeducation designed to reach our goal of graduating students who possess the knowledge, skills and habits ofmind necessary to work and live in the 21st century environment, and to prepare them academically forentrance into STEM post-secondary education and STEM workforce success.The Project goal will be additionally strengthened by the introduction of the counselor-based Individual Careerand Academic Plans ( ICAPs) linked to the web-based College in Colorado tracking system, to give studentsand their parents an interactive tool by which to plan and track STEM career exploration grades 7-12 and intocollege. The ICAP program was initiated by D49 two years ago and this year, inclusion of ICAPs in everyColorado high school became a state mandate, SB09-256."

Project Title: Technology-Mediated Integrated Learning Environment for High-Need Students
Project Description: "Expansion of current implementation of a flexible, hybrid online learning environment for high need students including special education, ELL, and over-aged and under-credited students.  The project will provide full wraparound services including college coaching.  This expanded initiative to meet the needs of more Fall River students at risk of dropping out of high school will incorporate the Resiliency Preparation School approach to connectedness-building personalized education, flexibility, and parent involvement.   The project will expand the number of courses developed and professional development provided and increase the capability of the online learning environment to differentiate instruction for ELL and special education students; increase the flexible graduation pathways available to students most at risk of dropping out; increase wraparound services including a social worker and college coach; increase effective student use of the social networking components of the online coursework; and infuse the RPS personalization culture and strategies, including parent engagement, in more student pathways.  Essential outcomes are improved or increased student grades, attitudes toward school, course completion and high school graduation, and enrollment and retention in college.Special features include a hybrid online learning environment with competency-based courses with embedded supports for ELL, special education, and over-aged and under-credited students; RPS' six unique and flexible graduation pathways, personalization culture and strategies, and parent engagement; wraparound support services including social worker and college coach.?????"

Project Title: Going Beyond the Numbers: Using Data to Engage and Empower Parents
Project Description: "Project Title: Going Beyond the NumbersType of Grant: DevelopmentProject Description: Families In Schools (FIS) proposes to further develop and implement a promising set of practices for school staff and administrators in three high-needs school districts that focuses on engaging and empowering parents and families through the use of data. The initiative focuses on developing the capacities of educators to effectively capture the attention of parents and caregivers with data, demystify the sometimes complex data within the education system, explain the implications of student and school data on child development and learning, and help parents pursue higher expectations for their child and their schooling. The initiative will be piloted in schools in Lennox School District, Montebello Unified School District and Los Angeles Unified School District.Summary of Objectives: Objectives of the three-year development project include: (1) to develop tools to support school efforts on using data to engage parents; (2) to expand the knowledge of school/district staff in how to use data effectively to engage parents;(3) to enhance parent engagement and motivation to guide their children's education towards high achievement in college and career; and (4) to increase the ability of parents to support student learning, including school readiness, college awareness, and English Language Development.Students Served: 15,000 students of parents participating in the workshopsSpecial Project Features: The initiative will address three Competitive Preference Priorities: early learning (CPP 5), college and career readiness (CPP 6) and English-language learners (CPP 7). Applicant: Family, Career and Community Leaders of America, Inc.
Project Title: Careers through Culinary Arts Program with FCCLA and NRCCUA
Project Description: "Careers through Culinary Arts Program, FCCLA and NRCCUA Validation GrantProject Description and Activities:  The primary mission of this joint program for validation and enhancement is to bolster the effectiveness of teachers and administrators that are operating a hands-on program in schools with high need.  This program has seen tremendous local success in engaging students in career training and activities that instill a motivation to pursue higher education and ultimately a successful career.  Funding will go directly to increases in staff, infrastructure, evaluation and resources on the ground.  This grant will allow the educators and staff of the Family, Community and Career Leaders of America (FCCLA) to leverage their access to high-need students combined with the resources, knowledge and existing program success of C-CAP.  Together, they can engage the National Research Center for College and University Admissions (NRCCUA), a non-profit educational research organization, to track the longitudinal impact that this program has on participating students. Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes:  The project has three primary objectives.  The first objective is to leverage the complementary strengths of C-CAP and FCCLA to enhance the efficacy of the existing program.  This will put more resources, training and opportunities in the hands of more teachers and students impacted by the existing program.  The second objective is, through the collaboration of FCCLA, C-CAP and NRCCUA, to provide validation for the existing and enhanced program.  Through this validation, project participants will have the tools necessary to provide this and similar programs to more students on a wider scale.  Finally, this grant should lead to the launching of new program locations to validate existing successes in other environments.  This is a vital step in creating a roadmap for future growth and impact of teacher effectiveness/student success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Interactive Instruction: Educating with Edutainment
Project Description: "The goal of this Development Grant is for Farmington Public Schools to partner with Scientifically Proven, asoftware development company, and Grace & Wild, Inc., an entertainment studio company, in an effort to createa unique educational opportunity for students in grades 5-8.  The I2 system, Educating with Edutainment, will becreated for approximately 3,500 students using an interactive game system that will match each unit taught withina grade level. The modules within the gaming system will be aligned to the MI Grade Level ContentExpectations. The system will be designed to pretest each student on prior knowledge for each concept.  Eachgrade level system will also contain content from the previous and following grade levels.  This will ensure thatstudents are able to experience success. Additional skill practice will be provided for students that are strugglingwith mastery of a concept and opportunities to advance when threshold skills are mastered.  This will offer thestudent, parent, and teacher an opportunity to track the growth of each student with activities that focus not onlyon education but engaging interactive learning opportunities.The I2 system will: a) Increase the success of underrepresented student populations in academically rigorous courses and programs; b)Increase the development anduse of formative assessment or interim assessments, or other performance-based tools and metrics that are alignedwith high student content and academic achievement standards; c) Translate the standards and information fromassessments into classroom practices that meet the needs of all students, including high-need students.  I2 createsadditional opportunities for teachers to create their own lessons as well as develop their lesson plans with existingexercises available in the system. The basic reports will also supply an output for evaluation of performance.  Weare hopeful that by Educating with Edutainment we will be making a difference."

Project Title: Farmington High School Programs Expansion
Project Description: "We at Farmington High School are seeking a Validation grant to significantly improve student achievement by closing achievement gaps, decreasing dropout rates, increasing high school graduation rates, and increasing college enrollment rates.  We propose to do this by addressing Absolute Priority 3. We propose1.	   All middle school students-IEP's, 504's, free/reduced, minority-will come to us at the high school ready to tackle rigorous and relevant academics. We will address this by expanding our current reform program High Schools That Work to include Making Middle Grades Work.2.	Students at the high school and middle school will complete a rigorous course of academics including dual enrollment classes. We will address this by expanding our current model Advancement Via Individual Determination to grades 6, 7, 10, 11, and by expanding our dual enrollment 'College Now' program. 3.	All students-including those from area schools-will have access to our expanded career and technical courses [Project Lead the Way Pre-Engineering, Agriculture Sciences, Television/Media Production, and Health Occupations] We will address this by employing a  career counselor and expanding our Health occupations course offerings.Our measurable goals will be: 1. Reduce the failure rate in grade nine by ensuring middle grades students receive the preparation they need to succeed in rigorous ninth-grade college-preparatory coursework. 2. Increase to 90 percent the percentage of students who transition into grade nine and complete high school four years later. 3. Increase to 55% the number of students in our district who will have successfully completed at least one dual enrollment college course by graduation. 4. Provide career counseling to 100% of our students who will create a career plan. 5.  Increase the number of health occupations course offerings to meet a student and community need."

Project Title: Cluster Community Schools Parthenon Model -- The Federation for Community Schools
Project Description: "The Federation for Community Schools, in close collaboration with Columbia College and DePaul University's Center for Urban Education, is submitting an application to the Department of Education for an Investing in Innovation (i3) Fund Validation grant of $20 million over four years in Absolute Priority 4, Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools.  Innovations will include: the implementing of a highly refined community school infrastructure, which includes a baseline of programming to provide extensive supportive services and supplemental educational learning time to low-performing students, and the implementation of four program pillars (academics, health, family supports and community engagement); and clustering community schools within a neighborhood in order to align the community stakeholders and their resources around the success of their children and align community schools to support students from pre-K through high school graduation.The Federation for Community Schools proposes establishing ten total neighborhood (in large urban districts) or community (in rural and suburban communities) clusters.  Each cluster will include the local high school as well as middle or elementary schools that 'feed' into the high school.  By aligning the schools with the educational pathway of the students, i.e. attending school from Kindergarten through high school, as opposed to randomly choosing schools within a large district to become stand alone community schools, students and their families will be able to access academic and support services throughout their education and during all children's critical developmental stages and educational transitions such as into high school.Anticipated outcomes include improved student academic performance and achievement, increased parental engagement and leadership, and increased community support of and involvement with schools.?????"

Project Title: Student-Centered Education Model (SCEM)
Project Description: "The founders of Cedar River Academy (?CRA?) invested a significant amount of time and money to establish a private school to demonstrate the benefits of active, student-centered thematic education. They have achieved their initial objectives of defining a working educational model, using the products of brain and educational research. They operate a school that accepts all children as they are, builds upon their strengths and works to eliminate their weaknesses. Although the CRA student body includes ELL students (20%) and students with learning disabilities (20%), CRA students are academically advanced, happy, and excited to be in school. Their model of student-centered education is demonstrable, replicable and scalable. In 2009, CRA administered the Iowa Test of Basic Skills without preparation. The 3rd grade students ranked at the 93rd percentile, and the 5th grade students ranked at the 99th percentile of all benchmark public schools. This result demonstrates that active-learning is effective. A consortium of public school districts and CRA has been formed to operate the Student-Centered Education Model project to demonstrate and study the effects of a research-based, active-learning education model, compared to a parallel traditional education model. The project is expected to demonstrate replicable model schools that deliver very high graduation rates, produce highly prepared graduates who successfully complete universitystudies, and operate within existing public school budgets.  This project will allow public school districts to examine the results of an active-learning education model, collaboratively adjust curriculum, assessments, intervention plans, and professional development programs to improve their programs.CRA will be transformed into a model school to provide the Consortium open communications, Internet-based video monitoring, base-line definition configuration management, professional development, and project management services. Educator... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"

Project Title: Reading Ferst: The Foundation for Success
Project Description: "?Any child who does not or cannot read is a child at risk.? ? www.ferstfoundation.orgA home environment of literacy ? books available; parent and child reading together ? can be a strongerpredictor of academic achievement than family income. However: ?More than one-third of children startkindergarten without basic literacy skills, unprepared to learn. ?Only 45.9% of Georgia?s children ages 0-5 areread to daily. ?Only 35% of Georgia?s 4th grade students and only 29% of Georgia?s 8th grade students areproficient or better at reading. ?Of students who are poor readers in the 3rd grade, 75% will remain poorreaders in high school. Many will drop out. ?A high school diploma is the single most effective preventivestrategy against adult poverty. Yet, Georgia is one of five states with the highest dropout rate.Child-by-child, the Ferst Foundation for Childhood Literacy (FFCL) is eliminating a major reason why parentsdo not read to their young children ? the lack of quality, age-appropriate books in the home. Books from FFCLare delivered monthly by mail, at no charge to families, in the child?s critical early years (ages 0-5) ofdevelopment. Addressed to the child, these books become the child?s own and, through ownership, an object oflove and a source of joy. FFCL breaks the generational illiteracy chain in low-income families where parentsdo not have the reading skills, the knowledge nor the resources to provide high quality, engaging educationalmaterials for their children.Since 2000 ? reaching more than 94,000 children ? FFCL has produced a paradigm shift with impressive results:children ready to read, ready for school, ready to learn. An i3 Development Grant will enable FFCL to reachevery low-performing, low-income and rural county in Georgia, to demonstrate the effectiveness of FFCL?sorganizational model and to provide a systematic study of FFCL?s Imagination Library / Leap Into Booksprogram -- a high potential program showing very promising r"

Project Title: Early Elementary Science Partnership
Project Description: "Early elementary students' achievement in science, and teachers' capacity to deliver high-quality, inquiry-based intsruction is limited by many factors in Chicago Public Schools. To fill this gap, The Field Museum and Chicago Public Schools (CPS) Office of Science have partnered to develop the Early Elementary Science Partnership (E2SP), a professional development program focused on improving K-3rd grade educators' ability to effectively teach science.  Partners in this project include The Field Museum, Chicago Public Schools Office of Science, the Chicago Children's Museum, Lincoln Park Zoo, Peggy Notebaert Nature Museum, and Northwestern University. The program evaluator is the Center for Elementary Mathematics and Science Education from the University of Chicago. The goals of the program are to 1) Improve early elementary teachers' understanding and ability to teach science through inquiry; 2) Improve elementary students' understanding and ability to do science through inquiry; 3) Strengthen early elementary teachers' ability to use museums/zoos to teach science; 4) Develop elementary teacher leaders in science; 5) Demonstrate an effective, collaborative partnership using informal and formal education resources. The project design includes: 1) Professional development at partnering institutions that enriches the endorsed science curricula for K-3 teachers; 2) University-based coursework in science content, pedagogy,  and inquiry-based methods for Teacher Leaders; 3) Teacher collaboration in vertical (K-3) and horizontal (grade-alike) teams; 4) Focused field trips for participating E2SP schools at partnering informal science and 5) Instructional support in K-3 classrooms and museums during focused field trips. The primary outcomes are improved teacher ability to teach inquiry-based science and increased student achievement in science in early elementary grades.????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: Florence Prever Rosten Foundation for the Media Arts
Project Title: MAPS Media Institute
Project Description: "The MAPS Media Institute is a highly innovative program that has been introduced on a limited basis in rural Ravalli County, Montana and with the assistance of the Investing in Innovation grant will expand to a during-the-school-day program that includes students from three local Title I high schools. The MAPS Media Institute's (MAPS) mission is to inspire, educate, train and create quality jobs in the media arts for students living in highly rural Western Montana. This will be done through a unique partnership between the Florence Prever Rosten Foundation for the Media Arts, a 501 (c)(3), and the local Licensed Education Agency (LEA). The project will engage at-risk, underserved rural youth by providing opportunities that combine education and business experience. To date, the results have been very positive academic, behavioral and economic outcomes. For example, MAPS student products have brought in nearly $200,000 in professional fees since 2005 and just four out of 200 MAPS students have dropped out of school. In 2008, Ravalli County had a per capita personal income of $29,743, which ranked it 37th out of the 56 counties in the state. This per capita income represented just 86 percent of the state average and 74 percent of the national average.  The low per capita income and the high unemployment rates translate into high poverty rates within the three schools targeted for assistance: Corvallis, Hamilton and Victor high schools. In 2008, the most recent year available, 42 percent of Corvallis, 33 percent of Hamilton and 58 percent of Victor high school students were eligible for Free or Reduced Lunch.  Of the 1,122 students enrolled in the three high schools, 439 were enrolled in the Free or Reduced Lunch program. All three high schools have Title I Targeted Assistance status. Of the three schools, only Victor High School made Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP). Both Corvallis and Hamilton high schools were in their first year identified for improvement under NCLB."

Project Title: TEACH with CLASSS
Project Description: "We are proposing to teach every child, every day, in every subject at a challenging level which will lead to student academic success through college and career, by coupling master teachers, a rigorous, aligned curriculum, real time data, and a unique form of differentiated instruction to sculpt instruction to teach each student in their zone of proximal development.  In order to make this a reality, the use of a variety of instructional technology is a must.  As our teachers integrate technology with our unique model of differentiated instruction and students succeed, Florence Unified School District will increase our high school graduation rate to 97%, with 97% of all students growing academically by at least one year, every year. This project has been attempted on a limited scale with three different demographic groups with outstanding results.  We propose to bring this to seven elementary schools (kindergarten through eighth grade) and two high schools (ninth through twelfth grade) which will allow us to serve approximately 8000 students across the district."

These schools encompass two school feeder patterns (Homestead and South Dade) in this area ? a feeder pattern consists of the elementary, middle and high schools within a given enrollment boundary. This area has one of the highest levels of underrepresented, underserved and low income populations in the state. This proposal has been named the MASTER EDUCATORS Program to give it a unique identifier to provide focus and a better understanding on the proposed transformation of the instructional staff. Project Title: The Elementary Lesson Study Mathematics Model Project  - ELSM
Project Description: "ELSM2 is a partnership bringing together Florida International University (FIU), Miami's public research university and one of the largest producers of Hispanic college graduates in the nation, and Miami-Dade County Public Schools (M-DCPS), the 4th largest school district in the U.S., to develop an innovative program for elementary school teachers within the I3 Development Grant category. ELSM2 meets Absolute Priority 1-Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Competitive Preference Priority 5-Innovations for Improving Early Learning Outcomes and Priority 7--Innovations to Address the Unique Learning Needs of Students with Disabilities and Limited English Proficient Student. ELSM2 consists of two tiers, one for grades 3-5 teachers and another for grades K-3 teachers, designed to enhance the professional development and retention of highly effective elementary school teachers through an innovative project that brings together mathematics focused coursework, video-supported lesson study, and connection of classroom practices with diverse student learning, including LEP students and students with disabilities. Tier one for 25 grades 3-5 teachers is a Master of Science (36 credits) with a focus on mathematics, classroom practice and student learning. Tier two for 60 grades K-3 teachers is an intensive study program also focused on mathematics, classroom practice and student learning for which the teachers will receive an Elementary Mathematics Education Mentor Teacher Certificate.  ELSM2 teachers will develop their mathematics knowledge and classroom practices, successfully impact their students' learning and achievement in mathematics, and contribute to building capacity that can support continued growth in mathematics teaching of district teachers within their schools and classrooms, as well as mentor FIU prospective elementary school teachers in field experiences."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: The ABC's of the Tier 1,2,3's
Project Description: "The Florida Learning AllianceThe ABC?s of the (Tier) 1,2,3?sThis project provides the means to eliminate student deficiencies in mathematics by providing rural elementary school teachers with the knowledge of research-based instructional strategies, as well as progress monitoring tools to ensure that students receive the best possible foundation in mathematics. The overall goal of the project is to enable these teachers to provide high quality evidence based instruction and intervention, and to effectively utilize student learning data to make critical educational decisions on daily basis ? to implement a successful Response to Intervention program.The ABC?s of the 1,2,3?s is based upon the highly effective AMSTI model which has been successfully adapted by a consortium of schools in Florida. Student gains in mathematics have been achieved in districts which have adopted the program.This project provides teacher with intensive professional development designed to improve content knowledge, increase understanding of the Florida Next Generation Math Standards, incorporate evidence based instructional strategies, and make data-driven decisions within an RtI framework. Teachers will be able to evaluate the effectiveness of the core curriculum, measure and analyze student achievement, and apply appropriate interventions in order to ensure continuous improvement in mathematics.In addition to providing training for teachers and school principals, the project will be developing a comprehensive website that serves as a repository for best practices and RtI strategies. These resources include videos, lesson plans, probes for progress monitoring and tools to allow teachers to collaborate with their peers throughout the state."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Hybrid Virtual Solution to Turnaround Schools
Project Description: "The Hybrid Virtual Solution to Turnaround Schools project focuses on whole-school reform by providing a comprehensive intervention to school turnaround. Through this project, Florida Virtual School will partner with three turnaround schools: two K-8 elementary schools and one high school to implement a hybrid school model which applies methods that have been proven to be effective for virtual education, combined with the social, emotional, and instructional benefits of a traditional school. The project will create an innovative alternative to the traditional school turnaround approach by synthesizing virtual curriculum and assessment with proven on-site turnaround instructional and administrative methods. The project seeks to turnaround three participating schools in the bottom 5% of their state within three years and serve 3,000 students. Other Partners include: Alvarez & Marsal, Connections Academy, Wireless Generation and the Friday Institute for Educational Innovation."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Expand FLVS Nationwide
Project Description: "The Expand FLVS Nationwide project extends the demonstrated success of Florida Virtual School (FLVS) in improving student achievement and college readiness by providing three high-need US rural school districts with a field-tested, standards-based curriculum of online courses in core, world language, elective, honors, and Advanced Placement (AP) subject areas, and the rigorous virtual professional development and leadership training required to implement this curriculum. The overarching goal of the Expand FLVS Nationwide project is to increase student achievement and improve college readiness within high-need rural school districts and the unique student populations they serve through the implementation of FLVS?s innovative models of online curriculum and virtual professional development and leadership training."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Algebra Expedition - A Game Approach to the Mastery of Algebra
Project Description: "The Algebra Expedition ? A Gaming Approach to the Mastery of Algebra will result in the development of high quality Algebra I and II educational games to be infused into existing FLVS courses, as well as serve as standalone supplemental learning activities for students across America, in both virtual and traditional classrooms. Designed to meet Florida Next Generation Sunshine State Standards, which are in alignment with forthcoming national common core standards, the games will increase student achievement by increasing engagement and providing any pace and any path learning. Florida Virtual School intends to expand upon the success of our first educational game, Conspiracy Code, which teaches a full semester of American History through a fully immersive and interactive game. This proposal will result in smaller games that can be infused into individual modules within our courses, allowing for greater flexibility, while still maintaining the appeal of a cutting-edge learning technology. Using this component approach also allows us to sell the product to markets outside of FLVS as a key element of our sustainability plan.Algebra I and II was specifically selected as the targeted courses based on the relationship between success in these topics and college access. We believe that increasing student achievement in algebra will result in increased college access and long term academic success. Our proposal will result in a product designed to appeal to all types of learners, and raise success in algebra across the United States."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Floyd County Professional Learning Academy
Project Description: "Floyd County Schools (LEA) in Floyd County, Kentucky submits a development grant application to proposes the development of the Floyd County Professional Learning Academy in the district for the purpose of improving student achievement by identifying, recruiting, developing, placing, rewarding, and retaining highly effective teachers and principals.  An exemplar model of one such academy exists in the urban Kentucky district of Jefferson County- the Jefferson County Public School Gheens Professional Development Academy.  The systemic approach of the Gheens Academy to improving teaching and its impact on student achievement has great potential for continued research and provide an infrastructure that works well in the midst of reform and transition - An infrastructure and support system that could serve Floyd County well in the face of upcoming transition to the national common core standards and the retooling of our state's assessment system.
