It is our working hypothesis that the framework of the JCPS Gheens Professional Development Academy and its models of building capacity with homegrown innovation would meet with great success in our smaller rural district impacting over 500 teachers and administrators and 6,100 students.The PL Academy will accomplish this multifaceted goal by:  (1) providing leadership and a central hub for professional growth, planning and idea exchange, (2) increasing teachers' and instructional leaders' capacity to bridge student achievement data, individual professional growth plans, and district professional development activities, (3) enabling educators to acquire and apply knowledge, understanding, skills and abilities to facilitate the achievement of students and (4) increasing the level of instructional support to educators at all levels (aspiring, new, experienced, in leadership, etc).  "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
The Virtual Microscope Lab Project: Computer-based Advanced Microscopy for
Student Achievement in Low-Performing High School Science Classes
Project Description: "Imagine manipulating research-quality specimens with magnifications up to 86,000x using a standard, internet connected computer. Originally developed for research at NASA, then usability tested and adapted for classroom use, the Virtual Microscope lets students see and do science in innovative and exciting ways, through the lens of virtual microscope technology (in a manner identical to research scientists). This project will upgrade the Virtual Microscope software and corresponding instructional resources, making it even more accessible for teachers to incorporate this internet based tool into the classroom. This enhanced resource will be used to assist and motivate the learning of biology, chemistry, earth science, and physics in low performing secondary school science classrooms.Summary of Objectives: Provide high-school science teachers and students unlimited access to an enhanced version of the Virtual Microscope Lab and instructional resources that support teaching and learning. The project will change how students experience the scientific world in ways that:? Enhance science teachers? ability to teach challenging scientific concepts? Motivate and engage underrepresented secondary students in the study of science? Stimulate greater student inquiry and exploratory learning in science? Make science learning contemporary using mobile devices and instructional technology? Enable students to better visualize abstract content and help improve learningTarget Numbers: Teachers: 300; Students: 36,000; Others: Nationwide impact via open educational resource science textbook publishers and online availability of Virtual Microscope Lab and supporting instructional resources. Special Features: Leverage and enhance the existing library of specimens and make them more available. Coordinate content with textbooks to target project?s deliverables with state standard curriculum. Provide free, online access to all resources for teachers and students nationwide."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Forbes Road Career and Technology Center
Project Title: This program is for economically and educationally disadvantages students who have began their technical education, but need to complete competencies to receive industry certification, employability skills and/or become a program completer.
EngageME P.L.E.A.S.E.
Project Description: "Project Title: EngageME -P.L.E.A.S.E. (Personalized Learning Experiences Accelerate Standards-based Education)			    Goals for this i3 project include: 1) increase student achievement and student growth as evidenced by reduction in numbers of high need students in subgroups and in total, 2) increase graduation rate in subgroups and in total, and 3) increase graduation rate for high need students, students in subgroups, and in total.  EngageME will address Absolute Priority 2:  Innovations that Improve the Use of Data and will integrate several systems into one data system to combine a Role-based Portal so students and teachers have access to all necessary resources to reflect on student learning and teacher instruction and design a personalized Learner Plan, which includes the student's longitudinal and immediate feedback data from prior courses, learning preferences, and intervention successes.  Teachers will prescribe for the student content and assessments based on standards, which will be delivered to the student.  The Assessment Engine will report on, and evidentially select options, to determine the student's mastery of standards.     Target number of students to be served in the project:  34,500 students in 35 schools   Special project features: This system will initially rely upon teachers to select learning activities from a repository (Learning Marketplace) based on data about the student to assist preparation of the student Personalized Learner Plan. To enhance replication, this Learning Marketplace will use Common Core Standards and the McRel Standards Compendium as the basis for alignment, automatically finding the Common Core State Standards in mathematics and English language arts aligned to the Georgia course taught by the teacher and pre-filtering the learning activities to a useful subset.     Project Partners:  FCS, Infinite Campus, and University of Georgia (evaluation)??"

Project Title: MATH SMARTS:  Making A Transformation Happen through Superior Math Achievement and       Revolutionary Technology Solutions
Project Description: "The MATH SMARTS project will test a blended model consisting of two intertwined components: (1) one-to-one computing with virtualized learner response systems to deliver a completely digital math curriculum, and (2) interactive whiteboard technologies and creativity software to support face-to-face instruction.  These components will work in tandem to provide an enriched level of student performance data. This study will use a quasi-experimental design comparing math achievement of students utilizing the prescribed intervention to students in control schools, identified based on very specific criteria, without access to the intervention.  The non-equivalent control group will be matched based on key demographic characteristics, such as ethnicity, poverty, and student English proficiency as well as achievement results in mathematics, school size and the type of technology equipment and digital resources available. There are other partners involved in the project.  Because the digital curriculum, technologies and web-based resources all require seamless integration, vendors are working together to develop a single plan for installation, professional development and continuous support. The four vendor partners are: The Center for Digital Innovation (McGraw-Hill Education) - CDI is responsible for the fully digital math curriculum, CINCH Mathematics, grades K-6 and the convertible PC's based on the Intel Learning Series that will give students access to a computer during the instructional day, and to the technology, lessons and even a network of peers after hours; Promethean  - will provide the virtualized learner response systems (ActivEngage) through which the curriculum will be delivered; Intel - will provide professional development around the Intel-powered convertible classmate PCs and ethnographic research; and Tech4Learning.com - will provide project-based learning (PBL) tools for additional assessment opportunities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: A Systems Approach for Data Analysis
Project Description: "FBISD's grant proposal addresses Absolute Priority 2. FBISD began to establish Data Teams at the classroomlevel during the 2007-08 school year, and specific experience and data in FBISD exist to establish that theData Team process is related to improved achievement for high-need students. This proposed project serves69,000 students, extends the existing data-driven foundation to all levels of the organization, focusesspecifically on the leader?s use of data, and creates a systemic, tiered approach to instructional decisionmaking. The project consists of three main activities: (1) systematic implementation of a specific five-step dataanalysis process at all levels of leadership in the organization, (2) research and development of a uniqueLearning, Teaching and Leadership Model that is real-time, adaptable, and multivariate and links teaching andleadership decisions to student results, and (3) an independent evaluation.The project goals are to develop system-wide capacity to use data to inform instructional decisions that lead toincreased student achievement, and to increase understanding of the teacher and leader actions that impactstudent results. Objectives are: (1) implementing effective Data Teams at all levels of leadership in theorganization, (2) promoting and sustaining the effective use of data to inform instructional decisions andstrategies, (3) creating quality assessments as a resource for data analysis, and (4) researching and developingan innovative Learning, Teaching and Leadership Model that is replicable by other school districts. Expectedoutcomes include increased student achievement, reduced achievement gaps, and improved leadership capacityin using data to make instructional decisions. Special features include development of a sustainable, researchbasedmodel, and systemic implementation of a collaborative, specific data analysis process for instructionaldecision making."

Applicant: Fort Payne City Board of Education
Project Title: Learning With Laptops
Project Description: "Brief Project Description including Project Activities:The Fort Payne City Board of Education proposes purchasing, installing and implementing the inclusion of a laptop cart with 30 computers, a wireless access point and a networked printer for each classroom in Grades 4-12.  This implementation would include providing adequate Professional Development to all teachers involved.  The project would also include the employment of 2 technology assistants for the entirety of the grant period (5 years).  The total students involved would be 2,154 with 570 of those students being Hispanic.  Summary of Project Objectives and Expected OutcomesWriting scores for all students in grades 5, 7 and 10 (Alabama Direct Assessment of Writing) will show a 10% gain over the course of the Learning with Laptops project.  Baseline data will be gathered for the current school year and compared with the 5 year period of the grant project.    Writing scores for Limited English Proficient students in grades 5, 7 and 10 (Alabama Direct Assessment of Writing) will show a 20% gain over the course of the Learning with Laptops project.  Discipline referrals will decrease system-wide by 10% during the grant period.Target Number of Students to be served in the ProjectThe total students involved would be 2,154 with 570 of those students being Limited English Proficient.  List of Official and Other PartnersThe City of Fort Payne will be our Official Partner in this initiative.?????"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: PRIME
Project Description: "The Fort Worth Independent School District (FWISD) proposes a five-year plan to increase college and careerreadiness and awareness district-wide by implementing a research-based comprehensive plan to create acollege and career ready culture among FWISD students and their parents by instituting Gold Seal Programs ofChoice, Student Support Teams, College & Career Camps, Trips, and Fairs, Bridges Transitions, and My Ten-Year Plan, College and Career Readiness curriculum, internships, and parent involvement.As the largest public school district in Tarrant County, with a student population of nearly 80,000 in grades pre-kindergartenthrough 12, it is among the fastest-growing public school district in the nation. FWISD has a highpoverty rate, with 72.3% of students eligible for free or reduced-price meals.College and career readiness is the product of a process that begins in elementary school and extends throughhigh school. (ACT?) Top administrators from FWISD?s Student Support Services and Elementary andSecondary Leadership divisions conducted a gap analysis of all district college and career initiatives anddetermined that the proposed activities, positions, and initiatives were the best way to increase districtperformance in these areas.With the support of partners, Tarrant County College District, Tarrant County United Way, The Fort WorthChamber of Commerce, REgion XI Educational Service Center, Workforce Solutions for Tarrant County, andthe Jobing Foundation, FWISD will make postsecondary success and attainable goal for each of its nearly80,000 students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Literacy in Transition (LiT)
Project Description: "Literacy in Transition: A Development Grant Proposal for Fostoria Community SchoolsThe center point for this grant is Literacy, which for our purposes encompasses reading, writing, and critical thinking (NCTE, 2005). This relationship is important, because too often programs that call themselves literacy programs are simply reading programs; it is this disconnect between reading and writing programs that we hope to address in this initiative, Literacy in Transition. The goal of this project is to bring into alignment various successful but disparate reading and writing assessment and intervention strategies being implemented in early childhood, middle childhood, and the secondary level-with the goal of strengthening students' reading, writing, and critical thinking skills across these transition points to empower them toward success, not only on state achievement tests, but into post-secondary opportunities and beyond. To accomplish this goal, LiT seeks to develop a consistent and comprehensive literacy program that addresses issues of transitions, by providing extensive professional development for faculty and administration, establishing support systems for students and families to prepare for post-secondary opportunities, and engaging community partnerships, with the goal of impacting all 1900 students in the district. LiT strengthens and aligns the already existing partnership being developed between Fostoria Community Schools and the Bowling Green State University College of Education and Human Development.Drawing from our experiences in literacy development (Gere & Shaheen, 2001; Murnen, T., & Rex, L., 2007) and urban school reform projects such as GEARUP (Kretovics, Farber, & Armaline, 1991), LiT addresses the following objectives: 1) Build on current but disconnected literacy tools to bring elements of the reading program more in line with each other, to scaffold the transitions for less able students; 2) Find, develop, and/or implement a reading assessme"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Virtual Teaching for the Visually Impaired
Project Description: "This request proposes a new service model to significantly expand the service delivery options and significantly lessen the constraints for students with a visual impairment by creating a supplemental service that overcomes the restrictions to equal access inherent in the current itinerant model. This new service model will allow students to be in contact with their TVIs virtually while remaining in the classroom environment and will also provide the students with rapid access to adapted classroom materials. These services will be provided on an as-needed basis; the need will be determined and the contact initiated, to the greatest extent appropriate, by students. The result will be increased access to resources in addition to improved timeliness, quality and variety of services. Previous experience with a small pilot has demonstrated the feasibility of this model.The implementation of this distance-education model will be made possible via wireless and web-based communications technologies. The teachers of the visually impaired will be able to communicate with students discretely via text and voice chat to answer questions. TVIs will be able to view the materials students are accessing on their computers and thus assist them in interpreting these materials. The TVIs will be able to view what is on the board or what is being projected in the classroom and then communicate this information to students who are visually impaired. Such support will supplement what is being said by classroom teachers and will give the visually impaired students access to the same materials as the sighted students.  Without leaving the classroom, students will be able to send images of print materials to the TVIs for adaptation and have them returned in an accessible electronic form. Elements of the classroom experience that were formerly inaccessible to visually impaired students will now be accessible in real time, in all districts, rural as well as urban."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Leveraging the Early Assessment Program for College
Project Description: "The Foundation for California Community Colleges, in collaboration the Long Beach, Shasta, and San Joaquin Delta consortia of high schools, community colleges, and state universities, propose the Leveraging the Early Assessment Program (LEAP) for College program to increase high need student access to and preparation for college. LEAP will: help students gain an understanding of college expectations and requirements, develop personalized plans for becoming college ready, provide students with an ?early signal? of their readiness for college through the Early Assessment Program (EAP), and provide academic interventions in math and English to address any gaps in learning before and after taking the EAP for students not yet demonstrating college readiness on the test.The program?s key strategies complement the implementation of California?s EAP, an augmented 11th grade California Standards Test developed to provide students with an ?early signal? of their readiness for college. These strategies include providing 9-12th grade students with information about college expectations, requirements, and options for financial aid; developing personalized college-readiness plans that include taking the EAP in the 11th grade; offering online education modules, workshops, and tutoring to supplement high school instruction & to support students? preparation for college; convening local inter-segmental teams to discuss curriculum, teaching practices & instructional materials to improve the alignment between high schools and colleges; and providing professional development for teachers using Expository Reading & Writing and Strengthening Mathematics Instruction programs. Program activities will serve over 40,000 students over a three year period at eleven high schools that have a significant population of high need student groups. The pilot also targets three rural high schools with specific activities developed to address distance barriers that inhibit student access to college."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Implementing Professional Learning Communities to Enhance Instructional Capacity and Increase Student Learning
Project Description: "Chicago Area 2 Schools participated in the Reading First grant which is concluding in June 2010.  The district has implemented standards-based, research-supported curricular programs and practices in grades K-3 as outlined in the schema of the federal Reading First program.  With the grant coming to an end, Area 2 Schools are committed to the continuation of the practices that have been implemented.  Due to the positive impact these practices have had on teacher performance and student achievement, the district aims to sustain and enhance professional development, data-informed decision making, and curricular design in grades four through six.  The i3 grant would afford Chicago Area 2 schools the ability to implement the following:Professional Learning Communities;  extend the instructional coaching program , expand  use of curriculum-based measurements in literacy and math;  develop a system of multiple measures that includes formative assessment;  enhance integration of technology;  implement differentiated instruction to meet the needs of all learners; (specifically special populations including ELLs); and design, implement, and evaluate a professional development plan that directly reflects the needs of Area 2, including coaching and mentoring as a means to deliver job-embedded professional learning experiences.Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes:The overall objective of this project is to increase student learning, (as evidenced by a compilation of student performance data). This improved learning is to be achieved through the enhancement of teacher effectiveness (as evidenced by various forms of data) via the implementation of empirically-based  research  practices.  Administrators and teachers will work collaboratively to provide a student-centered, positive working and learning environment that focuses on action-oriented results.  "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The CLASS Project
Project Description: "The Chalkboard Project, the National Commission on Teaching and America's Future (NCTAF), and eleven Oregon LEAs (Forest Grove, Sherwood, Tillamook, Bend-La Pine, Lebanon, Redmond, High Desert, Crook County, Oregon City, Sisters, and Vernonia), seek $4.7 million in i3 Development grant support for the CLASS Project (Creative Leadership Achieves Student Success). CLASS integrates five research-based objectives through a collaborative design process that is teacher-led, locally-driven, and district-wide, increasing the number of highly effective teachers educating 59,946 students in 101 schools with an innovative, sustainable approach for identifying, recruiting, developing, placing, evaluating, rewarding and retaining highly effective teachers, especially for high-need students in rural schools.The project hypothesizes that it is the integration of research-based teacher effectiveness strategies into an innovative human capital framework that increases the number of effective teachers and raises student achievement. Objectives: 1. Implement rigorous, transparent and fair performance evaluation systems that differentiate quality using multiple categories and utilize multiple measures of effectiveness with student growth data as a significant factor. 2. Implement compensation systems that use evidence of student achievement growth as a significant factor. 3. Implement career paths that expand teacher leader roles and responsibilities. 4. Implement comprehensive professional development systems that support job-embedded professional learning linked to student achievement and performance evaluation systems. 5. Implement policies and procedures equitably distributing highly effective teachers, focusing on high need students in rural schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Founding Fathers Academies Inc. dba Jefferson Academy
Project Title: Connecting the dots with more than just lines
Project Description: "With the objective of teaching, both typical and neurologically impaired, students within a full-inclusion multi-age classroom where prospective teachers are being trained by master teachers, on a daily basis, to deliver instruction through a variety of learning experiences that accommodates an Individualized learning plan for each student.  The Classroom will be supported by Social services delivering services to ensure: 1. student success at school and at home, 2. Staff and Parental involvement in student success, and 3. Staff in academic and personal lives."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Four Corners School of Outdoor Education
Project Title: Place-Based Education in STEM Learning and Teaching
Project Description: "Four Corners School of Outdoor Education (FCS) seeks $2,822,502 over 5 years from the Investing in Innovation Fund for its 1) Title Place-Based Education in STEM Learning and Teaching (PBESLT) project 2) Type PBESLT will be a Development project to build a model for Creating Effective Teachers that Serve Rural Schools 3) Project Description/Activities is an evidence-based, research-infused project to develop and test a K-8 teacher professional development model that integrates theories and methods of place-based education (PBE) and the framework of Earth System Science. PBESLT will leverage an existing FCS teacher professional development program that integrates PBE instructional strategies into science and math in rural/multi-cultural schools on the Colorado Plateau (S. UT, N. AZ, NW NM, SW CO). Place-based education is especially meaningful and culturally relevant to students and teachers in our study area that includes four Native American nations and is homeland of a large underserved minority-majority student population, as it situates teaching and learning in local environments and communities. Place-based education is strongly advocated as an effective means of engaging diverse and minority students, and retaining their interest in science and other academic subjects The accessibility of and trans-disciplinary pedagogical richness of local places offer a cost-effective alternative to traditional learning methods and environments. PBESLT will demonstrate this and offer ideas and templates to a wide variety of underserved rural schools with Native American student/teacher populations in other regions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovate, Validate, Accelerate: Redesigning Literacy Instruction Through Structured Data Analysis, High Quality Curriculum, and Technology Integration
Project Description: "This grant is written to investigate the correlations that may exist between comprehensive data analyses and improved student achievement in reading and writing. Through a structured, ongoing data analysis program designed around a literacy- focused prekindergarten program, a reading program based upon higher order thinking skills and content-focused leveled reading materials, and an interactive web-based technology program, we will investigate possible correlations to improved achievement in reading and writing for students.Correlations of higher achievement will be determined by student assessment data from the ISAT (Illinois Standards Achievement Tests) and NWEA MAP (Measure of Academic Progress) pre and post intervention implementation. The key project priority is to determine whether consistent analysis of data by teacher teams has a correlation to changing instructional techniques in the classroom and improved student achievement in reading and writing. Project objectives include pre-k program expansion to meet the needs of a 41% low-income community, implementation of a comprehensive literacy curriculum at grades K-8, implementation of a web based performance writing system, and implementation of an interactive web tools program to engage learners. 	1000 students will be served through this project.The Project Team is composed of school administrators, teachers, parents, and community stakeholders."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Franklin School Fun with Phonograms Grant
Project Description: "The applicant proposes a system for providing explicit phonics-instruction to emergent readers with the intention of developing early reading and decoding skills that will benefit them through all of their years of schooling and into life. It is the purpose of this grant to expand a phonetic reading method that has been proven to be successful to the local, state, and even national levels."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Frazier Digital Academy
Project Description: "The Frazier Digital Academy (FDA) Project is designed to provide an appropriate, relevant, and rigorous education to at-risk and high need students using a digital on-line platform. It will provide support using highly qualified facilatators to monitor, modify, individualize and evaluate student progress. Students will be given the opportunity to complete their education in a non-traditional setting and can be supported by using district educators when needed. The FDA will allow these students to obtain a Frazier diploma when they successfully complete their course work."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: i3 Inventing in Innovation Validation grant for Freeport High School and Dodd Middle School SCALE science classrooms
Project Description: "Freeport School District's Investing in Innovation i3 grant is a restructuring, research-based, and technology-infused implementation project, with the goals to improve Freeport High School and John W. Dodd's science teachers' access to technology and enhance STEM instructional strategies in science classrooms. The intended outcome is improved science knowledge, conceptual understanding, skills and student academic achievement in STEM.  	     The i3 program will support the district's sole high school, Freeport High School, State designated as Restructuring Advanced Year I for ELA, and an i3 grant Absolute Priority 4 school. It will also  support the sole middle school, John W. Dodd, which was removed from the list of Restructuring Schools just a year ago.  The program supports the acquisition of SCALE classrooms, equipped with critically needed technology materials and professional development designed to support teachers in using technologies efficiently. Professional development includes support from Nassau BOCES Model Schools, self paced Intel on-line courses to guide curriculum development, and classroom embedded on site visitations from SUNY Old Westbury science consultants/faculty. As a result of new technology access, science teachers will be empowered by knowledge and confidence in using the resources and will collaborate on exciting interactive curriculum projects. Over the five year project, more than 4,000 students will: receive a high quality integrated science education, during the school day, after school, in the summer, in authentic research settings; equipping them with technology skills, enabling them to fully participate in interactive learning, realize and achieve their potential, and become STEM savvy. Students will be more than adequately prepared to participate in AP science classes and college level courses through the district's Early College High School program.  SUNY Old Westbury STEP (Science and Technology Entry Program) Director"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: "Helping Hands" Science, Math, Technology, and Service Learning: Innovations in Teacher and Principal Training (pre K-12)
Project Description: "Fremont Unified School District (FUSD) and Math Science Nucleus (MSN) in conjunctionwith the City of Fremont (COF) are working to provide all children access to quality handsonscience and math. Teacher and principal ongoing professional development throughfield trips for students in the Fremont Learning Corridor and continued modeling, mentoring,and coaching in the classroom with hands-on materials are important to this proposal.Packaging materials and testing dissemination in rural areas in Madera County, Californiaand North Carolina will be tested the first two years. The second phase will increasecapacity in the San Francisco Bay area with a renovated Science Learning Center andmarketing strategies that would allow low income schools throughout the country to learnthe modeling and coaching techniques that increases a schools overall standardized testscores in 3-5 years.The Corridor is a 3 mile long region within Fremont that has features created by theHayward Fault including 2 lakes and a network of creeks that feed into the San FranciscoBay. This area is also the location of the Irvingtonian Fossils (a district in Fremont) whichdefines the beginning of the Ice Age in North America. This Corridor already serves over amillion visitors, and includes free or low cost school STEM activities to over 15,000 childrenper year. FUSD,MSN, and COF already have more demand than the current facilities canaccommodate.This proposal supports and expands several programs that have been jointly developedand internally tested over the last 25 years to make Fremont Unified School District a highperformance school district, although the students are very diverse ethnically, and socioeconomically.FUSD has continually improved the course of its teacher training to insuresuccess for all children. FUSD targets the schools with influx of low-income families togive all students equal access. The community is now urban with close to
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Early and Expanded Learning Agenda
Project Description: "The Early and Expanded Learning Agenda unites families, communities, schools, LEAs, expert technicalassistance providers, and key private sector and philanthropic institutions in a bold innovation that integratesstrong school day reforms and expanded learning resources (including after school, summer, and preschool).The Learning Agenda expands the time available for students to learn core academic content, especiallyliteracy and language arts, and enhances the support and instruction students receive both during and outside ofthe school day. Rooted in moderate evidence, the Learning Agenda enables persistently low-performingschools to meaningfully respond to the key learning challenges facing high-need students. Moderate evidencefurther indicates that the systematic integration of these proposed strategies multiplies the impact that any oneof them would have on their own.Supporting systems strategies (use of data, professional development, leadership support) will promote schoolturnaround and create the basis for scaling and disseminating the Early and Expanded Learning Agenda. TheLearning Agenda will turn persistently low-performing schools around so that: By grade 3, and continuingforward, all students score at proficient or above in English/Language Arts on the California Standards Test.The Learning Agenda will achieve the following key objectives: 1) All schools implement an evidence-basedreading/literacy strategy that is aligned and integrated throughout all programs; 2) All students reading belowgrade level have reading success plans which provide individualized instruction and support across allprograms; 3) All schools articulate with preschools and increase capacity to offer high-quality programming;4) All schools substantially increase learning time by ensuring that after school and summer programs gain thecapacity to serve students reading below grade level; and 5) All schools restructure by integrating out-ofschooltime resources."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Promise of College Readiness for All: The Expository Reading and Writing Course
Project Description: "The Promise of College Readiness for All: The Expository Reading and Writing Course is a four-year Investing in Innovation Development Grant led by the Fresno County Office of Education. The Expository Reading and Writing Course (ERWC), developed by the California State University (CSU) in partnership with California high schools, districts, and county offices of education, is an innovative college-preparatory English course that builds students' academic literacy skills while helping them forge new identities as literate individuals who can navigate the academic demands of high school and college. The course was designed in response to the need to reduce remediation in college. The Intersegmental Committee of the Academic Senates states in Academic Literacy that 'fundamental changes in pedagogy, advances in technology, and new emphases on critical reading, writing, and thinking across the curriculum' require educators to approach college preparation in academic literacy in new and creative ways in the 21st century (2002, p. 8). 	The grant will further develop and expand the CSU's Expository Reading and Writing Course and determine its effectiveness in preparing high school students for college success. The project will build on and increase the existing and ongoing statewide infrastructure for ERWC professional development led by the California County Superintendents Educational Services Association and the CSU. Grant activities will further develop the course by improving or creating new features of the curriculum, assessment, professional learning, and outreach and expanding high school course adoptions statewide. Course implementation and longitudinal student outcomes will be rigorously evaluated to determine the efficacy of the innovation in preparing students for success in college using a regression-discontinuity analysis in a quasi-experimental evaluation design.?????"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Turnaround Excellence Network
Project Description: "Friendship Public Charter School (Friendship) is the Washington DC area's largest public charter school, serving 6000 preK-12 students on nine campuses, including two in Baltimore. Since its inception in 1997, Friendship has enabled thousands of low-income students to become real achievers. Friendship applies its unique educational model with winning results to improve academic performance, educate the 'whole child,' offer families wrap-around social services, and direct students to college and to a solid, rewarding future. Its approach to serving students includes12% from special needs populations. Friendship proposes establishing a Turnaround Excellence Network, which will provide administrators and teachers in turnaround schools with the knowledge, skills and tools to lead an effective school turnaround. The Turnaround Excellent Network rests on two hypotheses: 1) turnarounds demand trained and experienced administrators and teachers (human capital) and 2) data must drive decision making. Both are based on Friendship?s best practices and 12 year history of transforming low performing schools into institutions of academic excellence."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Fulton Institute of Technology
Project Description: "Georgia?s Fulton County Schools (FCS) has developed an innovative technical high school initiative that integrates science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) curricula in a career academy model. We call it the Fulton Institute of Technology (FIT). FIT is an open-enrollment high school campus model focused on career and college readiness, especially among underserved students. Key program elements include: fusing practical and virtual learning in a technology-rich environment; career pathways offering hands-on learning experiences; dual-enrollment opportunities; preparation to take industry certification exams; professional development for faculty; Advisory Board participation by many local companies; and career interest inventories and career planning. FIT is promising as a means of impacting critical outcomes like student readiness for college and careers; student career aspirations and commitment; and student achievement in terms of graduation rate, need for remediation in college, and dual-enrollment completion. Preliminary evidence supports a reasonable hypothesis that FIT will make a positive difference in these areas for many students. The treatment group will comprise n=900 students who enroll in FIT from five high school campuses in the southern portion of FCS. The comparison group will comprise a group of students from the same high schools selected to match FIT enrollees in terms of socioeconomic and ethnic characteristics."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Investing in Innovative STEM Experiences for Rural Teachers (I3-SERT)
Project Description: "The Investing in Innovative STEM Experiences for Rural Teachers (I3SERT) program will be led by the Georgia Institute of Technology, through its Center for Education Integrating Science, Mathematics and Computing (CEISMC) and Distance Learning and Professional Education (DLPE) offices, in collaboration with a consortium of rural Georgia LEAs. I3SERT is an active collaboration between Georgia Tech and our partners including the Georgia Department of Education (particularly through the Career, Technical and Agricultural Education (CTAE) office), the Governor?s Office of Workforce Development (through the Georgia Work Ready program), the Technology Association of Georgia Education Collaborative, Georgia Tech?s Enterprise Innovation Institute, the University of Georgia, and corporations such as Georgia Power, UPS, Georgia Bio and General Electric. I3SERT will bring together two existing and one promising program to address the issue of disengaged students in rural Georgia through the professional development of their teachers. The programs are: 1) The Georgia Intern-Fellowships for Teachers (GIFT) work experience for teachers program, 2) the Electronic Advanced Global Learning Environment (EAGLE) online professional development program, and 3) The implementation of online professional learning communities. The overarching I3SERT goal is to increase the effectiveness of both CTAE and core science and mathematics teachers in making science and math concepts relevant to at-risk students in rural Georgia schools and thereby increasing science and math achievement. Towards this end the I3SERT collaborative will pilot and systematically study a program that combines summer work immersion, online learning experiences, and professional learning communities for teams of teachers from rural high schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Gadsden's Avatar Community:  The Embodiment of Hope
Project Description: "Gadsden County plans to enhance implementation of providing digital equipment to classrooms to enhance student engagement, train teachers and administrators in the operation of the equipment and its infusion into classroom instruction, and enhance the collection of digital content available for teacher use in the delivery of interactive digital instruction.  So far this project has yielded 33 and 74 percent learning gains in Reading in 2008-2009 and between 58 to 86 percent learning gains in Mathematics.  While there are pockets of excellence in a few Gadsden County schools, only 44 percent of Gadsden students are Reading at grade level, 54 percent are proficient in Mathematics, and only 22 percent are proficient in Science.  These proficiency levels, while low, are up from 2006-2007 percentages where only 38 percent of students were at Reading proficiency levels (14 percent below 2008-2009 levels); 43 percent were at Mathematics proficiency levels (21 percent below 2008-2009 levels); 16 percent were at Science proficiency levels (28 percent below 2008-2009 levels); and writing scores were at 76 percent (12 percent below 2008-2009 levels).   The cause of these rising proficiency levels, even in the face of annually rising academic bars set by USED, can be attributed to Gadsden's aggressive use of several innovative strategies and interventions, most especially the additional use of digital interactive equipment and content.   Based on research and the previous project's limited implementation in two of Gadsden's 14 public schools, it is reasonable to assume that further dissemination of these successful practices, continuing teacher professional development, continuing development of digital content, and installation of interactive whiteboards and student response systems in core subject classrooms will continue to positively impact Gadsden County's student achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title:
Learning for Support- A System of Supports to Motivate Students Toward 
College and Career Readiness
Project Description: "The project is a collaboration between a public school district with a large representation of high needs students and a private university system and their respective partners, to provide a comprehensive system of learning supports to enable students to access college and prepare for career readiness. The project activities are focused on transforming classroom learning by improved pedagogy, resulting in improved teacher and leader quality;  extending learning outside the classroom with partnerships with youth agencies and the use of technology,; and aligning community resources to support families.  The school and university will share professional development, faculty, resources, oversight, and monitoring of outcomes. The objectives of the project are: To assist families to develop graduation track and career pathway planning for their children beginning in the primary school years; to transform classroom learning to engage and motivate students; to extend learning outside of the classroom through partnerships with youth agencies, families and the use of technology and to connect learning to a real-world purpose and inspire students toward career paths. There will be an emphasis on the Collaborative development of multiple formative assessments embedded in the instruction process to monitor student understanding and provide feedback, and the use of balanced summative assessments, e.g. both performance and progress measures. The project will demonstrate the leadership, resources, and organizational model needed to incorporate the delivery of high quality standards and assessments through purposeful learning in an integrated approach with other areas of critical support.  Efforts to narrow achievement gaps thus far have often approached the problem situating the student has the source of deficit. In addressing gaps, students are often relegated to learning environments that further distance them from academic rigor and meaningful application of knowledge."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Galena Park Investing in Innovation(GPi3)
Project Description: "Galena Park Independent School District (GPISD) proposes to implement a comprehensive professional development program for consideration through the Investing In Education Validation Program.  The project - entitled Galena Park Investing in Innovation (GPi3) - is designed to provide all teachers with on-demand training in proven-effective strategies that meet the unique professional learning needs of each educator.GPi3 will serve a minimum of 21,450 students annually of which 78.1% (16,750) are identified as economically disadvantaged and 28.7% (6,150) Limited English Proficient (LEP).  The project will operate in alignment with the goals to:  1) To increase the number of highly-effective teachers and administrators within GPISD; 2) To improve the academic achievement of GPISD students; and 3) To improve the academic achievement of GPISD LEP students.  Outcomes results anticipated include a minimum of a 25% increase in the number of highly-effective teachers, improvements with teacher observation and assessment processes, a minimum of a 10% reading and mathematic improvement and a minimum of a 10% composite score increase on SAT/ACT test results among all GPISD students, and a minimum of a 10% reading and mathematic improvement among GPISD LEP students.In collaboration with our private sector partner, School Improvement Network, GPi3 will provide educations with access to a technology-driven library of professional teacher development resources, mobile teacher observation and assessment applications and innovative peer coaching strategies that offer proven-effective approaches for instruction.  The program will be monitored through a rigorous program evaluation system managed by independent evaluator, Dr. Steven Shaha."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Appalachian College Guides Program
Project Description: "The Appalachian College Guide Program will establish a pipeline of advisors who fit a 'near-peer' model to assist traditionally underserved students in gaining awareness of postsecondary educational opportunities and information about college preparation, admissions, and financial aid. Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: The Appalachian College Guide Program intends to improve the college-going culture and increase college enrollment of Appalachian high school students. Specifically, 90% of 11th-grade students are expected to complete college and career interest inventories and FAFSA Forecaster; and 90% of 12th grade students are expected to complete FAFSA and college applications. Other expected outcomes include an improved fit between students' college of acceptance and career interests and financial means, classroom assignments that focus on college, and student-exposure to college-readiness standards. Expected outcomes for the guides include commitment to a second year of service or intent to stay involved in college access efforts.Students Served: The Appalachian College Guide Program will reach 4,696 high school students in 8 school districts in the Southern Ohio Appalachian region"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: An Educational  Intelligence Platform to Improve College and Career Readiness
Project Description: "With our partner, we will develop, test, and implement an effective College and Career Readiness program based on a predictive model of student performance. The model will be developed based on historical student data relating to performance, interventions, and other educational methodologies needed to improve student performance. The Educational Intelligence platform will consist of a College and Career Readiness Portal and a Predictive Student Performance Improvement Model."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Preparing 9th Graders for Algebra I
Project Description: "(1) To determine if the methods, materials, and college-ready student achievement results that the Gateway Academic Program (GAP) consistently achieved in math through four small research studies with diverse, high-academic-need high school students enrolled in the District of Columbia Schools can be successfully replicated with similar students enrolled in the East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) of San Jose, California. (2) To determine if the methods, materials, and faculty pedagogical enhancement training results that the Gateway Academic Program (GAP) consistently achieved in three research studies with diverse math and science faculty at the University of the District of Columbia can be successfully replicated with math teachers of ESUHSD."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Generation Schools Talent and Time Innovations
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Preparing the 21st Century Teacher, Leader and Learner for Success
Project Description: "The Genesee Intermediate School District (GISD) has offered online learning for over ten years.  During the 2009-2010 school year, the GISD was given permission by the Michigan State Superintendent of Schools, Mike Flanagan, to lead and coordinate a statewide seat time waiver that would allow students to use online learning, without having to physically attend school.  This allowed students, who would have otherwise dropped out, fallen behind, not graduated on time, or been disengaged-to continue their learning.  In addition to this unique opportunity, over 40 teachers from four counties learned how to instruct as online teachers.  Initially, these programs acted independently, but increasingly were woven together with significant impact to student achievement.  Through professional development, improved practices in the classroom and new knowledge about delivering online instruction using the most recent technologies, teachers gained a new definition of what was needed to be an effective teacher for the 21st century.  This learning, combined with the online learning and the seat time waiver has given significant reasons to replicate this program. The expected outcomes would allow students to access online learning in order to gain academic credit, credit recovery, remediation, acceleration, dual enrollment and/or extended learning opportunities outside the regular school year; and teachers and principals will gain skills to use online instruction, in combination with research supported practices, for a variety of purposes in their classrooms and schools to better meet the needs of all students so they can be successful in courses and graduate on time. This innovative program would have the capacity to affect over 525,168 students in the state of Michigan, along with over 89,101 teachers and principals.  The official partner has not been finalized, but the GISD continues discussions with a variety of interested participants."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project SCALE
Project Description: "The GV BOCES SSS Center will work collaboratively with Center for Social and Emotional Education (CSEE)and Clemson University (CU) and Independent Evaluator, Fordham University to determine which of four best practice program interventions: PBIS, PBIS + School Climate (SC), PBIS + Olweus Bullying Prevention Program (OBPP), or PBIS+SC+OBPP is most cost effective and creates the most significant and practical improved outcomes for rural schools and their students in relation to significantly and practically improving school climate, citizenship, and academic achievement, and decreasing school bullying.  The GV BOCES SSS Center will work with CSEE and Clemson to design and implement four multi-day multi-year institutes for 6-8 multiple stakeholder school improvement leadership teams from rural schools composed of  staff, parents and to build their knowledge, skills and capacity to collect and analyze related data, revise/enhance related policies, practices and systems and implement the best practice programs with fidelity in the 24 - 32 rural schools.   Outcomes will then be compared to determine which interventions, and possible rural school adaptations to the processes produce the best outcomes for rural schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Virginia Initiative for Science Teaching and Achievement (VISTA)
Project Description: "The Virginia Initiative for Science Teaching and Achievement (VISTA) is a partnership among 47 school districts, six universities, and the Virginia Department of Education to build an infrastructure to provide sustained, intensive science teacher professional development to increase student performance. VISTA proposes a comprehensive professional development model to improve K-12 science teaching. The model incorporates and replicates two programs that have produced statistically significant gains in teacher instruction and student achievement in three large Virginia school districts. VISTA continues research as the programs are validated for wider distribution in Virginia. The programs target teacher needs:? Upper elementary (grades 4-6) teachers receive professional development in scientific, problem-based learning as well as student-centered inquiry. These teachers work in teams and receive feedback as they conduct inquiry-based science teaching in summer enrichment camps for children. Follow-up professional development helps them transfer science-based approaches to traditional classroom settings. ? Uncertified or provisionally licensed secondary (grades 6-12) science teachers, who often have bachelor?s degrees in science but little teaching experience or training, are given on-the-job and graduate-level classroom professional development, backed by online resources. They will attend in Year 1 and present in Year 2 at the annual state science conference.VISTA also builds a state infrastructure involving the State Department of Education, school district sciencecoordinators, specialists, principals, and science and science education professors. They provide theadministrative and academic leadership, technical resources and support needed to extend quality teaching tolimited English proficient students, rural students, students with disabilities and other special needs to ensurethat schools are helping them meet college- and career-ready standards."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Georgia Leadership Academy
Project Description: "The goal of the program is to address the large gaps in professional development for school teachers and administrators.  This is a largely unmet need for leaders of new and turn-around schools.  Through this program, Georgia Leadership Academy will (1) expand and develop our innovative professional development practices to enable it to serve as a model of best practice, (2) partner with the private sector including University of Southern California, Mosaica Education, and collaboration of schools in the state of Georgia, and (3) document best practices in professional development that can be shared and taken to scale based on demonstrated success.  To address Priority 1, Georgia Leadership Academy will expand GCSA's CharterLeader program and supplement it with the Mosaica Leadership Institute.  	The Georgia Leadership Academy will fill this gap by increasing the number of leaders who are trained through CharterLeader and the Mosaica Leadership Institute.   The goal of the program is to include helping aspiring educational professionals accelerate their path to school leadership.  Georgia Leadership Academy provides intensive training in all aspects of charter school leadership to fill Georgia's pipeline with an entrepreneurial and visionary 'new breed' of educators who are ready to lead schools.  The program addresses the first priority by increasing the number of highly effective principals hired in charter schools.  Participants will receive training in identifying, recruiting, developing, placing, rewarding, and retaining highly effective teachers."

Project Title: Reducing the Behavioral and Emotional Risk of Schoolchildren: A Clinical Trial of the Kids Intervention Data System (KIDS)
Project Description: "The overall goal of this project is to reduce special education service utilization by children with behavioral oremotional problems, children of color, and children with Limited English Proficiency. This project willprovide the first known empirical test of a fully data-driven public health service delivery model that isdirected at improving the behavioral and emotional adjustment of elementary school children. The data used todrive the delivery of services will include, 1) scores from a universal teacher-rated screening measure, 2)scores yielded by a comprehensive teacher behavior rating scale for identifying educator professionaldevelopment training needs, 3) scores yielded by the same comprehensive teacher behavior rating scale forselecting classroom evidence-based interventions for individual children, and 4) scores from progressmonitoring measures for collecting and assessing individual child evidence of responsiveness to interventions.The research program will be conducted at 12 elementary schools in the Los Angeles Unified School Districtusing an interrupted time series design."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Successful Teaching using Accumulated Results and Support Leveraged with Internet and Virtual Education
Project Description: "Successful Teaching Using Accumulated Results and Support (STARS) Leveraged with Internet and Virtual Education (LIVE)The STARS LIVE proposal is a validation project designed to help facilitate and enhance K-12 school and university collaborative partnerships  by providing a balanced approach, using the Internet and face-to-face communications, to improve teachers' and administrators ability to collect, analyze, and use data for instruction and decision making. Using Teacher-Intern-Professor groups with Anchor Action Research, which has previously been shown to be effective, teachers will very likely improve a unit of instruction while at the same time learn more about conducting research and interpreting data including test scores.  This approach is embedded in teacher residencies and provides a focus for clinical teaching. A second activity for teachers will be involvement in Cross Career Learning Communities where discussions about the use and interpretation of data in instruction will be central. Furthermore, the STARS LIVE grant will make a significant contribution to education by presenting a large scale multi-site intervention and evaluation of a teacher quality partnership effort with an extensive evaluation plan which includes matched comparison schools.  Georgia State University will partner with four higher education institutions: Albany State University (GA), Columbus State University (GA), East Stroudsburg University (PA), and Dowling College (NY) and their respective school systems to validate the project's two major activities, serving  22,965 students. The project has as its objectives: o	To increase teachers' knowledge of student data and interpretation. o	To create innovative approaches which improve data collection and interpretation.o	To increase student achievement.o	To increase teacher retention"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: After-School Debate Program
Project Description: "This After-School Debate Proposal seeks a development grant to serve 800 students in 20 middle and 20 high schools in Milwaukee, WI. In the first year, 15 high schools currently participating in the Milwaukee Debate League will hold 4-6 hours of weekly after-school debate instruction and participate in 8 monthly interscholastic tournaments during the academic year as a model for the 20 expansion middle schools and five additional high schools selected at random from the tier 2 and tier 3 schools in reading/language arts scores indicating a willingness to participate. In the remaining years, a two-summer student workshop and a one-week teacher workshop will provide training in debate fundamentals.  Throughout the school years for years 2-4, selected schools will implement the 4-6 hour after-school program and participate in the 8 monthly tournaments.  Teachers will also attend a series of one-day workshops, and receive base pay with the possibility of additional step-pay based on student participation levels. Curriculum materials (online resources, videotapes, lesson plans, and evidence packets) are included.   The program seeks to (1) improve standardized test scores in reading and English/ Language Arts by showing 7% gains over a matched comparison group; 2) decrease indicators of behavioral disengagement (disciplinary incidents, suspensions, and absences) by demonstrating statistically significant differences on each indicator from the matched group of non-debaters; 3) Improve student retention and progression toward graduation by (a) increasing the total credits earned at the end of grades 6-12, (b) increasing on-time promotion to grades 6-12, and (c) increasing the students who are at age for grade) at levels 7% higher on all indicators than the comparison group; and (4) Increase the number of students who pursue post-secondary education by demonstrating that the treatment group gains admission at a rate 10% higher on all indicators than the comparison group."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Creative Eye Curriculum
Project Description: "The result of this project will be a comprehensive, valid curriculum for developing critical and creative thinking that is aligned with assessments and professional development. This project is exceptional by applying empirically-valid and highly promising strategies that will achieve state standards in visual art, reading, language arts, math and science in a way that is economical and has significant promise for being scaled up to the state, regional, and national levels; it will be replicable in diverse student populations and instructional settings. High needs students in the treatment schools, having received differentiated instruction in a curriculum that combines Visual Thinking Strategies (VTS) and cognitively-based creativity training, will perform significantly better and develop faster than students in carefully matched comparison schools on measures of 1) 21st Century Skills, 2) standards-based art learning, and 3) achievement in subjects assessed by standardized tests."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, Inc.
Project Title: Strengthening the Self-Esteem and Aspirations of At-Risk Girls Through Career Exploration
Project Description: "The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York (GSCGNY) requests i3 support to study the efficacy of its newestinitiative, Career Exploration: Strengthening the Self-Esteem and Aspirations of At-Risk Girls. CareerExploration will be rolled out in 19 low-performing middle schools in the Bronx over a three-year period: theschool years 2011-2012, 2012-13, and 2013-14. First introduced in 2008-09 as a pilot in five high-needmiddle schools in the South Bronx, Career Exploration is a progressive initiative designed to ensure that largernumbers of low-income, middle school girls from minority backgrounds enter college or vocational schoolafter high school and pursue career opportunities that will bring them fulfilling jobs that lead to economic self-sufficiency.The core of the program is the development of key leadership skills in the middle school years,career awareness, and enhanced academic performance and self-esteem.Career Exploration will address Absolute Priority #4 and Competitive Preference #6. In 2008, the New YorkCity Department of Education (NYCDOE) reported that 45% of middle schools were failing to help three-quartersof their students develop basic English and math skills. Less than half of students were documentedas reaching English Language Art by the end of eighth grade, with only 60% of students reaching proficiencyin math. NYCDOE data also revealed that students who did not reach proficiency by eighth grade dramaticallylessened their chances of graduating from high school in four years, further impacting their ability to pursuecollege education.Middle school is a pivotal time for all girls as they begin to envision their futures. It is even more difficult forhigh-need students who do not have access to the same resources as their peers. Career Exploration isdesigned to provide a wide range of supports for these girls in an effort to promote their achievement in middleschool as well as their success in high school and beyond."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project IT Girl in Rural Communities: REfining a Model for STEM Education
Project Description: "In its proposed Development project, Girlstart will implement a tested model program called Project IT Girl. Thetarget audiences are predominantly at-risk high school and middle school girls from Austin as well as the ruralCentral Texas districts of Taylor, Granger, and Bartlett. In Project IT Girl, we seek to show how a successfulmodel for STEM learning/ college readiness / workforce development can be successfully implemented in adiverse range of school districts, especially rural school districts. To accomplish this, Girlstart will select atleast 80 girls for each of 2 cohorts (a total of at least 160 high school and middle school girls). In each of theproject years, each MS and HS cohort will participate in 176+ hours of 1.) School year programs comprised ofweekly after-school programs; six all-day Saturday workshops; and parent-daughter events, among otherinterventions; 2.) intensive, week-long Summer Academies and Summer Camps; 3.) internships; 4.)mentoring; and 5.) participation in an annual showcase of work on the web and in virtual environments.Through an intensive intervention of out-of-school programs, we will: 1.) Increase MS/HS students? STEMinterest and competency; 2.) Foster MS/HS students? STEM career exploration; and 3.) Improve students?college preparation and career planning. Project IT Girl will guide and support girls and parents as theynavigate the education pathway to STEM careers. Girlstart?s mission is to empower and equip girls in STEM.Since 1997, Girlstart has served over 20,000 girls and 5,500 teachers and families. We accomplish our missionby developing innovative models and processes for teaching STEM, empowering girls to achieve in STEMeducation and pursue STEM careers, thereby feeding the national STEM workforce."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: GUSD-i3
Project Description: "The Glendale Unified School District (GUSD) proposes to fully develop an alternative educational solution for out-of-school and at-risk high school students in California and nationally. GUSD-i3 will offer an innovative and collaborative program utilizing data-driven blended technological approaches to support learning needs of students who might otherwise drop out of school or fail to attain a diploma.GUSD-i3 will address the learning and social needs of non-traditional learners. Benefiting from the careful integration of self-directed instruction, sophisticated learning management tools to differentiate instruction, and small group discussions with teachers trained as mentors/ facilitators, students will develop the necessary self-confidence and personal motivation to take ownership for achieving their personal education goals.GUSD-i3 addresses the learning needs of high-risk students through a competency-based, self-paced program with clear quantifiable objectives and differentiated instruction suited to the individual student?s needs. Students with IEPs will be able to participate without significant adjustments."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Recipes for Success
Project Description: "Research undertaken by Glendale Unified Schools District (GUSD) has identified passing Algebra 1 as the main barrier to college entry for high need and Limited English Proficient (LEP) students.  Reasonable hypotheses highlight significant improvements in achievement gained by implementing a pan-district PD program which delivered a cohesive language and methodology for measuring attainment and progress.  GUSD proposes to use the i3 grant to address Priorities 2, 6 and 7 through the exceptionally innovative 'Recipes for Success' project which responds to our existing research.  A key strategy of the program is the development of 'Fave 5' and 'Lead 5' student and staff networks.  'Fave 5' will enable 'stuck' Algebra 1 students to reach out to a network of five knowledgeable 'friends' and the 'Lead 5' will enable staff to exchange ideas with other staff/experts. These collaborative online networks will be enabled through pioneering 21st century technologies including learning platform, podcasting and content creation tools. The number of students accessing four year college courses will also significantly increase through the project. To achieve this goal our private sector technology partner, RM Education, will provide a dynamic new College Entry Tool (CET) which will enable Limited English Proficient students to better plan and prepare for college. The tool will be fully inclusive of our Hispanic and Armenian communities and will include mini video interviews of real college graduates showing how the path they took to progress to college and how they overcame barriers.  Most importantly, the program will extend the scope of our existing change management and PD activities. A key objective of the program will be to expand the current face-to-face meetings to a highly collaborative online environment enabling the creation of digitally literate 'connected teachers' as per the National Education Technologies Plan 2010."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Assessment Literacy 101
Project Description: "The Glendale Union High School District Assessment Literacy 101 ProjectThe Glendale Union High School District (GUHSD) requests development grant funding for our AssessmentLiteracy 101 Project, an innovative professional development program that will serve 200 teachers andadministrators and over 105,000 students in an urban, high minority, high school environment. The purpose ofthis project is to enhance and expand an assessment literacy pilot program, with the goal of increasing the useof formative assessment data to improve student achievement. Results from an evaluation of this pilot revealedthat teachers and students benefitted from the assessment literacy training materials, technology tools, and dataanalysis techniques that were designed to assist teachers understand quality test development, use of data, anduse of assessment tools that increase student engagement. GUHSD, in partnership with Ottawa University, theArizona Center for Comprehensive Education and Life-Skills, and Western Maricopa Education Center isseeking funding to improve this model through the development of a graduate level assessment literacy coursefor 200 high school teachers, special educators, ELL teachers and career and technical education teachers. Toaddress the needs of special education and ELL students, the course will include specific training modulesdesigned to incorporate a curriculum that addresses the unique needs of these populations such as ELLassessment data, Individual Education Plan information, and test modification techniques for specialeducation. Innovative technologies that will be incorporated into this project include the use of student itemresponse pads, which provide immediate feedback to teachers on formative assessments, an on-line assessmentsystem called Galileo for test development and data collection, and electronic white boards for interactiveinstruction. The relevant absolute priority for this endeavor is Absolute Priority 2: Innova?TRUNCATE... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Gobles Smart Data System: Technologies, Tools, and Protocols for Usind Data to Improve Student Achievement
Project Description: "School districts around the country have data warehouses and other different data sets that don't 'talk' to one another.  This project brings together the diverse data used in a district (including teacher-developed assessments) in a way that it is useable and actionable by the classroom teacher.  The Gobles Smart Data System encompasses technology, tools, and protocols for using data to improve student learning.  In this system, the data are integrated, so no matter what data are reviewed, the reports all look the same - and are based on priorities of the district.  Additionally, the data is connected to the new Common Core standards and will provide many models of examples of formative assessment for those standards.  Based on the district's priorities, the data system will identify struggling students and supply recommended interventions.  The overall goal of this project is to improve student achievement in the content areas of reading, writing, and mathematics.  During this project, the development team will meet the objectives of (1) designing the technological tool that will bring key data together and ready for analysis without teachers having to run queries, (2) designing tools that help teachers and other stakeholders know how students are achieving in relation to the Common Core standards, and (3) designing protocols for analyzing and using data (e.g., tying data to interventions)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Expansion and Study of the Golden Apple Scholars of Illinois program
Project Description: "The Golden Apple Scholars of Illinois Program is an advanced teacher preparation and mentoring program of the Golden Apple Foundation for Excellence in Teaching (GA), a 501c-3 non-profit based in Chicago which recruits, prepares, places and mentors talented prospective teachers for teaching high-need students throughout Illinois. In partnership with 53 Illinois universities, this model has prepared 1,300 current or future teachers since opening in 1989. GA Scholars receive advanced teacher preparation during the summers of college, mentoring both before and after entering the teaching profession and professional development opportunities thereafter. Our records indicate 93% of Golden Apple Scholars teach beyond the five-year teaching commitment. Recent studies indicate that achievement of students taught by teachers who participated in the Scholars program surpasses that of students taught by other teachers.
