An i3 Development Grant will enable GA to expand the Scholars program: a) to prepare Scholars to teach in smaller urban and rural Illinois school districts and in low-achieving/probation Chicago schools, b) to study the performance of students taught by Scholars, c) to accept more Scholars into the annual cohort, and d) to quadruple existing mentoring for Scholars in teaching. Our objectives are: a) to prepare and place 150 future teachers and mentor over 400 teaching Scholars who will improve student performance in high-need schools, positively impacting 159,000 students, b) to increase the presence of such teachers in smaller urban and rural Illinois schools, c) to show through empiric study that the students of those taught by GA Scholars achieve."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Golden Eagle Charter SChool's Early College Academy
Project Description: "The Early College Academy at Golden Eagle Charter School will provide a support network for socio-economically disadvantaged, rural high school students to help them  successfully transition into college and career."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Benchmarking Early for Success
Project Description: "The Benchmarking Early for Success (Be 4 Success) project will demonstrate the effects of utilizing data to target early education interventions from preschool to third grade (PK-3), and the impact of those interventions on student success. This Development grant application addresses Absolute Priority 2 and two competitive priorities-innovations to improve early learning outcomes and innovations to address the needs of Limited English Proficient students.Our proposal will integrate multiple sources of data on children birth through eight with student achievement data to support decision-making that will improve children's school readiness and increase their language achievement by grade 3.  Districts will use the Kindergarten Student Entrance Profile (KSEP), a validated school readiness screening measure as a midterm benchmark to help evaluate pre-kindergarten services and determine Kindergarten through grade 3 interventions, which will be provided through extended learning time strategies. Overall, the project seeks to improve students' early language and literacy skills as measured by standardized language assessments in grades 2 and 3.Six local school districts (Goleta Union Elementary, Carpinteria Unified, Guadalupe Union Elementary, Lompoc Unified, Santa Barbara Elementary, and Santa Maria-Bonita) have joined together as official partners with the University California Santa Barbara Gevirtz School of Education in this project. First 5 Santa Barbara County will serve as an 'other partner'.  Be 4 Success will serve approximately 5,780 children (ages 4-8), in 14 schools and preschool communities across six districts over a 5-year period. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: JabrDigitAL: : Improving STEM Readiness in Middle and High Schools through an Innovative Application of  Gaming for Improvement in Mathematics
Project Description: "JabrDigitAL, originating from the Arabic word for algebra, engages a new generation of students through highly innovative and relevant video games that integrate mathematics curriculum and student interest. Drawn from standard mathematic concepts and curriculums used nationally yet tailored to the specific curriculum in an individual state or district, this innovation is the collective vision of a partnership consisting of seven Virginia local education agencies and a non-profit Higher Education Institution. The purpose is to leverage the motivation students' feel toward learning in a video game environment as a conduit to success and greater interest in mathematics. The outcome is higher mathematics achievement and advanced mathematics instruction thereby impacting post-secondary opportunity.  Strategies involve interactive, online mathematics multiplayer video gaming and best teaching practices that emphasize mathematics through gaming. At its core, JabrDigitAL meets students where they are, how they live and with what they do typically outside of the classroom and thereby creates the relevance and connection to the curriculum, empowering students to want to learn not merely for the sake of a test next week - but because they have the desire and a reason today!"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Back on Track  to SUCCESS
Project Description: "Good Shepherd Services (GSS) in partnership with a consortium of four New York City Department of Education Multiple Pathways schools and programs, Jobs for the Future (JFF), and an independent evaluator, the Academy for Educational Development (AED), is requesting a development grant for $5 million over four years in federal Investing in Innovation (i3) funds to develop a powerful model that will enable over-aged, under-credited (OA-UC) students to successfully prepare for, enter, and persist in obtaining a post-secondary credential.Absolute Priority Area 4: Innovations that Turnaround Persistently Low-Performing SchoolsCompetitive Preference Priority 6: Innovations that Support College Access & SuccessBy evaluating, demonstrating and communicating a three-phase college access and postsecondary support model - a broad range of enhanced instruction, student support services, and robust capacity building- project partners will develop and implement a sustainability and replication plan that will benefit many more students in the greater NYC Multiple Pathways network and additional cities across the nation with Back-on-Track schools and programs."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Partnering with Lindamood-Bell Learning Processes to Dramatically Impact Educational Achievement in Grainger County Schools
Project Description: "Attached is a proposal for funding of an i3 Developmental Grant which would allow staff members in the Grainger County School system the opportunity to work with consultants from Lindamood-Bell Learning Processes (LMB) to revolutionize classroom strategies and methodologies of providing literacy instruction in grades K-3. Through funding of this proposal, the county hopes to partner to help struggling readers by implementing a comprehensive model of professional development in language and literacy. Over the course of five years, one primary and four elementary schools will receive ongoing coaching, professional development, project management, and consulting from LMB professionals who are experienced with helping districts make reading on grade-level a reality for all students. LMB is an internationally recognized research and literacy organization and a leader in providing comprehensive professional development for literacy solutions for schools. Working directly with educators, consultants will use their extensive experience and previous successes to address professional development for teachers and literacy needs of students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Turnaround/Leadership Academy
Project Description: "he Turnaround/Leadership Academy will develop principals to have the skills, abilities, and practices that will influence student achievement for high-need students and implement an effective instructional leadership program with turnaround strategies for principals, including an additional emphasis on rural school settings.  Principals will receive on-site coaching and professional development at four Leadership Institutes per year and through a virtual community of practice. This project is designed to increase at least 50 principals' knowledge and skills in leadership domains (cognitive, interpersonal, and intrapersonal) and in mastering school 'turnaround' strategies, so that these principals can become effective instructional leaders, increase student achievement, including high-needs students, close achievement gaps, and transform their schools to meet the educational needs of all students. 30,000 students annually in at least 50 schools in North Dakota and Nevada."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Educator Academy 2.0
Project Description: "This project proposes a three-phase teacher education program that prepares candidates to reach all students in general education classrooms, including those with disabilities and other unique learning needs:1. Strategic Tutoring. After being trained in a research-validated instructional tutoring approach, program applicants will each assist secondary students for a minimum of 20 hours of high quality tutoring.2. Clinical Rotations. Over the span of one year, teacher candidates admitted to the program will spend several supervised clinical rotations in general education classrooms that include students with disabilities, low achievement, and limited English proficiency.3. Residency. Upon completion of the program, these new teachers will enter a two-year residency with intensive mentoring. During this time they will also earn a graduate endorsement in learning disabilities.As a result of this intensive training, experience, and mentoring, program graduates will be dual-certified in both general and special education and will be exceptionally well qualified to deliver high quality content instruction to students with unique learning needs."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Effective Teaching in the Students World
Project Description: "The Effective Teaching in the Students World project is designed to provide instruction in an environment that focuses on technology and real world application that exists in the world in which the student lives. Emphasis is placed on supporting teachers and administrators to build the skills that allow them to use inquiry and technology as an integral part of day-to-day learning, not as an add-on. Technology will be used to: 1) support curriculum alignment to state/national objectives, 2) map learning activities to content, 3) deliver rich media instructional content or experiential learning activities, and 4) facilitate ongoing assessment, integrated with practice and instruction. Students will complete school assignments and homework on technology similar to what they play with at home. Technology tools will be used to increase differentiated instruction providing a wider variety oflearning opportunities that reach students at different readiness levels. Industry partners will be a key element of support in development of virtual and hands-on applications that allow students to begin exploring the world they live in at a deeper level, thus helping them build skills and prepare to make effective decisions about their own personal interests and aptitudes. Relevance will be a key factor in supporting increased student engagement and achievement.  Intermediate and long-term outcomes have been identified and include: 1) student engagement improved at all levels and subgroups, 2) student achievement improved and sustainable from one level to the next, and 3) students gaining problem solving skills that support effective decision making."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Virtual Reality Education Pathfinders (VREP)
Project Description: "Virtual Reality Education Pathfinders (VREP), provides a disruptively innovative approach to student-centered learning poised to transform traditional education through engaging, rigorous, and highly-effective learning experiences. VREP provides three-dimensional (3D) virtual reality (VR) education to high-need students in three states (Connecticut, Iowa, and Ohio); tests the efficacy of the program for increasing achievement, graduation rates, and the numbers of students pursuing college courses and careers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM); and lay the foundation for scaling-up the approach to school districts around the country. 3D VR provides an innovative classroom experience leading to deep understanding and demonstration of standards. The multi-pronged VREP approach includes:o	VR Collaboration Center. Provides a safe and secure location for student developers, users, teachers and affiliate sponsors to share applications, resources and to collaborate with other members. Content experts vet VR applications to ensure accuracy and clear alignment to national and state standards.o	VR Institutes. Semi-annual VR institutes bring students and teachers together to learn VR software applications together. Student developers lead and facilitate this training with professional support. o	Students as Designers and Users. Students participate as both developers and users of 3D VR environments and applications. Teachers then use student-created applications to facilitate learning for all.Objectives and Outcomes: VREP seeks to show this highly-engaging, learner-centered approach increases: achievement on standardized exams; graduation rates; enrollment and achievement in STEM courses; and pursuit of STEM careers for targeted students and that VREP's innovative design speeds response to feedback and rapid scale-up.Target Numbers: After 5 years, across three states, VREP will serve 14,580 student developers and 270,000 student users."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: College Dreams i3 Project
Project Description: "The College Dreams i3 Project will provide long term resiliency development, academic enhancement, and college preparation for 600 students with multiple dropout risk factors who are in 6th to 12th grade in Josephine County, Oregon.  This i3 Project includes two Local Education Agencies and a network of community partners.  Based on external program evaluation results, we anticipate that Dreamers will have significantly lower dropout rates, better academic performance and school attendance, and stronger college readiness than random comparison students. The project model includes key components of What Works Clearinghouse evidence-based programs including staff with multiple roles, long term engagement with high needs students, close academic monitoring, individualized interventions, skill training, and linkages to families and community resources.  Innovative features include full-school academic records screening, early engagement during middle school, academic motivational enhancement, barrier removal assistance, performance-based scholarship awards, recognition ceremonies, community service, and college preparation coaching."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Putting a Twist on Education
Project Description: "We at Gray & Associates, Inc. / The Learning Curve would like to ?Put a Twist on Education,? in the State of Mississippi. We want to empower the students to take ownership of their academic experience and to ensure parents that when their children leave The Learning Curve?s afterschool tutoring, they have accomplished their goals for that day.We will partner with a consortium of Mississippi schools, both urban and rural, to establish a peer-tutoring program in combination with a new online lesson program titled: The Learning Craze. Our partners have assured us of their willingness to help us carry out this project. Peer-tutoring will help afterschool tutors by giving them more time for writing lesson plans and giving individual attention to needy students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: World Class Scholars
Project Description: "World Class Scholars (WCS) is a partnership between students, parents, school districts, Grays Harbor College and the Grays Harbor College Foundation since 1993. Starting in the 7th grade, students sign a commitment form to several scholastic, leadership and community service goals to be met before their high school graduation. Each year students will meet with appropriate WCS staff to go over yearly portfolio, academics and volunteer opportunities. There is a great need to serve our most underrepresented students in our community and we feel we can focus a lot of attention on our low income and minority populations. Also, we are looking to add a stronger college/career readiness aspect to the WCS program to better prepare our local students for the challenges down the road. To be recognized as a WCS, students must sign a commitment form, complete an annual portfolio, complete 10 hours of community service and graduate high school with an accumulative GPA of 3.0. Over the past couple years, over 100 students have been graduating our local high schools as World Class Scholars but that number could be significantly higher if the resources and manpower was available to do so and address the issues which face our neediest students. Each year we receive hundreds of students committing to the program only to see them fall through the cracks because of the lack of attention and preparedness."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Great Hearts Academies: A New Public School Model
Project Description: "The Great Hearts Academies model of public charter school education has the capacity to deliver high qualityGreat Books classical and liberal arts education to any community in the United States, including tocommunities consisting of predominantly underserved at-risk children, and meet or exceed the highest stateand national standards with a 100% college acceptance rate. Furthermore, the Great Hearts model for deliveryof classical liberal arts education based on the Great Books curriculum and Socratic Seminar instructionalmethodology is innovative and improves the achievement and moral formation for all students. This model isuniquely suited to translate standards and information from assessments into classroom practices conducive togenuine learning and meeting the needs of all students, including high-needs students. Great HeartsAcademies? nationally unique model of classical preparatory education in a public school setting has proven tobe scalable with quality, and can serve as a best practice model for education reform locally, regionally, andnationally. Great Hearts Academies hypothesizes that the crisis in American education (low academicperformance, student disengagement, and dysfunctional school cultures) can be solved, in part, by arecommitment to Classical, liberal arts education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Applicant: Great Oaks Institute of Technology and Career Development
Project Title: Improving Industry Certification Attainment: An Ohio Model
Project Description: "In the proposed grant, the LEA, Great Oaks Institute of Technology and Career Development will partner withNOCTI, The Ohio State University Center on Education and Training for Employment (OSU/CETE) and theUniversity of Minnesota for a five-year Development Grant focused on improving industry certificationattainment.The proposed activities involve providing assessment and related tools to assist students from 22 schools inobtaining industry credentials in twelve technical programs by the end of the five-year cycle. In addition,professional development focusing on data-driven instruction and the use of assessment data will also beprovided to over 300 career and technical education (CTE) teachers. It is expected that this project will impactover 16,000 students during the grant cycle, resulting in additional students earning industry credentials,completing their programs, earning college credit while in high school, enrolling in post-secondary educationand moving on to successful careers.In the proposed program, program components include pre-assessments, study guides, through-courseassessments and industry certification exams. To begin, seven industry certification agencies as well as twostate certifying agencies are strongly supporting this project. Three additional certifications will be secured inthe latter part of the grant cycle and offered to all participating students in Year 5."

Applicant: Greater Indianapolis Chamber of Commerce Foundation
Project Title: Common Goal Indianapolis
Project Description: "The Indianapolis Chamber, 11 school corporations and other partners propose to develop the Common Goal Initiative (CG).  CG will entail a data-driven early-warning system to identify students at risk of failing/dropping out, plus systematic interventions designed to help at least 2,000 more students succeed: graduation coaches, mentors, and internships operating out of every public school district (11) and every high school (20) in the county.  Interventions are based on a Graduation Coach Initiative first developed and studied in Georgia, where coaches promote not only high school graduation but also postsecondary enrollment/success.  With federal funding to fully implement Common Goal countywide for the next three years, partners are confident that graduation rates will increase by an average of 2.5 percentage points each year, to 80%, and students will go to college.  Student progress will be monitored continuously, with the data used to customize interventions.  The project will be rigorously evaluated, with a comparison group study by Indiana University's Center for Evaluation & Education Policy. ??????????"

Applicant: Greater Lawrence Community Action Council, Inc.
Project Title: ESPERaNZA Enriching Student Performance, Enhancing Reading and Nurturing Zealous Achievement.
Project Description: "ESPERaNZA, a development grant, will provide intensive intervention services for children who are at risk, most of whom are LEP: 43%, 30%, 45%, 47%, 50%, at five sites and 18% children with disabilities. GLCPC proposes to implement a forward design model merging their Early Reading First Project EStRELLA's most promising strategies with Community DayCharter Public School's Reading First strategies to support continuous progress for 617 high needs students in 37 classrooms. ESPERaNZA's design is based upon understanding SBRR, assessment measures, and the interpretation of the results to improve student achievement. ESPERaNZA will implement practices, strategies, and programs that are designed to improve educational outcomes for children and their families based on data. ESPERaNZA proposes: ? Support of birth to age 5 children and their families using the Parents As Teachers model; ? Implementation of an SBRR literacy program PreK to Grade 3; ? Use of data to support a standards-based instructional program, and, ? Provide support to area child care providers in SBRR strategies. Research-based professional development lies at the heart of ESPERaNZA's education reform. The common thread for all professional development will be student performance data-how it is managed and how it is used to guide instruction. A series of strategies that help staff: ?establish concrete objectives; ?identify data that lets staff know if those objectives are being achieved; and, ?helps instructional staff manage and analyze data so it can be used to improve instruction and increase student achievement will be utilized.This project will provide intensive support services for Tier 2 and 3 students to improve student achievement and narrow the achievement gap. At the end of the grant cycle all staff will increase their knowledge base of SBRR content and be proficient in data driven instruction.GLCAC is committed to demonstrating that the i3 grant strategies will improve student achievemen"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: College Bound: Leveraging Technology to Close the Parenting Gap
Project Description: "College Bound is an online education program that acknowledges and supports the truism: the parent is the child's first teacher.  Every day, new research points to the important role parents play in helping children develop a firm foundation for academic success.  Unfortunately, many low-income parents are unable to access this new information and translate it into practical strategies to support their children's education success.   	College Bound is an innovative and scalable e-learning program that aims to close this 'parenting gap' in America. Featuring brief video lessons in English and Spanish that teach parents the best ways to support their children's education, College Bound builds parents' skills step by step, grade by grade, beginning when their children are in preschool and ending when their children graduate from high school ready for college.	The project objective is to support the implementation of English Language Arts (ELA) and Mathematics standards by bolstering parents' abilities to 1) hold high and accurate grade-level expectations for achievement; 2) support standards-based learning at home; 3) partner with teachers to monitor and support performance in school; 4) cultivate skills that underlie school success; and 5) help children select challenging, college-preparatory courses. The expected outcomes are to positively affect the knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors of low- and middle-income parents, which will result in increased student academic achievement, high school graduation rates, and college degree attainment rates for lower-income students. ."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Green Dot University
Project Description: "Green Dot Public Schools, an organization whose 19 charter high schools have significantly improved achievement, growth, and graduation rates for more than 8,300 low-income, high need urban students, is requesting a Development Grant for Green Dot University (the Project), a two-year program designed to induct, train and support 22 effective school leaders who are needed to significantly improve student academic engagement and achievement - specifically within the context of the added difficulties that arise from a conversion project.  In the first year, future principals are front-trained and given the theory behind, and hands-on experience in, each facet of their future jobs so that they can prove their competencies in key areas.  In the second year, these new principals are provided with the intensive supports they need to continue their growth as they enact the massive changes required from a leader of a Transformation School."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Next Three Lockes
Project Description: "Green Dot Public Schools, an organization whose 19 charter high schools have significantly improved achievement, growth, and graduation rates for more than 8,300 low-income, is proposing The Next Three Lockes, a project whose principal objective is to transform three persistently low-achieving Title I schools over the next five years and in the process refine and codify our basic model.  The Project will directly affect approximately 9,000 high-need students as it delivers outcomes based entirely on their achievement: increased attendance rates and persistence; increased student academic achievement and proficiency in core academic subjects; increased graduation rates - and specifically increased college-preparatory graduation rates.  The Project will also provide a blueprint that can be used to replicate these outcomes and scale results to hundreds of thousands more low-income students who are currently being failed by our educational system."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Authentic Intellectual Work- Iowa - A Professional Development Project Using Authentic Pedagogy to Improve Student Achievement (AIW
Project Description: "AIW-Iowa?s goal is to increase achievement of all students, particularly low income and special needs students, while preparing them for post secondary success. AIW-Iowa has three objectives 1) increase the success of under-represented student populations in academically rigorous courses and programs 2) develop and use assessments which are aligned with high student curriculum and academic achievement standards guided by the Iowa Core/Common Core Standards (IC/CCS) 3) translate the aligned assessments into classroom practices to meet the needs of all students. Authentic Intellectual Work is defined by three criteria: construction of knowledge through disciplined inquiry to produce discourse, products, and performance that have value beyond school (VBS). AIW establishes criteria for teaching that maximize expectations of intellectual challenge for all students, increase student interest in academic work, support teachers in teaching for in-depth understanding rather than superficial coverage and provides a common conception of student intellectual work among teachers. AIW-Iowa is based on a substantial research base, positive student achievement trends from Iowa?s AIW schools, and quality professional development. The project is expected to have a strong and significant positive effect on student achievement gains and achievement gaps, as well as other student engagement, graduation rates, and college enrollment. The project has four dominant activity strands:1) Implementation of an organized four-year plan 2) Internal capacity will be built at all levels by providing additional training to administrators, coaches, liaisons, and lead educators 3) Teams of educators will develop authentic common assessments aligned to the AIW standards and the IC/CCS. Ultimately 413 Iowa schools, 34,744 teachers and 510,916 students will engage in more meaningful learning through AIW 4) Virtual Learning Networks will develop interdisciplinary learning opportunities grounded in the AIW"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Design, Develop, and Demonstrate: A Model for Student-Centered Learning
Project Description: "The Green River Regional Educational Cooperative is an educational service agency (LEA) serving 33 districtsin south central Kentucky. In working with teachers and leaders in our 250 mostly rural schools, we have seensignificant increases in student achievement. However, the impact has been in pockets where particularteachers in particular schools have participated in our work of the last 8-10 years.Through D3, we will take the common set of research-based practices and strategies from our previous work thathas proven to be effective and will implement these deeply across all classrooms of a single demonstrationschool, a school where all teachers and administrators will commit to implement the model with full fidelity tothe design. In doing so, we will create the student-centered learning environment necessary for today?s learnersin today?s world. Briefly, our objectives include: - Moving students toward postsecondary and careersuccess; - Increasing student academic success across all content areas; - Ensuring fidelity of implementationto enable replication of the student-centered learning model.D3 will directly serve 600-1,000 students in a single high school. However, the impact will not stop there. Wewill base the development of this demonstration site in part on the highly successful Literacy Lab sites weestablished in 2008 and 2009, reaching other schools throughout the region and state. Our partners, listed atleft, include regional, state and national organizations that are ready to support, learn from, and disseminate thefindings from this project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: On Demand Professional Development for Raising Student Achievement
Project Description: "Brief Description of Project: The project will provide teachers in Greene, Jones, and Putnam school districts in rural Georgia with 24/7/365 access to tools and resources that leverage 21st Century technology to make professional development more effective, convenient, and sustainable. This will enable continuous enrichment and learning opportunities aimed at improving teacher and principal effectiveness in order to increase student achievement and close achievement gaps. The essential elements of the project are:? Implementation of a Personal Learning Network (PLN) that brings teachers, principals, and other stakeholders together through anytime, anywhere web-based technology.? Web-based training and coaching, as well as face-to-face meetings to create a system-wide culture of professional development and to eliminate travel time and costs.? Principal and coach observation using electronic handheld devices to instantly link observation data with professional development to create a ?real-time cycle of learning? where 1) observers know what to look for based on the professional development focus and 2) teachers get immediate, prescriptive guidance based on the observation.? Collaboration and social networking ? teachers can share and collaborate on lesson plans, motivational techniques, classroom instructional strategies, etc, as well as videos of their instruction to drive learning and improve student achievement.Summary of project objectives and expected outcomes: The objective of the project is to implement a comprehensive, on-demand professional development that is effective, convenient, and sustainable. The expected outcomes are: 1) increase the number of students meeting standards proficiency by 10% annually; 2) increase number of staff development hours earned to 75 hours per teacher participant, and 3) increase knowledge of instructional leadership skills as measured by student achievement SMART goals as identified in their School Improvement Plans"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Road to Algebra:  Making Connections
Project Description: "The Road to Algebra:  Making Connections initiative proposes to develop a self sustaining, professional development model aimed at improved and augmented student achievement in K-algebra mathematics and advanced readiness for formal coursework in algebra.  The need for this project is critical in that algebra is commonly acknowledged as a 'gateway' to the opportunities of the 21st century.  Without the ability to succeed in formal algebra, stiudents are limited in their opportunities for technical degrees and careers, and U.S. students are failing at an alarming rate. In response, the Road to Algebra project proposes a training model that will take place in a K-algebra team format using three progressive phases where teachers: 1) do mathematics; 2) build and teach K-algebra vertically aligned curriculum; and 3) implement a mentorship model focused specifically on instructional decision making and long-term project sustainability.The project is unique in that it is framed around the development of building level K-algebra teaching teams and has two primary goals: 1) K-algebra students will demonstrate a greater mastery of conceptual mathematics and greater readiness for formal algebra coursework; 2) K-algebra teachers will gain greater proficiency in doing mathematics, teaching mathematics, developing vertically articulated curriculum, and in instructional coaching. At the end of the funding period approximately 4,000 students will have been served through formal grant activities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project SUCCESS
Project Description: "Project Success describes the GUHSD's i3 Development Grant proposal. The project targets high need eighth graders entering high school from nine K-8 districts. Project Success blends social/emotional supports and intensive academic interventions to bring students up to grade level enabling them to challenge rigorous courses including AVID, honors, and AP, and to ultimately, pursue college.Selected ninth graders attend a 4 Day 3 Night leadership and human relations camp in the summer (Camp LEAD) prior to entering high school. Camp LEAD is staffed by GUHSD personnel and current students. Through focused dialogue, experiential activities, and self reflection, students identify barriers to learning and understand how personal choices dictate success. Participating students also enroll in LEAD Academy, a year long class based on George Washington University's Freshmen Transition Standards. The course focuses on personal development, career and college planning, including a Post Secondary Plan, study skills and habits, direct literacy instruction, and motivational activities.  Project Success aims to increase skills, confidence, and personal motivation of 'high need' ninth graders to a level that enables them to take advantage of additional achievement and connectedness programs such as AVID, Career Technical Education, honors, and Advanced Placement. Expected outcomes include improved student achievement, reduced discipline referrals, steady attendance, and pursuit of college readiness and college enrollment. Over the life of the grant, Project Success would expect to serve approximately 4, 500 students.  Community partners include San Diego Youth Services (SDYS), all local law enforcement agencies, Child Welfare and Juvenile Justice."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: High School Transition Project (HSTP)
Project Description: "GroupWORKS will serve 1000 students per year through the High School Transition Program (HSTP) by intervening in three middle schools and three high schools within the Children's First Network (CFN), part of the New York City Department of Education (NYC DoE). Each of the experimental schools will hire an additional full time guidance counselor, funded by the grant, and trained by GroupWORKS facilitators, to focus exclusively on the transition to high school. The goals of the project are to provide support and training for at risk students so they can manage the transition to high school and develop the resiliency skills they need to succeed in high school and beyond.  The strategy is to work with at risk students in groups to provide social emotional learning, conflict management and resiliency skills, and to train counselors and teachers in supporting these at risk students.  Achievement of goals will be measured by comparing promotion, attendance, suspension and drop-out rates before and after implementation and between control and treatment schools. The success of the project will be evaluated by calculating the number of 9th graders who stay in school, attend school regularly, and are promoted to 10th grade.  Self and teacher evaluations of skill development, self-esteem enhancement, and school success will also be utilized."

Project Title: Center for Educator Effectiveness
Project Description: "In official partnership with Learning Point Associates, Guilford County Schools, NC, proposes, through an i3 Development Grant, to create a Center for Educator Effectiveness to address Absolute Priority 1. The target number of students to be served in this project is 71,464 with additional students to be served through scale-up efforts in 15 LEAs, 4 of which are rural.The Center for Educator Effectiveness will coordinate the systematic implementation of eight different talent management functions- preparation, recruitment, hiring, induction, professional development, compensation and incentives, working conditions and performance management. Major activities will include conducting an updated needs assessment, gap analysis, development of an educator talent graphic map (see Appendix H for an example), development of guidebooks for each of the eight educator talent functions, and 80 hours of training for teachers and principals.This project has six objectives that are aligned to the grant requirements as stated in the RFP. They are to 1) recruit effective educators into high-need schools, 2) place effective educators with high-need students, 3) identify effective educators using performance evaluations and Value Added Data (to measure student growth), 4) develop educators to be effective in achieving results with high-need students, 5) reward the performance of effective-educators in high-need schools, and 6) retain effective educators who teach high-need students. The expected outcomes are to increase student achievement, decrease the achievement gap, decrease dropout rates and increase high school graduation rates.Special project features include the use of the METworks Framework for Managing Educator Talent, Silk Road technology solutions, and the coordination of this i3 funded program with existing federal grants. A resource website, eight best-practice guidebooks and 80 hours of developed training will be available at no cost as a part of scale-up efforts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Guitars in the Clasroom: Teacher effectiveness and student achievement throughmusic integration.
GCEIC Innovative Academic Interventions
Project Description: "The project will improve student achievement in Math and Language Arts by vertically aligning curriculum, instruction, resources and assessments; increasing graduation rate by closing learning gaps and differentiating instruction; and preparing students for success after high school.  This will enable Katrina survivors to contribute to the economic revitalization of the Gulf Coast. The expected outcomes are: improving academic achievement during the school year, improving scores on the MCT2/SATP tests annually, providing teacher incentive awards, and addressing rigor of the forthcoming Common Core Standards. Consequently, school district ratings will continue to improve over time.  Professional Learning Communities will support instructional leadership creating holistic educational experiences for Gulf Coast students.      Stage 1 of the project incorporates a quality assessment suite providing tools to diagnosis learning gaps and data to drive instruction.  Educators will have the data needed to make modifications for students on an individual basis.  Stage 2 transforms assessment data into individualized instructional plans that identify strengths and areas of opportunities for students; providing differentiated instructional strategies with a variety of learning styles.  Stage 3 utilizes innovative uses of technology during additional/extended instructional time created by inventive scheduling. Stage 4 focuses on Professional Development and fostering Professional Learning Communities to retool the Gulf Coast's teaching force, thus creating classrooms where differentiation is achieved through technology.  Stage 5 provides incentives for teachers that master the methodology successfully and show the most student growth related to improving scores on state MCT2/SATP tests.      This project is vital to improving the academic lives of the at risk students in schools that survived Hurricane Katrina."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Dive Deeper: Lobster Science for Literacy and Learning
Project Description: "Our nation?s children are falling behind in science. This is in part because instructional time has been reallocatedto literacy and math and in part because the way we teach science does not reflect the way children learn.The proposed Dive Deeper program will implement kit-based science curricula linked with literacy and enhancedthrough place-based content. Over three years, Dive Deeper will reach 25 rural districts, supporting andengaging 90 geographically isolated teachers through workshops, in-service days, and web-based forums. Over3,300 students will benefit from deep learning that extends over 20+ class periods. It is our intention, assumingsuccess of the Dive Deeper model, to scale statewide (~15,000 students annually) following the grant period.Innovations include integration of authentic place-based science with language literacy and math to support deeplearning across 20+ class periods, and the development of new items to assess analysis, reasoning, andcommunication skills.Dive Deeper will spark an interest in science in our next generation, increase the quality and quantity ofinstructional time devoted to science, and support the development skills needed for college and careers in the21st century. Specific Objectives include:1) Students Make Meaning of Science;2) Teachers Demonstrate Enhanced Skills; and3) Evidence Supports Students? Gains in 21st SkillKey strategies will include: 1) building teachers' confidence across the practice of science; 2) motivating learningby connecting science sits to place-based content; 3) providing students with a peak learning experience inlobster science; 4 )developing a lobster science enhancement kit to ?Dive Deeper?; and 5) developing new 21stcentury assessment items."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: PRIDE:  Promoting Rural Initiatives in Distance Education
Project Description: "Ten rural districts in West Texas will align high school curriculum with postsecondary education and economic development activities in science, technology, engineering (as applied science and math), and technology.  Project activities will include developing  rich curriculum resources and supporting curriculum integration  in ten rural school districts in West Texas.Consistent with the goals and objectives of the Texas STEM initiative, districts will 1)  Provide a rigorous, well-rounded education - implementing a 1:1 computing initiative in grades 4-12; requiring four years of science and math; expanding extra-curricular activities in science, math, engineering, and technology; and requiring all seniors to complete and present a senior project;  2) Establish a personalized, college- and work-ready culture; and 3) Provide teacher and leadership development - investing in professional development for teachers (with the support of onsite instructional specialists); scheduling opportunities for shared planning; encouraging teachers to attend state and national conferences in their content area; and participating in STEM networks."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: GCPS QUALITY-PLUS LEADER ACADEMY
Project Description: "The proposed project will use the successful Gwinnett County Public Schools Quality-Plus Leader Academy model to increase the number of highly effective school leaders throughout the State in order to improve student achievement.  GCPS is a leader among Georgia school districts, as well as urban districts around the nation, in the effort to improve teaching and learning and close achievement gaps, and therefore stands as good candidate to further develop, validate, and disseminate best practices."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: TI-GERS and Technology
Project Description: "TI-GERS and Technology is a Development Grant request for $5,000,000 over five years. An i3 grant awardwill expand existing programs in the Hackettstown Public Schools District which combine ?High-Tech? with?High-Touch? to provide increased opportunity for student access to college and career, 21st Century, andSTEM curriculum.The objective of TI-GERS and Technology will be to integrate our after school activity program and highlyeffective technology for early intervention. Early intervention and individualized instruction will provideencouragement, foundation and resource understanding for STEM based instructional activities to preparestudents for success with college and career standards.The expected outcomes of this initiative will be to increase standardized test scores in mathematics, reading,increase participation in STEM related TI-GERS clubs, and increase overall GPA in the areas of language arts,mathematics and science for the entire population of our district?s 2000 students. The special feature of thisproject is the foundation already exists.The TI-GERS initiative has had Board of Education support going now into its third year and is well receivedby students, parents and staff. Hackettstown Board of Education also supports the Technology Plan whichallocates money each year for the implementation of instructionally appropriate software and hardware tosupport instruction. Our District Technology Plan is in line with the US Department of Education NationalEducation Plan 2010 and with the International Society for Technology and Education (ISTE). Partnershipsexist with Centenary College, Pearson Digital, Virtual High School, and the New Jersey High School ReformConsortium that will help Hackettstown Public Schools in the attainment of this initiative."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: STEM Innovation Academy for Rural Teachers
Project Description: "The STEM Innovation Academy strategy will serve as an 'innovation incubator' for teachers to create solutions to their instructional problems. A key principle of the strategy is that if teachers are to 'educate-to-innovate' they must know and experience principles of being an innovator. Teachers of Algebra 1, Biology, Earth Science, and Geometry in 10 high schools will form course-specific teams to develop virtual project-based learning (PBL) simulations as a solution for making rigorous math and science content more relevant to students in a high-poverty rural context. Teachers will network primarily in a virtual world.	Linked to the course-specific Virginia standards of learning (SOLs) and assessments, these real world simulations are intended to influence student self-efficacy as a mediating variable on student engagement, achievement, and subsequent selection of more advanced mathematics and science courses considered essential for pursuing careers in the green economy. The project will serve approximately 7,000 students.   	Academy teachers will integrate the 'green economy' PBL simulations and related assessments into their high school math and science courses. As a complement to the 'educate-to-innovate' strategy, teachers will complete a blended online graduate course, Principles of Innovation in Education. Students will produce promising entrepreneurial business ideas in a new web-based dual-enrollment course, Education, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship, with 100 tuition-free slots reserved. The course will link college and career readiness standards to innovation, entrepreneurship and development of local rural economies.	Official partners James Madison University and Edvantia, Inc. collaborate in this project of national importance with Halifax County Public Schools (applicant). Other partners include the Association of Educational Service Agencies, the Center for Rural Virginia, and eight additional rural school divisions in Virginia."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: College Bound and Beyond/PACP
Project Description: "College Bound and Beyond/PACP (Persistently Attaining College Preparation) is a unique initiative that will resolve some of the difficulties faced by four school districts in the Northeast region of North Carolina.  The action plan that is set forth will meet head on- to face, and  to over come many of the challenges faced by  our future leaders, our students.  One of the key focus or mission of the College Bound and Beyond/PACP, is to assist our youth in making colleges/universities and career choices at an early age, rather than a partial  or no development of career/college choices at a later stage of their educational development.  Therefore, the aims for the collaborating schools and LEA's are to provide initiatives that provide strong, rigorousand ambitious results.  CB & Beyond/PACP will host a series of innovations to learning and engagement that arenot currently implemented in areas of the Roanoke Valley region of the 1st Congressional District.  College Bound and Beyond will offer an array of opportunities to engage students in subjects, experiences andenhancements that will elevate their interest in our school, thus, leading our school to for front of academic gaps closing.  The project will serve those students enrolled in schools districts that are of Title I.  Many of thestudents enrolled in these school districts are faced with an insurmountable of underserved, deprivation of  educational supplies, unemployment, low capital per income, 70% minority populated, teen pregnancy, high school drop-out and lack of college bound or life-long career interests.  As a result of these findings, the CB & Beyond will established collaborative efforts among those schools to focus on closing academic gaps by communicating across districts, implement programs with quality and substance.  CB & Beyond will provide initiatives that provide strong, rigorous and ambitious results.  CB &Beyond/PACP will host a series of satellite learning sites."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Do the Math! - Bellwether Redesign Consortium
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Juvenile Justice Education Transformation
Project Description: "The Juvenile Justice Education Transformation (JJET) Model  will work with the MA Dept. of Youth Services (DYA)  Education Initiative Partnership and external partners to scale up our school transformation model, examine its efficacy, disseminate effective components and support replication. It focues on improving the delivery of education services to result in increased academic, social-emotional, and life outcomes for youth confined to long-term facilities in the DYS System."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: ABC Power Series and R.E.A.L. Link
Increasing Test Scores to Encourage Achievement (ITSEA)
Project Description: "With this grant, we will assist students and their families achieve college access (for the student) through a multi-faceted plan to increase student achievement and be better prepared to enter and succeed in post-secondary education. We plan to do this by using a combination of early intervention in the 7th grade, 9th grade, and 10th grade each year for three years to increase ACT Explorer, Plan and ACT test scores; career and high school planning (using resources available on collegefortn.org); creating a ?go to college culture? with parent and student rallies each semester; and financial aid preparation assistance."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Harlem Children Society i3 Validation Effort
Project Description: "The Harlem Children Society (HCS) has provided an after-school and summer informal education and academic enrichment mentoring program in Science, Technology, Engineering & Math (STEM) fields for low-income, minority youth who attend under-resourced and under-performing schools for ten years. In accordance with its central mission, HCS served under-resourced and under-represented students at an inverse ratio to most US universities' math and science student populations. The program is particularly successful in attracting young women, mostly from ethnic and racial minority backgrounds.  With this application, HCS respectfully requests funding to validate its efforts to-date at six sites (Harlem/New York City, NY; Washington, DC; Albuquerque, NM; Detroit, MI; New Orleans, LA; and the Hopi Reservation in AZ), serving 450 students during year one and 650 students by year five. The HCS has successfully evolved highly successful programs at engaging, training and retention of minorities and under-resourced and under-served youth communities in STEM disciplines. It believes in a hands-on approach to education, where such students are paired with scientists and provides tutoring so that they can participate fully and join an existing research team. Students are given individual projects within the investigation - the essence of HCS academic enrichment and mentoring program.  To-date, all (100%) HCS program participants have stayed in school, eventually graduating from high school and enrolling in college/university, 80% continue their studies in STEM fields. Program-wide, more than 60% of program participants come from families where a language other than English is spoken in the home.The HCS is addressing Absolute Priority 4-Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools and Competitive Preference Priority 6 and Competitive Preference Priority 7 and Competitive Preference Priority 8 (Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEAs)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: iOn Success Collaborative
Project Description: "The iOn Success Collaborative will partner Harlingen CISD, Manor ISD and five neighboring rural schooldistricts in the Lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas. The absolute priorities of the collaborative are: (1) tobuild capacity through teacher and principal effectiveness and; (2) enhance student learning for college andcareer readiness and provide high quality assessments. Competitive priorities addressed will focus on: (1)college access and success; (2) innovative practice serving at-risk and English Language Learners (ELL); and(3) serve a large population of students in rural districts.The iOn Success Collaborative will provide teachers and principals with professional development fromspecialists in the areas of math, science, technology, leadership, and English Language Learners (ELL). Theprogram design for this validation grant stems from a successful partnership between Harlingen CISD andManor ISD known as Project Connect 21. Preliminary findings from Project Connect 21 indicate significantgains through the practice of Project-Based Learning and implementation of the 21st Century learningframework. Replicating effective practices and creating professional learning communities, partneringdistricts anticipate continued significant gains.The project anticipates training approximately 350 teachers and administrators, and serving 20, 000 students overthe course of five years. Along with specialists at the district and campus level, partnering districts lookforward to additional support from the private sector including non-profit supporters which brings expertiseand dedication to the project."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Harrison School District Two Effectiveness and Results Pay for Performance
Project Description: "Harrison School District will be applying under the Investing in Innovation Development Grant program to introduce our Effectiveness and Results (E&R) Pay-for-Performance program. This program includes a rigorous teacher evaluation component, and a pay scale reflective of the teachers? effectiveness on student achievement along with other factors weighted into the evaluation.The main goal of the E&R program is having an effective teacher (Effectiveness) in every classroom, ultimately significantly improving student achievement and student success (Results) from Pre-K to beyond the graduation, for every student in the District. The four primary objectives of our program include are 1) by the 2013 CSAP, the District?s composite student proficient or advanced scores on the 27 CSAP exams will equal or exceed the state average; 2) by the 2013 CSAP, the District surpasses the state?s median longitudinal growth measure (50) on at least 16 of the 21 exams for which longitudinal growth is calculated; 3) For the end of the 2010-2011 school year (July, 2011), the District improves retention of high quality staff as measured by a 20% decrease in the number of proficient teachers resigning from positions in the District (using 2009-2010 data as a baseline); 4) for the 2012-2013 school year, the District improves teacher performance as measured by a 20% increase in the number of teachers receiving a proficient evaluation, using 2009-2010 data as a baseline.Harrison School District has a diverse student population of 10,600 students. We will be partnering officially with the Daniels Fund, and other partners are currently being sought."

Project Title: Betances Early Reading Lab PreK-3 Lab School
Project Description: "The Betances Early Reading PreK-3 Lab School being proposed by the Hartford Public Schools, the LEA inHartford, Connecticut, is a five year project that will create an innovative learning community by joiningtogether two powerful components. The core of the project is a PreK-3 school structure, which will immerseyoung learners in a rich literacy curriculum in the framework of a stable, consistent and aligned schoolenvironment that will facilitate grade transitions. The other integral component of this project is the EarlyLiteracy Professional Development Center. This Center is designed to create a learning community of teachersand staff who are dedicated to continually gathering, analyzing, reflecting and acting on data in order tomaximize student learning."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Higher Levels of Literacy for All Project
Project Description: "Hartland Consolidated Schools is requesting an i3 developmental grant to support our proposed Higher Levels of Literacy for All Project.  The HLLAP project is designed to utilize the highly effective Reading Recovery training program to improve student and teacher performance.  K-6 special education and K-2 general education teachers will receive intensive ongoing professional development in order to gain expertise in the area of literacy instruction and intervention.  Increased teacher effectiveness will close the achievement gap within our at-risk population, reducing the misdiagnosis of students as needing special education services.  Our project goals include; increased teacher effectiveness (absolute priority 1), closing the achievement gap (competitive preference priority 7), reducing special education numbers (competitive preference priority 7) and developing a system for continuous improvement (A2)"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Literacy Training Center
Project Description: "Haskins Laboratories of New Haven, founded in 1935, is an internationally-recognized, multidisciplinary institution which produces research that enhances our understanding of, and reveals ways to remediate speech perception and production, reading and reading disabilities, and human communication. Haskins also promotes the science of teaching reading through professional development and advocacy to inform public policy.Haskins will partner with the Boards of Education in the Cities of Norwalk, Stamford, and Weston CT, to create a sustainable, regional Literacy Training Center (LTC) that will translate cutting-edge research into classroom practice using scientific evidence and research-based methods of instruction Weston has a percentage of students whose needs aren't being met because of an identified reading disability. Norwalk and Stamford are cities with a concentration of high-need students, including economically disadvantaged students, English Language Learners and students with reading disabilities. Eleven of Norwalk's 19 schools are classified as 'in need of improvement,' as are 19 of Stamford's 20 schools. The LTC will provide Tier 3 interventions for 1476 1st-5th grade students at risk for reading failure, and students identified as having reading disabilities, with the goal of closing the achievement gap by:1.	Increasing the number of students at or above proficiency on the DRA2 by 10 % each year.  2.	Decreasing the number of students at basic or below on the DRA2 by 10 % each year.  3.	Increasing the number of students who are at goal on Connecticut Mastery Test (CMT) in the target population by 20 % over the four years of the intervention. Central to the project is a strong teacher training component that will improve teacher and school leader effectiveness.  An external project evaluator will assess the project's results. We will use specific evaluative information to write a design manual to facilitate replication in other settings."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Language Arts Multicultural Program (LAMP)
Project Description: "Hawaii County Economic Opportunity Council's Language Arts Multicultural Program (LAMP) uses alternative measures for learning, i.e., the positive behavioral development of high-need students that enhance academic achievement by stimulating their natural and inherent ability to develop steps in learning how to learn. LAMP staff assists LEA teachers in the classroom, particularly being vigilant of the performance of high-need students so LAMP staff is prepared to provide remedy in after-school sessions. Emphasis on fostering internality in students; homework completion; cultural activities; use of computer and other manipulatives; games requiring concentration, musical instruments, and parent participation are part of LAMP after-school activities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Hawaii  Department of Education Advanced Placement Initiative
Project Description: "More than 50 research studies show that rigorous courses of study, particularly Advanced Placement, significantly improve academic achievement and college performance. Since 2007, Hawaii has increased the number of students taking Advanced Placement courses by 19%, maintained a graduation rate at 80%, and decreased the dropout rate decreased to 15.4%. However a gap still exists for low-income students who represent 42 % of the student population but only 15.4% of the students taking exams for advanced placement in college. The Hawaii Department of Education (Hawaii) is the nation?s only statewide education agency (SEA) and a local education agency (LEA) for 170,488 students. It is a chain of islands covering 6,423 square miles in the central Pacific Ocean. Hawaii is applying for a Validation grant under Absolute Priority 3: Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High Quality Assessments; Competitive Preference Priority 6: Innovations that Support College Access and Success; and Competitive Preference Priority 8 ? Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEAs. Hawaii is requesting $7,640,358 in i3 grant funds for a comprehensive four-year validation project to scale-up and strengthen its successful Advanced Placement college preparation program statewide to increase equity and excellence for 80,000 secondary students and 1,500 teachers. Through this project, Hawaii proposes to: 1) Ensure access to Advanced Placement? courses for all students statewide; 2) Implement a research-based intensive college preparatory curriculum for targeted students in up to 10 high-need middle and high schools distributed across the islands; 3) Expand its library of AP online/virtual courses and supplemental services for students and teachers; and 4) Provide high-quality, job-embedded educator professional development to increase educator effectiveness statewide."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: 21st Century Teaching and Learning: High Tech Math Project
Project Description: "The Hawaii High School Consortium is collaborating in a project to create a 21st Century teaching and learningenvironment to support ?every student to become proficient in the knowledge and skills of mathematics inorder to be successful in postsecondary education and high-skilled careers without the need for remediation.?This Consortium of 6 high schools envisions a ?High Tech Math Project? that will incorporate interactivewhiteboards, learner response systems and digital media to encourage conceptual learning and a change ininstructional pedagogy to engage students and better meet their learning needs. A particular focus on thesubgroup populations of Special Education, English Language Learners and Disadvantaged will show theimpact of innovative strategies and instructional methods using new technologies and is expected to close theachievement gap for students in these subgroups. Teachers will participate in a systematic exploration ofintegrated technology in a supported and sequential continuum of professional development over a 4-yearperiod. Online programs in current implementation at the schools and supporting research have shown thatthese strategies work for all students, and that these subgroup populations have shown significant gains inacademics and confidence as learners. It is anticipated that student growth will be seen in test scores,confidence with emerging technologies and in authentic application of mathematics concepts in everyday life."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Health & Education Research Operative Services, Inc.
Project Title: Project Comet
Project Description: "Class-size Reduction (CSR) in grades K-3 has been shown to cost-effectively improve teacher effectiveness, increase student achievement rates, close achievement gaps, improve graduation rates, college attendance, provide long-term health benefits, and lower teen pregnancies.  Few experimental studies, if any, have confirmed the value of effective teaching in small classes beyon grade 3.  Key Activities: 1) teacher training on differentiated instruction; 2) principal/teacher collaborative learning sessions; 3) high inference measures of teacher effectiveness; and 4) randomized, experimental within-school design.  We wish to provide Scientific Based Research to determine the value of CSR in supporting effective teaching practices that meet the education needs of 4th and 5th graders, especially high-need students.  Based on evidence from the STAR Experiment, CSR in grade 4 and 5 should result in more effective teaching practices, which will lead to improved student performance."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: HealthCorps Expansion
Project Description: "In the style of a Peace Corps-like program, HealthCorps introduces high-need secondary students to an innovative health and nutrition education curriculum using recent college graduates as peer mentors. Education is a critical component of the dual national service program, which also promotes healthy futures for students and community members. Serving two-year program cycles, school-based Education and Peer Mentor Coordinators first undergo a month-long pre-service training. Coordinators' primary on-site activities include real-time classroom participation (augmenting and strengthening, not replacing or duplicating local teaching resources), and extracurricular activity development and coordination. The applicant proposes to expand the development of the program to new low-performing, high-poverty high schools in the rural regions of the Mississippi Delta, California's San Fernando Valley, Florida's Hillsborough County, as well as urban schools in Cleveland, Ohio, and New York City."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: emPowerU: Transformative Learning Culture
Project Description: "The partners in the emPowerU Transformative Learning Culture Project, including LEA's, Institutions of HighersEducation, and a Not-forProfit organization, will address five challenge categories both systematically andschool-wide. The five challenges are: School Culture, Principals as 'Learning Leaders,' Learning involvingrange of competencies, Rurality/Geographic Isolation, and Technology. The overall goal of the project is towork systematically and system-wide with all partners to transform the rural school culture toward an'unwavering belief in the abilty of all students to achieve success' beginning with principals and teachers, forthe purpose of improving students academic, civic, and employabilty outcomes."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Numeracy Team - A Proposal to Improve Teacher Effectiveness in Teaching High School Math
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: HELIX NETWORK OF EDUCATIONAL CHOICES DBA MENTORSHIP ACADEMY
Project Title: "The Integration of Education and Mentoring For Innovative Learning and Teaching Styles of STEM Subjects and the Digital Arts"
Project Description: "The Mentorship Academy of Baton Rouge will encompass two of the nation's most innovative charter highschools and will provide hands-on learning opportunities for students beginning in the ninth grade in year2010-2011. Each year thereafter the school will add an additional grade level until grade 12. Class size willnot exceed 25 students.There will be two schools within the Academy: Mentorship Academy of Science and Technology (MAST) andMentorship Academy of the Digital Arts (MADA).The Mentorship Academy of Baton Rouge is located in the downtown metropolitan area at 339 Florida Street,Baton Rouge, LA 70801. This will be the Academy?s first year of operation accepting students into the ninthgrade for the 2010-2011 Academic School Year. The mission of the Mentorship Academy is to assist in thedevelopment of young adults who learn continuously as our economies and communities change. This isaccomplished through mentoring relationships with industry professionals, project-based learning, crosscurricularteaching, and technology integration.Integration of various student projects will be a challenging bureaucratic, cultural and programmatic enterprise.It will be necessary to cross curriculum boundaries, address different academic cultures and norms, and ensurethe integrity of the courses, especially with regard to adding to and not diluting their impact. To accomplishthis, the integration efforts will be coordinated by and led by the PI and Co-PI/Program Coordinator with theassistance and advice of the academic instructors. The I3 project will focus on the following: (1) Project basedlearning and student presentations; (2) Student Advocacy and Leadership Development; (3) AcademicCoaching Program; (4) Student Showcases and participation in the High School Louisiana Science andEngineering Fair Projects and Digital Arts Creations Competition. (5) Summer Outreach Programs for studentsat univ across the US and Teacher Training Programs"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Professional Development Academy
Project Description: "Hemet Unified School District's (HUSD) Professional Development Academy (PDA) provides district-wide research-based professional development to increase teacher and principal effectiveness. The PDA implements a unique coaching cycle, where all teachers and principals are trained and supported in the use of research-based instruction strategies, district adopted curriculum, data analysis, and technology. Teachers and principals will become highly effective because of training and support received in research-based delivery of core curriculum using Direct Interactive Instruction (DII). According to research conducted by Binder (1998), DII may be the most thoroughly validated and consistently effective method of instructional delivery. The interactive teacher delivery model ensures that academic goals are clear to students, time allocated for instruction is sufficient, content is strongly congruent with skills, and concepts most often associated with basic information gathering are obtained. The PDA is exemplary because of  the way professional development is delivered, monitored, and supported through a continuous and systematic coaching cycle; which includes data analysis, formal training, demonstration lessons, in-classroom support, observation and feedback, and resources. The proposed model has resulted in increased academic achievement and increased principal and teacher effectiveness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Southwest Arkansas College Prep Academy
Project Description: "The State of Arkansas lags far behind the rest of the nation in equipping its residents with college degrees. TheSouthwest Arkansas College Prep Academy represents a cost-efficient, effective, and replicable approach foraddressing this problem. The Prep Academy is modeled on a pilot program that has operated for two years inClark County, Arkansas. The Prep Academy targets 8th-graders who indicate a desire to go to college butscore below benchmarks on the EXPLORE test. The four-year program brings participants onto a collegecampus for two weeks of rigorous academic instruction each summer plus monthly Saturday sessions duringthe school year. Courses are team-taught by college professors and high school teachers who employ proventest preparation curricula in addition to student-centered, culturally responsive, and other innovative instructionstrategies.
