Students also receive study skills instruction, assistance in applying for college and financial aid,and exposure to the college environment. The applicant and partners request a $2,791,671 Development grantto scale up the Prep Academy into a regional initiative, covering a seven-county area across SouthwestArkansas. The project will grow steadily to serve 768 students per year by Year 4. Outcome goals include:90% of participants complete four years of the program; 100% of completing participants graduate from highschool; 75% of completing participants score 19 or higher on all sections of the ACT (the standard for gainingunconditional acceptance into college); and 90% of completing participants attend college; and 75% of collegeattendees go on to a second year of college. More broadly, the goal of the project is to demonstrate thereplicability and scalability of the Prep Academy approach by employing it in a variety of different settings,connecting it with existing programs, and conducting extensive data collection and evaluation to monitor andenhance the program."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project STRIVE (Student and Teacher Resources for Innovation in Virginia Education)
Project Description: "To develop citizens capable of competing and succeeding in an ever-changing global workplace, educators must focus on providing students with real world experiences and 21st century skills.  To truly prepare students for higher level courses, emphasis must also be placed on the assessment of 21st century skills through use of engaging technologies in collaborative, inquiry-based learning environments with teachers and students using technology's power to transform knowledge and skills into products, solutions, and new information as deeper measures of learning. Project STRIVE is an opportunity to determine the power of collaboration between a textbook publisher, technology software provider, and highly qualified teachers to create engaging 21st century learning environments for the success of all students. Henrico County Public Schools is applying for an i3 Development grant under Absolute Priority 3: Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments. The merging of textbook publisher content with an interactive technology platform and high quality teaching through a student centered instructional design will provide for a richer learning experience for students.  It will provide the structure to take assessment of student learning, both summative and formative, to higher levels.  Project STRIVE will also address Competitive Priority 7: Innovations that address the unique learning needs of students with disabilities and Limited English Proficiency Students. The pilot schools in which this new model of teaching and assessing will be developed and tested have a high percentage of students with disabilities as well as other high-needs students. These students are typically underrepresented in high-level courses through their educational career. STRIVE will raise the expectation for these students and will provide an instructional setting with alternatives to the typical text-based content and multiple-choice assessments."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Ruskin Literacy Grant
Project Description: "The Ruskin Literacy Project (RLP) addresses Absolute Priority 4: Innovations that Turn Around PersistentlyLow-Performing Schools and Absolute Priority and Competitive Preference Priority 6: Innovations thatSupport College Access and Success. This project will provide support to develop content-area high schoolteachers as effective content literacy instructors. Students will benefit from this instruction making it possiblefor more students to access a successful post secondary education. This project is based on a model used byBenton High School in St. Joseph, Missouri for the past four years. Using Benton HS?s model and adding thecomponents of current research we are proposing a Development Grant which through increased and focusedliteracy strategies will turn a persistently low-performing school into one where all students will read on gradelevel, write coherently, speak with purpose and focus and think critically to solve problems."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Mississippi Early Childhood Education Innovation: Developing Data Driven Instruction
Project Description: "The objectives of this project are to provide professional development support to teachers so they can effectively use ongoing progress monitoring data on children?s growth to inform their use of developmentally appropriate early childhood education practices. Additionally, this project seeks to create an alignment of the preschool and early elementary systems through a data driven school improvement process that includes the input of community stakeholders. Expected outcomes of the project are increased quality of preschool, kindergarten, and first grade classroom environments, alignment and implementation of best practices by preschool and early elementary teachers, increased understanding and commitment to quality early childhood education by community stakeholders, increased school readiness of children and improved student achievement in elementary school. This project includes intensive (20 days) of professional development, the ongoing support of teacher mentors, and valid and reliable child, program, and school assessment tools to drive instruction and school policies and practices."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: High Tech High Flex to College
Project Description: "IHigh Tech High (HTH), a lottery-admission public charter school network, will partner with Carnegie MellonUniversity (CMU) to expand college access, entry, and completion rates for underserved students in rural andurban areas in California. The partners will adapt CMU?s validated college open online courses in science,technology, engineering and math (STEM), pilot them in high schools, and train teachers in their use. CK-12Foundation will offer state-approved standards-based digital STEM FlexBooks. Qualcomm will sponsor highneedstudents with access to personal mobile devices with mobile broadband connectivity. WestEd willconduct an impact evaluation utilizing a cluster-randomized controlled trial. Over five years, the project willintroduce six adapted CMU courses to 60 high schools, reaching over 18,000 students in rural and urbanschools and achieving a significantly higher rate of college prep course completion. By training teachers, theproject will trigger a sustainable, steady rate of expanded access to college gatekeeper courses, and subsequentcollege access, entry, and completion rates. This program will serve as a model for other states to increaseaccess to their public university systems."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Tomorrow's Schools Today
Project Description: "The High Tech High Graduate School of Education (HTH-GSE) will partner with High Tech High (HTH), a lottery-admission public charter school, to develop highly effective teachers and principals in approximately 175 new and existing schools serving 130,000 students nationwide. In a blend of residencies at HTH, and online training, teams of educators will acquire project-based teaching methods and develop strategies for enhancing teacher effectiveness by developing a culture of adult collaboration in their own schools.By fostering adult collaboration, the Tomorrow's Schools Today (TST) will boost the quality of leadership and instruction, the retention of teachers, and the engagement and achievement of students. At full implementation scale, TST will annually train 100 teachers and principals from 45-50 schools through the School Innovation Fellowship (SIF) and the HTH-GSE Master in Education (M.Ed.) programs in Teacher Leadership (TL) and School Leadership (SL). Participants will demonstrate improvement measured by changes in teacher behavior, innovations in curriculum and support structures, and high school students' acquisition of 21st century learning skills."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
Supporting Implementation of High Standards and Quality Assessments
by Providing High-Quality Academic Support During Out-Of-School Time
Project Description: "Higher Achievement is an after-school and summer academic enrichment program targeting high-need childrenin grades 5 through 8 from low-income communities. The program closes a persistent achievement gap byproviding 650 hours of intense academic training using an accelerated curriculum aligned to state and nationalstandards within a culture of strong relationships during the critical middle school years. HigherAchievement?s 35 years of experience and positive outcomes merit serious consideration as an evidence-based,results-driven best practice model that can be replicated nationally.In partnership with the District of Columbia Public Schools, Baltimore City Public Schools, and RichmondPublic Schools, Higher Achievement seeks a $4,990,199 Development Grant over a four-year period to: 1)increase the number of students served by 700 to assess the model?s replication potential in multipleenvironments; 2) enhance its standards-based curriculum, infusing it with college and career readinessstandards and packaging it in an easy to use format, and 3) evaluate curriculum and program implementation invarious settings resulting in a practice guide to be distributed to the field.Higher Achievement?s goal is to raise the academic achievement of high-need middle school students andsuccessfully transition them to high school. Measurable objectives are: 50% of scholars will increase a fullletter grade, improve on standardized tests, and reduce their school absenteeism, and 80% of programgraduates will advance to top high schools. Outcomes include: scholars will report gaining confidence in theiracademic abilities and that they feel academically motivated; scholars will be prepared for high school and willattend college."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Data Analysis to Achieve Reading Targets for Students (DAARTS)
Project Description: "Abstract for Data Analysis to Achieve Reading Targets for Students (DAARTS) projectProject description: Highline Public School District (HPS) in Seattle, Washington requests a development grant to ensure that teachers are able to effectively teach reading to students, particularly those who are high-risk, so they achieve benchmark by the end of the 3rd grade. The project addresses Absolute Priority 2 (innovative use of data), with project activities focused on aligning HPS' assessments and curriculum with the Washington state standards; training teachers to analyze that data and proactively adjust his/her instructional strategies to meet the needs of individual students, groups of students and his/her classroom as a whole; and partnering with the Community Schools Collaborative (CSC) and the White Center Community Development Association (CDA), community-based organizations that will provide health resources and out-of-school time (OST) programming that supports students' literacy achievement. Foundations, Inc. will provide technical assistance and capacity building around research-based literacy strategies. This project is innovative in that it focuses on ensuring that teachers are skilled at providing core literacy instruction and tracking student progress using reliable data, as opposed to waiting to intervene until students show signs of struggling to grasp reading skills. A special feature of the DAARTS project is that it addresses literacy within the context of the needs of the whole child, such as identifying health and developmental issues that delay reading and family issues that affect school attendance. Objectives and outcomes include improving teachers' ability to teach reading; increasing the number of K-3 students who reach benchmark each year; and replicating school structures that prove effective at increasing student literacy. HPS' target service numbers include 2,508 students directly served during the 5-year project period and an additional 2,94"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Math Instruction for 2015:  Research into Practice?????
Project Description: "The Math Instruction for 2015:  Research into Practice Development Grant will successfully impact student achievement in math by its systemic approach which fully utilizes technology as part of a comprehensive professional development plan to efficiently and effectively change teacher behaviors to enable them to implement Response to Intervention (RtI) in mathematics.  The educational leaders of HSD1J hypothesize that teachers need full implementation of a systemic professional development plan with technological innovations to more efficiently and effectively implement RtI in math with diverse student learners.  The specific aspects of the Math Instruction for 2015:  Research into Practice project are a web-based management system that fully integrates curriculum, assessment, instructional strategies, and professional development to support real-time data-driven decision making related to student mastery of standards aligned to the Common Core together with a system model for professional development that promotes full implementation at the 95%  level and provides for teacher mastery of the math content through the use of studio classrooms, on-line professional development, side-by-side modeling and coaching, and instructional rounds.  This project will add to the research base by implementing a quasi-experimental study of over 30,000 students utilizing clear goals:o	HSD1J students will complete higher levels of math courses which will prepare them for success in college.o	HSD1J students will demonstrate improved performance on objective math tests.o	HSD1J teachers will demonstrate their understanding of pedagogyo	HSD1J teachers will demonstrate their understanding of math contento	HSD1J teachers will utilize high leverage practices to impact student achievement"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: HW-SC School Turnaround Project
Project Description: "This project responds to a request from the Rochester City School District (RCSD) for Hillside Work-ScholarshipConnection (HW-SC) to initiate scaled-up delivery of its student support model as an integral component ofRCSD?s mandated turnaround plan for persistently low achieving schools (Portfolio Schools Plan 2010-2012).HW-SC?s student support model blends wrap-around school and community based guidance, academicsupport, work readiness, job-placement, post secondary planning, advocacy, and crisis counseling services ?and has a demonstrated track record of both significantly improving the graduation rate of participating highneed students, and of supporting their successful entry into, and retention in, post secondary educationpathways. RCSD has asked HW-SC to initiate scaled-up delivery of its student support model at four of itspersistently low achieving high schools (or their successors) ? all of which are undergoing a mandatedturnaround process. HW-SC will look to serve approximately 50% of the high needs students in each of theseschools. Each participating student will receive up to 4 years of intensive support, and 2 years of follow-up --all anchored by a Youth Advocate and driven by an Individual Graduation Plan.This project is designed to support the turnaround of persistently low achieving schools -- as demonstrated by theleading indicators of improved attendance, increased grade-level promotion, and decreased drop-out rates;along with the lagging indicators of increased graduation rates, and both college access and success. Otheroutcomes that will be tracked via HW-SC?s online Efforts Towards Outcomes database include (i) the % ofstudents with an Individual Graduation Plan; (ii) the % of students completing the Youth EmploymentTraining Academy; (iii) the % of eligible students employed by HW-SC?s employer partners; and (iv) the % ofstudents completing HW-SC?s Post Secondary Planning and Support program."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Hispanic Youth Institute: A Targeted College Preparatory Program That Improves High-Need Student Achievement
Project Description: "The Hispanic College Fund, a national nonprofit organization, requests a development grant of $2,239,161 to scale the Hispanic Youth Institute and turn around four persistently low-performing schools by integrating student supports into the school model to address non-academic barriers to student achievement. The Hispanic Youth Institute is currently run in eight communities nationwide and will serve more than 1,000 students in the summer of 2010. It consists of a summer college residency on a regional university campus that is followed by year-round information and outreach that reinforce the key themes of the program:  Achieve a college education, pursue a professional career (with an emphasis on business and STEM), and give back to your community as volunteers.This five-year grant will be utilized to serve 4,600 students in four Innovation Fund Absolute Priority 4 Schools: Andrew Putnam Hill High School (San Jose, CA); Carl Hayden Community High School (Phoenix, AZ); R.L. Turner High School (Carrollton, TX); and Woodrow Wilson High School (Los Angeles, CA). The Institute addresses specific issues that research has shown are fundamental postsecondary matriculation stumbling blocks for the Hispanic community: By the end of each year, 75% of the students served will report an understanding of the college application and financing process, access to professional mentors, and the possession of a peer network that supports their success. Through the development and mobilization of peer leaders, the Hispanic Youth Institute will foster a college-going culture among Hispanic-majority schools, resulting in widespread student achievement improvements in some of America's most challenged secondary institutions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Hispanic Information and Telecommunications Network, Inc.
Project Title: HITN's Community Connect to Success
Project Description: "The Community Connect to Success project enlists partners within four regions of New York: Brooklyn, the Bronx, Amsterdam, and Buffalo.  All four of these regions are characterized by high poverty, English language learners, a relatively low median age, and a significant Latino population.The overarching goal of this project is to implement innovative distance learning strategies and socio-emotional supports for struggling students at virtual learning sites within community-based organizations, which will aid in turning around persistently low-performing high schools in New York according to Absolute Priority #4.Under this goal there are three objectives:  1) implement innovative programs to enable high school students to successfully prepare for college admission (to meet Competitive Priority 6); 2) implement innovative practices, strategies and programs designed to address the unique learning needs of limited English proficient students (to meet Competitive Priority 7); 3) build on the research of this relatively untested program through rigorous, independent, third party evaluation.Instructional time for core subjects will be increased through self-paced online courses, supplemented by socio-emotional supports to address non-academic barriers to student achievement through partnership with community-based organizations (CBOs).  The project will expand new methods of curriculum delivery that are being proven successful through a current project in collaboration with Lehman College. Expected outcomes: serve at least 450 students per year (an average of 75 students per site); achieve a sustained participation rate of 75% (1,013 students over three years); and have a positive outcome to the hypothesis of 'Students receiving intervention treatment will demonstrate greater academic gains than do students in the control group'."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Missouri Literacy Standards Project
Project Description: "The Missouri Literacy Standards Project (MLSP) is a collaboration between ten rural Missouri school districts, the Missouri Reading Initiative professional development program and the Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.  Project activities include alignment of state curricular standards with professional development in literacy, development of supportive systems of high quality assessments and implementation of a multi-year profession development program in high needs rural schools.  Two hypotheses are proposed for the project: H1: Student achievement will improve as measured on MAP scores.  H2: Professional development will result in classroom practices which will be more aligned to core standards as compared to before program implementation.   The goals of MLSP are:  1)  The useful application of new curricular frameworks based on the Common Core Standards in English/Language Arts and Literacy in History/Social Studies and Science;  2) Support of systems of high quality assessments so that those frameworks become common practice in Missouri schools; 3) Improved classroom practice; 4) Improved student achievement.  The eventual outcome of the grant project will be, if deemed successful after a rigorous evaluation, a scale-up to statewide implementation. The five-year project will impact 6,500 - 7,500 students.?????"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Comprehensive Summer Learning Program
Project Description: "The proposed project will leverage Holy Cross?s educational expertise in the expansion of evidence-based practices that will target children birth to 3rd grade with strategic services and the primary goal of achieving grade level educational milestones for its participants.  The three primary objectives are: first, facilitate successful transition from early childhood education to kindergarten, second, maintain connections with families while providing support services to parents and their children year-round, and third, maintain educational records of each student in order to address educational barriers, developmental delays, unidentified disabilities, and/or other educational or health related issues.  The provision of services for students will be academic, cultural, health, nutrition, disability related, and social service while the parents will receive parenting, job training, financial literacy, and leadership training services."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: HOPE Center, Inc.

Applicant: Horizons National Student Enrichment Program, Inc.
Project Title: Summer-Specific Student Assessment Project
Project Description: "Horizons National, a national network of high-quality summer learning programs for low-income elementary and middle public-school students, will work in partnership with the National Summer Learning Association (NSLA), the nation's network hub for thousands of summer-learning programs and stakeholders across the country,   and Wireless Generation (WGen), an educational technology firm, in the creation of summer-specific assessment and intervention tools.  These technology-enhanced assessments will measure student academic growth in summer learning programs and district summer programs for eventual use by summer programs nationwide.  Horizons will contribute to the design, pilot the tools and develop more robust relationships with its partner public schools in more than 20 LEAs to support 12-month learning for low-income students most affected by summer learning loss.  Following the grant term, WGen and NSLA will make these summer-specific tools, including on-line training platforms and other grant products, widely available to public schools and other summer learning programs.Official LEA partners include Wicomico County, MD and Chatham County, GA.  Horizons works in partnership with public schools in sixteen other districts nationwide, all of whom will benefit from this project; we expect to include several more of them, including New York City and Washington, DC, as official partners by September.    LEAs have no cost, but  will be asked to exchange data and participate in consultation regarding mutual students.  Other partners:  National Summer Learning Association, Inc. and Wireless Generation Inc.2,500 low-income K-8 Horizons students in twenty-four school districts, and more than 200 students from other summer programs and district summer schools will be involved over the four-year project period. Once the products, systems and protocols are developed, the potential students that would benefit from their use could number several hundred thousand."

Project Title: Hornell Holding Our Own (H2O2) Projecet
Project Description: "The H2O2 Project will: a) expand an evidence-based, alternative program for at-risk students in grades 7-9 byproviding early and ongoing interventions; b) enrich a BOCES-led alternative program for students in grades 10-12 through on-line curricula and work experiences; c) integrate digital technologies; d) utilize a case managementapproach; and e) engage students in service learning and volunteer experiences. A rigorous evaluation led byprincipal investigators at Syracuse University will test the H2O2 hypothesis that this combination of resources andservices will: a) increase credits attained by at-risk students; b) improve graduation rates and reduce drop outrates; c) increase student content knowledge; d) enhance the quality of 7-12 teaching; e) enhance student?s locusof control; and f) enhance student?s preparedness for college and careers. H2O2 is poised to develop acomprehensive model that meets the needs of at-risk students and ensures that they develop the skills to graduateand transition to college and careers. More importantly, the model may be replicated across New York andbeyond, further leveraging U.S. Department of Education funds."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Houston A+ Challenge Network
Project Description: "Project Title:  Houston A+ Challenge Network			Grant Type:  Development    A+ hypothesizes that focusing on the students in the middle, differentiating student instruction and teacher development, and involving all stakeholders-from superintendents to parents-will produce the following four measures of success:  1) Improve teacher practice and increase teacher capacity;  2) Increase the achievement and college readiness of targeted middle school students; 3) Increase student achievement for all students in the targeted cohort grades;  and 4) Sustainable gains at a campus after the first two years of intense engagement.  A+ will use i3 funding to launch the innovative Challenge Network in order to build capacity in middle schools and significantly increase the number of students who are not just proficient, but on track to be truly college ready.  With each partner school, A+ performance coaches will analyze student data of incoming 6th graders and engage parents whose students achieved proficiency but fell short of commended in the previous year.  Coaches will work intensely with teachers, principals, and the targeted cohorts in each school in literacy or numeracy for a period of two years.  The Challenge Network program aligns with Absolute Priority 2:  Innovations That Improve the Use of Data and Priority 3:  Innovations That Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-quality Assessment   Target number of students to be served: 15,500 students in five districts in three years    Special project features: The Houston A+ Challenge believes that ignoring the importance of middle schools, over-relying on proficiency levels as an indicator of success, and the failure of public and charter school districts to share effective practices, must cease.    Official and other partners:  Houston A+ Challenge and five Texas public school districts-Aldine, Alief, Goose Creek, Humble, and YES Prep."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Project Exemplary Learning through Newcomer Centers (Project XLNC)
Project Description: "The Houston Independent School District (HISD) has designed and proposes an I3 Development Grant, ProjectExemplary Learning through Newcomer Centers (XLNC), as an innovative program of reform to serve 710secondary (grades 6-12) immigrant English Language Learners (ELL) students during the first and second yearof enrollment in US schools. HISD personnel have evaluated student data, interviewed teachers/administrators,surveyed students, and reviewed national research/district programs concerning effective secondary ELLprogramming. Project XLNC proposes a multi-faceted approach of Newcomer Center development, includingprofessional development, student enrichment and acculturation, ESL material and technology infusion,college readiness, and family involvement. Project XLNC proposes to support participating students within asmall learning academy with coursework emphasizing English language and literacy development. TheNewcomer Centers will employ a program coordinator, a social/outreach worker, and native language tutors tofurther support the proposed instructional program. All instructional staff will be supported in a reflectivecoaching model with comprehensive professional development utilizing Sheltered Instructional ObservationalProtocol (SIOP), sheltered content, and instructional technology strategies. The instructional program will befurther enhanced with a variety of ESL materials and instructional technology. Expected outcomes includeincreased passing rates on state assessments (TAKS and TELPAS) and higher high school completion rates. Asupplemental online reading development program designed for ELL students will be implemented to supportstudent achievement. A college bound culture will be developed with the proposed partnership at theUniversity of Houston (Downtown) and the University of St. Thomas with project students and their familiesempowered to successfully access post-secondary educational opportunities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Transforming Teaching for Student Success (T2 S2)
Project Description: "The Howard County Public School System and its partners will implement a comprehensive, research-basedplan to effectively integrate technology into the classroom through intensive application of student-basedtechnology as the primary medium for instruction, intensive professional development, co-teaching, andcreation of learning communities.The initiative will provide multiple and flexible methods of presentation, expression and engagement to addressthe needs of high needs, diverse student populations. HCPSS also will provide access to technology-basedinstructional materials to parents so they can support the academic success of their children. The approach isbased upon the strategies described in the text, Using Technology with Classroom Instruction that Works(Pitler, Hubbell, Kuhn, Malenoski)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The School & Talent Development Model: A Collaboration between Yale and Howard University
Project Description: "This 'Validation Proposal' is the merging of the School Development Program (Yale University) and Talent Quest (Howard University) school reform initiatives into the School and Talent Development Model. This merged design applies child, adolescent, and talent development principles at the school and classroom level.  The School Development Program (SDP) and Talent Quest (TQ) initiatives both have had successful experiences in empowering all educational enterprise stakeholders; affording these educators the understanding of child, adolescent and talent development principles via school improvement and capacity building projects, leading to higher academic outcomes for urban and minority students. Bringing the two school reform approaches together, should result in even greater breadth in school reform, and the implementation of complementary programs that should greatly insure high quality outcomes for students. The School and Talent Development Model (SaTDM) will seek to transform school structures; enable school leaders to be change agents; improve teaching expertise; provide developmentally appropriate evidence based instructional strategies; infuse whole child themes into curriculum modules; and conduct remedial/enrichment and school family community partnership programs. The activities originating from TQ will be first implemented inside classrooms and later in other school settings. Those originating from SDP will first be integrated at the macro school level and subsequently inside classrooms. This inside-out and outside-in dual approach is an innovation that we expect to reap great benefits for schools and the students that they serve. The SaTDM will work with 40 schools from the District of Columbia, Prince George's County, MD and Chicago, IL serving 20,000 low-performing students.  Community Academy Public Charter Schools in Washington DC (LEA) and the Chicago Public Schools (LEA) will serve as official partners with Yale and Howard for this project."

Applicant: Howard University Public Charter School of Mathematics and Science
Project Title: Excellence Equals Mastering and Succeeding in Mathematics and Science [E=(MS)2]
HUDDLE Learning, Inc. I-PATH
Project Description: "The current proposal will implement successful SES interventions, designed by HUDDLE, in 60 schools, which includes research based academic software, direct instruction, and tutor and student incentives, inside the school day in randomly selected design. In year one, classes will be randomly selected and half will serve as treatment groups. In the second year treatment and control groups will be reversed. All classes in the participating schools will receive treatment group activities in year three. The independent measure of progress is the NWEA MAP assessment developed by the Northwest Evaluation Association.  In addition, randomly selected schools will be chosen and teachers will receive bonuses (stipends/additional compensation) when classes exceed expected gains as measured by the NWEA assessments. Also, students in randomly selected schools will receive monetary awards for achieving higher than expected reading and/or math scores"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Human Development Corporation of Metropolitan St. Louis
Project Title: HDC CASASTART
Project Description: "HDC CASASTART is a community-based, school-centered program designed to keep high-risk 8 to 15 year-olds free of drug and crime involvement through an intensive and coordinated marriage of preventative services and community engagement. A central notion underlying this program is that while rates of experimentation with drugs and alcohol are roughly similar for pre-adolescents from all backgrounds, those who lack effective human and social support (i.e., family, school, and community organizations) are at much higher risk of continuing and intensifying substance abuse or involvement with juvenile crime. This program is deisgned to develop and compensate for these missing ties, thus reducing the risk factors in the youth's life and inreasing the likeliness they will continue on a positive direction toward completing highschool and continuing on with post-secondary education. Case management is at the center of the CASASTART program design. These individuals work to address the individual needs of participants as well as broader problems in their families and communities. In addition, CASASTART case managers work closely with teachers, police officers, social service agencies, and neighborhood residents to coordinate needed services and support to prevent or counteract the familial, social, educational, and psychological factors that make children vulnerable to substance abuse and juvenile crim. HDC will act as the lead agency in this program. All direct service staff will be actual employees of HDC, however, the case managers will be placed directly into 10 schools (both middle school and high school). Case managers will be responsible for working one-on-one with studetns and families as well as tracking the complete progress of the student. This work consists of assessing the specific risk factors that a child and their family is experiencing and brining in the proper community resources to address these issues."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Redwood Coast Program of Increased Expectations
Project Description: "Redwood Coast Program of Increased Expectations (RCPIE) RCPIE is a collaboration between the Humboldt and Del Norte Counties Offices of Education, 15 school districts, College of the Redwoods Humboldt State University, the United Way and Umpqua Bank.The United Way has pledged to raise up to 100% of our yearly match and provide staffing to coordinate a community-based mentoring program for 6-8 grade students; Umpqua Bank will provide staff time to support our Earn for College savings program.  We are also applying for funding with the Rural School & Community Trust and the i3 Foundation Registry.RCPIE meets Absolute Priority 3 with an innovative program of mentoring, modeling and monitoring which complements the ongoing implementation of high standards and high-quality formative assessments focusing on middle school students, teachers and parents. RCPIE also meets Competitive Preference Priorities 6, 7 & 8.RCPIE will provide site-based professional development at 23 schools for teachers including modeling of classroom practices taken from the AVID program and formative assessment support. The PD and mentoring, modeling and monitoring in participants' classrooms will translate the standards and information from assessments into classroom practices that meet the needs of all students, including high-need students.  RCPIE will provide local middle school students with a program that includes college readiness, career and college planning and college site visits. RCPIE will work with parents by providing (1) parent education and support, (2) an active role in the development of their child's 6-year plan, (3) transition to middle and high school support including training in Academic Socialization.RCPIE will train over 200 teachers and serve over 7,800 students over five years.RCPIE Goals Improve academic outcomes for all studentsClose the achievement gap for Native American, ELL and Low Income studentsImprove student readiness of college and careers?????"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Habor High School
Project Description: "Harbor High School is an alternative school setting for 120 at-risk students in grades 11 and 12.  The school's graduation rate ranges from 30 to 40 percent.  Student achievement data reveals small increases in this area, with standardized test scores well below state and county averages.  Not surprisingly, most students are reading 6 grades below their current grade level.  Economically disadvantages students make up well over 50% of the population and students-with-disabilities make-up 20% of the students.  Twenty percent of the students in the program have been incarcerated either during, or prior to, their schooling at Harbor High School.This project seeks to turn this school around using high school quality professional development,  coupled with instructional practices that integrate writing throughout all content areas; a solid Career Preparation System; academic partnerships with post-secondary institutions that facilitate duel enrollment, articulation agreements; expansion of students' opportunities to recover credit with flexible course scheduling that expands classes beyond traditional school hours and structures; academic partnerships that compliment core content coursework bringing the classroom into the real work.  One special interest is teaming with the film industry to prepare student for new employment opportunities in Michigan.  To support all aspects of the project, the incorporation of supports that remove non-academic barriers that interferes with academic success (such as providing students with skills and training to handle difficult problems).  The overarching instructional strategies will include a project-based, cross-curricular approach that uses technology to support all aspects of programming."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Communities for Student Achievement
Project Description: "The Communities for Student Achievement Project is a community-based partnership that engages all facets, individuals and groups within local communities to participate in the achievement of every child we serve.  We will engage 2,000 students at 12 public high schools located in Area 23 in Chicago, IL and 2 public high schools in rural Arkansas where 75 % of students are designated as high risk.   icouldbe.org is partnering with One-Economy (Official Partner), Monster.com (Other Partner), and Kuder, Inc. (Other Partner) to leverage the resources of these outstanding leaders in the field and combine our tested and proven curricula and content that includes online and in-person structured activities focused on career exploration, college preparation and parental and community involvement strategies for at-risk students across the US.  With this program model, we can surround each child with a minimum of seven caring adults who will individually work with them throughout their high school years.  Most importantly, this model is scalable, and can work in any size community."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Rio Grande Valley Center for Teaching and Leading Excellence
Project Description: "Title:  Rio Grande Valley Center for Teaching and Leading Excellence	Type:  Development    IDEA Public Schools, a high-performing charter management organization, and Pharr-San Juan-Alamo, a large, innovative public independent school district, will work in concert with Teach For America and Dr. Noel Tichy, who designed and helped launch the New York City Leadership Academy, to create an end-to-end human capital pipeline based on proven, yet innovative methods.  The Center will develop a permanent and sustainable capacity to recruit, select, onboard, evaluate, reward, support, train, and retain teachers and school leaders for both LEAs.  This work will create multiple pathways to teacher and school leadership, thereby increasing the number of highly effective teachers and school leaders for high-need students, which will increase student growth and achievement. (Absolute Priority 1).  Center goals include 1) increasing the number of new and experienced teachers and other instructional leaders that receives high-quality training and support;  2) increasing the percent of highly effective teachers and school leaders and 3) the number of students assigned to these teachers/leaders;  4) increasing student growth and achievement;  and 5) retaining high-quality teachers and leaders to support district growth.   Target number of students to be served in the project: 50,365 students by year 4    Special project features: The core strategy for the program is to work with innovative human capital experts to import proven human capital practices into IDEA and PSJA.  The Center will be developed as a semi-autonomous entity to promote its ability to focus on continuous improvement.  The core focus of the Center will include 1) recruitment and selection; 2) new teacher onboarding, training and support; 3) experienced teacher skill advancement; 4) instructional coach/assistant principal training and support;"

Applicant: Illinois Consortium for the 21st Century, Inc.
Project Title: The Enriched Learning Turn-around School Model
Project Description: "By integrating each element of the proposed next generation 21st Century Enriched Learning Model, each school restructured in alignment with that K-8 model will turn around its low academic performance and prepare students with 21st Century Skills and content for advanced academic and workplace success. Activities include professional development for principals and site leadership teams, culture assessment and feedback, professional learning experiences for school faculty in 21st Century Skills and Content, classroom technology, high yield instructional strategies, project based learning, training of trainers and site coaches, and Next Generation Assessments."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Illinois Consortium for the 21st Century, Inc.
Project Title: 21st Century Minds: Connecting Brain Research to Reading Improvement
Project Description: "The Illinois Consortium for the 21st Century and Area 2 of the Chicago Public Schools (CPS) are strategically focused on 21st century learning and the use of data and technology in identifying students at risk and remediating identified deficiencies. Our objective is to use data and effective brain-based learning strategies to improve reading and language development skills for students, including students in Tiers II and III of the Response to Intervention (RtI) protocol, Limited English Proficient students (LEP) and Students with Disabilities. The plan involves using data to identify at-risk students and implementing Scientific Learning's Fast ForWord computer learning program to redirect student language skills to optimize conditions for improving reading skills.The program involves using extended day mobile learning labs for forty minutes, four days per week for thirty-two weeks over a three year time period. The grant will support professional development on how to effectively use data and the software to inform instruction, extended day pay for teachers to implement the program, a salary for the project manager, hardware and software needs (e.g. mobile laptop carts, headphones, software, etc.), and assessments aligned to state standards. The primary grades will receive Fast Forward's Language Product Series for grades K - 4 (average length is 16 weeks), then they will participate in the Early Reading Product Series (another 16 weeks). For the intermediate grades 5 - 8, students will receive Fast Forward's Literacy Product Series (16 weeks) and then participate in the Early Reading or Intermediate Reading Series, depending on their rate of growth and level of reading proficiency. The expected outcomes from the project include improvement in reading readiness skills and improved reading comprehension."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Collaborative Inquiry in Action
Project Description: "The goal of IMSA's Collaborative Inquiry in Action is for educators to demonstrate the capacity to implement inquiry-based and real-world constructivist approaches in the teaching of STEM content, concepts and processes to their students, leading to an increase in the student's achievement in STEM disciplines.  IMSA will develop further and expand upon its' model for producing highly effective teachers.  This program will focus on teachers of grades three through eight in two diverse communities: an urban environment--Area 15 of Chicago Public Schools and a rural environment- several school districts in LaSalle County.  Through a five year, multi-million dollar program, IMSA will impact hundreds of teachers and thousands of students.  Teachers will learn the core concepts in the STEM fields, develop a common understanding of inquiry-based teaching skills, be supported by a professional face-to- face and virtual learning community, and become leaders of other teachers in their own school system.  School administrators will gain insight on how to adequately support non-traditional teaching and learning experiences in their schools.    A Community Advisory Council of leaders from the for-profit and not-for-profit private sector will meet together with the project leaders and participants to offer advice, counsel, and support for the project throughout the demonstration and in order to bring it to scale.  Most importantly, students will succeed in solving problems, thinking critically, and collaborating with others.  The increase in student achievement, as well as increase in student interest and participation in the classroom, particularly in the STEM disciplines, will be the measure of the Teachers' success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: RELEVANCE PROJECT
Project Description: "The Relevance Project proposes to draw on real-world business/industry knowledge to strengthen the application of foundational language arts, mathematics, and science content standards in secondary, 9th through 12th grade, classrooms. The project will involve the development of a website (Web 2.0/wiki style site) which will facilitate a process for obtaining relevant industry expertise as it relates to the application (real-world examples) of science and mathematics standards for education.	This project will further facilitate the use of such information by developing lesson plans (and accompanying assessments), ensuring the connection of what is being learned to the world of work and college/career pathways. The educational challenge being addressed is, as the title suggests, making the connection of what is being taught/learned to the real-world of business/industry; helping make the application of the standards seem relevant to our students. Every educator, and business person, is well aware of this challenge, and of how difficult it usually is. 'Where am I ever going to use this?' or 'Why do I need to learn this?' are questions that every instructor has heard and, while there are sometimes answers provided (though not often enough) sometimes the answer is 'Because there is a test on it next Friday.' That answer never was acceptable but in the world that we live in, where information sharing is possible and even popular at this point, there is no reason for not having a whole lot of examples out there.	Posting a standard and simply telling a student that we are learning it because the state of California, or any other state, says it is important is not enough. The standard is important but it is our job as educators to help our students understand its relevance in the real-world; developing lesson plans and supporting materials that show the application of standards in the real-world of business/industry will go a long way toward meeting this challenge."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Improved Solutions for Urban Systems (ISUS) Inc
Project Title: ISUS-Dropout Recovery Initiative
Project Description: "Improved Solutions for Urban Systems (ISUS) Inc, with the three ISUS Institutes (dropout recovery schools), proposes to further develop, document and evaluate the ISUS competency-based approach that prepares high need youth; especially those who are court-involved, gang-involved or special needs - with high school diplomas, industry credentials, college credits and life-changing perspectives.In 2008-09, ISUS schools were ranked 2nd, 4th and 15th highest performing among the 62 public schools in Dayton.  Also, the ISUS founder was selected by Civic Ventures for the prestigious Purpose Prize and by the Dayton Business Journal for the Regional Leadership Award.  ISUS students practice their skills in the context of service to the community. Healthcare students volunteer in hospitals and nursing homes; computer tech students refurbish computers that are gifted to inner city children; and construction students rebuild entire neighborhoods. Innovations grant goals are to document promising processes, program elements, culture and relationships; secure third party evaluation; create operations blueprint and scale up to 1300 students in four locations.Official Partners-the ISUS Institutes/Other Partners -Sinclair Community College, Associated Builders & Contractors, Montgomery County, Rotary Club, Ferguson Construction, University of Dayton Business Research Group and the National Youth Employment Coalition (NYEC) funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Success In Schools Consortium
Project Description: "Incight, in partnership with Emerging Leaders Northwest at Oregon Health & Science University, Oregon Institute on Disability and Development, the Oregon Parent Training Institute, Portland Public Schools and other community partners propose to implement the Success in School Consortium (SIS), a youth-led dynamic, peer mentor-based educational transition project whose activities (targeted transition training, resource dissemination and on-going peer mentor support).  This project will result in improved student achievement and growth, narrowed achievement gaps, increased high school graduation, college enrollment and completion by youth with disabilities or individuals who are at-risk of educational failure in Oregon."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: ST. FRANCIS PUBLIC SCHOOLS TEACHER-TO-TEACHER PROJECT
Project Description: "St. Francis Teacher-to-Teacher project will expand and further evaluate ISD #15?s evidence-based Teacher Academy framework of professional development linked directly to a performance review system that forms the basis for all teacher compensation enhancement. Summary of objectives and expected outcomes: The overarching goal is to increase student learning in every T2T classroom by providing teachers with the support and tools they need to become highly effective: 1). Change districts? organizational climate to promote positive attitudes in teachers and students toward school and learning; 2). Increase the number and percentage of highly-effective teachers; 3). Increase teachers? perception of their instructional efficacy; and 4). Improve student performance across all student groups on grades and standardized tests, and begin to close achievement gaps. Target number of students: 43,800 over 3 years (14,600 each year). Special project features: 1). collaboration between district and teacher union leadership in participating districts; 2). professional development targeted to assessed teacher needs; and 3). additional teacher compensation based on performance measures that include evidence of student improvement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Validating Quest Atlantis: Substantiating the Value of a Game-Based Curriculum
Project Description: "The purpose of this validation grant is to assess the efficacy of a game-based curriculum for fostering writing and scientific  and mathematical literacy in 7th grade students through a series of randomized control trials (RCT)and fidelity studies, with the broader goal of scaling up our game-based curriculum. Over the past three years,researchers at Indiana University (IU) have designed a game-based curriculum known as Quest Atlantis (QA),which leverages research on learning, games, and narrative to support meaningful understanding. Rockman etal, in collaboration with developers at IU, and the Wisconsin Charter School Association, is proposing an implementation study and RCT investigate the efficacy of these innovative curricula. While we address a range of issues and priorities, the focus of this grant is on the academic achievement and motivation of high-need students. Specifically, as discussed in the narrative, this grant addresses Absolute Priority 3 and Competitive  Preference Priorities 7 and 8."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Testing and Replicating an Accelerating Post-secondary Learning System: 
A Comprehensive Model for School Reform
Project Description: "   The innovative strategy strategy envisioned here intersects perfectly with two nation-wide processes. First, we now have common standards that provide the direction for curriculum development and  the technological capacity  to plan and track student progress for individual students in Core subject areas. Partnering with Using ACT's  assessment system, we can assess college readiness capacity and plan appropriate high school courses and interventions with them and their families.  We have designed a coaching model that provides for the weekly assessment of key concepts, as well as extended opportunities to learn (differentiated interventions)  in order to achieve mastery before a student ends a unit of study and ultimately a course of study. Six instrtuctional coaches will support the implementation throughout the four core subject areas in grades 9 and 10. Teachers in a comprehensive high school can collaborate within and across content areas and elective courses of study to track individual student progress. The assessment system intentionally intervenes with students who lag behind or simply need more time supplementary support can be targeted to provide just in time support. Leadership in the school is solely organized around the flexible, just in time allocation of resources (human capital and program dollars) to support teaching and learning including a virtual high school curriculum in learning modules that are available 24/7. The process has been developed in a single comprehensive suburban high school serving 2500 students and will be diffused into an urban school serving 2200, that is consider exurban , that ban of neighborhoods and schools that contant light industry, commerce, and service that form the border neighborhood outside of large US cities but not in the suburbs.  Research and evaluation procedures will document the fidelity of implementation in early adopter schools and measure the impact of the process on student outcomes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Indianapolis Investing in Innovation (I4)
Project Description: "I4 proposes a previously untested combination of evidence-based and promising practices to improve early literacy, reduce health and developmental barriers that interfere with early literacy, and to increase teacher and principal effectiveness, within a targeted approach reform framework.      Specific interventions focused on K-3 students include 120-155 minutes of daily language arts blocks, infused with action-based learning and sound technology; health/developmental screenings; connections to internal and community resources for additional literacy support and to address social-emotional needs and health/developmental barriers to early literacy; and family engagement strategies to boost connection to school and to reduce absenteeism. All interventions will be guided by an individualized Reading Success Plan (RSP), which captures the strengths and needs of all K-3 striving readers, summarizes current literacy achievement, attendance, health/developmental/ behavior issues, and family data, and updates goals and interventions every 6 weeks to accelerate progress towards grade-level reading. All teachers will participate in professional development that includes specific training, job-embedded coaching and peer learning focused on developing early literacy. Weekly assessment of students and comprehensive reviews of striving student data every 6 weeks will drive differentiated instruction so that each child reads at grade level by the end of 3rd grade. An Implementation Fidelity Committee comprised of IPS and its private and public partners will ensure alignment of internal systems, policies and resources; and attract and align external resources to benefit participating students. The implementation and outcome evaluation by Chapin Hall, as well as the technical assistance by Foundations, Inc. will create the documentation, tools and processes for scaling beyond the over 3,500 students that will be served during the grant period."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Inkster Public Schools - Project K-Nect Plus
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
ICEF Public Schools: Preparing Students for College by Turning Around the 
Lowest Performing Schools in South L.A.
Project Description: "ICEF is a non-profit organization in partnership with a consortium of schools with a proven track record of  improving student achievement and student growth, closing achievement gaps, decreasing dropout rates, increasing high school graduation rates, or increasing college enrollment and completion rates. ICEF is seeking a $5 million Federal Investing in Innovation Fund Development Grant to support school turnaround interventions (Absolute Priority 4). Specifically, with this grant and philanthropic matching support, ICEF will turnaround a large, low-performing middle school (that meets the grant's turnaround eligibility criteria) and transform it into four smaller high performing middle schools that embody our innovative five essential elements and seven core practices. The process and outcomes will be evaluated by researcher, Dr. Dick Carpenter of the University of Colorado.  This project 1) addresses a profound unmet need for high-need students, 2) implements practices, strategies and programs that have not been widely adopted, and 3) has a clear set of goals, strategies and intended outcomes that are measurable, specific and aligned with Absolute Priority 4."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: ICEF Writing Model: Creating College Readiness Through Reading, Writing and Thinking
Project Description: "The Inner City Education Foundation (ICEF) is proposing to implement the 'ICEF Writing Model' as a Development Grant project of the I3 Fund. The project addresses Absolute Priority 3 by expanding the number of high need students receiving instruction through its highly effective Writing Model. It also addresses Competitive Preference Priority 6 by integrating the Writing Program across K-12 curricula, adding college readiness activities for each grade. The project will integrate critical writing instruction into curricula and classroom practices reaching nearly 10,000 students in K-12th grades.  Major project activities are: a) Back mapping the Writing Model curriculum from college level standards to create materials for teachers from K-12, b) Creating assessments that raise AP and SAT scores of high need students, and c) Disseminating the Writing Model at national partner sites. Objectives are: 1) Increasing the number of teachers using the standards and assessments of the ICEF Writing Model in ICEF classrooms by 400%, 2) Increasing by 200% the number of ICEF high school juniors demonstrating early college readiness by passing the Early Assessment Program (EAP), 3) Increasing the average scores of high need ICEF students on SAT exams, and 4) Expanding by 300% the number of teachers using the ICEF Writing Model at sites outside the ICEF network. Outcomes include: 1) Development of K-12 curricula materials, 2) Increased numbers of high need students earning AP credits and passing college readiness assessments, 3) Increased SAT scores of high need students at ICEF schools and partner sites, and 4) Increased numbers of teachers using ICEF Writing Practices and Assessments. Prospective site partners include Envision Schools (Bay Area), CEO Leadership Academy (Milwaukee, WI), Mariana Bracetti Academy (Philadelphia, PA), and The College Ready Promise group funded by Gates Foundation. The project is of special interest due to its national scope and student cohort of 10,000"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Excellence through Execution in Entrepreneurial Schools Program
Project Description: "Program OverviewExSL is the nation's first program which provides school leadership teams a framework to successfully execute their vision in start-up and turnaround schools. The end result - moving new schools further, faster.  Launched in 2008, ExSL is a partnership between Inner-City Teaching Corps and The Levy Center at the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University. The program is designed to develop leaders who are effective in executing in entrepreneurial environments and offers exposure and access to the insightful wisdom of successful start-ups and entrepreneurs in other industries. ExSL consists of 4 elements: The ExSL Summer Institute at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management, plan development, the ExSL Principal Forum, and dynamic on-going assessment and coaching. Our MissionEvery child deserves a superior education. To that end, ExSL has set its sights on a new and higher standard for American public schools. Fusing the best of enterprise and education, ExSL is leading the charge for effectiveness in a time of sweeping change and catalyzing a new age for start-up schools that enable under-resourced schools achieve their highest potential.Our Goalso	Enable faster and higher academic achievement o	Increase probability of overall success of participant schoolso   Develop a nationwide network of start-up and turnaround school leaders"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Institute for Academic Excellence: SOPHIE B. WRIGHT CHARTER SCHOOL
Project Title: USING DATA TO TARGET INSTRUCTION
Project Description: "The Sophie B. Wright Charter School is proposing to conduct a three year project addressing Priority 2: Using data to assess student progress and inform best instructional practices.  Using the TargetTeach? Data Management System to collect data from a variety of sources, teachers and school leaders will be trained in the areas of data interpretation, collaborative planning around data use and student achievement, and refining instructional practices. Job-embedded professional development will focus on the five TargetTeach? components which address the key requirements for ensuring an accessible curriculum for all students:   1) Identification of instructional goals; 2) Curriculum Alignment; 3) Filling in the instructional gaps; 4) Using incremental formative assessments and 5) monitoring student progress by using formative assessment data to drive instruction.  We will assess students frequently, to identify at-risk students earlier, enabling teachers to target their specific deficiencies.  High need students will participate in daily sessions of individual and small group tutoring provided by volunteers from the For the Children Organization.Coaching and modeling to further develop teacher efficacy and capacity will be ongoing. ENI's coaching staff will observe teachers four to ten times over the course of a school year, providing feedback and using reflective questioning techniques to guide teacher development in the areas of  classroom management, standards-based instruction, using data to drive instruction, and differentiating of instruction."

Applicant: Institute for Native Pacific Education and Culture (INPEACE)
Project Title: INPEACE Hawaii i3
Project Description: "The INPEACE-Hawai?i i3 innovation project builds upon years of community-based work in the most vulnerable communities across the state of Hawai?i. The model includes supporting effective teachers who teach children ages 0-8 and focuses on improving early learning outcomes so that children arrive at school ready to learn. By building upon SPARK and P-3 work we have developed a model that includes the expansion of 0-5 parent participation preschools, culturally competent curriculum delivered in an outdoor classroom, family literacy for low performing kindergarteners, home-visiting in rural communities where access and transportation is limited, and a recruiter to get every child age 0-5 into a effective early childhood program with a strong parent empowerment component. In addition, all teachers of children ages 0-8 who are working in communities where low performing schools exist will be provided academic, financial, and social support to obtain a CDA, AA, BA or MA in early childhood.The project goal is to close the achievement gap for children 0-8 years old in the lowest performing public schools in Hawai?i. Over the course of 5 years approximately 45,345 children, 380 teachers and 34,690 parents will be served in these high need communities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Project CHILD 3.0
Project Description: "Project CHILD 3.0 will expand a highly successful innovative instructional system for grades K-5 called Project CHILD (Changing How Instruction for Learning is Delivered). The project goals are: 1) to increase academic achievement in reading, writing, and mathematics by engaging and challenging high-need elementary students and their teachers, and 2) to create a cost-effective school turnaround model that can be articulated, validated, and widely replicated in persistently low-performing schools. During Year 1, the objective is to develop updated CHILD 3.0 materials, upgrade classrooms with state-of-the art instructional technology, and develop customized data feedback systems. During Years 2-4, we will implement and evaluate CHILD 3.0 in eight diverse regional demonstration schools impacting 3,500 students in grades K-5. During Year 5, we will begin a regional awareness and dissemination process to get commitments from at least 16 low performing schools to adopt the CHILD 3.0 model in order to reach the ultimate goal of impacting 10,500 students. Throughout the life of the grant, we will provide intensive professional learning and will develop a Project CHILD Virtual Community (PCVC) for online professional learning and collaboration, connecting all CHILD schools with the grant-supported demonstration schools. The CHILD 3.0 model will also create safe and inviting school climates at the demonstration schools through intensive leadership development and by introducing a relationship-based community discipline model. Special features of Project CHILD 3.0 include increased emphasis on technology applications, project-based learning, positive school climate, leadership development, teacher collaboration, full inclusion of English language learners and students with special needs, and continuous data feedback to guide instruction. All instruction will be framed around 21st century skills and high standards. The school of tomorrow is here today!"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: Institute for the Study of Knowledge Management in Education
Project Title: Knowledge Collaborative for Equity-Based Professional Learning Communities
Project Description: "This application will fund a Knowledge Collaborative for Equity-Centered Professional Learning Communities (ECPLCs), an innovative approach to attract, train, and retain quality principals at 26 San Francisco-area schools. Principals will meet as a group with an experienced mentor/educator with a deep understanding of principals? needs. Participants also will engage in an online Professional Learning Community to exchange information and strategies."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Institute for the Study of Knowledge Management in Education
Project Title: The Science Collaboratory
Project Description: "The Collaboratory is a project to provide more hands-on science instruction to elementary school students, particularly Latino students. Each school will receive a vertical garden where students can grow food and observe an ecosystem at work. Teachers at each school will receive face-to-face and online professional development not only on the garden but also on other techniques to infuse hands-on science. An online Professional Learning Community also will bring teachers together for possible collaboration across districts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Instructional Technology Services of Central Ohio, Inc.
Project Title: TIKES: Technology for Inspiring Kids and Engaging Schools
Project Description: "Ed Techs from across Ohio are partnering with member school districts to create the TIKES Project, an innovative program that uses Educational Applications (Apps) and iPads in PK-3 classrooms. Activities include teacher training, assessment of content design and classroom management strategies through small-group demonstration in the classroom, Apps gap analysis for reading and math, and mentoring to build a progressively increasing number of groups. Rigorous studies will to measure the effect on student achievement for low-performing or developmentally challenged children."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Instutite for Research and Reform in Education, Inc.
Project Title: Lighthouse District Partnership for Dropout Prevention and Secondary School Success
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Math Smart! Innovation System for Targeted School Reform
Project Description: "The Intercultural Development Research Association, with Texas State University, will implement Math Smart!Innovation System for Targeted School Reform, a professional development model with 3 years of solidpositive results in math student achievement in high need schools. In this development grant, we will partnerwith 7 high schools at AYP Stages 3, 4 & 5, and corresponding feeder middle schools with the greatest studentneeds. Unlike a one-size-fits-all short-term strategy, Math Smart! has multiple integrated strategies within afluid approach that comprehensively builds on local contextual factors, addresses needs from a strengthperspective and creates a collaborative sustainable community of practice among students, teachers, schoolleaders and parents. We will integrate resources and student support and address academic and non-academicbarriers to achievement. The project will increase students? math preparedness and expectations for college,transforming thinking and practice so that low-performing schools foster high expectations, create a collegegoingculture and incorporate college readiness standards. Outcomes will include: (1) High need students(ELLs, low-income students, migrants, and students with disabilities) meet local and state math achievementstandards and are college ready; (2) School leaders and teachers are content ready and culturally proficient tocreate a college-going culture for all students; and (3) Strong and sustainable collaboration among participatingschools is evident and effective in building capacity to meet the needs of traditionally underserved students.Goals and objectives include: (1) Improve the pedagogy and cultural competence of teachers and schoolleaders; (2) Strengthen teachers? mathematics content knowledge and cultural proficiency in serving high needstudents; and (3) Sustain a virtual network of participating schools that strengthens schools? capacity to servetraditionally underserved students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Learning and Mentoring as a Community of Practice - A Planned Variation of the Coca-Cola Valued Youth Program
Project Description: "If students, teachers and school leaders were to become a community of learning and practice, to establish a senseof value and build a stronger team, then students ? including high need students ? would have increased schoolattendance and academic success and reduced disciplinary problems. The Intercultural Development ResearchAssociation, along with 6 districts in 3 states and The Coca-Cola Foundation?s private sector support, willdevelop and rigorously evaluate a promising innovation, Learning and Mentoring as a Community of Practice? A Coca-Cola Valued Youth Program Planned Variation, to meet these goals. Through this developmentgrant application (CFDA 84.396C), IDRA proposes to build on success of a model we researched anddeveloped for 3 years with core content area 8th grade teachers in a rural district in Texas? Lower Rio GrandeValley serving mostly Title I English language learners. Designed to address Absolute Priority 1 ? Innovationsthat Support Effective Teachers and School Leaders, it will increase the number and percentage of highlyeffective teachers and school leaders, especially for high need students, by developing communities of practicein 4 middle and 6 high schools in 3 states using learning community and mentoring strategies, positivelyimpacting 25,750 students and 125 teachers and administrators.
