It also addresses 3 Competitive Priorities:Enable K-12 students, especially high school students, to successfully prepare for, enter and graduate fromcollege by instilling a sense of value in at-risk students, enhancing their opportunities to pursue a 2- or 4-yeardegree; Address unique learning needs of disabled students or linguistic and academic needs of ELLs bydirectly serving, with cultural competence, a significant number of ELLs and special needs students; and Focuson the unique challenges of high need students in rural local education agencies by developing and evaluatingthe model in four rural schools serving high need students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: International Baccalaureate Schools of Alabama, Inc.
Project Title: Alabama IB Incentive
Project Description: "Brief project description:The primary goal of the Alabama IB Incentive is to provide more students with a first-class, world-class education through the high standards and quality assessment provided by International Baccalaureate (IB) Programs.  To achieve this goal, IB Schools of Alabama (IBSA) will partner with local education authorities.  Project activities will include establishing, expanding and funding IB programs to prepare students for success in college and beyond.  IB Programs included in the plan include the IB Diploma Program, Middle Years Program, and Primary Years Program as well as the IB Career Related Certificate.Summary of project objectives & expected outcomesThe Alabama IB Incentive will address absolute priority 3 by bringing the high academic standards and quality assessment of the IB Programs within reach of more K-12 students, including high-need students.  This will also address competitive preference priorities 6 and 7.  To meet this objective, IBSA and partner LEAs will:o	Establish new IB programs in Alabama in locations that will serve all students, including high-need students.  Result: The number of IB programs in Alabama will nearly double and the number of students with access to an IB program will more than double in the next five years., o	Extend existing IB programs in Alabama to reach more students and prepare them for college and career success.  Result:  More students, including high-need students, in Alabama will be able to attend and succeed in college due to participation in high quality IB programs.o	Expand teacher training, support services for students, and access to technology and other educational resources. Result: More schools will be able to offer the high international standards of IB programs and support all students, including high need students, in reaching these standards. Target number of students to be served in the projectCurrently, approximately 4,500 students in IBSA member schools are participat"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: International Center on Deafness and the Arts
Project Title: Scientific Validation of Integrated Learning Through the Arts
Project Description: "The International Center On Deafness and the Arts has designed this project to validate an innovative approach for children who are deaf and hard of hearing which integrates academic learning, social skill development and emotional stabilization with the arts through the creative activity of producing a play. The method utilized to accomplish this goal of integrating arts and learning is reviewed in a step by step process. The validation process utilizes a basic science approach by the children through an analysis of quantitative EEG studies of a model group of deaf children which reveals their brain function. Also included will be results from neuro psychological cognitive testing and academic achievement assessment.Data which provides evidence of success which has resulted from past involvement in the Children's Theater of the Deaf at ICODA by a group of 45 students will be shared. Their thoughts as to how this process helped them to become high achieving adults who function at a much higher level than is customary for individuals who are deaf and hard of hearing are including in the Appendix."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: International Technology and Engineering Educators Association
Project Title: STEM byDesign
Project Description: "This project facilitates integrative STEM professional development by migrating a model that has provensuccessful over the last three years in South Carolina to at least 20 additional states. The project capitalizes onan existing infrastructure that has shown tremendous impact in a short time and promises the potential forcontinued growth.Within the scope of this project, ITEEA seeks to address three specific goals:1. Migrate the EbD? STEM Institute Model to at least 20 additional states.2. Further develop the model into a sustainable system.3. Collect longitudinal data about how STEM teams adjust their action plans.To accomplish these goals, ITEEA will work with principals, teachers, guidance counselors, and other educationprofessionals and experts from each state to deliver STEM Institutes in a longitudinal fashion, allowing followupand adjustment specific to the needs of each state. This will be accomplished through direct involvementwith schools in the EbD Consortium of Schools, otherwise known as the EbD Network, some 170+ schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: International Technology and Engineering Educators Association (ITEEA)
Project Title: STEM byDesign
Project Description: "This project improves the use of STEM student assessment data by capitalizing on an existing infrastructure thathas shown tremendous impact and growth. There are four goals:1. Assess hands-on student achievement efficiently for the T and E of STEM.2. Streamline collection of mathematics and science achievement data.3. Initiate data analysis.4. Link data collection on student achievement and teacher professional development.Data will migrate from independent testing programs to a web-enabled user system and supporting infrastructurethat automates data collection and disbursement for all output points.The new web interface is a single, automated access point for student assessment and professional developmentacross the U.S.The macro design incorporates software that links student assessment results on the T and E of STEM, scienceand mathematics achievement data, and teacher professional development. Data analysis begins in Year 2.Output to schools, teachers, and researchers will be nearly instantaneous, allowing data to impact decision-makingby informing instruction and professional development in real time and data mining to occur."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Improving Student Achievement for English Language Learners
And Turning Around Persistently Low-Performing High Schools
Project Description: "Improving Student Achievement for English Language Learners And Turning Around Persistently Low-Performing High Schools		Internationals Network for Public Schools (Internationals) and its official partners, the National Council of La Raza (NCLR) and the New York City Department of Education (NYC DOE), seek an i3 Development grant under Absolute Priority 4-Innovations That Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools to further develop and scale its high school model to increase academic achievement, graduation rates, and college- and career-readiness for underserved English language learners (ELLs).  		Specifically, Internationals will meet the goals of this priority by: (1) reconstituting two NYC high schools that are being phased out by the NYC DOE; (2) delivering a targeted intervention in 16 of the lowest-performing schools in NYC by providing professional development to teachers to help improve student achievement and help prevent phase-out; and (3) supporting a national Community of Practice with NCLR to foster sharing of best practices among the 18 NYC high schools to be served under this grant, as well as the additional 60 high schools currently supported by Internationals and NCLR in NYC and across the country. The entire project will serve more than 40,000 students. NCLR will also leverage its vast network of over 300 affiliates across the country and deploy its national staff to disseminate best practices for educating ELLs in a variety of online and in-person forums. 	Dr. Richard Baecher of REB Consulting Systems will evaluate the efficacy of the model in improving outcomes for ELLs in low-performing high schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Access to Postsecondary Learning for Underrepresented Students (A+)
Project Description: "The Access to Postsecondary Learning for Underrepresented Students (A+) Project is a collaboration that buildson the strengths of a well-established K-12 college success program (AVID) and an exemplary communitycollege program for underrepresented high school and first-year college students. Capitalizing on the successesof both programs, Project A+ creates seamless, consistent coursework and wrap-around services from middleschool through the first year of college.Each Project A+ goal is designed to increase academic achievement, success in earning college credits, andcollege-readiness behaviors for academically-average underrepresented students in an urban setting.To achieve Project A+ Goal #1: Middle School Student Achievement and College Readiness, middle schoolstudents will fulfill high school course requirements and explore STEM careers during a summer program on acollege campus. For Goal #2: High School Student Achievement and College Readiness, high school studentswill improve scores on Minnesota achievement tests in Math and Science by utilizing interactive software thattargets specific areas for skill-building. Goal #3: High School Students Earn College Credits provides onlinecollege courses during the school year and campus-based college courses in the summer, with extensivesupport services (Structured Learning Assistance). Goal #4: College Enrollment provides Project A+ coursesand services to high school graduates enrolling in college, thus creating a seamless transition with ongoingsupport services. Because each project activity is based on existing programs that have undergone rigorousevaluation in other states, Project A+ will demonstrate substantive gains in academic achievement scores,successful completion of college courses and acquisition of college readiness behaviors for underrepresentedstudents in the academic middle."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Reaching and Teaching Struggling Learners I3
Project Description: "With REL Midwest guidance, Reaching &Teaching Struggling Learners' (RTSL) asserts that the program design to  support adults in the effective use of data will lead to improved results for students with IEPs and other vulnerable student populations. The unique characteristics of the program design include collaborative inquiry skills and methods. These professional development targets provided to secondary schools is intended to support leadership and stakeholders to adequately conceptualize the issue of dropout. RTSL uses the early warning sign data with the schools in their initiative. I3 funds would provide the initiative with a chance to increase teacher use of the early warning signs.  The third request for I3 support involves an expansion of the quality of the evaluation methods so that the initiative may further explore the positive results reported in the first cohort. RTSL would like support to determine whether positive results with second cohort of schools will produce positive results. REL Midwest staff, student and leadership surveys are ready to measure the RTSL effect. Target number of students to be served: over 5000 students will be servedSummary of project objectives & expected outcomes: Measure the effectiveness of the program design in terms of the correlation between student results and teacher and leader effective use of data.  Assess whether the design's emphasis on inquiry before intervention selection has an effect that can be measured in terms of student data, surveys, and positive changes in graduation rates for student with disabilities. Through diffusion of early warning sign data through the Microsoft Data Dashboard, RTSL asserts that access to data will impact teacher engagement with dropout prevention and will result in positive changes in graduation rates.Consider how the results collected from the REL Midwest surveys of staff, students and leaders might be better understood if the initiative could access a more robust collection"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Project 2Tap: Technology for Teaching, Acheivement and Progress
Project Description: "Serving over 1000 students in their respective middle schools, Saydel Community School District (Saydel) inDes Moines, Iowa, and Lewis Central School District (Lewis Central) in Council Bluffs, Iowa, arerepresentative of an unfortunately pervasive national problem: the continued existence of persistently lowperforming schools. They are also representative of school districts nationwide who are pursuing educationalexcellence with a sense of urgency, an eye toward innovation, and a tireless focus on creating positive schoolbasedchange. Iowa State University (ISU), in partnership with Saydel and Lewis Central, have developed aconceptual framework which is intended to translate project resources into outputs and outcomes that willpositively impact the Saydel Community Schools, Lewis Central Community Schools, ISU, and the broadernational focus on turning around the persistently lowest performing schools. The conceptual framework isactualized in the 3 main components of the 2TAP project:1) Provide laptop computers to every student and teacher in participating schools, positioning students to becomecreators, rather than only receivers, of content, to participate in global collaborative projects, and to improvetheir 21st century literacy skills.2) Provide ongoing professional development based on research that will transform teaching and learning.3) Infuse technology coaches into participating schools to enhance transfer of training."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: COMPASS: collaborative Organizational Model to Promote Aligned Support Structures
Project Description: "Iredell-Statesville Schools? proposed program, COMPASS: Collaborative Organizational Model to PromoteAligned Support Structures, focuses on innovations that support effective teachers and principals (AbsolutePriority 1). Since our reform efforts began over 7 years ago, our district has seen significant increases instudent achievement for all groups of students. Our project was developed based on the successfulimplementation of our Performance Excellence Model which is recognized as a national best practice. Ourhypothesis is that systematically, aligned support structures to provide sustained professional development forteachers will increase teacher effectiveness and positively impact student outcomes. Through COMPASS, wewill continue to improve upon these significant gains through the implementation of two research-basedstrategies; Response to Intervention (RtI) and Professional Learning Communities. These strategies aresupported by four key structures, including: Instructional Facilitators, RtI Liaisons, Instructional TechnologyCoordinators, and Exceptional Children Specialists. Our district has seen promising results in student academicachievement through the individual implementation of these research-based components. However, throughCOMPASS, we will address a largely unmet need with a focus on high-need students. We will take thisimplementation to the next level by blending each component and providing cross functionality of the supportstructures to increase teacher effectiveness and ultimately improve the academic achievement of our high-needstudents. Our project has three key outcomes: 1) Increase teacher effectiveness to ensure all students succeed;2) Improve academic achievement of high-need students; and 3) Improve academic achievement of studentswith disabilities and LEP (CPP 7). COMPASS will lead us in the right ?direction? and enable us to provideinnovative strategies to build highly effective teachers to ensure all students succeed."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Irving and Associates Character Education Services, Inc.
Project Title: Ready to Learn
Project Description: "In an effort to establish innovations that turn around persistently low performing schools, Irving & Associates Character Educational Services, Inc. (501 c 3 non-profit organization) will collaborate with the Research Association of Minority Professors and 20 urban and 2 rural public schools. This initiative demonstrates the value of character building in early learning programs and set high standards for early learning by working with parents and teachers of pre-kindergarten to third grade children. The RtL program will integrate character building activities based on selected episodes from 'Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids' into the language arts curriculum in kindergarten - third grade. This initiative will impact more than eighty teachers and more than a thousand students per year. 	The Ready to Learn (RtL) will 1) facilitate early learners in developing reading, writing, speaking, listening, motor and social skills by linking character building activities with K-3 curriculum,  2) sustain and advance children's achievement skills, and self-esteem so that they are fully prepared for schools' academic and social environment; 3) provide professional development for teachers to familiarize them with the Ready to Learn  (RtL) program, to promote positive expectations for  student performance; and 4) establish student, teacher, and parent cooperative programs that will reinforce the character building and  academic values of Ready to Learn.   Quantitative and qualitative analysis will be used to assess the success of the program."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Irving Literacy Engagement and Acceleration Resource Network
Project Description: "ILEARN will use literacy and school readiness data to create early warning systems for children who are not fully engaging their literacy potential. Those at-risk youth will be targeted with a combination of school, family and community resources to create literacy interventions from cradle to career. Special attention will be directed to demographics that have demonstrated achievement gaps in the Irving Independent School District, including Limited English Proficient students, students with disabilities, and pregnant and parenting students.  Whiledifferent intervention strategies will be used to maximize the learning potential of each cohort of targeted childre and families the activites are designed to align and deploy a consisten ladder of success from birth through college or career. ILEARN is intended to (1) advance literacy throughout the community; (2) engage families, businesses, civic organizations, faith-based organizations and other community partners inpromoting and developing literacy; (3) build social, emotional, and academic capital for at-risk students by pairing them with both in-school and community-based learning partners; and (4) transform Irving from a traditional school-based educational model to a learning community that integrates school- and community-based learning."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: i3 Project
Project Description: "The goal of the Itasca Area Schools Collaborative (IASC) during the five-year funding period is to target high-need students in 8th through - 10th grades, to increase graduation rates, utilize tutoring through technology with more selection in rigorous courses, and provide college-ready access for students and teacher leadership.  The IASC school districts cover more than 4,350 square miles or almost 2.8 million acres in rural northern Minnesota.  Current research demonstrates that financial incentives for students will motivate them to respond better to learning.  Such incentives will motivate students to read more, improve grades, achieve better attendance/behavior, and earn higher test scores.  Projects of this size and scope of the proposed  i3 grant  have been successfully implemented by Educational Talent Search.  Their programming has improved students' academic readiness, closed achievement gaps, and increased college enrollment rates of high-need students.  		Partnering with Blandin Foundation and community chambers provides the foundation for program success and future program sustainability."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Jackson Community College's College Preparedness Program
Project Description: "Jackson Community College (JCC) is changing the focus and objectives of their College Incentive Program (CIP) from college attendance to college completion with a postsecondary credential, and also changing the name to the College Preparedness Program (CPP).  The new program will continue to identify qualifying ?at-risk? students in the 6th grade and provide them with a full-ride scholarship to JCC if they complete all the program requirements.  Beginning in 8th grade, and every year thereafter until graduation, students will be assessed with the Compass college placement test to determine whether they are testing at grade level and on the path to becoming college ready by graduation.  Those who are testing below grade level will receive skill building/remedial education courses at JCC during the summer.  All participants will be required to participate in annual ?college exposure workshops? and ?taste of college? workshops.  Our objectives and expected outcomes over the 5-year grant period for all participants in the program include: 1) 97% high school graduation rate; 2) 50% college readiness rate in reading, writing, and math, by graduation; 3) 40% college attendance rate; 4) 60% college persistence rate; 5) 54% college retention rate; and 6) 36% will obtain a college credential in 3 years.  Our program will serve 100 new students each year, a total of 500 by the end of the 5-year grant period.  Our partners include the Jackson Community Foundation, and the Jackson County K12 school districts ? Columbia Schools; Concord Schools; East Jackson Schools; Grass Lake Schools; Hanover-Horton Schools; Jackson Public Schools; Michigan Center Schools; Napoleon Schools; Northwest Schools; Springport Schools; Vandercook Lake Schools; and Western Schools."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Gateway to College
Project Description: "In response to the Office of Innovation and Improvement's Investing in Innovation Fund Guidance, the East Side Union High School District, in collaboration with James Lick High School in San Jose, CA and Apangea Learning are working together to propose an application for the I3 development grant.  This collaboration will target students with an expressed interest in attending college that are defined as 'at-risk' in a primarily urban and diverse school system.  Through the use of needed tutoring for each student and accessible data that determines each student's learning needs, we will be able to provide students with customized learning programs that give them the tools to be successful and ultimately turn around the low performance of James Lick High School."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Establishing Middle Ground
Project Description: "Establishing Middle Ground (MG) is an exceptional approach to the absolute priority of Turning AroundPersistently Low-performing Schools (AB4) through the competitive priorities of Supporting College Accessand Success(CPP6) and addressing the Unique Learning Needs of Students with Disabilities and EnglishProficient Students(CPP7) by: a) Focusing on 10-14 years old students in middle school grades 5-8, b)Explicitly integrating BBBS mentoring with school and mentor recruitment, with the Career DevelopmentAcademy Adult and Family Learning Center and JMU teacher education, c) Adding ELL Parents EducationalPartners at the middle School level and modifying it, with support from its developers ALRC, to addressAfrican American families and families with disabled children, d) Establishing an 8th Grade Academy at eachschool and bringing area professionals together with these students through our area Education Foundationsand JMU Professors in Residence, f) Holding Middle School Leadership Institutes each summer at JMU, andg) Placing teacher preparation teams ?in residence? at the middle schools to address differentiation and uniquelearning needs for disabled and ELL students"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Reading Frontier of Texas to Cyberspace and Beyond
Project Description: "We propose to provide laptop computers, loaded with Lexia software for every student attending the schools in this project grades K-2nd. The Lexia software will be used as a supplement to the schools reading curriculum. We intend to utlized the state reading assessment given called the Texas Reading Primany Inventory as our baseline as well as progress assessments each year. There will be mulitple trainings for the teachers to attend to learn how to use the software and all of the tools with it. On the Lexia Software is a tool to asses the students progress on a daily, weekly or monthly basis. This will help the teachers determine where the weak spots are for each child, making faster referrals for additional help if needed. This will ensure reading success for these children in school. We will provide the tools each teacher needs for success, training, a computer for the teacher, a COW for each class and a LCD TV also to use as a teaching tool. Training for the teachers will be held each year including update trainings on the software program."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Jefferson County Board of Education (dba Jefferson County Public Schools)
Project Title: Jefferson County KY Board of Education DBA Jefferson County Public Schools, National SAM Project with "other" partners: California, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Iowa, Kentucky, Missouri
Project Description: "The Jefferson County Public Schools, home to the National SAM Project, submits this Invest In Innovation (I3) proposal at the Validation Level, designed to address Absolute Priority #1: Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals; and Competitive Priority #8: Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEAs.The SAM Project is a whole school change strategy designed to refocus the role of the principal from the school manager to instructional leader, resulting in an increase in the amount of time and effort spent on improving teaching and learning. This focus engages all stakeholders and ultimately leads to improved outcomes for students. Recent studies of successful schools connect strong school instructional leadership with higher student achievement, and that leadership effects are usually largest where and when they are needed the most. The SAM project is a proven effective school improvement model that has been shown to be effective in high need schools and with high need students.More than 300 schools have implemented the SAM model to date. The National SAM Project involves districts, universities and state education agencies in 7 partner states: California, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Iowa, Kentucky, and Missouri; and further expansion through this grant is expected in Indiana, Kansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Nevada, New York, South Carolina and Texas. The model will be evaluated in urban, suburban and rural districts, with the ultimate goal of raising student achievement in all types of settings. Specifically, resources set aside from this award will improve conditions for school leaders and will ultimately lead to improved outcomes for all children."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Jefferson County Board of Education DBA Jefferson County Public Schools
Project Title: Making Time for What Matters
Project Description: "Jefferson County Public Schools (JCPS) wants all students to acquire the skills and dispositions to succeed as contributing citizens, versatile workers, and innovative leaders for the 21st century.  While many reforms in large urban systems have failed to reach their potential because they were done incompletely or in isolation, our work will reach across the needs of students, deeply and sustainably into the operations and culture of schools and district. Consistent with the grant application, we have four goals: improve achievement and close achievement gaps; decrease dropout rates and increase high school graduation rates; increase college readiness and access; and improve teacher and school leader effectiveness.	Our i3 Development grant, will demonstrate the power of a coherent targeted strategy to turn around our six, persistently low-performing high schools in the context of a trimester schedule that will drive academic acceleration, promote social and emotional well-being, and advance teacher professional growth.  The targeted intervention consists of three parts. Academic acceleration: The trimester schedule will give struggling students over 30% more learning time to catch up with their peers, increase time for in-depth study, and increase opportunities for electives and advanced study.  College Access Time:  The schedule will enable regular small group meetings that support a strong relationship with an adult who is ?on my case and on my side?; affiliation with peer group who have similar interests and career focus; and, provide adult support for encouragement, course selection, habits and persistence for college readiness. Teacher Professional Growth: The trimester schedule will enable increased time for collaboration and reflection within discipline about teaching and learning and provide time for collaboration across disciplines about students and gives time for work with content/pedagogy experts. We will develop professional learning communities to t... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Using a Five Pronged Approach for Improving Student Engagement and Academic Success: Assessment, Pathways, Academies and Technology.
Jenkins County PATHWAYS
Project Description: "Our project, Jenkins County PATHWAYS, supports Absolute Priority 3 and the Competitive Preference Priorities 5, 6, and 8.  PATHWAYS, Providing Alternatives To Help With Adult - Youth Success, is designed to be an exceptional approach toward serving high-need students and their families in a new and innovative way.  High-need students are defined as students at risk of educational failure or in need of special assistance and support in order to graduate from high school, be prepared for college and a career, remain free from violence and negative risk indicators, and become a self-sufficient adult.PATHWAYS is aligned with high academic content and achievement standards and with high quality assessments that are based on the Georgia Performance Standards and that measure students' progress toward college and career readiness. The goal of our PATHWAYS project is to support the implementation and evaluation of innovative best practices that 1) Encourage strong partnerships, 2) Improve student achievement, 3) Close achievement gaps, 4) Decrease dropout rates, 5) Increase high school graduation rates, 6) Increase college enrollment and completion rates, and to 6) Become fully self-sustainable.  The PATHWAYS project directly aligns with Absolute Priority 3 and allows our students and their families to select various alternative educational PATHS.  These alternative educational PATHS increase their opportunities and allows our targeted students and their families access to choices regarding:  A) How instruction in core content areas is received, B) What type of rigorous and relevant curriculum is available and accessible, C) What form and how often assessments are administered, and D) How assessment results will be analyzed and transferred into classroom practices that are both beneficial and efficient.  The PATHS are the family-strength based, highly innovative, and best practice based strategies of our PATHWAYS project that provide alternative educational strategies."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: JFYNet/OE
Project Description: "JFYNet/OEAfter 10 years of program development and 1st-generation implementation yielding improved student achievement, the Mass. nonprofit JFYNetworks is pleased to announce JFYNet/OE ('OE'='Open Education').  This is a 5-year R & D initiative to validate JFY's promising method for integrating technology with teacher support to leverage increased student achievement of standards.  Program goals: To improve student achievement (on state standards assessments) and increase number of students choosing STEM for college/career.  Core hypothesis:  That standards-based, assessment-driven use of technology, with proper supports for teachers, will drive increases in achievement.  JFYNet/OE will serve 10 high-need schools in 5 Mass. LEAs, serving 20,400 students (with some year-to-year duplication) over 5 years.  JFYNet/OE brings together the R&D innovation capacity of Mass. Inst. Of Tech., Sebit Corp. & Innosight; the on-the-ground commitment of 5 LEA superintendents & their school staffs; the assessement expertise of Galileo software, Arizona State U. & MIT; the content reservoirs of MIT, Monterey Institute & Adaptive Curriculums; & the instructional technology, learning standards & teacher training expertise of JFYNetworks.  JFYNet/OE integrates technology into the classroom to yield assessment-driven, standards-aligned results by increasing access to high-quality digital-based material, developing a user-friendly platform for accessing that material, & training teachers to use the technology in their daily teaching practice for improved student achievement.  As a promising practice, JFYNet/OE is ready for a more rigorous study of results.  Outcomes to date show that JFYNet students show greater gains than their peers & that the greatest impact is on high-need students.   JFYNetOE introduces significant new Open Source & Open Platform resources to the arena of e-instruction, bringing high-quality math & science research into the classroom while building in sustainab"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Jobs for America's Graduates Proposal for an i3 Grant
Project Description: "Jobs for America?s Graduates (JAG) is a 30-year old non-profit youth development program dedicated to helping at-risk young people graduate from high school and make successful transitions to postsecondary education or meaningful employment. JAG has served more than 750,000 students since its founding three decades ago. In 2010, 42,000 students are participating in JAG programs around the country. For the i3 grant, JAG will address Absolute Priority Four ? Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools. JAG proposes over a five-year period to grow and expand its innovative model. The JAG model is a targeted approach to decreasing the number of students who drop out of high school. The model is based on the use of teaching/leadership/mentoring by JAG specialists who are on site at high schools to provide students with a caring adult presence, an advocate for their situations and needs, and a facilitator to connect education, employability, and ultimately success. JAG will integrate its model of ??student supports?? into the school model to address non-academic barriers to student achievement by accomplishing two overarching goals: 1. Expand the reach of the JAG Model to serve 5,650 more students in seven states under the leadership of seasoned State Affiliates who, in most cases, have decades of proven experience and success. 2. Bring the JAG Program to scale in persistently low-performing schools through sustainable delivery and financing beyond the five-year grant period."

Project Title: Early College Expansion Project
Project Description: "Jobs for the Future, early college school consortia from North Carolina, Texas, and California, and the state-levelearly college high school intermediary organizations from these states have formed the Early College ExpansionPartnership (ECEP), which will dramatically increase the number of high-need students who graduate from highschool college- and career-ready. Under a 3-year i3 validation grant, ECEP will ramp-up early collegeimplementation and further develop the model by:? Continuing to support the development and enhancement of high quality early college consortia schoolsin North Carolina, Texas, and California, through: delivery of the Early College ProfessionalDevelopment program; designing and implementing STEM-focused dual enrollment and postsecondarycourse pathways; and refining and validating strategies for on-line dual enrollment course-taking andassociated student supports.? Scaling up early college implementation in school districts anchored by high performing early collegeschools. ECEP will support scaling in five smaller, rural districts and six larger districts, and will build thecapacity of district partners to sustain and scale early college designs.? Creating a robust, enhanced platform of professional development and design services, including:codification of tools and processes to build district-level capacity; ?blended? on-line and in-personprofessional development delivery; new analytic tools and teacher resources; and rich structures tosupport in-depth and effective peer learning and collaboration.A third-party evaluation will describe project implementation and assess impact through: quasi-experimentalanalysis of impact of consortia schools in Texas and California; quasi-experimental study of impact in scaling-updistricts; analysis of implementation approaches used and depth of model implementation in existing schools andexpansion sites; and cost data analysis."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: K-5 Mathematics Mastery: The Gateway to Student Success (K-5 M2)
Investigation of the Seahawk Virtual Learning Environment
Project Description: "Investigation of the Seahawk Virtual Learning EnvironmentSophisticated learning technologies such as simulation and gaming have the potential to engage students in complex problem solving and have proven effective in promoting learning, but these cutting edge technologies have rarely found their way into K-12 instruction. Under this project, the Center for Technology in Education (CTE) at Johns Hopkins University (JHU), along with its partners the JHU Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) and Baltimore County Public Schools (BCPS) will further develop the Seahawk VLE.  Seahawk is a high-fidelity simulation based on geospatial terrain data obtained from NASA.  The current version of Seahawk embeds STEM learning activities in geometry and environmental science within the Mt. St. Helens volcano setting.  However, the VLE is a flexible tool that can be adapted to various locales and STEM content. A key to this is a Curriculum Customization Interface (CCI) that allows non-programmers to create new content aligned with standards.Seahawk is now being used in Chesapeake High School, a high-need school within the BCPS system. The VLE is used in Chesapeake?s Arena room and in a specially designed virtual computer lab (V-Lab) in which all workstations have 3 monitors, though it can also be used on more common single-screen configurations.Under this grant, the partners will accomplish the following: 1) refine and enhance the Seahawk VLE; 2) refine the pedagogical model for use of the VLE; 3) prepare for an efficacy study; 4) conduct the efficacy study; and 5) prepare for expanding use and validation of the Seahawk VLE.A comprehensive evaluation will include formative input, an implementation assessment, and an efficacy study, which will investigate the potential of simulation technology in various configurations to increase student engagement, achievement, and interest in STEM."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Validating the Talent Development-Diplomas Now Secondary School Turnaround Model
Project Description: "The Talent Development Secondary program (TD) at Johns Hopkins University is applying for a Validation Grant, in partnership with 14 school districts, City Year (CY), and Communities In Schools (CIS), to validate a whole school reform and student support model specifically designed to turn around Absolute Priority 4 secondary schools with low graduation rates and their feeder middle schools. These are the secondary schools that drive the nation?s dropout crisis. An Investing in Innovation (i3) grant to TD would: 1) Bring our most advanced version of the TD model, known as Diplomas Now (TD-DN), which has been designed to enable the successful turnaround, restart, or transformation of the nation?s lowest performing schools to 60 middle and high schools in 14 districts, serving 57,000 students; and 2) Enable a randomized control trial evaluation study by MDRC to show under what conditions this combination of reforms is powerful enough to enable high schools currently graduating 30-60% of their students to achieve graduation rates of 80% or more and y reduce by two-thirds the number of middle school students sent to high school off-track and behind grade level. TD-DN will provide the management, operations, external evaluation, and sustainability required to serve students effectively. TD-DN has secured the full 20 percent match ($6 million) from the PepsiCo Foundation. The infrastructure and financial wherewithal is in place to scale the TD-DN Turnaround model beyond the schools involved during the grant.Project Partners: Budget amounts for districts to be determined."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Lifting the Floor by Raising the Roof
Project Description: "The project provides the innovation of lifting the standards for high needs students through close alignment and measurement of mental motivation and leading-edge content in STEM. The California Measure of Mental Motivation (CM3) scale scores are correlated with academic performance of rural, small city and coaching for students and families for college application and financial aid success."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Validation of a statewide Response to Intervention model in the effective use of data to improve achievement for all students
Project Description: "A consortium of public schools (local school districts and intermediate school districts) with support from Michigan Department of Education is applying for funding from the U.S. Department of Education Office of Innovation and Improvement under the Investing in Innovations (i3) Grant Program (CFDA 84.396B). The purpose of this grant is to validate the use of enhanced data systems (Absolute Priority) that drive Michigan's Integrated Behavior and Learning Support Initiative (MiBLSi) advancement and expansion in improving student achievement and closing achievement gaps among Michigan students. (Competitive Preference Serving Students with Disabilities and Limited English Proficiency Students, and Serving Students in Rural LEAs.) Although the MiBLSi project has demonstrated success, it has not been scientifically validated.The MiBLSi initiative embraces a Response to Intervention (RtI), multi-tiered, approach that directly aligns with state and national educational priorities. The schoolwide behavior and reading components of MiBLSi focus both district and school improvement efforts on improved outcomes for all students.  Outcomes are addressed through the integration of three critical elements: data-based decision making, evidence-based practices in support of students, and systems support for principals and staff. Schools will participate in training and technical assistance at the universal, secondary and tertiary supports level. Additionally, capacity development (e.g, development of local trainers, coaches, leadership teams) at the district and intermediate district levels will take place around implementation supports.This project will utilize a randomized, wait-list control effectiveness trial with groups of schools from four different intermediate school districts and seven local school districts. All participating schools will receive exposure to the treatment package over the course of the project. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Internal Data Coach Development
Project Description: "Hypothesis: The ability of a school to effectively use data to impact instruction and student achievement will be greatly enhanced by the existence of a well trained internal data coach who is knowledgeable about instruction, possesses data analysis skills and coaching / facilitation competencies.  Title:		i3 Internal Coach Development ProjectType:	  	DevelopmentTarget#:	3800 students per year	Partners:	Kalamazoo County School Districtso	Climax-Scotts Community Schoolso	Comstock Public Schoolso	Galesburg-Augusta Community Schoolso	Gull Lake Community Schoolso	Kalamazoo Public Schoolso	Parchment School Districto	Portage Public Schoolso	Schoolcraft Community Schoolso	Vicksburg Community SchoolsOutcomes:1.	A comprehensive selection and training protocol for Internal Data Coaches will be developed and implemented.2.	Internal data coaches in each building will facilitate the use of data to guide instructional decision making3.	Academic achievement will be enhanced for all students by the increased use of data to inform instruction.	This grant proposal is intended to improve student achievement for all students through the involvement of Internal Data Coaches working .5 FTE in each school building. These Internal Coaches would be individuals knowledgeable in research based instructional strategies who would receive nine days of training in the selection, analysis and application of data to inform instruction, as well as coaching and facilitation skills and matching of best practice instructional strategies to data. The Internal Coaches will be supported by External Coaches for five years with a gradual reduction in onsite involvement over the five year period."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Chrysalis Project: Transforming Kansas City Schools
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: PSI:i3 Project
Project Description: "PSI has proven over a 10-year period in a pilot school to increase the number of HS students taking and passing AP exams in Physics, Chemistry, and Biology to 4.5 times the state average in NJ. The PSI-i3 Project takes this proven curriculum and delivers it in an innovative, program of graduate coursework that enables experienced, successful teachers recommended from 7 high-need districts, to learn new content knowledge and 21st century pedagogy, enabling them to educate their students to achieve at much higher levels in science and math.This project will serve 5200 (unique) or 8560 (duplicated) students, inasmuch as most students will take more than one course. The proposal is for a Development grant for a period of 4 years.In serving the high need studens,  the objectives of the PSI-i3 Project are to: (1) increase to at least 20% the percent of students who take AP courses in the target subjects; (2) of students taking AP courses, increase to at least 10% the number of students who pass the AP exams; (3) increase the number of skilled, certified HS teachers of the target subjects by at least 100; (4) markedly improve participating PSI students' achievement on the state mathematics testDistinctive features of the PSI-i3 Project include: (1) tested capacity and methods for scale up; (2) PD leads to added teacher certification; (3) social constructivism balanced with direct instruction; (4) high levels of technology integration; (5) uniform, consistent, frequent assessment; (6) transformed classroom spaces; (7) cohort structure for PD; (8) online Professional Learning Community; (9) WNET project dissemination through TV and Internet video.."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: 21st Century Global Tech School within a School
Project Description: "Kentwood Public Schools seeks funding to pilot a Global Tech school within a school for High School Freshman and Sophomore classes.  The project will serve 200 students who self-select into the program.  KPS hypothesizes that project-based learning methods combined with right-brain learning activities, provided by collaborating community agency, West Michigan Center for Arts & Technology (WMCAT) will increase student engagement in the classroom and better prepare students for the 21st Century workforce. The project team believes that the combination of project-based and right-brain development methodologies and a customized approach to project and curriculum development will improve standardized test scores, school attendance and behavior;  strengthen cross-cultural appreciation among peers, and result in students who have the combination of skills that are needed in the 21st Century global economy."

Project Title: AVID Enriched Turnaround: A Model of Comprehensive Reform for Schools Serving Rural English Learners
Project Description: "Keppel Union School District seeks to develop a national model for school turnaround by expanding its own turnaround efforts at Almondale Middle School. Project activities will target innovations that support college preparation and meet the learning needs of English Learners by expanding three programs currently in place at the school: The AVID program that is developingour students? college-readiness skills, the district-adopted direct instructional model that is compelling our teachers to deploy effective instructional strategies, and the English Learner program that is enhancing our students? subject proficiency andcommunication skills. To culminate the project, a third-party professional writing team will develop a publicly accessible implementation manual, which will provide a complete guide for similar middle schools seeking governance restructuring. A third-party independent evaluation team will formally evaluate the program throughout the process."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Kickapoo Nation School Project Based Learning Initiative
Project Description: "The Kickapoo Nation School Project Based Learning Initiative (KNSPBLI) is a three year longitudinal,progressively expansive, culturally founded program designed to reduce student drop-out rates and increasestudent achievement and matriculation into post-secondary education.Kickapoo Nation School (KNS), owned by the Kickapoo Nation of Kansas, provides a unique educationalexperience through traditional values and culture. The student population is 100% American Indianrepresenting multiple tribes throughout north east Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, and South Dakota. Enrollmentis approximately 100 students with capacity of 400. Extremely economically disadvantaged, 87% of thestudents receive free or reduced lunches. KNS has a uniquely qualified superintendent who is an enrolledmember of the Turtle Mountain Chippewa tribe.The KNSPBLI will contribute significantly to preserving native language and culture by engaging culturallyrelevant curriculum meeting the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 requirements and Kansas state standards.The KNSPBLI addresses critical needs of students who experience educational underachievement or failureincommensurate with aptitude and abilities resulting from mainstream linear designed curriculumsinappropriate for American Indian students. (Reyhner, 1991; Dingman, Mroczka & Brady, 1995).While improving environmental and tangible resources, this project provides the required intensive, value addedstaff training and professional development to implement, conduct and expand services to PK-12 students andadult community learners. The on-site adult learner program(s) is expected to fluctuate between 25 to 50people. As online and distance education opportunities expand, we expect many more tribal members toparticipate from outside the immediate area. This project will significantly increase learner outcomes andpositively impact siblings, extended family and other community members. The KNSPBLI will facilitatecollaborative enga"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Kids Orbit/District 13 Consortium
Project Description: "The Kids Orbit?distric 13 Consortium project, a partnership of elementary schools in District 13 located in Brooklyn, NY, will partner with Kids Orbit (KO), a non-profit afterschool program and the lead applicant, and educators from the University of Conncecticut (U Conn) in order to provide administrators, teachers and other staff members with the pedagog ad content knowledge necessary to further the gains that have taken place in New York City public schools since 2003 under the Children's First Reform Initiative??Truncated"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: K.I.N.G-Knowledge and Innovation Necessary for Generations
Project Description: "Our project falls within the Development grant program and addresses the absolute priority 3, Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High Quality Assessments.  Specifically, we will be developing, implementing and assessing programs using 21st Century Skills and STEM related activities to improve low income, urban primary and middle school students' progress toward college and career. The need for STEM related activities, college and career readiness, and 21st Century Skills have been well documented and are at the forefront of education reform and related policy development. A long history of research, and the need to emphasize skill development at the earliest elementary level, has increasingly been recognized as a needed foundation for long-term success.  Reliable, effective strategies are paramount to meeting these challenging needs and require dynamic teaching through multiple mediums. King Academy has a proven record of success in closing the achievement gap and can catalyze the improvement of K-8 STEM education programs that will improve college and career readiness. To meet our goals, we have partnered with two leaders in the STEM and 21st century skill development areas, iSPACE (interactive Space Programs and Career Exploration) and Creative Learning Systems' SmartLab. Both programs will be held during out of school time hours and are dynamic informal education programs that focus on STEM activities that are based on the practice of 21st century skills. We believe that, if integrated from the beginning of a child's school experience, 21st century skills of critical thinking, analytic reasoning, problem solving, and written communication become habit so that the transition to a high school environment that emphasizes work and college readiness is seamless. Furthermore, starting early with high need students also instills and reinforces, year after year, the confidence to pursue STEM related courses and careers."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Building Effective Administrators in Rural Schools (BEARS)
Project Description: "The Building Effective Administrators in Rural Schools Project is requested as a Development type of Grant.  The goal of this grant is to increase student achievement in rural schools of both regular students and in the populations of English Language Learning (ELL) students by facilitating collaboration with other school leaders that is currently not possible because of a school or district's geographical isolation and by increasing the time spent in research-based educational leadership activities by rural principals in the Southeastern regional area in the State of Washington.  We hope to achieve this by establishing active multi-district Professional Learning Communities (PLC's), to participate in an embedded professional development program during the school year and by sponsoring additional trainings that specifically addresses increasing the amount of time that a principal will spend in educational leadership activities in their school as opposed with managerial tasks that can either be delegated or performed with greater efficiency..  We expect the participating principals to participate in problem solving topics in increasing student achievement through effective teaching as they collaborate in their respective regional building level teams.  These activities will be monitored and reinforced with an evaluation system that will be used in every building that will outlive the grant funding.  The other partners in this project are as follows:  Kiona-Benton City School District (grant applicant), Finley School District, Columbia Burbank School District, North Franklin School District, and Richland School District.  Additionally, a PhD-level expert in this type of professional development has agreed to assist us with support in this project and will be a part of the leadership team in planning and implementation activities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Teaching Improvements for Math Effectiveness (Time): Grade K-5 Professional Learning Communities for Small School Districts ?????
Project Description: "The goal of this grant is to increase student achievement in mathematics by facilitating collaboration with other teachers that is currently not possible because of a school or district's geographical isolation and by increasing teacher content knowledge in mathematics in the kindergarten through 5th grade spans in two regional areas in the State of Washington.  We hope to achieve this by establishing active multi-district Professional Learning Communities (PLC's), to participate in an embedded professional development program during the school year and by sponsoring a Summer Conference that specifically addresses increasing teacher's mathematics content knowledge within the context of what they need to teach students.  We expect the participating teachers to participate in action research as they collaborate on effective strategies to increase student math achievement as well as focus on mathematical knowledge that they need to help their students comprehend the essential foundational math understandings and skills necessary to progress in their secondary school career.  These activities will be monitored and reinforced with a coaching model to establish teacher-leaders in every building that will outlive the grant funding.  The other partners in this project are as follows:  Kiona-Benton City School District (grant applicant), Prosser School District, Finley School District, Paterson School District, Winlock School District, Onalaska School District, Morton School District and Mossyrock School District.  Additionally, two PhD level experts in this type of professional development have agreed to assist us with support in this project and will be a part of the leadership team in planning and implementation activities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Capital Teaching Residency: The Future of Training Highly Effective Teachers
Project Description: "KIPP DC and E.L. Haynes Public Charter School, two of the highest performing charter school organizations in the District of Columbia, request funding for the expansion of the Capital Teaching Residency (CTR) to increase the number of highly effective teachers within DC. CTR is unique in that it will train reliably effective teachers. CTR prepares new teachers to be effective in urban settings the way hospitals prepare doctors. CTR is a yearlong residency that integrates the elements of coursework, practicum, mentorship, and coaching within the environment of a high-performing school. By placing them in environments that are successfully closing the achievement gap, CTR graduates will be the most prepared teachers in the country when they begin their first year as teacher of record. The program is highly selective to ensure candidates with the highest potential of success are chosen. Throughout the practicum, residents are matched with a highly effective mentor teacher, who provides support and feedback. As residents? teaching skills progress, they are given more responsibility, following a model of gradual release. After the yearlong residency, CTR graduates receive two years of alumni support to ensure their success. Over the next five years, this collaborative effort will produce over 340 teachers who will have the tools, experience, and competency to impact over 55,000 high-need students. The objectives of the CTR are: 1) Increase the number of highly effective teachers; 2) Increase teacher retention; and 3) Provide a national example. The expected outcomes CTR will reach are: 1) By 2015, CTR will have added 340 teachers to the field; 2) a 90% retention rate of CTR graduates; teacher retention at partner schools will increase by 10% in first year; 3) 75% of CTR graduates will demonstrate more than one year's growth in student achievement in their first year as teacher of record; and 4) CTR will be a model for one other charter school partnership by 2015."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Success as the Norm: Scaling-Up KIPP's Effective Leadership Development Model
Project Description: "The KIPP Foundation, a nonprofit organization, and the consortium of KIPP schools and regional organizations propose to scale up KIPP's leadership development model to increase dramatically the number of highly effective principals prepared to lead schools that place PK-high school high-need urban and rural students on a path to success in college.          In a nation in which less than 10 percent of students from low-income families earn bachelor degrees, KIPP has developed a research-proven approach that is achieving radically improved student achievement and attainment outcomes.  KIPP has accomplished dramatic results across very diverse geographies and different student populations by developing principals who operate under a shared set of principles known as the Five Pillars, and who focus on a common mission - success in college.         Through this project, KIPP will: (1) Deepen and expand the reach of KIPP's Leadership Development Programs to train 1,000 future principals of excellent KIPP and non-KIPP schools and to enable at least 50 percent growth in annual KIPP school openings.  (2) Support and evaluate the effectiveness of KIPP principals by enhancing elements of KIPP's performance evaluation system including the research-based Leadership Competency Model and Healthy Schools and Regions Framework.  (3) Equip high-need urban and rural school districts and charter management organizations with KIPP's best practices."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Transforming Education: Trans-disciplinary Learning for College, Careers and Beyond
Project Description: "This project focuses on three components of the educational environment to achieve alignment in 1) classroom teaching and learning, 2) leadership, and 3) the use of data.The goal of this project described in the grant application is to improve achievement for all students, including high needs students, by aligning middle and high school learning with real world environments through project/problem based, transdisciplinary learning using Science, Technology, Engineering and Math programs of study. This goal will be achieved by providing 21st Century learning experiences for all students to better prepare them to face rigorous higher education coursework, career challenges and a globally competitive workforce.The education system in the region will be structured for change. Building administrators and leaders are foundational in the creation of a positive impact on the system. Classroom teachers, the one component of the learning environment which most directly affects student achievement, will be supported by building administrators and outside consultancy specialists. Network centered learning clusters within building and outside the schools with business leaders and other schools will provide the basis for collaborative learning at all levels.Data will be used regularly to give immediate feedback to students, teachers and administrative leaders. Pathways to improvement will be determined in a non-threatening format to transform the entire system. Businesses from the local community are a part of the dialogue by hosting site visits and internships to help educators learn first hand about the workforce skills needed for the 21st century. The entire region will benefit with a more highly skilled workforce, leading to an increase in the potential pool of qualified applicants and creating a more positive economic outlook"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Kiwanis Activities, Inc. dba Pfeifer Kiwanis Camp
Project Title: Alternative Classroom Experience (ACE)
Project Description: "Since 1988 Pfeifer Kiwanis Camp has operated the Alternative Classroom Experience (ACE) in Central Arkansas. ACE is a 30-day residential, educational, and wilderness experience for 3rd, 4th, and 5th graders who are not achieving their potential in the regular classroom. Besides academics, campers learn problem solving skills, crisis management skills, and acceptance of personal responsibility through a variety of outdoor, environmental, and team-building activities. Parents are required to attend Parenting Workshops regarding discipline, communication, and problem solving. ACE recognizes that high needs students often have non-academic barriers to achievement that cannot be overcome in the regular classroom setting. ACE provides student support in the form of prevention, parent involvement, social skills training, cultural awareness, and intense residential programming. Pfeifer Camp will partner with the Little Rock and Pulaski County school districts and AmeriCorps to provide ACE and to incorporate a School-based ACE program for ongoing student support. ACE results show that students grow approximately

Applicant: Klamath River Early College of the Redwoods
Project Title: Native Transformative Education Center
Project Description: "Klamath River Early College of the Redwoods (KRECR) will expand its research based  model to include additional grade levels and increasing coordination with other existing education providers in this economically distressed, rural community (Klamath, California) located on the Yurok Indian Reservation. The model will build from the existing early college high school to include PreK-14 and will demonstrate that culturally relevant standards based curriculum provides cumulative positive benefits socially and academically for high needs students, in particular economically disadvantaged and/or Native American students.  It is our belief that this model will result in improved scores on standardized academic tests, improved attendance rates, improved transition from lower grades to secondary grades, improved graduation rates, and increased post secondary enrollment."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: College Plus (+) Prep
Project Description: "The 'College Plus (+) Prep' will combine the Accelerated College Approach with Career and Technical Education, Advanced Placement and Dual Credit courses throughout seven academies to ensure that all graduating students will achieve (1) acceptance into a university with transferrable credits earned through Advanced Placement and Dual Credit classes, (2) an Associate's Degree from a local 2 year institute, or (3) a ceRtIficate in an employable field such as computer networking, cosmetology, engine repair or pharmacy technician. Each academy will include an interdisciplinary Texas Performance Standards Project, a statewide standards and assessment system used to capture the high levels of achievement of gifted and talented students, and focus on the core content areas English Language Arts, Mathematics, Science and Social Studies courses with interdisciplinary connections. These seven academies, containing 16 clusters of CTE classes are (1) STEM, (2) International Business, (3) Health Science Occupations, (4) Liberal Arts and Communications, (5) Fine Arts, (6) Criminal Justice, and (7) Environmental and Natural Sciences.Project activities will use 1:1 technology to develop and adopt new methodologies to help learners excel in all subjects. Beginning in 2009, 98% of all students at Klein Forest High School received laptop computers for use in and out of school. Partnered with the 'College Plus (+) Prep program, Klein Forest students will graduate from high school prepared to compete in the global society."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Creating a Corridor of Innovation: Dramatically Changing the Equation for Student Success in Rural, High Need High Schools
Project Description: "This project proposes to create a system of STEM-focused, project-based, technology infused New Tech High Schools in four of the nation?s persistently lowest-achieving, lowest income and most economically underdeveloped rural communities, located in the I-95 corridor in South Carolina Within the five-year project, 2010-11 will be spent in planning, training, and technology installation; with the schools opening in 2011. Ongoing operation will be supported by an integrated technology platform; site visits by KnowledgeWorks; a SC-based regional manager; staff of the Riley Institute; and state and national convenings for NTHS staff. Systemic changes render NTHSs largely self-sustaining; KnowledgeWorks? well-developed infrastructure, support and experience with similar projects in different settings render them replicable.Objectives, outcomes: Student success will be maximized through the acquisition of core knowledge and of technology, analytical, critical thinking, problem-solving, and collaboration skills. 95% of students will meet state achievement standards. In a state near the bottom of national indicators, attendance, graduation and college entry and success will exceed national averages; dropout rates and discipline referrals will fall lower than national averages, and achievement gaps will narrow by 50%.Official and other partners: KnowledgeWorks , a consortium of schools including Colleton, Edisto, Marlboro, and Scott?s Branch high schools, and the Riley Institute.Special feature: Special attention will be brought to student?s college and career readiness through a an intensive collaboration with business and industry, to align learning with job growth sectors, develop individualized internships and real-world learning projects, and position graduates as regional assets to area economic development organizations."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Optimizing Potential by Unifying Stakeholders
Project Description: "Using field-tested experience from the transformation work of KnowledgeWorks in 30districts across five states and the District of Columbia, OPUS focuses on localization and personalization as the key to improving school operations and student achievement.The OPUS initiative enacts school transformation the following five core processes:? Implementing an individualized, data-driven, five-year strategic plan.? Establishing multiple highly functioning small schools that share space in the former comprehensive high school, each with its own real-world focus, but all committed to personalization and college and career readiness.? Building the capacity of everyone in the school through five-year structured professional and leadership development plans.? Developing a culture where a focus on student growth and achievement drives every process in the school, from teaching practice to building operations to district-level supports.? Bringing key stakeholders to the table who commit to fundamental school reform locally and to advance the vision of a future-oriented education for all students.Through OPUS, students? educational experience will be transformed as (1) all 9th-, 10th-, and 11th-grade students are enrolled in a college- and career-ready curriculum; (2) state exam pass rates increase; (3) on-time, grade-level progression increases; (4) dropout rates decrease; and (5) Advanced Placement and dual-enrollment participation and increase. Over the five years of the grant, OPUS will transform the lives of approximately 24,000 students. In addition, at the end of the grant, the schools are expected to be successful institutions of learning that will continue to transform 6,000 more students? lives each year.This initiative brings together an unprecedented collaboration of KnowledgeWorks with the National Education Association, the National School Board Association, and the American Association of School Administrators, the unified stakeholders of the initia"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Foundations for Innovation in STEM Education-- The Philadelphia STEM Teacher Leadership Program
Project Description: "The Foundations for Innovation in STEM Teaching (FFI) is a Philadelphia-based STEM Teacher Leadershipprogram sponsored by La Salle University that responds to the critical need to support innovative practices foreffective science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) teaching and learning throughout the K-12continuum in a large, high needs urban school district and public charter schools. FFI will support effectiveSTEM teaching and learning through an innovative STEM Teacher Leadership Institute program. The prograwill transform science pedagogy in Philadelphia to more closely reflect modern science practice, involve k-12teachers in a community of practice that develops instructional programs and strategies, and train teachers tolead innovation at every school in the project. K-12 teachers will work together to create a program pipelinethat leaves students highly prepared for college and career. A diverse group of stakeholders will be involved inevery aspect of the project, forging productive relationships among science, education, and industrystakeholders and will transform STEM teaching and learning in Philadelphia."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Delta Force for College and Career Readiness
Project Description: Project Description:  Delta Force for College and Career Readiness project is a collaborative effort to create a college going culture in three rural school districts in South Texas.  This project will focus on creating Tech Prep Support Teams of trained staff in research-based best practices aimed at integrating the Texas College and Career Readiness Standards into the core curriculum.  Parents Community Trainers will also be organized by the Abriendo Puertas Partnership for Parent Outreach activities.  Students will be guided by district staff and Llano Grande Partners in developing critical readiness skills through college and career focused activities. The three districts and partners will work collaboratively to address all the key skills students need for successful transition into college and careers of their interest.
