Project Title: Acadiana New Tech High School
Project Description: "There are five neighboring Local Education Agencies in South-central Louisiana, also known as Acadiana, that have historically proven to be under-effective at successfully preparing students for graduation and college readiness.  These five Local Education Agencies (LEA) include Lafayette Parish, Iberia Parish, St. Landry Parish, St. Martin Parish, and Vermilion Parish. The ultimate goal of the Acadiana New Tech High School is to create a sustainable and increasingly effective program that will improve the results for underrepresented high-needs students in standards based, rigorous academic classes to better ready them for college and their tech-based futures in the working world.  The Acadiana New Tech High School is slated to operate within Lafayette Parish, at one of its excess sites, and enroll students from its four neighboring parishes of Iberia, St. Landry, St. Martin, and Vermilion as well.  ?????"

Project Title: Quinpoint Demonstration Progarm
Project Description: "Hypothesis:  Can strategic improvement strategies, targeted at district-wide systems change, positively impact persistently low-performing school districts and raise academic success for high-needs students?  Lafourche Parish School District has created a consortium with two neighboring districts with similar needs, Avoyelles and Sabine, to implement the Quinpoint Demonstration Program - a district-wide assessment and intervention program that will revive persistently low-achieving schools with lasting, systems-based changes.  Focused on intensive professional development and leadership capacity-building through professional mentoring, the Quinpoint program has been successful turning around similarly low-performing schools.  JBHM Education Group will provide project services.  Results will be evident within one year, however, after four years of program implementation Quinpoint strategies and methodologies will be fully integrated into targeted districts and fully self-sustaining."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Assessing Data for Vital Achievement Needs and Classroom Excellence (ADVANCE)
Project Description: "In the past four years, the Lake Elsinore Unified School District has significantly decreased the achievement gaps between high-need students (SED, EL, and SWD) and their counterparts through focusing instruction on rigorous content standards and using data to guide classroom instruction. In order to support teacher effectiveness, this effective strategy will be combined with a unique data approach for identifying effective teachers and best practices used by these teachers. Findings and video lessons will becollected and posted on the district's website to serve as resources for all educators. Moreover, teachers in need of additional support, as evidenced by data, will participate in a Targeted Assistance and Support Collaborative that will use research-based strategies demonstrated to increase teacher effectiveness and student learning. The project will meet the following objectives: identify exceptional teachers for best practice resources; identify teachers needing additional support; increase the use of formative assessment data to guide classroom instruction; increase monitoring, intervention and effective strategies used for SWD, LEP, and other high need students; and increase the percent of students leaving high school college-ready"

Project Title: Every Student Future Ready
Project Description: "The Lake Washington School District (LWSD), in partnership with EDMin.com, Microsoft Corporation and The College Board, is pleased to submit our Every Student Future Ready project for consideration for funding of the Development Grant under the Department of Education's Investing in Innovation Fund (i3). Our request will provide us with $4,000,000 over 4 years to enable us to fund our project, centered on Absolute Priority 3: Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessment, and Competitive Preference 6: Innovations that Support College Access and Success. The outcome of our Every Student Future Ready project to develop a system-wide approach to ensuring that each and every LWSD student graduates with content knowledge, skills, and attributes required to be prepared for college, prepared for the global workplace, and prepared for personal success. Our project objectives are to: 1) develop standards-based learning progressions, scales, and assessments; 2)  determine key college and Future Ready performance indicators for each grade level; 3) build a comprehensive data system and data dashboard/scorecard that displays student progress toward proficiency on key performance indicators to district staff, parents, and students; and, 3) develop a system-wide culture focused on the use of data to improve learning for all students, especially those historically underserved and underperforming. While all LWSD students will be benefit from our project, funding will be targeted toward the approximately 6,000 LWSD students needing the most significant intervention to become Future Ready. Through the Every Student Future Ready project, LWSD will be able to better articulate high standards for all students, assess students' performance against those standards, identify those students who need the most significant intervention, and provide the necessary resources and supports enabling each and every single student to be Future Ready"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Creating an Environment for Success
Project Description: "After two years of research and discussion, Lakeland High School is now a member of the New Tech Network (NTN), a high school reform model known to create an engaging student-centered learning culture. Using rigorous project based learning, students also acquire critical 21st century skills as they work on complex projects, collaborate with peers, and are assessed on authentic outcomes. In order to support this type of learning, Lakeland's proposal focuses on construction and technology costs necessary to transform traditional classrooms into large areas capable of the flexibility to support inquiry and project based learning while integrating the 21st century skills, including technology literacy."

Applicant: Lakeshore Alliance for Student Success, Inc.
Project Title: Balanced Literacy Initiative
Project Description: "LASS Balanced Literacy Initiative goals follows:To implement the Balanced Literacy Initiative at an additional 24 schools in the LASS membership schools in order to improve literacy rates in Lake, Porter, and LaPorte Counties of Northwest Indiana. To aggressively train 24 literacy coaches and literacy teams in the Literacy Collaborative? Model to acquire expert in-depth knowledge level. All teachers trained will be able to deploy the characteristics of the BLI in their classrooms as well as to become an expert trainer of the literacy team in their schools. LASS projects that the BLI will assist 12,500+ students in achieving a higher level mastery of the Language Arts on ISTEP+ by 21% over the 5-year period. The Balanced Literacy Initiative will also improve literacy in the 24 participating schools, which will be evident through individual student reading level advancement tracked through runningrecords.Working with Purdue University, LASS will oversee the implementation of the BLI for improving literacy by training a teacher and teams in each of the 24 schools. Each year a group of literacy coaches will be trained as well as training for the literacy team. LASS will provide additional training and support by using a systems approach in the 1st through 8th grades in these 24 schools by:(1)Including training and mentoring of school principals and PLC-leaders to become facilitators and leaders of grade-level and interdisciplinary teams(2)Facilitating the creation and maintenance of district-level PLCs in each school to broadly share successful lessons/units, practices, and assessments across schools.(3)Providing direction for and oversight of the development, analysis, and use of formative performance-based and objective literacy assessments to guide instructional changes.(4)Providing instructional monitoring by a master literacy teacher (independent of the project) who will monitor team meetings and instruction, provid"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Using Data to Improve Student Outcomes through Informed Instruction
Project Description: "Using Data to Improve Student OutcomesThis 4-year Development Grant project will implement a Response to Intervention (RtI) InstructionalIntervention/Progress Monitoring (IIPM) Model pre-K-8, in urban and rural schools in Lane County Oregonthat need to raise achievement and close the achievement gap. The project partnership includes applicant LaneCounty School District 4J and 4 ?other? partners: the Lane Education Service District, the University ofOregon Behavioral Research and Teaching (BRT) Center, Early Childhood CARES, and the EugeneEducation Association (EEA) teachers? union. The project will develop an RtI/IIPM Model that equipsteachers to use benchmark and progress monitoring data to differentiate instruction to meet the needs of allstudents. The program has raised achievement and reduced achievement gaps in District 4J.This RtI/IIPM Model integrates 3 research-based components: (1) the EasyCBM Benchmark ProgressMonitoring Assessment System, (2) school-based coaching and (3) school data teams that use data to designinstructional interventions and monitor individual student progress. Initiated in 2006, the proposed project (1)completes development of measures and professional development at the elementary and middle levels; (2)extends the program to meet unique needs of 7 rural school districts; and (3) develops and pilots early learningprogram measures.The project will offer 2 years of professional development to 2 cohorts of 6 teachers in each school in using theEasyCBM assessment and in how to use data to design instructional interventions. One outcome will be acomplete set of EasyCBM benchmark and progress monitoring assessments preK-8, developed by BRT.Another will be on-line video professional development that can be used nationally. The $6,000,000 project,providing matching funds from the University of Oregon Department of Continuing Education, will reach over5,000 high needs students and cost less than $1,100 per student."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Capital Area High School Diploma Completion Initiative
Project Description: "Project Title: Capital Area High School Diploma Completion Initiative (CA-HSDCI)In 2006, the Michigan Department of Education established the Michigan Merit Curriculum; requiring students meet higher standards for high school graduation to ensure possession of the skills necessary for the 21st century workforce including higher technical competence, adaptability, and critical thinking by increasing solid core competencies in English, math, science, and technology.  These changes place many at-risk youth in Michigan at even greater risk of dropping out.  Lansing Community College (LCC) and area intermediate and local school district partners have embraced this challenge and seek a Development Grant to refine and evaluate a pilot program that re-engages area at-risk youth, and provides them with the support and skills to complete their high school diploma while simultaneously earning college credit towards a certificate or an Associate Degree and secure employment in the technical jobs in the community. The project model includes: core academic college courses that meet state standards taught by college instructors with a class size of 20 restricted to HSDCI students and supplemental instructors, i.e. college students, who support the instruction and facilitate structured study hours to assist students with their course assignments.  In addition, students have access to wrap around supports provided a case manager and a social worker to provide emotional support and access to community services.  Employability Skills, career assessment, and career exploration activities are infused in weekly Team Time and in a summer work base learning program.  All students have a community person as a mentor to provide them support, inspiration, and career validation through online and in-person mentoring on a weekly basis."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Promises Kep Consortium
Project Description: "This project will use a combination of universal scholarships, additional standardized assessments, academic supports, mentoring, and college planning/preparation activities to improve student readiness for and success in postsecondary education. The project will be implemented in five communities across Michigan. Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: This project seeks to (1) improve student academic and social readiness for postsecondary education, (2) remove financial barriers to college access, and (3) improve the retention rate of students in higher education. The project expects to see increased numbers of students entering higher education and succeeding there.  This will be achieved by students having a better understanding of expectations, processes, and resources and having improved academic preparation. Target Number of Students to be Served: This project will serve approximately 10,750 students over a five-year period. Special Project Features: This project is unique in that it presents a strategy for incorporating college readiness, access, and success activities across grades 8-14.  "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: I Thrive Thru Technology iT3
Project Description: "The iT3 proposal focuses on technological innovations implemented to develop college prepared cyber-citizens.  We will exploit and leverage the power of technology to make data driven decisions, offer differentiated instruction, provide just-in-time tutorials, share meaningful and timely information and provide a seamless continuum of transition services to college. Our research-based programs are model worthy. Summary of project objectives and expected outcomes:  Technology innovations - 1:1 computing for students and teachers, web-based data management programs and computer assisted instruction (CAI) will lead to increased critical thinking, differentiation, personalization and student engagement which will translate to increased student achievement as evidenced by statistically significant increase in number of students enrolled in college prep courses, advanced placement and Career Technical Academies, International Baccalaureate, graduation rate, college acceptance and increase on standardized test scores.Target number of students to be served: 7,600 LVUSD students in initial research projectSpecial project features:  Computer Assisted Instruction - I CAN Learn and ALEKS; 1:1 computing, use of web-based tools - Moodle, Quia, and Basecamp; Skype peer-tutoring, interactive whiteboards, data analysis programs MMARS/LARS, college awareness webinars, and Naviance Succeed."

Project Title: Future Teachers for a New Tomorrow
Project Description: "As a way to build a workforce of effective teachers and principals, we will create Future Teachers for a New Tomorrow Clubs at high need middle and high schools in Santa Clara County.  The clubs will provide extended training of home grown teachers in the schools and districts where they will become teachers.  The project will provide mentors to assure that future teachers are well trained.  The clubs will combine instruction in teaching with practice, a combination that research indicates is the strongest method for teaching effective teachers.  The club members will tutor students younger than themselves at schools that feed into their own schools.  In this way, performance of at-risk students will be raised immediately while future teachers hone their teaching skills over a period of as much as six years before they begin the undergraduate training as teachers.  The program will hold a summer teaching camp each year to consolidate the learning of the future teachers and to recruit new future teachers and teacher-sponsors.  A feeling of isolation is a major cause of teacher attrition.  This program will create a local teacher association to which the future teachers will belong and in which they will continue to participate when they earn their credential.  In this way, a support structure is provided that will increase the length of time teachers spend in teaching as a career.  Club members will be taught in a uniform manner using live broadcasts weekly that will allow top educators to reach all the club members at once.  The San Jose Unified School District?s sophisticated Data Warehouse tracking system will be used to measure effects and permit changes in the program to be data driven."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Law and Leadership Institute, LLC
Project Description: "The Law and Leadership Institute, LLC seeks funding through the Investing in Innovation Fund Development grant to fund program activities.  The Law and Leadership Institute ('LLI') is  a statewide, four-year program of study designed to increase the college attendance and graudation rates of high school students from under-served schools in the Ohio cities of Akron, Cleveland, Cincinnati, Columbus, Dayton and Toledo and ultimately prepare them to excel in their chosen professions.  LLI specifically aims to diversity the legal profession by establishing a pipeline of minority students who are provided significant exposure to careers in the law as well as the necessary academic training, life skills development and test preparation to be successful in college and law school. LLI has partnered with each of Ohio's nine law schools to conduct a 'Summer Institute' in law and leadership for at least four weeks in six cities.  In addition to instruction on writing, reading comprehension and leadership development, the Summer Institute includes a mock trial competition for rising 9th grade students, a paid intership at local law offices for rising 10th grade students and SAT/ACT test preparation for rising 11th grade students.  LLI also conducts programming and mentoring during the academic year to reinforce skills learned during the Summer Institute. Approximately 30 students in each city, or 180 statewide, enroll as rising 9th graders in the hallmark Summer Institute housed at one of eight Ohio law schools.  Each year, a new class of rising ninth graders will be admitted in each city.  Law students, assisted by a public high school teacher, serve as instructors for the Summer Institute classes. Established members of the legal profession voluteer as speakers, host field trips, encourage students to consider professional careers and help prepare students for the college application process."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Lawrence County Joint Vocational School District
Project Title: THE LEARN PROJECT
Project Description: "Project Description:  Lawrence County, Ohio is a rural county in southern Ohio that is characterized by high poverty rates and low educational attainment. The county has 23 public schools that comprise eight school districts.  The eight districts will  develop The Literacy Education And Retention Network.  Through the development of the network, literacy rates in each school district will be increased.  We will accomplish this through the implementation of a proven, research based software program.Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes:  The objectives of the LEARN project are to increase literacy and retention rates in each school with the expected outcome of increased graduation rates as well as enrollment rates into post secondary education.  Using a proven research based software programs students can achieve a 1 to 2 year gain in reading skills in 4 to 16 weeks. Special Project Features:  The LEARN project will have the capacity to be completely mobile and can be implemented with minimal additions to current staff.  It is also self sustainable at minimal cost after initial start up and implementation. Selected curriculum is applicable to K-12."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Reach and Teach Model for the Holistic Education of At-Risk Youth
Project Description: "Under the auspices of the i3 Fund, Lawrence Hall Youth Services anticipates that improved student achievement, graduation rates, and community college/vocational program enrollment are the results of holistic consistently practiced methods that are derived from evidence-based research and address the comprehensive needs of the whole student.  Aspects of the Reach and Teach Model are currently in place and have promising results.  The entire model, however, is still evolving; it requires more research, testing, data collection/analysis, and additional resources for full implementation within LHYS before it can be scaled up then replicated to other schools that serve a similar student population."

Applicant: Leadership for Educational Achievement Foundation,  Inc
Project Title: The Rural Leadership Alliance: When Research, Practice and Community Support Systems are Aligned
Project Description: "Addressing Absolute Priority #1 and Competitive Priority #8 of the i3 grant, the Rural Leadership Alliance will provide professional development of the highest quality ot rural school principals throughout New York State, framed upon a multi-year, multi-tiered professional development delivery model that is research-based and aligned ot the ISLLC 2008 standards. The RLA will develop a cadre of highly experienced rural school coaches/mentors to guide theory into practice. Porgram content will include summer institutes and workshops based on established curriculum form the Mid-continent Research for Education and Learning and the Twin Tiers Coalition for Learning. The project will be guided by the unique experience of all project partners, including supplementary learning activities from the Leadership for Educational Achievement Foundation, Inc., the New York State Center for Rural Schools and the Rural Schools Association of New York. Ongoing coaching and use of technology will be integral components of the Rural Leadership Alliance.Ultimately, the project aims to serve 85,872 students. The Rural Leadership Alliance is a collaboration of nonprofit organizaitons including the Leadership for Educational Achievement Foundation, Inc. (LEAF), the Mid-continent Research for Education and Learning (McREL) and the Tiwn Tiers Coalition for Learning (TTCL and a consortium of high need rural school districts that includde the following LEAs: Bradford CSD, Brasher Falls CSD, Cincinnatus CSD, Downsville CSD, Dundee CSD, Elba CSD, Fallsburg CSD, Gouverneur CSD, Harrisville CSD, Jefferson CSD, Keene CSD, La Fargeville CSD, Laurens CSD, Lowville CSD, Margaretville CSD, New Lebanon CSD, Northville CSD, Norwood-Norfolk CSD, Oppenheim-Ephratah CSD, Roscoe CSD, Roxbury CSD, Schroon Lake CSD, Sharon Springs CSD, Whitney Point CSD. Project Description: "The Learning Center! Project G.R.O.W. (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) Starting in Kindergarten, students spend extended time daily with an investigative / math basics, problem-solving approach to mathematics, science, technology and engineering while developing critical thinking skills that assure STEM literacy for all students 3) FLOWER:A diverse, multi-faceted enrichment/support program  is designed to engage and create a sense of community for all students and parents within an  academic environment supported through physical and environmental wellness. 4) ENVIRONMENT: The school must establish a give-and-receive relationship with the community at large - parents, community members, public agencies and private businesses - to create a healthy, competent, prepared for 21st Century ?Community of Learners?. Project G.R.O.W. embraces this 2 part hypothesis: All Four Components of Reform: 1. broad-based literacy 2. S.T.E.M.  3. Enrichment/Support and 4. ?Community of Learners?   must be present to produce sustainable growth in diverse and high-needs populations of learners within low performing schools in need of restructuring. Applicant: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program, LLC
Project Title: Active Learning Leads to Literacy (ALLL)
Project Description: "ABSTRACT - The Active Learning Leads to Literacy Project (referred to as ALLL or the PROJECT) requests support under the Development category of the Investing in Innovation Fund. The PROJECT is intelligently designed to address a perennial education question concerning the link between the arts and differentiated teaching (to pupils displaying diverse learning styles). Since the evolution of homo sapiens, humans have created art; the arts are an essential part of our nature and all children respond to one art form or another. The PROJECT will further scientifically test the efficacy of a well-defined promising arts-integrated instructional methodology on the teaching and learning of English language arts skills by grades K - 2 pupils.The PROJECT uses drama, dance/creative movement, the visual arts, music, cooking, and games to promote growth in literacy skills of kindergarten through second grade pupils. Sample instructional activities include: making shapes of letters with their body while singing the sounds of the letter and dancing to reinforce letter recognition, creating phonic flap books to build decoding skills, miming to foster learning of new sight words, using puppets to tell stories, using drama presentations to teach character analysis, singing songs such as The Silent Letter 'E' to illustrate phonemic concepts, and other interactive strategies to teach the school's 'business as usual' (BAU) early childhood curriculum."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Virginia's 21st Century e-Teacher Initiative
Project Description: "The Virginia 21st Century e-Teacher Program (21 e-Teacher) is a Development Grant Proposal, addressing i3Absolute Priority 1?Innovations that Support Effective Teachers. A three-year program will be implementedin two Virginia local education agencies (LEAs) that have demonstrated need (Manassas Park City andPortsmouth City) and a pilot program will be expanded in Virginia Beach City Public Schools (VBCPS).LearniT-TeachiT, along with the University of Virginia (UVA), the National Institute of Aerospace (NIA) andVBCPS, have formed a partnership to harness the power of 21st century e-Teaching to increase the number ofteachers who are highly effective with the subsequent outcome of improving student achievement.21 e-Teacher will train teams of teachers from each LEA for certification through UVA?s 21st Century e-TeacherGraduate Series, a rigorous online professional development program that leverages innovative coursewareinto Professional Learning Communities (PLCs) that result in an immediate and transformational impact onclassroom teaching. The courseware will expand to include new units on effectively integrating AssistiveTechnologies throughout all grades and subjects, a well-documented approach towards improving learningoutcomes for students with disabilities, thus addressing i3 Competitive Preference 7, as an innovation thataddresses the unique learning needs of students with disabilities. In Year 2, LEA teams will create their ownlocal Professional Development Programs as a non-credit version of 21 e-Teacher by assigning small groups ofUVA certified teachers from Year 1 to train additional cohorts of teachers. The result of their efforts will be acertified or local credential for more than 700 teachers across three LEAs, impacting approximately 16,000students as the program continues in Years 2 and 3 (see Table A1 in Section A for details)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: One to One iPad/iPod Touch in Education
Project Description: "A grassroots collaboration of Lee, Owsley, and Wolfe County School Districts, Northern Kentucky University, and Apple Computers wishes to implement the One to One iPad/iPod Touch in Education project. During the three (3) year grant period all high and middle school students will receive iPads and all students and the elementary schools will receive an iPod Touch. Teachers at these facilities willl receive MacBooks and the device their students are using. The project will create a digital learning cafe environment, focusing on the greatest areas of academic needs through a review of student testing and assessment scores. A Vanguard Group of 10 school district teachers will be formed at each district and will assist in the integration of these technologies into curriculums, lesson plans, and special assignments. This environment will foster 21st Century Learning Skill by providing the tools, staff professional development, and technical support to meet the following objectives and goals: 1) collaboration: devices will allow the follwing types of collaboration; student to student; teacher to student, and teacher to teacher; 2) creation: devices will empower and enable students to complete cross platform multimedial projects, utilizing Macs and Window devices; 3) Distribution of Data: protocols to distribute and collect data from both students and teachers, including iTunes U, Kentucky Encyclomedia, and district data servers to name a few; 4) Mobile Access of Data: anytime/anywhere access to approximately 3,200 students and 250 teachers in Lee, Owsley, and Wolfe Counties in Eastern Kentucky through distribution of devices, organizing Vanguard Groups, professional development, and collecting research and grant related data."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Promise of Algebra: Teaching Math Beyond Textbooks and Classroom Walls
A Validation of the Literacy Collaborative School Improvement Program
Project Description: "This five-year Investing in Innovation Validation project will address the need to strengthen early literacy instruction for high-needs students, who would otherwise struggle in early grades without a high quality literacy learning environment, through a partnership of three large school districts; a consortium of rural schools; a school improvement program, Literacy Collaborative (LC), that trains school-based literacy coaches and supports whole-school improvement; Teachscape, an innovative educational technology company; and a research and development center, the Center on Teaching and Learning at the University of Oregon. The project will build on a recent IES-funded study that showed a 32% value-added increase in student literacy growth in 17 LC schools. In this project, the partners will work together to create a blended face-to-face and online version of LC's rigorous coach training program, create new technology-supported tools for using data in LC schools, and implement LC in 92 schools. A randomized trial of the LC program will further test its ability to raise student achievement for more types of high-needs students. We will gather data about educational practices that are effective for students who are English language learners, have disabilities, or attend rural schools. At the end of the project, all 92 schools will have trained coaches and the districts will be prepared to expand and sustain the program.  Literacy Collaborative will also have a blended training program and new technology tools so it can be scaled-up to a regional or state level. We estimate that 37,000 students will participate in the LC program during the five project years."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: K 16 Bridge Program Partnership Project
Project Description: "The Lewis Center for Educational Research will develop and expand the K16 Bridge Program Partnership Project to significantly increase the number of high risk high school students in California and Texas who will complete high school, transition to a postsecondary educational instituiton and complete a course leading to a certificate or degree. Currently the program is limited to the number of students reached, but with the assistance of an extensive network of collaborating LEAs, State agencies high schools, non-profit organizations, we will expand the successful but limited efforts of the K16 Bridge Program to serve a minimum of 500,000 students through 69 school districts across California and Texas."

Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Academic Achievement through Community Engagement for Hisk-Risk Students
Project Description: "This project, Academic Achievement through Community Engagement for High-Need Students, addresses Absolute Priority 3: Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments by helping students, particularly youth who are identified as Limited English Proficient (LEP), improve academically and complete high school.  Liberty's Promise, a nonprofit organization that supports low-income, immigrant youth, will carry out a community engagement project in partnership with a consortium of seven public high schools in suburban Maryland.  This intervention involves a 30-hour, 10-week, after-school program of civic engagement and (for legally documented youth) an eight-week professional internship.  During the three-year grant period, we expect to serve 900 LEP students in our after-school program.  Of those youth, 360 (40%) will also intern at a local nonprofit organization, government agency, or small business, typically during the summer.  The Department of Social Work at George Mason University will undertake an ongoing evaluation of the project.To help LEP youth achieve academically, we have three objectives: (1) 80% of our youth increase their civic knowledge and understanding of their community, (2) 60% of our youth become more engaged in the community, and (3) 80% of our youth pursue pathways to college and/or employment.Sessions of the after-school programs of civic engagement will occur twice a year (once in the spring and once in the fall) at partner schools or at local community sites.  Each session will be held twice per week. For each program, a course facilitator will be hired to run each session and introduce youth to the day's topic. The program consists of group activities, field trips into the community, and guest speakers.  Sessions include financial literacy, college and scholarship representatives, panels of speakers from local organizations to enhance community involvement, and job preparedness workshops."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Life Services System of Ottawa County, Inc.
Project Title: Parents and Communities United for Success
Project Description: "Life Services System (LSS) is proposing a strategy that involves combining several proven programs, with some supplementation, to create a continuum of support from Birth through 3rd grade (0-8).  The program goals will be accomplished through a targeted approach to reform involving augmenting the school week/year with more time for students to learn core academic content; integrating support services to address the non-academic barriers of children, beginning at an early age; engaging parents in their children's development and learning, starting at birth; establishing a protocol for schools and parents to work together on an educational plan for their student/child; and securing the private sector's support and understanding of the importance of early childhood learning."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Transforming Lincoln's Kindergarten Program: Extending Time and Integrating Instruction to Support the Development of the Whole Child
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: ACE - Analyze, Create, Evaluate
Project Description: "LPS proposes to implement this project to guarantee a highly effective teacher in every classroom and a highly effective principal in every school by creating an interconnected system of appraisal, professional development, and student achievement for 35,000 students. This Validation project will analyze, create and evaluate (ACE) the system continuously. The perpetual motion towards excellence will improve student achievement for all student groups. The Grow Our Own focus program will include partnerships with Doane College and the University of Nebraska Lincoln focused on teacher and administrator development, recruitment, induction, and on-going professional development based on the effective teacher/principal targets established in the new appraisal systems. This grant will support the implementation of a new teacher appraisal system and a new principal appraisal system linked to a technology system to enhance the use of student data in both formative and summative ways.The objectives of the project are grouped under the following goals: 1) Implement newly developed, research supported teacher appraisal system; 2) Implement the principals' appraisal system; 3) Teachers and principals that receive grant interventions will improve effectiveness through an integrated professional development plan based on the results of the teacher/principal appraisal system supported through the use of technology; 4) Pre-service teacher candidates receiving grant interventions will have stronger impact on student achievement. Primary outcomes will be: a) Increased number of effective teachers and principals; b) improved evaluation and supervision system that fosters highly effective teachers and principals; c) Improved student achievement for all students; and, d) Improved use of data to increase student achievement. Official partners for the project include: University of Nebraska Lincoln, and Doane College."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Investing In Innvoation at Lincoln University
Project Description: "Lincoln University, in keeping with its 150-year history of educating African Americans as well as other underrepresented groups in society, is proposing to sponsor an Investing in Innovation project which will serve approximately 360 students (ninety per target school) in the Philadelphia School District.   These participants will come from three target schools that have been identified as low performing by the state of Pennsylvania and one target school that is currently in warning status.  The city of Philadelphia, which makes up the county of Philadelphia, is the eighth largest school district in the nation.  After nine years of state-mandated requirements to restructure the entire school system, Philadelphia still struggles to provide an adequate education to its young people.  The schools targeted for service in this proposal currently do not have enough textbooks for their students to take home.  Students from these schools have some of the lowest scores in the state on the standardized test mandated by the No Child Left Behind Act.  The graduation rates for these schools are low.  The dropout rate for three of the target schools is eight times greater than the Chester, Montgomery, Bucks and Delaware, school districts which are the surrounding counties.The overall purpose of the Investing in Innovation project at Lincoln University will be to close the achievement gap of the target schools by decreasing the dropout rates, increasing high school graduation rates, increasing college enrollment and completion rates, increasing the number of students at each school who attain a proficient level or above on the 11th grade Pennsylvania System of School Assessment"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Academy of Technology and Multimedia Studies at Lincoln-Marti Charter Schools?????
Project Description: "The Academy of Technology and Multimedia Studies (ATMS) at Lincoln-Marti Charter Schools will serve as the 9th-12th grade Program of Studies at Lincoln-Marti Charter Schools. Upon acceptance into the Academy, students will participate in a program that will prepare them to lead the next generation of multimedia artists and producers.  Students will have access to the latest industry-specific equipment and resources.  The curriculum will emphasize real world instruction and the cutting-edge technology that drive the film, television, radio, music business, graphic design, web design, and computer animation industries.  Students and faculty will participate regularly in conferences and workshops to sharpen their skills and keep abreast with the latest technology and industry standards and practices.  The Academy will offer students the opportunity to participate in field-based learning opportunities which will facilitate student's network within the industry.  The curriculum will offer a strong four-year foundation in various areas of multimedia productions, taught by certified instructors, in-field professionals and professors from adjoining colleges.  Dual enrollment college-level courses will bridge the pathway from high school to college."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Little Dixie Community Action Agency, Inc.
Project Title: Project SUCCESS (School Utilizing Community Collaborations to Ensure Student Success
Project Description: "Little Dixie Community Action Agency, Inc.(LDCAA)  is requested $4,999,841 in funding from  the U.S. Department of Education's Investing in Innovation fund  in order to operate PROJECT SUCCESS (Schools Utilizing Community Collaborations to Ensure School Success.  Project SUCCESS is a collaboration between LDCAA and 5 partnering public school districts in grades pre-k through three, all schools are located in rural southeast Oklahoma.  Project SUCCESS will implement a successful model for supporting effective teachers and principals which has been field tested by LDCAA for five years through funding provided by the U.S. Department of Education's Early Reading First Program.  The model incorporates three key components:  extensive professional development; a quality classroom environment, and intense parent involvement.  Project SUCCESS will expand on this model to include a technology component in order to ensure cost efficiency in regards to information dissemination and project replication across an unlimited geographic area.  In addition, Project SUCCESS will also include a research component which will provide data on the hypothesis that through the use of technology  effective professional development can be delivered to teachers in remote locations and at a reasonable cost."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: College Readiness Course Series
Project Description: "Lone Star College-Online is part of the Lone Star College System (LSCS), an innovative and comprehensive two-year community college system located in the north Houston, Texas area. The LSCS is the second-largest community college system in the state of Texas, providing educational programs and services to over 135,000 students annually and encompassing over 1400 square miles.Lone Star College-Online, the online teaching and learning division of the LSCS, requests funding for an i3 Development Grant for the purpose of creating the College Readiness Course Series (CRCS). The College Readiness Course Series will include multiple courses designed to bridge skill gaps of an estimated 7,000 high-need students not eligible for dual-credit course entry during their sophomore or junior year. Program Goals are to:1. Prepare high-need students for college level courses while in high school2. Reduce the number of developmental education courses at the college level.3. Increase high school graduation rates.4. Increase college enrollment and student successThe CRCS Project is a collaborative effort between our K-12 partner Aldine ISD and Lone Star College System faculty. As a 2009 Broad Prize winner for Urban Education in 2009, Aldine ISD is uniquely positioned to provide the targeted population of students with the opportunity of participating in this project. Aldine ISD is fully accredited from the Texas Education Agency and in 2008 was the 11th largest school district in Texas."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Destination Lone Star College
Project Description: "Destination Lone Star College is a collaborative effort between our local ISD?s and Lone Star College System faculty. This program will serve approximately 69,547 students. Lone Star College System, as the primary applicant, is seeking $30,000,000.00 through the Investing in Innovation Fund to support a community-wide initiative that will target and support the efforts of at-risk students attending fifteen (15) area high schools and eight (8) independent school districts (ISDs), as they become aware of and prepared to enter college level courses. LSCS is working with private sector partners to secure an additional $6 million in matching funds for this project. As the applicant, LSCS intends to facilitate the entire project and budget while working with the ISDs. The technology along with the technological support will be provided directly to the schools from LSCS. Ultimately, Lone Star College System intends to increase student achievement and attainment, by building off of its proven evidence-based interventions, activities, and programs.Destination Lone Star College?s goals are based on the assumptions that students who successfully transition from high school to college are (1) aware of their options and college requirements at an early age; and (2) academically prepared students that are able to move directly into college level courses, shortening the length of time and expenses required to obtain higher education.Program Goals are to:1. Destination Lone Star College creates an opportunity for high school students attending at-risk schools to develop a college-going culture.2. Destination Lone Star College will increase academic preparation for students in danger of being under-prepared for college level courses."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Long Beach - Fresno COMPASS Project: Collaborative Opportunities for Making Proficiency Accessible for Student Success
Project Description: "The Long Beach Unified School District (LBUSD), in partnership with the Fresno Unified School District (FUSD), will implement the Long Beach - Fresno COMPASS Project (Collaborative Opportunities for Making Proficiency Accessible for Student Success) through an i3 Development grant.  Beginning in 2008, LBUSD partnered with FUSD as an alternative way to provide support to a school district that was in Program Improvement and required an external consultant to work with them to design their improvement plan. Through this proposal, COMPASS will focus on two key areas - implementing the Mathematics Achievement Program and Professional Development, and implementing a consistent and articulated writing program. Through innovative partnership strategies, COMPASS is uniquely positioned to address Competitive Priority Areas 6 and 7, and Absolute Priority Area 3.	COMPASS activities will roll-out over a five-year period, with Long Beach focusing on writing from 2010- 2013 and Fresno focusing on mathematics during this same timeframe. In 2013, the two school districts will engage in a transitional period where best practices and lessons learned will be integrated into Partnership activities.  Throughout the life of the i3 grant, intensive and innovative sharing will occur that continuously focus on quality improvement that drive curriculum, instruction, and professional development.  During years 2013-2015, the districts will change curricular focus areas and implement key strategies based on lessons learned supportive of academic achievement.	This project has three aligned strategies: training teachers in common instructional approaches, supporting teachers in implementing key writing and mathematics strategies through coaching, and monitoring of both strategy implementation and student learning.  The ultimate outcome is to increase students' readiness to successfully participate in advanced high school and collegiate coursework without remediation."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Scribo Digita: Innovating Instruction Across the Curriculum through Writing
Project Description: "Longwood Institute for Teaching through Technology and Innovative Practices (ITTIP) and collaborating LEAs have studied the impact of an Automated Writing Evaluation (AWE) tool, MY Access!, on improving the writing achievement of students of all students. Results from a pilot middle school implementation have shown significant improvement on standardized writing test scores. An objective is for middle and high school students to use MY Access! to help them increase their writing proficiency, which will benefit them as they move on to college and the workplace. In addition to examining the impact of MY Access! on student writing, Scribo Digita will focus on changing teacher instructional practices in rural, semi-urban, and high-need middle and high schools in Central Virginia through train-the-trainer Writing Across the Curriculum (WAC) professional development, with the objective of increasing teacher leadership on writing and school-wide incorporation of writing projects into the curriculum in alignment with Common Core Standards for Writingand Virginia Standards of Learning. Teachers will use MY Access! to assess students? writing and to meet the varied needs of students in all sub-groups. The project will track students in their choice of advanced courses, dual enrollment courses, and colleges for admission. The ability of MY Access! to effect change in teacher practice and student writing performance will be assessed via a stratified (by grade span) two-level design with delayed treatment that nests students within schools that are randomly assigned to receive MY Access! or not.  From within the MY Access! recipient schools, the value added of Writing Across the Curriculum will be explored through a Year 3 randomized trial assigning half of the MY Access! schools to receive WAC professional development and examining outcomes. The project will provide opportunities for virtual field trips to college campuses and face-to-face interactions with academic experts."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Lorain City Schools Universal Preschool Program
Project Description: "Lorain City Schools is expanding its existing preschool program to serve an additional 1,200 children over a fiveyear period. Lorain's preschool model shows promising results in the area of improving student readiness forkindergarten. National research reveals that students who participate in preschool programs demonstrateincreased student achievement throughout elementary and secondary school career."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Northern New Mexico Inquiry Science Education Consortium Project
Project Description: "Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) Foundation in Espanola proposes to create the Northern New Mexico Inquiry Science Education Consortium Project as a regional program to improve performance of high-need students in grades K-6 in Northern New Mexico through an i3 Development grant.  As a nonprofit, LANL Foundation will be the lead applicant with a consortium of LEAs: Santa Fe, Espa
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: LOS ANGELES COUNTY OFFICE OF EDUCATION
Project Title: Project 21: Coming of Age as 21st Century Learners and Critical Thinkers
Project Description: "Addressing Absolute Priority 3 ? Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments, the Los Angeles County Office of Education (LACOE) proposes PROJECT 21 to utilize project-based learning (PBL) to build 21st century skills. The project aims to increase both the success of all students and, in particular, under-represented, high-need student populations by helping schools and educators create PBL-driven classroom environments. PROJECT 21 features three critical supports?professional learning communities, peer coaching, and technology?that will enable teachers to translate academic standards and information from assessments into intellectual behaviors identified as academically rigorous at the highest level of Bloom?s Taxonomy, i.e., critical thinking."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Humanitas: On Track for College and Career
Project Description: "LAEP will expand its promising Humanitas initiative into 12 small high schools or SLCs, enrolling 4,500 primarily low-income, minority students, in the L.A. Unified School District. LAEP?s Humanitas initiative is an instructional model featuring theme-based, standards-based, college-prep curriculum that includes engaging interdisciplinary lessons that are relevant to students. Humanitas has three core components: 1) high-quality academic preparation, 2) learning linked to real-life experiences, and 3) college-access. Teachers will receive extensive PD and collaborate closely. LAEP?s connections to community and business organizations will provide student with work experiences and enriched learning. College-access services will reduce barriers to college. Prior implementation of Humanitas has produced evidence that students score higher on standardized tests, accumulate more credits, stay in school, graduate on time, and have higher intentions to attend college vs. nonparticipants."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: L.A.'s Bold Competition -- Turning Around and Operating Its Low-Performing Schools
Project Description: "The Initiative focuses on enhancing the distinctive features of an open competition for operators of turnaround schools. In the competition, applicant teams and selected schools can receive support through the Los Angeles School Development Institute (LASDI); iDesign, a unique department in Los Angeles Unified School District's Innovation and Charter Schools Division that focuses on empowering and supporting schools to implement innovative and effective practices; and other mechanisms that aim to accelerate student achievement by reforming the way in which school districts serve and support their students. The primary objective of the Initiative is to create a rich portfolio of high-performing schools that are tailored to and supported by the local community. To do this the project will: (1) Enhance the Public School Choice Selection Process, (2) Support the Implementation of the Instructional Plans of the Selected Teams, and (3) Implement Accountability and Continuous Improvement Measures.The L.A. Compact, an unprecedented and diverse collaborative of 18 major Los Angeles institutions, whose members include Official Partners (UNITE-LA and the United Way of Greater Los Angeles) and Other Partners (City of Los Angeles, the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, United Teachers Los Angeles, and the Association of Administrators Los Angeles), will not only further develop and enhance the process through focused school- and community-based support, but will also help to ensure transparency, accountability and competition. L.A. Compact members will engagie parents, teachers, bargaining units, organized labor, nonprofit organizations, administrators, and private businesses - stakeholders that are demanding better schools - and empower them to shape the management structures, leadership, instructional models, and school cultures and climates in Los Angeles' low-performing schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: PRIME TIME Full Circle: A Parental Engagement Model for School Reform
Project Description: "PRIME TIME Full Circle:  A Parental Engagement Model for School ReformPRIME TIME Full Circle is a comprehensive school initiative applying for an I-3 Development Grant that offers unique and effective teacher, parent and student supports that address Absolute Priority 4: Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools via Competitive Preference Priority 5--Innovations for Improving Early Learning Outcomes and Competitive Preference Priority 8-Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEAs.  PRIME TIME Full Circle is a partnership between the nonprofit Louisiana Endowment for the Humanities, the largest state humanities council in the country, 4 urban and 1 rural LEAs. This project is designed to reach as many as 32,100 students at a cost of $5 million, for an average of roughly $155 per student.  PRIME TIME Full Circle incorporates three structural phases of the LEH's proven programming: (1) teacher graduate seminars that bring advanced literacy techniques into the classroom; (2) PRIME TIME Family Reading Time programs led by scholars and storytellers to engage families in the school setting; (3) and the newest element: PRIME TIME Homeroom, professional development workshops that deliver PRIME TIME techniques to  classrooms, all with the ultimate mission of engaging families and teachers to improve outcomes for students in Louisiana's lowest-performing schools, thus increasing School Performance Scores.Previous PRIME TIME Family Reading Time (PT FRT) family literacy programs and the  PRIME TIME teacher professional development programs (PT TIAS) have resulted in statistically significant improvements over non-participants on both the state LEAP and iLEAP tests.  The increase in standardized test score performance was particularly pronounced among minority (African-American) students and students on free and reduced lunch.  PRIME TIME Homeroom adds an additional dimension completing a structure to engage parents and maximize school effectiveness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Aspiring to Excellence: Investing in Innovative Teacher Professional Development
Project Description: "Aspiring to Excellence: Investing in Innovative Teacher Professional Development is an i3 Validation proposal addressing Absolute Priority 1--Innovations that Support Effective Teachers. An extraordinary evolution and adaptation of previously successful Louisiana Endowment for the Humanities (LEH)-directed teacher professional development programs, Aspiring to Excellence is designed to increase teacher effectiveness, as measured by student performance on the State of Louisiana's standardized tests in English Language Arts and Social Studies, as well as other objective measurements of teacher and student growth. The 5-year project involves innovative year-round teacher professional development programs, including 100 intensive graduate-level summer teacher institutes enrolling a target of 400 teachers of high-need students annually who teach an estimated 176,250 students over the course of the project, and regular, day-long in-service workshops, on a regional scale never before available to Louisiana public school teachers. Based on past results a significant increase in student test scores is targeted. Aspiring to Excellence is a partnership between the nonprofit LEH, 2 urban and 4 urban/rural school districts (Caddo, Calcasieu, East Baton Rouge, Jefferson, Orleans and Terrebonne parishes); and 5 public and 2 private universities (Louisiana State University and A&M College, Louisiana State University at Shreveport, Nicholls State University, McNeese State University, University of New Orleans, Tulane University and Loyola University of New Orleans); and KnowLA, the digital encyclopedia of Louisiana history and culture. Additional partners are the National Council of Teachers of English, the Gilder Lehrman Institute for American History, the National Archives, the Library of Congress, the Smithsonian Museum of American Art and the National Portrait Gallery. In addition, the proposed project targets 13 additional school districts proximate to the 6 LEAs of record."

Project Title: Recovery School District
Project Description: "Louisiana?s Recovery School District, with its ?other? partners Advance Innovation Education and Sweat EquityEducation, is applying for a Development Grant under Absolute Priority 4. This project will study theeffectiveness of the Sweat Equity Education project-based intervention targeting high-need students, to turnaround the RSD?s I3 Fund Absolute Priority 4 high schools. The study will measure the impact of theintervention on improving academic outcomes, closing the achievement gap, and increasing studentengagement by lowering dropout rates, thereby increasing high school graduation and college access rates.SEE taps into students? passion for pop culture and interest in design and fashion via real-world projects andpublic/private partnerships. Its interdisciplinary, project-based learning approach integrates concepts frombusiness, design, technology and entrepreneurship with core coursework in literacy, math, and social scienceknowledge. One hundred percent of SEE?s participants to date--high-need minority students from low-income,urban neighborhoods like RSD?s population?have graduated from high school, and 95% of the first cohorthas been accepted to college.Two successive cohorts of 900 students from eight high schools will be randomly assigned to the experimental orcontrol groups. The control group will take two semesters of Business Computer Applications. Those assignedto the SEE intervention will experience a two-year program consisting of foundational concepts, skills anddesign projects for real companies in the four semesters of 10th and 11th grade years, with an optional 3rd year(12th grade) peer-to-peer mentoring of students in the next cohort. Their instructors will receive training in theSEE curriculum, program elements and overall approach one semester ahead of each of the four courses. Withthe end product of original concepts and designs presented to real world clients, SEE participants begin tounderstand the relevance of school"

Project Title: RSD - RTI and Early Learning
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: Louisiana State University and A&M College
Project Title: The Magic Circle: Case-Management, Student Data and Improved Achievement
Project Description: "The LSU College of Education is applying for a Developmental grant under Absolute Priority 2 and Competitive Preference Priorities 6 and 8. This study intends to investigate a case-managed dropout prevention program for at-risk students using long-term, relationship-based strategies designed to foster academic achievement, college access, and workforce readiness. The investigation will include 6 cohorts including 4 groups participating in various dosages of treatment and 2 comparison groups. Three of the treatment groups participate in the highest dosage of case-management which consists of a residential summer on the LSU campus, followed by 4 years of school year services. One treatment group participates in a case-management component for 4 or more years that does not have a residential component. All treatment groups will receive some combination of the following activities in the case-managed design: tutoring, counseling, mentoring, work readiness, credit recovery, summer school, leadership, and parental involvement. The program as described above is designed to increase the graduation rate of program participants over comparison groups. Annual objectives are established for each student which includes attaining the required high school credits for promotion to the next grade and passing Louisiana?s Graduate Exit Exam (GEE) required for students to graduate from high school. The program intends to target 1,300 students in the treatment groups and 1,200 students in the comparison groups. A specifically designed data base (GUPPES) by the faculty and graduate students from the LSU College of Engineering has been created to support the case-managed delivery of the program. The data base tracks student demographics, services and outcomes. LSU is officially partnering with three LEAs: the Recovery School District of New Orleans (inner-city), the St. Helena Parish Public School District (rural), and the East Baton Rouge Parish Public School District (urban/suburban)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Louise ISD Investing in Innovation
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Sowing the Seeds of STEM Success
Project Description: "Sowing the Seeds of STEM Success is a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) project designed to improve the educational outcomes and learning transitions of elementary students.  By providing an engaging, integrated STEM program that is aligned to high standards, children are better prepared for success in core academic subjects and successive grades.  The project leverages the development and implementation of hands-on technology and engineering curriculum that integrates and supports science and mathematics instruction within the context of a place and a targeted STEM career field. At the root of the Sowing the Seeds of STEM Success project is a curriculum design that is matched to early learning milestones and employs inquiry and design-based instructional strategies in order to ensure that all students meet them. By implementing this integrated STEM curriculum and assessment program with fidelity, providing ongoing professional development to teacher and principals, with support from adminstrators and the community, and through co-curricular opportunities for cooperative competition, all students will find success in STEM subjects, develop a level of STEM literacy, and increase STEM achievement."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Computer Adaptive Diagnostic Teast: An Innovation to Improve the use of Data
Project Description: "The goal of the project is to develop and implement a computer adaptive diagnostic data tool that will assist educators in making accurate and reliable instructional decisions to improve student achievement.  The objectives of the project are: (1) to improve educator data use; (2) to improve student achievement; (3) to improve teacher effectiveness; and (4) to narrow the achievement gap for special needs students.  In order to achieve the aforementioned goals the project activities include:  assessment tool development, online course development, development of personalized study plans for remediation of achievement deficits, and offering high quality, job-embedded professional development.The LPVEC expects its innovation initiative to result in the creation of nine full time jobs, the training of 170 teachers in online course development and data driven instruction, the delivery of over 20,000 hours of high quality professional development over the 60 month project period, the development of one cognitively adaptive assessment tool addressing learning standards across grade levels 6-9, and 320 individualized instructional units.  The LPVEC will provide the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary access to the tool at the end of the project period thereby making the tool accessible to approximately 79,000 students.  The project expands upon the LPVEC online learning project.  The project will allow the LPVEC to use its experience in online learning and online course development and the knowledge and skill set of three trained psychometricians to integrate the principals of adaptive and differentiated instruction into traditional online learning.  Victory Energy Solutions has agreed to provide financial support for the project."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Innovating Instruction: Creating Success
Project Description: "Lowndes County Public Schools have consistently ranked in the lowest 5% of schools within the State of Alabama.  In order to change this downward trend, the Board of Education is excited to implement a Total School Transformation plan, that addresses needs for changes in instruction and use of technological assets, but more importantly, addresses the culture within the schools.  Traditional instructional models, i.e. teaching to the bell curve, where some students are statistically expected to fail, are no longer acceptable in our district.  Unwilling to remain at the bottom with persistently low-achieving schools, the Board of Education is embracing comprehensive instructional strategies, informed by data driven research assessment tools, to implement a prescriptive, individualized learning program, constantly monitoring and measuring mastery of standards, and adapting instructional components for successful mastery by each student. Data, technology and instruction modules will be introduced to created individualized learning modules for each student.  The goal of this transformative process is create positive changes for our students, demonstrating that each student has the ability to master and learn concepts, and remediate learning deficits, but most importantly, places our children on a pathway to success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Guiding Education Transitions
Project Description: "Highly qualified and professionally trained college student practitioners serving as transition coaches will support urban high school students as they transition into and out of high school. Loyola University Chicago seeks funding for its Guiding Education Transitions (GET) program, an innovative Devlopment Grant initiative that addresses Absolute Priority #4 by contributing to the turn around of low performing high schools. Guiding Education Transitions will increase instruction time and provide targeted support that addresses the critical academic and non-academic needs of two transitioning urban student groups - high school freshmen and senors. The GET program will impove student achievement, decrease dropout rates, increase graduation rates, and incrase student matriculation into productive post secondary options. ? GET Student interventions will serve approximately 5,200 students on Saturday mornings in 3 urban high schools that share an average profile of at least 90 percent low-income enrollment and 64 percent or less graduation rate. GET will provide two distinct interventions: GET-Freshmen! and GET-Seniors! High achieving transition coaches in both GET interventions will facilitate small learning environments that expose students to high quality standards based instruciton, motivational pedagogy and practical applications that demonstrate the relevancy of higher education. GET transition coaches will work in a ration of 1:4 for 3-hour study sessions at an urban school site from 9am-12 pm on 22 Saturday mornings during the school year. GET-Freshmen! will focus on homework support and basic skill building while GET-Seniors! will explore the gamut post-secondary topics. ? Partners in the GET-Program include the Chicago Public Schools central office as well as the students, staff, and administrations of Curie Metro and Kelly High Schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project K-Nect
Ludlow Public School's Project High Performers: Improving Achievement through Data-Driven, Job-Embedded Professional Development
Project Description: "Ludlow Public Schools' (LPS) exceptional approach to meeting the Secretary's Absolute Priority #2, 'Innovations that Improve the Use of Data,' is Project High Performers, a comprehensive job-embedded professional development program. Using data-driven decision making at critical points, Project High Performers provides LPS teachers with the knowledge, skill-building opportunities, and infrastructure necessary to meet their students' academic and social-emotional needs, thereby greatly impacting student learning, growth and achievement. Through this program, teachers participate in over 100 hours of intensive professional development over the course of each school year in the form of (a) Cycled Coaching in Literacy and Math, (b) the Service Team Model for Collaborative Problem Solving; and (c) the Flexible Framework for Creating Trauma-Sensitive Schools. Each approach represents a best and/or promising - but not yet widely adopted - method of job-embedded professional development focused on improving teacher effectiveness in the context of a coordinated, efficient infrastructure. Furthermore, their combined use has never before been implemented outside of Ludlow and will allow LPS' teachers to meet the need of students in the general population as well as those with special needs."

Project Title: Creating a Community-based, Data-driven PK-16 Network to Increase Postsecondary Attainment Rates of Rural Students
Project Description: "The project integrates regional pre-K through Grade-16 systems into a cohesive, data-driven network so that schools and communities achieve a 50% postsecondary degree attainment rate among adults aged 25 and over by 2020. Specific strategies are: (1) establishing and evaluating the success of a PK-16 network that integrates key leadership from Lyndon State College with representative schools from supervisory unions in the Northeast Kingdom (NEK), a substantially impoverished rural area in Vermont, as well as representatives from tech/vocational and other relevant organizations; (2) conducting a longitudinal panel study to pinpoint how students in the NEK make postsecondary decisions and how to best target interventions to enhance their postsecondary attainment and persistence; (3) facilitating curricular and structural change at the school level, including the adoption of professional development activities for rural teachers and associated school personnel; and (4) expanding into grades 4-12 a postsecondary service learning model that involves students and teachers in community-based, contextualized learning experiences."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Maximizing the Middle: A Responsive and Data Driven Model for Student and Teacher Excellence in Macomb County
Project Description: "Maximizing the Middle: A Responsive and Data Driven Model for Student and Teacher Excellence in MacombCounty proposal is an exceptional approach to meeting the needs of middle school students by focusing onimproving the academic proficiency and the social, emotional and health preparation of students in grades 6-8to meet Michigan?s rigorous requirements for high school graduation and to ensure college and careerreadiness. This proposal will use as its Absolute Priority?Innovations that Improve the Use of Data by usingstrategies, practices or programs that are designed to encourage and facilitate the evaluation, analysis, and useof student achievement or student growth data by educators, and other stakeholders in order to informdecision-making and improve student achievement, student growth, or teacher/principal/school, or LEAperformance and productivity. The Michigan Education Association (MEA) and American Federation ofTeachers (AFT) are ready to collaboratively join with the MISD to research, develop, and implement a highlyreliable student growth model that can be used with a research based evaluation instrument for teachers in thecounty."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Reaching Our Potential: Expanding College Readiness District Wide
Project Description: "We would like to close the achievement gap at Madison Consolidated Schools by implementing the AVID program, which has shown considerable success in sending lower socioeconomic and minority students to college. We also hope to use the program as a catalyst to highly train teachers to use AVID's research based practices and methodologies. Finally, by using AVID's requirement to collect data about our programs, we hope to use that data to help all of our students succeed academically and to use the information to guide school improvement practices."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Madison County Early Childhood Alliance
Project Description: "The Madison County Early Childhood Alliance will bring high quality preschool education to students throughout Madison County. The Early Childhood Alliance will bring together organizations of the Madison County community that assist with the development of young children. The purpose of the Alliance is to promote consistent, high quality preschool education through the use of high standards and high-quality assessments regardless of the agency providing services. The Alliance forms a partnership with the school district and several privately-run child care centers in the community.
