This partnership provides those child care centers with benefits including training and support for implementing Kentucky Early Childhood Standards, mentoring time with preschool and kindergarten teachers in the district, and other resources to promote kindergarten readiness. The Alliance would fund a Madison County Schools classroom in each of the participating child care centers including a certified preschool teacher and assistant. These additional classrooms would provide opportunities for children who are not currently enrolled in the state-funded preschool program or in the federally funded Head Start program."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Ready Together: Children, Families and Schools
Project Description: "Ready-Together- Children, Families and Schools project is designed to raise student performance in SST 5 elementary school buildings in School Improvement status.??.Truncated"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Androscoggin Digital Literacy Project
Project Description: "This Development project is designed for Absolute Priority 3 - Innovations that complement the implementation of high standards and high-quality assessments. This 3-year project will engage teachers in a job-embedded and professional learning community-oriented model of professional development, through which teachers will learn an instructional model that they will then apply in their classrooms to help both high-need and non-high-need students learn the digital literacy skills that are critical for college- and career-readiness.This project will serve about 430 classroom teachers and 5350 students in four Maine high schools and three Maine middle schools. The instructional model, Internet Reciprocal Teaching (IRT), teaches online reading comprehension, communication, and problem solving skills in five areas: identifying important problems, locating information, critically evaluating online information, synthesizing information, and communicating information online. In addition, IRT develops the more rigorous and challenging collaborative skills required to work online with students in other locations, completing a project that is integrated with subject area curricula.This project will extend previous work to a sample population of both high-need and non-high-need students in all grades at the middle and high school levels and in all subject areas, again in classrooms with 1-to-1 laptop access for students. This project will train secondary teachers to implement IRT in subject area classrooms, using a professional development model trialed last year in Maine.As our nation increases the use of the Internet in school classrooms, it is essential that we begin to help teachers integrate online reading comprehension skills into content classes.  This is especially important since academic achievement is dependent on the ability to read and comprehend at high levels, and the Internet is now a primary source for information and communication."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: RTI Plus One
Project Description: "The Maine Support Network (MSN), a 501 (c)(3) non-profit organization, applying with a consortium of sevenMaine school districts, seeks a five-year i3 Development Grant in response to Absolute Priority 3, Innovationsthat Compliment the Implementation of High Standards and High Quality Assessments, and CompetitivePreference Priority 8, Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEA?s. The partners will support rural districtsto meet the RTI Tier I goal of 80% of students reaching grade level benchmarks in the core program allstudents experience, reduce special education referrals, establish continuous improvement cycles inparticipating districts, and create comprehensive K-12 RTI system models in the areas of reading/literacy andbehavior. The project will directly impact 60,000 students by the end of the fifth project year and regional andstatewide dissemination activities conducted with the project partners in years three through five will reach anadditional 71,000 students.The Response to Intervention (RTI) Plus One Project will implement a strategic set of innovative strategies toimprove student achievement and close achievement gaps experienced by high need students in rural Maineschool districts. The project team unites the knowledge, skills, and experiences of the Maine Support Network(MSN) and the Public Consulting Group (PCG) related to RTI, reading/literacy, and behavior. The projectpartners have substantive experience working with rural districts to implement systemic change and havesuccessfully overcome a number of common barriers faced by rural districts."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Closing High School Achievement Gaps in Literacy through Innovative Technology Supported Personalized Instruction (TSPI)
Project Description: "Maine Township High School District 207 (Maine 207) requests $4,999,959 from the U.S. Department ofEducation?s Investing in Innovation Fund for a Development grant to further develop, and refine atransformational, research-based practice to substantially reduce high school literacy achievement gapsthrough the use of technology supported individualized instruction (TSPI). Google is providing an in-kindmatching donation of software and data-processing services of $1,956,000. This project would begin inJanuary of 2011 and finish in June of 2015 and would involve instructional interventions over a period of threeschool years (2012, 2013, and 2014), working in six high schools from two school districts, Maine 207 andCommunity Unit School District 300 (CUSD 300), the project will directly impact at least 12 instructionalcoaches, 70 administrators, 400 teachers, and 12,000 students.Together with its partners [CUSD 300, Google Inc (Google), Computer-Using Educators, Inc.(CUE), and Oneto-One Institute (OTO)/Project Red], Maine 207 seeks to prepare for a future validation study by (a) usingpilot test data and research findings to refine the Technology Supported Personalized Instruction (TSPI) model(b) testing the model in an expanded context by joining with a school district with greater numbers of highneed students, many of whom are Limited English Proficient (LEP); (c) expanding Maine 207?s capacitythrough additional partnerships; (d) conducting a well-designed, well-implemented experimental study,designed by Center for Research in Educational Policy (CREP) at the University of Memphis, to test impact ofthe initiative on closing the high school achievement gaps in literacy and science."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Manteca Academic Achievement Grant
Project Description: "Manteca?s Accelerating Achievement in Reading through Rigorous and Strategic Intervention (MAARRSI) program proposes to develop an innovative reading intervention and continued support strategy that will accelerate the impact of the evidence-based intervention by developing an exceptional and sustainable model for integrating a district-wide, systemic and rigorous use of data to drive instructional practices in reading for the lowest-performing ELLs and SPEDs in 4th through 12th grade.  MUSD will, by the end of Year 3, serve 6480 students and increase the current rate of reading achievement to 3x that of Whites, making significant gains in closing the achievement gap and raising graduation rates by 3% among these subgroups. This model will produce replicable strategies that are data-driven and accomplish the following measurable annual objectives: 1) Ensure Access to evidence-based, data driven intervention for the very lowest ELLs and SPEDs at every site, hiring sufficient numbers of intervention staff for a 1:8 ratio, and having sufficient quantities of curricula; 2) Accelerate impact of the intervention by ensuring rigorous implementation that includes provision of intensive professional development and coaching for all staff, integration of Data Reflection Teams and high fidelity of the implementation; and  3) Ensure Sustainability of the intervention effects beyond the term of the grant funding by embedding the key replicable intervention support strategies into at least one core Bridge class per site, eliminating skill regression for READ 180 graduates, developing administrative leadership and in-house experts (2 Coaches and 3 Lead Teachers), and by annually communicating successes.  Together, these practices will build a data-driven culture that ensures effective intervention supports for a broader range of students, expanding impact and accelerating academic achievement for those most in need."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Total School Transformation
Project Description: "The Marengo County Schools have consistently ranked in the lowest 5% of schools within the State of Alabama.  In order to change this downward trend, the Board of Education is excited to implement a Total School Transformation plan, that addresses needs for changes in instruction and use of technological assets, but more importantly, addresses the culture within the schools.  Traditional instructional models, i.e. teaching to the bell curve, where some students are statistically expected to fail, are no longer acceptable in our district.  Unwilling to remain at the bottom with persistently low-achieving schools, the Board of Education is embracing comprehensive instructional strategies, informed by data driven research assessment tools, to implement a prescriptive, individualized learning program, constantly monitoring and measuring mastery of standards, and adapting instructional components for successful mastery by each student. Data, technology and instruction modules will be introduced to created individualized learning modules for each student.  The goal of this transformative process is create positive changes for our students, demonstrating that each student has the ability to master and learn concepts, and remediate learning deficits, but most importantly, places our children on a pathway to success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Transforming Juveniles Through Successful Transitions
Project Description: "Transforming Juveniles through Successful Transitions (TJST) is an innovative program placing the approximately 15,000 youth involved in the justice system annually in Maricopa County, AZ, on the path to college and career readiness by bridging their transitions through the educational continuum. TJST will reform and re-invent juvenile external transitions systemic processes by establishing alliances between the Maricopa County Educational Service Agency, the Maricopa County Regional School District #509, the Arizona Department of Juvenile Corrections, the Maricopa County Sherriff?s Office Jail School, and eight (8) District Alternative Education High School Programs to provide access to high-quality instruction aligned to state and national standards to this population of underserved youth. Resources and supports provided through TJST will vastly improve the likelihood of long-term success and reduce the current rate of recidivism for these students by creating and maintaining positive affiliations in the following four (4) areas: Education and Career, Hobbies and Recreation, Home and Family, and Community and Service. These affiliations ensure that youth will productively transition out of the juvenile justice system and into traditional educational settings, preparing them for high school graduation, college, and career opportunities."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Maricopa, County of      DBA -Tolleson Union High School District #214
Project Title: Life Advantage Advancing Academic Potential (LA[3]P) - Equalizing the Race for Underrepresented Students
Project Description: "The TUHSD Life Advantage Advancing Academic Potential (LA?P) project will serve over 106,000 students throughout the state of Arizona during the five-year project period and establish solid program parameters and processes that will facilitate replication during a post-grant scale up period.  This application meets Absolute Priority #3 - Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments, and requests consideration under Competitive Priority # 6 - College Access and Success and #7 - Serving Students with Limited English Proficiency. TUHSD's University High Academy is already achieving significant success in working in a public high school setting with students that are 80% ethnic/racial minority members to support academic outcomes, close achievement gaps and increase college readiness, access and success.  In 2008 and 2009 school test scores on state standardized tests in reading, writing and math exceeded those of all other comprehensive public schools in the county.  In 2010 the school's inaugural class achieved a 100% graduation rate and a 100% college admission rate.Primary components of the model include:  a strong core curriculum of rigor; high expectations of students in a culture of excellence; dynamic peer support, strong parent engagement and support for student success; embedded academic coaching; structured planning for college access starting from Day 1; committed, high quality staff and access to resources. For the i3 Development project phase TUHSD will refine the program, complete a comprehensive quasi-experimental evaluation, secure additional program resources and disseminate information and results through professional presentations, print media and web-based communication that can inform students, professionals and family members throughout the world."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Visions of Success
Project Description: "Marietta City Schools i3 project, Visions of Success,  presents a matrix of seven dynamic factors including: (1) school choice; (2) thematic school-based learning (3) research-based programs; (4) 'charter system' status; (5) gifted learning environments, (6) data informed instructional prescriptions; and (7) one to one learning; that present  a vibrant model of innovation and success.  When blended these strategies may offer the 'missing link' of meaningful reform, exceptional student achievement and parent/community engagement.  The district presents a model of innovation for the success of all student groups that, with the assistance of i3 funding, will add new elements of innovation, formalize products and strategies for replication and secure its future as a vital educational model.	Specifically, the Visions of Success project will overlay three (3) district wide innovative initiatives designed to enrich the district's core components of choice/thematic learning, charter/flexibility/accountability, and program innovation/enrichment/rigor.  Visions of Success is a five year, $5 million project that builds and shares innovation?????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Readiness Education by Accessing Data for Youth (READY)
Project Description: "This Readiness Education by Accessing Data for Youth (READY)   'Development' project will implement a model program in seven high schools targeting 140 teachers and 6,389 at-risk students. This five year development project will refine and apply a model high school program consisting of the following components that show promise of greater impact: 1) Professionally develop teachers' competencies in developing the 21st Century Skills of at-risk students, integrated across all subject areas, 2) Create inquiry and discovery learning environments that transform the 'abstract and distant' into 'concrete and personal', engaging at-risk students with academic content that nurtures, challenges, and inspires, who feel teachers and other students know who they are and care about them. 3) Provide differentiated instruction using computer-based learning that remediates reading and math skills. 4) Develop at-risk students' computer competencies with wireless laptop computers, Email, Internet, and videoconferencing, and 5) Conduct systematic experimental research and evaluation with external experts, to evaluate fidelity of model implementation, and teacher and student outcomes.  The development project will test the following hypotheses (H):  H1 High school teachers can be trained to create inquiry and discovery learning environments that engage at-risk students and increase their achievement. H2 Improved assessment of students' learning, combined with individualized computer-based instruction that is integrated with a supportive learning environment, will enhance learning outcomes for at-risk high school students.  H3 Videoconferencing, enhanced Email and Internet use by students and teachers, and distance learning technologies will bridge the 'digital divide' to improve learning processes and student outcomes.  H4 Inquiry and discovery learning environments will enhance STEM learning outcomes for at-risk students, so they are better prepared for college and/or career."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: INNOVATE
Project Description: "INNOVATE (Innovations Supporting Teachers and Schools) requests an i3 Development grant in order to provide targeted, strategic interventions and service to 14 schools and over 6,500 students throughout the target region. The general goal of the project is to produce long-term and systemic positive effects for high-need students by targeting reading and math achievement. INNOVATE plans to achieve this goal by developing and implementing innovative practices and strategies that support effective teachers and leaders. The specific goals for INNOVATE are to increase the number and percentage of highly effective teachers and leaders and to raise student achievement in reading and math. INNOVATE intends to reach each of these goals by conducting the following activities: (1) providing teachers with on-going job-embedded coaching and instructional modeling to create model classrooms to support standards-based instruction, (2) implementing extended learning time in the schedule for ELA/reading and math, in addition to creating a summer transition program for students struggling in the above areas, and (3) enhancing leadership skills in the areas of instructional strategies, coaching vs. mentoring, coaching vs. evaluating, and diagnostic, formative and summative assessments. In addition, this collaborative model seeks to improve teacher and leader effectiveness through the implementation of a balanced literacy model and best practices, thereby affording students at the elementary and middle school level to make statistically significant literacy/reading and math gains over their baseline achievement data. Partners in the project include Achievement Link Educational Consultants, Marion County Public Library, Empowerment Women Magazine, Johnsonville, SC Lions Club, Tuppwerware Corporation, Institute for Education Innovation and the Florence County Library."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The ELITE Program
Project Description: The proposed project title is The ELITE Program (Enhancing Learning Innovations through Technology-assisted Education.)   The grant type requested is a Development Grant.   The ELITE Program is created to increase the effectiveness of educators to facilitate the successful academic achievement of students both while in school and after they graduate.  The program combines technology as well as education innovations to achieve its objectives.A summation of the ELITE Programs Objectives include; (1) Provide high need students the opportunities normally not afforded them in academics. (2) Prepare and equip all students for college entry and completion. (3) Develop and expand the existing comprehensive professional development program of the district. (4) Perform district wide student assessment and tracking to continuously improve student learning. (5) Provide every tool necessary for the high-need student to perform high.
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Florida IT Academy Program Project
Project Description: "A validation study featuring an interrupted time series design is proposed for the Florida IT Academy Program Project, which will through partnerships, plan, implement and evaluate over a five-year period, a regional information technology program with a progression of information technology courses leading to industry certifications and college credits via articulation agreements for 90 high-need and other students in each of the targeted 38 schools per year. Among the major outcomes are the following: 1) At least 80% of internships undertaken will be successfully completed during the five-year grant cycle, 2) At least 86% of all program participants who take the examination will earn the industry certification of Microsoft Certified Application Specialist, 3) At least 80% of all program participants who take the examination will earn the industry certication of CompTIA A+, 4) At least 75% of all program participants who take the examination will earn the industry certification of Microsoft Certified Desktop Suppport Technician, 5) At least 75% of all program participants who take the examination will earn the industry certification of Microsoft Certfied Information Technology Professional, 6) At least moderately strong correlations between program participation and a) the likelihood of completing a high school diploma, and b) the likelihood of enrolling in an institution of higher education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Blue Ridge Consortium for Technology and Digital Opportunity
Project Description: "Project Description:  The Blue Ridge Technology Consortium seeks to build on existing efforts to prepare our teachers to provide the 21st century learning experiences that are desperately needed in our rural and poor communities, by:o	Expanding the training to reach additional teachers in the area,o	Continuing to upgrade the guidance we provide to teachers in order to keep pace with the rapid changes in mobile technology and digital media, ando	Providing additional guidance to students and families on responsible, safe and ethical use of technology tools and digital media.  Project objectives and expected outcomes:  o	Providing research-based, quality professional development and resources to support effective integration of technology into classroom learning. o	Improving teacher and student access to technological resources in classrooms.o	Developing a region-wide connectivity model for voice, data, and video to enhance instructional and professional development opportunities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Transition to High School: Marygrove College Consortium to Deliver Innovative Science/Technology/Arts Education in Seven Middle Schools
Project Description: "Marygrove College?s Institute for Arts Infused Education (IAIE), in consortium with 7 public schools or academies and arts organizations, proposes establishing arts-infused education units in grades 6-8 wherein students use arts and technology to investigate renewable resources, clean energy, and environmentally responsible living. This program is an extension of one established on a limited basis in 2005. Although the research is anecdotal, results have been very positive. Other similar IAIE programs (grades 3-5) show impressive academic increases documented by two quantitative research studies reporting the program had a ?large treatment effect.? (Greene et al, 2009).The five year arts-infused integration (AIE) project will:? improve academic success for high-need students (direct service);? improve teacher and principal effectiveness (professional development);? decrease dropout rates in high schools (?transition to high school? programs; and? close technology gaps for these high-needs schools (free access to technology)Objectives:? 30 hours of instruction in 42 classrooms annually (total 168 classrooms x 25/classroom x 30 hours=126,000 contact hours over grant term);? 10 hours of teacher professional development annually (10 x 7 schools x 4 years= 280 hours) and unlimited free access to online lesson plans;? free access to computers/technology and training in new media use;? access to college campus programs and ?transition to high school? workshops and individual counseling for grades 6-9 students and parents (2 workshops per school per year and by-appointment individual sessions=14 workshops and # individual sessions).Outcomes:? Students will engage with real-world issues with adults using new media that will prepare them for rigors and issues of their future;? Schools and teachers will receive training in new media and equipment to build capacity, enliven the curriculum, increase effectiveness, and create communities of practice."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Maryland Business Roundtable for Education, Inc.
Project Title: Chart Your Course to College and Career (CYC3)
Project Description: "To significantly increase the number of high-need, low-income students who take and complete rigorous science and math courses that will enable them to qualify for college admission and to successfully participate in college-level coursework, the Maryland Business Roundtable for Education, in partnership with two LEAs and local colleges, will provide a triage of just-in-time services, tools and motivation to support students preceding critical decision points as they move from 8th grade through high school and into college.  Through an innovative combination of personal interactions, experiences and technology, we expect to:  ? increase student expectations to graduate from college, ? provide information and awareness about the connection between college, careers, and academic preparation, ? strengthen the culture and support elements that influence student decisions and actions."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: I-LEARN
Project Description: "I-LEARN will engage students and families as it provides universal access to technology and connectivity. We expect the following: All children will enter school ready to learn. All HS graduates will be prepared for post-secondary options. Students and families will take ownership in learning. Students will learn in new ways. Classrooms will transform to student-centered environments. Teachers will help individual children learn and grow.I-LEARN will provide Personal Learning Devices for all K-12 students and for the families of pre-K children in need. A variety of I-Tools used at age appropriate levels will engage and empower our learning community. Our goals are to prepare all children for school; educate K-12 students in effective, real-world ways; and assist all learners in transitioning from one level to the next. Objectives (Prepare): (1) Engage parents; (2) Ensure all families have access to community services; (3) Provide Pre-K students with learning resources. (Educate): (1) Ensure access to technology and world-wide learning resources for all students; (2) Reform teaching and learning; (3) Restructure curriculum by matching individual needs with available resources.  (Transition): (1) Expand learning options to meet the needs of 21st Century learners; (2) Provide students with learning opportunities that will prepare them for college and the workforce; (3) Prepare teachers to assume the role of mentor/facilitator.A special feature is the inclusion of the families of pre-K children in need. I-Tools will connect them to the array of services available locally and to the on-line pre-school educational community. We also emphasize transition from pre-K on - through meeting individual needs, project-based learning, dual enrollment, tech prep, middle college, and other approaches.By providing universal access to PLDs, wireless connectivity, staff development and parent training, I-LEARN will change teaching and learning in 3 rural counties in West Michigan."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Mass Insight Education and Research Institute Inc.
Project Title: Meeting the Turnaround Challenge
Project Description: "On behalf of a robust partnership of local educational agencies (LEAs) and leading non-profit organizations, Mass Insight Education and Research Institute (?Mass Insight?) is applying for a federal i3 validation grant to turn around persistently low-performing schools.Over a 5-year grant period, we will focus on achieving 3 goals:1) Create ?Partnership Zones? in 10 selected districts, establishing the conditions and capacity necessary to support dramatic, intensive turnaround interventions in chronically low-performing schools;2) Validate the role of ?Lead Partners? as in-district managers of turnaround by incentivizing 9 nonprofit organizations to work in Partnership Zone districts and, subsequently, effect dramatic improvements in student achievement for approximately 65,000 students in participating Partnership Zone schools; and,3) Scale the Lead Partner field nationally through a ?Lead Partner Collaborative? to help turn around more chronically low-performing schools while leveraging an unprecedented availability of public funds.We believe we are the only i3 applicant to offer a validation project for turnaround that:1) is based on a comprehensive conceptual framework for scaling turnaround that helped shape the U.S. Department of Education?s (USED) new 1003(g) School Improvement Grant (SIG) strategy, has been adopted by major districts such as Chicago, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C., and that U.S. Education Secretary Arne Duncan referred to as ?the bible of school turnaround?;2) provides an innovative, in-district approach to turnaround as an alternative to the current turnaround landscape dominated by charter school operators on one side and district school improvement efforts bound by standard bureaucracy and regulation on the other; and3) simultaneously provides a collaborative, national approach to building the Lead Partner field."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Expanded Learning for Results (ELR)
Project Description: "Massachusetts 2020 Foundation Inc., DBA National Center on Time & Learning (NCTL) requests $5 million for Expanded Learning for Results (ELR), an i3 Development grant under Absolute Priority 4: Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools: (b) targeted approaches to reform, and (1) providing more time for students to learn core academic content by expanding or augmenting the school day, week, or year. This five year project will support the transformation of an estimated 25 persistently low-performing schools, in ten states through a school improvement approach that combines increased learning time with focused efforts to: strengthen instructional leadership, improve instruction through data, and build a school culture of excellence. By supporting the replication of the ELR model, NCTL will further demonstrate the most effective strategies for increasing learning time to improve student achievement and disseminate lessons learned broadly to the education field. Through the i3 grant, NCTL will directly improve educational outcomes for approximately 15,000 students, yet will indirectly reach many times this number through our documentation efforts.  This proposal centers on two core activities.  First, we will engage 25 schools in a multi-year TA program, such that after three years of implementation, schools will cut the gap between the proficiency rates of their students and the state average by at least 50%.  Schools will also achieve state and federal proficiency targets and show significant improvements in student engagement compared to pre-ELR scores. Second, we will document and share 'what works' in ELR schools. By the end of the grant, NCTL will have created a range of highly accessible products that articulate how schools can use additional time to boost student achievement and engagement in learning, use data to improve instruction and engage in intensive professional development to improve teacher and school leader effectivenes"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Boston Schools Environmental Initiative
Project Description: "For the past seven years, Boston's Haley, Philbrick, and Young Achievers schools have worked in close partnership with Mass Audubon's Boston Nature Center, using experiential learning to engage students in interdisciplinary studies of the local environment as a strategy to improve student academic achievement. As a result, these schools have seen substantial gain on state test scores for all academic disciplines; demonstrated improved science instruction; engaged students in meaningful problem solving of real life environmental issues; demonstrated notably higher attendance rates among Boston city schools, and are among the most parent requested schools in Boston. The Boston Schools Environmental Initiative works with schools in Boston to foster hands-on/minds-on science and environmental awareness. This program of the Boston Nature Center assigns a full time Teacher Naturalist to work in Boston Public Schools in a whole school change model. The goal of this innovative program is an incremental, systematic development of the school culture leading to improvement in student achievement that takes place through the program's research based theory of change. The Teacher Naturalist models, mentors, and coaches inquiry-based teaching methods for classroom teachers; provides ongoing professional development and facilitated curriculum planning to integrate science instruction through all subjects; and provides resources for schools to conduct curriculum-connected, field-based learning. The four partners would now like to scale up their approach for using experiential environmental education to reach more Boston Public Schools. This proposal focuses on supporting the three model schools to expand their own innovative curriculum, move what they have learned to the broader education community, engage three schools that have demonstrated readiness to a full-scale program expansion, and engage five new schools in a four-and-a-half year program rollout.?"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Closing the GAP: Creating High-Performing Schools (CGAP)
Project Description: "We propose to transform persistently low-performing schools and start new charter schools, creating 30 high-performing schools serving 10,000 students in our neediest communities. Schools will implement the research-based, whole-school model utilized by the highest performing urban charter schools in Massachusetts. At the heart of the model is an unwavering focus on school mission, college for all, and a coherent system of practices, policies, and procedures dedicated to serving that mission. Key too is a school culture of high expectations, support, continuous improvement, and dedication to the rigorous system of MA Education Standards and linked assessments. To create these schools, we will conduct needs assessments, facilitate action planning, and train teachers and leaders via an integrated series of workshops, school study tours, consultation, and partnering. We will document the project and share that documentation widely. To facilitate sustainability, we will review successful school turnaround methods, and we will develop relationships between charter and district schools. Summative and formative evaluation by the project?s outside evaluator will inform and refine our work, hold us accountable, and contribute to the critical work of creating high-performing schools that serve high-need students.The project will be carried out by a lead non-profit, the Massachusetts Charter Public School Association, in partnership with the Massachusetts Charter School Consortium, a group of MA charter schools that close achievement gaps and increase achievement for all students. The Consortium schools will provide much of the training offered through the project, and partnering non-profits will conduct project management, additional training, and evaluation: Building Excellent Schools, Center for Education Policy of UMASS (outside evaluator), Community Partners Inc, Massachusetts Center for Charter Public School Excellence, and Project for School Innovation."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Lexia Reading for Tier II and Tier III Students
Project Description: "The Matanuska-Susitna Borough School District would like to expand usage of a computer-based reading intervention program, called Lexia Reading.  Within our RtI framework, we have begun using Lexia with our ELL population and the data has been promising.  We would like to expand usage to involve our special education, economically disadvantaged, and Tier II/Tier III students district-wide who are in need of targeted intervention in the area of reading.  Lexia Reading pinpoints specific areas of deficits in each individual student which then allows the teacher to provide targeted assistance in that area while the program continues to provide extra practice until mastery is reached.  We are interested in reaching more students who could benefit from this program and this grant would help us to accomplish this."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Integrated College Experience (ICE)
Project Description: "Mater Academy, Inc., a nationally acclaimed charter school organization, is partnering with other charter schoolsacross Florida to develop the Integrated College Experience (ICE) in promoting innovative educational reform.ICE will develop a seamless secondary to post-secondary program aligned to national standards and tested viahigh-quality assessments geared at minimizing the academic gap between secondary and post-secondaryinstitutions. Supporting a national transition to high academic standards and high-quality assessments thatmeasure student progress toward college, ICE directly aligns with the i3 Fund Program?s Absolute Priority 3:Innovations that Complement the Implementation of Standards and High-Quality Assessments.Competitive Priority 6 ? This project supports college access and success as it implements innovative practicesdesigned to 1) enable middle and high school students to successfully prepare for, enter, and graduate from atwo or four-year college; 2) address students? preparedness and expectations related to college; and 3) assiststudents and parents in understanding college affordability, financial aid, and college application processes.Competitive Priority 7 - The project also supports the unique learning needs of students of limited Englishproficient students by incorporating strategies geared at increasing college completion rates, especially for highneed students, and subsequently challenging other observed disparities in our current educational system,while significantly reducing the achievement gap on a national scale.Grant funds will assist to further develop and analyze the model in preparation for a replication initiative thatwould progress first regionally and eventually statewide. This level of analysis would allow Mater to enhancemodel elements that have the highest impact on student achievement through studies that can further validatethe causal correlations between program elements and overall student outcomes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Breaking the Cycle of Failure: Students and Teachers Learning Mathematics Together
Project Description: "A diverse group of 200 high-needs students will learn mathematics alongside 24 of their middle and high school mathematics teachers in a series of groundbreaking intervention courses. These courses are designed to meet a range of learner needs without any labeling of students.  MEC courses have been offered to thousands of K-12 classroom teachers and many university level mathematicians, engineers, and teacher educators throughout the US.  Building on a pilot with high-needs high school students in Kent, WA, the courses will now be expanded, adapted, and implemented in two school districts in efforts to transform mathematics teaching in ways that will prepare students for the needs of the 21st Century and in order to close the learning gap that exists for ethnically diverse and poverty-impacted students in partner school districts.  The Washington STEM Center, our private funding partner, will coordinate the development of a 'Studio Site' where the Mathematics Education Collaborative and IHE Faculty Fellows will work with teachers, students, administrators, and parents, making the work transparent and available for study by other teachers, leaders, policy makers, researchers, and project staff in real time and through video playback.  Additionally, these students and teachers, over 6,000 of their peers, and mathematics and teacher education faculty and pre-service teachers at local colleges and universities will participate together as learners in an innovative web-based school-year follow-up.  All aspects of this proposed work will be carefully documented and resources for taking the work to scale will be developed.  Independent research and evaluation teams will study the work and contribute critical new knowledge to the field.This proposed work will accomplish the following: (1) transform mathematics classrooms and teacher preparation programs across the K-16 continuum; (2) engage over 150 classroom teachers, over 200 high-needs poverty impacted middle and high"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Education Connection
Project Description: "The emphasis on meeting test performance standards causes many teachers to focus more on covering thecurriculum, teaching content and less on teaching process. Some principals are unprepared to identify teacherbehaviors that are most likely to improve the performance of students. The project will change this practice asour teachers are given instructional strategies and tools to provide differentiated interventions that address theneeds of individual students, and principals are trained to encourage and support more effective teachingpractices. Research findings have shown that explicit instruction can play a critical role in helping all studentsuse metacognitive strategies to learn more efficiently and easily. This project will initially train readingspecialists and special education resource teachers to effectively plan and co-teach students who are most atriskof failure. Their roles will be redefined as strategic instruction specialists and they will provideindividualized instruction for students with disabilities and others who need Tier 3 interventions in an inclusiveenvironment. Technology tools that accelerate and individualize learning and increase motivation will beprovided for students. These specialists, with support from our university partner will provide leadership toexpand these practices to all classroom teachers. The district will partner with a high school in the communityin years 2-5 of the project.Expected Outcomes: The percentage of students meeting and exceeding state performance standards willincrease significantly each year for all subgroups; and, the gap in performance of students with disabilities andtheir peers will significantly decrease. The district will work with DePaul University and Governors StateUniversity for program evaluation and training."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Expansion of the I CAN Learn Instructional Improvement System
Project Description: "The Maury County Public School system (MCPS) in Tennessee is seeking an i3 Development grant to concentrate on math proficiency among all student groups.  MCPS will put an extreme emphasis on the math education of our students and teacher training over the next five years in order to improve district-wide performance.  We are currently working with the I CAN Learn IIS, a fully-instructional math program with scientifically proven results, for over a year now and have seen great preliminary results.  MCPS currently uses the I CAN Learn Instructional Improvement System (IIS) in all 8th grade math classrooms.  Because of the positive results we have seen, we want to expand the IIS to include 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th, 9th, and 10th grade math students.  The IIS program is the only program to have received the highest distinction of 'Positive Effects' from the Department of Education's What Works Clearinghouse.  We will use this research and our success thus far to expand this program to scale district-wide.  MCPS will focus on Professional Development for differentiated math instruction for all math teachers from Pre-K-12th grades, improving AYP benchmarks in math with African American students and Students with Disabilities subgroups, increasing student success on the TCAP Achievement CRT in math, improving MCPS' Value Added grade in math for grades 3-8, closing the math achievement gap with underperforming student subgroups, and increasing gains in math achievement for 6th grade students.  The flexibility of the program will allow us to target all of our student populations with just one intervention.  This will allow our teachers to have one focus while working to improve our schools' performance in math.  MCPS will be able to have a centralized database that can be used to track progress and a classroom management system that will provide teachers with a multitude of tools for remediation, monitoring, and the adjusting of student instruction to ensure student progress."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: McCurtain County Education Co-op dba Southeastern Oklahoma Interlocal Cooperative
Project Title: Project SOETS
Project Description: "Our project, Southeast Oklahoma Educational Technology Support (SOETS), is applying for a Five YearDevelopment Grant that will support students, especially those in high need, teachers and principals from ruralschool districts by improving the constancy of their information technology (IT) systems and providingknowledge, skills and integration hands-on professional development in technology so more time can befocused on instruction to improve student achievement and growth. The SOETS project will support the IT ofthe participating school districts by standardizing technology services, develop a help desk to hasten proactivetechnology support, advise on purchasing appropriate technologies and provide support resources to meet thegoals, objectives and expected outcomes of our proposal. The SOETS project will also provide professionaldevelopment using online and face-to-face strategies to grow teachers and principal?s confidence, knowledge,skills and integration of educational technology to meet the objectives and expected outcomes of our proposal.Objectives: 1) expand student achievement and growth through the effective use of educational technology, 2)implement centralized proactive IT services within SOETS to support the technology framework/infrastructurefor each school district, and 3) provide professional development that encourages teachers and principals togain a deep understanding and confidence in the use and integration of educational technology. Expectations:1) significantly increase the number of students passing the Oklahoma PASS and graduating within theSOETS project area, 2) dramatically improve the IT infrastructure and ?up time? and 3) substantially increasethe number of teachers and principals using and integrating educational technology."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: McCurtain County Education Co-op dba Southeastern Oklahoma Interlocal Cooperative
Project Title: Project RAISE
Project Description: "Project Rural Assistance Initiative for Special Education (RAISE) delivers special education services (physical, occupational, and speech therapy) to students in rural Southeast Oklahoma. This project now serves 47 school districts within thirteen counties; however, the need is far more significant in this underserved region. SOIC is applying for a Five Year Development Grant to increase teacher effectiveness, positively impacting student learning. This will be accomplished by providing training to develop teachers? knowledge and skills in the Response to Intervention (RtI) methodology and integrating Assistive Technologies (AT) into the curriculum. RtI is a systematic approach to instruction with two main goals: maximize student achievement and identify students with disabilities. Project RAISE will provide the necessary professionals and resources tosuccessfully intervene on behalf of students with special needs. Objectives: 1) educate teachers in methods of identifying at-risk students, 2) recruit and supply support professionals who will provide intervention services to students, and 3) provide effective intervention tools and resources. Expectations: 1) enhance teacher effectiveness, 2) create manageable classrooms with teachers reaching curriculum goals, and 3) increase reading and math achievement scores of pre-school through third grade students. SOIC?s 35 years of experience working with schools to improve learning outcomes currently impacts more than 3,900 special needs students and provides the foundation to offer Project RAISE services to all 111 school districts in thethirteen Southeastern Oklahoma counties."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Footprints for Success in McDowell County, NC
Project Description: "The use of data in this project will enable us to design individual footprints for success for students and participating schools. The footpritns will include data that addresses academic, social-emotional, psychological, and physical factors. This application will leverage the successful efforts of the National Dropout Prevention Center (NDPC) as a participating partner to utilize a Dropout Early Warning System (DEWS). The system will be based on readily available school and agency data. The participants from the schools and agencies will establish an inter-agency framework for sharing information and data. The increased collaboration and delivery of multi-faceted interventions will improve student performance and reduce incidences of non-responsive school climates. The NDPC will provide technical assistance with implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of research-based interventions for students and cohorts. Quantitative and qualitative data will be analyzed by outside evaluators."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Collaborative Reasoning:  Becoming a Nation of Leaders
Project Description: "McLean County Unit School District No. 5 (LEA applicant) is requesting a Validation Grant under the i3 Grant Program.  Unit 5 will utilize the funding for the substantiation and expansion of the practice called Collaborative Reasoning (CR), which is a peer-led, open format discussion that is intended to stimulate critical reading and thinking and to be personally engaging.  In a program of research conducted under Dr. Richard Anderson at UIUC, the outcome results showed that after participating in eight discussions over a 4-week period, the CR group performed significantly better than the control group on measures of listening and reading comprehension and writing.  Participants, including African American, European American, and Latino/a students, came from rural and urban schools serving low-income neighborhoods, middle-income neighborhoods, and neighborhoods with concentrations of families with limited English proficiency.  CR discussions, in diverse classrooms, revealed a powerful unforeseen force in these student's discussions: student leadership. This CR validation project will also facilitate the evaluation, analysis, and use of student growth data utilizing the Measures of Academic Progress for 250,000 Illinois K-12 students by educators and families through expanded access to the IlliniData portal, a data management system that pulls sensitive data about students from multiple systems and provides teachers and administrators access to data for decision-making regarding instruction and intervention."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: STEM Innovation Grant
Project Description: "McMinnville School District?s STEM Innovation Project proposal, which is submitted as a Development grant, will provide standards-based STEM-intensive education to approximately 5,195+ K-12 students for each year of the five-year project or over 25,975 students in total.  Activities will be hands-on, experiential, industry-based and field-based operations that integrate STEM knowledge and skills in robotics, electronics, civil engineering, environmental engineering and sciences, engineering design, and aerospace sciences applications. Project objectives are to provide intensive content-based professional development that will enable teachers to implement high standard, rigorous and relevant teaching and learning and high-quality assessment that will increase student achievement, foster the development of innovative, collaborative, cooperative, and problem-solving skills, and prepare students for success in postsecondary STEM education and careers that earn a living family wage.  Anticipated project outcomes include: 1) Increase teacher content knowledge, competency, and confidence in teaching STEM2) Increase student achievement in math and science, attaining academic performance targets that are above state/national average3) Narrow achievement gaps in math and science among students subgroups, attaining subgroup academic growth targets that are above state average4) Increase technological literacy by 50%5)  Increase student proficiency on authentic applications of STEM knowledge and skills6) Increase dual high school/college credits earned, graduation rate, and postsecondary enrollment and persistence rates.The project will be implemented in partnership with Evergreen Aviation and Space Museum and Michael King Smith Educational Institute, which will provide matching funds in excess of the 20% requirement."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Birth Through 3rd Grade Project
Project Description: "Project Abstract (Required)McMinnville School District?s Birth through Third Grade Prevention and Early Intervention Project is being submitted as a Development grant to implement innovative practices, strategies, and programs that will improve educational outcomes for high-needs students.  Project objectives are to build a bridge to graduation and postsecondary completion by increasing school readiness, ensuring every child enters kindergarten with skills at or above age five, foster early school success, and increase the percentage of students performing at or above grade level in reading and math by the end of third grade.  The project will provide services to approximately 2,400 students per year/12,000 over the duration of the project.Project components and activities include:?A Child Development Center with mobile capacity to provide curriculum resources, modeling, and coaching to parents of high-needs children, birth to age three?Preschool for high-needs children, ages three to five? Kinder-Plus for high-needs students?Extended day/year and supplemental support for high-needs students in K-3rd gradeThe project will be implemented in partnership with Willamette Valley Medical Center Birthing Center, Virginia Garcia Medical Center, Salem Family Literacy Center, McMinnville Education Foundation, Life Strategies Foundation, and others.  Anticipated project outcomes include: 1) Increase parent knowledge, skills, and competency in promoting early literacy, numeracy, and social, emotional, and cognitive development in their children; 2) Increase school readiness to ensure early school success; 3) Increase student achievement in reading and math, attaining academic performance targets that are above state average; 4) Narrow achievement gaps in reading and math among students subgroups."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
A Butcher, A Baker, A Candlestick Maker
Preparing K-12 Students for the 21st Century Workplace Through Project-Based Learning?????
Project Description: "The primary goal of this project is to ensure that high school seniors graduate with the skills necessary to enter into colleges and universities and/or the workplace with ease.  Because many of the Project-Based Learning, or Senior Project, skills included in this proposal align with those in the Louisiana content standards and Grade Level Expectations and because it not only meets but also exceeds the existing state standards, Senior Projects will increase graduation expectations for all seniors.  Moreover, Senior Projects is a student-driven paradigm that empowers the student to choose a culminating senior project focus that is right for him/her.  Thus, the senior capstone is one that has the potential for success for every single student.  We propose a strategy to embed over the five-year grant period Senior Projects in the curriculum of every high school in Louisiana.  The State Department of Education strongly supports the initiative and is eager to provide support throughout the state.  	The grant leadership team is comprised of three dedicated and experienced teacher/administrators who have worked with thousands of high school students over the combined 70 years of classroom teaching.  We are confident that infusing Senior Projects into every senior classroom in the state will increase retention and raise the Louisiana school system to a level of achievement it has not reached before. "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Ready, Set, Go
Project Description: "In response to the kindergarten readiness needs of all children in East Providence, and the recognition that kindergarten readiness predicts third grade test scores and future academic success, Meeting Street and the East Providence School Department (EPSD) will implement 'Ready, Set, Go,' a universal child development screening program for all East Providence children under the age of five.  Each year, all 2,500 East Providence children under the age of five would be eligible to receive a standardized child development assessment that assesses each child's trajectory toward meeting developmental milestones and kindergarten readiness in the five generally accepted domains of school readiness.  Meeting Street will provide these services in homes, libraries, community centers, medical offices, and child care centers and use bilingual staff as part of this effort.  We will also establish drop in and play groups, language development groups, early literacy activities, parent education programs, and other services for children ages birth to five to promote kindergarten readiness.  Children who screen risk positive will be referred to the appropriate community resources.   'Ready, Set, Go' will also coordinate with screening activities already efforts already underway in pediatric offices, child care programs, and Early Head Start/Head Start to reduce duplication of effort and increase integration and sharing of information.  The project will establish a data system that is flexible and supports aggregation, analysis, and longitudinal tracking for research, evaluation, and quality improvement.  EPSD administrators will be trained to use this data to for program planning, curriculum development, and resource allocation to create 'ready' schools.  Kindergarten teachers will also be trained to use standardized kindergarten readiness tools.  Outcomes to be measured include school readiness at kindergarten and third grade test scores."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Center for Teaching Excellence
Project Description: "Meeting Street and the East Providence School Department have established a partnership to apply for a five year Development Grant to implement and assess the effectiveness of a fully inclusive elementary school at the AM Waddington Elementary School in East Providence, Rhode Island.  East Providence has the highest rate of students receiving special education services in the state, with 26% of students having Individualized Education Programs.  This rate is nearly 50% higher than the Rhode Island average of 18% and almost double the national rate (13.7%) of students receiving special education services.  Far too many of these students are educated in self-contained or segregated settings and their standardized test scores lag behind their peers without disabilities. Building on the success of Meeting Street's long history of providing inclusive education and its success with students with and without disabilities, Meeting Street has partnered with the East Providence School Department to create a model K-5 inclusive elementary school for 450 students.  Starting with kindergarten and adding a grade each year that is inclusive, our goals are to improve student outcomes while increasing the effectiveness of school teachers.  Key strategies include investing in professional development for teachers in co-teaching, differentiated instruction, behavior management, RTI/MTSS, and Responsive Classroom.  Each of these areas of development has been shown to have promise in improving student outcomes.  At the same time, the district will extend the kindergarten program at Waddington to become a full day program to give all students in the inclusive kindergarten classrooms the best opportunities for success.  Ultimately, teachers will be hired, recruited, trained, evaluated, rewarded, and retained based on measurable results educating all children."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
The Memphis SITES-M Project: Building on "Strengthening Instruction in TN
Elementary Schools - Focus on Mathematics"
Project Description: "This project will address the need of improving the mathematics performance of the elementary school studentsin the Northwest Region of Memphis City Schools. The project will diretly serve 200 teachers and over 3,000students. The need assessment for the proposed intervention in this project is based on the available data onmathematics performance of students in the target population. The target schools are in a high poverty regionserving primarily African American children. NAEP data at national and state levels show a dire need forimproving the performance of African American elementary children to close a significant race/ethnicity basedgap. The persistence of this gap continues to affect readiness for middle school which in turn determinesretention and graduation from high school."

Project Title: Menominee in Motion
Project Description: "Menominee in Motion, the title of Menominee Indian School District's (MISD) Investing in Innovation Fund proposal, is a Development grant. The programs and practices in this proposal will address many unmet needs that are unique to the Menominee Indian School District, the only public school in Wisconsin to be located almost entirely on Indian lands. This Title I, rural school district serves 854 students of which 99% are Native American, 84% are on free and reduced lunch, and 24 % have a disability.   The goal of this project is to increase the college prep and career readiness skills of  preK-12 under-represented, high-needs students by using a unique combination of eight programs/initiatives individualized for each of the three schools (elementary, middle and high schools). The project activities will include: 1) aligning the 4K-12 curriculum with the Wisconsin standards and implementing them with high model fidelity, 2) developing and adding advanced dual enrollment classes and an Advanced Placement math class at the High School, 3) developing and expanding the college prep and career readiness curriculum,  4) providing supports to families so they can be more actively engaged in their children's education and 5) increasing district-wide systemic use of data to improve instruction.    The eight programs/initiatives in this project were adapted in terms of the cultural context, to meet the local needs of the rural, Native American student population in the Menominee Indian School District. Over five years they were piloted at MISD, evaluated to determine their efficacy on increasing student achievement and performance, and then adapted, adopted, or eliminated based on the results. The promising programs included in this project include two early learning programs,  three school-community programs, one ninth grade transition program, one instructional framework program and one system-wide approach to using data."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: STEM Connect
Project Description: "nConnect's STEM Connect project will serve over 6,700 participants in Southwest Washington. nConnect is submitting this proposal in partnership with (a) three LEAs representing three high schools  - Fort Vancouver High School in the Vancouver School District, Heritage High School in the Evergreen School District, and Kelso High School in the Kelso School District; and (b) the support of more than 50 individuals from education, labor, industry, philanthropists, other non-profit organizations. The project will create a culture and community of high expectations, build awareness of STEM career paths, expand upon innovative strategies to dramatically improve student achievement in STEM disciplines, and add to the body of research that demonstrates these strategies' effectiveness. Over 6,000 students will be served through this proposal, including 600 low-income youth who will receive intensive services including mentoring, internships, and case management. Over 200 teachers and administrators will build their capacity and skills to effectively and creatively engage students to meet rigorous standards as well as to create a culture within the building that expects and achieves excellence for all students.  More than 250 industry professionals will mentor and coach activities for students and teachers. Finally, nConnect will provide outreach services to an estimated 400 parents and guardians of disadvantaged students who will learn strategies to support their children's education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Innovative Instsruction for Intelligent Reading: The i3 Reader
Project Description: "Meridian Public School District will serve the approximately 1370 students in the three middle schools (grades 6-8).  We propose to increase the number of middle school students reading at or above grade level in three years, as measured by prescribed reading assessments, and the percentage of students scoring proficient or above on the Mississippi Curriculum Test - Second Edition.  This will be achieved by continuing the instructional leadership training implementation of the district principals, assistant principals, and district administrators, by hiring a reading coach for each of the three middle schools who will train, model, and mentor the teachers in differentiated reading instruction, provide basic reading support strategies to volunteer parent 'Reading Buddies', and provide direct instruction to struggling students.  Reading will be emphasized throughout the curriculum.  The goals of the grant are 1) to increase the fluency rate of middle school students to 150 words or more per minute, 2) to increase the number of students scoring proficient or above in the vocabulary content strand as measured by the MCT2, and 3) to increase the number of students scoring proficient or above in the comprehension content strand as measured by the MCT2.  The Phil Hardin Foundation will provide matching funds and will be an integral part of ensuring that the goals of the grant are carried out."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Mentoring New Teachers
Project Description: "In Year 1, 8 induction coaches will be highly trained to be effective coaches in classrooms of teachers new to the district. The induction coaches will receive training in content areas, coaching, and new teacher pedagogy. The elementary induction coaches will be trained in literacy, math, and all content areas. The secondary coaches will be trained in either math or literacy content. In Years 2-5 the induction coaches will be assigned to elementary and secondary schools. Ongoing professional learning will be provided to the induction coaches, building administrators, and new teachers throughout the grant. Student data will be collected, analyzed, and used to monitor and adjust the professional learning. The overall goal of the grant: new teachers will organize and orchestrate a classroom environment for learning and practice principles of standards-based education (clarity of curriculum goals, use of formative and summative assessments based upon curriculum goals and documents - frameworks, continua, essential learnings, and a variety of teacher tools - and design and implement instructional strategies and interventions that engage all students in meaningful learning). After two years of coaching, students in classrooms where coaching has occurred, will out-perform students in classrooms where teachers only received the traditional mentoring support on the Colorado Student Assessment Program. This development grant will target 28,080 students over the five year period."

Project Title: Metro ECSU Gateway to College Math Initiative
Project Description: "It is believed that algebra achievement is the gateway to closing achievement gaps, promoting access to collegeand supporting a highly competitive 21st century STEM workforce. Focusing targeted strategies aimed atturning around Absolute Priority 4 Schools by increasing the number of students successfully completingAlgebra 1 and 2 will significantly increase graduation rates, decrease the racial achievement gap. This effortwill enable more students to graduate from high school within the greater Minneapolis-St. Paul area, collegeready and with 21st century workforce skills. The initiative will focus on actively supporting the developmentof pre-Algebra and Algebra skills in participating middle schools and high schools, provide clear connectionsfor parents and children to college-bound readiness strategies and increase the capacity of participating schoolsto address the unique learning needs of Students with Disabilities and Limited English Proficient Students.The outcome of this program will create a scalable action plan that will not only be sustained in the Metro areabut may be expanded and replicated in other areas with similar high needs."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Customized Student Learning Paths via SMART Partners
Project Description: "Customized Student Learning Paths via SMART PartnersMetropolitan Nashville Public Schools in official partnership with Alignment NashvilleValidation Grant addressing Absolute Priority 2: Innovations that Improve the Use of Data	Metropolitan Nashville-Davidson County Schools (MNPS) in official partnership with Alignment Nashville proposes to validate research findings from education, evidence-based health care decision support, and from its own experience with Small Learning Communities (SLCs) to support a customized learning path for every student. The innovation using data is the creation of a dashboard-facilitated, data- sharing process to integrate information from schools, community and business partners on behalf of each student, creating SMART Partners. This improvement in the use of data will be achieved via six interdependent goals that drive: a) differentiated instruction, b) customized professional development for SLC academy coaches and teachers, c) coordinated interactions of students with community service providers and business partners, and d) full integration of teachers and services for Exceptional and ELL students into the SLCs. A school-data version will be implemented in 12 previously comprehensive MNPS high schools going wall-to-wall as SLCs, and serving an estimated 17,500 students in 2010-2011.  An experimental treatment group of six high schools currently meeting the federal definition for persistently low-performing status will employ bi-directional data sharing via the Data Dashboard-Whole Child, with separate dashboard views for students, teachers, parents/caregivers, community service providers, and business partners. Once validated to improve success predictors and student outcomes, bi-directional data sharing with SMART Partners will inform a customized student learning applicable in any public education context.  "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Prevention/Intervention/Enrichment Project
Project Description: "The Metropolitan School District of Lawrence, in Indianapolis, has a 57% minority, 44% poverty rate and only 52% of 10th grade minority passing the State-required ISTEP tests for graduation.  Four years ago Lawrence replaced the 'old' industrial arts, typing, and traditional biology classes with Project-based classes in Project Lead The Way's Health Services, Bio-Medical, other STEM areas as well as Robotics, Web Design, Interactive Media productions, etc. performance/production assessments.  These Project-approach strategies and PLTW have demonstrated success and promise for academic improvement and holding power for high-needs students from MS to graduation.  Building on this success the PIE Project has 3 foci:1. Prevention-preventing prolonged academic difficulties through early intervention and technology in the district's 2 Early Learning Centers for 6wk olds-pre-school, especially for infants and toddlers of high risk girls, maintaining the girls in school during and after pregnancy;2.  Intervention-such as the 5 Augustus Hawkins Literacy Centers, established by the official partner, the National Council on Educating Black Children, providing reading and life skills (from the Peace Learning Center) supports daily, or Summer AdvantageUSA, College Summit, or Tu Futura for the high Hispanic enrollment--all especially for high risk students;3.  Enrichment-providing ample opportunities for all students, especially the high-needs, to take rigorous Springboard and AP, STEM, PLTW, and Butler Early College courses and have meaningful career internships.  Professional development will be provided by NCEBC with a cultural audit by Bethune Institute.  The goals are to increase the graduation rate and post-secondary enrollment or preparation for a career path profession; to expand recruitment, supports and community involvement for high risk student, and to decrease disproportionality.  These are aligned with demonstrated needs with Performance Outcomes expected to show"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Metropolitan School District of Warren Township
Project Title: The Warren Way: An 8-Step Process for Continuous Improvement
Project Description: "Using a proven 8-Step Process as its framework, an effective high school reform model will be implemented for successful replication in other low-achieving secondary schools to substantially increase achievement, graduation rates and college preparedness. An integrated system based on Deming?s Plan-Do-Check-Act business management model and Effective Schools research form the foundational pieces of the 8-Step Process. Data drives instructional pacing calendars and teaching focus; principals and teacher teams use interim test results in monthly data meetings to monitor progress, identify student needs for remediation or enrichment and adjust instruction; and formal Process Checks monitor outcomes. Fully-employed in K-8, significantly increased achievement compels full implementation of the model at the high school level. Funding will enhance existing frameworks as K-12 instructional calendars and interim assessments are realigned to Common Core Standards, and middle school literacy coaches participate in data meetings and support literacy across non-English course content areas.
