Funds will target support for high-need high school students. Incoming freshmen at high-risk for dropping out will receive individual, group and parental support to address non-academic barriers to success. Learning time will be extended for underachieving and underrepresented HS students through after-school tutoring for students failing interim assessments; double-blocked English 10 and Algebra I classes for students at highest risk based on prior year data; and 10 additional school days for students failing State tests or English and algebra course work, and five more days for students in advanced placement or dual enrollment courses. An external evaluation assesses (a) measurable participant and student outcomes, and (b) the quality and delivery of project activities providing ongoing feedback for project improvement. Formative evaluations examine reasons an intended outcome was achieved."

Applicant: Metropolitan School District of Wayne Township
Project Title: Data-Driven, Accelerated Reading Model
Project Description: The school will implement a framework for systematically using students' reading data to identify and address major barriers to high levels of reading achievement.  A data management system through a mobile platform will organize all students' data for the data team to review. Classroom teachers and interventionists will review the data together and decide what the instructional focus should be for accelerating students' reading progress. Students will participate in goal setting and monitoring their progress.
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Power of U
Project Description: "We have data. We have innovative programs. We still see gaps in achievement in middle school mathematics.We need a system builds on our successes and delivers instructionally relevant and student-specificinformation in a form all teachers can seamlessly apply in their classrooms. It must integrate existing and newdata with the best instructional tools and programs to produce achievement gains that are measurable andsignificant.The Power of U is a Development innovation intended to address Absolute Priority 2: Innovations that Improvethe Use of Data. The Power of U is being piloted during the summer of 2010 in our district and is a strategy tomove classrooms from their traditional structures to highly significant levels of differentiation. It is a system ofteacher tools supported by McGraw-Hill that integrates student progress along a learning progression, and withaligned instruction and assessment. It is intended to enable teachers to meet every student?s needs each day.An algorithmic computer program will incorporate data from daily assessments, resources, and other logisticalrequirements and link student performance to individual pathways along the learning progression. Thisdynamically updating system will help teachers to schedule and deliver instruction to students in the skills theyare ready for and in the educational modalities that are most effective for them. Students will also be involvedin tracking their progress and being active participants in their achievement. This provides teachers, not onlywith useful data, but with ideas about how to take actionable steps in instruction as a result of those data.The goals of the Power of U are to improve teachers? use of data in grades 6 ? 8 Mathematics, assure thatteachers understand and can determine instructional next-steps to differentiated and individualized instruction,and to improve student achievement and engagement in mathematics."

Project Title: College Leadership Academy
American Virtual Learning Cloud
Project Description: "This proposal for a Validation Grant is submitted by Michigan Virtual University in alliance with 7 other State Virtual Schools (Official Partners): Connecticut Distance Learning Consortium, Idaho Digital Learning Academy, New Mexico IDEAL, North Carolina Virtual Public School, Montana Digital Academy, Virtual Virginia, and Wisconsin Virtual School, (hereafter the Alliance). Education Development Corp. (EDC) is an additional Official Partner. This project addresses Absolute Priority 4 and Competitive Preference Priorities 6 and 8. The Alliance will leverage their collective experience and leadership to extend proven capabilities of online learning into new learning environments. The Alliance will provide leadership for the American Virtual Learning Cloud (AVLC), utilizing shared computing to transform online learning into a collaborative network of learning resources not otherwise available to the educational community at this scale. The Alliance will be able to deliver services to 235,735 students and professional development to 6,941 education professionals through the Alliance-LEA network. Project goals include (1) Provide school leaders in low-performing schools sufficient data to make major, rapid changes to improve student performance; (2) Improve low-performing school performance through the delivery of high-quality online and blended instruction; (3) Increase student motivation and engagement through meaningful career information and guidance; and (4) Increase teacher capability and commitment through meaningful professional development. Expected long-term outcomes for low-performing schools include: (1) increased data awareness and use by school leaders and teachers; (2) increased quality of ELA, Science and Math content offered; (3) increased student awareness and attitude towards post-secondary education and/or career possibilities; and (4) improved instruction through increased teacher pedagogical and content knowledge."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Success For All
Project Description: "Led by Mid Central Educational Cooperative (MCEC), Success for All represents a partnership between the multiple LEAs in the DIAL consortium in eastern South Dakota. Through this program these LEAs will work collaboratively to: 1) Create evaluation tools to develop more effective teachers and principals using multiple means of assessing student growth;  2) Provide professional development to create multiple means of assessing student growth using existing tools; 3) With the PAST Foundation, train their teachers and administrators in transdisciplinary, project-based learning (T-PBL) to raise the achievement of and better engage high need students; 4) Create professional learning communities so teachers can become more effective in improving the achievement of high needs students. Teachers and administrators will review current research on evaluation to promote more effective teachers and administrators using multiple measures, then create those evaluation tools. Both groups will receive professional development from MCEC and ESA 3 staff to delve into the DSTEP data on student proficiency using a new growth model to improve the success of high needs students. Finally, DIAL schools, employing the expertise of the PAST Foundation, will create T-PBL communities across the consortium districts. This will enable the professionals to develop meaningful, engaging and relevant transdisciplinary projects and assessments designed to engage high needs students. Over 10,000 students from these rural schools will be impacted. By using previous work in interpreting and using the achievement data of their students, the evaluation work of SD and other educational experts, plus incorporating the T-PBL model, this consortium will capitalize on the assets of the educational professionals in their schools, further develop that corps, and create the conditions in all classrooms that lead to success for all students, but especially, those with high needs."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Synergy Today, Attainment Tomorrow
Project Description: "The Mid-Ohio Educational Service Center (MOESC)?in partnership with North Central Ohio?s Tech PrepConsortium, the University and College Access Network (U-CAN), and a regional group of business andphilanthropic leaders?requests an i3 Development grant for Project STAT (Synergy Today, AttainmentTomorrow). The five-year project is designed to improve academic readiness and postsecondary success amongsocioeconomically disadvantaged rural students in the North Central region of Ohio. It will develop andimplement professional development and curricular support that strongly complement the implementation of highstandards and high-quality assessments (Absolute Priority 3). As its central focus, Project STAT will define anapproach to helping educators improve students? performance against the college and career readiness standardsthat are shaping the future of education.Through Project STAT, approximately 18,900 middle and high school students in 23 school districtsspanning four largely rural counties will benefit from teaching and assessment practices that prepare them for thekinds of problem-solving and innovation challenges they will face in postsecondary programs and skilled jobs.Each team of teachers will incorporate project-based learning, formative assessment, career exploration, and linksto the University College Access Network of North Central Ohio. To ensure the quality of students? learningexperiences, the STAT team will facilitate ongoing professional development with teachers and with building anddistrict leadership teams. All major sectors of postsecondary education and workforce training will provideexpertise and guidance in aligning academic content, instruction, and assessment with the expectations studentswill face after graduation."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Systemic Reform for High Schools in Michigan's Mid-Sized Urban School Districts
Project Description: "An established coalition of mid-sized school districts in Michigan presents this validationproposal to implement the strategies of Effective Schools Research and the Consortium ofChicago Schools Research. This initiative focuses on improving educational outcomesfor persistently low performing high schools. Through data-informed application ofstrategies that address systemic barriers to school success, this comprehensive initiativepromises to validate the seminal research of Effective Schools researchers Ron Edmonds,Wilbur Brookover and Larry Lezotte, as well as Chicago school reform researcherAnthony Bryk and colleagues. The result will be improved academic outcomes andgreater access to highly rigorous instruction and post secondary education for allstudents. Special focus will address the needs of students of color, students from lowincome households and English language learners. Project features include intensive onsitecoaching and professional development support to improve instruction, enhanceschool and central staff leadership, and to produce accountability to break the cycle oflow performance. This five year initiative produces regional impact for the secondaryschools in Michigan's mid-sized school districts. It uses strategies from the researchliterature to build a sustainable intervention for successful change in urban schools.Through a combination of central and district based leadership teams and coaches theproject uses the power of cross-district learning communities to enhance individual andsystem performance. A formative and summative quasi-experimental evaluation designwill produce detailed reports and information for implementation and replicationdecisions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Middle Ga. RESA Collaborative: Coaching for Math and Reading Literacy Success
Project Description: ".Middle Georgia RESA Collaborative: Coaching for Math and Reading Literacy Success requests an i3 Development grant in order to provide targeted, strategic interventions and service to 10 schools and over 7,000 students throughout the Middle Georgia region. The general goal of the project is to produce long-term and systemic positive effects for high-need students by targeting reading and math achievement. Middle Georgia RESA Collaborative plans to achieve this goal by developing and implementing innovative practices and strategies that support effective teachers and leaders. The specific goals for Middle Georgia RESA Collaborative are to increase the number of teachers and leaders who are highly effective, increase student achievement in math and reading, and improve teaching and learning through the use of technology (Blended Learning). Middle Georgia RESA Collaborative intends to reach these goals by conducting the following activities: (1) providing teachers with on-going job-embedded coaching and instructional modeling to create model classrooms to support standards-based instruction; (2) providing teachers with math and reading endorsement; (3) offering professional learning activities that serve to enhance teacher effectiveness through the use of technology-rich learning environments; and (4) enhancing leadership skills in the areas of instructional strategies, coaching vs. mentoring, coaching vs. evaluating, and diagnostic, formative and summative assessments. In addition, this collaborative model seeks to improve teacher and leader effectiveness through the implementation of a balanced literacy model and best practices, thereby affording students at the elementary and middle school level to make statistically significant literacy/reading and math gains over their baseline achievement data. Partners in the project include Achievement Link Educational Consultants and Classworks by Curriculum Advantage, Inc."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: High Expectations Rich Opportunities (HERO): Instructional Improvement System for Managing Student Engagement, Achievement, and College and Career Readiness
Project Description: "The Enlarged City School District of Middletown (ECSDM) requests a Development Grant to design andimplement an innovative instructional improvement system that captures data on student engagement in schooland participation in a wide variety of academic interventions, extracurricular activities, and research-basedprograms. ECDSM will partner with the SAS Institute to augment the unique capabilities of its EducationalValue-Added Assessment System (EVAAS?). ECDSM will partner with TERC to design and implementsustained professional development that promotes collaborative problem solving and action planning andenables administrators and teachers to use HERO to identify the specific engagement and learning needs ofindividual students and take action to meet those needs. ECDSM will support the implementation of HEROwith a rollout of mobile touch-screen devices to enable more efficient collection of comprehensive data onstudent participation and more frequent conversations among teachers, students, and parents aroundengagement, participation, and achievement goals. HERO will capture engagement and participation data for3,538 middle school and high school students in ECSDM.The rationale for incorporating indicators of student engagement into EVAAS is based on robustmultidisciplinary research showing a positive correlation between student engagement and academicachievement. The direct outcomes of HERO are expected to include more accurate projections of studentachievement and more effective implementation of existing initiatives to improve student achievement. Theexpected indirect student outcomes are continued increases in academic achievement on required New YorkState tests, the proportion of students who receive Regents Diplomas, and the proportion of students whoenroll in two-year and four-year colleges."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Raising Student Achievement Through Diffeentiated Instruction, Balanced Literacy, and Small Learning Communities
Project Description: "This Investing in Innovation Validation project is part of a district wide ongoing strategy to redesign and strengthen our capacity to maintain the IDEAL and LEADS models of instruction in our elementary and middle schools and to develop and implement small learning communities in our two high schools in order to improve student achievement, particularly for high need students. Our strategy for redesign began several years ago in our three middle schools with the implementation of the LEADS model of instruction. LEADS, Literacy is Essential to Adolescent Development and Success, is a balanced literacy program for grades 3-8 that enables classroom teachers to differentiate instruction through the use of leveled texts. LEADS is focused on supporting reading and writing while connecting these skills to the content areas through a strong focus on expository reading and writing. IDEAL, Initiative for the Development of Early Advancement in Literacy, is a similar literacy program for students in grades K-2. At the high school level, along with adapting and instituting the LEADS model with high school teachers and students, we will be establishing a series of grade level and career-themed small learning communities in order to promote personalization and greater student achievement. Incoming students will be heterogeneously placed into one of four houses as part of a Freshmen Academy. The Freshmen Academy house teachers, along with teacher advisors and counselors, will be able to identify struggling students and recommend the appropriate interventions. In addition to the Freshmen Academy, we will create six career academies that students can choose to enter based on their interests. Our district follows a K-16 philosophy for our 10,400 students, knowing that preparation for college begins when students first enter kindergarten."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Early College Program
Project Description: "Millard Public Schools will implement an Early College (EC) program at the district's lowest performing highschool. The program will target subgroups typically underrepresented in post-secondary institutions, includingstudents who are disabled, economically disadvantaged, have limited English proficiency, and belong toethnic/racial minority groups. Other students also will be served. Three hundred fifty juniors and seniors willsimultaneously earn high school and college credit, gain experience in and an understanding of the academicrigor and effort at the college level. They will simultaneously earn a high school diploma and an Associate'sdegree or up to two-years college credit at no personal cost by high school graduation, thus reducing the timeand expense usually required to complete post-secondary education. Support services such as mentoring, socialservices, and seminars for students and their parents on financial assistance, scholarship applications, andcollege admission also will be provided to them at no personal cost."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: MINDi3 National Math Initiative: The Expansion of an Innovative Approach to Teaching and Learning Mathematics
Project Description: "The MIND i3 National Math Initiative project is a validation proposal that will accelerate the use of MIND?sinnovative, neuroscience-based, visual approach to teaching and learning math. MINDi3 addresses AbsolutePriority 4: Turning around Low-Performing Schools. While MIND?s approach is effective for all students, ithas proven especially effective for students who have low English language proficiency, learning disabilities,or are classified as special education. Among high-need students, the MIND program has raised mathproficiency on standardized tests by double-digit percentages. MINDi3 will serve schools in ProgramImprovement or corrective action where math success for all student subgroups will lead to the turnaround oflow-performing schools. MINDi3 will be deployed in 800 schools in 13 geographically diverse LEAsrepresenting 8 states, including California, Florida, Illinois, Kentucky, Nevada, New York, Texas andWashington, D.C. It will reach 600,000 students and 14,000 teachers. At MINDi3?s core is ST Math??aweb-based instructional software that works for both teachers and students and is designed to be implementedin conjunction with classroom instruction as a supplement to the school?s standard math curriculum. Thesoftware makes use of gaming technology, stepping students through increasingly difficult problem-solvingpuzzles. Initially, the software presents the math concept visually and then introduces symbols and languagerepresentations. MINDi3 includes professional development and real-time reporting on student learningpatterns and mastery to inform instruction. Evaluated by the Educational Policy Institute, the i3 grant will beused to validate that MIND?s approach delivers consistent, replicable results at a far-reaching and importantscale across the U.S., including accelerated rates of removal from Program Improvement or corrective action."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Montana Project: Transforming Teaching to Transform Learning (T3L)
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project TALK - Teaching Academic Language to Kids
Project Description: "Project TALK Teaching Academic Language to KidsThe purpose of the project is to implement high standards and high quality assessments for English language learners in four rural Missouri districts. The project constitutes a model implementation of the World Class Instructional Design and Assessment - WIDA PreK-12 ELP Standards, its aligned assessments, and a new professional development program, Content and Language Integration as a Means of Bridging Success (CLIMBS) to integrate WIDA ELP standards and state content standards. The overall goal of the project is to determine if teachers' participation in the CLIMBS course results in value added effects on students' English language proficiency  The course is a professional development program designed to teach professional learning communities (PLCs) ways to integrate the WIDA PreK-12 English Language Proficiency Standards and state content standards. The integration of standards is supported by research-based instructional practices to scaffold ELLs access to the mainstream content curriculum. The treatment consists of five face-to-face sessions, team collaboration via an online forum, and practice activities to complete between sessions. After completing the course, teachers will continue planning activities with their PLCs and will receive two coaching sessions a year for two years. The CLIMBS course uses the train-the-trainer model. CLIMBS facilitators are trained in pairs during a multi-day training led by WIDA.  The exceptional approach is to test the efficacy of the newly developed CLIMBS course replicating an evaluation model reported by Biancarosa, Bryk, and Dexter (2008), an accelerated longitudinal cohort design with a value-added analysis of program effects."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Developing the Collective Capacity of Rural Schools to Improve Student Learning
Project Description: "Previous efforts to improve student achievement have focused primarily on building individual schoolcapacity and not the collective capacity of several schools or school districts. Reform efforts, wheresuccessful, often are not sustained when a key leader?a superintendent, principal, or team of teachers?is notlonger involved. Equally important, there is much to learn and share across schools and school districts. Weare proposing a four-year development project to increase the collective capacity of high-poverty rural schools.Participants include superintendents of all 34 rural school districts in a high-poverty, seven-county region inMissouri; the principals of 37 schools within those districts; and all teachers in those schools serving acombined K-5 enrollment of 9,025 students. Joining these teachers, principals, and superintendents as partnersin this project are the Missouri State University and its West Plains campus, specifically a rural educationcenter at West Plains, and the Springfield Public Schools, an urban school district with advance technologyand skills for the collection, analysis, and use of assessment data for learning. To improve teacher andprincipal effectiveness in rural schools serving high-need students?priorities that are the focus for thisproject?we will develop, implement, evaluate, and refine the following integrated components for impactingcollective capacity across the 34 rural school districts, particularly with regard to the literacy development ofstudents: a field-based master's degree program tailored for teachers in rural schools; an academy for schoolprincipals to serve as an ongoing professional learning community; an online student assessment system anddata warehouse for student demographic and achievement information; on-site literacy coaches andconsultants; and an interactive website for sharing best practices and networking with teachers andadministrators across the 34 rural school districts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The MLA Partner School Model
Innovating Schools Through The New Directions Academy
Project Description: "Innovating Schools through the New Directions Academy. The Mobile Area Education Foundation, the Mobile County Public School System (MCPSS), and Diploma Plus (DP) propose to transform the Continuous Learning Center (CLC), an alternative school for special education students. By expanding and implementing an innovative, targeted reform strategy called the New Directions Academy (NDA) to serve the needs of overaged, undercredited students by providing day or evening courses, accelerated credits based upon student competency, and college/career opportunities. CLC will expand to three programs: (1) the current CLC program serving special education students with severe behavioral problems who are placed in this environment for at least 45 days; (2) the NDA-day program; and (3) NDA-night program, which will both serve overaged, undercredited regular and special education high school students who are 16 years or older and have at least 10 credits from across the MCPSS. Students in both the NDA-night program and NDA- day programs will use a performance focused curriculum based upon Pearson's NovaNET computer-based curriculum and the Diploma Plus model. The DP model begins with identifying what students need to know for a course and uses a backward planning process to develop curriculum maps, authentic assessments and lesson plans that will enable students to meet the prioritized standards by demonstrating their knowledge of the content. Instructional components will be supported by advocate counselors who will meet the social/emotional needs of the students, and post-secondary/ internship coordinators will provide post-secondary planning and subsidized job-based internships.  Innovatively, the MCPSS Average Daily Attendance funds earned from student enrollment the year before will fund a yearly expansion. Over 4 years, the NDA enrollment will increase from 100 to 350 students, CLC's graduation rate will increase from 0% to 60%, and the school will move to 'Clear' on its AYP"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Project AP
Project Description: "Research has found that students who are exposed to rigorous courses in grades 7-12 have the strongestcorrelation to bachelor's degree completion. With Project AP the Mobile County Public School System(MCPSS) will implement a program designed to increase participation and success for students in AdvancedPlacement (AP) courses while providing equitable access for all students. MCPSS will implement a standardsbased,vertically articulated curriculum aligned to state and national standards. District leadership, teachers andcounselors will be equipped with instructional strategies to prepare students for college matriculation and willparticipate in year-long professional development. MCPSS proposes to increase college readiness for allstudents while providing academic support to ensure success for high-need students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Literacy Leadership Academy
Project Description: "Establish a regional 'Literacy Leadership Center' to develop the fidelity skills of district leaders to yield maximum effect of research-based English Language Arts practices to increase student achievement.  Training academies targeted at building leaders, literacy coaches and curriculum leaders will provide instruction in development of research-based competencies through:  monthly trainings, on-line professional development, bi-weekly mentoring and creation of a systems growth portfolio documenting program protocols and procedures.  A web-based clearinghouse will be established for national publication of practices providing models for replication.  Partnerships with Apple and a Higher Education Task Force have been established: Apple will provide in-kind matching funds to support the use of ipad's for ELA program evaluations, observations and data analysis, IHE Task Force will provide final portfolio evaluation and embed clearinghouse evidence into in-service curriculum."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Differentiated Instruction Professional Learning Community
Project Description: "Monroe #1 BOCES is seeking an i3 Development Grant in order to establish a Differentiated InstructionProfessional Learning Community.  Research shows that differentiated instruction is effective in improving student achievement, yet remains widely underused. Research conducted within our local area further supports the notion that while teachers recognize the value of differentiated instruction, they do not use it in a consistent manner. Therefore, in an effort to improve student achievement and graduation rates, particularly in an area where 9 of the 57 persistently low-performing schools in New York State reside, this organization would like to expand current professional development offered while honing in specifically on differentiated instruction. The project entails establishing a professional learning community (PLC) focused solely on differentiated instruction. Teachers, coaches, and administrators from local schools and districts wild be encouraged to participate in the PLC. Participants will receive training on how to foster a differentiated classroom and school, will develop plans to take the information back to their schools and districts to include in professional development and school improvement plans, and will receive ongoing support from Instructional Specialists as they move toward a fully differentiated educational environment. The PLC will provide participants with the tools and knowledge to turnkey train colleagues at their own schools, with ongoing support via PLC meetings and online forums. The PLC will expand in each of the five years of  grant period, to ultimately reach teachers, coaches, and administrators across New York State."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: STEM For Girls
Project Description: "The purpose of the Getting Girls Ready - Academy for Careers in STEM (Girls STEM Academy) project is tobring together organizations and educators that are committed to informing and encouraging girls to pursuecareers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).      Monroe #1 BOCES is seeking an  Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Development Grant to address the needfor providing a platform to increase the number of under-represented student populations (girls) in academicallyrigorous courses and programs (STEM) with a design-based contextual learning opportunity.     It is Monroe #1 BOCES hypothesis that by providing girls with early awareness to STEM career opportunitieswe will support a pathway to monitor and  measure students progress for transitioning into and graduation of college programs coordinated through high academic content and achievement standards with alignment inschool based academies and career mentorship opportunities."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Rural Science for Life Lab
Project Description: "Monroe County School District located in rural southwest Alabama proposes to implement the Rural Science For Life Lab through PACERS, INC. The intent of this Development Grant would be to provide real life experiences to make science and math relevant in order to improve student achievement and growth. There are four hundred twenty African American K-12 students from three Title1 school wide programs at Beatrice Elementary, J.F. Shields and Monroe Intermediate will participate in greenhouse and gardening, aquaculture, and alternative energy projects and activities. Students will also be provided project based learning activities and will be able to participate in credit recovery programs through computer based learning. STI Achievement Services will work collaboratively with science and math teachers and self contained classroom teachers on developing pacing guides and curriculum alignment of the Rural Science for Life Lab content with courses of study. STI Services will also provide assistance to teachers on creating and implementing innovative lessons and units, assessing students? science and math deficiencies, modeling, coaching and providing job embedded professional development, using data to drive instruction and infusing technology into hands on, real life project based learning in a rural setting. [Competitive Priority 8] PACERS Inc., the sponsor of the Rural Science for Life Lab, will provide the required 20% match consisting of an active and involved cadre of volunteers consisting of parents, community members and expert consultants who will assist with the implementation and sustainability of grant project activities. Monroe County School District proposes, as a result of the above activities, strategies, programs, support and involvement, to improve achievement in Persistently Low-Performing Schools in the area of science and math by 10% by the end of a (5) year period. [Absolute Priority 4]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Montana Learning Center at Canyon Ferry Lake
Project Title: Science Inquiry Learning through Technology
Project Description: "SILT provides onsite/online professional development supported by instructional coaching in science inquiry,physical and earth science content and Native American culture to increase elementary/middle school studentachievement using technology as an implementation tool. Aligned with Montana?s standards and assessments,SILT will:Improve student achievement and college- and career-readiness in science and technology for high needs studentsthrough a technology-infused, inquiry-based program using an innovative, blended onsite and onlineinstruction coaching model and high-quality professional developmentThe SILT partnership will:? Establish a professional learning community.? Implement data-driven update of the SILC professional development model.? Improve teacher instructional pedagogy and inquiry-based science content knowledge in earth and physicalscience.? Disseminate project results through teacher presentations and staff articles for peer-reviewed journals.? Integrate technology tools to create 21st-century learning environments, increase student achievement andprepare students for the 21st-century workforce.The target number of students to be served is 1800 ? 2000 elementary and middle school students across amaximum of 100 classrooms per year in partner districts, scalable to the rest of the state with increasedfunding. The SILT professional development partnership consists of: * The Montana Learning Center atCanyon Ferry Lake; * The MSU - Bozeman Science/Math Resource Center, Departments of Education, NativeAmerican Studies, Physics, Earth Sciences and Chemistry; * Bozeman, Helena, Hardin and Havre PublicSchools; * Other partners are affiliated rural and private schools and districts in Montana?s RegionalEducational Service Areas (RESA) II, III and IV."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Montana Tech of the University of Montana
Project Title: Project Access
Project Description: "Project Access addresses Absolute Priority 2 and Competitive Priority 6. It is based on the hypothesis, supported by limited research, that rigorous and relevant mathematics and science preparation, together with individualized support for high-need students, will result in dramatic improvements in student outcomes and school performance. The project will create a STEM Academy at four Montana high schools with a large number of high-needs students. Project Activities include: increased individual support for high-need students and their parents, improved use of data by STEM teachers to adapt instructional practice, expanded professional development for STEM teachers to integrate technology-infused instructional tools, expanded use of STEM professionals in the classroom, a STEM Summer Institute residential intensive integrating professionals and hands-on learning experiences to expose students to STEM careers, expanded access to college scholarship assistance, expanded opportunities for students to take dual credit courses.Project Access is designed to improve high school student outcomes, including standardized test scores, course taking rigor, graduation rate, college enrollment, and college degree attainment. It will also improve teacher instructional practices. The project goals are: improve data utilization to identify student ability and ensure progress, increase the number of high school students pursuing rigorous STEM studies, improve science and math performance of middle and high school students, increase college readiness and access for STEM students, and refine innovation by assessing successful practices and disseminate findings.Project Access will serve approximately 5,000 high-need Montana students annually. Private sector funding is secured through STEM businesses to provide scholarhsip dollars and in-kind match to the project. Official partners include Montana Tech, MT's CHE office, 3 LEA's, and an external evaluator."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Cyber-Demonstration School
Project Description: "The Cyber-Demonstration School is a project that will build on past successes by Montclair State University in delivery of professional development in STEM subjects and improving achievement among students of treatment groups of teachers, as determined by external evaluators. The project will offer members of the CUSP consortium professional development designed by the best providers in the eastern USA, offered in several convenient venues to foster the modeling of hands-on, constructivist approaches, followed up in classrooms with in-person coaching and networked videoconference and online support systems. Project activities will include 5-day summer institutes, instruction in formative assessment, MAP testing to track student progress in algebra, on-going professional development in content and pedagogical content knowledge, in-class coaching, webcam mentoring by STEM professionals, and web-cam connections in real-time to scientists at remote research stations, as well as classrooms in action.The main objective of the project is to improve teacher effectiveness and student achievement in algebra, biology, and environmental science (grades 7-10) using the already proven professional development approaches of MSU?s Math-Science Partnership projects. The strategies and approaches of the MSP programs of PD will now be adapted, amplified, enhanced, and delivered in new ways through online instruction and the use of instructional technology. The adaptations will include greater STEM faculty involvement with schools and classrooms, and creative use of online teaching tailored to teacher and student needs. Project assessment and evaluation will pull data from statewide assessments as well as formative assessments. The why and how of project successes will be tracked through the use of the Learning Climate Questionnaire with teachers and students to detect changes in responses to educational programs before and after the project treatment."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: North Star
Project Description: "Project North Star will be the next generation of elementary instruction. In a quest to raise expectations for students of all colors, broaden instruction to include science, social studies, and the arts while exceeding AYP, and to save teachers and students valuable instructional time, Montgomery County Public Schools (MCPS) and Pearson, LLC are partnering on a one-of-a-kind, research-based project.  MCPS is requesting $4,999,633 in i3 funds to develop a curriculum and online professional learning community designed to nurture the skills and mindset that will guide children towards the north star of college readiness. The project includes development of a unique college-ready elementary curriculum aligned to the Common Core Standards. Integration of content and processes is key to the innovative and time-saving design of this curriculum. Critical and creative thinking skills, and academic success skills form the nucleus around which reading, writing, mathematics, science, social studies, and the arts are carefully planned by marking period. The power of making connections among contents will help unleash the natural curiosity of young children and the habits that mark the academic mind - persistence, questioning, and collaboration - will be developed beginning in Kindergarten. In addition to $1,000,000 in matching funds, Pearson will bring its considerable assets and expertise to help develop the first generation of post-NCLB assessments that measure achievement of challenging academic standards alongside the skills that develop advanced learners. The final key design feature of this project will be curriculum-aligned, just-in-time professional development offered in a collaborative Web 2.0 environment.  Teachers will be able to harness the power of instructional experts and their peers to solve complex and commonplace teaching challenges. When fully scaled-up this project will reach over 450,000 students and will be standardized for use across the nation."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Revolutionizing Education Through Digital Conversion
Project Description: "The Mooresville Graded School District (MGSD) is applying for an i3 Developmental Project Grant in order to bring to scale a Digital Conversion project that is revealing significant increases in academic achievement for all students in its district. This Digital Conversion project is an innovation that complements the implementation of high standards and high quality assessments, which is Absolute Priority 3. Since beginning this conversion, indicators suggest academic performance for all students is increasing along with school attendance and graduation rates, while dropouts, discipline and suspension rates are declining. In addition, we assert that our Digital Conversion includes innovative practices and strategies that effectively prepare K-12 students for successfully entering college with 21st century skills.  	Mooresville Graded School District realizes numerous factors that must be addressed for public schools today:1)	Content and methodology within public schools are no longer current and relevant for 21st century learners; these content and methods do not capture the interest nor motivate and engage students;2)	In today's society schools are more diverse in terms of culture and economic background of students and families they serve;3)	There is an economic divide in our country; moreover, there is a digital divide regarding access to technology and digital content (i.e. inequitable access to information in a digital age); and4)	Overall student achievement in public schools needs to be improved, particularly for high-need students, as well as achievement gaps closed between majority students and subgroups of students (e.g. students with disabilities, limited English proficient students, minorities, etc).Through its comprehensive Digital Conversion, MGSD is addressing the above needs and embracing its philosophy of every child, every day, thereby revolutionizing education in a way that allows all children to move successfully into the future."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: College Preparatory Academy
Project Description: "The Program is entitled the College Preparatory Academy. The Program will serve 250 students in  9th-12th grade to include innovative techniques employing instructions, tutoring, counseling, extra-curricular activities, and a series of' workshops and symposiums for students and parents that will be woven throughout the life of the grant.  Students will participate in after school and online tutoring, one-on-one supplemental instruction in reading, math and science, hands-on lab experiences and global learning in specific countries identified in the Program Narrative.  Special aspects of the project are the Parent University that will include seminars, workshops and home visits to increase parental involvement and assist them in building a support system for their child and hands on research opportunities with college research coordinators.The overall objectives of this project are to improve (1) academic achievement rates; (2) standardized test scores; (3) retention rates; (4) graduation rates; (5) college going rates; and (6) college completion rates. It is expected that at the end of the grant period, the overall achievement gap of the student participants will be significantly decreased."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovations in Math and Science
Project Description: "The Program is entitled the Innovations in Math & Science. The program will serve 250 students in 9th-12th grade to include innovative techniques employing instructions, tutoring, counseling, Saturday academic clinics, extra-curricular activities, directed research in science, math, technology and engineering (STEM) and a series of' workshops and symposiums for students and parents that will be woven throughout the life of the grant.  Students will participate in after school and online tutoring, one-on-one supplemental instruction in reading, math and science, hands-on lab experiences and field research and global learning in specific countries identified in the Program Narrative.  Special aspects of the project are the Parent University that will include seminars, workshops and home visits to increase parental involvement and assist them in building a support system for their child and hands on research opportunities with college research coordinators.The overall objectives of this project are to improve (1) academic achievement rates; (2) standardized test scores; (3) retention rates; (4) graduation rates; (5) college going rates; and (6) college completion rates. It is expected that at the end of the grant period the overall achievement gap of the student participants will be significantly decreased."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Rejuvinating the Spirit of Learning
Project Description: "Rejuvenating the Spirit of Learning will serve 710 students in grades Pre-K- 12th grade to include innovative techniques employing instructions, tutoring, counseling, extra-curricular activities, directed research in science, math, technology and engineering (STEM), and a series of' workshops and symposiums for students and parents that will be woven throughout the life of the grant.  Students will participate in after school and online tutoring, one-on-one supplemental instruction in reading, math and science, hands-on lab experiences and field research and global learning in specific countries identified in the Program Narrative.  Special aspects of the project are the Parent University that will include seminars, workshops and home visits to increase parental involvement and assist them in building a support system for their child and hands on research opportunities with college research coordinators.The overall objectives of this project are to improve (l) power promoting ratio (2) academic achievement rates;(3) standardized test scores; (4) retention rate; (5) college going rate; (6) college completion rate and (7) the number of students that take the SAT."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Morgan County Georgia Expanded Learning Time Project
Project Description: "Based primarily on the research of the National Center on Time and Learning and the recommendations of the U.S. Department of Education in the final Race to the Top guidelines issued in November 2009, the project seeks expand instructional time for at-risk students to a minimum of 300 hours per year to more fully integrate expanded learning time and implement a balanced approach that provides more time for core academics, for enrichment subjects, and for teachers to collaborate."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The High School Media Academic and Career Development Program
Project Description: "The application is for a development grant that will target 500 students in ten high schools. The focus of theprogram is to improve the performance of underrepresented groups in rigorous, intense academic programs whilein high school and to prepare them to be successful once admitted to college. An additional 3,000 students willbe reached in the program?s efforts to include all students and their families during sessions on collegeadmissions and financial aid processes. The specific objectives of the High School Media Academic and CareerDevelopment Program are to (1) to increase college- and- career readiness; (2) to increase high school graduationrates; (3) to improve students? knowledge of college admission and financial aid processes; (4) to providecontinuous personalized tutoring and mentoring; (5) and to utilize the Media Sales Institute as the major pipelinefor students choosing careers in media sales. These objectives will be effectuated using award-winning onlineinstructional programs and curricula; academically rigorous after school, weekend, and summer enrichmentprograms; intense parental involvement, peer mentorship, and a novel career-focused Media Sales Institute toenhance students? academic skills for college and career readiness. The expected outcomes are for participants to(1) experience higher state mandated High Schools Assessment scores and Scholastic Aptitude Test scores thannonparticipating students at their respective schools; (2) to test high enough on the Accuplacer college entranceexams to be exempt from taking remedial classes once admitted to college; (3) to have 100% of students applyand be admitted to a four-year college; (4) to provide students and their parents with information about thefinancial aid application; (5) and to provide students media internships. The program will partner with tenBaltimore Metropolitan high schools, the state of Maryland and Personal Selling Principles (Media SalesInstitute)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Improving Academic Outcomes for Children of Incarcerated Parents
Project Description: "We serve children of incarcerated parents (CIP?s) in Flint, MI. We will use program evaluation and achievement data for these high-risk students (preschool-8th grade) to strengthen family-school connections and improve student achievement. We will build our capacity by hiring and training staff, and developing a model to partner with additional partners in the community. We will disseminate this model for others who work with this population to enhance their academic achievement. Motherly Intercession (MIC) has served CIP?s for 11 years and partners with two local schools (Northridge and International Academies). Goals are to: 1) evaluate MIC program effects on CIP?s pre-academic skills and achievement; and 2) refine our school partnership model to enhance CIP?s academic outcomes. MIC programs include: school readiness (preschool); tutoring (school-age); family support; social-skill building; arts/culture education; and developmentally-tailored civics/legal education (designed for CIP?s).Summary: Objectives, Expected Outcomes: Outcomes are math/numeracy, reading/literacy, social competence, and classroom adjustment, to be assessed quarterly via multiple methods and measures. We use an interrupted time-series wait-list control group design, expecting children in MIC programs to make gains in all areas over time. Partnership goals are to establish effective family-school communication and use data (school records, individual assessments) to monitor and enhance student progress. Process evaluation will refine our model for dissemination.Number of Students to be served: 150 (preschool through 8th grade)Special Features: Focus on children of incarcerated parents; building on strong community experience serving this group; developing school partnership model for dissemination.Partners: Motherly Intercession, Inc. (Lead); International and Northridge Academies (School Partners); University of Michigan School of Public Health (Evaluator); Genesee County Jail."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Accessing College and Careers through Education and Support Services, Project ACCESS
Project Description: "The purpose of the Mount Vernon City School District's (MVCSD) Project ACCESS program is to increase high school graduation rates and the number of students who complete a postsecondary credential or degree, especially among groups of students in its very high need Mount Vernon High School (MVHS) whose students traditionally attend college at disproportionally lower rates than the rest of the state.	     We will test the impact in a five year longitudinal study and Big Brother, Big Sister interventions using the 'gold standard' of research design that ensures randomization, experimental/control groups and pre and post testing.	If America is to remain competitive in tomorrow's global workforce, our students must first be able to successfully complete the first year of college without the need for remedial or development al education.  To this end we will complete the following strategic tasks.  Develop and implement district-wide standards and expectations for college readiness in collaboration with college partners and district staff in the recruitment, preparation and retention of teachers and administrators to improve teacher quality; provide one-on-one or small group consultation to help students and their families navigate the process of college admissions and financial aid and maximize their chances of obtaining admission to schools of top choice and create and support a student centered active learning environment by providing the data, support and training and essential classroom technology necessary for an engaged inclusion learning environment."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Metropolitan School District of Washington Township
Ben Davis E-Learning Academy: A Pathway to the High School Diploma
Project Description: "Students need multiple pathways to a high school diploma.  Research indicates that 'on average, students in online learning conditions performed better than those receiving face-to-face instruction' (Means et al, 2009, p. ix). In an era of economic challenges, it is critical that instructional programs be of high quality as well as fiscally responsible. The Ben Davis eLearning Academy will be a blended school program that is self-sustaining and captures the best of virtual learning for students.  This school will provide students the courses, support, and learning opportunities for a high school diploma in a 21st century environment.  It will also provide the students and families of MSD of Wayne Township another choice or pathway to a high school diploma."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: STEM Games - Multisensory Interactive Learning Games for Science Using Math
Project Description: "Project Description: Design, develop and deploy a series of multisensory interactive games for the web that engage middle school students in scientific and mathematical inquiries. These personalized multisensory explorations of scientific concepts and processes help develop skills in foundational math and science. Students who demonstrate mastery of STEM concepts will gain access to tools that shape the characters and action in the games. Innovative real time assessment techniques will provide students, parents and teachers a 360 degree view of student thinking and collaborative abilities. Students who play STEM Games will develop competence in math and science and also acquire training in programming. Children in middle school have unique learning styles and math-science instruction is addressed to language learners. Games overcome motivational resistance to math study and engage girls and minorities on an equal footing with Caucasian males. This material will afford ways for non-language learners (tactile, auditory and other) to explore mathematical and scientific concepts. Our goal is to provide multiple sensory and cognitive pathways to mastery. We will also create role models with whom diverse children can identify. We intend to deliver an integrated math and science curriculum, presented in an alternative, self-paced fashion which will be data driven based on the students' strengths and weaknesses.  We also hope to deliver deeper, more accurate assessments of subject understanding, and more durable access to knowledge acquired by the students.."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Reconnecting Youth Centers
Project Description: "1.  Project Title:  Reconnecting Youth Centers2.  Type: Demonstration Grant 3.  Project Activities: The Reconnecting Youth Center initiative will build a coordinated and collaborative system of Reconnection Centers that provide immediate educational reengagement for out-of-school youth.  The centers will use consistent assessment, testing and placement protocols that facilitate the evaluation, analysis, and use of student achievement or student growth data.  This data-driven decision-making, at the student level, by educators, families, and other stakeholders will inform decision-making and improve student achievement and student growth.  The RYC eliminates traditional, school district boundary-based barriers which prevent out-of-school youth from re-engaging with education.  This new partnership will open new options for our youth through placement in 'best-fit' programs anywhere in the county.  4. Summary of Objectives and Expected Outcomes: By attending post secondary school or job training or securing sustainable employment, out-of-school youth will become productive citizens contributing to their community.5. Targeted number of Students Per Year:  500 annually 6. Special project features:  Placement without borders; individual assessments, student reconnection plans and long-term follow up will increase retention and completion.  7. Partners:  Six Multnomah County School Districts; Office of the Mayor - Portland, Oregon; Multnomah County Human Services; Multnomah County Juvenile Justice; Portland Public Schools Foundation; Leaders Roundtable; Mt. Hood Community College."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Reading and College and Career Success Program
Project Description: "Description: Targeted, aligned interventions to systemically improve reading for all students and assemble stakeholder groups to design schools to meet 21st century needs of students and the community.Project and Activities: These systemic approaches will build on the reading improvement achieved in grades K-3 and engage all stakeholder groups to ensure students are ready to succeed in college, technical training and careers and become accomplished citizens while meeting personal, community and civic needs:  1) Train 100% of teachers in grades 4-12 to apply researched-based reading practices and teach reading in the content areas; 2) Provide on-going coaching from Literacy Coaches; 3) Utilize a brain-based software program for struggling students to improve comprehension; 4) Monitor progress and provide interventions for students in grades 4-12 through Lexile; 5) Use assessments, project evaluation and reports to guide continuous improvement; 6) Disseminate findings and share practices through a learning community, the state leadership institute's curriculum, the Department of Education training and  communications, and an on-line network; 7) Build the capability of district and school leaders to use effective performance management strategies for 21st century learning environments; 8)Train and hold leaders accountable to apply implementation protocols which ensure targets are achieved and practices and results are sustained during and after the grant period; 9) Engage stakeholders in reading initiatives and design of 21st century schools to meet student and community needs.Expected outcomes:  1) Improve reading comprehension for all student groups; 2) All content-area teachers score 'proficient' or above on performance assessments of reading teaching practices; 3) Increased Advance Placement enrollment, graduation rate, college readiness and college entrance; 4) Comprehensive 21st Century School Plan; 5) Increase involvement by all stakeholders."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: i3Math and Science Program
Project Description: "The program is designed to (1) increase the success of 9th grade under-represented students in academically rigorous courses, and (2) increase the development and use of formative assessments and metrics that are aligned with high student content and academic achievement standards.  The purpose of the i3 Freshman Academy is to recruit 100 Low-income and/or First Generation students for participation in an innovative Life Coaching Program .  The Murray State University (MSU) i3 Math and Science Project proposes to serve 100 students from selected counties in western Kentucky (KY), eastern Missouri (MO), and northern Tennessee (TN).  MSU, which lies in the center of the target area, is a comprehensive, regional university providing excellent educational opportunities for students.  Target area students come from families whose annual income is at or below 150% of federal poverty level. The average salary for a family of four in the target area is $31,128, whereas the national average is $52,029 according to the U.S. Census Bureau (2008).  This proposal offers a motivational technology skills building plan, for students in grade 9.  The academic component is structured to provide opportunities to build academic and social skill by providing Life Coaches for the students.  Each student will develop, along with assistance, an Individual Life Plan (ILP). The culmination of the Program will provide participants with workshops on college preparation, career choices, and financial literacy.  The summer component centers on an innovative cooperative learning researched based curriculum.  Participants will work with professors who hold Ph.D.'s or graduate students experienced in conducting scientific research.  "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: i3Math and Science Program
Project Description: "The program is designed to (1) increase the success of 9-11th   grade under-represented students in academically rigorous courses, and (2) increase the development and use of formative assessments and metrics that are aligned with high student content and academic achievement standards.  The purpose of the i3 Math and Science Program is to recruit 100 Low-income and/or First Generation students for participation in an innovative Life Coaching Program .  The Murray State University (MSU) i3 Math and Science Project proposes to serve 100 students from selected counties in western Kentucky (KY), eastern Missouri (MO), and northern Tennessee (TN).  MSU, which lies in the center of the target area, is a comprehensive, regional university providing excellent educational opportunities for students.  Target area students come from families whose annual income is at or below 150% of federal poverty level. The academic component is structured to provide opportunities to build academic and social skill by providing Life Coaches for the students.  Each student will develop, along with assistance, an Individual Life Plan (ILP). The culmination of the Program will provide participants with workshops on college preparation, career choices, and financial literacy.  In addition, it they will receive six hours of college credit.  The summer component centers on an innovative cooperative learning researched based curriculum.  Participants will work with professors who hold Ph.D.'s or graduate students experienced in conducting scientific research.  "

In addition, it they will receive six hours of college credit.  The summer component centers on an innovative cooperative learning researched based curriculum.  Participants will work with professors who hold Ph.D.'s or graduate students experienced in conducting scientific research.  "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Mu-Ha-Ch - CSU partnership to improve early learning outcomes
Project Description: "Three school districts in central, western Georgia (Muscogee County, Harris County, and Chattahoochee County) will collaborate with Columbus State University (the official partner) to create a pre-K through 5th grade laboratory school on the university campus for this Validation Grant application.  Teachers from all three counties would each teach at the laboratory school for a period of two years.  Half of the faculty would be from the public schools in those counties, while the other half would be faculty of Columbus State University.   In Year I, the teachers would receive intensive professional development which they would implement in the classroom. In Year II, those teachers would also serve as mentors to the new first year teachers.  After two years, the public school teachers would return to their district classrooms where they would provide professional development to teachers in their school and serve as mentors.  The goals of the project are to: create a model school using technology to improve student achievement that can be replicated worldwide,  increase student technology literacy,  increase community understanding of the importance of STEM, develop model technology enabled STEM labs emphasizing, interdisciplinary, hands-on, inquiry-based (guided discovery) learning aligned to the Common Core State Standards and the Georgia Performance Standards, provide high quality K-12 professional learning opportunities, and increase student engagement and interest. It is planned for 572 students and 28 teachers to be impacted annually, between year IV and year V, 250,000 students will have been impacted, and by year IX, over 500,000 will have been directly impacted by the program.  It is expected that students in the laboratory school will score at least 20% above district and state scores on standardized test scores."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Project TURN (Teaching Undergraduates Right Now)
Project Description: "Muskogee Public Schools TURN Project (Teaching Undergraduates Right Now) validation grant will serve 506 teachers and 6,408 at risk students in grades K-12. Muskogee students are at risk for academic failure due to high dropout rates, poverty, births to teens, gang activity, exposure to trauma, violent crime arrests, child abuse/neglect, unemployment, single-parent homes, and the prevalence of alcohol and illegal substances in the community. The project will address Absolute Priority 3: Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessment. The project has established five primary goals:GOAL 1. Increase the success of underrepresented student populations in academically rigorous courses andprograms.GOAL 2. Enhance the quality and access to postsecondary education.GOAL 3. Develop safe schools and strong character.GOAL 4. Serve families who qualify for early intervention services.GOAL 5. Transform education into an evidence-based field.Competitive priorities include numbers (5) Innovations for Improving Early Learning Outcomes, (6) Innovations that Support College Access and Success, and (7) Innovations to address the Unique Needs of Students with Disabilities and Limited English Proficiency. The project will engage ten partners to effect positive academic change: Oklahoma University K-20 Center (official partner), AVID (Advancement Via Individual Development), PLTW (Project Lead the Way), Literacy First, STEM training (Science,Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics), SAMHSA?s Positive Action, Learning Academies, Jim Faye?s Love and Logic, and Ruby Payne?s Understanding the Framework of Poverty. The Education Foundation of Muskogee will provide the twenty percent match in the amount of two million dollars."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Gateway to Implementing Technology and Engineering Standards
Project Description: "The Gateway Project is designed to increase the number of K-12 school districts implementing high qualitystandards and assessments for technology and engineering, increase student achievement on the MassachusettsComprehensive Assessment System (MCAS), and increase the number of students pursuing STEM fields. Acomprehensive evaluation will; 1) measure program effects on both short-term and long-term district outcomes2) support quality program management with formative feedback throughout the program, and 3) captureattitudinal, perceptual, and behavioral change among participants.Core project activities include: 1) three-day institutes in which district teams participate in district-wide planningto implement technology/engineering in their school districts and 2) Regional Leader institutes to develop?program experts? who will then co-lead informational sessions and institutes in their geographic regions,leading to an exponential increase in the number of districts exposed to the project and its goals. Othersupporting activities include: In-district visits, Callback days, Seminar sessions and Annual symposia."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Roadmap for Life
Project Description: "The purpose of the development project, Roadmap for Life,  is to incorporate a comprehensive educational and career data?.. Truncated Notes"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Students First: College and Career Readiness Program
Project Description: "Valley Springs School District in Valley Springs, Arkansas is proposing  to form a Community of Learning based on their Students First! College and Career Readiness Program.  The LEAs in the Community of Learning are located in the Ozark Mountains in northern Arkansas.  Identified as rural, three of the LEAs are among the poorest in the United States. Valley Springs District has had great success especially in the area of preparing students with the least needed remediation upon entering college.  This grant allows development of the program with input from the participating LEAs so that it is portable and replicable in other schools in the Ozark Unlimited Resources  Cooperative.  A multi-pronged project, the challenge begins in Pre-K and proceeds through graduation in a standards-based challenging curriculum based on the Arkansas Frameworks and Student Learning Expectations.  Extended time is given for those students to master the skills and subject matter in after-school sessions.  The program features bell to bell instruction which increases the success of under-represented student populations ( economically deprived or special needs populations) in academically challenging programs.  Best practices incorporate rigorous and relevant project,  inquiry,  and design-based contextual learning opportunities.  Technology-supported  instruction with after-school technology access, and  inclusion with supports for special needs students is provided. Supports for high-needs students include: after-school tutoring, graduation coaches for students at risk of droppping out, early grade identification with interventions for students at risk of retention, outreach to low-income parents to meaningfully engage them in the teaching of their children.The system is data supported through state and formative assessments to inform and align curiculum to Student Learning Outcomes translated into classroom practices that meet the needs of all students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Nah Tah Wahsh Public School Academy
Project Title: Innovative strategies for improving student achievement through the effective use of data.
NALEO Education Leadership Initiative
Project Description: "The NALEO Educational Fund seeks to significantly expand the governance skills of Los Angeles County Latino school board members, providing them with an advanced knowledge of pertinent education reform issues, such as, but not limited to:  establishing and maintaining quality data and data systems; recruiting, developing, and retraining highly effective teachers; creating common standards;  K-16 system alignment; and accelerating postsecondary degree completion.  In partnership with the Los Angeles County Office of Education, the NALEO Educational Fund will seek to provide governance training to the approximately 115 Latino school board members in the County.  The primary vehicle through which this leadership development training will take place will be the Leadership Group.  Given the length of this grant period, the NALEO Educational Fund will create two Leadership Groups over the course of the grant period, with each group comprised of approximately 12 Los Angeles County Latino school board members.  The intent will be to engage and mobilize these policymakers to conduct intensive community, policy, and advocacy work around opportunities for innovations that improve the use of data in their individual communities for a 24-month period.  During the trainings, an emphasis will be placed on the U.S. Department of Education's Absolute Priority Two-Innovations that Improve the Use of Data.  In order to reach the approximately 115 Latino school board members in Los Angeles County the NALEO Educational Fund will hold two NELI Los Angeles Regional Trainings, which will incorporate an ongoing discussion and strategy for meaningful data usage.  Additionally, the NALEO Educational Fund will hold three regional meetDesigned to serve the entire constituency of Latino school board members in Los Angeles County."

Project Title: Student -Centered 21st Century Learning in Napa County (SC21)
Project Description: "The NVUSD is submitting this Development Project for funding under the i3 Competitive Grant Program to expand the Student-centered 21st Century Learning in Napa County project based on the success of Napa?s flagship New Technology High. The project hypothesis is:  Student achievement, specifically in underrepresented populations, will increase across targeted schools by expanding the New Technology model through teacher professional development and certification. This hypothesis is supported by research-based findings that indicate the New Technology model when implemented across all grade levels will lead to positive student outcomes. The vision is to extend the New Technology High model of project-based learning and 21st century skills development to traditional high schools, middle schools, elementary schools, and rural LEAs within Napa County.
