The goals of expanding Student-Centered 21st Century Learning county-wide at all grade levels include: (1) Increasing student achievement across participating schools by expanding the New Technology model, especially in underrepresented populations, (2) Disseminating the successful New Technology model county-wide to meet emerging school needs, and (3) Establishing a teacher professional development and alternative certification route in conjunction with local institutes of higher education.Project activities will be centered in the newly established Napa SC21 Centers for Excellence, which will serve as the designated sites for all professional development activities. The Napa SC21 Centers for Excellence will be housed at two sites: McPherson Elementary School and Napa New Technology High School. Elementary professional development activities for grades K-5 will be at the McPherson Elementary School site, and secondary professional development activities for grades 6-12 will be at the Napa New Technology High School site."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Learning Readiness and Academic Success through Student Owership of Data
Project Description: "The Learning Readiness Physical Education(LRPE) TM program at Naperville Community Unit School District 203 in Naperville, Illinois, has a unique combination of reinforcing student goal setting and formative assessment data within a classroom context of action-based learning that has led to demonstrated results in its high-need 9th grade population. The i3 Validation grant will allow for the systemic study and expansion of the LRPE program of high-intensity aerobic Physical Education and intervention-based math and reading classes to reach over 25,000 students in rural, suburban, and urban education settings. District 203 will analyze the implementation of a data system that will demonstrate significant cognitive gains by teaching students to examine data and by informing decision making through the use of technology. This data collection system will be easy to use and data will be made readily available to foster decision making skills that will improve instruction and learning behaviors. Teachers will use the data to help guide the next steps of a student?s progress in all academic areas. With the use of such data, the focus is holistic in nature, looking at the whole child rather than contained to the individual subject area. The level of student reflection and use of data will vary based on the grade level. Beginning at the elementary level, students will discover the relationships between their various learning data and begin to set goals for improvement in all areas for their health, academic achievement, and behavior. At the middle school level students will begin to observe the correlation to their academic performance and the learning behaviors they utilize that increase focus, engagement and brain function. Students in high school will make informed decisions about their learning. Through the use of data, this project helps students make decisions to improve their health, increase achievement, and implement positive behaviors beyond high school."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: LEARN SMART
Project Description: "Under the Learn, Engage Actively, Research, Never-endingly (LEARN) Science, Math, Arts & Activity, Research & Technology (SMART) The Natchez-Adams School District (NASD) has chosen to propose under the Development Grant and address the Absolute Priority 4?Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing School.Extensive training will be provided by NASD to engage actively teachers, administrators and students, in ?never-ending? research (LEARN), to teach and supervise technology rich science, math, arts, research and technology (SMART) instructional activities and offer students extended learning opportunities. Approximately 150 teachers and administrators will be served and an estimated 5,400 students over the five-year period of the project trial. Technology rich innovative practices will engage students in grades 5 through 8.NASD, considered a Rural and Low-Income School (RLIS) under this program authorized under Title VI, Part B of the ESEA."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Stengthening Career Academies for Student Success
Project Description: "The National Academy Foundation (NAF) requests an I-3 Development Grant to develop and implement Strengthening Career Academies for Student Success, an innovative program for service delivery grounded in a new set of standards and assessments. Strengthening Career Academies will lead to a significantly and systematically higher quality of performance across its national network of career academies.  The program will demonstrate what research and experts have long stated is the magic in moving young people on a path to success, and debunk old perceptions that only some can be prepared for college and that only some need career readiness.  Our proposed program will take the best practices for public-private partnerships and student engagement and align it with the necessary qualifications to move students to success.This proposal addresses Absolute Priority #3 (Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards Assessments) in terms of increased success of under-represented students in academically rigorous courses and programs; increased use of performance-based tools and metrics aligned with high quality student content and academic achievement standards; and ability to translate standards and information from assessments into classroom practices.  The proposal also addresses Competitive Preference Priorities #6 (Innovations that Support College Access and Success) and #8 (Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEAs.)  Although we are not applying under Absolute Priority #2 (Innovations that Improve the Use of Data), we believe that the work being conducted will address this as well. The National Academy Foundation manages a network of over 500 high school career academies in 41 states and the District of Columbia. These public schools-within-schools use a career-themed curriculum tied to state and national standards to provide 50,000 students each year with an outstanding college-preparatory education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National American Indian, Alaskan & Hawaiian Educational Development Center, Inc.
Project Title: The National American Indian, Alaskan & Hawaiian Educational Development Center
Project Description: "NAIAHEDC, in partnership with 28 K-5 geographically-isolated rural LEA's, across 7 states with majority populations of AI/AN & PI underserved students, is seeking Validation funding to address Absolute Priority #1 & Competitive Preference # 5, #7, & #8."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Association for Urban Debate Leagues
Project Title: Communication Based on Evidence Initiative (CBEI)
Project Description: "The Communication Based on Evidence Initiative (CBEI) uses afterschool policy debate as an instructional vehicle to complement the implementation of the Common Core State Standards in English Language Arts (CCSS). Policy debate trains independent engagement with complex informational non-fiction texts and effective writing of arguments based on evidence - literacy skills prioritized in the CCSS. The CBEI will (i) increase the successful participation of high-need urban students in policy debate while (ii) evaluating the effectiveness of debate as a rigorous academic intervention.  CBEI's objectives are to (i) train teachers to teach CCSS-aligned debate instruction, (ii) increase participation of high-need students in debate, (iii) develop debate performance feedback systems, and (iv) pilot in-school debate programs. The outcomes are: Improvement in Student Achievement (e.g., graduation / dropout rates; standardized test scores in reading and writing; GPAs; honors and AP credits earned; and college enrollment) and Increase in Participation (e.g., number of student participants; hours of student after-school practice; rounds of debate competition; hours of student summer and weekend instruction; and competitive intensity).By year three, CBEI will reach approximately 3,970 urban debaters per year, for an estimated five-year total of 12,000 students.The NAUDL, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization (NPO), is the lead applicant for CBEI. CBEI's official partners include four debate NPOs (in Chicago, Boston, Houston, and Jersey) and four LEAs (Chicago Public Schools, Boston Public Schools, Houston Independent School District, and Newark Public Schools). The CBEI also includes two other partners: (i) The National Forensic League and (ii) the University of Southern California Annenberg School of Communication.  Independent evaluation will be conducted by Learning Point Associates."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Developing and Implementing the Curriculum for Agricultural Science Education (CASE)

Applicant: National Association of Police Athletic/Activities Leagues, Inc.
Project Title: National PAL Dropout Prevention Program
Project Description: "Using the National PAL Dropout Prevention Program , an innovative interactive CD program  that was designed by Dr. Harold Shinitzky and Dr. Chuck Friedman to address at-risk behaviors.The program uses interactive video examples with a focus on realistic real-life scenarios, and by asking teens to make choices in these situations, the actual consequences of their decisions, right or wrong, can be previewed for each participant. This is highly effective in helping adolescents learn good decision making and the consequences of their decisions in various aspects of their lives from gang involvement to shoplifting to drug use. The program is a 'Designated  Model Curricul by the Institute of Dropout Prenvtion.The partnership consists of National Association of Police Athletic/Activities Leagues, Inc.  (National PAL), the Western Suffolk County BOCES and St Josephs College. National PAL will be the lead agency for the grant, Western Suffolk County BOCES will train personnel and deliver  the program to participants and parents and St Josephs College will be providing facilties and assisting the recruitment of private and parochial schools.Participants will be tested pre and post program to measure outcomes.The program addresses the risk-factors associated with poor school performance and attendance, which leads to dropping out of school. The program will comply with Section 427 of GEPA and provide access  regardless of gender, race, national origin, color, disability, or age.The program will also provise other non-school hour referrals to the Nassau and Suffolk County PAL programs and other activities to encourage positive participation in healthy, Safe and suppervised environment that will also address associated risk-factors.Professional development training will be provided to teachers, parents and other school and key personnel by Dr. Harold Shinitzky (train the Trainer) providing  BOCES with qualified and competent personnel to conduct local trainings."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: NATIONAL BOARD FOR PROFESSIONAL TEACHING STANDARDS
Project Title: National Board Certification for Teacher Leaders: A Scaleable Model to Certify Accomplished Teacher Leadership that Results in Measurable Student Learning
Project Description: "National Board Certification for Teacher Leaders is an innovative project grounded in evidence on National Board Certification (for teachers) authenticated by the National Research Council. Through the development of common standards and a common assessment for accomplished teacher leaders, NBPTS seeks to leverage teacher leaders to increase teacher capacity to improve student learning.NBPTS envisions that National Board Certification for Teacher Leaders will:1)	certify accomplished teacher leaders with proven ability to lead teachers as a means to improve student achievement and growth in high-need schools in urban and rural districts.2)	complement the Common Core State Standards, a joint project by the Council of Chief State School Officers and the National Governors Association, through teacher leader facilitation at the school or district level.3)	enhance federal efforts to improve teacher preparation through clinical teacher training models that require effective teacher leaders or effective mentors in school districts.NBPTS acknowledges that effective teacher leaders not only need to be effective teachers, but also effective in working with adults. NBPTS also realizes that student learning improves when teachers, principals, and all staff work together to create communities of learning in their schools. The overarching goal of the National Board Certification for Teacher Leaders is to create a cadre of teacher leaders who are well prepared to improve teacher practice and student learning. Ultimately, NBPTS seeks to link leadership and learning as a means to improve school and student performance.  ??NBPTS will reach out to rural LEAs in Alabama and New Mexico. NBPTS seeks to include the voice of rural school districts in developing National Board Certification for Teacher Leaders, as well as help rural districts provide job-embedded professional development on-site at the school level that have a positive impact on student achievement and growth."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Center for Electronically Mediated Learning
Project Title: P.E.B.B.L.E.S. Project:  Extended Learning and Teaching Initiative
Project Description: "A consortium, led by the National Center for Electronically Mediated Learning (NCEML), Bethany, CT, the Tennessee Organization of School Superintends and a cohort of rural Local Education Agencies and one (1) not-for-profit community-based agency, The Learning Collaborative, Inc. (501 Union Street, Nashville, TN), will join together to demonstrate how students in grades k-12 can improve their academic achievement levels, how teachers across curriculum domains can increase their effectiveness (i.e., productivity and accountability), and how school leaders can enhance their communication and motivational skills when liberated by a revolutionary technology called - P.E.B.B.L.E.S.?  (an acronym for Providing Education By Bringing Learning Environments to Students). P.E.B.B.L.E.S. is a revolutionary electronic learning environment (ELE) that is grounded in the concepts of 3D networked virtual environments (NVEs) and Virtual Interactive Communities (VICs). P.E.B.B.L.E.S. was launched as the world?s first fully functional telepresence application in 2002. Since 2005, the technology has been used to teach students with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) and to provide teachers and school leaders with innovative approaches to learning, supervision and professional development options."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Center for Family Literacy, Inc.
Project Title: Fostering School Engagement and English Learning for Latino Families
Project Description: "This project offers a transformative approach to the role of family literacy in school improvement. The project will leverage existing NCFL/Toyota Family Literacy Program K-3 services at 11 schools in 5 districts. With grant funds, efforts will expand to cover entire elementary schools (K-5). Each participating school also will create a family resource center with a schoolwide focus."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: National Center on Education & the Econo
Project Title: The Leadership Compact: Principals Leading, Students Achieving
Project Description: "The National Center on Education and the Economy (NCEE), in partnership with over 300 school districts, seeks a Validation Grant to implement a proven leadership devleopment program across seven states.  The Executive Development Program for School Leaders was developed by NCEE and is now implemented through its wholly owned subsidiary, the National Institute for School Leadership (NISL).  Since 2005, over 3,800 school leaders have completed the NISL Program.  Two rigorous quasi-experimental evaluation studies have linked NISL's training to student achievement gains.  This proposal lays out a plan to validate thesefindings across a sample of 2,000 schools serving over a million students across seven states using a large-scale, randomized evaluation design.  Learning Point Associates (LPA) will bethe independent evaluator of this project.  This proposal addresses Absolute Priority 1 - Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals.  This project will focus on creating highly effective principals.  Over 2,000 principals will receive the leadership development training in this proposed project impacting the lives of about 470,000 poor students and about 430,000 minority students.  This proposal also addresses Competitive Priority #8 - Innovations that Serve Rural LEA's by addressing the unique needs of 77 Rural LEA's that have joined our Leadership Compact."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Commission on Teaching & America's Future
Project Title: Teachers Learning in Networked Communities (TLINC)
Project Description: "Teachers Learning In Networked Communities (TLINC) is an i3 Development proposal addressed to AbsolutePriority 1. TLINC?s goal is to improve teaching effectiveness and teacher retention in high need schools.TLINC was created with pilot funding from AT&T Foundation, Microsoft, Pearson Inc., and U.S. Ed(FIPSE). TLINC?s web-based learning community improves teacher preparation and induction by embeddingnovice teachers in a real-time 24/7 support network of peers, mentors, higher education faculty, accomplishedclassroom veterans, and knowledgeable others. TLINC has been rigorously evaluated during its pilot phase;with this i3 proposal NCTAF will refine and test the impact of the TLINC strategy across an expandednetwork of sites. Our hypothesis is that participation in TLINC professional learning communities duringpreparation and induction will significantly improve teacher retention and teaching effectiveness during thecritical first, second, and third years of teaching. To test this hypothesis we will use a longitudinal, quasiexperimental,non-equivalent control group design, which will compare the outcomes of teachers participatingin the TLINC program with teachers who are not participating in the TLINC program immediately followingpre-service training and for two years thereafter. We will target a total of 4,992 teacher candidates, 16,450novice and accomplished teachers, and 1,348 faculty, directly impacting 536,041 K12 students during the fouryears of the project. Our district partnerships are: Arizona State U./Isaac School District;Georgia StateU./consortium of rural GA districts; Montclair State U./ Newark Public Schools (PS); U. of CentralOklahoma/Oklahoma City Schools;U. of Colorado, Denver/Denver Metro area PDS districts;U. ofMemphis/Memphis City Schools;U. of New Mexico/Albuquerque PS;U. of Northern Iowa/consortium of ruralIowa districts; U. of Texas, El Paso/El Paso Regional Induction Districts; and U. of Washington/Seattle PS."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Commission on Teaching and America's Future
Project Title: NCTAF STEM Learning Studios
Project Description: "The National Commission on Teaching and America?s Future?s STEM Learning Studios initiative will partner school districts in Maryland, New Mexico and South Carolina and charter schools in the District of Columbia with government agencies and private sector partners to create collaborative Learning Teams at each participating school. These teams would become professional development partnerships for teachers who will learn how to engage their students in learning activities that draw on STEM education content and the challenges and discoveries emerging from the STEM field today. These cross-discipline teams match teachers with STEM professionals from private sector companies and government agencies, who apply their scientific expertise and passion as content experts, mentors, and coaches working shoulder-to-shoulder with STEM teachers and students (virtually as well as face-to-face). NCTAF?s STEM Learning Studios initiative engages students in deep, extended science inquiry and project-based learning, while providing teachers with continuous embedded professional development to improve STEM content knowledge and pedagogy. Through a current grant with NASA, NCTAF has piloted this model in two Maryland school districts, demonstrating how learning teams can improve STEM education ? both in student achievement and professional development for educators ? as well as successfully engage STEM professionals who have deep content knowledge and experience in project-based Learning Studios with educators and students. Over 5 years, NCTAF will expand this initiative to 29 schools, reaching over 42,000 students and 145 educators, while engaging over 100 STEM professionals in improving STEM outreach and education."

Project Title: Developing Leaders for Minority Student Achievement
Project Description: "NCLR in partnership with two LEAs will implement a principal leadership and mentorship project thatincreases the number of principals who are highly effective and implements innovative practices designed toaddress the linguistic and academic needs of LEP. The project will test the hypothesis that the academicachievement of typically low-performing, secondary school students in community schools improves whenprincipals in their schools participate in a facilitated support structure anchored in effective instructionalleadership strategies. Project activities include the provision of intensive professional development aroundleadership and mentorship skills with a focus on literacy development for LEP students through cohort meetings,coaching sessions, and site visits. A group of four principals will become mentors to the eight others as they alldevelop and implement school improvement plans. As a result of the project, NCLR will develop a tool kit forschools and organizations that support charter and community-based schools on how to implement a similarprogram."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
Project Title: Improving Mathematical Performance and Algebra Readiness for Title I School (IMPARTS)
Project Description: "This project will enhance the quality of mathematics instruction and Title I interventions in ways that ensure thathigh-need students in grades 3?6 can succeed in algebra?a gatekeeper course for college and career readiness.To address Absolute Priority 1 (innovations that support effective teachers and principals), we will providesustained professional development (on-site, online, in communities of practice, and at professionalconferences) to district and school leadership teams, teachers and Title I specialists in the progression of coremathematical concepts and skills needed for future success in algebra."

Project Title: Accelerated Pathway to College
National Flight Academy Aviation Classroom Experience (NFA-ACE)
Project Description: "The National Flight Academy Aviation Classroom Experience (NFA-ACE) is a highly immersive integrated curriculum designed to stimulate student achievement in science, technology, engineering, and math by engaging in interactive flight simulation experiences. The primary objective is stimulating interest in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) and reinforcing a sound understanding of math and science skills taught in traditional core courses. This project will serve as a learning laboratory for research for collaborative team-based approaches for STEM initiatives which will be a promising strategy for retaining members of Underrepresented Minority Groups in STEM educational tracks. Scholarships to the National Flight Academy School will be offered to all students who complete the NFA-ACE program. This Validation Grant will be used to fund twenty six (26) middle and high school NFA-ACE classrooms in Escambia and Santa Rosa County District Schools. Schools will be located in rural areas with a large percentage of at risk and under achieving students. Special projects include adding two NFA-ACE teacher training classrooms at the University of West Florida and NFA NAS Pensacola, FL. The curriculum will be developed and evaluated for use in all schools across the United States. The proposed research will advance knowledge of shared mental models in team-based learning, affinity spaces to facilitate the development of useful social identities (especially among members of underrepresented groups in STEM fields), and group dynamics on volitional strategies for learning. The estimated number of students served will be 9,984 per year for five years for a total of 49,920 students. The official partner is The National Flight Academy in collaboration with the University of West Florida, Escambia and Santa Rosa District County Schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Forum to Accelerate Middle-Grades Reform
Project Title: Schools to Watch:  School Transformation Network
Project Description: "The National Forum to Accelerate Middle-Grades Reform Schools proposes to develop and test a promising innovation aimed at 1) building the capacity of persistently low-performing middle grades schools, 2) improving their students' academic performance, and 3) closing achievement gaps among sub-groups. The Forum will develop and test the innovation with a consortium of 18 urban and rural schools in three states-North Carolina, California and Illinois. The innovation uses the (1) Forum's Schools to Watch (STW) criteria as a framework for change; (2) tools for school assessment, goal setting, action planning and monitoring; (3) a multi-layered system of support including a STW coach, a principal leadership coach, and a mentor school matched by demographics; and (4) focused professional development designed to build a learning community and address the needs of students at risk of educational failure.         Over time, we expect the 18 schools to 1) strengthen their structures, norms, and processes for continuous improvement; 2) increase their academic rigor; 3) promote equity for all students, including those with disabilities and limited English proficiency; and 4) develop an array of supports designed to meet the needs of young adolescents.  Over the 4 years, the project will serve approximately 18,000 students in the 18 schools. Our State STW Program, which now operates in 19 states, provides a strong infrastructure necessary for both scale-up and sustainability."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: NIFDI I3 Proposal for Enhancing Teacher Effectiveness
Project Description: "This project will validate the role of well-designed and systematic implementation support in enhancing teachers' effectiveness in improving student achievement using the Direct Instruction (DI) approach and the extent to which computer-based methods of support can be effective, efficient, and useful to teachers using DI. This project will 1) validate the effectiveness of NIFDI's model of support for DI implementations; 2) validate computer based-methods of monitoring student progress, evaluating teacher effectiveness, and providing on-going coaching support; and 3) compare the relative effectiveness of a) minimal support, b) in-person support, and c) computer-based methods of support in enhancing teacher effectiveness and student achievement.  These methods will be validated in five different states at both the primary level and upper elementary level with rural and urban schools and with schools serving students with a wide range of ethnic and socio-economic characteristics (including schools with large ESL populations)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Institute for Excellence in Teaching
Project Title: Innovation through the TAP System: Scaling a Comprehensive District Reform Model
Project Description: "Over the course of this grant, 13 schools Knoxville (TN) will implement TAP to decrease the percent of ineffective teachers, build the local capacity for teacher effectiveness reform, and increase student achievement. TAP addresses the challenge of attracting and retaining talented teachers in high-need schools through its integrated model of teacher advancement within the classroom, ongoing professional development on site, multiple teacher evaluations with trained evaluators, and performance-based compensation to reward individual and collective success in observed instructional skills and student growth."

Applicant: National Institute for Excellence in Teaching
Project Title: Increasing and Sustaining Teacher Excellence in High Need Schools - TAP: The System for Teacher and Student Advancement
Project Description: "Over the course of this grant, schools in Ascension Public Schools (LA), School District of Pickens County(SC) and Pflugerville Independent School District (TX) will implement TAP to decrease the percent of ineffective teachers, build the local capacity for teacher effectiveness reform, and increase student achievement. TAP addresses the challenge of attracting and retaining talented teachers in high-need schools through its integrated model of teacher advancement within the classroom, ongoing professional development on site, multiple teacher evaluations with trained evaluators, and performance-based compensation to reward individual and collective success in observed instructional skills and student growth."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: National Math and Science Initiative, Inc.
Project Title: The National Math & Science Initiative's Partnership to Increase Student Achievement and College-Readiness
Project Description: "The National Math and Science Initiative (NMSI) will use the proposed i3 Scale-Up Grant to continue scaling the successful Advanced Placement Training and Incentive Program (APTIP) to reach approximately 406,438 students in 206 high schools plus feeder middle schools in 13 states. APTIP empowers high-need students to succeed in rigorous courses, thereby creating a culture of college-readiness. APTIP?s objectives: to increase student achievement, college enrollment, and college completion. APTIP accomplishes these objectives by increasing the number and diversity of students taking and passing College Board Advanced Placement courses and exams in math, science, and English in order to provide students with academic content that is tied to high standards and high-quality assessments. Two strong quasi-experimental design studies confirm that APTIP produces significant increases in student achievement, college-readiness, and college success. Expected program outcomes are: (1) significantly increase the numbers and diversity of students taking and scoring 3 or higher on AP math, science, and English exams, and (2) increase college enrollment and persistence, especially for traditionally underrepresented students. NMSI is partnering with 153 LEAs to replicate APTIP in Colorado, Indiana, Michigan, and Minnesota. NMSI is also collaborating with the Military Child Education Coalition to establish the Military Initiative Network, which will implement APTIP in schools that serve a significant portion of children in military families. The Military Initiative Network will include 13 LEAs and 50 schools spanning 10 states (Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Kansas, Kentucky, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Virginia, and Washington). NMSI?s Official Partners: Notre Dame University, the Colorado Legacy Foundation, the Michigan Mathematics & Science Centers Network, Friends of Education, the American Institutes for Research, and the 166 LEAs in the 13 states mentioned above."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: National Network of Digital Schools
Project Description: National Network of Digital Schools (NNDS) in partnership with PA Cyber School and 18 School Districts from SC to Guam are seeking to validate the success achieved by students at Pa Cyber through the use of curriculum designed by NNDS
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: National Organization of Concerned Black Men
Project Title: Saving Lives and Minds (SLAM) Academic Improvement Project
Project Description: "Concerned Black Men?s-National Organization (CBM) proposes to expand its Saving Lives and Minds (SLAM)Academic Performance Project to include 4 schools in two states (Virginia; Maryland) and the District ofColumbia. This project has been implemented with success in the District of Columbia since 2001. Theexpansion will target the poorly performing students in persistently lowest achieving schools, schools that arebeing restructured or are in corrective action and schools failing to meet Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP).The Organization will include the following schools; 1) Walker Jones Elementary School ? District of Columbia;2) Savoy Elementary School ? District of Columbia; and 3) Dr. Rayner Browne Academy ? Baltimore,Maryland. CBM also is seeking to select either 4) William Ramsay or Cora Kelly Elementary schools inAlexandria, Virginia. All the above schools are in need of assistance. As an example, Walker Jones is beingrestructured. In school year 2009, only 38% of students at the school were at or above proficient in reading and41% were at or above proficient in math (District of Columbia School Profiles, 2010). Savoy Elementary in theDistrict of Columbia is in improvement status. Only 26% of students at Savoy were at or above proficient in mathin school year 2009 while 29% were proficient in reading. Dr. Rayner Browne Elementary did not make adequateyearly progress (AYP) and has been listed in improvement status by the Maryland State Department ofEducation. In school year 2009, only 46.3% students at the school scored at or above proficient in math and57.0% were at or above proficient in reading (2009 Maryland Report Card). Moreover, similar results have beenobserved at Cora Kelly and William Ramsay Elementary schools. Cora Kelly ES did not make AYP and has beenplaced on the school improvement list by the Virginia Department of Education (VOE)-(2009, VirginiaDepartment of Education Report Card)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: The New Science and Mathematics Teachers Academy
Project Description: "The New Science and Mathematics Teachers Academy (NSMTA) addresses the significant national need for effective rural and urban teachers of science and mathematics by lowering the number of new teachers who leave the school and/or profession during their first three years, and raising their effectiveness through a content-based induction program featuring mentoring and a content-specific virtual professional learning community. This innovative program that will impact 800 teachers and 324,000 students over five years has been tested by the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) for three years. The goals of the program are to (1) increase the retention of the new science and mathematics teachers, and (2) ensure that they become highly effective teachers. The hypothesis of the project is that an online mentoring system can help to improve teacher effectiveness, with the areas of pedagogical content knowledge and scientific inquiry practices expanding to the greatest degree in one year. The mentors are critical in supporting the practices and the pedagogical content knowledge development of the new teachers.The new teachers participating in the Academy will benefit from content-specific mentoring, participate in electronic modules specifically designed to increase the effectiveness of new teachers, and be part of a robust professional learning community.  The domains of teacher effectiveness include content knowledge, pedagogical content knowledge, classroom learning environment, student assessment, and professional learning community.To develop the promising practices of its New Science Teacher Academy, NSTA is joining forces with the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM) to expand the scope, and two school district partners:  a consortium of school districts in Alaska, and the Atlanta  (Georgia) Public Schools, to include teacher and student diversity across rural to urban settings."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Teach for Beaverton
Project Description: "The National Staff Development Council (NSDC), the National Commission on Teaching and America's Future (NCTAF), Beaverton School District (BSD), and Oregon State University (OSU) propose a significant response to the following unmet needs as identified by BSD:o	Building and sustaining a culture of collaboration within BSD schools and across the district;o	Developing a new model of rigorous and relevant preparation and induction that builds a coherent connection between teachers' preservice experiences and their first years of teaching so that all children receive an excellent education from highly effective educators;o	Increasing the diversity of BSD's teaching force and develop systems to support promising first generation, minority BSD students into the teaching profession; ando	Developing an aligned definition and evaluation of teacher effectiveness that follows teachers from preservice into experienced practice and informs policy and practice at each step of the way.The partners will meet these needs through an exceptional approach to Priority One, Strategies that Support Effective Teachers and Principals, that creates a model for long-term, sustainable improvement of teaching effectiveness and student achievement for all students, especially those with the highest needs. Our model spans the entire continuum of the teacher career pathway to engage every teacher and incoming teacher in a seamless system of continuous improvement in teacher effectiveness. At its core, our model is an intentional combination of two proven strategies: 1) teaching residencies that create a dynamic and professionally relevant clinical practice teaching experience; and 2) 'learning schools' where teacher collaboration creates a 21st century teaching and learning environment that supports continuous growth in teaching effectiveness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: LINGOLINK to LITERACY
Project Description: "This Project entitled, LINGOLINK to LITERACY, will focus on Absolute Priority # 4?Innovations that TurnAround Persistently Low Performing Schools. The innovation of the Rule of 3 for teaching interdisciplinaryvocabulary is the critical instructional LINK to close the achievement gap for English language learners(ELLs) who are one of the fastest growing groups among the school-aged population. In the last two decadesthe growth rate for the ELL population was 169% as compared to the 12% growth for the general schoolpopulation (Francis et al, 2006). There are over 9.9 million ELLs of which 5.5 million are classified as LimitedEnglish Proficient (LEP) by virtue of their scores on assessments of English language proficiency and theirparticipation in Title III services. Although the majority, 80%, of ELLs in the United States, are Spanishspeaking, there are over 400 other spoken languages.This Project will implement a reform approach for vocabulary development with 6 participating partners (LEAs)who are rural districts thaThe overall goal of Project LINGOLINK to LITERACY is to coach teachers in an innovative systematicinterdisciplinary vocabulary program using the Rule of 3 tied to comprehension passages to develop thecritical LINKS to literacy that will 1) accelerate ELLs and other students? interdisciplinary vocabularydevelopment and 2) develop the interdisciplinary comprehension skills needed to access content across subjectareas. The goal is to use these innovative LINKS to increase achievement for ELLs and all students atpersistently low achieving schools. A secondary goal is to use the technology of IRIS CONNECT as a LINKfor the training and coaching of teachers who are geographically diverse in rural school districts. These goalsare correlated to the development grant absolute priority 4 which is to use innovative strategies to turn aroundthe achievement at persistently low performing schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: National Urban League Project Ready:  Expanded Opportunity Pilot
Learning Powered by Technology: The CIRRUS Initiative
Project Description: "The National Urban Technology Center is a 501(c)(3) educational corporation that develops web-based e-learning curricula that help youth make positive, life-affirming decisions as well as develop constructive attitudes and behaviors regarding their education and health. The curriculum, called Youth Leadership Academy (YLA), consists of several self-contained, developmentally sequenced modules and employs a carefully designed mix of group activities, games and structured exercises. YLA is a technology-rich e-learning platform and curriculum for building the critical skills necessary to graduate, gain acceptance in post-secondary education, make career choices and be successful in the workplace. Through embedded professional development, it also provides for teacher comfort with the use of e-learning platforms in the classrooms.This i3 Development Grant is requested to implement YLA in 15 high schools (in Brooklyn & the South Bronx, New York City; & in Niagara Falls,Buffalo, Rochester & Spring Valley, NY), and provide YLA's full range of services in all grade 9 ELA classrooms in year 1, grade 10 ELA classrooms in year 2, and grade 11 ELA classrooms in year 3. (ELA classrooms were selected as reading is a proxy for academic success.) 100 students in each school will be targeted for treatment over the 3 year project. With ongoing support to educators served in previous years, the project expects to reach approximately 4,500 students over three-years. During the project, seven teachers, administrators and specialists will be trained annually in each school. The evaluation will measure student academic and socio-emotional outcomes, teacher attitudes toward technology as an engaging and powerful learning and assessment tool, and will help decide whether these outcomes correlate with the efficacy of YLA. Evaluation data have shown that students who have participated in the initiatives have made greater academic and social-emotional gains than students who have not. "

Project Title: Service-Learning Strategies for Success
Project Description: "In this Investing In Innovation development project, the National Youth Leadership Council (NYLC) will partner with North Carolina's Guilford County Schools (GCS) to implement district-wide service-learning, an educational strategy that galvanizes core curriculum by linking it with meaningful service. Over three-years, NYLC and GCS will address Absolute Priority 1: Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals by integrating service-learning into all 120 schools across all curricular areas K-12, building the capacity of teachers and administrators, and thereby increasing student engagement and academic achievement.NYLC will advance teacher and principal effectiveness through the implementation of research-based service-learning practice standards using professional learning communities, supported by an online community of service-learning teachers, expert advisors, and multimedia resources, and strategic partnerships to sustain and grow the effort. Engaging 71,000 students district-wide, teachers will improve their effectiveness, as measured by: increased student achievement on state assessments; reduced gaps in achievement between groups of students; improved student attitudes toward learning; professional collaboration; and performance on observations of teaching effectiveness. Key partnerships for this project include The University of Minnesota (supporting evaluation) and Communities In Schools North Carolina. High-quality service-learning is a multi-faceted teaching method that significantly improves academic achievement. This innovative strategy has been implemented across the country with promising results, but needs a more systematic approach and evaluation. In this project, training and evaluation approaches - using multiple measures of effectiveness - will help service-learning shape the next generation of schools and provide replicable models of teacher training, student engagement, and school reform."

Project Title: Pathways to Innovative Literacy Instruction
Project Description: "The Pathways to Innovate Literacy (PILI) project is the outgrowth of a successful 8-year partnership between National-Louis University (NLU), the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC), and Chicago Public Schools (CPS) with support from The Chicago Community Trust (CCT). The PILI model will improve infrastructure, leadership, and classroom practices related to literacy achievement at the Area/District, school, and classroom level. Its overarching program goal is to validate how the PILI model improves student achievement and reduces gaps in literacy between groups, including students with disabilities and who are LEP, by increasing the number of effective teachers, literacy professionals, and principals. PILI?s program goals are: 1) Increase student literacy achievement to 85% ?meets and exceeds? (targeting 20% ?exceeds?) by 2016 using the Illinois Standards Achievement Test (ISAT) and district benchmark assessments; 2) Reduce literacy achievement gaps by 50% by 2016 on the ISAT and district benchmark assessments; 3) Increase the rigor of classroom assignments by 50% as a means of raising expectations and student performance; 4) Increase the percentage of students in intervention schools who ?exceed? standards by 100% (from 10% to 20%) by 2016 as a means of increasing the percentage of students who are ?college ready;? 5) Increase the percentage of Area teachers holding literacy endorsements or specialization from 8% to 33% by 2016; 6) Increase the number of Area elementary teachers who obtain master?s degrees (from 2% to 20%) by 2016; and 7) Increase the effectiveness of principals? literacy leadership as indicated by growth on the indicators and in student achievement. Funding through the US Department of Education will validate the effectiveness and scalability of the PILI from 18 schools to 52 schools over 5 years."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Native American Community Academy Indigenous Innovations
Project Description: "The focus of NACA?s development grant will be to create a residency program that increases the number ofNative Americans who become teachers and principals and that increases the number of high-performingeducators who work with Native youth. The residency program will allow for systematic study of the impact oflanguage and culture on learning and result in documented research that links indigenous perspectives tostudent outcomes. The goals of the project are:To demonstrate that pedagogy which supports cultural learning styles in tandem with academic rigor and teacherand principal effectiveness increases the retention, achievement, social wellbeing, and graduation of high-riskstudents.To increase the number of high-performing instructors and instructional leaders targeted at Native communitiesand representative of Native communities.As a result:1. Students? academic achievement will improve by 1.5-2.0 year?s growth.2. Graduation rates will improve (compared to state statistics for comparable at-risk students).3. Students will be confident in their cultural identity and emerge from high school ready to be Native leaderswithin the context of their individual lives (school, home, community, etc.).4. Students will complete at least six hours of college credit prior to graduation.5. Students? self-reported overall physical and mental health will improve.6. Teachers from rural and/or indigenous areas will become high-performing educators who are able toincorporate cultural context into their schools.7. NACA will create a network of residency schools to further develop teachers and instructional leaders servingNative communities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: i3e3:  Equality in Opportunities, Equity in Outcome; Excellence in Operation
Project Description: "The Natomas Unified School District, a LEA with twelve P-12 schools serving 12,000, is applying for the i3 Development Grant -- entitled 'i3 e3': Equality in Opportunity; Equity in Outcomes, and Excellence in Operations. NUSD serves as the i3 grantor and the fiscal agent. The Project Leads will guide the i3e3 project: data systems and  technologies to answer our FOCUSED Absolute Priority 2 (AP2), with equality in opportunities for access and resource allocation to support teachers and students (AP1)  and equity in outcomes driven by high standards and quality assessments (AP3)  and quality first instruction for over 12,000 students. The evidence of our success will lie in the 'turnaround' of our lowest schools. Project Description: Our partnerships make this possible: 1) Arizona State University's (ASU), their non-profit Equity Alliance (EA) and data platform Leadscape?   give teachers and principals feedback about biases in data patterns, and strategies to mitigate bias.  2)  Learning Plus?  reform facilitators will use Intel-Assess?, a reliable test item data bank, to facilitate grade level teams to develop benchmark assessments, pacing and standards maps. SchoolCity?  technologies provide data  to inform instruction, calibrate standards,  design interventions, and target assessments while West Ed provides explicit support to Teach for Success (T4S) and will improve lesson planning, standards-based instruction, and administrator feedback to teachers. GOALS: Our reform encompasses all 4 Absolute Priorities: to improve the data driven culture to support student and teacher progress monitoring in an effort to close the achievement gap with equal outcomes for all students. NUSD will: increase meeting targets for API; .increase sites meeting AYP; increase differentiation of instruction, and improve utilization of instructional time for all 12,000 students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Western Knowledge Network
Project Description: "Summary:  The mission of the Western Knowledge Network (WKN) is to implement an integrated, comprehensive statewide plan based on Baldrige principles to increase the number of percentages of highly effective teachers or principals, which results in improved student growth and performance???????????????.TRUNCATED"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Regional Academy
Project Description: "Nazareth College of Rochester, in concert with the Rochester City School District and other school districts inMonroe County, New York, requests i3 funding to support the development of The Regional Academy, aninnovative form of Pre-K to grade 12 schooling aimed at transforming educational experience in the U.S. Thepurpose of The Regional Academy is to present a research based educational model aimed at desegregatingstudents on the basis of socio-economic status, race, and geographic location. Concomitantly, it will serve as amodel site for the clinical preparation of teachers and other school leaders.As a new form of public schooling to be created as a legal statute by the New York State Legislature, TheRegional Academy will educate students from age three to grade 12. The Regional Academy will enroll 75students per grade for a total school population of 1125 students. Fifty percent of the students will come fromthe City of Rochester and fifty percent will come from suburban and rural Monroe County School Districts.Selection of students will be based on blind lottery, with no entry requirements, making the student populationtruly diverse. This process will ensure a valid selection of important sub-groups such as special education andEnglish language learners which often are under-enrolled in charter schools.The working hypothesis is that high need students will most directly benefit from the explicit focus of TheRegional Academy, reflected in a demonstrable improvement in academic achievement, graduation rates, andother educational and social indices. Moreover, the school will benefit those students who are not otherwiseregarded as ?high need,? and it will have demonstrable impact on the professional preparation of teachers.Finally, the school will present a new model for schooling that will be replicable to the nineteen other areacolleges in the Rochester metropolitan area and beyond to other educationally troubled urban areas in the U.S."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: 9th Grade Financial Literacy, College and Career Readiness Curriculum
NFTE California Entrepreneurial Pathway to College Attainment Program
Project Description: "Project Description: The Network for Teaching Entrepreneurship (NFTE) California program offices (San Francisco and Fresno/Central Valley) will use the NFTE high school course as opportunity for 11th and 12th graders to earn college credit while in high school.  Through the program, students will gain an awareness of the strong connection between educational attainment and entrepreneurship. Objectives are to reach 210 low-income, low-achieving students in the San Francisco and Fresno California Unified School Districts over a 3 year project period. The program will encourage students to think about college, and at the same time provide them with mentoring and academic support services needed to enter college. Expected outcomes are to:o	Provide more academic opportunities and electives for low-income high school studentso	Increase student educational and career aspirationso	Help students transition to collegeo	Help low-achieving students meet academic standardso	Reduce dropout rates    A participatory action research evaluation process will engage key stakeholders. The project will also draw upon the expertise of experienced evaluators and entrepreneurial educators to complete the research team. The research approach will support open, broad-based involvement of project team members as collaborators on decisions guiding all aspects of the evaluation, including the development of the logic model, assessment tools, data collection, analysis, and use of findings to improve project delivery."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: A Look into the World of Algebra and Geometry
NBISD - Comprehensive Academic Project
Project Description: "New Braunfels ISD administrators developed the Comprehensive Academic Intervention Project, a comprehensive Pre K-12 response to intervention continuum of services for all students so that all NBISD students can reach their potential and participate in and complete the rigor of Pre AP and AP classes and be prepared for college access and success."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: NDCC Alternative Learning Community Program
Project Description: "We have been very successful tutoring K -12th grade students. However, our tutoring program does not impact the needs of another group of at-risk students. They are students who were dropped from school rolls because of truancy, students who just dropped-out, students with excessive suspensions, or students who have been expelled. The innovative alternative learning community program we are proposing will address the needs of the at-risk students identified above. Under this proposed plan students will work to earn 24 carnegie credits which will lead to a regular diploma and high school graduation. Students not on track for the regular diploma will be offered the opportunity to enroll in a GED program.   Placement of over-aged students in middle school and ninth grade presents several academic and social concerns for these students. I previously worked as the guidance director for a program of this nature. We were a school within a school. Over a five year period we were able to graduate over 150 students who were over-aged and two years or more below grade level. During the program's last three years, we had nine students who were among the top ten honor graduates. This was a first for this program; the program was closed due to lack of funding. Many of these students never completed school because the program was no longer available. These were students who could not make it in your traditional school settings.    The innovative alternative learning community program we are proposing will address the needs of the at-risk students identified above. Under this proposed plan students will work to earn 24 Carnegie credits which will lead to a regular diploma and high school graduation. Students ages 16 to 19, who have earned freshman status or better and have attained at least 6 credits, will utilize the 'self-paced, college-prep Apex curriculum under Plan A.  Students aged 16 to 20 and  not on track for the regular diploma will be offered the opportunity to enroll i"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: New England League of Middle Schools
Project Title: Classroom21
Project Description: "We are organizing the world's data for public education so that teachers can use them to better link educationalstandards with college and career readiness standards, and in doing so make learning more real and relevant tostudents who are at risk of educational failure. While all student populations will benefit, at-risk students willexperience the value of their education at much higher levels, and better connect their learning to success inlife; all leading to higher levels of engagement and motivation to meet education proficiency levels. We planto create 360 data-enriched lessons for all subjects spanning grades 5-8 and surround the lessons withprofessional development opportunities for both in-service and pre-service teachers. We plan to sustain theproject by charging schools a small annual subscription fee for our service and be financially self-sufficient atthe end of the grant period (3 years). We expect to reach 117,000 students and be the nation's centralrepository of results-oriented educational content designed around real world data. The expected result forstudents is higher levels of student engagement leading to improved academic acheivement (short term),reduced drop out rates in 9th grade (long term) and higher promotion rates of students from 9th to 10 grade (longterm). For teachers, the result will be new tools and training that will enable them to differentiate instruction athigher levels, be more dynamic and interesting, and connect their classroom to the world outside the classroomin ways that have never been done."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Boost! Integrated Data System (IDS)
Project Description: "New Haven Public Schools (NHPS), with official partner United Way of Greater New Haven, is requesting a Development Grant for our Boost! Integrated Data System (IDS).Our hypothesis is that the creation of Boost! IDS for data sharing and reporting among schools and partner agencies will magnify the impact of support services on student achievement. We will create: (1) an integrated data warehouse that combines student-level school data with data from 30 community agencies addressing academic, physical, social, emotional and family support needs; (2) a web-based portal to provide up-to-date information on individual students, and aggregated data for reports and analysis; and (3) training to build local capacity to use data to improve student outcomes. Boost! IDS will promote student achievement and close the achievement gap by: improving service coordination; facilitating access to services; improving service quality; making most efficient use of resources; and using data to leverage policy and system change.Key project objectives include: (1) create the data system; (2) provide access to data on services and student achievement; and (3) train all schools / partners / parents and serve all 20,000 NHPS students. Key outcomes include: increased number of students receiving services; increased coordination of services; more effective use of resources; and closing of the achievement gap between NHPS and the State. Boost! IDS offers meets Absolute Priority 2: an innovation that will improve the use of data.Boost! IDS will be exceptional in five essential ways. The wraparound services and data system itself will: (1) focus on student achievement; (2) link data from multiple sources to individual students; (3) use existing databases in a common warehouse and create web-based reporting capacity; (4) coordinate electronic referrals to track and measure impact and minimize service fragmentation; and (5) utilize data to inform broad scale program and systems change."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: TALENT (Teacher And Leadership Excellence/Effectiveness --> [through] New Tools) Program
Project Description: "The New Haven Public Schools (NHPS) will implement the TALENT Program, a systematic set of practices and strategies that will strengthen human capital management, and specifically the district's need to strengthen the supervision and coaching of teachers. The Program will operate by importing the key dimensions of the teacher and principal talent system from Achievement First (AF). In so doing, the grant will enable the landmark teachers' contract and evaluation process developed in collaboration with the New Haven Federation of Teachers (NHFT). TALENT represents a groundbreaking consolidation of district, union, and charter practice, rightly focused on the specific practices that develop and enable outstanding teachers and principals thereby transforming student achievement. NHPS proposes to adopt the key features of AF's talent management systems, with an emphasis on the supervision and development of teachers, including through management systems and data-practices. AF has developed effective, focused systems to support teacher supervision and coaching. These practices have ensured that AF schools have a high percentage of effective teachers and principals, and have been central to AF's gains in student achievement. The replication of AF talent practices in NHPS represents a significant opportunity to improve talent systems and student achievement. NHPS and AF have designed a plan for transferring the knowledge, practices and systems from AF into the district. The TALENT program will allow NHPS to invest in a 'Talent Team'. Through the joint 'Aspiring Leaders Program,' NHPS staff and aspiring NHPS principals will participate in AF's intense leadership training to bring AF's systems into their schools. NHPS schools will 'right-position' school leadership by hiring key staff (OMs, IMs)  in order to focus on teacher coaching. NHPS will also redirect substantial portions of their PD time, to replicate the AF's embedded Data Days."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: A Statewide Strategy to Improve Student Achievement in Persistently Low-Performing Schools
Project Description: "As a statewide strategy for expanding learning time in schools, New Jersey After 3 (NJ After 3) seeks aDevelopment Grant totaling $5 million over a three-year period through the Investing in Innovation (i3) Fund.In this project, New Jersey After 3 will serve ten (10) persistently low-performing public schools in ?officialpartner? urban districts? Camden, Newark, and Trenton. The i3 grant and matching funds will expandlearning time by more than 40% each school day for 1,500 high-need students in grades kindergarten througheighth grade in schools that have not made Adequate Yearly Progress for three years or more. NJ After 3 willincrease the amount of time students are taught Language Arts and mathematics by teachers who are certifiedin those content areas (70 minutes each school day), and will provide these lessons within a framework thatincludes enrichment activities (e.g., Arts, Service Learning, Health & Fitness, Career Skills) led by trainednonprofit afterschool educators. Combined, these activities will build students? skills in critical subjects, injectrelevance, and create opportunities for hands-on application, making school and learning more accessible andenjoyable for students. By strengthening students? core academic skills, developing stronger studentconnections to school, cultivating engagement in learning, and forging connections between students andadditional caring adult educators and mentors, NJ After 3 will lay a strong foundation in the elementary andmiddle grades that ensures student participants advance on-time through high school graduation and achievecollege and career success."

Applicant: New Jersey Chamber of Commerce Foundation
Project Title: Expanding and Evaluating the Impact of The LearnDoEarn Student Achievement System
Project Description: "This proposal seeks funding to expand and evaluate ?informal curriculum? developed by the New Jersey Chamberof Commerce Foundation called ?LearnDoEarn.? Currently serving 130,000 students in 200 diverse schools,funding will allow the program to serve 520,000 students by the end of five years and gauge impact on course-takingpatterns, test scores, drop-out and college admissions/attendance rates. LearnDoEarn capitalizes onbusiness? uniquely influential position as students? future employers, using knowledgeable adults (virtualbusiness people) to connect academic and behavioral decisions made in middle and high school with futureemployability and earnings. LearnDoEarn classroom lessons are colorful, age-appropriate presentations thatconvert research into actionable directives for students in grades 6 - 12, defining unequivocal goals that willlead to college and workplace success.LearnDoEarn is a high-impact, low-cost, and highly scalable solution that presents eye-popping data toyoungsters who may have not been advised properly or are too immature to make appropriate choices withoutadult influence. The explicit messages embedded in LearnDoEarn lessons have produced significant increasesin the numbers of students taking more rigorous courses, especially in math, science, and IB/AP. Positiveresults in schools with significant numbers of minority and low-income students are even more striking.Lessons build an understanding of the need for education beyond high school regardless of future plans; definethe impact of hard work in hard courses, especially in math; present information from employers who lookclosely at the personal behaviors of job candidates that influence employability (criminal convictions, druguse, smoking, driving records, etc.) that even teenagers need to keep in mind; and offer advice on theaffordability of higher education.Lessons are supplemented with wall posters, parent videos, engaging activities, reward credentials, and more."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Improving school readiness and academic preparation among poor, at risk children in persistently low performing charter schools
Project Description: "Charter schools vary in their success in closing the achievement gap for poor Black and Hispanic students in inner-city schools (Center for Research on Education, 2009). This project is intended to provide a template for charter schools for intensive intervention. The intervention will have three prongs: parent training, teacher preparation, and low-ratio, intensive intervention in reading, mathematics and social development. Students will be recruited for the project through pre-school programs in inner city schools and followed for the four years of the project through longitudinal growth curve analysis and quasi-experimental repeated measures. The three prongs of low-ratio, intensive intervention will be based on the systems-interaction approach to reading (Scanlon, Vellutino, Small, Fanuelle, & Sweeney, 2005), a combination of computational association and problem-solving in mathematics, termed Hot Math, (Fuchs, Fuchs, Stuebing, Fletcher, Hamlett, & Lambert, 2008), and social development through a program intended to promote wellness in children at risk (Cowen, Hightower, Pedro- Carroll, Work, Wyman, & Haffey, 1997). Parent training will be provided through the four years of the project for all participants (240 per year). Students will be followed through the first three years of schooling in their school of choice ? public, non-public, non-participating charter schools, and participating charter schools. In participating charter schools students (120 per year), paraprofessionals, and teachers engage in the previously noted, research-validated approaches in reading, mathematics, and social development through intensive (1-to-2) intervention by paraprofessionals for 30 minutes per day in reading and mathematics and thirty minutes per week in both individual and group interventions for social development."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Transforming a Challenged School into an Institute of Excellence
Project Description: "New Jersey City University will partner with the Jersey City Public Schools to address the needs within Martin Luther King Jr, Elementary School where 75% of its students, did not score proficient in both mathematics and language arts on the state assessment. Seven % are students with disabilities, and 19% are ELL. Each year, 300 students will be targeted for direct services. Implementation will be led by a Change Agent (Project Director). IEM embodies three components: (1) Organizational Development (2) Expanded Learning and (3) Family/Parent Engagement. Other partners include: Learning Point Associates (external evaluator), Liberty Science Center, the Jersey City Recreation Dept., The Jersey City Free Public Library, the Boy Scouts, and the African-American Museum. Goals and Objectives: To effectively apply the Institute of Excellence Model (IEM) and turnaround a failing school to an Institute of Excellence; and Validate the IEM."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Arts Improving Math Scores (AIMS)
Project Description: "The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra (NJSO), The Latino Institute of New Jersey, LL Teach Inc., Lakewood Public Schools, and Hewlett-Packard have formed a consortium called Arts Improving Math Scores (AIMS).  The goal of the AIMS program will be to combine each partners strengthens to provide a comprehensive approach to a major restructuring of the Lakewood Public School District.  The AIMS partnership will also conduct an experimental study of music education practices as they impact student math and literacy performance in grades K to 12.  The project targets 2,740 elementary and secondary students in the Lakewood Public School district over 36 months in an effort to reform and revitalize the failing Lakewood school district.  	AIMS will build upon the most successful programs from each of its partners to propose a unique and comprehensive approach to school reform.  This will include music education and instrumental instruction programming from the NJSO with a verifiable record for improving the academic and social outcomes of program participants.  This programming will be combined with a proven approach to math learning from LL Teach called 'Communicator Math.'  It will engage parents and the larger Lakewood community (previously inhibited from participating in their children's education due to a language barrier) with the expertise of the Latino Institute of New Jersey, and provide the technology and IT infrastructure to prepare Lakewood's students for future success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Principal Leadership Development Program
Project Description: "New Leaders for New Schools is applying for a Development grant with the NYC Department of Education as an official partner to develop, implement, evaluate and refine the Principal Leadership Development Program (PLDP). (A second partner LEA will be identified before the grant.) Through program impact and system change, the PLDP will 1) retain and continue to develop highly effective principals; 2) improve the performance of less-effective principals; and 3) become a core component of LEAs' principal effectiveness systems, increasing the number of principals with the knowledge, understanding, and application of leadership practices and actions to lead improvements in teacher effectiveness and student achievement. The PLDP design includes: o	Developing specific rubrics for practices in targeted domains of principal effectiveness that are directly aligned to the districts' evaluation system of principal effectiveness;o	Leveraging digital leadership content of effective principal practices at each rubric level;o	Integrating the rubrics and digital content into a powerful system of mediated, direct development delivery to principals that is driven by their identified needs and that leverages technology to enhance scalability, sustainability, and usefulness.o	Embedding the program model and findings into district partners' principal effectiveness systems, programs and policies (e.g., standards, identification, recruitment, development, compensation, and retention/promotion/dismissal). Over time, the PLDP will serve as a scalable, sustainable model for individualized, job-embedded principal development that LEAs nationwide can use as they revise their principal effectiveness systems, moving principals to improved performance and student success. The PLDP will serve 61,650 students by grant-end; its impact on district systems potentially could reach all principals and students in the partner LEAs (including 1.1 million NYC DOE students)."

Project Title: The New and Aspiring Principal Effectiveness Strategy
Project Description: "The New Leaders for New Schools (NLNS) mission is to ensure high academic achievement for every student by attracting, preparing, and supporting outstanding leaders. Our vision is that one day every student will graduate high school prepared for success in college, career, and citizenship. Our research-validated New and Aspiring Principals Effectiveness Strategy (NAPES) is breaking new ground with dramatic improvements in school performance. NAPES has three components:1)	Recruiting, selecting, training, and supporting aspiring and new principals2)	Data-driven research and evaluation to drive continuous improvement of our program in order to spread what's driving dramatic achievement gains in pockets to much greater scale3)	District alignment to create conditions in which well-selected, well-trained principals have the aligned accountability, context, and meaningful support needed to succeedFor Investing in Innovation (i3), NLNS is applying for a Validation grant in official partnership with Baltimore City Public Schools, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, Oakland Unified School District, and the Recovery School District in New Orleans to address Absolute Priority 1 and Competitive Preference Priority 8. Other partners include Chicago Public Schools, Prince George's County Public Schools, Memphis City Schools, Jefferson Parish School District, the New York City Department of Education, and District of Columbia Public Schools.Our goals are: (1) expand NAPES's scale; (2) validate NAPES's impact; (3) create and disseminate research; and (4) demonstrate capacity for greater scale and sustainability. This project will scale NAPES to directly impact and substantially increase achievement for over 100,000 additional students by the end of the grant period, which would in just five years nearly double the number of K-8 students directly impacted by New Leaders principals today. NAPES will also create an actionable knowledge base on how to create nimble learning organization"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Elev8 New Mexico: An innovative approach to full-service community schools as
a model for turning around low performing schools.
Project Description: "The New Mexico Community Foundation (NMCF) seeks to further develop Elev8, its full service communityschools model, as a targeted innovation under Absolute Priority #4 of the Investing in Innovation program.Currently, Elev8 is a nationally implemented community schools model that integrates extended learning,school-based health and a range of family support and engagement activities. NMCF proposed to refine its Elev8model to serve as a targeted strategy for turning around persistently low-performing schools. The goal of Elev8is to remove barriers to learning by (1) providing rich and rigorous extended learning opportunities for allstudents; (2) integrating comprehensive school-based health care; and (3) coordinating a range of familyengagement activities and social supports.
