The hypothesis is that a community schools model that (a) buildscapacity to leverage limited resources and partnerships, (b) is culturally competent with regard to NativeAmerican and Hispanic populations, and (c) integrates closely with the school instructional program is a viableand durable approach to school improvement and will yield significant student outcomes."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: New Mexico i3 Rural Project
Project Description: "The Center for the Education and Study of Diverse Populations' proposed project will serve 5700 mid and high school students from 5 districts (12 schools that are located on or near tribal lands and serve Native American students). The schools also serve high percentages of rural Hispanics and English language learners. CESDP's official partner is the LEA, Grants-Cibola County School District, with whom CESDP has worked for 4 years. The project will support the state's efforts to implement high quality standards and assessments, support college access and readiness, advance the effectiveness of teaching and leading, and increase the success of minority students in advanced classes. The project will focus on teacher professional development and coaching for all teachers in the areas of culturally competent teaching and curriculum design, extending the use of academic language and thinking, sheltered instruction strategies for English Language Learners, Advancement Via Individual Determination (AVID) college-readiness strategies, school/family partnerships, and intervention approaches for low performing students. The program objectives are to expand efforts to increase the success of high-need, rural, minority students, especially Native American students, in academically rigorous courses and programs that prepare them for college and careers, increase the development and use of formative assessments or other performance-based metrics by teachers and leaders, increase teachers' abilities to translate standards and information from assessments into highly effective classroom practices."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: New Mexico Regional i3 Rural Collaborative Project
Project Description: "The Center for the Education and Study of Diverse Populations  at New Mexico Highlands University proposes a project that will support the state's efforts to implement high quality standards and assessments, support college access and readiness, advance the effectiveness of teaching and leading, and increase the success of minority students in advanced classes in a consortium of New Mexico's rural secondary schools with high concentrations of English Language Learners, Hispanics, and Native Americans. Project staff will work with each school to form school-based i3 teams and begin the planning phase by collecting and analyzing data and forming an action plan. The implementation phase will include expanding the use of high-quality, college- and career-ready assessments such as ACT, EXPLORE and PLAN;  providing professional development for teachers in the use of assessment data to inform instruction; aligning curriculum and assessments with Common Core standards; and implementing Advancement Via Individual Determination (AVID) and sheltered instruction strategies. The project will also support AP  training for  teachers and a statewide Leaders Network.The project objective is to work with the state to expand and replicate a successful model that improves students' access to and success in college and careers. The expected outcomes include increasing minority students' access to and success in advanced courses, implementing college and career ready assessments to inform  instruction, improving teacher and leader efficacy through professional development, and creating an e-network of rural teachers and  leaders who share resources, curricula, and best practices that work in rural schools."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: New Orleans Learning Supports Initiative (NOLA LSI)
Project Description: "Schools in New Orleans are serving students who score well below basic levels of academic performance and who also bring high levels of mental distress into the classroom. Causes for this mental distress include the lingering effects of trauma from Katrina and its aftermath, difficult home lives, learning disabilities, grief and trauma due to high rates of violence in the city, and poverty. Recognizing that these challenges need to be addressed in order for schools to be successful, the New Orleans Learning Supports Initiative proposes to implement a comprehensive and integrated model of learning supports and school readiness in seven low-performing schools, targeting over 2,800 students.  Our approach is supported by a growing body of research that demonstrates that academic learning improves when students' social and emotional needs are met.  Our learning supports model is based on the model created by Adelman and Taylor, and builds on two years of work in implementing learning supports in Langston Hughes Academy Charter School (an official partner on this grant), with good success. Our project has three goals: Implement and refine our Learning Supports and school readiness model in six new schools; Establish a 'Learning Supports Institute' to train teachers and social workers to lead Learning Supports initiatives in new schools; and Create a constituency of schools willing to implement Learning Supports to ensure scalability of the project. Anticipated outcomes include: improved student academic performance; improved school attendance rates; reduced disciplinary referrals; improved teacher capacity to foster the social, emotional, and intellectual development of all students; and identification of additional schools to implement the learning supports modelThe partners in this project - New Orleans Outreach, Children's Bureau, Langston Hughes Academy, and Institute for Mental Hygiene - have considerable experience working on these issues and working together "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Scaling The New Orleans Charter Restart Model
Project Description: "This project will take an innovative model of education reform developed in New Orleans and spread it to otherurban school districts struggling to turn around failing schools. The heart of this model lies in building thepermanent infrastructure and capacity to replace persistently low-performing schools with charter restartsexecuted by high-performing charter organizations. With the support of a five-year i3 Validation Grant, theproject partners will be able to expand capacity in New Orleans to turn around the bottom 5% of failingschools each year, and then replicate this model in Memphis and Nashville ? creating the foundation forlonger-term scale-up to other districts serving high-need students across the nation. To make this aspiration areality, New Schools for New Orleans (NSNO) has partnered with Louisiana?s Recovery School District(RSD) and Tennessee?s Achievement School District (ASD). The primary grant activity will be sub-grantingfunds to high-performing charter operators to execute school turnarounds through the charter restart model.Only those operators with a robust, quasi-experimental data-backed performance will be funded to replicate.To augment supply of high quality charter operators, NSNO and ASD will incubate new CMOs, and to ensurethis quality standard is being upheld, RSD and ASD will provide the crucial turnaround infrastructure. Thisenhanced infrastructure, combined with expanded charter operator capacity, will ensure that strongturnarounds are the consistent course of action when a school is persistently low performing."

Project Title: Expanding and Replicating a High-Impact  School Turnaround Model
Project Description: "Chronically failing schools and the academic achievement gaps they perpetuate rob too many students of a greateducation and the opportunity to succeed in college and beyond. The Mastery model offers a unique, exceptionaland highly successful approach to turn around chronically low-performing schools. Over the next 5 years,Mastery and the project partners will replicate Mastery?s innovative model to turn around 34 chronically lowperformingschools serving 17,850 high-need students. This project will also codify, validate and disseminatebest practices to inform a broader stakeholder audience.This project expands the work of Mastery itself, replicating its model in 11 additional schools; supports thedevelopment of a School Turnaround Academy to codify and train others on the turnaround model; and providesintensive support to 3 emerging turnaround organizations, ReNEW Schools, UP Schools, and ScholarAcademies, to implement the Mastery model in 23 failing schools, thereby expanding the universe of effectiveschool turnaround operators. Under the leadership of NewSchools Venture Fund, the project will disseminatebest practices to a broad network of policy-makers, funders, education leaders, and education entrepreneurs.This country is desperate for solutions for our chronically failing schools. This project provides a model and apath forward towards a quality education for all."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Building the Supply of No Excuses Schools for the Nation
Project Description: "A new school model, commonly called ?No Excuses,? is one of the highest-impact innovations servinghigh-need, low-income students. These schools are specifically designed to operate in communities with largenumbers of failing schools, in order to close the achievement gap and prepare students for success in college.Three of the country?s leading No Excuses school operators are Uncommon Schools, KIPP NYC, andAchievement First, collectively known as UKA. These non-selective public charter school networks share acore set of practices, systems, and operating conditions that are producing extraordinary results and providingexcellent educational alternatives in grades K through 12 for communities where students would otherwise betrapped in chronically underperforming schools.Over five years, this proposal seeks to increase enrollment in UKA schools by over 17,000 students in NewYork, New Jersey, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Massachusetts ? thereby tripling the number of high-needchildren reached by their No Excuses schools. At the same time, the partners to this proposal will distill andevaluate this innovation?s highest leverage elements and disseminate them for even broader impact. UKA andtheir network of schools plan to achieve these objectives through a partnership with Teacher U andNewSchools Venture Fund. Teacher U, a nonprofit joint-venture of UKA grounded in the No Excuses model,will provide the pipeline of teachers necessary for the replication of No Excuses schools. NewSchoolsVenture Fund, a nonprofit grant-making organization, helped to create the nation?s first charter managementorganizations (CMOs) and remains a leading funder of high-impact education organizations serving high-needstudents. New Schools Venture Fund will provide strategic expansion guidance to the UKA No Excusesnetworks, support the capture and dissemination of knowledge, and ensure the success of the project."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: New Teacher Center-Launching the Next Generation of Effective Educators
Project Description: "New Teacher Center: Launching the Next Generation of Effective EducatorsThe New Teacher Center (NTC) and its official partners, six high-need urban and rural local educational agencies(LEAs)-District of Columbia Public Schools, Austin Independent School District (TX), Grant Wood AreaEducation Agency (IA), Palm Beach County Public Schools (FL), East Side Union High School District (CA),and Alum Rock Union Elementary School District (CA)-seek a Validation grant under Absolute Priority 1 (andCompetitive Preference Priority 8). NTC meets the grant's eligibility criteria and, with its partners, will addressPriority 1: identify, recruit, develop, place, reward, and retain effective teachers. NTC will replicate, scale, and validate its innovative, two-year teacher induction and full-release mentoring program, to be implemented within the context of broader teacher policy reforms. LEAs will expand and improve their induction programs to meet the highest standards of assessment, quality, data analysis, and accountability to increase student achievement. NTC will help strengthen its partners' capabilities on all elements of Priority 1. LEAs will participate in one of the following communities of practice based on their progress on reform efforts: Leaders, Developing Leaders, or Emerging Leaders in Teacher Effectiveness.The objectives of this grant are to increase student achievement, teacher effectiveness, and teacher retention, andto create permanent capacity within LEAs to lead teacher effectiveness efforts. The project will serve 180,000 K-12 students and 2,000 new and experienced K-12 teachers, with a primary focus on poor and minority students, English language learners, children with disabilities, and students in rural communities. SRI International, a well-respected evaluation organization, will conduct an independent evaluation of NTC's comprehensive model to show its impact on teacher effectiveness and student achievement.  "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: New Visions for Public Schools, Inc
Project Title: Virtual Learning Initiative
Project Description: "New Visions for Public Schools, the Digital Youth Network and Remix Learning propose the Virtual LearningInitiative, a project designed to fulfill the promise of the digital revolution by leveraging an existingtechnology platform and further developing it to design, test, and disseminate a model for teaching andlearning in New York City high schools that is aligned with the skills students need to be successful in the 21stcentury.In its first three years, VLI will fully develop a format, an online delivery platform, and an initial set of high-qualitycurriculum units that fulfill the promise of online learning and support genuine adoption of rigorousstandards for college and career readiness. At the same time, the project will build the capacity of participatingteachers to deliver this new model by engaging them in a collaborative process to develop the platform andmaterials in year one, test and refine them in year 2, and expand their use in year three. We propose toimplement and evaluate VLI in ten high schools in New York City, beginning with the 9th grade and scalingup to additional grades during and after the grant period.The overarching goals of the Virtual Learning Initiative are: first, to design a challenge-based educational modelthat enables students to engage in authentic, rigorous, interdisciplinary learning experiences; and second, toenable delivery of that model through a web-based platform, creating a learning environment that is media-rich,participatory, highly customizable based on embedded assessment data, and scalable."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: New Visions for Public Schools, Inc.
Project Title: New Visions' Teacher Certification Initiative
Project Description: "New Visions? School-based Teacher Preparation Initiative (TPI) will build upon two existing programs, the Urban Teacher Residency (UTR), a partnership with Hunter College that prepares new teachers in high-need areas; and the Scaffolded Apprenticeship Model (SAM), a partnership with Baruch College that prepares new school leaders to lead school reform. In both models, the majority of learning takes place at the school rather than in university classrooms. TPI is the next evolution of this work - a teacher preparation program that is focused on moving student achievement across schools. Through a new initiative about to be piloted in New York State, New Visions will apply to become a graduate-level teacher preparation provider, leveraging our close relationship with schools to develop a new teacher preparation model that pairs aspiring teachers and experienced mentor teachers within a school. Teacher cohorts at each school will examine student data and develop interventions to improve student performance. New Visions will work with the New York State Board of Regents to certify and grant Master's degrees to up to 124 new math, science, special education and English as a second language teachers over the next five years. Only candidates who can demonstrate impact on student performance will become teachers. Program graduates are required to teach in high-need New York City schools for four years."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: New Visions for Public Schools, Inc.
Project Title: New Visions' Charter School Initiative
Project Description: "One of the most important challenges facing our nation is the ability of public schools to prepare students, particularly traditionally underserved students, to graduate from high school and succeed in college and careers in the 21st-century global economy. Nobody has demonstrated a solution at scale?with one exception: New Visions for Public Schools in partnership with the New York City Department of Education. Our flagship enterprise, the New Century High School Initiative (NCHSI)?through which we created 99 small effective schools to replace large, failing schools?resulted in externally validated gains in student achievement and graduation rates for students, the vast majority who entered high school severely underprepared. Moreover, NCHSI launched NYC?s broader successful small schools creation effort to address low performing schools, impacting the system of 1.1 million students. We now seek to start and manage additional new schools as part of the city?s effort to turn around low-performing schools and broadly disseminate our model.Our approach:1)Apply lessons learned from NCHSI to a charter school and charter management organization model, creating 10,800 new high school seats in New York City, with a focus on the common core standards, new types of assessments, inquiry and imaginative learning through a partnership with the Lincoln Center Institute.2)As part of the New Visions charter model, further refine our approach to ?inquiry? to develop educator capacity to use data and student work to identify learning needs; design, implement and test instructional and systemic changes; and continually improve their methods based on a detailed understanding of the needs of students.3)Disseminate the model and components across NYC, states and district networks through NYCDOE, Lincoln Center Institute, the Annenberg Institute and the Public Education Network."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Regional Partnership for High Performing Community Charter Schools
Project Description: "Regional Partnership for High Performing Community Charter SchoolsThe promise of the charter schools were three fold; they would increase student performance, serve at risk students and families, and ultimately serve as the research and development arm of the traditional public schools, filtering back innovative and effective practices.  Unfortunately when the data is reviewed, the record of success is mixed at best.  The Regional Partnership (RP) will address structural deficiencies in the charter school 'market' leading to more and better charter schools, explicitly taking on the demand side in empowering parent to make better choices, and finally will seek to identify, through the use of data, effective practices in charter schools and disseminate them out to the entire education sector.  The RP will initially launch in NYC and will add new sites each year to two years dependent on demand and capacity of new site partners. Project Activities for the RP will include: (1) New school incubator and startup support, (2) Human capital sourcing and development in key areas- Instruction, management, finance, operations, and governance, (3) Early stage replication support for high quality schools, (4) Data-based identification and dissemination of effective practices, (5) Family empowerment through provision of better and more digestible information delivered to parents by parents.The RP will have an intense and unwavering commitment to the systematic collection, analysis and use of data across stakeholder groups.  This data will be used to help families make better choices, help boards understand and manage school performance, school leaders adjust and target instruction, and researchers to identify and analyze best practices, helping to peer into the black box of effective schools and disseminate effective practices to the traditional public schools in a positive and supportive way."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: New York City Outward Bound Center, Inc.
Project Title: Great Teachers, Great Leaders
Project Description: "The Great Teachers, Great Leaders project builds off of the successful work New York City Outward Bound has done in establishing a Network of college preparatory Expeditionary Learning schools it operates in NYC. The project is a partnership between NYC Outward Bound and a consortium of its nine Network schools and a 10th school approved to open and join the Network in Septmeber 2010.  The project focuses on strengthening the extensive package of services and supports provided to Network teachers and principals in the areas of recruitment, training, coaching, incentives/rewards, and assessment. This package of services and supports is helping to give Network teachers and principals the tools and approaches they need to bring out the best in all their students. The project will result in a significant expansion of this Network, with the number of students served by Network schools expected to more than double during the grant period. It includes a rigorous evaluation component, using a quasi-experimental design, as well as a number of activities aimed at documenting and disseminating practices that prove to be particularly effective in supporting high quality teaching, strong school leadership and improving student outcomes."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: PEARLS: Partnerships for Educational Attainment and Relevant Learning in Science
Project Description: "The New York Hall of Science (NYSCI) will lead a five-year project that will build partnerships between schools within the New York City Department of Education Integrated Curriculum and Instruction Learning Support Organization (ICI) network and two other nonprofits to increase student achievement in STEM courses and standardized tests; increase graduation rates; increase rates of college acceptance; and increase interest in STEM subjects. Working with three cohorts of 36 at-risk, urban high school students, the PEARLS project will engage students in a comprehensive set of apprentice-based and in-school experiences. Activities will be aligned with New York State STEM standards and will be designed to foster creative approaches to STEM learning and support the development of collaboration, communication, and critical thinking skills. Each cohort will participate in an apprenticeship beginning in the fall of their 9th grade year and lasting three years, and they will receive $8,000 in stipends for dedicated participation. At NYSCI, apprentices will be exposed to inquiry-based science experiences, and then guided through opportunities to design interactive learning carts for science center visitors and co-develop/co-teach STEM lessons to younger peers. High school success and college readiness workshops will be provided by the network of schools within ICI, and participants will be required to attend. Drawing from the expertise of Jacob Burns Film Center (JBFC), participants will become versed in the technical and creative use of media and digital technology through summer projects that complement other apprenticeship activities. An external evaluation, conducted by Learning Point Associates, will consist of formative and summative studies to measure PEARLS' progress, performance, and intended outcomes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Broader, Bolder Approach (BBA)
Project Description: "The Metropolitan Center for Urban Education in the Steinhardt School of Culture, Education and Human Development at New York University in partnership with six school districts (Christina School District - Wilmington, DE; Newark Public Schools - Newark, NJ; Cortland Enlarged School District - Cortland, NY; Somerville School District - Somerville, MA; Philadelphia School District - Philadelphia, PA; Woodlawn Promise Zone Schools - Chicago, IL) proposes a three year I3 development grant to develop an innovation zone within each school districts where the Broader Bolder Approach (BBA) will be implemented. Metro Center-BBA is the enactment of three reform efforts: a) implementation and utilization of a data platform for informing core instructional programs and interventions; b) development of community schools that provide health and social services to students and also serve as laboratories for professional development of new and experienced teachers; and c) development of an innovation zone in which typical labor agreements and contracts are waived in order to extend school day and year, and create greater flexibility in teaching and learning assignments. The premise of Metro Center-BBA is to establish a stewardship of core principles within each district on how teaching, learning and fairness should engage social and academic needs in order to change the trajectory of our most vulnerable populations. These principles guiding educational reform will include investing in the whole child, serving as guardians of educational equity, and preparing for a future of wellness. Our approach responds to Absolute Priority 2 - Innovations that Improve the Use of Data as well as address Competitive Preference Priority 6 - Innovations that Support College Access and Success; and Competitive Preference Priority 8 - Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEAs.  "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: SIGMA-Simulations and Games with Embedded Assessment for Middle School Mathematics
Project Description: "The Games for Learning Institute proposes a five-year project to develop and test a series of computer-based simulations and minigames for integration into the grade 6 mathematics curriculum that are tied to NY State math standards. This work will address absolute priority #3 of the i3 RFA (Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments), as well as preference priorities 6 (college access) and 8 (schools in rural areas) and will be based on evidence from our previous research with simulations and games, conducted by the investigators over the last five years. In order to support teachers in successfully implementing the simulations and games into their classrooms, we will develop and test curricular materials for integration of each simulation and game, and will develop an online professional development course for middle school math teachers to guide them in the successful use of the materials. The design of the simulations and minigames will include embedded assessments to provide teachers with rich learning process and outcome data that they will be able to view in a web-based portal.Simulations and games will be evaluated using classroom observations, user logs, quasi-experiments, and experiments to test specific features of their design, and, based on this evaluation data, will be refined and revised. In addition, an independent evaluator will carry out a formative efficacy trial in year 3 (N=450) that will provide log-based process data, standardized test data, as well as interview and survey data that can be used to further refine and revise the sims and games. A summative evaluation in year 5 (N=600) will provide efficacy data for the sims and games that can be used as a basis to scale up. Evaluations will be conducted with populations that include high-need students with low socio-economic status and from ethnic and racial minority groups as well as ELL students, in urban and rural schools."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: New York University School of Medicine
Project Title: Promoting Academic Growth Among High-Need Students: ParentCorps/TeacherCorps
Project Description: "This Validation initiative, a partnership between the New York University Child Study Center and the New YorkCity Department of Education, addresses Absolute Priority 1 through the implementation and evaluation ofParentCorps/TeacherCorps, an exceptional approach to helping principals to close the achievement gap forlow-income, minority students by facilitating successful transitions to school and promoting opportunities forlearning in the early grades. A well-designed and well-implemented randomized controlled trial providesevidence that the program has a significant, substantial and important effect on student growth whicheffectively reduces the achievement gap for urban, minority students by 40% to 60%. This Validation initiativerepresents the final step toward fully establishing the evidence base prior to scaling-up to serve diversecommunities throughout NYC and at the state and regional levels.ParentCorps/TeacherCorps is a highly innovative multi-component program to improve student academic growthamong high-need students by supporting elementary school principals to implement strategies that reducebehavior problems in the classroom and increase family engagement during early childhood: 1) PrincipalLeadership Consultation to establish the foundation for successful and sustained implementation; 2)TeacherCorps Professional Development and Consultation to foster effective collaboration with parents andclassrooms that promote learning; 3) ParentCorps Parents as Partners events and Family Groups to engageparents in education and to promote social, emotional, and behavioral development.This project will evaluate the program in schools serving black and Latino populations. The evaluation includes arandomized controlled trial in 32 schools to assess impact, and comparisons involving 8 additional schools toinform the approach to scale-up."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: New York Youth At Risk, Inc.
Project Title: World Leaders
Project Description: "YAR as the applicant for an i3 (Investing in Innovations) development grant plans to partner with a consortium of schools, Paul Robeson High School and Boys and irls High School, that will act collaboratively to turn around their status as consitently low-performing schools in corrective action.  Kaplan, Inc. will be another official partner for this program and Hunter School od Social Work will be another partner (nonofficial).  We will be addressing Absolute Priority 4b and Competitive Preference Priority 6 though this program.??.Truncated"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Building Bridges From Academic Engagement to College Access and Completion (Bridges Project)
Project Description: "The purpose of the Bridges Project is to introduce higher academic standards to high school students whilepromoting college access and success through the use of higher education and business partners. The project proposes to engage the business community in promoting academic rigor, to target college access programming linked with academic rigor and success, and to create a unique K-20 Educational Consortium to develop core competencies and high academic expectations.  Activities will include a diverse range of college access events, college mini-fairs for rural high schools, trainings and activities targeted at underserved high school students. Access conventions will be held in underserved regions promoting peer-to-peer student panels promoting access and student success.  NH College & University Council will coordinate the Bridges Project. A systematic change in NH's thinking about academic rigor, curriculum content and college access and success will occur during the grant period.  Increase NH's college going rates from 59% to 69% and build on-going collaboration and understanding between K-12 and college faculty regarding common academic expectations.  381,742 of NH high school students will participate in college access activities delivered by the Bridges Project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Teachers for the Future
Project Description: "Niagara Falls City School District, in collaboration with Niagara University and three other area school districts, proposes to implement a validation grant to further evaluate the impact of a professional development model developed by the District and Niagara University that supports effective teachers and administrators and ultimately will lead to improved student achievement.  The project, Expanding Teacher Quality, will be implemented over five years and will include the following key activities:o	Identification and training of instructional coaches and content specialists in science, technology and mathematics to serve each collaborating school district.o	Creation of teacher leaders in every district who are prepared to support ongoing implementation following the grant period and can provide turnkey training to new teachers in other buildings and new teachers hired in the District.o	 Establishment of a cadre of teaching professionals with Master's Degrees in Math, Science and Technology (MST), a degree program created by Niagara University to prepare teachers to integrate these subjects into core subject areas.o	Creation of professional learning communities within each district and among participating districts, to share effective practices.o	Provision of job-embedded professional development, provided by instructional coaches, to support ongoing implementation of the program and assist teachers to address challenges to implementation and increased student achievement.Student outcome objectives include increasing the percentage of grade 3-5 students achieving grade-level competency in math and science, and increasing the achievement of students of treatment teachers in grades 3-5 of underachieving NCLB sub-groups by 5% annually."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: 1:1 Laptop Initiative to Enhancing Student Achievement through Improving Standards Operationalization, Curriculum Alignment, and Assessment
Project Description: "Following the highly successful 1 to 1 learning initiative introduced six years ago in conjunction with the Michigan Freedom to Learn Initiative at Oak Manor 6th grade Center in Niles Community Schools, Niles, Michigan, we seek to address our continuity issue by continuing the project through the 12th grade and making 1 to 1 learning our standard educational practice.  Our Oak Manor experience has proven we are expert at this practice - we have continually and graphically demonstrated that we can close learning gaps between subgroups and majorioty students while imrpoving achievement for all students.  This is demonstrated on our Michigan Eaducational Assessment Program (MEAP) scores in all of our subgroups, on all tests.  Oak Manor school has been named a Michigan Technology Showcase school, and we have demonstrated our ability to work with private funding sources, a group of foundation partners who paid for the renewal of the project two years ago at Oak Manor. These foundations have committed to support the match for the project.   We have supported our application with extensive research proving the efficacy of 1 to 1 learning in closing achievement gaps, and have entered into a partnership with Western Michigan University to ensure fidelity of implemementation, quality of professional development, and validation of our results leading to scalability to the state and national levels."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Northeast Tennessee College and Career Ready Consortium
Project Description: "The Niswonger Foundation is partnering with 15 local education agencies in Appalachia to establish the Northeast Tennessee College and Career Ready Consortium.  Partner LEAs include Bristol Tennessee City Schools, Carter County Schools, Cocke County School System, Elizabethton Tennessee City Schools, Greene County Schools, Greeneville City Schools, Hamblen County Schools, Hancock County Public Schools, Hawkins County Schools, Johnson City Schools, Johnson County Schools, Kingsport City Schools, Sullivan County Department of Education, Unicoi County School System, and Washington County School District.  The Consortium plans to expand access to rigorous courses by: (1) creating a regional coordinating body that will analyze course supply and demand in the region and determine courses needs; (2) scaling up local promising practices to offer more rigorous courses, including distance and online learning, Advanced Placement, and dual enrollment; and (3) providing new resources on college preparedness, access, and application processes via college counselors.  Key objectives over the five-year grant period include: (1) offering an additional 45,646 seats in rigorous courses to high school students in the region, with an additional 15,804 seats in these courses being provided annually after the grant ends; (2) ensuring that by 2013-14 at least 10% of students in the region graduate from high school with a full year of college credits, and an additional 20% of high school students graduate with at least half a year of credit; and (3) increasing the region's college enrollment and persistence rates by at least 10% by 2014-15.  To ensure sustainability, LEAs will have incorporated over 80% of the grant costs into their annual operating budgets by 2014-15.  The Consortium has a strong set of state and national partners that will help scale the grant in two other regions of the state beginning in 2013-14 if the project proves successful."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Curriculum and Assessment Program
Project Description: "The Noble Network of Charter Schools Curriculum and Assessment Program (CAP) provides consistent language around standards; common student assessments; and a platform to share best practices at Noble?s campuses, a consortium larger than most US school districts. It impacts the relationship between teachers, students and curriculum and provides a platform for accelerated change. The CAP aligns teaching to college-readiness skills and uses data from regular student assessments for sharing of teaching best practices. The program includes: quarterly student assessments built and revised by Noble teachers; professional development after assessments for all teachers; and professional development at Noble campuses. Short-term outcomes are academic achievement, teacher improvement and college readiness skills and long-term outcomes are high school graduation, college matriculation and college graduation."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Improving Teaching Effectiveness in the Chicago Public Schools through Data-Driven Instruction
Project Description: "In the proposed grant, the non-profit applicant NOCTI will partner with the Chicago Public Schools (CPS). The proposed activities involve providign externally-validated, industry-specific, standardized assessments to all Career and Technical Educations (CTE) programs citywide by the end of the five year cycle, and to provide, in parallel, extensive professional development on data-driven instruction and use of assessment data to all 330 CTE teachers. It is expected that this project wil improve instruction to approximately 25,000 CPS students each year, which in turn should yield more students earning industry certifications, completing their programs, earning college credit while in high school and eventually enrolling in post-secondary education, and moving on to succesful careers.This project will directly increase CPS CTE high school students' likelihood of college and career success. Approximately 25% of CPS high school students participate  in CTE programs, and CTE well implemented across the nation has proven to reduce dropout rates and to enhance students' college enrollment, employment, and earnings levels. CTE courses provide industry-focused instruction and information around how to progress through college and career pathways - including 2 and 4 year colleges - related to those courses, led by instructors who are knowledgeable adults with specific information about those career pathways and about how entry-level jobs in these pathways can provide the earnings that make college affordable. The NOCTI assessments and associated professional development on data-driven instruction will in turn increase students' likelihook of success in their CTE coursework. CTE also integrates core academic concepts in its curriculum; thus, the assessments and professional development work done in CTE programs will have a positive impact on the core academic achievement required for college entrance and success, as well."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Investing in Innovation Fund (i3)
Project Description: "Strengthening Instruction in Rural Virginia Elementary Schools:Focus on Mathematics (SIRVES-M)AbstractNorfolk State University (NSU), Virginia State University (VSU) and Educational Testing Service (ETS), have formed a consortium with Franklin City Schools, Hopewell City Schools, and Northampton County Schools to develop and implement a five-year professional development program focusing on improving mathematics instruction. Together, we aim to strengthen instruction in mathematics at the K-4 level by working with Historically Black College and University (HBCU) professors in mathematics education, HBCU pre-service teachers, and in-service teachers in partner rural, low performing elementary schools. All elementary schools in this consortium are identified as Title I Schools. The proposed program, Strengthening Instruction in Rural Virginia Elementary Schools: Focus on Mathematics (SIRVES-M), provides two-week Summer Mathematics Institutes, Saturday Math Workshops, training in ETS observation and formative assessment protocols, summer math camps for students and their parents, and implementation of Professional Learning Communities. Together these activities offer the newest thinking in professional development for mathematics education and for standards-based instruction aimed at increasing teachers? mathematics content knowledge and pedagogy. The specific objectives of this project are: 1) to improve mathematics content knowledge and pedagogy among K-4 teachers in Virginia?s HBCU partner elementary schools; 2) to improve the mathematics proficiency of K-4 students of teachers in participating schools; and 3) to re-examine and strengthen HBCU teacher training curriculum in mathematics education. The ultimate goal of this project is to improve the teaching and learning of mathematics in the identified economically disadvantaged elementary schools in order that they reach and maintain yearly Virginia State?s accreditation in mathematics."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Comprehensive District Reform to Turn Around Low-Performing Schools
Project Description: "The Normandy Public School District in St. Louis, Missouri has embarked upon a comprehensive effort to turn around the performance of all 11 of its schools, including two schools that the State of Missouri identified as 'persistently low achieving.'  This proposal will accelerate and deepen those efforts across the 5,000 student district in ways that increase college access and success.  This comprehensive approach will change leaders and the nature of leadership in the district's schools; improve the nature, focus, and quality of instruction; and the increase the extent to which students, parents, teachers, and support staff commit to the work of improving learning results.  The project will yield improved learning results, first through the district's new rigorous benchmark assessments that are carefully aligned to state standards.  Ultimately, the project will yield improved learning as evidenced by improved scores on the Missouri Assessment Program examinations, increased percentages of students taking the ACT, improved composite ACT scores, increased credit accrual rates, and reduced dropout rates. The proposal builds upon a partnership established two years ago between the district's new leadership team and the National Center for Urban School Transformation, an entity that identifies, studies, and promotes the best practices of high-performing urban schools and districts.  Through this proposal we will advance our efforts to make the Normandy School District the first predominantly Black district in Missouri to evidence achievement results that exceed state averages."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: North American Council for Online Learning
Project Title: Student Online Learning Leaders
Project Description: "Student Online Learning Leaders (SOLL, pronounced ?soul?). SOLL?s exceptional approach willprovide a model where a team of 10 to 15 secondary school students will be a school?s foundation forproviding support for online learning to both teachers and their high-need peers. SOLL is not yourtypical bring a group of teachers into an ?innovative? workshop and watch the students learn strategy.SOLL will prepare all stakeholders, including secondary school students to ensure they utilize onlinelearning in ways that improve academic achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: LPP-Sync Algebra Readiness: A Diagnostic and Targeted Intervention System
Project Description: "Title: LPP-Sync?Algebra Readiness: A Diagnostic and Targeted Intervention SystemType of Grant Requested: DevelopmentTarget number of students to be served in the project: 760Official Partners: North Carolina State University, Sampson County Schools (NC LEA).Other Partners: Digital Millennial Consulting; Horizon Research, Inc.The LPP-Sync?Algebra Readiness project addresses a critical need: to increase the success of underrepresented student populations in academically rigorous mathematics courses. The project develops and implements a technologically-based interactive diagnostic assessment system built on empirically validated learning trajectories and production of learning progress profiles for grades 4-7. All content is aligned with the Common Core Standards (officially adopted in NC) with intensification of rational number and algebraic reasoning. Targeted instructional interventions designed to attract students to STEM fields, are delivered on wireless mobile devices or laptops and facilitate peer-to-peer/mentor mathematical discourse via carefully monitored social networking. Teacher PD improves teacher content and pedagogical practices with formativeassessment; leadership PD improves leaders? support for teachers? use of the system and ensures technological facilitation. The project employs quasi-experimental design with two elementary and middle schools in a highneed rural county in North Carolina to evaluate effects. Measurable outcomes include student achievement, teacher content knowledge, classroom observations, and state-of- the-art data mining capabilities to evaluate longitudinal effectiveness. The technological system is designed for equity of access (nearly-ubiquitous 3G wireless networks; durable, affordable user devices) and promotes scaling due to central hosting, single cloudbased platform, and reliance on frugal device- specific interfaces."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Technology Enhanced Algebra Readiness (TEAR)
Project Description: "The Technology Enhanced Algebra Readiness (TEAR) project addresses a critical need in NC and the nation:improving the mathematics achievement of middle school students so they are better prepared to succeed inAlgebra I, a critical gateway course. This project will validate an approach previously found to have significantimpact on student achievement, teachers? pedagogical content knowledge, and classroom practices in schoolsin rural Maine, through a study conducted in collaboration with the Maine 1:1 Learning Technology Initiative.The TEAR approach makes extensive use of technology, providing an instructional improvement system withdiagnostic assessments combined with software designed to help teachers target instruction while engagingstudents in interactive, inquiry-based activities. Technology is also used to support teacher professionaldevelopment through online workshops, professional learning communities, and virtual recording andreviewing of classroom activities.This project is submitted under Priority 3, Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments, byhelping mathematics teachers transition to the new Common Core Standards and prepare their students forassessments based on those standards. The project also addresses Priority 2, Improving the Use of Data,through a focus on diagnostic assessments, and Competitive Priority 8, through a focus on rural schools.The TEAR project will be based at the Friday Institute for Educational Innovation at the North Carolina StateUniversity (NCSU) College of Education, and will be conducted in collaboration with sixty middle schools inrural areas of North Carolina; Education Development Center, Inc. (EDC), which developed the program to bevalidated; RTI International, which will conduct the project evaluation; the North Carolina Department ofPublic Instruction, which will support implementation and scale-up; and the GoldenLEAF Foundation, whichhas committed the matching funds."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovative Strategies To Develop Math Minds
Project Description: "This development proposal is based on the bed of research that suggests that the skilled use of longitudinal and formative assessment data to inform instruction will significantly improve student achievement.  Teachers will receive support to use an assessment data tracking system to optimize their use of longitudinal assessment data.  Teachers' and students' knowledge, skill, and use of the formative assessment process will improve as a result of the program.  The program will provide instruction and support to implement ELL strategies in the classroom using the Guided Language Acquisition Design (GLAD) model and instruments developed by Marzano Laboratory.  Teachers will use ELL strategies to improve students' academic language proficiency in the math domain.  Teachers in the program will receive operational support from a Mathematics Innovation and Data Specialist (MIDS) to help retrieve and organize assessment data for efficient and effective teacher use.  The five-year program outlined will deliver high-quality professional development to approximately 60 middle-school mathematics teachers in rural North Central Washington.   The collaborative project between North Central Education Service District (NCESD) and ESD 105 in Yakima, Washington will target approximately 4200 students, 25% of whom are Latino English Language Learners (ELL)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Pathways to Success
Project Description: "The Pathways to Success Project is a student-centered, demand-driven innovation launched to proactively adapt to the dynamically changing needs of students, schools, institutions of higher education, and employers. The P-16 strategic plan developed by the group provides a framework that can be used in any secondary school program to promote student engagement in learning, increase learning and academic achievement, and improve graduation rates and entry into postsecondary education.  The project is innovative in that it provides a structured set of courses for each career pathway and leads students to explore certification, associates degree, baccalaureate, and graduate degree options in each area.  The model also utilizes six recommendations from the Institute of Education Sciences Dropout Prevention Guide to provide research-based components that support learning.  Students in the program use problem-solving and decision making skills to map out, monitor, and control their course sequences within each pathway. Incentives in the form of college credit course scholarships earned for meeting academic standards on state assessments provide motivation to apply for, work toward, and realize educational goals.  The innovative Pathways to Success model moves from preparing students for college, to preparing them for college, careers and beyond."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: From country road to the information superhighway: 1:1 Living Textbook for Rural 21st Century Learning and Post-Secondary Success
Project Description: "North Daviess Community Schools (applicant), on behalf of our consortia official partners, Cloverdale Community Schools and Daviess County Economic Development Foundation Incorporated, submit our application for the Investing in Innovation fund grant.  The focus of our grant application is to increase the math proficiency of our 5th through 9th grade students and help them acquire 21st Century Learning Skills though the implementation of a 1:1 'living textbook' initiative and community learning centers.North Daviess Community Schools has a 1:1 'living textbook' initiative at the 9th grade level.  Through implementation of this grant would expand this to 5th through 9th grade and would assist Cloverdale Community Schools in the implementation of the 1:1 'living textbook' initiative.Cloverdale Community Schools has implemented 21st Century Community Learning Centers to extend the learning opportunities for students and the community.  Cloverdale Community Schools will assist North Daviess Community Schools in the implementation of 21st Century Community Learning Centers as part of our Investing in Innovation fund grant.  The project will close the digital divide and improve student achievement in the two school communities by providing 1:1 affordable computer access into the community through the 'living textbook' to allow for anytime, anywhere, anyhow learning. Textbook alternatives will be used to have the students and teachers create content that can be shared globally and not rely upon the textbook companies to provide the content.  The outcome will be higher-order thinking and a more relevant and engaging curriculum to meet state academic math standards.  "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: North Gem "Go On" Project
Project Description: "The North Gem 'Go On' project is designed to build on our phenomenal strength of high graduation rates and low dropout rates by providing rural high school students the courses and support necessary to prepare for, enter, and succeed in college. A college track and counseling to students throughout high school will be provided. Most of the funds requested will be used to create the North Gem Virtual Academy. From this resource students will have access to a wide variety of advanced courses necessary for college preparation but not currently offered in our little rural school."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Renewal of North Greene High School

Applicant: North Mississippi Center for Higher Educational Advancement
Project Title: Investing in Innovation Initiative
Project Description: "The Investing in Innovation Initiative will be one of the vehicles by which NMCHEA commits to studentacademic access and success. NMCHEA will serve Lowndes and Holmes County School Districts ofMississippi under the Absolute Priority 4-Persistantly Low Performing Schools.The project will serve more than 800 students each year in grades 4th-12th. There will be a total of 4,000 studentsfor the five-year grant period. The project and school staff will utilize technology and instructor as a tool ofmanagement in providing project services to student. The project will provide innovative technological supportin programs of reading and instruction in introductory facets of STEM curriculum that will provide academicenrichment. All students will be provided counseling on the importance of continuing their education. Theproject will also provide workshops and seminars to parents on the importance of postsecondary education,postsecondary educational opportunities available, and their role in supporting the project's efforts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Systematic Data-Driven Processes to Increase Achievement for High- Need Students
Project Description: "The importance of data analysis for student learning is strongly evident to all stakeholders in the North Palos School District 117 community. District 117 currently utilizes targeted systems for assessment and effective data analysis. Student achievement data derived from nationally normed and local assessments is examined in order to make instructional decisions based on student needs and ensure that all educators are implementing our standards based curriculum effectively. Data at the school level is reviewed weekly through Professional Learning Communities and quarterly at the school and district levels through the Quality Review Process. The Quality Review process is in place to improve academic achievement for all students.In looking to further develop this process, we are applying for this grant under Absolute Priority 2: Innovations that Improve the Use of Data. Through our current Quality Review process, we recognize that while student achievement overall has risen considerably, we need to narrow our focus to specific learning needs of our students with disabilities, Limited English Proficient students, and the 360 3 and 4 year-old students in our early childhood center.To meet these needs, we are requesting grant funding to implement new data management systems with increased analysis and reporting tools, technology components to allow for online curriculum sharing, training on the effective use of data, expanding for home access to district technology tools for teachers and students, personnel to help implement these programs, as well as funding to permit teachers more time to collaborate on data and strategies for our high-need students. Additionally, we are looking to further implement research-based assessments that will provide us with better information to inform curriculum and instruction. Emphasis will be placed on implementing valid and reliable assessments for English language learners and students with disabilities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Northeast Arkansas i3 Mathematics (NE Ai3M) Initiataive
Project Description: "This five-year quasi-experimental research-based project addresses the issues of high standards by developing videos for schools that target Arkansas Mathematics Standards and Student Learning Expectations in Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry.  High quality assessments are addressed by providing nine-week interim assessments in each of those domains.  Classroom and out-of-classroom practices will be manipulated to examine the use of three levels of technology (none/standard, supplementary video lessons, and lessons downloadable onto iPods) on math learning and achievement.		The NE Ai3M Consortium Project includes the NEA Co-op, Arkansas State University-Jonesboro (the IHE nonprofit organization), 13 Arkansas Education Cooperatives, the Arkansas Science and Technology Authority, and three private sector parties (Apple, Inc., eInstruction, and Data Driven Software Corporation [D2SC]).	OBJECTIVE:  To increase student learning of Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry in Arkansas classrooms. Note that each domain (Algebra I and II, and Geometry) will be tested sequentially and independently across years. Thus, the outcomes apply separately and independently for each domain.		The project will impact approximately 2,500 high school Algebra I, Algebra II and Geometry students across the state of Arkansas.  A high percentage of these students will be high-need students from rural schools and communities."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Environment as an Innovative Integrating Context for Learning
Project Description: "This proposed project engages 7 rural school districts in partnership with a non-profit environmental education organization in professional development and planning for using the environment as an integrating context (EIC) for learning.  This requires a restructuring of curriculum to focus on environmentally related/place based themes for learning reading, writing, math, science and social studies and the use of outdoor learning spaces as a significant part of instructional practices.  Major activities include intensive professional development in using EIC in grade level appropriate practices, collaborative strategic planning among the project management team, school administrators, lead teachers and pilot teachers, assessment and development of outdoor learning spaces and focused implementation that uses formative assessments to guide practice.  The non-profit partner will support implementation with ongoing mentoring, coaching and co-teaching to insure effective implementation among pilot teachers."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Instructional Rounds in Rural Settings: Improved Achievement for High-Need Students
Project Description: "Instructional Rounds in Rural Settings: Improved Achievement for High-Need Students represents a development grant proposed by NorthEast Washington Educational Service District 101 of Spokane, WA, an eligible LEA, on behalf of a consortium that includes Educational Service District 105 of Yakima, WA, 28 rural LEAs serving 13,053 high-need students in Eastern Washington, and the School Improvement Network (a private-sector firm). This project will implement innovations to support effective teachers and principals, and addresses the competitive preference priority for innovations serving rural LEAs.Using a method developed by Harvard scholars, this project will implement Instructional Rounds (IR) to improve teacher and principal effectiveness that will result in improved achievement for high-need students. The following Theory of Action, which represents a reasonable hypothesis, represents the focus: If superintendents, principals and teachers collaborate regularly through a Professional Learning Community to develop the necessary structures and systems to support the instructional core (teachers? knowledge and skills; student engagement; and academically challenging content), then student learning will increase."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovations 101
Project Description: "Based on a promising program from Washington state, a ?missing discipline? of college and career readiness will be introduced to 60,000 students in 100 U.S. high schools. Twenty hours of planning and self-management instruction will be provided in each year of grades 9 ? 12, producing more college and career ready students in participating schools. All students will present their college and career readiness plan and portfolio in a student-led conference every year. Every student?s readiness will be quantified according to grade-specific standards. Off-track students will be identified and remedial services will be provided to put them back ?on-track.? A readiness infrastructure will be developed in each school to manage the continuous improvement and sustainability of the program. This will be accomplished at a cost of $33/student/year."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Making College Real for Chicago High School Students
Project Description: "Making College Real will extend a comprehensive and integrated sequence of services to 1,000 Chicago Public High School students to increase their graduation rate and ultimate success in college.  To accomplish this, the project addresses critical needs identified in the research that places students at risk of educational failure, including low achievement.  This development grant is proposed by Northeastern Illinois University's Chicago Teachers' Center in partnership with the Chicago Public Schools.  This project will engage all stakeholders in a high performance learning community that creates a coordinated system for early intervention through (1) building relational trust; (2) a four-week summer transition program; (3) targeted push-in support and tutoring; (4) drop-out and truancy prevention; (5) credit recovery; (6) college readiness support; and (7) celebrating success.  Our objectives are to: increase time on task and students' proficieny in English, mathematics, and science; improve student attendance rate; decrease student dropout rate; increase ACT scores; increase the rate of high school graduation; increase students' and families' knowledge of college and financial aid options; increase college-going rate; and outreach to students and parents driven by the data that identifies students' needs.  Our outcomes include: increasing annual percentage of completed homework assigments, overall GPA, attendance, and the percent of freshmen students who are on-track to graduate; increasing by at least 20% more students who will receive a composite score of 20 or higher on the ACT; increase overall ACT average by 15%; attaining an 85% or higher graduation rate; ensuring that 85% of cohort seniors will complete the FAFSA and college applications; ensuring that 30% more cohort students will enroll in college; improving communication among the teachers, parents and students measured by pre-post surveys."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Primary Mathematics Intervention Program - 2
Project Description: "Primary Mathematics Intervention Program ? 2The goals of the project are to:? Identify, recruit, develop, reward and retain mathematics teacher-leaders who are capable of building capacity for effective mathematics instruction in their elementary schools and in their districts.? Increase elementary teachers? mathematical and pedagogical content knowledge.? Improve elementary school student achievement in mathematics, with particular emphasis on at-risk students in rural and schools with large percentages of under-performing students.Teachers will participate in a 3-year long, supported, professional development program that consists of activities related to working in one-on-one and small group settings with struggling students in grades K-3, mathematics intervention teaching in K-5 classrooms, team building, and leadership capacity. The target student population is students whose mathematics achievement is substantially below grade-level. The project will build on an existing highly successful intervention program and will lead to significant and substantial gains in the mathematics achievement of these students. Over the course of the project 40,000 students will be reached."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Hand Up
Project Description: "By reconfiguring its 6-8 classrooms, adding a fifth day for middle school activity to a four-day school schedule, that is directed by the Northland Area Family Service Center, Northland Community Schools will lay the foundations and build momentum for academic competence by closing the achievement gap, as well as build the self-esteem and competence students need to succeed. The highest quality teachers will share a common vision, work as a team to create a dynamic learning community, be knowledgeable about adolescent development and know how to build meaningful connections with parents. These teachers will be assured professional development opportunities and the assistance of a curriculum specialist so they can create a rigorous, challenging curriculum that is cross-disciplinary, research-based and addresses the state standards and beyond within a safe, respectful and nurturing environment. Their efforts will be complemented by in-school and after-school activities that provide academic enrichment, parent activities, socialization opportunities and community engagement. Both school and Family Center activities will be coordinated.The middle school, in its four core subjects - language arts, math, science and social studies - will be taught across the curriculum and be linked to real world situations, some of which can be provided by the Family Center.  A special education teacher will be part of the teaching team and her students an integral part of classrooms where their achievements will be celebrated. The pod system creates small communities where the same student group remains together through three middle school grades to alleviate the stress caused by the profound physical, emotional and mental changes of puberty. The students build connections not available at home and home connections through Family Center programming. This distinct learning environment will improve student aachievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Getting Ready To Learn
Project Description: "The Northwest Arctic Borough School District (NWABSD) is a public school which operates as a Local Educational Agency (LEA) under the auspices of the State of Alaska Department of Education. The NWABSD serves eleven Inupiaq communities of remote Northwest Alaska. The NWABSD proposes to develop a five year/60 month kindergarten through third grade (K-3) literacy program based on the success of a quasi-experimental study named Getting Ready to Learn (GRTL). The GRTL experiment was conducted from 2004 to 2007 and produced promising results. Our GRTL program is based on a reasonable hypotheses that, like the GRTL experiment, if learning intervention is provided to high needs children, then there will be causal conclusions in educational development."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Getting Ready To Learn
Project Description: "To address district wide barriers to student achievement, the Northwest Arctic Borough School District proposes to develop a five year project that will model an experiment that produced promising results.  The experiment was titled Getting Ready To Learn (GRTL).  Our GRTL program will provide a targeted and systematic approach to delivering early learning services to 'high needs' children age birth to 4 in schools located on 11 remote villages in the Northwest Arctic Borough."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Northwest Georgia Regional Education Service Agency
Project Title: Project DATA (Driving Attainment Through Assessment)
Project Description: "The Northwest Georgia Regional Educational Service Agency (NWGa RESA) proposes to implement Project DATA (Driving Attainment Through Assessment) as a Validation Grant funded under the Investing in Innovation Fund Grant Program. Project DATA will utilize a systems change approach to assist districts in creating a culture in which improved use of data becomes the norm. NWGa RESA will implement Project DATA for the next five years, addressing Absolute Priority 2 (Innovations that Improve the Use of Data) and Competitive Preference Priorities 6 (College Readiness) and 8 (Rural Schools). This project will impact 16 school districts in 10 counties in the northwest corner of Georgia. The objectives of Project DATA are: 1) to increase student achievement in Math, Science and Reading Comprehension for all groups of students in the NWGa RESA districts, 2) to increase graduation rates and post-high school readiness for all students graduating from NWGa RESA districts, and 3) to provide regional support for NWGa RESA districts in using data. Major project activities consist of implementation of a comprehensive assessment and data management system for all 16 school districts; administration of assessment instruments to students in the region to provide for college and career readiness; and professional learning for teachers to analyze the results of these assessments to advise students.Northwest Georgia RESA will team with providers that have products and services supported by rigorous research studies illustrating their effectiveness. Because Project DATA will provide a regional approach to benchmark assessment and data management, NWGa RESA will be able to better plan support services for districts, and districts will be able to consolidate resources to address common needs. The extensive collaborative nature of Project DATA will impact the region at a level that will exceed the work of this grant.?????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: SORIN
Project Description: "Southern Ohio Rural Innovation Network (SORIN) Project DescriptionThe Southern Ohio Rural Innovation Network (SORIN) proposed hypothesis states that learning for public purpose pedagogy (LPP) when associated with positive academic and social outcomes among students, most particularly among those students not otherwise engaged?e.g., at-risk students, will result in increased student motivation and achievement.  The SORIN model activities are framed upon five innovation strategies:  Innovation 1 infuse national and state standards with learning for public purpose pedagogy by improving stakeholder (teachers, school leaders, community, students) understanding and appreciation of learning that is relevant and rigorous; Innovation 2 Implement an Early Warning System for students ?at-risk? of school failure in grades 3, 6, 9, and 11; Innovation 3 improve research and analysis in rural education by adding to the rural education literature base; Innovation 4 infuse a framework of college and career access activities to encourage early college awareness and preparation for students and families in the high-need, rural Appalachian region; and, Innovation 5 connecting multiple sectors of service, education, and economic development agencies to identify critical needs of the schools and communities.The project will measure three outcomes 1) The development of culturally responsive institutions; 2) Increased student achievement and motivation; and 3) Improved communities. SORIN will initially target 9000 students in seven school districts over a two-county region of Appalachia Ohio.  Ohio Appalachia has 342,840 students between ages 5 and 17 and neighboring states of Kentucky (194,985) and West Virginia (301,993) have a total of 839,818 students.The lead applicant, Northwest LEA meets the eligibility for the priority on both the SRSA and the RLIS programs. Other LEAs in the grant are Bloom-Vernon, Green, Symmes Valley that are also listed on either the SRSA or RLIS program ... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Northwest Michigan Community Action Agency CARES - Children Acquiring Reading Essential Skills. (NMCAA CARES)
Project Description: "NMCAA Children Acquiring Reading Essential Skills (CARES), will implement and evaluate a unique collaborative model for creating a data driven unified educational system from preschool through third grade that improves the school readiness of high risk children from low income families who reside in 6 rural school districts (SRSA 2009) in Northwest Michigan. We will align curriculum, assessment and instruction so they are directed towards the same ends and reinforce each other. The intention is to forge a unified system of education from preschool through the early elementary grades that maximizes the use of data driven decision making.
