Data systems and their informed guidance will be used to: 1) align programs horizontally with curricula, assessment, and instruction; 2) target the development of reading skills and later reading proficiency; 3) align vertically the content and quality of instruction; 4) assess what is taught and how, to achieve reading success and do this with technological rigor to harness technology to make this merger feasible. By the end of project funding, we will have: 1) created and pilot tested an intervention and supporting materials for improving the use of data to align competencies, curriculum and assessment across preschool and elementary school systems; 2) produced state of the art, technology-based training materials to assist local communities and states in understanding and adapting a unified approach; and 3) documented what it takes to forge a partnership to create a multifaceted linked education system. NMCAA CARES represents strong partnerships between: 3 regional Intermediate School Districts and their early childhood and data management systems; the regional Head Start provider with a track record of collaborations with LEAs to positively impact child outcomes; 6 SRSA eligible rural LEAs within the partner ISDs;and is supported by the W K Kellogg Foundation, Teaching Strategies and Hatch computers to meet the i3 required match."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Increasing the Impacts of an Outdoor School Model On High Needs Students
Project Description: "The proposed project will examine the impacts of a residential outdoor school model (Northwest Outdoor Science School or NOSS) on 6th grade students, particularly on those with high needs.  NOSS will use funding provided by i3 to support 1,400 students to participate in an extended program that allows students with high needs the extra time to acclimate to the novel setting and engage in additional interdisciplinary field studies promoting higher level understanding. Funds will allow for the development of facilitator institutes focusing on best practices, content standards and innovative assessment strategies.  Rigorous research routines will be established to study the impacts of various program lengths as well as the academic and personal impacts on the high school student leaders.  Funding will provide opportunities for NOSS, schools and the private sector to gather together to garner long-term, stable funding for this powerful program and to share results throughout the region, state and country."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Turnaround Competencies for Success: A Model for Supporting Effective Principals and Teachers
Project Description: "The Minnesota Service Cooperatives are submitting an application titled Turnaround Competencies for Success: A Model for Supporting Effective Principals and Teachers (TCFS) for an Investing in Innovation development grant. Struggling high schools need teachers and principals that have the drive, persistence, influence and skills required to turn around low performance. The TCFS Model is based on competencies identified through research that enable a person to be successful in a specific job or role. The TCFS Model offers a way for schools to determine the current capacity of teachers or principals to meet job demands while also identifying the critical skills they need to develop. Using the TCFS Model, the Minnesota Service Cooperatives will train school leaders to better identify, select, recruit, place, develop, reward, and retain effective highly effective teachers and principals in low-performing high schools, and thereby increase the number of teachers and principals who are highly effective.This goal will be achieved through the following objectives: 1) Prepare trainers to assess Turnaround Competencies, administer the Behavior Event Interview process, and develop competency profiles of individual teachers and school leaders. 2) Develop coaching techniques and professional development modules aligned with the Competencies and assist participating schools with the alignment and integration of each school?s human resources with the TCFS Model. 3) Administer the TCFS Model in pilot sites by recruiting additional low-performing high schools and supporting the development of an action plan for implementing the TCFS Model, including a competency-based evaluation tool. 4) Monitor and evaluate the pilot sites to determine if participating schools increase the number and percentage of highly effective teachers and leaders in their schools as compared to numbers and percentages of highly effective teachers and highly effective leaders in control schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Data to Enhance School and Student Outcomes (DESSO)
Project Description: "Project description including project activities: DESSO will refine and further validate a project that innovatively draws upon the principles of Response to Intervention (RtI) and that will take that system of assessing and improving student outcomes to a new level of effective implementation.   As an approach to data collection and as an evidence-based system for improving student outcomes, DESSO, will be developed collaboratively by the LEAs and evaluated by Loyola University of Chicago School of Education.  RtI strategies will include: organizing problem-solving RtI teams within demonstration site schools who will be supported by 15 Lead Coaches.  Teachers will acquire the expertise on how to build school wide consensus on RtI, develop an effective infrastructure for RtI, and implement extensive systems of universal screening, on-going base-line assessments, monitoring of student performance, and using the data collected and analyzed to identify evidence-baaed instructional interventions for students in tiers 1 (whole school change with universal screening), 2 (group interventions for students requiring additional instructional support), and 3 (intensive interventions for students with special needs).  "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Southern California Collaboration for the Advancement of Principals and Teachers (SCC)
Project Description: "By bringing together partners with records of academic success in innovative K-12 programs serving rural and urban areas, and by capitalizing on the Professional Development (PD) that made them successful, SCC will deliver more comprehensive, practical and effective principal PD to replicate these successes. This program will model the research-based best practices it is designed to instill, incorporating interactive workshops, on-the-job mentoring and coaching, and online learning. It will also introduce a proven process of individualized PD planning and self-assessment to perpetuate best practices over timeObjectives: 1) Expand highly effective PD for rural and urban principals. 2) Establish a self-sustaining community of educators/leaders/learners. 3) Facilitate replication of successful innovative models such as such as early-college and online/hybrid schools. 4) Expand online learning opportunities for principals, teachers and students.Outcomes:  Increase the number of highly qualified principals in Southern California, providing leadership for a new crop of high-performing schools.128,500 students in schools served by program participants during the grant period, plus countless additional students who benefit over time from practices and tools provided through this program. Unprecedented collaboration across different types of schools and programs; special focus on strengthening/enhancing/sharing the lead partner's early-college model; incorporation of online learning to provide additional geographic and scheduling flexibility."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Accelerated Leadership Performance Project
Project Description: "Through the Accelerated Leadership Performance (ALP) project, a national consortium of ten LEAs, SEAs, universities and other education-oriented nonprofits will validate the NYC Leadership Academy's research-tested (Corcoran et al., 2009) school leadership preparation and support programs. Grounded in common leadership performance standards, the consortium will customize the Leadership Academy programs to serve a range of rural, urban and suburban contexts, building the capacity of school-level leadership for school improvement and turnaround as evidenced in student performance outcomes. With focus on serving high-need students and schools in each locale, the ALP Project will enable districts and states to maximize their human capital investments, provide rigorous, relevant, and locally responsive, experiential preparation and support programs, and match the strongest leadership talent to the most concentrated student needs. The ALP Project's local activities are grouped into three broad categories: 1) replication or adaptation of the Leadership Academy's Aspiring Principals Program (Delaware, New Haven CT, Peoria IL, Springfield MA, Rhode Island); 2) replication or adaptation of the Leadership Academy's APP-derivative coaching programs implemented state-wide or virtually state-wide (Delaware, Illinois, Missouri, Kentucky, Rhode Island); and (3) replication or adaptation of the Leadership Academy's APP-derivative coaching programs implemented at the district level (participating Virginia districts).  Using web-based technologies, face-to-face convenings, and on-site consultancies, the Leadership Academy will help build the local capacity of all participating consortium sites for robust, sustainable and accountable school leadership development systems."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Oakland  Educator Pipeline
Project Description: "Oakland's Grow Your Own Educator Pipeline       	This collaborative proposal for an i3 Development grant expands an Oakland Grow Your Own Educator Pipeline (OEP) in the Oakland Unified School District (OUSD), through implementing a replicable site and community-based  model of teacher effectiveness aligned to professional development. This project has two objectives: 1) implement an Urban Teacher Quality Index (UTQI), a locally generated teacher effectiveness tool, and 2) mentoring of new, local, Intern teachers of color (recruited and placed through Teach Tomorrow in Oakland (TTO)) by experienced, effective, local Mentor teachers of color who enroll in an Urban Teacher Leadership program at California State University East Bay. The UTQI assesses student, school, district, and community needs, and translates these into a measurement tool to assess teacher effectiveness, which guides professional development and mentoring of new intern teachers by teachers identified by the UTQI as effective in areas of Intern teacher needs. The UTQI aligns district, university, and community efforts to measure and increase teacher effectiveness. 	Expected outcomes include use of the UTQI to prepare, assess, and support Intern, and Mentor teacher development; alignment of professional development provider efforts; increased retention rates of teachers of color; increased capacity to provide relevant, timely coaching; and demonstrated student growth as measured by the UTQI. This project is expected to impact 25 intern and 25 mentor teachers each year, resulting in up to 1500 students being impacted annually. 	OUSD serves as the LEA, CSUEB serves as co-author of the grant and an Official Partner. Additional partners, include the Bay Area Coalition of Equitable Schools, RT Fisher Educational Enterprises, the Chavez Institute at SF State, and Oakland Mayor Ron Dellums."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Can tiered interventions reduce disproportionate minority contact (DMC) in OUSD? A validation study of Ripple Effects technology.
Project Description: "Can tiered interventions reduce disproportionate minority contact (DMC) in OUSD? A validation study of Ripple Effects technologyIn response to alarming levels of disproportionate minority contact in OUSD and against a harsheconomic background that requires new models of efficiency, OUSD in partnership with AIRproposes a linked set of RCTs to validate the impact of a technology-enabled suite of training,guidance, assessment and data management tools for student and teacher support, called RippleEffects. The technology will be used in a three-tiered system of intervention to: universallypromote core social emotional competencies at key developmental points; selectively provideearly intervening, behavioral training and personal guidance as part of RTI; and both standardizeand personalize positive discipline responses within a framework of restorative justice. RippleEffects technology has shown moderate evidence of effectiveness in raising grades, reducingdiscipline referrals, suspensions and drop out rates, and increasing scores on empathy andproblem-solving, especially among African American and LEP students. This validation studywould expand the conditions of use under which the program will be evaluated. Specifically,Ripple Effects would be used in school-wide, site-based and person-specific configurationswithin a social model of community engagement, a practice model of RTI, and a financial modelof increased efficiencies. The study would test impact at individual and group levels on studentand teacher social-emotional competencies, school culture, student behavior and academicperformance at varying degrees of usage and different grade levels. It would examine economicimplications of use and answer the question: Can school-wide, tiered use of Ripple Effectstechnology reduce disproportionate disciplinary contact and narrow th"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: VISA Virtual Instruction for Science Achievement
Project Description: "VISAVirtual Instruction for STEM AchievementOcean View 5-8th grade students will soon embark on a new four year journey through science. Supported by Innovation I3 grant funds, the 'old' science program will add a whole 'new' hands-on, minds-on learning component. Andrew, a sixth grade student at Spring View, enters his classroom for science instruction, but he is not toting a textbook and paper.  These days, science is conducted in a virtual lab complete with wireless laptop carts, probe ware, response systems, online electronic learning resources, and presentation software.The VISA program has three goals: 1) to improve 5-8th grade CST/standards based STEM achievement scores by an average of 10 percentage points (target: EL/SWD students) 2) to increase student and teacher effectiveness in technology literacy by access to 21st century learning tools and 3) to apply these skills in a career/college ready STEM coursework. The project is supported by private sector partners, including: Boeing Aircraft, Discovery Education, Smart Technologies, Tiger Woods Foundation Learning Center and West-Ed (PASS) Partnership for Assessment of Standards-Aligned Science.Students will use of technology tools for communication, problem solving, and increase their ability to create and evaluate information to improve learning. Electronic resources provide for virtual field trips and video conferencing activities. Students will create inquiry based science projects rooted in the physical, life, and earth science standards for their grade level. The investigative/experimentation component of VISA will increase inquiry science instruction by two hours weekly.The grant provides funds for two mobile laptop carts for 5th-8th grade at each site, probe ware, microscopes, document cameras and webcams for each school site."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Community-Based Instructional Coaching (CoBIC)
Project Description: "Ogden School District (OSD) has developed an innovative teacher professional development model for junior high and high schools that we call Community-Based Instructional Coaching (CoBIC). A ?development?-level Investing in Innovation (i3) grant will provide resources we need to conduct a rigorous quasi-experimental study of CoBIC. Results could more conclusively demonstrate its efficacy. Student communities form a foundation for CoBIC. Each community of students is led by a corresponding professional learning community (PLC): teachers, a counselor, an administrator (vice principal), and education specialists (special education, ELL/ESL, etc.). PLCs meet regularly to collaborate and support one another and to participate in data-driven professional development. Within each PLC, we provide instructional coaching, which we define as activities that help teachers enact research-based practices. During the project period, we will implement and administer CoBIC with fidelity in all OSD junior highs and high schools. We will increase teacher skills and knowledge as measured by the PRAXIS Principles of Learning and Teaching assessment and the Utah Professional Teacher Standards Continuum of Development. We will increase student achievement as measured by standardized tests and decrease the single-year dropout rate among students served by participating teachers. Partners will include professional development providers, e.g. consultants like AVID, the Stanford School Redesign Network, etc. and Utah?s universities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Increasing teacher effectiveness in mathematics at Ogden Preparatory Academy?????
Project Description: Ogden Preparatory Academy wishes to propose a project to increase the effectiveness of teacher s and principals  in best practices in order to improve our students' achievement in mathematics education .   The school will implement professional development and teacher training in best practices as well as introducing school-wide teacher assessments and teacher coaching.  Also the school will add additional personnel to assist in teaching and monitoring students skills acquisition in mathematics.  Teachers will have additional resources such as computer labs and manipulatives as well as additional training to help them improve their use of best practices in mathematics education.
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Success Tier
Project Description: "In Okeechobee County Schools, the challenges have become the catalyst for investing in an innovation that has the potential for challenging educators to re-think some of the standard practices on delivering education services to high need student populations. The Success Tier project advances a strategy that has been positively tested and implemented but is in need of additional funding to fully develop the program base and be prepared for replication. The Success Tier project directly addresses the program requirement to address the learning challenges of the district's highest need student populations. The innovation that Okeechobee County Schools brings to the U.S. Department of Education's Investing in Innovation program is a model that recognizes that the success of all the district's students begins by creating pathways to success for the district's highest need students.  Transforming the challenges of high need students into a tier of successful students will propel learning and motivate new strategies of teaching for all students.  As students transition from the 'Achievement Academy' back to their home schools, the project proposes to demonstrate -- How these students become ambassadors and enablers of innovation for learning that will seed innovation and success among their mainstream classmates.  .  ?????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: OBPS i3V: FOCUS
Project Description: "LEA:  The Old Bridge Township Public Schools (LEA) will adopt and track the results of implementing Math in Focus: the Singapore Approach as the new district-wide math program for its twelve (12) K-5 Elementary schools. This adoption also includes the introduction of Destination Math and Learning Village as technology-based support programs and the technology upgrades to the K-5 classrooms to transform them in to 21st Century learning spaces. A comprehensive Professional Development plan for teachers and other staff has been designed and will be implemented by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt as project partner.  Dr. Roger Farr and the Educational Research Institute of America (ERIA) will serve as the Independent Evaluators for the Project and Dr. Linda Ginsburg and Rutgers University, Center for Mathematics, Science and Computer Education have agreed to develop and offer mathematics content courses for elementary teachers, designed to enhance their ability to use curriculum materials effectively and provide in-class mentoring.  This application proposes a five-year (5) project with formal adoption of the curriculum during the 2010-2011 school year and professional development and evaluation continuing through 2015.  Old Bridge Township Public Schools (OBPS) is one of New Jersey?s largest suburban school districts.  Located in Middlesex County in the center of the state, it serves nearly 10,000 students daily, 4200 of whom are in the K-5 elementary schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: A High Reliability approach to Scaling-Up and Sustaining Proven Education Models in Under Served Rural Schools
Project Description: "Our proposed project will increase overall achievement levels and reduce achievement gaps in mathematics in 12 high-poverty rural LEAs. The project is designed to increase overall levels and reduce or eliminate achievement gaps in math achievement and high school graduation rates. The project will implement cooperative learning instructional model reforms in grades three to eight, and National Math and Science Initiative Advanced Placement reforms in middle and high schools. Activities include extensive teacher professional development, deployment of teacher coaches in each LEA, frequent on-site technical assistance, and provision of timely performance feedback. Our management plan is grounded in a scientifically validated high-reliability organizations framework. Performance indicators include scale scores on state tests, the percentage of children in grades 3-8 who achieve advanced proficiency in mathematics, AP math and science course enrollment, percentage of AP exams passed at Mastery levels, percentage of high school graduates passing one or more courses above the level of Algebra II, and on-time graduation rates. It will reach approximately 42,000 children within the span of the grant period. The project has been endorsed by the Secretary of Education of Virginia, the Commissioner of Education of Kentucky, U.S. Congressional Representatives in both states, the Virginia Superintendent of Public Instruction, the American School Counselors Association, and a host of other stakeholders, including state representatives, local foundations, rural educational technical assistance centers, corporations, and institutions of higher education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: i-AM Success -- Investing in Assets for Multi-generational Success
Project Description: "This proposal will support the efforts of eight public school districts serving students in Douglas and Sarpy Counties in eastern Nebraska who are collaborating with non-profit organizations and service providers in the Greater Metropolitan Omaha Area to expand learning opportunities aimed at improving academic achievement and high school completion for the high needs target audience of pregnant and parenting teens and their children. Addressing issues that challenge low performing schools, this project will focus on health and educational needs of the target population -- approximately 10,000 pregnant teens, teen parents (moms and dads) and their children -- over a 5-year period. At the heart of the project is the need to support pregnant teens and teen parents on a pathway to completion of a high school diploma and the skills necessary for transitioning into self-sufficiency through college or a career. This plan will include a focus on programs and services through a holistic approach, an integrated service delivery model, and strategic multiple pathways for teen parents to complete a high school diploma. A unique element of this proposal is the network of early childhood services designed around the concept of the 'parent as the first teacher.' These two priorities support a holistic approach to impacting generational poverty through a tandem approach to meeting the needs of pregnant and parenting teens and their children. A comprehensive focus on literacy and early literacy will also be woven into supports for teen parents and children. Official Partners are Omaha Public Schools (fiscal agent) and public school districts in Bennington, Douglas County West, Elkhorn, Gretna, Papillion-La Vista, Ralston and Westside. Other Partners are Building Bright Futures, Child Saving Institute, Heartland Family Service, Lutheran Family Services, Nebraska Children's Home Society and Visiting Nurse Association."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Project K-nect Plus
Project Description: "Onslow County Project K-Nect Plus - This project requests  $7.8M grant funding to support the validation of the successful trials of the mobile learning initiative 'Project K-Nect'.  This investment is offset by a nearly $2.1M contribution of the Project partners, representing a 27% match from program participants.  This Validation Grant extends K-Nect services to a population of 2100 middle and high school students enrolled in Onslow County schools.  The project will provide for the development of curriculum resources (targeted at lower socioeconomic underperforming students and students with disabilities) in the Math topic areas ranging from Algebra I to Geometry, Algebra II, and Calculus.  The content will be optimized for delivery on 3g enabled smartphones provided to each teacher and student participant.  The instructional intervention includes the appropriate scalable technology tools (mobile devices, a Mobile Learning Management System, communication, blogging, and instant messaging services), professional services for educators and students, and comprehensive research framework, the blend of which will result in irrefutable evidence as to gains made by students when provided an 'always on' mobile learning system.  The Project K-Nect Plus system proposed herein bridges the historical and persistent socioeconomic fueled digital divide and achievement gaps in US K12 education.  Validation of Project K-Nect Plus, its delivery system, positive outcomes achieved by students, and the economic efficiencies derived from broadband-connected mobile learning technologies, provides a compelling 'reference design' for how US school systems can implement, at scale, equal student access to instruction support systems regardless of the student's location, income level, or academic preparedness.  This Project has significant implications on the direction that schools pursue both in design of instructional programs, but also the tools used to implement these programs (at sca"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: OWFS Collaborative Future Thinking Learners Program
Project Description: "Open World Family Services, Inc. and our partners a local LEA and rural community-based nonprofit organization believe that this is what we as educators and systems of education in the United States should be doing - thinking in the future.  Our proposed program will serve as a developmental program offering 450 to 600 children the opportunity to learn in new and different ways.  Our Future Thinkers will be exposed to a NASA Educational Program designed to encourage learning in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) areas during the school year and in the summer.  Children will be given the opportunity to conduct experiments in a variety of STEM areas, learn to present these methods and develop trial and error examination skills which have been shown to help children think independently."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Opening Minds through the Arts Foundation
Project Title: Opening Minds through the Arts
Project Description: "The Opening Minds through the Arts (OMA) Model is a whole school operating system that enables schools to implement, through planning and training, the use of arts integration to teach math, science, reading, writing, and social studies in every classroom, every day of the school year, and to reach every child regardless of language, socioeconomic status or ability.  The OMA Model is based on brain-based learning, multiple intelligence theories, and the neurological development of children.  It is backed by 10 years of development and supported by a training and technical assistance team that is implemented by the OMA Foundation, a nonprofit organization whose mission is to bring arts integration to as many children as possible.  The OMA Model has been researched by WestEd, Inc. documenting robust and significant gains in student achievement when this arts integration model is implemented.  Teacher focus groups additionally have stated that 'OMA mitigates the impact of poverty, lack of English proficiency, and the high mobility rates prevelant in many schools.' Our Model is exceptional, our experience is exceptional, and our prospects for transforming education in this country are exceptional."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: FIVE MILLION KIDS (5MK) Initiative
Project Description: "The FIVE MILLION KIDS (5MK) Initiative is Operation HOPE's national campaign to reverse rising high school dropout rates by 'making smart cool'.  5MK seeks to rebrand education in the minds of at-risk students, utilizing financial literacy education to provide practical lessons in the language of money and  thus making school relevant by serving as the key to controlling their financial future. 5MK also strives to bring economic literacy to at-risk students' families, schools and neighborhoods, helping build healthy communities to support student success. 5MK's objectives include: educating five million low-wealth youth and their parents, guardians and teachers in financial literacy; facilitating 50,000 new starter savings accounts for youth on a matched basis; securing $50 million in Earned Income Tax Credits (EITC) for parents and teachers; opening 50,000 new bank accounts for the unbanked and under-banked, using their EITC benefits; recruiting and training 25,000 volunteers to teach financial literacy, dignity and entrepreneurship; recruit 5,000 grassroots leaders nationwide to work in their communities to reverse the high school dropout rate; secure $100 million of in-kind media space to rebrand education as smart and cool  and secure 50 celebrity ambassadors to endorse the 'Make Smart Cool' campaign. 5MK's expected outcomes include an increase in awareness of financial literacy skills among at-risk students, an increase in financiallyliterate behavior among these students and  their parents, an increase in financial stability of low-income neighborhoods and a decrease in the high school dropout rate stemming from greater motivation for at-risk youth to succeed and stay in school."

Project Title: Changing Schools from the Bottom Up
Project Description: "Pathways to College, in collaboration with five underperforming urban and rural high schools, seeks an i3 Development grant to test that students themselves can be a critical, but largely ignored and under-utilized resource for school turn around strategies. Pathways to College, initiated under the auspices of A Better Chance (ABC) but now an independent 501 (c) (3) organization, began as an after-school program focusing on college access. Success reaching that goal ? 100% of its students have been accepted by at least one college, most by at least one selective four-year college - has led to the  realization that the program?s activities and successes are having a positive impact on non-participating students and others in the school. Pathways now seeks to test rigorously this emerging major hypothesis: given the power of peer pressure, bottom up strategies that focus on students as active partners in, rather than the objects of, turn around efforts may provide more consistent and effective results than the current and far more extensively used top down strategies. At the very least, this bottom up strategy might prove to be a valuable complement to those other efforts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: ACCESS Application for I3 Developmental Grant under Priority Four
Project Description: "The Orange County Department of Education operates the largest public alternative education program in California known as ACCESS. ACCESS serves the hardest to reach, most credit deficient student population in the county. In spite of the obstacles students face, they are still able to make-up credits at ACCESS and get back on track toward graduation. Orange County has the lowest dropout rate in the state, much due to the existence of ACCESS.     OCDE is applying for a for a three-year Development Grant under Priority 4 for 'Turn Around Schools', as well as special consideration under Competitive Preferences 6 and 7. This proposal is referred to the ACCESS I3 Grant and will focus on two educational strategies. The first is a 'wrap-around learning center' school model that incorporates flexible educational modalities and support services. This I3 grant will establish a new school based on this model to serve 1,000 students per year. Special features include an educational program for over-aged, under-credited students. ACCESS has expertise in establishing new schools and keeping them operational. The second strategy is the ACCESS Truancy Response Program (ATRP), which is a series of progressive truancy reduction interventions. When piloted within one ACCESS region in 2008, ATRP interventions led to a 58% reduction in overall truancy during the six month trial. This grant will expand ATRP throughout ACCESS to serve 4,800 students with truancy issues. Both strategies are intended to incorporate flexible educational options and support services to increase high-risk students' overall academic success and seamless transition to college/career.      ACCESS will formally study both strategies to uncover essential components to bringing them to scale in other regions, states, and national programs. Both strategies show great potential for success, but neither has been formally studied or widely adopted."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Orcas Island School District Start Strong
Project Description: "*Investment in Innovations Development Grant**Project Summary*Orcas Island School District's *START STRONG* project for the Investment inInnovation (i3) Development Grant is based on the following hypothesis: If Orcas Island School District partners with pre-schools, particularly for high-need children, and implements the International Baccalaureate Primary Years Program for all students, we will raise achievement levels of existing and emerging high-need students.Orcas Island School District's *START STRONG *investment in innovationencorporates five strong, concrete steps:1)   Partner with our local preschool consortium, Orcas Family Connections,to enhance the quality of early learning programs so that all children,especially high-need children, are kindergarten-ready.2)   Implement the International Baccalaureate Program for all of ourstudents K-8.3)   Increase the number of Orcas Island School District high schoolstudents earning college credits while in high school through AdvancedPlacement and through articulation agreements with state colleges forhands-on CTE (Career and Technical Education) and other hands-on classesthat do not qualify as AP classes.4)   Ensure all OISD high school students will take part in guidance andcounseling plans in order to graduate college- and career-ready. TheOISD *START STRONG* proposal includes the use of the Washington State Navigation 101curriculum, particularly the online lessons and portfolio, as a part of ourguidance and counseling plan. 5)  Include Spanish language acquisition for all Orcas Island SchoolDistrict students. This addresses the unique learning needs of students withlimited English proficiency, as well as the importance put onsecond-language acquisition by the International Baccalaureate program.Orcas Island School District was established in 1937; it consists of fiveschools, including a 'one-room schoolhouse' that doesn't use electricity onan island accessible only by priv"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Relevant Educational Implementation of Technology (REALITY)
Project Description: "Oregon City School District has made impressive gains in technology literacy, parent involvement, and high school state assessment scores. Teachers have had an assigned laptop for 3 years now and we have enacted a 3 year sustainabiltiy plan since they are now the center of the classroom. Our 6th grade experimental study on 1-1 laptop use shows the treatment group at an 8th to 10th grade level in technology literacy assessment against both the state and district standards. Sustained professional development has been a high priority in Oregon City School District and the skill level of our teachers reflects it. We are focused on sustainability, student-centric classrooms, and more learning opportunities through differentiation made available with technology.  We are data driven and plan on using student technology to enable instant formative assessments which will drive our Professional Learning Communities. We will leverage technology as a platform for many other improvement projects.Our goal is to give students in grades 3-12 an iPad for use in school for digital textbooks, general computer use, as well as literacy and math programs. Students in grades 6-12 will be allowed to take them home, and graduating seniors who apply for college get to keep their iPad after graduation. Oregon City High School offers over a dozen dual credit courses so why not start providing (and requiring) technology for students as nearly all colleges already do?  We believe that providing a computer after graduation will encourage more college enrollment as will increased participation in dual credit courses. We will use the iPod touch as an intervention tool for at-risk readers by sending it home loaded with audiobooks, podcasts, and applications that have been proven to help catch struggling readers up to or beyond grade level. This model will be deployed in our neighboring LEA at one middle school."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Ready, Set, Go Development Grant
Project Description: "Orleans Parish School Board proposes to implement a ?Ready, Set, Go? initiative and seeks a Development Grant to fund it.  The scope of this project will target the improvement of student achievement of 630 students in grades 7-9 who are 99% African American at McDonogh 35 High School and 15% Limited English Proficient and 82% African American at McMain Secondary School.  The hypothesis of this project is to improve achievement in mathematics and reading by six per cent at the end of the three year period through facilitation, analysis and use of student achievement and growth data by educators, families, and other stakeholders to make informed decisions [Absolute Priority 2].  This project is innovative in that summer parent academies, quarterly parent training sessions, and job embedded coaching and professional development for teachers and administrators will be implemented [Competitive Preference Priority 6].  In addition, STI Achievement Services or an equivalent service will work collaboratively with the schools on creating and implementing innovative lessons, assessing student deficiencies, modeling lessons for teachers, providing job embedded professional development, using data to drive instruction and infusing technology into project based learning [Competitive Preference Priority 7]. Partners in this project are Old City Building, Cooper-Hewitt, and CORE Element.  Letters of support from them are located in Appendix D."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Redesign Revolution
Project Description: "The Ouachita Parish School Board proposes to use (i3) funding to attain the following goals:Goal 1:The number of students scoring a 3 or higher on an AP exam will equal or surpass the 2013-2014 national average.Goal 2:The students of Ouachita Parish that enter post secondary education upon graduating from high school will equal or surpass the national average for the 2013-2014 school year.Goal 3:The percent of minority and low-income students enrolled in the district will equal the percent of minority and low-income students enrolled in AP, PreAP, and Dual Enrollment courses across the district.Goal 4: Fifty percent of the targeted schools? ?high need? students will be enrolled in support services such as AVID or after school tutoring by the end of the four year initiative.Goal 5:Eighty percent of the K-5th graders in the district will be enrolled in a core curriculum activity based P.E. Program.This K-12 project will serve 19,080 K-12th graders using the following age appropriate activities related Absolute Priority 3.? K-5 Curriculum Based Physical Education Program? AVID and After School Tutoring as support for ?high need? students? Teacher training to incorporate rigor? Administrator, Counselor, Teacher and District Level Training to address issues of Equity and Access? AP, Pre-AP, and Dual Enrollment CoursesThe University of Louisiana at Monroe will serve as an official partner and the College Board will also be a partner. (Letters of Support in the Appendix)Many of the proposed activities were initiated during the implementation of the Advanced Placement Initiative 2006-2009 which targeted two high schools, two middle schools, and sixth graders at six elementary schools. We have used the external evaluation from that initiative to justify the feasibility of continuing the project at the targeted schools and expanding the successful strategies that were implemented with API to all schools in the district."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Educare Innovation
Project Description: "The Ounce of Prevention Fund and its Official Partners request a Validation Grant under Absolute Priority 2:Innovations that Improve the Use of Data and Competitive Preference Priority 5: Innovations for ImprovingEarly Learning Outcomes. The proposed project will scientifically validate and scale the Educare Innovation, aset of best practices in data use that encourages and facilitates the evaluation, analysis and use of studentachievement and growth data by educators, families and other stakeholders to inform decision-making andimprove high-needs student outcomes, birth to third grade. The Educare Innovation creates a partnershipbetween a birth-to-five early childhood education school, a Local Education Agency (LEA), and a localevaluation partner to implement a cycle of formative assessment and data use.The proposed i3 project will validate the Educare Innovation through a randomized control trial in five birth-tofiveschools and LEAs, while extending its reach and evaluating fidelity of implementation in 15 additionalbirth-to-five schools and their LEAs. Over 15,000 students will be reached over five years. The projectevaluation will track progress toward four measureable outcomes: 1) Reduction and elimination of theachievement gap for high-needs children at by entrance to kindergarten; 2) Increased teacher effectiveness asevidenced by teachers? use of research-based instructional practices; 3) Implementation of a Research-ProgramPartnership and intensive, data-driven coaching of teachers; and 4) Alignment of educational strategies, birththrough the primary grades to sustain the gains achieved by high-needs learners.Official Partners include: Ounce of Prevention Fund (Chicago), Clayton Early Learning (Denver), Educare ofOmaha, Next Door Foundation (Milwaukee), and Tulsa Educare, Inc.; Chicago Public Schools, Omaha PublicSchools, and Tulsa Public Schools; and FPG Child Development Institute at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: Our Lady of the Lake University
Project Title: South Texas College Connection 2
Project Description: "This is a partnership between Our Lady of  the lake University (OLLU), Texas State Technical College and two LEAs (Harlandale ISD and La Friera ISD. The purpose is to expand and validate the OLLU model, and adapt the model to the Rio Grande Valley in the following four ways:1. Improve teachers' knowledge in STEM disciplines through tuition-free master's level programs;2. Improve pedogogy through intense professional devleopment;3. Stimulate interest in STEM among K-8 students with afterschool clubs and summer daycamps;4. Implement classroom 'Conexion' to give potential dropouts a vision of STEM college and careers."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Our Piece of the Pie, Inc.
Project Title: Pathways to Opportunity
Project Description: "Our Piece of the Pie, Inc. ?, (OPP?), will partner with school districts in Connecticut in a targeted reform effort to help over-aged, under-credited students graduate high school and college. Relying on our extensive and successful youth development services, we propose to establish three transfer high schools that integrate a recuperative curriculum with intensive youth development services. Our objectives during the course of this project are: (1) to establish three transfer high schools in CT;  (2) to demonstrate their effectiveness through rigorous evaluation and; (3) to produce a template for transfer schools that can be adopted - both statewide and beyond - to address the needs of failing schools and the most at-risk students.  Our goals are for over-aged, under-credited students to graduate high school and college.  OPP brings a number of innovative strategies to prepare over-aged, under-credited students for success. We engage in a community partnership with the schools to address the needs of over-aged, under-credited students directly in school. We align academics, youth development, and workforce development in a single integrated approach that connects students to college and career planning.  We continue our youth development strategy through college and graduation by providing a bridge of support and mentoring from the transfer high schools through post-secondary institutions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: BIST Innovative Strategies for Improving School Success
Project Description: "This project proposes to use a quasi-experimental design to systematically study the efficacy of the Behavior Intervention Support Team (BIST) model. Activities include establishing data collection and management strategies and fidelity measures; conducting annual training on concepts, language and skills; annual trainings for leadership teams; monthly on-site coaching visits with grade level teams; quarterly, district-wide BIST teacher meetings; quarterly district-wide BIST administrator meetings and conducting a comprehensive evaluation."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Kulia I Ka Nu'u (Strive for the Highest)
Project Description: "Project Kulia I Ka Nu'u is a consortium project of three elementary schools in high poverty rural communities on the Island of Oaha, Hawaii.  The project will combine culture and placed based curricula that meet current Hawaii content and performance standards, a proactive parent involvement program and career planning and development stragis utilizing the Kader career system to collectively increase student achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Painted Desert Demonstration Projects dba The STAR School
Project Title: STAR 3-to-3rd Math and Literacy Project
Project Description: "Abstract forThe STAR 3-to-3rd Math and Literacy ProjectFor Schools Serving Native American and Native Hawaiian Children		This proposal is designed to fully  research and refine the promising practices shown by the STAR Early Learning Program in math  skills development for rural Native American and Native Hawaiian children through high quality preschool experiences, to extend the essential parts of this approach to skills development in  grades K-3,  and to implement this model program in diverse indigenous communities around the country, including schools serving Navajo, Native Hawaiian, Pima, and Cherokee communities. Since these communities are all indigenous and all rural, yet all unique in their cultural context, an essential part of  the STAR model is to be place-based and to integrate the positive cultural values of each indigenous community into the behavior and context of the skill development in the children.  Thus this proposed project will provide extensive training and interaction with each site on how to integrate the positive cultural values into instruction.   	This proposed project will focus on researching a model that emphasizes high standards by building on four major characteristics, all of which are characteristics of a high quality early education program: 1) rich language environment ; 2) high quality developmentally appropriate materials that allow learning math concepts ; 3) a positive emotional climate with sensitive and responsive teachers; and 4) Opportunities for children to explore their environments."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Middle-grades Algebra Success through Higher Order Thinking (MAS-HOT)
Project Description: "Project Title: MAS-HOT Middle-grades Algebra Success through Higher Order ThinkingOur focus question: How do we foster success with the challenging mathematics of algebra for our large Hispanic English learner middle school population by increasing their academic engagement, effort and problem-solving skills to prepare them for college and career? Our innovation is to use visualization strategies and a ?growth mindset? to1) build linguistic pathways for our language learners by tapping into what research shows are existing and strong visual skill sets2) use these skill sets to strengthen and build the higher order thinking skills needed for success in algebra3) generate more active engagement and confidence with content by expressly developing an understanding of how we think and learnThe project will use the work of Dr. Carol Dweck and her ?Brainology?program to help students shift toward a ?growth mindset? by teaching them about the brain, how to strengthen it, and how to better develop useful study skills. We will also use the visualization models developed by VTS to improve critical thinking and language skills via discussion and writing. Taking these two innovations in tandem with coaching teachers in the development of rigorous and engaging math lessons, we hypothesize that we can build students? language capacity, confidence and higher order thinking skills to better access challenging mathematics, and in effect, nurture students more capable of success with algebra standards."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Increasing School success through Community Collaboration (ISSTCC)
Comprehensive Dual Enrollment Model
Project Description: "The Investing in Innovations Project - Comprehensive Rural Dual Enrollment is a Development Grant to serve seven hundred students sponsored by Palo Verde College to expand its dual enrollment effort by developing a middle school, high school and community college learning community to close the achievement gap and increase the college graduation rates for high need students. This project is unique because of the setting in Blythe, California a small rurally isolated city of 12,500 with one middle school one high school and one community college. This unique setting creates a controlled situation to effectively evaluate the impact of a comprehensive and targeted dual enrollment project.Summary of Project and Expected Outcomes:Palo Verde College objectives, activities and services and outcomes align with the four components of project services by student level. The Middle School (7-8 Grades) Component will focus on Academic Skills development to prepare students to enter high ready for a rigorous curriculum of study. The expected outcome is to achieve grade level proficiency or above on the STAR Test. The High School (9-10 Grades) Component will focus on academic development, college skills preparation and counseling so students may be successful in their rigorous high school curriculum in preparation for participation in the dual enrollment project. The expected outcome is to achieve grade level proficiency or above to facilitate college course enrollment. The Dual Enrollment (11-12 Grades) Component will focus on academic support and counseling with the outcome of academic success at both educational levels. The Community College Component will provide academic support and counseling to achieve academic success and college graduation.Other services will include on-going skills assessment to focus services to individual student needs, student and family social development to build a college success community, services to address curriculum alignment between the... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Parents as Educational Partners (PEP) Project
Project Description: "Pursuant to the Absolute Priority #3 ? Innovations the complement the implementation of high standardsand high-quality assessments. The Palomar College Parent and Educators Project grant objectives stipulate theuse of annual California STAR Testing/California State Standards Tests (CST) standards and test results. Withthese high quality annual and longitudinal assessments, from 7th grade to 11th grade, participating students willknow their scores and be able to identify areas of improvement/s, specifically in math and science.The Parent Institute for Quality Education (PIQE) will provide and implement their 9-week parenteducation course at 8 of the PEP grant schools. The goal of this project piece is to help parents becomeacculturated and familiar with their local school system. As a result, better parent to school connections willencourage these parents to seek and provide support to their child?s school. Additionally, the Palomar Collegeteam will work with teachers to provide the four-week PEP Math and Science course, as a community collegecourse that will cover the middle school California math and science standards, standardized test scoreinterpretation, and the math and science sequence completion necessary to prepare for college admission.Consequently, parents will have a deeper understanding of the California state standards and college admissionrequirements their children must meet and how as parents they can support their learning at home.The Palomar College Parents as Educational Partners (PEP) interventions and evaluation hope todemonstrate that students whose parents receive intense parent education programming, training from teachers toincrease understanding of math and science standards, and parent as educators opportunities which support mathand science standards will be more likely to be college ready than their peers whose parents do not receive theseservices."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Inland North County San Diego -- Academic Achievement for All (INC, SD AAA)
Project Description: "The Palomar College (PC) Investing in Innovation (i3) Validation Grant project seeks to acutely address educational  deficiencies plaguing high-need students? high school graduation goals and college enrollment dreams. The exceptional methods proposed will significantly tackle the priorities of the i3 grant and will incorporate innovative strategies not currently widely adopted in the country, and not previously conducted so comprehensively, nor in such a collaborative approach. Th PC  i3 grant will serve a consortium of 14 Local Education Agencies? (LEAs) and their select middle schools that feed into high schools; all with high rates of academically at-risk students and comparably lower-college going rates. The geographic area, to be served,  in the northeastern most part of San Diego County; an often underserved and sometimes forgotten area that has many  pockets of poverty and greater breadths and depths of diversity. The title for the PC i3 project is Inland North County, San Diego ? Academic Achievement for All (INC, SD AAA), deemed as such to place emphasis on the education potential for students of this area, and the need for stronger collaboration between LEAs, PC, California State University San Marcos (CSUSM), local Chambers of Commerce (and businesses/industries),Tribal Councils, and Non-Profit (community-based) Organizations (NPOs). The strategies are simply twofold: 1) to integrate and utilize the comprehensive programs and services of the College Board for students and teachers/staff, in feeder middle schools and their high schools, and 2) to have college/university personnel work  in the schools, with teachers/staff, to coordinate the College Board programs and services, while also incorporating  activities, programs, events, and services (APES) that promote a college-going culture and assist students (and the parents and teachers/staff) with increased high school academic achievements and post-secondary education  and career planning for a... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Systems Knowledge for Collaboration and Innovation (SKCI)
Project Description: "SYSTEMS KNOWLEDGE FOR COLLABORATION AND INNOVATION (SKCI): A NETWORK TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE TEACHERS AND PRINCIPALSVISION, GOALS, AND WORK ? The vision of SKCI is: Create a mutual learning network of schools and partners that operate as a system for developing and retaining highly effective teachers and principals, and who engage students at high levels of learning for the 21st century. The goals of the project are:Goal 1 ? Increase the school district?s ability to operate as a coherent system.Goal 2 ? Expand teachers? knowledge for engaging students at high levels of effectiveness.Goal 3 ? Expand principals? knowledge of effective instructional leadership.Goal 4 - Close the achievement gap of ELL and SPED with other groups.Goal 5 ? Increase the high school graduation rate and strengthen college readiness pathways through partnerships.The SKCI project vision and goals are intended to ultimately impact 59 rural school districts that include over 50,000 students by starting with one district, Pampa School District as a ?test bed? for innovation. The SKCI project, designed in partnership with the Pampa Independent School District, Schlechty Institute, Education Service Center, Region 16, Clarendon College, Cabot Business, and university technical assistance providers (TAP), will test a three layer model for three years in one rural school district in the Region 16 area - Pampa Independent School District ? to create a system of highly effective teachers and principals. As Pampa implements the SKCI project, they are willing to open up their district publicly to serve as a studio-based learning model for others in the Region 16 area, thereby creating a mutual learning network."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Personalized Learning in the 21st Century: The Panasonic Foundation Multi-state Network for High Standards and High Quality Assessments
Project Description: "  Our experience teaches us that building sustainable systems of high standards and high-quality assessments requires organizing and aligning the various parts toward a single purpose.  This initiative has one overarching purpose: Improve academic and social outcomes for all students so that they are prepared for success in college and careers. The Panasonic Foundation -- an endowed philanthropic non profit that provides expertise rather than grants - together with its partner school districts, has been working to build sustainable systems that improve educational outcomes for all students.  Given i3 funding, PF will establish a multi-state network for high standards and high-quality assessments of four K-12 urban public school districts, concentrating, in part, on a cohort of  five high-need schools within each district.  Common Core State Standards (CCSS) will guide rigorous teaching and learning that aims for college- and career-readiness.  We will assist districts in revising their current curriculum using CCSS, developing formative assessments, and implementing summative assessments to be developed by federally-funded consortia.  Our multi-state network will be one of the first to implement CCSS coast-to-coast and to measure their effectiveness in preparing students for college and careers.  We propose to assist teachers in using one-to-one computing that engages students as partners in their learning and extends the instructional day aligned to CCSS.  There is good reason to use one-to-one computing for our purpose.  There is moderate evidence from research that one-to-one computing leads to increases in student achievement and engagement.  While research on one-to-one computing is promising this model is largely untested particularly among high need students in urban schools.  If we are to close achievement gaps and prepare students for the accelerating demands of globalized world, we need to demonstrate the viability of just such game-changing practices."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Improve students' academic achievement through the use of technology in school; assisting all students in becoming technology literate, and integration of technology with teacher training and curriculum development.

Applicant: Parent Institute for Quality Education Inc
Project Title: Family Engagement for Student Achievement
Project Description: "The Parent Institute for Quality Education (PIQE) is seeking $18.5 million dollar grant for a 5 years to provide its FESA Project to 98 low performing schools with a high percentage of ELL students in six school districts in three state regions: California, Minnesota and Texas. The FESA project components are: PIQE BASIC: The Parent Engagement in Education Program, A nine-week workshop that teaches low-income parents on how to navigate the public education system.  PIQE ADVANCE: Four Month Coaches Follow Up Program, providing four months 'coaching' to graduate parents to reinforced new-acquired knowledge and skills; Professional Development for Teachers and Counselors, to train school staff on research-based strategies to increase the involvement of low-income families; Leadership Development for Parents, offering parents the opportunity to play a leadership role in addressing the 'non-academic' barriers to student achievement through action research projects. Objectives:  (1) Increase high school graduation rates of high risk students. (2) Increase parents' knowledge about the school system and the academic expectations for their children; (3) Create at each school site the conditions for an effective parent-teacher communication and collaboration; (4) Improve home conditions supportive and conducive to learning. (5)Improve teacher/counselors knowledge and practice of effective parent involvement strategies; (6) Create and support effective parent leadership practices at each school site. (7) Foster the creation of a college culture amongst parents, students, teachers and counselors. Targeted number of students: 65,060. Partners: In California: San Diego Unified School District (21 schools), Ceres Unified School District (11 schools), West Contra Costa Unified School District (21 schools), Oakland Unified School District (21 schools); in Minnesota: Saint Paul County Public Schools (12 schools); in Texas: Houston Independent School District (12 schools)."

Project Title: Improving Educational Outcomes for American Indian Children
Project Description: "This BabyFACE project will replicate the evidence proven, home-based services of the successful Family And Child Education (FACE) program in 24 Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) schools.  BabyFACE will serve high-needs American Indian families with children ages prenatal to 5 years living in the catchments areas of BIE schools that are not currently offering the FACE program to families. Services to families will include home-visits, routine health and developmental screenings for the children, parent group meetings, and resource referrals as needed. Families will receive weekly or bi-weekly visits from certified parent educators.The project goals are to narrow the achievement gap at kindergarten entry for American Indian children and to improve student achievement in reading and math through third grade.  The objectives are a) early identification of health and developmental issues and referral for intervention of any delays, b) increasing parental knowledge of child development, c) increasing access to literacy resources in the home, d) increasing literacy activities, e) increasing parent involvement in their child's education, and f) increasing school readiness.  The outcomes are a) fewer special education services, b) parents utilize effective child management techniques and have age-appropriate expectations for their children, c) more books and pre-literacy materials in the home, d) parent spends more time on literacy activities with the child(ren), e) parents attend or initiate meetings with teachers, and f) children score better on assessments. FACE is an adaptation of the Parents as Teachers (PAT) model that include Native language and culture.  Evaluations of the PAT model meet the moderate level of evidence.  The outcomes for both FACE and PAT have been proven effective in 'leveling the playing field' for high-needs children when entering kindergarten. FACE has been successfully replicated and is now offered at 45 BIE schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Pathways to Higher Education
Project Description: "Pathways is an integrated program of research-base models beginning at birth and culminating in higher education, designed to dramatically increase the engagement of parents and families in the education of their children. The two major research models utilized are Parents as Teachers and the National Network of Partnership Schools' Action Plan Team model. 	The project has 3 goals, each with 3 objectives. 1) To increase school readiness for low-income and ELL children with the following objectives; children enter kindergarten ready for school; parents including ELL parents and parents of students with special needs, learn their role as first teacher; and childcare professionals embrace parents as partners, including ELL parents and parents of students with special needs;  2) Increase student achievement with the following objectives: establish working partnerships between parents, schools and community including ELL parents and parents of students with special needs; increase usage rate of academic interventions for low-achieving students; students; and parents including ELL parents and parents of students with special needs are prepared for the key transitions.  3)Parents and students prepare for post-secondary education/career throughout their pre-K - 12th grade education with the following objectives: children enter kindergarten ready for school; parents including ELL parents and parents of students with special needs, learn their role as first teacher; and childcare professionals embrace parents as partners, including ELL parents and parents of students with special needs.	The total number of students to be served are 6,491. A special feature of the project is The Wisconsin Covenant which is a core element of the design, and guarantees access to both public and private Wisconsin higher education for students who pledge to achieve academically and maintain solid citizenship"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Parents Step Ahead Centers
Project Description: "While Parents Step Ahead currently offers school-based educational programs, schools need an onsite resource that will serve the needs of their parent population. We propose to establish a Parents Step Ahead Center in three Title 1 schools (elementary, middle and high school). The Centers will help parents and the school officials address barriers by providing them with a variety of resources, experts, and seminars. In partnership with the Dallas Independent School District, Parents Step Ahead plans to work with schools, community partners and experts to create Centers tailored to the populations they serve.The Parents Step Ahead Center is unique in that each Center will employ a social worker and psychologist who will each work with parents on a daily basis. The social worker will examine behavior and offer advice to parents and students on emotional and educational well being. They will have the capabilities to make house calls to examine the personal environment of students. Similarly, psychologist will provide pyschoeducational assessment and diagnosis of specific behavior and learning disabilities. Psychologists will also provide expertise to school personnel to address challenges facing parents and children.In addition, the Center will regularly produce Parents Step Ahead seminars. These seminars will include presentations by experts, community resource fairs, meals, childcare and raffles culminating in the raffle of a computer for a family.A.2.1 GoalsAll Centers will encompass these fundamental goals: (1) recognize, respect and address needs, cultural diversity and economic position; (2) increase awareness and accountability of parents? roles in student achievement; (3) improve communication between school and parents; (4) foster strong relationships among families, teachers, community organizations and city departments to ensure sustainability; (5) Provide access to and education of technology?TRUNCATED"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Bringing Mindfulness into the Classroom
Project Description: "Park Day School brings an innovative & exceptional approach to support high need elementary school students. Having delivered the program to 6,000 high need students, preliminary evidence indicates that mindfulness enables children to focus, self-regulate, feel less stress & more connection in their schools. This replicable program has been delivered by teachers in Texas & Virginia.A four year grant will provide mindfulness training to 160,000 students, 6,500 teachers & hundreds of schools. The applicant will directly provide a five-week program to approximately 17,000 students & 1,275 teachers in 85 schools. Others will obtain mindfulness skills through teachers trained live or online. Every aspect of this program will be researched.Launched in 2007 as a pilot by Park Day School, a private school that, for 18 years, has collaborated with 51 Title One elementary schools, Mindful Schools has produced the most effective results of our programs that have enhanced student achievement & growth. The project addresses Absolute Priority 4 & Competitive Priorities 5 & 7 & will measure the efficacy of mindfulness to turn around persistently low-performing schools through targeted approaches to reform. The project will demonstrate that mindfulness allows more time for students to learn core subjects because of students? increased ability to focus & the minimization of disruptions. Research will show how mindfulness can be integrated into the school model as a vital student support to address non-academic barriers to student achievement. Work with the Ed Depart at Holy Name College will demonstrate how mindfulness can be a vital support to enable new teachers to begin their careers with less stress & more effectiveness.Mindfulness has been used & researched in the medical world for over 30 years. More recently the corporate world has offered on-site classes for their employees. Problems in education today make schools the next logical frontier for mindfulness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Partners for Developing Futures
Project Description: "Partners For Developing Futures (?Partners?) in collaboration with a consortium of high achieving minority led charter schools is pleased to present its application to the Department of Education?s Investment in Innovations Fund (?i3?). Unlike other applicants, we do not present an innovative ?project?. Instead, we present our organization as an innovation in creating and sustaining minority-led high quality charter schools serving low-income minority students.Partners is a social venture investment fund that invests in high-potential, early stage minority-led charter schools /networks that educate high-need students. Partners? approach to investing is similar to venture capitalists, who take talented entrepreneurs through a very competitive, rigorous process with a keen focus on short- and long-term outcomes. Like preceding social venture funds such as Venture Philanthropy Partners, NewSchools Venture Fund (NewSchools), and Charter School Growth Fund (CSGF)?the latter with whom Partners incubated, we invest in talented education leaders and their charter schools. The return on investment is not only financial, but also social and one that contributes to the creation and sustainability of outstanding charter schools that provide the high-quality public education that increases high-needs students? academic achievement, high school graduation rates, and college enrollment and graduation. The ultimate goal is to find the best minority leaders with the highest probability of efficiently starting and running a successful charter school or network that is sustainable primarily on public funds, and facilitate the creation and operation of that school so that it has demonstrable results for high-need students. By targeting an untapped population of school leaders who have gone missing and unnoticed in the charter school sector, Partners? directly addresses Investing in Innovation?s Absolute Priority #1: Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals."

Project Title: Partnership for Regional Education Preparation (PREP-KC) application forDevelopment Grant to address Absolute Priority 3 (Innovations that Complementthe Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments)
Project Description: "PREP-KCs proposed program will expand and scale implementation of promising and innovative strategies toprepare urban students for success in college. Expansion will occur in an urban six-district ?footprint? in bistateKansas City and will increase the percentages of low-income students who enroll in post-secondaryeducation with the academic preparation necessary to succeed in college and the 21st century workforce. Thesestrategies will improve outcomes for Kansas City students while also improving the economic vitality of theKansas City region. Funds from the i3 grant would go to support and expand the following strategies (inpartnership with 4 post-secondary institutions and 6 districts collectively serving over 60,000 students):Standards-based Curriculum, Instruction, & Assessment (matching or exceeding state standards) which close thegap between minimum high school requirements and college-readiness. PREP-KCs standards initiative bringsstandardized curriculum assessments, instruction and grading to scale in middle and high school mathematics(and will expand to additional core content areas).Post-secondary Pathways which provide scaleable strategies to provide urban high school students withopportunity (and expectation) to complete rigorous college courses while simultaneously completing highschool. PREP-KC will expand post-secondary pathway strategies including: early college, STEM AcceleratedAcademies, and wrap-around supports to increase college preparation and college-going while decreasing theneed for remediation in college.Data-driven decision-making supported by a web-based Data Dashboard which tracks and analyzes data for eachschool district and high school to show longitudinal trend lines on formative and summative measures.
