TheDashboard tracks key outcomes and leading indicators which predict improvements or declines in studentoutcomes, making it possible to intervene proactively to remove barriers indicated by the data."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Partnersip Scholars Program
Project Description: "The project goal is to assure that bright but economically and culturally disadvantaged students are limited not by their environment but are assured of progressing to a level determined only by their own considerable talents to the end that they will be competitive for entry into four year colleges with scholarship aid. This is achieved by long-term (7th through 12th grades) intensive extracurricular mentoring. Our approach has been validated by the studies of the Johns Hopkins sociologist Karl Alexander which conclude that ,' virtually all of the advantage that bright wealthy students have over bright poor students is the result of differences in the way privileged children learn when they are not in school. Poor homes and communities do not have the resources, enrichment opportunities or activities  so that talented students can keep learning outside the formal classroom'.Our 15 year record strongly supports this conclusion and our remedy: Providing for our 7th through 12th grade 'scholars' what a middle class family would provide for their college-bound child. Please note that we accomplish this for a total cost per scholar over the six year program of $11,000 or an average of just $1830 per year /scholar.The volunteer mentor directs the program for his/her scholar and provides counseling, encouragement  and evaluation of the scholar's development as he/she progresses through the program.In addition to the individual mentors we have a volunteer College Coordinator at each venue to optimize the college admission process. Our 14 year record speaks for itself: We have inducted 507 7th graders; 229 are progressing in 7th through 12th grades; 188 have graduated from high school with a drop-out rate of zero and a entry rate to four year colleges of 94%; current scholarship/financial aid per scholar averages>$70,000 over 4 years. This record from public schools, where high school drop-out rates approach 40%, match those of the best private prep schools in the country."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Completion, Career, and College:  High School Success and Beyond
Project Description: "Pasadena Independent School District is the applicant for a partnership that includes Devers ISD, Laying the Foundation, and Rice University School Math Project and will implement a program of whole district reform called Completion, Career, and College:  High School Success and Beyond (C3).  C3 will significantly expose 51,513 K-12th grade high needs students to a culture of college and career readiness.  C3 will require five years to implement and continue beyond as it will result in whole district reforms rather than temporary programs.  C3 reforms will increase curriculum rigor and alignment to state and college standards at both Pasadena and Devers ISDs by:o	Aligning, deepening, and increasing the academic rigor and college alignment of K-12 math and implement a district-wide reading initiative;o	Expanding underserved student access to classes nationally recognized as preparatory for postsecondary, such as PreAP, AP, and Dual Credit; o	Accelerating students who are behind academically;o	Assessing student academic and college readiness.C3 will also significantly increase K-12 student and parent exposure to college and career readiness/awareness activities and experiences by:o	Continuously exposing K-12 students to a vision of pursuing college and careers. o	Continuously preparing K-12 parents to support college/career directed students.    Pasadena and Devers ISD will see improved student academic growth; achievement gaps closed; a decrease in dropout rates; an increase in high school graduation rates; and an increase in college enrollment and completion rates."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Pipeline to Excellence
Project Description: "The Pasadena Unified School District Pipeline to Excellence project is designed to meet the needs of the our significant population of English learners, with a particular focus on Long Term English Learners who have been in U.S. schools for six or more years, are underachieving, and although still in need, may not be receiving specialized services and instruction geared to ELs. Pipeline's research-based strategies of coaching, professional development to increase content knowledge and pedagogical skills, lesson study and the creation of professional learning communities have been recognized as best practices by the California Math and Science Partnership program. We will also provide coaching for effective principal leadership and strengthen the human resources infrastructure needed for successful implementation. Outcomes include teachers' improved instructional skills and use of effective strategies, especially for English learners; improved teacher content knowledge; and the creation of sustainable professional learning communities at middle schools facilitated by effective principals. Student outcomes include increased levels of proficiency for English learners and of all students in math and English language arts as measured by benchmark assessments and state standardized tests. The project is intended to reach 4,500 students in grades 6 through 8 and will be independently evaluated with dissemination of results for expansion into the high school level or replication.."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Turn-Up Columbus
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Imagine Learning: How to Use Beginning of Year, End of Year, and Benchmark Test Data to Strengthen Student Learning Gains During the School Year and to Design Individualized Instruction Programs to Stem Summer Learning Loss
Project Description: "Imagine Schools at Cortez Park will partner with 70 public charter schools nationwide (with 37,000 students) and Imagine Schools, Pearson, and others to validate our approach to using student data before, during, and after the school year to empower teachers to individualize instruction and to give school leaders information to assess teacher and school performance and adjust. Cortez Park is a diverse school, with 82% minority students, 30% English language learners, and 90% qualifying for free/reduced price meals. There will be extensive professional development for teachers and principals on use of data to inform individualized instruction. With this approach, 78% of the partner schools? students have exceeded national learning gain norms for math and 67% for reading. Two-thirds of students in the combined 71 schools have attained learning gains above the national norm.The project includes validation of a data-driven summer enrichment program to counteract the summer achievement loss that erodes learning gains attained during the school year and particularly affects needy students. Forty schools will be randomly selected for the summer program. They will provide a five-week individualized, inquiry-based program to students utilizing the PC Plus instructional system.Evaluation of the school year program will compare learning gains of the students at the 71 partner schools with national norms, compare summer students learning gains with the control group, and gather information from teachers and school leaders to improve the professional development and results. It will aim to improve the program and to extract a set of best practices and lessons learned to inform project replication.The schools expect to directly reach 100,000 or more students collectively with this program, and we intend a broad outreach program that could persuade thousands of schools serving millions of students to benefit from the program."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Economic Development through Educational Attainment (EDEA)
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: PCSD Professional Learning Communities (PLC):  Expanding Your Horizons
Project Description: "Paulding County Schools (PCSD) proposes to implement an Investing in Innovation Development Grant to benefit the educators and students of our district.  The proposed initiative will provide an innovative professional learning program designed to increase the percentage of highly-effective teachers within the district and enhance the academic achievement of our students. Specific goals of the project include:  1) To improve the academic achievement of PCSD students; 2) To improve the academic achievement of PCSD special needs students; and 3) To enhance the effectiveness of PCSD administrators and teachers.The proposed project will reach a minimum of 28,350 PCSD students annually through a comprehensive approach for improvement that integrates technology-driven, standards-based teacher training, targeted assessment aligned with learning standards, and peer engagement to create an academic environment that focuses on reaching every student through every lesson.  Implemented in collaboration with our private sector partner, School Improvement Network, the project will provide an on-demand library of professional teacher learning resources that utilizes technology to effectively deliver professional research-based training, will allow teachers continuous access to individualized support on a variety of relevant topics to improve the effectiveness of their classrooms.  In addition, administrators will utilize a specially designed application for teacher observations that will allow them to accurately address all aspects of the assessment and immediately provide teachers with prescriptive guidance on recommended professional learning trainings that they can access to address issues identified during the observation.  Finally, peer modeling will be implemented through instructional learning segments designed to document effective strategies and share them with educators throughout the district and beyond."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Alternative High School:  Developing 21st Century Citizens
Project Description: "As part of an effort to achieve district mission and goals the Paulding County School District (PCSD) seeks the Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Development Grant to establish the 'Alternative High School: Developing 21st Century Citizens' program. The AHSD-21 program is designed to increase the overall graduation rate among high school students to one hundred percent (100%) during the five-year time frame of this grant. A total of 594 high school students will be served through the AHSD-21 Program. A breakdown of student enrollment includes: year one: eighty (11th and 12th) grade students enrolled; year two: ninety-six (9th and 12th ) grade students enrolled; year three: one hundred and fifteen (9th and 12th ) grade students enrolled;  year four: one hundred and thirty-eight (9th and 12th ) grade students enrolled; year five: one hundred and sixty-five  (9th and 12th ) grade students enrolled. Total students enrolled for year(s) one through five equals 594.  The AHSD-21 program addresses Absolute Priority #3: Innovation that Complement the Implementation of High Standard and High Quality Assessments and provides an online school program for high school students that have become disengaged with the traditional classroom setting. The program will also, through the collaboration between the school district and community leaders, 'Support College Access and Success' (Competitive Preference Priority #6)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Gamers to Graduates
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Peers Making Peace/Positive Action Centers i3 Validation Grant Program
Project Description: "PaxUnited, Inc., a non-profit organization, in partnership with approximately twenty (20) Local Education Agencies (LEAs) in twenty (20) States and Territories are proposing to implement the Peers Making Peace, Positive Action Centers Program (PMP/PAC) on school campuses identified as ?persistently lowest-achieving schools? as determined by each state and as described in the Investing In Innovative Fund (i3) Grant Program, 84.396B Validation grants.The innovative approach combining peer mediation and peer mentoring services is the only researched-based program that has been recognized by four Federal Agencies: OJJDP as a Model Program, the USDE, Office of Safe and Drug-Free Schools as a Promising Program, the Center For Substance Abuse Prevention as an Exemplary Program and SAMHSA?s, National Registry for Evidenced-Based Programs and Practices as a Legacy Program.  PaxUnited, Inc. and its partners address Absolute Priority 4, Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools, with a targeted approach to address non-academic barriers to student achievement and also, Competitive Preference Priorities 7 & 8 addressing Limited English Proficient students and rural students.  The Goals and objectives of the program include: increasing academic achievement scores and increasing graduation/promotion rates for students from urban and rural schools and Limited English Proficient students, from 15-25% over the five-year project period.  Also, to decrease the achievement gap, decrease drop out, retention and absenteeism rates, and decrease disciplinary referrals for violence and substance abuse.A conservative number of 231,000 students will be impacted by implementing the PMP/PAC program over the five-year period.  An independent project evaluator, using a Quasi-Experimental design, resulting in a wealth of reportable data, will conduct a longitudinal study."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Catch the Next College Access Project (CTN)
Project Description: "CTN validates and expands the approach of the Puente Project, a transformational educational program that works within public high schools to double the rate of college enrollment, improve academic performance, raise educational aspirations, and support college graduation for Latino and other high-need youth.  The Puente Project works through participating school districts to coordinate implementation, galvanize student interest, engage parents, and support educational and community goals.  A key program component is initial and continuing professional development for teachers and counselors who deliver the program to mixed-ability, selected students in preponderantly Latino high schools. CTN leverages Puente's proven approach and success in the Hayward School District, our LEA partner and leading demonstration site, with the resources of PBS Education and CTN, Inc., with the introduction of digital classroom tools, social media platforms for educator and student peer support, and online professional development. This facilitates expansion to a wide variety of school settings, brings costs down to a scalable level, and makes key resources universally available..?????"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Access and Achievement for All
Project Description: "Pearland ISD proposes to build an infrastructure of access that can bridge the gap to high achievement for  28,947students with the potential to reach over 500,000 students within the five year timeline of the grant.  In order to provide extensive professional development in partnership with two other school districts and  the CollegeBoard. The  primary outcome of increased college readiness for all students will be achieved through  intensive professional development, use of assessment data, incorporation of a rigorous college readiness curriculum, and the establishment of partnerships across parents, communities, and schools.  Special project features include a Parent Champion who will serve as a liaison between school and home, extensive counselor training, summer college readiness camps, and the development of virtual communications that connect students to teachers outside their home campuses.  It is understood that before students can meet a high standard for achievement, they must first have access to a rigorous curriculum, teachers must have access to appropriate and meaningfulprofessional development, counselors must have the access and ability to interpret data and assist parents and students as they negotiate a path to higher learning, parents must have access to information in their nativelanguage, and administartors must have access to a professional."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Pay it "Four"ward
Project Description: "Peoria Unified School District's project, Pay it 'Four'ward, will implement a variety of techniques and methods to help distinct target populations, low-income, second language learners and sepcial education preschoolers, enter kindergarten at a more level playing field with their more privileged or typically developing peers. Through staff development around increasing language and literacy in the preschool environment and curriculum and through extending implementation of the distric's focus on Response to Intervention to the preschool level, the PUSD preschool program will expand the existing collaboration between special education and general education at the preschool level which will benefit all preschoolers, not just those identified as at-risk. This will be achieved through a full inclusion, mixed age preschool model with side-by-side special education and general education classrooms on elementary school campuses. Additionally, teachers will learn to collect and analyze data to effeectively implement lessons and interventions that align to each student's individual need. PUSD cureently serves nearly 1,000 three- and four-year-olds each year, but waiting lists tell us that the need is not fully met. Nearly 2300 students enter kindergarten each fall. Pay it 'Four'ward will expand current programming and allow more preschoolers to learn from their peers in classrooms guided by a staff proficient in their understanding of how young children learn best. Through this intensive intervention when a child's brain is most pliable, the district will have fewer children entering kindergarten on IEPs or with the need of specialized placement in English Language Development classes. This full inclusion model has the endorsement of the Arizona Department of Education. As an official partner, Southwest Institute for Families and Children will provide evaluation and professional development services."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Project PD4ME
Project Description: "Project PD4ME will roll oiut in the 8 scihools during tihe first year of tihe grant, adding 22 Title I schools in the second year, and the remainder of the district schools (70 total) in tihe third iyear of tihe grant period.  Activities will include a scaled approach to training all sstaff on PD 360 in a compreihensive standards-based instructional framework, which will be tightly linked to resources in PD 360 so tihat all training received will lbe reinforced, supported, ongoing, and job-embedded through on-demand technologly.  The PD 360 mobile application from Scihoiol Improvement Network, used with an iPad or Blackberry handheld device, permits a principal coach, or mentor to conduct an observation of instruction.  The observation data is linked to programmed content in PD 360, which will include state and district learning standards and targets, and given tihe instructional staff prescriptive giuidance on needed professional development (PD)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: C2 + M=R (CollegeCareer + Math = Readiness) Initiative
Project Description: "AbstractPerry County School District located in rural West Alabama proposes to implement the C2 +M=R (College and Career + Math = Readiness) Initiative. The scope of this Development Grant would be targeted toward the improvement of student achievement of the (800) iGeneration students in grades 7-12 who are 100% African American and attend the Title I (95% poverty level) High Schools; Francis Marion High School/Robert C. Hatch High School, through extended learning time and access to innovative technology. Perry County Schools propose to improve achievement in Persistently Low-performing Schools in the area of mathematics by 6% at the end of a (3) year period. [Absolute Priority 4]  In order to increase College Access, a partnership with Wallace State Community College and proposed funding will allow forty (40) first generation college students per year, in the district's two high schools, to receive a scholarship to begin college math coursework onsite, before graduation. The initiative also includes an innovative extended learning opportunity. Students may attend the summer iPad (Increasing Perry's Academic Deficiency) Academy which will focus on improving math skills through project based learning, exposure to 21st Century technology, a career and college theme including onsite weekly visits, and a technology incentive. Students who complete the Academy are given the use of an iPad computer, eReader, iPod and Internet access in their home for the school year. [Competitive Priority 6] To retain teachers in the rural, low performing district, the initiative also proposes to strengthen inexperienced teachers' skills by hiring a district Math Coach and purchasing STI Achievement Services to work collaboratively with the math departments on creating and implementing innovative lessons, math assessments, modeling, providing job embedded professional development, using data to drive instruction and infusing technology into project based learning in an Open Lab setting"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Perspectives Charter Schools' College for Certain Education Model
Project Description: "Perspectives Charter Schools' College for Certain Education Model Development Application for the Investing in Innovations Fund (i3)  addresses Absolute Priority 3:  Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments and Competitive Preference Priority 6:  Innovations that Support College Access and Success.Research demonstrates that academic and college readiness standards-based curriculum and assessments can increase college access and success.  We are requesting $5 million for a three-year development grant project to further refine the design of, further evaluate, document and disseminate Perspectives Charter Schools' research-based successful College for Certain Education Model in order that it might become replicable and transferable to our official partner, The Chicago Public Schools, and to other schools and districts.  Perspectives Charter Schools College for Certain Education Model demonstrates that high graduation, college enrollment and persistence rates can be achieved for economically disadvantaged, underserved populations of students.  The innovations that Perspectives Charter Schools has developed result in our greatest outcome - 89 percent of our students graduate on time, more than 90 percent of our students enroll in college and today 76 percent are still enrolled.?????"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: i3 at PHASE 4
Project Description: "PHASE 4 has provided alternative educational opportunities to at-rist students at their Learning Centers since 2003. In partnership with two LEAs, PHASE 4 will use these developmental funds to diversify its educational opportunities, by developing the curicular and co-curicular activites necessary to offer academic tracks: postsecondary, work-ready and miltiary-ready. At the same time, PHASE 4 will develop a program for families of these at-risk students; and will develop a Charter School model based on the PHASE 4 approach. All materials will be accessable to students with disabilities and limited English Language profeciency. The challenge of offering these programs to rural LEAs will be attacked. In addition to the development phase of this project, there is a growth phase. All of the materials developed by the specialist teams assembled for this project, PHASE 4 will increase the number of Learning Centers from 6 in PA to 19 nationwide. Teachers and staff at these additional centers will be trained at the PHASE 4 Training Institute. Once these centers have been operational for one year, they are completely and financially selfsustaining. Each Center will have a program (Family Power Center) which will encourage the involvement of parents in the learning community.Lastly, there will be a research component to this project that will support independent experiment reseach on the effectiveness (validity) of the PHASE 4 approach."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: CSTEM High School Summer Intensive
Project Description: "The CSTEM - High School Summer Intensive Program is being modeled after some proven southern state(Tennessee, Georgia) programs; called Governor?s Academies. The Governor Academies are residentialprograms for high school youth held on their University campuses. Thus, this application for a developmentgrant request; to develop this program for the future use of our state, and to show that a working model couldexist and be used for our high school students? future. The CSTEM - High School Summer Intensive programwill be an in-residence summer academy which will be held at the Arizona State University Polytechnic Campus.Through the program, the student population of 9th ? 11th graders, while transitioning to their next grade, canchoose from one, and or up to three, academic foci within the STEM disciplines. This in-residence summeracademy at Arizona State University Polytechnic Campus allows high school students to choose an academicfocus or career track to immerse themselves in exploration, skills building, and college-readiness. Sampleworkshops and tracks include Medical Symposium, Math and Science Honors, Game and Cartoon Animation,Engineering Symposium, Roller-Coaster Design, Digital Game Intensive, Digital Art, Robotics, Accounting, etc.Students will be able to choose 2-week, 4-week or 6-week specialty career tracks.--Graph--Additional themes or alternative workshops can be considered based on 1) availability of faculty on any givensummer 2) changing combinations of subjects and/or 3) integrating new related issues in the field e.g. global andenvironmental sustainability, science and the law, business and engineering, architecture, bioengineering. Withthis structure and varied content topics, this summer intensive program will provide students with the followingoptions of stay and experience. Expected participation during grant period is projected below.--Graph--"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Systems Thinking in Schools:  Promoting and Assessing 21st Cnetury Thining Skills
Project Description: "Knowing the power of systems thinking to improve the critical thinking of all learners, especially those at-risk students who have had greater difficulty fully engaging in traditional classrooms, the Waters Foundation in conjunction with the Pima County School Reserve ESA will build teacher capacity throughout Pima County to develop and use formative assessments to improve student achievement on state tests.  The infusion of this innovative practice will ensure students make connections, see learning in a larger context thereby increasing transfer, recognize multiple perspectives and identify patterns and trends. Over the course of this grant participants will collect and analyze assessment data on 15,000 students, in order to systematically and reliably examine the impact of systems thinking on overall achievement, language development, and preparation of students for advanced courses of study. Over 500 teachers will be trained in methods that increase student engagement thus improving student achievement on rigorous academic standards.  Each of these teachers will benefit from one-on-one mentoring to ensure application of the methods and to increase personal reflection on student work, tracking student progress to increase achievement.  The long term result of this i3 project will be valid, reliable data showing the impact of systems thinking on student learning and making available the application of these engaging methods for all students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovations Supporting Teachers and Schools
Project Description: "Innovations Supporting Teachers and Schools (an Investing in Innovation Development grant program) will provide targeted, strategic interventions and service to more than 6,700 students in the state of Georgia.  Our innovative design utilizes the deployment of coordinated grade level professional teaching and learning team meetings (TLTM module).  In addition to correlation procedures which gauge the reliability and validity of the module, the process ensures the precise coordination of: (1) consensus on common pacing, (2) selecting state standards to be taught, (3) creation of common assessments, (4) determination of instructional strategies, (5) analyzing data for formative corrections, (6) and determination of re-teaching and reassessment for final mastery of grade level content.  The initiative will result in building collaborative networks and improved social capacity in schools yielding significant increases in the number of teachers and leaders who are highly effective especially for teachers of high-need students, improving student engagement and significantly reducing the high school cohort dropout rate.  Project goals are subdivided by performance objectives of (1) identifying effective and ineffective teachers, (2) supporting teachers and principals in schools by implementing evidence-based outcomes and practices through implementing a balanced instructional coaching model and significantly improving teaching and learning practices, (3) improving educator practices to improve the academic performance of students with disabilities and Limited English Proficient (LEP) students in reading and math, (4) facilitating outreach strategies for parents and communities to increase engagement, (5) develop improved self-awareness and leadership in the students with disabilities and LEP identified as at-risk for dropping out of school.  Partners include Clemson University, The Houghton Mifflin Company, Achievement Link, Inc., Institute for Education Innovation."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: 21st Century Science Connect Initiative
Project Description: "The ?21st Century Science Connect Initiative? is a unique partnership between the Piper, USD 203, theSoutheast Kansas Education Service Center, the Center for Learning Tree Institute Discovery Education, and441 elementary schools throughout the state of Kansas. The Science Connect Initiative addresses AbsolutePriority 3 ? Innovations that complement the implementations of high standards and high-quality assessments.In addition, this project addresses the following competitive preference priority - #8 Innovations that serveschools in rural LEAs. This project will accomplish the following goals, reaching more than 113,000 studentsacross Kansas.Goal 1. Develop and increase teacher and school leadership effectiveness.Goal 2: Develop a comprehensive instructional reform utilizing data.Goal 3: Provide Technical Assistance and Sustained Support."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project Rural: Rural teachers Unite to Reach All Learners
Project Description: "Project RURAL: Rural teachers Unite to Reach All LearnersThe overall goal of Project RURAL is to increase the number of highly qualified teachers with effective teaching skills who will close the academic achievement gap of students and commit to teaching in a rural LEA for a minimum of three years. The 60-month RURAL Project is aligned with Absolute Priority #1: Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals and Competitive Preference Priority #8: Innovations that Serve Schools in Rural LEAs. Sixteen rural school districts and the Pittsburg (KS) State University Teacher Education program formed a partnership to meet the needs of rural schools.  Four strategies were specifically chosen, some of which have proven successful in urban settings or have been promising but not adopted in this powerful combination in rural schools.1 Develop Professional Development School (PSD) Partnerships with rural LEAs and PSU  2 Participate in Year-Long Internship (Student Teaching) and Earn Multiple Endorsements.  3 Integrate a Focus on the Rural School Cultural Context in Courses and Internship 4 Conduct One-on-one Induction/Mentoring Program and Professional Development via Distance Learning The evaluation will employ an experimental design (participants randomly assigned to experimental and control groups) and will rely on inferential statistical methods to analyze the data to ascertain whether or not a difference exists between the outcome for the experimental group and the control group.  Teacher candidates will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:  an intervention group (specialized teacher preparation curriculum focusing on the learning needs of rural students and multiple certifications/endorsements, year-long internship in a rural  Professional School Partnership school, specialized induction experience for first three years of teaching that includes mentoring and targeted, individualized professional development) OR a comparison group."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Empowerment Tools for Community Schools
California Rural and Small School District Improvement Consortium
Project Description: "A system-focused reform support organization, Pivot Learning Partners (PLP) proposes to create a California Rural and Small School District Improvement Consortium for an Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Validation grant with a focus on Absolute Priority 2 (Innovations that Improve the Use of Data). Pivot Learning Partners will serve a statewide network of high-need small, rural, and medium-sized rural-serving school districts by validating Pivot Learning Partners' research-based data-based decision-making program, the Cycle of Inquiry (COI).                                                           By providing participating districts with data and assessment tools to drive the COI and improve the use of data, along with the professional development and ongoing coaching educators need to use the COI process to improve teaching and learning, the Consortium aims to create a collaborative infrastructure providing new communities of practice in which small and rural districts can build their capacity to address common problems, effect changes in school culture and leadership practices, and significantly improve student outcomes.PLP will partner with five California local education agencies (LEAs) to serve as Official Lead District Partners, Ukiah and Central Unified School Districts, Palmdale and Lancaster School Districts, and the Imperial County Office of Education, which enroll approximately 58,000 high-need students in isolated and rural settings. An estimated seventy-five additional small LEAs in regional clusters will join the Consortium as part of this five-year project as Supporting Partners. Taken together, the California Improvement Consortium will serve an estimated 180,000 students across California. PLP will also work with other partners, the Small School District Association (SSDA), to support the management and coordination of these small LEA Consortium members, and School Wise Press (SWP) in the design and delivery of data and assessment services... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Placencia Yorba Linda Unifed School District
Project Title: Project iLearn
Project Description: "Project iLearn is an i3 development grant that scales up innovative practices in a research-based, multi-tiered Response to Intervention system.  Current implementation yields compelling results in the reduction of special education referrals and increases in the number of students meeting grade level standards in Reading by at-risk subgroups.  This project has two goals: 1) Analyze and utilize data to inform decision making and improve student achievement, and 2) Address the unique learning needs of students with disabilities, English learners, and children age three to five.  Project objectives and outcomes validate that 1) interventions targeted to student needs will raise achievement for high need students and reduce referrals to special education, 2) the use of standards-aligned assessment data improves teaching and learning, 3) high quality early childhood programs increase school readiness and success, and 4) interactive technologies increase student motivation and engagement to advance student achievement.  A strategic plan addresses the following areas:The use of data to inform instructionA K-8 multi-tiered Response to Intervention (RtI) modelThe use of interactive technology in classrooms to motivate studentsAdditional School Readiness preschool classes for early intervention and to allow students with disabilities and English learners addition access to preschoolThe creation of a two-year developmental 'Preppy K' kindergarten programContinued professional collaboration through professional learning communitiesInnovative leadership at the district, site, and project levelsThe project further develops iLearn district wide, and, along with systematic documentation and evaluation, will result in a model that can be replicated in other P-8 educational settings."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Plato Academy on behalf of Schools Leadership Consortium, Citizens Alliance for Progress & R'Club, Inc.
Project Title: 360 DEGREE LEADERSHIP PROGRAM
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Making Community Connections-MC2
Project Description: "PlusTime NH and QED Foundation propose to develop and implement the Making Community Connections (MC2) Multiple Pathways system to effectively deliver the most academically rigorous learning for the greatest numbers of students, particularly those students least likely to have access to those opportunities. MC2 will feature an online portal that coordinates design, implementation and assessment of high quality learning opportunities. Students will be able to develop a personal learning plan, identify ELO options, match state and national standards, request a teacher-coach with expertise in the ELO competencies, and document learning through a variety of formative assessment tools and performance-based assessments. The online portal will be designed to be user friendly, paying particular attention to graphics, readability, and language, with a dynamic and engaging interface.A key strategy of MC2 is to provide ongoing support, monitoring, and feedback for all parties. Teachers and community partners in both LEAs will receive training and ongoing professional support. An accountability plan will be collaboratively developed; performance indicators will be established and monitored for students, teachers, community partners, and MC2 Coordinators; and metrics and data systems will be implemented from the outsetThe primary premise of the MC2 system is a shift from the ?batch and queue? model of public schooling to ?continuous flow?, where learners progress and graduate based on mastery of competencies, rather than time. This provides essential flexibility for systematically responding to specific needs of all learners. A second key premise is that implementing high standards and high quality assessments requires students to engage directly with understanding the content and skills needed to meet those standards and to co-design work that enlists them in mastering academically rigorous and relevant content and skills."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: New England Network for Personalization and Performance (NETWORK)
Project Description: "The New England Network for Personalization and Performance (NETWORK), described in the following pages, represents a truly innovative approach to preparing and motivating students for postsecondary success. Our hypothesis is:  A network of schools, working together to create authentic tasks and common rubrics to measure uncommon assessment tasks, will foster personalized learning resulting in higher student achievement, as demonstrated by lower dropout rates, higher graduation rates and demonstrable success after high school.  Our challenge (and the innovation) is to puzzle out how to transform existing, comprehensive high schools into schools where learning is personalized for all students.  The NETWORK builds on the promising work and proven results of the New York Performance Standards Consortium (Consortium), applying that work to new settings and with new populations.  By the end of the fifth project year, every student in every network school will have participated in at least two personalized, inquiry-based experiences and demonstrated mastery through performance assessment (and some will have participated in more).   Students experiencing and participating in these uncommon learning and assessment tasks (with common scoring) will have a much greater likelihood of graduation and success in college and career.The New England Network for Personalization and Performance (NETWORK) is made up of thirteen high schools (close to 11,000 students) across four New England states - Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: HandsOn Schools
Project Description: "Overview'Our school is a better place. It presents all of us with different opportunities to help each other and our community. It does not matter if you are a rich kid or a poor kid or what kind of shoes you wear. The program teaches us that we all have something to give: time, talent, treasure; they all matter just the same.'                                                                                                              HandsOn Schools Participant, Newark, NJThere is an undeniable crisis in America's education system. Schools are being forced to seek out innovative solutions to this growing crisis while simultaneously coping with ongoing financial issues. HandsOn Schools looks to address this crisis by offering a model that engages students in high-quality service-learning and improves the academic climate by supporting teachers and reconnecting the school to the community. This low-cost model leverages the time and talent of parents and community members to increase school capacity through guided engagement and volunteerism, and also impacts K-12 students directly through classroom curriculum and hands on service-learning.  HandsOn Schools works with districts to engage teachers and schools by providing national and onsite support. The model's approach combines teacher training in curriculum-integrated service-learning with intensive training and program support to school and community volunteer Service Leaders. Service Leaders play a powerful role as change agents who develop service opportunities, mobilize and train others.HandsOn Network, Children for Children, and The LEAGUE have joined forces to create a movement igniting the power of young people called HandsOn Schools. HandsOn Schools transforms the academic and life success of students by uniting the collective resources of students, teachers, parents, and communities through service and service-learning."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Pathways to success
Project Description: "Portland Public Schools is requesting $11,223,531 under the i3 Validation grant for its Pathways to Success proposal targeting Portland High School.The project seeks to validate the Talent Development High School model developed by Johns Hopkins University?s Center for Social Organization of Schools. The project will feature: small learning communities created by use of interdisciplinary teams for 9th and 10th graders, and Career Pathways for 11th & 12th graders; heterogeneous groupings; expanded use of looping; extended school day/year programming to provide additional learning time, especially for students who are English language learners (ELL), those with disabilities, and students who are at risk of dropping out; strong planning and professional development for faculty to support changes in school structure and instructional practice; and school-wide conversion to standards-based assessment.This is a whole school change project whose goal is to improve outcomes for PHS students who are ELL, have disabilities, or are at-risk of dropping out. Project objectives include improving average attendance from 84% to 92%; increasing school completion rate from 74.1 to 90%; increasing by 10% annually the percent of ELL who receive a 3 or better on the ACCESS test; and helping PHS achieve adequate yearly progress (AYP). The project will serve about 912 students annually or about 1,900 unduplicated students over 5-years. Approximately 956 (50%) will be students who are ELL, have disabilities, and/or are performing at a low level and at-risk of dropping out.Special features include an ELL population with over 40 languages, and an initiative that has made laptops available to every high school student. The project partner, LearningWorks (LW), is a 501c3 offering alternative education, vocational instruction, and case management services to high school drop-outs. Under this proposal LW will partner with PHS to strengthen and expand extended school day/year programming."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: To Ride Alongside a Light Beam
Project Description: "The project submitted, 'To Ride alongside a Light Beam', will address needs of the two lowest-achieving elementary schools in Portland Schools with significant numbers of Limited English Proficient (LEP) students - Riverton and East End Elementary Schools. (At Riverton, 46% of students are LEP; at East End, 39% are LEP.) Portland, a federal refugee resettlement area, supports a very diverse public school population, 28% of students, out of a total of 6,938, are Limited English Proficient (LEP), speaking more than 50 different languages. (Since Fall, 2009, Portland schools have enrolled 432 new refugee and immigrant students who alone speak 31 of the 50 languages in the system.)For our refugee and immigrant students, the need to adopt a new country derives from severely traumatic situations. Displacement brings not only the joys of living in a free and democratic society, but also heartaches, loneliness, poverty and many other challenges. The Portland schools will help their students meet these extraordinary challenges by offering an innovative and sustainable instrumental music program that combines the best of the Portland Symphony Orchestra (PSO), and the Portland Youth Symphony Orchestra (PYSO) with Portland Public Schools' music educators, beginning in grade 3 and expanding to grades 4 and 5 in subsequent years. In partnership with the PSO and PYSO, Portland educators will institute the 'El Sistema' model of music education, a positive, innovative and creative model, proven for its effectiveness in Venezuela and other countries. The approach will provide more time for students in grades three through five to learn instrumental music by increasing the school day to provide daily instrumental music instruction in ensemble experiences. Research shows that disadvantaged youth who participate in this intense instrumental program, with music ensembles being the key to learning and performing, improve academically, behaviorally, and raise education aspirations."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Clean Energy Academy
Project Description: "Colorado's focus on a Clean Energy Economy balances energy conservation with a broader mission to expand renewable and clean energy resources that will build the state's economy.  Poudre School District is poised to participate in this plan with the creation of three high school Clean Energy Academies, offering students pathways to energy and other science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) careers through a rigorous and relevant curriculum. Each Academy will enroll 100 students in the 9th grade in 2011-12, with the eventual involvement of 1200 students in grades 9-12 at all schools by 2014. The pathway will include targeted enrollment by students who will benefit most from an engaging, project-based learning experience, including minority students, English Language Learners, and economically disadvantaged students. Front Range Community College, Colorado State University and energy-based businesses throughout the community will be involved in the project implementation. The overall goals of the proposed Clean Energy Academy are:1.	To develop a high school Clean Energy Academy that will implement high standards of design-based contextual learning in the delivery of STEM coursework based on clean energy related content.2.	To implement a Clean Energy Academy that builds student preparedness and 21st Century skills for success in college and other post-secondary programs.3.	To implement a Clean Energy Academy that targets English Language Learners and economically disadvantaged students in order to improve their academic outcomes, close the achievement gap in core content areas, decrease the drop-out rate and increase their college and career-readiness."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Improving Student Achievement through Student-engaged Academic Planning and Computer Adaptive Assessments
Preclarus Mastery Academy
Project Description: "Project Description: Preclarus Mastery Academy is a 5th-12th grade charter public school seeking to serve low-income and high-needs students in the city of St. Louis. The school will open Fall 2011, with a de-tracking (High Honors Only) program aimed to promote academic success and eliminate the achievement gap for high-needs students. Ultimately, students will perform beyond grade-level proficiency and graduate from the nation?s top colleges. Through extensive on-site research of the nation?s top-performing public schools ? some of which utilize ?Honors Only? and de-tracking curriculum, Preclarus will implement the best practices regarding curriculum, teaching, and classroom culture to most effectively implement an environment of excellence and accomplish academic success.Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: Preclarus? mission is to fully equip low-income students with the academic, social, leadership and character qualities needed to enter into and graduate from top universities. Objectives include 80% of all 8th grade students achieving ?Proficient? or ?Advanced? status in algebra, 80% of all students enrolled for more than 3 years achieving ?Proficient? or ?Advanced? status on state issued and/or comprehensive exams, 95% of all 11th grade students scoring above the national average on the ACT, and 95% of all graduating seniors enrolling at a Preclarus ?Preferred College.? In the long-run, Preclarus will become a gold standard for educational excellence.Target number of Students to be Served: 320 (initially)Special Project Features: The Preclarus model includes a de-tracking curriculum specifically designed to bring all high-needs students through a single, ?High-Honors? program. Supporting features include post-secondary support for high school graduates, more time on task through a longer school day, and grade promotion based on mastery of core standards."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: President and Fellows of Harvard College
Project Title: Capital Gains 2.0
Project Description: "In partnership with The District of Columbia Public Schools, The Education Innovation Laboratory at HarvardUniversity proposes to oversee the design, implementation, and execution of Capital Gains 2.0, an input-basedstudent incentives program for middle and high school students. Capital Gains 2.0 aims to boost academicachievement by providing cash incentives to students for inputs of their achievement to the educationproduction function including metrics for attendance, behavior and grades. CG2.0 exploits the success ofEdLabs? past incentives trial in Chicago, Dallas, New York City, and Washington DC. Conclusions of the trialproved student achievement could be improved, as measured by standardized tests. The effect of participatingin the incentive program was consistent with successful reforms of recent decades, however, financialincentives were shown to have a considerably lower cost"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: President and Fellows of Harvard College
Project Title: Project READS: Using Data to Promote Summer Reading and Close the Achievement Gap for Low-SES Students in North Carolina
Project Description: "The proposed project will address Absolute Priority 2-Innovations that Improve the Use of Data. The applicant organization, Harvard University, will work with the Durham (NC) Public Schools (DPS), Communities in Schools of North Carolina (CIS), a non profit organization, and other partners to implement, validate, and scale up an innovative approach to combating summer loss among low-income children. The Project-called READS (Reading Enhances Achievement During Summer)-provides children with books during the summer and promotes summer reading with teacher and parent 'scaffolding.' In implementing READS, districts must adopt a set of data use strategies that inform decision-making and help to improve student achievement, such as examining spring to fall achievement gains or losses and using the results of student surveys and achievement tests to select books that are well matched to students' reading skills and interests.   The proposed project has three phases: Phase 1 Validation, which includes testing READS in several districts including DPS and an effort to increase the effectiveness and cost effectiveness of the program; Phase 2 Validation, which involves expansion into more districts and many more schools and testing the cumulative impact of READS across summers; and Phase 3 Scale-Up, which involves expansion into 20 more districts. In Phase 1 Validation, an independent evaluator will a) conduct two experiments that test the effects of the READS program that was implemented previously and an enhanced version of it, and b) analyze the cost effectiveness of the basic and enhanced versions of READS to identify the most cost effective version. In Phase 2 Validation, the evaluator will a) conduct an experimental test of the cumulative effects (across 2 summers) of the most cost-effective version of READS (CE READS) in as many as 10 school districts, and b) compare achievement growth in the summer and school year for students who received CE R"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Improving Writing with My Access
Project Description: "Preston Public Schools is proposing a project that will provide middle school students in grades 6-8 with an online writing program that will help to improve the writing skills of all students, preparing them for the skills necessary to go on to college.  Partnering with Vantage Learning, the district will provide 3 years of student subscriptions to the program as well as ongoing professional development and suppot for teachers.  The online writing program helps teachers to differentiate for each student because it instantly provides feedback on student strengths and weaknesses.  Teachers can tailor instruction according to needs using the provided data from the program.  Students will also instantly see how they did and receive detailed reports on how to improve their writing."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: C-STEM
Project Description: "Prince William County Public Schools will offer comprehensive course offerings in hands-on STEM content areas, coupled with intensive outreach efforts, to result in larger numbers of students voluntarily participating in STEM classes, larger numbers of students viewing STEM as a career path, and larger numbers of students graduating to pursue further STEM education.  Activities will focus around three main areas:  Robotics, VA STAR (computer building and repair) and Industry Partnerships.  Through C-STEM, PWCS has designed a plan that will expand these three separate offerings while harmoniously blending them as exceptional approaches and best practices into a replicable curriculum.  The C-STEM project will increase high-needs students' progress toward college and career readiness by exposing students to all levels of high performing, high needs careers targeting those living in poverty, those speaking a language other than English in their home, and those at-risk of becoming juvenile delinquents.  PWCS will expand these project-based and inquiry-based offerings within its own division, as well as reach beyond its boundaries to six neighboring and rural divisions that are less fortunate.  The Careers on Wheels bus, a repurposed school bus that will serve as a mobile educational outreach tool, will visit each of these neighboring divisions as a C-STEM kick-off event - delivering exciting, hands-on STEM career field education opportunities to underserved students throughout Northern Virginia."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: HEART After School Program Training and Supplemental Funding Project
Project Description: "This grant application is based on theories and practices that support two key influencers of student academicachievement in the out of school hours: ongoing, effective staff development and supplemental funding to payfor ongoing training.The overall goals of this project are: 1) Improve program quality and results by identifying and testing bestpractices and competencies for After School Program paraprofessionals and managers, and implementing aprocess that ensures education and training are accessible throughout California, later expanding to a nationallevel; and 2) Identify and disseminate proven financial models for ASPs that use supplemental funds to sustainand ensure effective staff professional development, for improved student academic achievement.The project will use the HEART After School Program training and supplemental funding models, compare themto those of other successful after school programs that have achieved demonstrated improvement to studentacademic achievement, and develop the following:1. Identify after school worker competencies and develop and disseminate a paraprofessional curriculum andcertification process through distance learning methodology, for easy accessibility to workers;2. Develop a training and coaching curriculum to be used onsite with after school workers, and complete 'Trainthe Trainer' programs throughout California3. Identify and disseminate supplemental funding models for after school programs which increase programs'capacity to afford and provide ongoing training and professional development to staff, to ensure academicgains by students in after school programs."

Project Title: PAGE Principals Leadership Network
Project Description: "The PAGE Principals Leadership Network, designed for talented, future-oriented Georgia principals, deepens principals' knowledge, capability, and confidence to lead change on behalf of students across the state. Principals who join the network desire to redefine the principalship in ways that make student engagement and profound student learning the driving purpose in their schools, the force behind well-reasoned decisions, and the shaper of practices throughout their schools. As participating principals, leaders recognize that new models for principal leadership will guide them to become leaders of leaders in their schools, where teachers are deeply respected and supported in becoming leaders, designers, and guides to instruction. Invited principals make a two-year commitment and join a cohort of thirty colleagues similarly driven by a desire to make a lasting difference for public education in Georgia."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Teacher Academy Expansion
Project Description: "Expansion of the Professional Association of Georgia Educators' Teacher Academy to provide for a campus in Macon to serve the needs of 42 primarily low-resourced rural south Georgia school systems serving a high concentration of low income students (70 percent and above on free and reduced-price lunches).  Over the past six years, the PAGE Teacher Academy has demonstrated remarkable success in preventing talented novice teachers from leaving the profession.   A primary goal of the new two-year Academy program is the professional development of novice teachers so they will be more effective in the classroom, view teaching as a rewarding and long-term career and assume transformational leadership roles in creating a culture of change in the profession and in the schools where they teach. Emphasis is placed on high-potential novice teachers with demonstrated leadership capabilities observed by local principals and school superintendents."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Building Respectful Learning Communities (BRLC) Project
Project Description: "The proposed project will: (1) Develop, field test, and incorporate several specific modifications into the BRLC model in order to make that model more cost-effective, sustainable, and scalable; and (2) Demonstrate the capacity of the BRLC model to promote and accelerate a turnaround of persistently low-performing schools and a substantial improvement in the academic achievement of their students. The BRLC model creates growth-oriented behavioral norms for both staff and students while strengthening their social-emotional competencies. It allows school staff to practice and apply social-emotional skills, enabling them to become more effective collaborators with each other and role models for their students. It employs experiential activities, goal setting, and a structured group process. Anticipated outcomes include improved student academic achievement and engagement in school, increased time on task, improved classroom and group management as well as improving staff culture."

Project Title: College Preparatory Program for Middles Schools
Project Description: "Brief Program Description - Project Discovery will partner with the Community Action Partnership of Staunton, Augusta, and Waynesboro, and the Augusta County, Waynesboro City and Staunton City Public schools to present a program of college awareness and college readiness training.  This training will be aimed at both students in 7th and 8th grades, and their parents.  Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes - The objectives of this program will be to present students with the necessary information to plan and successfully complete and college preparatory curriculum during their high school career.  The object for parents will be to assist them in understanding the necessary steps needed to prepare for the application to college and application process for financial aid for their child. The expected outcomes for the students will be a reduced dropout rate, higher levels of advanced placement and dual enrollment classes completed, and a higher rate of matriculation to post secondary education.  For parents the expected outcomes will be a higher level of financial literacy and a greater understanding of the college enrollment and financial aid process.Target Number of Students to be Served - 800Official Partners - Community Action Partnership of Staunton, Augusta, and Waynesboro, and the Augusta County, Waynesboro City and Staunton City Public schools"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: PROJECT FORWARD LEAP EDUCATIONAL ENRICHMENT PROGRAM
Project Description: "Project Forward Leap (PFL) will demonstrate the effectiveness of two strategies to increase the rates at which high-need students take academically rigorous programs in their high school years and matriculate to college than a comparable population. PFL will: 1) Enroll a critical mass of middle-school students, 10-15% of all fifth grade students, from four low-performing schools (405 students total) in three partnering school districts: Chester Upland School District, School District of Lancaster, and Milwaukee Public Schools (WI) to demonstrate that enrichment, in a small cohort, can serve to raise the performance of all students within the grade. This will be undertaken through PFL?s proven, academically rigorous residential summer institutes on college campuses and a high school college preparation and coaching initiative. Seventy percent of the fully enrolled population will participate in an advanced or high-level, core subjects program. Gains of 5-10% are anticipated for the remainder of the cohort.  And 2) Conduct, with grant support, Summer Teacher Academies, backed by two weekend school-year retreats, for a cohort of math teachers from eleven low-performing middle schools (44 teachers) and three high schools (36 teachers).  Through the Summer Academies and school year workshops the teachers will advance their pedagogical practices and improve high-need student preparedness for advanced level courses in high school. High performance in math and algebra is a key indicator of high-need student success in academically rigorous programs in high school. Through this initiative the teachers will reach a total of 6,872 students per year who will increase participation in advanced courses in high school by 35%"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project GRAD (Graduation
Project Description: "Project Title:  Project GRAD (Graduation Really Achieves Dreams)	Type:  Validation    GRAD's PreK-12 model is designed to build a firm academic foundation for students, create a college-going culture, engage parents and the community, and build capacity in teachers and administrators for systemic change through the implementation of five interdependent and mutually reinforcing components and their related program goals:  1) Improve student achievement in literacy and mathematics;  2) Improve school climate and classroom learning environments;  3)  Increase high school graduation rates;  Increase parent and community engagement;  and 5) Improve college access and success rates.     Target number of students to be served in the project: GRAD will serve 22,831 students in 12 elementary, five middle,13 high schools, and one K-12 school from its current network, with an additional six schools in new school districts that meet the i3 definition of 'persistently low performing schools.'    Special project features: GRAD will focus i3 resources on Absolute Priority 4: Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-performing Schools (via a targeted approach to reform) and Competitive Preference Priority 6:  Innovations that Support College Access and Success.    Project partners: The communities that GRAD is targeting for this proposal are geographically and demographically varied and include Official Partner GRAD sites and Official Partner LEAs in California;  Atlanta, Georgia;  Newark, New Jersey;  Akron and Cincinnati, Ohio;  Philadelphia and Chester, Pennsylvania;  Knoxville, Tennessee;  and Houston, Texas and one rural community in Kenai, Alaska.  Each of these schools will receive the necessary resources to implement the full GRAD model and to achieve a substantial turn around within the grant period."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project Lead the Way's Critical Role in America's Education
Project Description: "Project Lead the Way, Inc. (PLTW), the leading provider of middle and high school STEM education in the U.S.,currently serves more than 350,000 students at more than 3,400 implementations in all 50 states and theDistrict of Columbia. While this may seem significant, it represents penetration of only 1.34% of middle andhigh school students nationwide. Research shows that PLTW students close the achievement gap, becomeengaged with their learning, discover a passion for STEM, and are 10 times more likely than their collegegoingpeers to pursue STEM-related degrees and careers. Our Activity-, Problem- and Project-Based (APPB)learning model prepares students to succeed in post-secondary education and STEM careers regardless ofsocioeconomic status, ethnicity or gender. With the benefit of I3 grant funds, we will fund the expansion of ourhighly-recognized STEM curricula into selected public middle and high schools targeting high needs studentsacross the country, with special emphasis on students in low-income communities, underserved minoritystudents, and students in rural schools. We will use a competitive grant process to select our partner LEAs inorder to promote equity and fairness in the distribution of more than $44 million, assuming that we areawarded $50 million and outside resources provide $10 million of matching funding. Our overarchingobjective, with the benefit of this grant, is to provide our quality STEM education to more than 1.4 millionstudents within five years. Our principal goal is to close the achievement gap and increase student success incollege and STEM careers."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Preparing Propel's "Promising Principles" for Replication
as a Whole-School Turnaround Design for High-Need Students
Project Description: "The Propel Schools Foundation has attained remarkable success in improving student achievement among high-need populations at its four K-8 charter schools in the Pittsburgh area.  Propel's innovative whole-school model relies on six 'Promising Principles' that combine to create a distinctive, enthusiastic school climate.  Propel seeks an Investing in Innovation development grant to dccument the practices by which these six principles are applied; to develop an implementation guide, a video, a web site, professional development materials, a self-assessment tool, and a training institute to foster replication of its model; and to replicate its model at three additional schools.  A rigorous validation study willl be conducted during the first replication, at a Propel-managed school opening in fall 2010.  In addition, Propel plans to implement its model as a turnaround strategy at two struggling charter schools in a neighboring state beginning in fall 2011."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Integrated Data for Academic Success
Project Description: "Community and School partners in Providence seek to develop an integrated data system that will serve to provide meaningful, timely and accurate information for more effective data-driven decision making to ultimately improve student achievement for struggling Providence students at all levels.  The systems and processes will enable a range of stakeholders (academic and non-academic) to utilize all data to improve the institutional/organizational system's ability to support student achievement and academic outcomes.  The Integrated Data for Academic Success (IDAS) project will create a unique data integration and evaluation system that will enable a wide range of stakeholders to systematically and routinely access and utilize data to evaluate and improve effectiveness of programmatic and academic interventions,  Through IDAS, the partner organizations will build a system that will enable both real-time and evaluate use of data from diverese sources in a single dashboard; build culture of data usage that drives improvement; and improve coordination of child-centered strategies among educators and community organizations.  IDAS will build a sustainable and etensible data system, and will develop a lasting set of processes and depth of human capital that can be refined , utilized in myriad ways, and provide the interconnectivity that is needed to take a whole student/whole community approach to improving student achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Program for Instructional Excellence and Principal Leadership
Project Description: "This proposal is being submitted for the creation of the Program for Instructional Excellence and Principal Leadership. PIEPL will certify Teach for America alumni as principals. The institute of higher education and official PIEPL partner that will provide this certification and traditional education is National Louis University in Chicago, IL. Providence St. Mel School (PSM) will provide an internship for PIEPL corps members while they study at NLU. PIEPL will fully fund their corps members? education and living expenses throughout this year long educational period. Following this education PIEPL corps members will spend a year in partially subsidized residency at a partnering LEA. Upon completion of this residency, PIEPL graduates will be placed in leadership position in a high need school within a target area. There they will implement the successful strategies of PSM's leadership model. As they do so they will continue to be supported by leadership teams from PIEPL. In return for their subsidized education and residency school leaders from PIEPL will be expected to serve a minimum of four years in their initial high-need schools. The goal of this program is to provide high need schools with effective leaders to spearhead an academic turnaround for their students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: PROVIDING COLLEGE ACCESS TO UNDERREPRESENTED YOUTH IN URBAN AREAS.
Digital Learning Resources for Improved Math Achievement
Collaborating for Success
Project Description: "Mississippi children enter Kindergarten academically unready, as shown in very low scores on nationalachievement tests. One reason for this is that Mississippi is one of only ten states with no publicly funded pre-Kindergarten program. There is much resistance among child care providers to instituting such as program, butexamples from other states show that public-private collaboration, in which both public schools and privateproviders participate in service delivery may be a way forward. The Collaborating for Success pilot aims toimprove young children?s school readiness so that children are prepared for success in core academic subjectsby providing certified pre-Kindergarten teachers to childcare centers for at least three instructional hours a day.These teachers will be provided by the Lead Partner, the Emerson Family School, a high-quality, fee-basedbirth-to-five school operating under the umbrella of the Starkville (MS) School District. Partner Providers,childcare centers in Oktibbeha County will provide the Lead Partner with access to the children in theirchildcare centers and space in their facilities for instruction. Partner Providers will also allow their staff towork as assistants to the Lead Teachers who teach pre-K classes. The Lead Teachers, will provide increasedinstructional time to the children, as well as playing an important role in connecting children and their familiesto social services, including a comprehensive resource center for parents hosted by the Lead Partner. A MasterTeacher, employed by the Lead Partner, will facilitate in-service teacher development and support and reduceisolation of in-field teachers in very rural areas. Of the eighteen child care centers that have volunteered toparticipate in this study, approximately one-half will be randomly assigned a Lead Teacher, while the othersites follow usual practice. The results will be compared to assess the affect of the program on schoolreadiness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
The Effective Combination of Professional Development, Peer Support, 3D
