Visualization and Digital Media on Student Performance in the Science Classroom
Project Description: "KCPT in partnership with five community schools will use a multifaceted approach over the course of three yearsto improve teacher effectiveness and high-need student academic success. By providing a powerful andinnovative combination of professional support and development programs along with cutting-edge 3Dvisualization and digital resources, KCPT will enable science teachers to engagingly present challengingconcepts and improve students' ability to learn and retain valued information.The program will utilize the power of the Public Broadcasting System (PBS) through PBS TeacherLine PeerConnection, PBS TeacherLine/ISTE Capstone Certificate Program, and PBS TeacherLine?; the power ofprogressive academic media through 3D visualization, PowerMediaPlus?, Learn360?, and Teachers' Domain;and the power of KCPT to document and track program progress through The Local Show, a communityprogram on issues of local interest and import.KCPT's objective is to advance the academic success of high-need students by improving the skills andabilities of educators. By providing a unique and powerful combination of resources, KCPT will empowerscience teachers and instructional coaches to effectively focus on their bottom line: student success. Throughstreamlined communication, easy online professional development programs, and exciting multimediaresources that engage a variety of learners, students and educators will flourish and readily achieve success."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project Based Literacy in After School Time (Project Blast)
Project Description: "Project Based Literacy in After School Time (Project BLAST) is  an out-of-school time (OST) project-based literacy program for low-income sixth, seventh, and eighth grade struggling readers in New York City OST programs. The Official Partners are P/PV and the NYC DOE, with DYCD as the Other Partner. This project will address Absolute Priority 4b, a targeted approach to reform that increases time for students to improve core literacy skills, and Competitive Preference Priority 6. Project BLAST provides high-quality literacy instruction within the context of a high-engagement, project-based learning approach for a minimum of 4 hours weekly.  Youth are engaged in projects for which they have input and control. Staff provides structure and guidance as youth research, read, write, discuss, create products and think deeply about topics they care about. Project BLAST is built on P/PV's research-based Youth Education for Tomorrow (YET) OST program that uses balanced literacy components. A standards-based independent reading approach (100 Book Challenge?) develops reading muscle. Middle school has been identified as a critical intervention point for improving students' academic self-concept and performance.  Through highly engaging project-based learning struggling readers and writers will develop stronger literacy skills and achieve at higher levels. Based on previous research, participants who remain engaged for the full school year will improve their reading levels an average of 1.1 grade levels, a rate much higher for students who are behind in reading. Through collaborative work among peers, leadership opportunities, and work that addresses issues relevant to their lives, students attitude will change so that they identify themselves as better prepared for a successful entrance to 9th grade and college. After an initial planning year 2010-2011, the project will target up to 1500 middle school students over three years."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: From Paint Can to College: Publicolor's Paint Club Program
Arts Impact Development Project
Project Description: "Puget Sound Educational Service District will fully develop, refine and pilot-test the Arts Impact instructional model in grades K-5, building on previous experience and making the improvements to fully develop Arts Impact as a model to strengthen arts education and increase literacy and math achievement of traditionally underperforming students. Arts Impact provides teachers with intensive professional development in the Arts Impact instructional model so that teachers can effectively use arts infused strategies in teaching core content subject area skills and as a result increase arts, literacy and math achievement of underperforming students. Arts infused teaching provides the avenue to reach students with different cultural, social, and economic backgrounds that result in very different ways of thinking, learning, and behaving. The project will address: 1) need for teachers to learn how to infuse arts instruction into basic curricular content areas to increase the potential for student learning; 2) need to infuse arts instruction directly into basic curriculum; and 3) the need for valid assessment strategies that can provide evidence of learning in the arts, literacy and math in balance with and as a complement to high stakes tests."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: A Comprehensive Approach to Community-Centered Education with Shared Facilities
Project Description: "A cross-disciplinary team of Purdue University researchers, in partnership with four Local Education Agencies(LEAs) with high-need students in rural and urban settings, and with support from for-profit and non-profitorganizations, is seeking a validation grant to implement and evaluate a Comprehensive Approach toCommunity-Centered Education with Shared Facilities. This innovative approach is twofold: It provides aframework for comprehensive school reform, and it capitalizes upon underutilized space at the IN StateFairgrounds in Indianapolis to provide shared facilities that will be available?in both the real and virtualsenses?to stakeholders within our partner LEAs as well as other students outside our partners? purview. OurC3T framework has at its foundation four principal pillars: a STEM-focused and inquiry-based Curriculum, aculturally relevant Character Education component, programs and facilities that incorporate, engage and servethe Community, and a Technology umbrella that enhances safety, facilitates learning, promotes healthy andgreen living, and enables a rigorous metrics system. Each pillar is grounded in evidence-based practices. Weare packaging the pillars together in a manner that is designed to have a transformational effect on the studentsand communities we serve.Team Purdue proposes to carry out our vision through our partnership with HEAT (Health/Life Sciences, Energy,Agriculture, and Technology) Academy, a new charter school that will be located at the Fairgrounds. HEATAcademy will serve as the locus for our Living and Virtual Laboratories. Additionally, we are proposing tobring Imagine Indiana Health & Life Sciences Academies East and West, two existing charter schools in urbanIndianapolis, to full implementation of our C3T framework as well as Geist Montessori Academy inMcCordsville, IN, a rural school that will provide a complementary context. Approximately 5,500 studentswill be served over the project?s 5-year duration."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Validating Scaffolded Guided Inquiry for K-8 Science and Literacy: The Indiana Science
Initiative
Project Description: "The vision for the Indiana Science Initiative is to validate a statewide K-8 science education reform based uponscaffolded guided inquiry using research-based curricular materials enhanced with literacy education. Researchhas documented that programs like this have shown positive impact on student achievement in SouthernCalifornia, Alabama, Delaware, Southeast Florida, and Ohio. Reform is achieved by addressing the five areasfor systemic science education reform: Curriculum, Professional Development, Materials Support,Administrative and Community Support, and Assessment. Particular to this proposal, the ISI will have aspecial focus on equity to address the needs of all students in Indiana."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: I3-E3: Engineering Education for Excellence: Improving Science and Math Achievement of Elementary and Middle School Students
Project Description: "In the U.S., there is a growing inequality of access to challenging science and math courses as well as to higher education prerequisites. INSPIRE, a research center at Purdue University dedicated to promoting engineering education among P-12 students, hypothesizes that utilizing engineering as an applied context with innovative teacher support structures will increase elementary and middle school students' achievement in math and science and foster early interest in related careers. This innovative, large-scale development project will meet the absolute priority of increasing the success of under-represented student populations in academically rigorous courses and programs. We will examine our hypothesis with a cluster randomized trial study with two objectives: (i) Evaluating the effect on students' core academic achievement in math and science when an engineering context is applied through Engineering is Elementary (EIE), model-eliciting activities (MEAs) and children's literature curricula; and (ii) Improving and developing existing/field-tested curriculum and support for teachers.  Each of the three large school districts involved has a proven relationship with INSPIRE and a large population of minority students. We will use a mentor training and on-line courses to optimize teachers' professional development contact hours. All of INSPIRE's data will be generated from classroom settings. In total, an estimated 21,240 students (approx. 6,300 minority students) and 648 teachers will be engaged. Curriculum will be developed in English and Spanish, and appeal to both genders by emphasizing the empathetic 'social good' aspects of an engineering career. INSPIRE's critical research will determine if using the applied integrative context of engineering will advance students' academic achievement, critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities and prepares them for an increasingly technical workplace."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Upper Cumberland College Ready/Career Ready (CR2)
Project Description: "College Ready, Career Ready (CR2) is a Validation project that expands a successful learning approach, integrating virtual learning best practices, with dual enrollment (DE) and advanced placement (AP) courses to enhance student college and career readiness of rural high school students in the Upper Cumberland region of Tennessee. Specific outcomes include increased academic achievement as evidenced by ACT scores, AP test results, and graduation rates; increasing numbers of students graduating from high school with post-secondary credits; and equity of access to diverse, high-quality courses across the partnership. CR2 consists of: Sharing online and distance high school courses aligned with the TN curriculum frameworks to enable students to take courses not otherwise available, provide flexible access to courses, and allow credit recovery in a timely manner; Increasing access to dual enrollment (DE) and Advanced Placement (AP) courses that are more rigorous than most traditional high school courses; Recognizing and rewarding exemplary teachers through AP professional development to build local capacity to initiate and deliver virtual and AP courses; Providing quality virtual professional development for teachers K-12; and Engaging LEA teacher leaders with postsecondary educators to develop, implement, and evaluate strategic plans for increasing student DE and AP participation. The project will serve 28 schools in 19 predominantly rural counties. Eleven of the partner LEAs are RLIS eligible. If currently funded, CR2 services would be available to approximately 33,000students in grades 7 ? 12. Supporting partners include a university, four community colleges, and three technology centers. The external evaluation includes a well-designed quasi-experimental study and provides for timely, databased feedback. The partnership is committed to statewide scale-up following successful completion of the Validation project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Passport Program
Project Description: "The Passport Program curriculum is developed by Performance Solutions by Design, Inc.  This curriculum is based on The Leadership Academy they have created for world-renowned organizations globally.  Goals of the curriculum are to support core academic courses, develop Leadership, transition to college and/or career and even enhance entrepreneurial skills for youth grades 10-12, all linked to the successful acheivement of their individual Development Plans  Facillitation of the curriculum is based on the adult learning principles of -Tell, Show, Do, Review; and will be conjoined with engaging classsroon activities, interactive on-line mini workshops, video vignettes, suggested reading, guest speakers, and travel.  All participating students will receive a mock passport that the students will receive stamps for completed core curriculum as well as the provisions of the Program.  They will receive stamps for hours served in the Passport Mentoring Program as well as all community service.  The students will be engaged by the program that keeps them busy and lets them know how important their education is not only to them but to their community.  They will receive tangible benefits from attendance and commitment..  The Passport Program will prove to them that with a solid education and a service mentality they will fulfill any goal that they endeavor.  The Passport they will receive at graduation will solidify the promise that they can go anywhere, and do everything in life that they envision.The program also offers training for administrators and teachers.  The training program being offered has successfully worked in a number of Georgia School Districts."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Using Project MORE to Improve the Use of  Data for Educators, Administrators, and Parents of Struggling Readers
Project Description: Project MORE will incorporate progress monitoring and data-based decision makining in order to improve reading for high-need students using 1:1 effective and affordable volunteer reading mentoring through an e-training platform.
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Investing In Innovation
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Investing In Innovation
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Quaker Digital Academy under New Philadelphia City School District
Project Title: Enhancing Opportunities in Technology for Appalachian Americans
Project Description: "Quaker Digital Academy and New Philadelphia City Schools are requesting an Investing in Innovation Fund (i-3) Development Grant from the US Department of Education.  Quaker Digital Academy and New Philadelphia City Schools serve about 3500 students throughout the State of Ohio, particularly those students located in rural Appalachian Ohio, through both traditional and on-line formats. It is the intent of our project to enhance and expand the technology embedded experiences for both students and teachers as a means to prepare these students for post-secondary educational opportunities and the rigors 21st Century workforce. Specific student activities would include, but not limited to, providing all students with a technology hardware so they can readily access resources, including textbook information, both inside the school and while away from school. This device would also provide a means of 21st Century communication between students and staff; and provide students a tool necessary for accessing information in our fast paced digital world.  This would also provide students an opportunity to engage institutions of higher education. In order to create a 21st Century learning environment for students, specific teacher activities would include access to digital resources needed to expand their instruction beyond the traditional school day, to address varied student learned styles within the classroom and enhance communication between home and school.  Teachers would be provided on-going training opportunities to embed technology experiences into their lessons.The objective of this project is to provide the typically underserved and technology limited Appalachian students of our region with the means to be competitive in a technology rich world.  The expected outcomes will be that students and teachers access and utilize technology on a daily basis for learning, instructing, exploring, demonstrating, and communicating."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools in Four Rural Arkansas Districts through Leadership Coaching & Pedagogy Facilitation
Project Description: "This project is the further development and validation of our innovative approach to 'comprehensive school turnaround' in 10 persistently low-performing rural schools in Arkansas. It will proceed for duration of three years and form the basis for a longitudinal study while validating our ability to scale up a model that effectively combines the successful and research-based elements of: (1), Principal Leadership Coaching, where a principal in a low performing school is provided with an experienced successful turnaround principal in a coaching relationship; (2),Teacher Effectiveness training using Pedagogy Facilitators, master teachers in reading and math, that work in the school assisting teachers in the classrooms, supported by professional development ; and (3), One2One Mastery? Instruction, a data aligned instructional method that combines computer aided-instruction (CAI), with small group mastery instruction, for high-risk/ high need students ranging from 'early childhood learners' to high school students.  The project will include a cohort of 10 principals from 4 rural school districts with their administrative and teaching staffs, and impact over 12,000 students, grades K throught 12, and their parents during the three year project. Hypothesis:  A comprehensive school turnaround model that combines the elements of leadership coaching , teacher effectiveness training, and  targeted data informed instructional practices, may significantly improve math and reading skills and improve performance on high stakes tests for high-need /high-risk students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Using Staff Development to Create Traditional Curriculum to Match our
Traditional School Mission and Close the Achievement Gap
Project Description: "Our project, ?Using Staff Development to Create Traditional Curriculum to Match our Traditional SchoolMission and Close the Achievement Gap? works to eliminate the achievement gap through several methods. First we address the barrier of time by giving teachers time to plan curriculum by arranging for substitutes to spell them for a
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project READY (Racine Effort for Academic Development for Youth)
Project Description: "Project READY is collaborative community project to institute a holistic approach to educating students that isgrounded in our districts NORTH STAR vision of graduating students who are career and college ready. It isbased on the Learning First model of a) advancing student learning core, b) building staff capacity, c) aligningresources and d) engaging families and the community. Specifically we will intertwine the strengths ofourpost-secondary institutions, workforce development center, social service organizations, business leadersand public officials to create a sustainable school reform approach for our five target schools. Our goals are toimprove teaching abilities, improve academic achievement, improve social and behavioral functioning andimprove the career and college readiness of all students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: iLearn: Exploring Mobile Technology in soutwestern Virginia Classrooms
Project Description: "Recently published articles in the field of educational technology have described four technological trends, whichwill most likely have a significant impact on how educators teach in future classrooms. These trends arerepresented in the availability of: 1. virtually limitless, free, keyword-searchable information, 2. wifi-enabled,locations-aware mobile technologies, 3. Web 2.0 technologies, and 4. handheld and desktop games andsimulations (Dede, 2005; 2009; Bonk, 2009). The goal of this developmental grant proposal is to address thepriorities of the U.S. Department of Education by creating engaging and effective learning environments thatleverage emerging mobile and Web 2.0 technologies to enhance the efficacy of teachers in southwesternVirginia. Within a collaboration among Pulaski County Public Schools, New River Community College,Apple Inc., Common Sense Media and Radford University, the proposed project will have three majorcomponents: 1. location-aware mobile games and simulations; 2. iPod Touch and iPad applications; and 3. preserviceand in-service professional development and education.Standards-aligned, mobile games, iPod Touch and iPad applications will be designed to target high need,fundamental knowledge in core content areas and implemented within multiple schools in rural LEAs servingapproximately 10,000 students in 15 schools in the Appalachian region of southwestern Virginia. Theproposed project will also provide professional development classes and training for the participating teachersto ensure successful integration of the tools and applications. A mixed methods research approach willexamine the relationships among the location-aware mobile, iPod Touch, and iPad games, academic contentknowledge, scientific inquiry, socio-emotional outcomes such as academic engagement and self-efficacy, andthe demographic characteristics of rural, underserved students in participating classrooms."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Raising A Reader: A Further Validation of Program Effects and Expansion of Program Augmented by Family Nights
Project Description: "Oral language and literacy skills in early childhood have been linked to children?s long-term school success, and book-sharing and family engagement interventions are among the innovative strategies shown to promote such skills in young children (The National Institute for Literacy, 2008).  Raising A Reader -- a turnkey program with a book rotation system, parent and educator training and information, and library linkages ? is among a handful of such interventions with extensive evaluation evidence (including a recent random controlled trial) demonstrating effectiveness in increasing family engagement and early language and literacy skills. We seek an i3 Validation Grant to support the proposed project, entitled Raising A Reader: A Further Validation of Program Effects and Expansion of Program Augmented by Family Nights. Project goals are: 1) to further validate the positive effects of Raising A Reader on children and families, focusing on settings with less instructional support than prior validation studies, and 2) to expand a validated and augmented version of Raising A Reader to thousands more young children in nine states across the U.S.  Careful evaluation and expansion planning and implementation, and strategic partnerships with universities and strong current program affiliates will help achieve these goals. In five years, the project will reach 24,760 four- and five-year old children in prekindergarten and kindergarten settings, including Head Start and other subsidized settings that serve children from low-income families.  The project boasts a consortium of committed partners: The University of Texas-Houston (Dr. Jason Anthony, co-PI); The University of Houston (TIMES Center, independent evaluator); The Silicon Valley Community Foundation and the W.K. Kellogg Foundation; and numerous LEAs, individual public elementary schools, and community agencies serving young children (CA, CO, FL, MA, MI, MS, NM, TX, VA; See Appendix D for complete partner list)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Building Teacher Leadership for Instructional Improvement
Project Description: "Over the course of five years, a two-year teacher residency program for three cohorts of (72) total PK-12 teachers of  English Language Arts, Math, Special Education, and English Language Learners will be implemented in the Randolph Public Schools with the purpose of providing participants the knowledge and skills to become instructional leaders in their schools and in the district.   A second and complementary project component is the development of a performance-based compensation system for teachers that would reward individual initiative and career growth of teachers, and build the instructional capacity of the school/district.   Project activities include the provision of five graduate courses in instructional leadership to resident teachers, the development of lab classrooms in each of the six schools, and action research.  As a result of participation in the residency program, teachers are expected to take a leadership role in building-based instructional leadership teams, develop and test curriculum intervention modules with academically @risk students, and provide professional development programming for peers.  The expected intermediate outcomes of the project include the demonstration of effective instructional practices by resident teachers, improvement in instructional practices of 50% of peers, and evidence of distributed leadership for instructional improvement across schools.  Expected long-term outcomes over five years include a 30% increase in the number of students who demonstrate proficiency on state tests in ELA and Math, a 20% reduction in achievement gaps among student sub-groups, and an increase of 20% in ELA and Math proficiency on state tests for students with disabilities and Limited English Proficiency. The target number of students to be served through the project is 2851.  The University of Massachusetts Graduate College of Education is collaborating with the district in the planning and implementation of this project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Systemic Reform for Student Success
Project Description: "The Re-Inventing Schools Coalition (RISC) will partner with a coalition of 16 LEAs in five states to implement the RISC Approach to Schooling to realize the objectives of Absolute Priority 3. The three-year project will include professional development, coaching, site visits, and evaluation to assist each LEA in shifting from a teacher-driven, time-based traditional system of education to a learner-centered, performance-based system, characterized by high-quality standards, performance levels, rather than age-based grade-level benchmarks, a unified community committed to helping all students reach high achievement levels, and a system organized around the goal of dramatically increasing student achievement."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Reach for Tomorrow - Teen REACH, Illinois
Project Description: "Reach for Tomorrow (RFT), a nonprofit organization, proposes a development grant project to implement anacademic enhancement that increases achievement in high-need secondary school students, raises graduationrates, and increases the number of students continuing on to post-secondary education. This innovativeprogram addresses Absolute Priority 4 (innovations that turn around persistently low-performing schools), andwill be implemented within an after-school program operating at i3 Absolute Priority 4 schools. RFT iscommitted to making college accessible to everyone through two components: vigorous academic supports andmeaningful field experiences. The first component is a cost-effective computer-based academic program calledExtralearning Online, which (1) provides individualized student assessments to identify skill deficienciesacross core academic subjects, and (2) creates self-paced, interactive learning programs that accommodateindividual learning styles, address skill deficiencies, and decrease gaps in grade level achievement. The secondimportant component to RFT is a summer experiential program that engages students in college/career-themedactivities to motivate them to complete their education and plan for a post-secondary future. The summerexperience also serves as an incentive for students to use Extralearning Online within an after-school program.RFT programming is outcomes-based and uses a sustainable/replicable model. This project addressesCompetitive Preference Priority 6 (innovations to support college access and success). The project will beimplemented throughout Illinois, and success will be demonstrated through a matched comparison groupstudy."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Reach Institute for School Leadership
Project Description: "The Reach Institute for School Leadership is a multi-tiered program for developing highly effective teachers. Through comprehensive partnerships with schools small, innovative schools, Reach supports the needs of teachers at multiple levels: novice teachers in the Intern program, emerging teachers in the Induction Program and teacher leaders in the Leadership Academy. Each offers opportunities for teachers to receive tailored feedback appropriate for their level of development while earning increasingly advanced certification. All programs focus on the particular context of the teacher and school, allowing for each teacher's unique needs and contexts to be addressed. The program employs six strategies throughout: job embedded coaching, personalized professional development, need-to-know content knowledge, coaching and mentoring, collaboration with colleagues, and reflection. Each of these practices serve to create teachers who continually improve upon their practice as measured through the California Standards for the Teaching Profession and to demonstrably increase student achievement. A component of the project includes designing a value-added system for examining teacher effects on student achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: One District, One Book
Project Description: "Read To Them, a literacy non-profit organization based in Richmond, Virginia, offers a novel strategy to help turn around low-performing schools via its One District, One Book initiative.  The strategy enables parents of elementary school children to read high quality children's novels at home.  This technique yields two significant effects vital to improving low-performing schools: it better prepares elementary school students to read and to become proficient readers, and it sparks an increase in parental involvement and awareness in their children's academic lives.Read To Them has been using this strategy, through its pioneering program, One School, One Book, for the last three years, bringing these benefits to 125 schools and approximately 50,000 students/families across North America.  Following its recent success in Bentonville, Arkansas (ten schools, nearly 6000 families, all reading E.B. White's The Trumpet of the Swan, in February, 2010), Read To Them has embarked on a partnership with the 70,000 member International Reading Association in an effort to spread the idea at the district level.  The new, expanded initiative is called One District, One Book.Specifically, the project seeks to add 5-10 districts (approximately 150 schools), representing 75,000 students, each year for the next three years.  Read To Them will conduct research surveys and use quantitative data such as compilation of test scoring to document the positive effects of the program.  The long-term plan is to use data from these new schools and districts to document the meaningful and constructive value of the program, and thus enable its expansion to scale up to targets of 100,000; 250,000; and 500,000 students.  Ultimately, Read To Them hopes that One District, One Book can become the program to help realize President Obama's goal asking parents to 'turn off the TV, put the video games back on the shelf, and read to their children.'?????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: READING CONNECTIONS' SOLUTION TO ILLITERACY

Applicant: Reading Excellence and Discovery Foundation Inc.
Project Title: READ+: Collaborative Use of data in the Non-testing Grades
Project Description: "READ+ will combine a proven after-school tutoring program for K-1 students with collaborative data analysis by READ staff and school personnel to identify and differentiate instruction based on srudents' strenghts.  With basic reading skills assured by READ turoring for more than 6,000 students, teachers will be able to enrich language and literacy instruction for all students, promoting whole school improvement and closing the achievement gap for them and their 12,000 classmates.  Tutoring will take place in grades K-1; professional development in data analysis and implementation will involve teachers in grades 1-5.READ+ will begin with a consortium of five elementary schools in Year 1.  In Year 2, 10 schools will join; 10 more in Year 3; five more in Year 4, for a total of 30 (20 in New York City and 10 in other parts of the country.)  Schools outside of NYC will have professional development sessions through virtual technology and in-person visits.  In Year 5, we will continue services to these 30 schools and solidify and present findings through conference presentations, webnairs, website postings and printed material suggesting best perfomance practices for collaborative use of data to improve achievement of all students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
It's About Time: Adding instructional time for reading through 
Reading In Motion.
Project Description: "Reading In Motion (RIM), a 27-year-old Chicago, IL, nonprofit requests funds for expansion of our innovative project to provide more time for students to learn to read by increasing instructional time for reading within the school day. This project's goal is to get every child in K and first grade in partner schools reading at or above grade level.  This project will be delivered within the Chicago Public Schools (CPS) and another urban school district to be identified by August 2010.  The objectives are: o	Ensure that all K and first grade students receive the right amount of reading instruction during the school day to produce the desired reading results (at least 80 minutes daily for every K and first grade student to make a year's worth of progress, with an additional 20 - 80 minutes daily for each first grader reading below grade level to make 'catch-up' growth).o	Ensure that all K and first grade students receive the right method of instruction, defined by this project as direct, teacher-lead instruction that keeps students engaged and focused on learning for the whole lesson, and that provides high quantities of practice and immediate instructor feedback for each student.o	Ensure that all K and first grade students receive the right content, defined for this project as phonemic awareness, alphabetic principle, and fluency-three of the five key skills identified by the National Reading Panel in 2000.Over a four-year period RIM and its partner schools will: 1) Train all K and first grade teachers in the summer in RIM's methods;  2) Provide bi-weekly support from Reading In Motion coaches for each teacher; and 3) Insert Extra Dosage Instructors in all first grade classrooms to implement additional small groups daily, thereby doubling instructional time for students who need it most. The outcome to be achieved: in participating schools the percent of students reading at grade level at the end of K and first grade increases each year until it reaches 100%."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Reading Partners After-School: Leveraging ELT with a School-Day Link to Improve Reading Achievement
Project Description: "With an i3 grant of $1.2M over 3 years, Reading Partners (RP) will pilot an innovative program that combines ameasurably effective literacy intervention program with a newly developed reading-themed after-schoolenrichment curriculum. The pilot program will directly serve 1,200 students at 8 elementary schools.The goal of the project is to create an extended learning time program that leverages California?s massive $550Mstatewide After-School Education and Safety (ASES) fund to help turn around persistently low-achievingschools. RP's after-school program will be a uniquely comprehensive approach, combining school-day andafter-school strategies to generate significant improvement in reading achievement for participating students.If successful, the project will unlock ASES as a major asset in helping LEAs turn around persistently lowestachievingschools by demonstrating the impact that academically-focused ELT programs with strong links tothe school day can measurably improve student and school achievement.Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes:1) Expand from 1 pilot program site to 8 replication program sites;2) Serve 1,200 K-5 students reading below proficiency;3) Demonstrate significant, measurable improvement in reading skills for enrolled students as measured byprogram assessments and state testing;-80% of RPAS target students will improve their achievement in reading skills as measured by standardizedassessments;-RPAS target students will gain 1.5 months of reading skills for every month in the program, significantly closingtheir achievement gaps.4) Demonstrate significant, measurable improvement in performance of schools adopting RP as measured bystate and federal accountability systems."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Partnering to Prosper:  A Multilateral Approach to Improving Reading Achievement for High-Need Students
Project Description: "With an i3 grant of $7.8M over 5 years, Reading Partners (RP) will expand its measurably effective literacy intervention program from 24 elementary schools in 2009-10 to 100 school sites by 2014-15. 12 LEAs from across California will partner with RP to deploy the program at their lowest-achieving schools.To ensure sustainability of the project, i3 funds will be used to build organizational infrastructure to support greater scale and for research on the impact of the program as it grows to include a larger and more diverse set of participating schools. Direct program delivery expenses will be provided from other more renewable sources.By the conclusion of the project, RP will have provided targeted one-on-one literacy interventions to 16,000 K-5 students and helped 100 struggling schools improve achievement. It will also have demonstrated the impact its program can have in both the nation?s largest state and the state with the worst reading scores for high-need students from low-income backgrounds."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Reality Changers 2.0: Building MORE First Generation College Students
Project Description: "?Reality Changers is a model ? not just for the city or the state, but for the country.?-US Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, December 10, 2009Reality Changers seeks to multiply its results of transforming low-income, inner-city youth into well-prepared,university-bound scholars by submitting a grant request entitled, ?Reality Changers 2.0: Building MORE FirstGeneration College Students.? A Validation Grant is requested because of Reality Changers? exceptionalapproach to an unmet need for high-need students, clear goals and strategies, and evidence-based practices.Project activities serving 8th-12th graders include a comprehensive weekly tutoring and leadership program, UCSan Diego?s Academic Connections Summer Residential Program, summer camp during the week preceding thestart to each school year, random drug testing, and up to 30 weekends of community service projects per year.Furthermore, 11th graders enroll in the Princeton Review SAT Preparation Course and 12th graders participate ina 40-week immersion program called the Senior Academy to successfully navigate the college application andadmissions process.As Secretary Duncan witnessed last December, the objectives and outcomes of this request are to multiply thedemonstrated success that Reality Changers has produced over the past ten years. Specifically, this project willsignificantly improve student achievement, close achievement gaps, decrease dropout rates, increase highschool graduation rates, and increase college enrollment and completion rates.This project seeks to serve up to 1,000 at-risk and in-risk students over five years. The most special feature ofthis project is Reality Changers? unique, decade-long relationship with UC San Diego that has provided hundredsof inner-city, high-school-aged youth with the opportunity to spend three weeks each summer living in collegedorms, taking college-level classes, and earning genuine college credit."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: (no title - paper application)

Applicant: Rector & Visitors of the University of Virginia
Project Title: IDENTIFICATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF DISTRICT AND LEADERSHIP CAPACITIES TO OPTIMIZE SCHOOL TURNAROUND SUCCESS
Project Description: "Turning around persistently low-performing schools is a moral imperative and a national policy priority. The need for effective school turnaround strategies far surpasses the supply of approaches with a record of even moderate success, sustainability, or scalability. The University of Virginia-School Turnaround Specialist Program (UVA-STSP) is a two-year district and school leader development program that includes executive education, strategic support, resources, and tools for school and district teams charged with embarking upon bold turnaround initiatives in an effort to rescue schools from failure. Although our work to date with 121 schools in 9 states has yielded promising results, further program development and refinement and more formal, systematic study is warranted. Based on the research literature and our experience, we propose that deploying highly effective leaders and building district capacity by codifying the systemic conditions and capabilities to support highly-capable leaders has potential to optimize the success of turnaround efforts. We propose that we can improve school turnaround outcomes by developing a more intentional effort to build district capacity to support turnaround and in particular to implement rigorous, competency-based leader recruitment, selection, and development procedures. In partnership with the Darden School Foundation, Cincinnati Public Schools and the Texas Education Service Center 13, we are applying for a $4.2 million dollar, three-year i3 grant to develop a novel approach to school turnaround that incorporates an intense focus on district capacity and selection of highly-skilled turnaround leaders. We propose that by developing this rigorous, integrated turnaround approach we can improve and expand our impact, dramatically improve academic outcomes for high-needs students, and inform national school turnaround efforts beyond just those schools/districts that partner with the UVA-STSP."

Applicant: Rector & Visitors of the University of Virginia
Project Title: Development of a School-wide Pre-Kindergarten to Elementary System for Evaluating and Supporting Teacher Effectiveness
Project Description: "The Center for Advanced Study of Teaching and Learning (CASTL), at the University of Virginia, in partnershipwith schools in New Jersey and California, will develop and test (Development Proposal) a new model forevaluating and improving teacher effectiveness (Absolute Priority 1). We will collaborate with schools todesign and test a school-level approach to ensuring that high-needs students are receiving effective teachersthroughout the pre-kindergarten (PK) to elementary years (Competitive Preference Priority 5). This approachbuilds from a set of validated approaches to teacher evaluation and professional development that emanatefrom a standardized and validated approach to observing teacher effectiveness across the PK to elementarygrades, called the Classroom Assessment Scoring System (CLASS). Years of research in thousands ofclassrooms across the country indicate the ways in which CLASS observations identify components ofteachers? daily interactions with students that contribute to students? learning. More recently CASTL hasdeveloped and validated approaches to improving teacher effectiveness by targeting these specific dimensionsof teaching practice, including a coaching model, a course on effective interactions, a video library of effectiveteaching, and professional learning communities.To date these improvement approaches have been tested separately, primarily in early childhood settings. In thisdevelopment work CASTL will collaborate with six schools to refine and consolidate these approaches intoschool-wide model for evaluating and improving teacher effectiveness. Importantly, all of the schools withwhom we will be working serve large numbers of high-need students. Many of the schools serve largenumbers of English Language Learners (Competitive Preference Priority 7) and we will also partner with onerural school in California (Competitive Preference Priority 8)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Rector & Visitors of the University of Virginia
Project Title: Increasing  Effective Teacher-Student Interactions in Early Childhood to Improve Early Learning Outcomes
Project Description: "This project will seek to validate an early childhood professional development intervention, MyTeachingPartneror MTP Consultation, for improving teacher effectiveness (AP 1) to improve children?s early learningoutcomes (CPP 5). The current and proposed work on MTP Consultation, an innovative, web-mediatedconsultation intervention with early childhood teachers, is guided by evidence for the need to greatly improvethe quality and impact of early childhood education, and that teacher-child interactions, a critical mechanismby which preschool enrollment improves readiness skills, can in turn be improved through professionaldevelopment interventions. Despite billions invested in early education to support children at-risk of schoolfailure, publicly-supported early childhood programs are not producing the level or rate of gains needed. Arecent review of preschool program effects emphasizes the low levels of program quality, the paucity ofeffective professional development (PD) interventions, and the modest nature of any detected effects. And,controlled studies show that the benefits of preschool are highly dependent on both teachers? effectiveimplementation of quality curricula and their everyday interactions with young children. MTP Consultationproduces more effective teacher-child interaction through regular individualized feedback and video analysisof teachers? own and other teachers? interactions, showing effect sizes of .77-.97 on teacher behavior and .25-.57 on child early learning outcomes. MTP Consultation is a promising and empirically-supported PDintervention with potential scalability and effects larger than those typically reported for PD. Results of thisvalidation work will provide estimates of the impacts of MTP on teacher-child interactions and children?s earlylearning outcomes and allows a test of whether consultation provided to teachers improves children?soutcomes as a function of changes in teacher-child interactions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Project T.E.E.N.
Project Description: "As stated by former U.S. Surgeon General, Dr. Jocelyn Elders, 'You cannot educate a child who is not healthy, and you cannot keep a child healthy who is not educated.' The purpose of the Red Clay Consolidated School District's Project T.E.E.N. (Teen Exercise, Education and Nutrition), is to increase academic achievement through a combination of academic tutoring and the development of healthy lifestyles for high need students in 9th and 10th grade in three of the district's lowest performing high schools. The project has three core components: physical activity, academic tutoring and nutrition education.Red Clay Consolidated School District is seeking a four-year Investing in Innovation  Development Grant to address Absolute Priority #4: 'Innovations that turn around persistently low-performing schools' and Competitive Priority #7: 'Innovations to support the unique learning needs of students with disabilities and English language learners'. Through facilitation, coordination and delivery efforts of a Project Director, a part-time secretary, 4 part-time instructors, and 2 part-time partner staff the following outcomes are intended: 1) 610 participants will receive physical activity/physical education; academic tutoring (as necessary in English/Language Arts and math); and nutrition education over four years. 2) 90% of the 9th and 10 graders that participate who do not 'meet standard' on standardized assessments will remain in the program in the next school year; 3) 65% of participants will improve fitness levels and other health factors.  To accomplish these objectives and meet the purpose of the i(3) Development Grant, the District will test high-potential practices and strategies around physical activity and nutrition that may improve the academic performance of these high need student populations. The Red Clay Consolidated School District requests $ 110,363 for the first year."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Regents of the University of California
Project Title: College Access: Teaching Readiness in Algebra Instruction Now (CA TRAIN)
Project Description: "Nine school districts and the University of California address the absolute priority of enhanced data systems and plan to increase algebra proficiency by grade 9 to 75%, intention to apply and applications to college, parent involvement in college planning, and teacher mathematics and science knowledge . Results from 50,000 county children show that 23% of 9th graders are algebra proficient. Using some random assignment, a no-treatment control and a regression discontinuity approach, teachers, students and parents will receive access to an enhanced student information system, comprehensive professional development, direct instruction, increased learning time, and parent education. The design will enable testing the incremental effects of each of these elements over five years. Partners are a subset of a county P-20 STEM Council which leads data collection, capacity-building and public dissemination tasks. P-20 Council assessment indicates that while achievement and college-going rates among Latino children are low, practices with limited evidence, but supported by national research and theory are in place and can support a development effort."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Regents of the University of Minnesota
Project Title: STEM Integration through Modeling in Middle Schools (SIMMS) Project
Project Description: "This development project will investigate the implementation of Model-Eliciting Activities (MEAs) in the middlegrades at Lee County Schools (NC) as a means to integrate STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, andMathematics) concepts in existing classes. MEAs are interdisciplinary, team-based, complex problems. Therealistic problem solving in MEAs fosters meaningful interpretations and development of mathematical andscientific models using various representations of concepts, promoting learning with conceptual understanding.  MEAs are different from the traditional textbook problems in that they are self-assessable, open-ended, andrequire the construction of models that are shareable, reusable, and generalizable.MEAs will be implemented in grades 6-8 in three middle schools. The contexts for the MEAs are the Paxton-Patterson modules that are part of each school?s STEM Lab, which include such topics as alternative energy,forensic science, and digital music. Some MEAs already match the contexts while others will need to becreated. The project will investigate the implementation and subsequent knowledge gain of studentsparticipating in courses that use MEAs for STEM integration.The project consists of three components: (1) create and implement 4 STEM-context MEAs per year in each ofthe three middle grades in Lee County Schools; (2) provide teacher training and assistance in theimplementation; (3) research the impact on students and teachers of this training and systematicimplementation. The development and research of these models and modeling based curricular materials isguided by three research questions: 1. What is the impact of a district-wide intervention (MEAs) on studentmath/science achievement during middle school? 2. What is the impact of a district-wide intervention (MEAs)on teacher practice? 3. What mathematical and scientific knowledge is elicited from students while working onMEAs? How can this be used to shape instruction?"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Regents of the University of Minnesota
Project Title: Ramp-Up for Readiness
Project Description: "Ramp-Up to Readiness is a school-wide guidance program that helps junior and senior high school students develop the knowledge, skills and habits for success in college and other forms of postsecondary education. The program guides students past thirty major Milestones on the road to reaching five Readiness Goals: Academic Readiness, Admissions Readiness, Financial Readiness, Career Readiness and Personal and Social Readiness. To advance students? progress through the Milestones, Ramp-Up to Readiness also provides students and schools with a set of tools, including the Ramp-Up Curriculum; grade-specific Readiness Rubrics; the PREP, to measure each student?s level of engagement in school; Support Networks; On-Ramp Interventions for additional support; and Naviance Succeed, a powerful Web-based platform.As a school-wide guidance program, Ramp-Up to Readiness complements efforts to raise standards and implement high-quality assessments by improving students? motivation to succeed in school, their willingness to put forth sustained effort, their ability to make sound educational decisions and their capacity to regulate their own behavior in ways that promote academic success. Ramp-Up achieves those objectives by helping all students develop powerful goals for postsecondary education and a career and then helping them advance toward those goals as they progress through junior and senior high. Ramp-Up strengthens students? motivation and capacity to master high standards and to succeed on challenging assessments.Ramp-Up to Readiness will increase the number and diversity of students in participating schools who: (1) take and succeed in rigorous college-preparatory courses, (2) perform at the college-ready level or above on state and national assessments, (3) gain admission to and secure needed financial aid at a postsecondary institution and (4) succeed in first-year, credit-bearing coursework at a postsecondary institution."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Regents of the University of Minnesota
Project Title: Accelerating Reading Proficiency of High Need Early Learners
Project Description: "'Accelerating Reading Proficiency of High Need Early Learners' is a developmental grant proposal targeting Absolute Priority 3:  Innovations that complement the implementation of high standards and high-quality assessments.  Consistent with Competitive Preference Priority 5, the project is designed to systematically improve early learning outcomes of 1st - 3rd grade students who are not meeting grade-level MN state standards for reading proficiency.  In Minneapolis Public Schools (MPS), 85% of European American students read at or above the proficient level, compared to 37%, 36%, 32%, and 25% of Native American, Hispanic American, African American, and English Language Learning students, respectively.  Project activities will involve (a) interim assessment to identify students early who are not meeting statewide norms for reading proficiency, and (b) implementation of instructional strategies matched to individual student needs to accelerate the reading growth of high need students.  Consistent with Competitive Preference Priority 7, the University of Minnesota, and its official partner, MPS, will provide individualized assessment and intervention to accelerate the reading proficiency of 600 Native American, Hispanic American, African American, and English Language Learning students over 5 years.  After demonstrating the impact of individualized assessment and intervention, specific tests of dosage and maintenance will be conducted, and procedures to ensure sustainability will be implemented.  Specific project goals include:  (1) to increase the percentage of high-needs students in grades 1-3 in MPS who meet or exceed the MN state standards for reading proficiency,  (2) participating student gains will maintain for 1-4 years following intervention, (3) MPS educational staff will incorporate interim assessments into their routine educational practices to identify high need students and oversee individualized intervention to accelerate reading growth."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Region 8 Education Service Agency of Northeast Indiana (Inter-Local Education Agency)
Project Title: Navigation 101
Project Description: "Based on a promising program from Washington state, a ?missing discipline? of college and career readiness will be introduced to 60,000 students in 100 U.S. high schools.  Twenty hours of planning and self-management instruction will be provided in each year of grades 9 ? 12, producing more college and career ready students in participating schools.  All students will present their college and career readiness plan and portfolio in a student-led conference every year.  Every student?s readiness will be quantified according to grade-specific standards.  Off-track students will be identified and remedial services will be provided to put them back ?on-track.?  A readiness infrastructure will be developed in each school to manage the continuous improvement and sustainability of the program."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: TEEM Initiative
Project Description: "The proposed goal is to: Enhance learning and academic performance of all students (including low-achieving and low-income, children with limited English proficiency, and disabilities) by cultivating excellence in teaching, instructional delivery, technology integration, student support services, assessment, and school operations in all campuses of Region One.  Objective: 1) Raise academic achievement of all students in core subjects; 2) Increase college readiness of all high school students; 3) Increase college enrollment among graduating high school students; 4) Increase graduation rates all high school students; 5) Decrease dropout rates in all grades K-12; 6) Increase early literacy, language, mathematics, and social development skills among Kindergarten students; 7)  Increase  student Pre-K to Kindergarten to from middle to high school; 8) Increase leadership skills, pedagogical and content knowledge, and teaching strategies of school administrators and teachers  through ongoing, high-quality, job-embedded professional development and follow-up support; and 9) Evaluate, validate and improve the TEEM Initiative through rigorous evaluation efforts and replicate the TEEM Initiative  in all school campuses (K-12) within Region One.    Outcomes: Participating campuses will improve in:  1) number of Pre-K and Kindergarten students determined school ready; 2) increased TAKS scores; 3) number of students enrolled in college; 4) number of students in concurrent/dual enrollment programs and AP courses; 5) number of students performing at and above proficient levels; 6) performance level of campuses on AYP assessments, 7) participation rate and average scores of students on SAT/ACT exams; 8) attendance and dropout rates of students; 9) number of students college ready as defined by TEA;  10) graduation rates; 11) number of highly effective teachers; and 12) participation  rate of educators in professional development  programs."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Systemic Navigation and Planning (SNAP)
Project Description: "This proposed project would take the Systemic Navigation and Planning process into multiple districts for training and implementation.  This project provides new and innovative ways to review data and establish findings that drive effective campus and district plans.  Impacting the culture of the pilot districts is key to the success of this program.  We endeavor to impact culture through the development of strong district vision, mission and core belief statements that lead to effective district-wide goals.  The project will also provide on-line and other electronic tools to guide the comprehensive needs assessment, district/campus planning process and the development of a system consisting of a common language, common structures and common processes.  Utilizing other Regional Service Centers, we will pilot these programs across the state in districts exhibiting a diversity in size, demographics and performance.  Evaluation and feedback will play a very important role in the future direction of the project."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Improving Mathematics Achievement in West Virginia through Innovative Educational Technology
Project Description: "West Virginia's workforce is poorly prepared for the mathematical reasoning required in a 21st century knowledge economy. The need for an immediate, high-impact mathematics intervention is strong. Led by Regional Education Service Agency (RESA) 2, this project provides instructionally diagnostic data to teachers and supporting their integration of data-driven instructional practices into the classroom, impacting over 40,000 students across West Virginia. The use of this technology will enable teachers to gain better insight than ever before into their students' understanding of mathematics. Teachers and administrators will work with experts in understanding data to develop instructional interventions that are suggested by analysis of this second-by-second view of student performance.We will dramatically improve mathematical achievement of secondary students in West Virginia students by (i) providing real-time, formative data to help teachers differentiate classroom math instruction; (ii) improve math instruction via a research-based intelligent tutoring system; and (iii) facilitate conversations about data between teachers, researchers, and educational leaders.  Our design reaches over 40,000 students in 40 middle and 70 high schools. The primary outcome measure for most of the impact studies will be the state's mathematics achievement tests, including WESTEST 2 and ACT scores.We have assembled a team of expert Other Partners who are extraordinarily qualified to successfully implement this program: Every RESA in West Virginia, 8 total;  SRI international, leading experts in effective evaluation and use of educational technology, as independent evaluators of this project;Carnegie Mellon University faculty in the Pittsburgh Science of Learning Center and Open Learning Initiative;The West Virginia Department of Education;Carnegie Learning, Inc., leading provider of educational technology and services for mathematics students and teachers.."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: GLOBAL 21 Profile
Project Description: The ?Global21 Profile? program will assist schools to adopt collaborative and inquiry-based learning strategies to support their implementation of high standards and high-quality assessments that will result in more individualized instruction which benefits all students. The innovation will deploy content and professional development resources that employ transformative curriculum and assessment methodologies to prepare students?including high-need students and those in Rural LEAs?with the depth of knowledge and learning skills that research suggests are strong predictors of college/career success.
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: From Conceptualization to Application (From C to A) Project;  During the implementation of the proposed projects participants will conceptualize core concepts and apply their knowledge into new challenging learning experiences.
Project Description: "The program goal is to increase the Annual Yearly Progress of students with the implementation of Project Based Learning Strategy delivered through a systemic implementation of Professional development sessions. The expected outcome is to increase by 5% the  Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP) at Las Piedras' schools, on core academic subjects: English, Spanish, Mathematics and Science through a professional development program and coaching based on school needs and toward relevant instructional areas as curriculum, strategies, technology and evaluation. Students needs will be addressed by engaging students in project-based learning  activities; an inquiry-based approach to learning where students create knowledge and understanding through activities through inquiry and meaningful tasks. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Improving Reading Comprehension through Formative Reading Assessments
Project Description: "Through this project, AgriScience Reading and Comprehension Assessments will be developed and utilized as formative assessments in high school agricultural education classrooms throughout the State of Illinois.  The assessments will enhance existing agricultural education curriculum in Illinois, which consists of more than 700 academically-aligned lesson plans.  The project will also consist of professional development activities which will train Illinois agriculture teachers on how to effectively use reading strategies and implement the reading and comprehension assessments.Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes:o	Develop seven-hundred AgriScience Reading and Comprehension Assessments which will be used by high school agriculture teachers in Illinois to assess and improve students' reading skills.o	Implement a professional development plan that fully prepares the four-hundred Illinois agriculture teachers to implement content area reading strategies and effectively utilize the AgriScience Reading and Comprehension Assessments. o	Research the reliability and validity of the AgriScience Reading and Comprehension Assessments and determined their impact on the achievement levels of rural LEA students on the reading portion of the Prairie State Achievement Exam (PSAE)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Rensselaer, Columbia, Greene Counties Board of Cooperative Educational Services d/b/a Questar III
Project Title: Tech Valley STEM21 Innovation in Education Project
Project Description: "The Rensselaer, Columbia, Greene Counties Board of Cooperative Educational Services (Questar III BOCES)and the Capital Region BOCES from the Capital Region of New York State are submitting an i3 DevelopmentGrant to implement the Tech Valley STEM21 Innovation in Education Project that focuses on AbsolutePriority #3. The STEM21 project is based on the hypothesis that by extending, strengthening and expandingthe proven teaching methodology and practices of Tech Valley High School (TVHS) throughout the region, apredictable increase in student achievement among all students in the region will ensue as indicated bysignificant gains in achievement scores, graduation rates and readiness for college and careers. The model alsoexpands professional development opportunities for local and regional teachers to increase expertise in thedelivery of an integrated project based learning curriculum and provides a plan to increase college andworkforce readiness for high needs students, especially minorities and women. TVHS is an innovative publicsecondary school that delivers a STEM across the curriculum through project-based learning activitiesdeveloped side by side with the region?s high tech business and industry. A regional teacher center and threeinstitutions of higher education ? University at Albany, Union College, College of St. Rose - will form thebasis of a regional collaborative that constructs an innovative teacher and principal training model thatencompasses both pre-service and in-service professional development and has the potential to developalternate paths to teacher certification within the state. The goals of the project are: 1: Accelerate the TechValley High STEM21 prototype development to ensure high standards and quality education and assessmentsfor student achievement, progress toward college and career readiness; 2: Disseminate the Tech ValleySTEM21 prototype to improve student achievement and growth throughout the region and New York State"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Leading, Learning and Teaching in Mathematics: Transforming Schools, Classrooms and Culture
Project Description: "The Renton School District?s i3 Development Grant proposal will improve achievement for underserved students by providing substantial support to increase the effectiveness of teachers and principals (Absolute Priority 1). The content focus will be mathematics and will include Competitive Preference Priorities 6 and 7. The project includes a student support system, teacher and principal support system and the development and implementation of a teacher evaluation system with student achievement at its core using high quality, multiple assessment measures.Objectives include: (1) Increase the capacity of teachers to meet the learning needs of struggling students; (2) Increase the rigor of classroom instruction and student responses to mathematics tasks; and (3) Develop, implement and evaluate a teacher evaluation system that provides multiple forms of evidence of teacher effectiveness that has student achievement at its core.Outcomes include: (1) Implementation of Common Core standards connected to district expectations and instructional practices; (2) Improve student performance on state assessments, formative, benchmark, end-of-course and classroom-based assessments (3) Increase the number and diversity of students succeeding in higher-level math courses; and (4) Increase graduation rates and ensure students graduate college and career ready, particularly high-need students.Renton?s project will directly serve 3,130 students in grades 6 through 10. Our official non-profit partner is the Institute for Systems Biology (ISB) a nonprofit center for biomedical research located in Seattle. ISB has a strong mission-driven commitment to education, as exemplified by its education group known as the Center for Inquiry Science (CIS). Other partners include the University of Washington, Center for Educational Effectiveness and Education Northwest, with our 20% match provided by the Washington STEM Center."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Project iPANDA - Innovative Practices in Analyzing New Data and Assessments
Project Description: "Project iPANDA proposes to provide target West Virginia Response To Intervention (RTI) schools with augmented data collection and analysis resources that will support more rigorous use of student data, enabling these RTI programs to successfully and consistently improve student achievement.  This program draws upon RTI research best practices to provide teachers and staff with the tools necessary to insure local RTI success, and it will also provide new data, proving that this combination of rigorous data tools indeed allows RTI programs to produce significant increases in student achievement.  This program will rely heavily upon rigorously designed and implemented, scientifically controlled, quasi-experimental studies to establish the best approach to determining student needs, evaluating the efficacy of intervention, and tracking student development."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: CFWV Curriculum and Education Access Center
Project Description: "The Regional Education Service Agency 7 (RESA 7) project is designed to promote goal setting, student achievement, and enhance awareness of the need to expand access to postsecondary education while becoming a resource for all students, families, and communities for information to succeed in the 21st Century.  Through the implementation of a curriculum articulating the importance of postsecondary access, the agency aims to significantly improve transition rates across all facets of the P-16 educational pipeline.  Through the implementation of the initiatives articulated above, RESA 7 will work toward achieving five distinct objectives.  Those objectives are:Objective One: To increase the number of high-poverty, at-risk students who are prepared to enter and succeed in postsecondary education.Objective Two: To increase the students' knowledge on goal setting and the necessary actions to achieve their goals.Objective Three: To increase the rate of high school graduation and participation of cohort students in postsecondary education. Objective Four:  To increase cohort students' and families' knowledge of postsecondary educational institutions, admissions requirements, and financial aid. Objective Five: To ensure effective, efficient, and most appropriate use of resources through intentional collaboration with identified partners that are committed to the goals of the curriculum."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Research Foundation of  the City University of New York  on behalf of Baruch College
Project Title: CUNY Latino and Immigrant Student Initiative
Project Description: "The School of Public Affairs at Baruch College (SPA) and the City University of New York (CUNY) seek fundsfrom the i3 Investment in Innovation Fund for 'The CUNY Latino and Immigrant Initiative'. ThisDevelopment grant addresses absolute priority 4 -- Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low PerformingSchools -- and competitive preference priorities 6 -- innovations that support college access and success --and 7 -- innovation to address the unique learning needs of students with limited English Proficiency. TheInitiative innovates by promoting partnerships between CUNY and SPA, immigrant community organizationsand New York City public high schools. These partnerships will promote high school graduation in lowperforming schools, and build bridges to college and capacity to support success there in newcomercommunities. T he College Prep and Bridge Program offers After School and Mentorship programs tostudents, mainly newcomer groups (e.g. Mexicans and Central Americans). It provides extra instruction incore areas, and embeds After School staff in the regular school day. Our Mentorship Program offers one-oneonementoring for our high school students by a college or graduate student, and a partnership with parents.The College Bridge Program offers students concrete support from CUNY staff, mentors, and the communitythrough the college application process, and support in college. Our Building Civic Capacity for EducationProgram will offer fellowships for Masters students (many, children of immigrants) who will work asteachers/administrators or in organizations promoting education among newcomer communities. SPA haslong built civic capacity in emerging immigrant communities. We anticipate serving 300-400 students peryear, and expect a large majority to graduate and attend college. Partners: CUNY, SPA, Washington IrvingHigh and Eastern Brooklyn Congreations high schools, Mexican Educational Foundation of New York."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Research Foundation of CUNY on behalf of Lehman College
