Project Title: Investing In Innovation: Creating a Pathway of Excellence for the South Bronx
Project Description: "To meet the challenges of national priorities and the localized urgency the CAPE partnership unites: 1. the nationally recognized teacher preparation programs and faculty of Lehman College a Bronx-based, Hispanic-Serving Institution; 2. the demonstrated commitment of the NYCDOE to increase student achievement in the South Bronx; 3. the expertise of the Educational Testing Service to provide research-based professional development and support through Keeping Learning on Track (KLT)? and Mathematics Challenges (MC)?  for in-service teachers and school leaders to impact student achievement, 4. the extensive and successful work of the Education Development Center, Inc. for math teacher professional development using Developing Mathematical Ideas (DMI)? and the evaluation expertise of Research for Better Schools to assure effective implementation and outcomes."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Research Foundation of SUNY on behalf of SUNY Cobleskill
Project Title: Rural NY Investing in Innovation Project (Rural NY i3)
Project Description: "Annually, this project will provide services to all 1,368 middle and high school students at eight Small, Rural School Achievement (SRSA) eligible school districts in three impoverished northern New York State counties. Primary services will include: full-time professional one-on-one and small group tutoring, mentoring, academic counseling for students and parents, and college, career and cultural exploration activities to all students as well as Advanced Placement and dual-enrollment coursework to 11th and 12th graders. Additional academic enrichment and assessment will come from The College Board and its CollegeEd curriculum, MyRoad, SpringBoard, Accuplacer, PSAT/NMSQT, SAT and the SAT Online Review for all students. Nationally recognized professional development opportunities will be offered to administrators, guidance counselors and teachers.The primary objectives are to a), increase the achievement of rural, socially and culturally isolated students in rigorous academic programs and help them prepare for, enter, and graduate from two- or four- year colleges, and b), increase the capacity of the districts to provide quality instruction and formative and interim assessment data for core subjects. Measurable outcomes will include an increase in NYS Regents? scores, decreased dropout rates, increased AP and dual-enrollment participation, increased knowledge of admissions procedures and financial aid availability, 100% college application rate, 100% acceptance rate, a 90% college-going rate, and a markedly increased college persistence rate.Official Partners include: the State University of New York at Cobleskill (non-profit organization) and a consortium of eight central school districts: Elizabethtown-Lewis, Fort Ann, Johnsburg, Minerva, North Warren, Schroon Lake, Westport, and Willsboro.Other Partners include: The College Board and Paul Smith?s College."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Research Foundation of the City University of New York
Project Title: New Pathways to College
Project Description: "The City of New York (CUNY), in partnership with the New York City Department of Education (DOE), seeks funding to conduct a Validation Project to address I3 Absolute Priority 3 and I3 Competitive Preference Priority 6. The proposed project, New Pathways to College, intends to increase high school and college graduation rates by developing an academically rigorous sequence of college-sponsored courses and activities as part of an 'enhanced comprehensive dual enrollment' program.CUNY has been in the forefront of efforts to strengthen and expand dual enrollment programs, a promising approach for preparing students for the rigors of college. CUNY's dual enrollment programs, including College Now and the Early College Initiative, help schools adopt more rigorous academic programs that meet a college preparatory standard, help students meet high school graduation requirements and help students prepare for success in college. Elements of the proposed program include: college access and success courses, College Foundation courses, developmental courses oriented to CUNY's placement exams and college credit courses.  CUNY proposes to conduct a five-year project designed to validate the effectiveness of its comprehensive dual enrollment efforts and to develop a replicable model for the establishment of similar programs in the nation's largest cities.  The final measures of the effectiveness of the proposed project will be to demonstrate increased rates of high school and college graduation for participants as compared to non-participants with similar characteristics. The project will involve 4 to 5 of CUNY's colleges (including community and senior colleges) and approximately 20 public secondary schools enrolling approximately 19,000 students a year.  Participating schools, reflecting the various types in the system, will be selected in cooperation with the DOE to ensure the inclusion of substantial numbers of students from under-represented populations in college.  "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: RF-CUNY on behalf of Queensborough Community College
Project Title: The Community Campus Project
Project Description: "The CCP is a targeted approach to help turn around persistently low-performing schools through the creation ofexpanded out-of-school time learning opportunities in core academic subjects, integrated student supports toaddress non-academic barriers to student achievement, and multiple pathways to earn high school diplomas.The CCP also addresses competitive priorities 6 and 7 by providing educational programs to support collegeaccess/success and address the needs of limited English proficient (LEP) students. The CCP 4-year programdesign is anchored by two out-of-school time programs at the QCC campus: a 30 week after-school programfor 100 HS students and a 6 week summer program operated by 75 HS and 180 MS students. Activities includeDual Enrollment Courses taught by QCC Professors, Homework Assistance/Tutoring, SAT Prep,College/Financial Aid Application Assistance, Visual and Performing Arts, Sports/Rec, Service-Learning,Leadership/Character Education, Job Training/Certification Programs, and College Student Supports."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Powering Up Parent Engagement To Improve Student Achievement
Project Description: "This Powering up Parent Engagement to Improve Student Achievement project represents an exceptional approach to key priorities we seek to meet: it addresses a largely unmet need, particularly for high-need students, and is a strategy that has not already been widely adopted.  Our proposed project systemically embeds proven leadership training in Bridgeport, CT for both school personnel and parents to positively impact parent involvement in schools, teacher and principal effectiveness and ultimately student achievement. Combining comprehensive civic leadership skill training for parents with Dr. Joyce Epstein's model for school, family and community partnerships will lead to action in education reform, greater accountability and higher student achievement.  The result of joint action planning and implementation related to school improvement and student performance between trained parents, community and school leaders, will be unprecedented. All partners are trained, and committed to come together and work together with the expressed goal of improved student success. We will evaluate the action outcomes of combining trained parents, teachers, community and school leaders. This project addresses Absolute Priority 1, 'Innovations That Support Effective Teachers and Principals'.As Secretary of Education Arne Duncan noted in a speech on May 3, 2010 to the first annual Mom Congress on Education and Learning, 'It is well-documented-and plain common sense-that parental involvement in a child's education boosts student learning and improves both behavior and attendance.  We know that children with parents who are engaged in their education are less likely to drop out.'   Secretary Duncan continued on to say, 'There is surprisingly little research, however, to show what works and doesn't work in family engagement programs to accelerate student learning.'   Our project is designed to do exactly that in one urban high needs LEA."

Project Title: Early Literacy Cultural Collaborative
Project Description: "This Development project is designed with the hypothesis that Black and Latino students acquire early literacy skills in English at accelerated rates when instruction is delivered within the context of culturally relevant pedagogy.  In the lives of Black and Latino students, there are a variety of adults who can serve a role in building literacy skills based on the culturally relevant experience of children. This project will bring these individuals together (educators, families, and home care providers) in a collective effort to enhance literacy for students of color, including those who are identified as 'Limited English Proficient' and those who come from low-income homes.  Professional development experts will provide training and coaching in five communities at neighborhood schools, where these individuals can partner together at the end of the school day. Summary of project objectives and expected outcomes:o	Teachers will use Interactive Shared Book Reading, Interactive Writing, and Culturally Relevant Practices in classrooms to increase reading and writing skills.o	Adults responsible for the afterschool care of students will use Interactive Shared Book Reading and Interactive Writing with individual students to increase reading and writing skills.o	Educators and the care providers will share information about students' experiences, language, culture, learning styles, and monthly progress.o	Students entering a grade without the prerequisite reading and writing skills or below grade level will make minimum gains of 1.5 academic years by the end of the school year.o	Black and Latino students will make adequate academic progress to be at or above grade level by the end of their academic school year, resulting in reduction in the overall achievement gap among subgroups of students. o	Over the five year span of the project, first grade, Kindergarten and then second grade students, as well as their care providers and teachers, will participate in the project."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Rhode Island Mayoral Academies: An Innovative Approach to Building an Outstanding Human Capital Pipeline
Project Description: "RIMA will support the creation and growth of outstanding human capital programs that identify, recruit, develop and place high-performing teachers and future leaders in mayoral academies and other RI schools. RIMA will meet this ambitious goal by: (1) serving as the ?first-touch? resource for new and experienced teaching candidates and career-changers who wish to teach in RI, and an information clearinghouse for alternative human capital providers and CMO partners; (2) codifying and expanding a teaching residency program to directly certify highly effective educators to work in mayoral academies; and (3) developing a data warehouse to track the effectiveness of our strategies in improving student performance.Our project objectives are: (1) Establish a recruitment strategy and clearinghouse for RI teaching candidates and CMO partners to recruit a sufficient number of highly effective educators to staff RIMA?s growing portfolio of outstanding mayoral academies; (2) offer direct certification through a rigorous residency program to train 27 new teachers and 33 lead teachers in mayoral academies across the state; and (3) develop and maintain a data warehouse to enable tracking and analysis of the success of RIMA?s efforts and the effectiveness of its Resident completers in the classroom.By 2015, mayoral academies will grow to at least nine schools serving 3,016 students and employing 114 teachers and 83 teaching Residents. Hundreds of other students in RI will benefit from the project indirectly, through Residents or lead teachers who may transition to traditional district schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Richard Milburn Academy, Inc. (RMA), a Virginia 501(c)3
Project Title: Go Career! Go College!
Project Description: "Richard Milburn Academy, Inc. (RMA) is applying for a Development Grant. The RMA Team has operated 14 charter high schools for high need students since 1998. The RMA charter schools have 6 basic components and 5 innovative components as follows:A.	 Basic Program Components:-Academic Core Curriculum-Remediation/Skill Building	-Work Study-Life Skills	-Low Pupil Teacher Ratio-Monitored StudyB.	 Innovative Program Components:-Non Traditional Scheduling Options-Experiential Learning	-Milburn High School Online-Portfolios-Graduation and Post Secondary SuccessThe 7 RMA schools included in this grant have had promising results for high need students. RMA produced significant: 1.) attendance rates of 80% or better with an 87% average; 2.) pass rates on state assessments of 70% or higher on state mandated assessment tests with an 82% average; 3.) success of 79% in keeping high need students in school progressing towards graduation with an 86% average; 4.) senior graduation rate of at least 58% with an average of 68%; 5.) high percentage of postsecondary college enrollments of at least 44% with an average of 52%.The Project Evaluation will be done by RMC Research, an expert in educational evaluation. The evaluation uses a quasi-experimental randomized design. The evaluation has two major objectives: 1) to assess and enhance the process of developing and implementing the RM program model and 2) to assess the effect of the model on student results. A formative evaluation will be conducted in Years 1/2 to refine and expand the current model, followed by a rigorous summative evaluation on the effect of the RMA model on student results in Year 3."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: "Paying it Forward:"  Educating America's High-Need Students
Project Description: "Our goal is to retrieve high-need, at-risk, high-school students residing in Florida who have dropped out of school, and provide an educational offering in an innovative, self-paced, contemporary, and  individualized instructional program that results in a high school diploma, suitable vocations, or continuing education that includes enrolling in, and graduating from a two or four year college. Curriculum and instructional practices will focus on the learning needs of students who have dropped out or who are in danger of dropping out of  school.  We intend to focus on a long-term approach that will: o	enhance the holding power of schools, with an intensive focus on ninth grade o    focus on the forces outside of school that contribute to dropping out o    address the needs of those groups at highest risk of dropping out o	build on the skills and understanding of the adults who affect teens' motivation and ability to stay in school Building Hope will make available interest free loans of up to $600,000 to local nonprofit entities that successfully receive a charter for the renovation and repair of the building that has been selected as a school site. The payback will commence when the school reaches enrollment 400 students. There is enough cash flow between the anticipated student enrollments of 400 to 500 students to pay back the loan over a 3 year period. Each school will be able to make payments of approximately $17,000 monthly, for a yearly total of $200,000. These funds will enable Building Hope (who will be custodians of the account,) to make loans in perpetuity.  Thus, schools could be replicated (using the original i3 grant monies), throughout America. This would be based solely on the market need for 350-500 drop- out students in a community. Many of these schools can flourish in towns and rural counties that have populations that have less than 35,000 residents."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Go Center
Project Description: "The Richmond County School System (RCSS) in Georgia's second largest and oldest city of Augusta is proposing to establish Project Go Center a unique graduation campus for both college and career development geared specifically to meet the needs of the most challenged students that have been designated as high at-risk students or as recent recovered dropouts. The goal of the proposed program is to prepare and support 2,500 students of a total student populace of 32,375 for the challenges of turning around chronically low performing urban high schools as 8 of 10 did not meet 2009 Annual Yearly Progress (AYP). The Go Center will provide; alternative pathways for high school graduation with online, hands-on and traditional credit recovery classes; site-based career apprenticeships; a caring restructured high school community with highly trained teachers and administrators; support services to include childcare and transportation; modern technology in classrooms to include smart boards, slates and personal laptops; a college bound preparedness to include college mentors, goal setting, tours and admissions support; a one-stop solution for major graduation setbacks with creative incentives for graduation and post secondary matriculation.  The Go Center's curriculum allows students to quickly recover lost credits and also blend apprenticeship experiences to connect education and real life solutions to overcome both poverty and prior academic failures. RCSS will employ only the best teachers and administrators to work with targeted participants in a newly renovated facility utilizing modern urban best practices. The ambitious goals are to increase graduation rates to 90%, decrease the dropout rate to only 10%,   increase popost secondary preparedness to 85%, and have 100% participants recover credits to get back on track towards high school completion."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: STEM 4 All
Project Description: "The applicant, Richmond County School District located in southern North Carolina, is a largely rural county with approximately 46,000 residents. The school district consists of 18 public schools. In 2009-10, the district enrolled approximately 7,630 students, including 5,447 (71%) low-income students. For the past two years, the district has been in LEA Improvement Status, not meeting its Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP) targets; however, the district has experienced success in ways that are associated with this proposal. Richmond County Schools with Anson and Scotland County Schools, have formed a partnership with the NC Motorsports Association, NC Biotechnology Center, and NC State University, and will contract with Skylink Family and School Network and Microspace Communications Corporation to create and implement a curriculum of STEM education that will reach all students via satellite technology and cyber learning.Cyber-learning and cyber-teaching extends 21st-century learning opportunities beyond the single classroom, school, and even district, to states, the nation, and the world. The technologies available today hold great promise and potential to provide a new way to increase K-12 student understandings of STEM concepts, creative thinking and problem solving, along with providing STEM career opportunities, especially for students attending high needs school districts.With this Development grant, Richmond County will implement a program to help all students improve their STEM skills and help the school system and partnering school districts meet their goals for student achievement. The project is replicable and can be taken to scale in a cost-efficient manner. The satellite technology is capable of reaching school districts anywhere in the nation."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: "Providing Opportunity Driving Educational Rigor"
Project Description: "The purpose of the Providing Opportunities Driving Educational Rigor (PODER) Program is to expand the useof innovative practices proven to have an impact on student achievement, closing achievement gaps of the K-5th grade students in Rio Grande City CISD by providing technological tools for constructivist learning;training for participants for decision-making through the use of data aggregation and analysis; and systematicimplementation, effective program monitoring, and the critical uses of a data-driven evaluation plan. PODERconsists of three facets to implement: the iPads for Academic Development (PAD) Project, ProvidingOpportunities that Work (POW) Project, and Providing Academic Innovation through Data (PAID) Project.The PAD Project provides physical, human, and intellectual resources of the program, ensuring the provisionof the physical resources of Apple iPADs with application software for every campus, monitors/televisions,and library resources to be used. Further, PAD provides Specialists as the human resources needed for theeffective monitoring of the program implementation, instructional integration of technology into thecurriculum, the use of Shared Inquiry, progress monitoring through data collection and analysis, modeling, andguiding teachers in the implementation of the program components. Finally, PAD provides the intellectualresources in the training needed to develop high quality teaching. The POW Project provides the restructuringof the curriculum, correlated activities, and instructional modalities by which teachers rely. Through the POWProject, Apple iPAD applications will be correlated to the new adopted textbooks and the present curricula inthe district. The PAID Project consists of a system of formative, data-driven decision making; effectiveresponses to intervention; and flexibility of instructional design in order to ensure academic success. PAIDprovides the assessment component of the entire program."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Data Matters: Leveraging Algebra 1 Success for College Eligiblity
Project Description: "Project Description: This grant proposal supports a local school district, El Monte Union High School Districtin Los Angeles County in collaboration with Rio Hondo College District to make a concerted effort to use datain more ?promising? coordinated ways. These strategies will accelerate learning, maximize resources, increaseefficiency, and improve student success, all of which will lead to increased high school graduation rates andimproved college eligibility and subsequent enrollment. These improvements will be fostered through aninnovative method of using student generated data to train teachers and direct their teaching throughprogressive techniques and methods. Improved student outcomes will be realized by increasing success in highschool Algebra I through integrating data-driven student preparation activities to generate greater studentintentions to complete a four-year degree.Summary of Project Objectives/Outcomes: Two earlier GEAR UP (spell out) grants expanded awareness of theeffectiveness of a multi-education level collaboration that demonstrated continuous student improvementamong the low-income and underrepresented students pulled from the area?s historically non-college-boundpopulation. The central and innovative use of math diagnostic testing and formative assessments from thesegrants provide continuous data for teachers at the high schools. As a result, use of data is at the heart of thisproposal to effect classroom change and modify instruction. These promising practices integrate studentsupport activities by measurably improving student college preparation and success.Data-Driven Interventions? Training teachers to use data outcomes and assessments to change the way they teach,? Providing teachers with new instructional techniques, practices and pedagogy,? A Multi-District Math Articulation Task Force,? Use of ?Data Chat? providing collaborative time among teachers and community college faculty to reviewAlgebra placeme"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project PRIME for Algebra Success
Project Description: "The Rio Hondo Education Consortium PRIME Project is proposing to serve a total of 9,090 middle school students over a five-year period with funds for a Validation grant.  California has set a high expectation for 8th grade students - to take Algebra 1 and be tested on it as part of the state's accountability standards.  Currently, our schools are facing a huge hurdle --- 55% of our students are failing to successfully pass algebra in the 8th grade, with even greater numbers subsequently (70%) failing algebra in high school and college.  In order to meet this mandate, the PRIME project will work to ensure that every student in middle school receives the necessary preparation to be able to enter and succeed in the 8th grade algebra course.  The success of this project will lead to overall increases in the number of: (1) students successfully passing algebra in the 8th grade and subsequently in high school; (2) students graduating from high school; (3) students entering and completing post-secondary education, and (4) students pursuing careers in science, technology, engineering and math.  The project intends to be successful by: (1) working to initiate systemic school changes that institutionalize efforts to increase algebra readiness and success by replacing ineffective teaching models; (2) providing students with an array of student support services during non-school hours; and (3) by hosting educational parent events to increase parent involvement.The success of the project will rest upon a systemic approach to the project by working to build the internal capacity of the target schools.  The quality of the delivery of services by an experienced project staff with 20+ years of educational programming, along with the support of official partners, such as Renaissance Learning and New Mexico Highlands University, as well as the dedicated commitment of other existing community partners will help to achieve increased math achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The College Guidance System
Project Description: "Rio Rancho Public Schools (RRPS) proposes creating a comprehensive college-readiness system that preparesstudents for academic, college and career success. The College Guidance System (CGS) contains a strategy toachieve 3 goals: 1. greater academic rigor aligned with assessments, 2. strategic college-going support tostudents and parents, and 3. a reorientation of teachers, counselors and administrators that focuses on collegereadiness. RRPS will form a consortium with Bernalillo Public Schools and two Albuquerque Public Schoolsfeeder patterns to develop and implement CGS. Nonprofits College Board and AVID will serve as ?otherpartners? and provide extensive professional development on college-readiness curricula and assessments.Innovative CGS initiatives include implementing AVID and SpringBoard in targeted upper elementary, middleand high schools; creating College Centers to hold multi-media materials and information on college readiness;developing College Guidance Teams of teachers to target and support high-need students to graduate collegeready; recruiting Advanced Placement high school students to mentor and tutor students in elementary andmiddle schools; appointing a college counselor in each high school to ensure all college-ready initiatives areimplemented with fidelity and to build awareness of available college-going supports; developing a systemic,sustained plan to engage parents in college readiness early in their children?s education; and offering intensiveprofessional development to enhance instructional skills. assessment literacy, and college-going literacy.Ultimately, the goal of CGS is to create a college-going culture to prepare all students, especially high-needstudents, to enter and succeed in college."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Equity and Excellence for all Students Project
Project Description: "The Equity and Excellence for all Students Project will increase the participation and improve the success of under-represented student populations in academically rigorous AP courses. To accomplish this goal, the LEA will create a comprehensive Pre-AP and AP system in grades six through twelve, expand AP course offerings, develop a Writing and Critical Thinking curriculum targeting English Language Learners and students with disabilities, as introduce 1-to-1 Technology as a tool to improve teaching and learning. A university-based external evaluator will conduct a thorough external evaluation of the project and assist in the creation of a replication handbook. Evaluation methods, including quasi-experimental analyses, will produce quantitative and qualitative data addressing fidelity of implementation and all expected measurable outcomes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovative Consulting Approach to Student Achievement
Project Description: "Riverside County Office of Education (RCOE) is submitting this (i3) Validation Grant proposal to expand itsInnovative Consulting Approach to Student Achievement (ICASA) program. ICASA provides on-site,customized service to districts using a comprehensive Consulting Framework and Principle Matrix to guidesystem-wide improvement based on the analysis of a variety of academic achievement, school culture, andleadership capacity data. Each participating district will receive services from RCOE and its partners, based ona data-based Implementation Plan developed annually in collaboration with an RCOE ICASA lead. Otherproject activities will include participation in an annual RCOE-sponsored DuFour Conference on ProfessionalLearning Communities (PLCs), Data Team trainings, professional development and support for high schoolteachers aimed at student achievement growth, closing the achievement gap, and preparing students withcollege-and career-ready skills. Project objectives include implementing consistent systems and practicesdistrict-wide to increase understanding and ownership of the PLC process, improve quality of district-levelbenchmark assessments and data analysis skills to ensure student mastery of rigorous standards, meet theunique learning needs of high needs students through greater implementation of targeted strategies, increasestudent achievement and close the achievement gap, decrease the dropout rate, increase the California (CA)High School Exit Exam pass rate, and improve student readiness for college and career. This project will serveapproximately 259,000 students in 37 educational agencies in Riverside County, CA; Sanger, CA; andBetendorf, Iowa. Official partners are Sanger Unified School District (USD) in CA and Mississippi Bend AreaEducation Agency in Iowa to replicate the ICASA process. Also served: Alvord USD, Coachella Valley USD,Jurupa USD, Moreno Valley USD, Palm Springs USD, Palo Verde USD, Perris USD and nine privatepartners."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Digital Learning Revolution
Project Description: "RUSD's Digital Learning Revolution will focus on each incoming 9th grade class over the proposed three-year period of the grant and continue to provide resources and support through grade 11 by the end of the three year grant period.  Each 9th grade student will be provided with a Personal Learning Management Device (PLMD) that is multimedia and Internet capable and that will be used at school and home.   This device will contain or have access to all of the high quality standards-based curriculum and assessments applicable to each student's academic schedule.  Resources will include all of the districts adopted textbooks, open source material and iTunes University lectures and course content.  The PLMD is interactive in nature and contains tools that enable students to write, draw or type over or onto any curriculum resource.  Each device will have built in calendaring, collaboration, and communication capability enabling effective two-way communication between teachers, students and parents.  The PLMD and the accompanying management system allow for assessments to be given and submitted electronically so that students and teachers can track progress and obtain additional help as needed.  All resources provided on the device are available via the Internet using a management system that allows parents and all stakeholders' access to all resources including student assignments, progress and grades.  All identified students will have access to high quality standards-based curriculum resources and assessments that are aligned to the State of California framework and have been locally adopted by our board of education.  Adopted resources will be provided for all 9th-11th grade courses.  Each PLMD provides the capability for teachers to provide ad hoc formative assessments providing immediate feedback of student understanding allowing the teacher to re-teach or differentiate based on student needs. DLR will revolutionize how students learn, communicate and collaborate."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: California Open Campus Initiative (CAOCI)
Project Description: "The California Open Campus Initiative (CAOCI) supports sixteen California school districts in partnership with businesses, non-profits, and institutions of higher education, in leveraging time, resources, and opportunity to increase student achievement in math and science and promote college readiness for all students. Federal funds will expand access for 297,778 California students to rigorous, evidence-based, Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) resources via a centralized virtual learning environment, which is accessible to students in classroom, home, or any location with access to the Internet. A shared learning management system will allow teachers, throughout the consortium, to access digital content and engage in an online community of practice. This reform-minded strategy, at the grassroots level, will support teachers in becoming agents of change within their schools, while providing access to a powerful online network through which to propagate best practices for STEM educators throughout the State. The partners identified within this application are uniquely positioned to serve a wide-range of high-needs students in California. The research and evaluation components of the proposal are supported by the University of Southern California (USC) and will produce scientifically-based evidence relating to the impact of program components on multiple student achievement outcomes. USC has developed a comprehensive research design that incorporates random assignment and use of control groups. To support validity and generalizability, random assignment of treatment and control groups will be maintained at the classroom level in each district. The California Open Campus Initiative represents an innovative effort to build collaboration between districts and expand access to college preparatory and standards-based curriculum and assessments. It is a model with strong likelihood of producing scientifically-based evidence that supports replication."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Mastering Standards in Rural Classrooms: Making Assessment Data Learning
Project Description: "Roanoke City Schools (RCS), in partnership with the Alabama State Department of Education (ASDE) andAuburn University (AU), seeks a Developmental grant in the amount of $2.5 million to implement andinstitutionalize a competency-based curriculum model that will improve the use of assessment data (AbsolutePriority 2). The model builds on the promising practice of classroom assessment as learning. The goal is tovalidate the research on this innovative practice by demonstrating district wide transformation of the learningexperience in rural classrooms. Assessment literate teachers will use just-in-time assessment data to closestudent achievement gaps, while increasing rural students? low expectations (Competitive Priority 8).An online assessment literacy course for educators and easy to use assessment delivery and tracking software willbe developed at the start of the project. Once these are deployed, assessment literate teachers will implementan innovative K-12 competency-based curriculum developed by RCS and AU. Based on assessmentsadministered over student laptops, the new software will track each student?s mastery of every standard.Teachers will use the software to provide all students, high needs and rural, a recovery path for missedstandards. The expected outcomes: 1) teachers and students will see assessment in the classroom as learning;2) students will master all state and national standards; 3) students, rural and high need, will believe that theycan graduate high school and be college and career-ready.RCS presents a comprehensive reform initiative for all of its 1,500 students and a well developed plan toimplement this vision of assessment for learning. With committed partners RCS will create a replicablecurriculum that will close the achievement gap for all its students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Strong Teachers. Strong Students. Strong Schools.
Project Description: "The Strong Teachers. Strong Students. Strong Schools. project is a five-year proposal by Roanoke City Public Schools (RCPS) in Roanoke, Virginia.  It offers three inter-related, mutually-reinforcing components on an educational continuum that strengthens teacher and student performance from preschool through college by supplying strategic interventions for teachers, students and our pre-k partners. Program models have strong empirical support and a body of emperical research. Project objectives and outcomes include a variable compensation program for all 1,100 teachers and principals, improved instructional quality and performance, and the promulgation of Social-Emotional Learning (SEL).  The project impacts all 13,000 students and 1,400 faculity. The project concentrates on high-need students and schools. Special features of the project include: 1) engagement of most teachers in our city, from pre-k to college, 2) a unique, linked continuum of services including a matured, variable compensation plan, 3) an SEL program supporting teachers and students, and targeted mentoring and coaching for all school transition trouble spots, leading to sustainable, replicable system change based upon the best, fully-supportable strategies from around the nation. Official partners include RCPS, Virginia Western Community College, Radford University (SEL training), Smart Beginnings (pre-k education), Virginia Polytechnic Institute (VT), Total Action Against Poverty (TAP)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Robert W. Woodruff Arts Center, Inc.
Project Title: The ASC Project Charter
Project Description: "The Woodruff Arts Center, with its official partner, Atlanta Public Schools, seeks a Development Grant todirectly support high-need students who might otherwise be lost in a traditional high school, especially onewhere the arts are not valued or offered. The ASC Project Charter will develop a replicable sequence ofcurricula and assessments, based upon 21st Century Skills aligned with Georgia?s new Fine and PerformingArts Standards, establish a small high school of the arts and provide a critical pathway for K-8 students togrow through arts learning. This project will test the hypothesis that high-need students who successfullyengage in a comprehensive and rigorous sequence of K-12 arts instruction and performance assessment willsignificantly increase achievement in the arts and other academic areas, with the result being an increase inhigh school graduates prepared for college entry and the 21st Century workforce, than will high-need studentsassigned to a carefully matched comparison control group. At the end of the grant, the project will reach 2,500high-need students and will establish three distinct, but related, replicable and scalable products that arealigned with state standards. These replicable products include:1. A K-12, arts-based 21st Century Skills curricular package of learning units and performance assessments thathas demonstrable impact on high-needs students in achieving state standards in the arts and tested academicareas.2. A methodology for changing teaching and learning using authentic arts-integration strategies that is effectivewith high-needs students, based upon the Reformed Teaching Observation Protocol and the ClassroomAssessment for Learning and Teaching.3. An education model, explicitly utilizing 21st Century Skills, leading transitions from elementary to middle tohigh school, supporting graduation and college-readiness, resulting in the creation of a small school of the arts,the Atlanta Studio Conservatory."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: International Transitional Program
Project Description: "The proposed International Transitional Program represents an exceptional and innovative approach to reform set forth by the reauthorization of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, State Reform and the Strategic Plan of the RCSD. Specifically it seeks to programs of English Learners and encourages an innovative approach to program and practices to support English Language Learner success. Furthermore, this project addresses a largely unmet need of transitional support for approximately 175 secondary ELLs who are assessed high-need students. These students come from a different country and have limited to no English proficiency, are preliterate in English and or have had limited or interrupted schooling (SIFE) in their native language (NL). They may also have limited or no literacy in their native language. This proposal encompasses practices, strategies, and program that have not already been widely adopted. The proposed International Transitional Program will effectively provide cultural orientation for students and parents K-12, and create a transition process for newly arrived ELL students in grade 7-12 who are SIFE and Non-SIFE. It will accelerate and promote academic student success through full - extended day academic and ESL course schedule. Students will then transition into a well prepared and welcoming high school that matches their learning profile and indentified program plan. The proposed International Transitional Program will provide a range of services for students in grades 7-12 who are under credit and/or over age and are at risk for not completing the requirements to obtain a Regents diploma. The program will offer supplemental and accelerated academic courses. An additional innovative approach to student learning is our design to create student Learning Profiles which will give educators a clearer picture of student cognitive growth and previous education, as well as providing the student with input on their academic progress, needs, ?????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Integrating Arts Across Academic Boundaries
Project Description: "The IA3 project is a targeted reform effort for grades K-6 in Rochester's low achieving, high poverty elementary schools, a rural high poverty school district and an area suburban district. The project is based on the success of Rochester's 2006-2009 Federal Arts in Education Model Development and Dissemination experimental, randomized study that showed statistically significant growth in K-6 student achievement.  The proposed i3 project enhances the 2006 AEMDD project by incorporating identified project activities and replicating successful strategies among the general education populations in 13 elementary schools as well as Limited English Proficient students and Students with Disabilities.  The project continues to focus on 10 hours of high quality integrated arts professional development to core class teachers and Teaching Artists, and emphasizes special professional development for Special Education teachers and ESOL/Bilingual teachers. Grades K & 5 will receive music integration, Grades 1, 2, & 6 will receive theatre/movement integration, and Grades 3 & 4 will receive Visual arts integration."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Promise Project
Project Description: "The Rochester City School District (RCSD) is submitting The Promise Project for consideration as a Validation Grant. The proposed Promise Project is a developmentally sequenced constellation of eight interventions targeting 4,300 students in eight elementary schools in the RCSD and 1,400 students in five elementary schools in small, rural schools. The conceptual framework for The Promise Project integrates a bio-psycho-social model and an ecological framework.  Pertaining to school achievement, an ecological framework focuses attention on the key systems that support children's learning, including school environment, classroom functioning, family, and community, as well as on the strength of reciprocal engagement between those systems.  Research suggests closing gaps in achievement and in health for disadvantaged children is dependent on strengthening individual-level development and on strengthening integration between these key spheres, including strong parent-school ties and family ties to community.   Outcome Goal 1: Increase the academic achievement and attendance, and decrease the number of disciplinary actions among the 5,700 students targeted by The Promise Project Outcome Goal 2: Improve the physical wellbeing of all 5,700 students targeted by The Promise Project.  The eight research-based strategies include the following within three thematic areas of intervention.  Physical Health and Wellness: Strategy 1: R.E.S.H.A.P.E. the Future; Strategy 2: The W.I.S.E. Project -- Mental Health and Classroom Competence: Strategy 3: PATHS; Strategy 4: Primary Project; Strategy 5: Rochester Resilience Project; Strategy 6: Coping Power -- Access to Caring and Healthy Support Networks: Strategy 7: Generation Two; Strategy 8: Afterschool Programs.  The Promise Project partners include the University of Rochester, the Children's Institute and Generation Two.  A value-added strategy will be an urban-rural exchange program for a select group of sixth grade students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Rochester Project Based Rural Initiative
Project Description: "This initiative will target approximately 2,300 elementary and middle school students attending RochesterCommunity Schools and Northwest Shelby County Schools. Our official project partners include:Northwestern Consolidated School District; Verizon; Community School Corporation of Eastern HancockCounty; Rochester Telephone Company; Ball State University; University of Indianapolis, Center forExcellence in Leadership of Learning; IBM; Ivy Tech; and Purdue University. Through the RCSC i3 initiativewe will equip schools and classrooms with an upgraded technology infrastructure to provide one-on-onecomputer use, large screen projectors, remote student response systems and wireless tablets; Increase studentand teacher access to digital content including web-based curriculum and online educational resources;Increase technology supported collaboration and communication among teachers, parents, students andcommunity members to improve instruction and learning; and Implement technology infrastructure that willsupport the migrate the institution of PBL in K-8 classrooms while making instructional happen throughtechnology resources. Teachers will be trained through collaboration with universities and professionaldevelopment resources such as Center for Excellence and Leadership in Learning (CELL) at the University ofIndianapolis where a cadre of teachers will become trainers for other in-district educators building aprofessional instructional workforce fully equipped for PBL."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Defying the Norm - A Model for Student Success
Project Description: "Rockdale County Public Schools (RCPS) is, and has been, completely committed to the use of data to drive increases in student achievement and enjoys a deeply engrained culture of data inquiry.  We will implement a data warehouse with a user-friendly, customizable dashboard  that will dramatically improve timely and accurate access to data, not to mention the number of people who use the data, and the amount of time they will gain to use what they've learned from the data.  We believe that data warehouse abilities will help RCPS (and other districts) make better, faster, more efficient instructional decisions using custom reports designed specifically to deliver the information that is relevant. A comprehensive data consolidation mechanism will improve relevancy and accuracy of search results and increase access points so users find information quickly and easily. Next, this system will enable more meaningful and useful reporting, providing specific drill-down accuracy and information consolidation for all levels of users. Additionally, it will streamline searching and information retrieval, increasing the number of times information is accessed. These reports will lead to instructional and operational changes that increase student achievement and meet the complex reporting needs at district, state and federal levels. Finally, a data warehouse will facilitate the exchange of data with the project's official partners at the state and national levels.  ??"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Rocketship Education: Innovation, Empowerment and Leadership
Project Description: "Rocketship Education proposes a truly scalable model for high quality college prep charter schools. Rocketship?shybrid school platform, parent empowerment, and intensive leadership development ensure high studentachievement in high-need urban areas. Using a unique blend of talented, well-supported teachers, onlineinstruction, intensive intervention, an extended school day, and enrichment, Rocketship has achievedmeasurable results in urban neighborhoods in San Jose, California, where the surrounding public schools arefailing. The majority of Rocketship?s students are English Learners from low-income families: a demographictoo often condemned to educational failure in our country. However, Rocketship has created the third-highestranked elementary school in California for low-income students. We will demonstrate that our system isscalable in all its facets: finances, teacher recruitment and development, hybrid instruction, and parentempowerment."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Developing the Rodel Exemplary Teacher Initiative: A Unique Collaboration to Increase the Number of Future Educators Equipped to Effectively Teach in High-Need Schools Through Mentorship by Exemplary Teachers

Developing the Rodel Mathematics Initiative: A Unique Non-Profit Foundation Increases Mathematics Achievement of High-Need Students by Weaving Together Standards-Based Teaching and Learning Opportunities for Administrators, Teachers, Families, and Student
Project Description: "Since 2003, the Math Achievement Club by Rodel (MAC-Ro) has helped improve mathematics achievement for thousands of high-risk Arizona elementary students by providing a program that focuses all stakeholders on implementing the Arizona Mathematics Standard with fidelity. This application seeks funding to revise the current MAC-Ro program components to align with the new Common Core State Standards; design program components for additional grade levels; expand the delivery of the program into more public and charter schools with high-need and limited English proficient (LEP) students, including those in rural and tribal communities; increase the rigor of the research base to show the effect of MAC-Ro on student achievement; and prepare for potential growth into communities outside of Arizona. The goal is to increase mathematics achievement at schools implementing MAC-Ro, including increased mathematics achievement for LEP students and at schools in rural and tribal communities. This goal will be accomplished through four components/objectives: (A) provide standards-based, supplemental student materials to increase practice and attainment of the state-adopted mathematics standards; (B) provide professional development opportunities, tools, and support for teachers to increase their knowledge and implementation of the state-adopted mathematics standards; (C) provide companion workshops and support materials for administrators to increase their knowledge and implementation of the state-adopted mathematics standards; and (D) provide companion workshops and materials for families to increase awareness of grade-level standards and assistance to their children. In addition to measuring each of these objectives using independent measures, a regression discontinuity research model will use standards-based assessment data and other measures to explore the quantitative relationship between the various program components, treatment fidelity, and student achievement."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Technology Renaissance Enhancing Education (TREE)
Project Description: "The Technological Renaissance for Enhancing Education (TREE) is a 5-year project designed to integrateinteractive whiteboards and touch screen tablets into instruction. The ultimate priority is to turn around lowperformingschools with particular emphasis on LEP students. This will be attained through theimplementation of four goals: to improve students? reading and math achievement, to increase graduate anddecrease dropout rates, to support college readiness and access, and to empower students with 21st centuryskills. Cyber Academies will also be established to enable students to take courses at their own pace, or earnhigh school credits, which will result in a higher number of high school graduates, and those entering college.School information will be provided in English and Spanish, which makes it accessible to all parents. Afterthe grant life, it is expected that all schools will meet or exceed Annual Yearly Progress (AYP) goals for math,reading, and graduation rates."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Public School Waldorf Teacher Development Project
Project Description: "The Public School Waldorf Teacher Development Project will address the expanding need for Waldorf-trainedclassroom teachers in public schools. Fully trained Waldorf teachers are not now available to meet thatdemand. Test results have shown that fully trained Waldorf teachers in public schools are highly effective andthat their students reach high levels of academic achievement on standards-based measures of success. Thisproject will develop a replicable program for the training and development of public school Waldorf teachersand the systems of ongoing support they need to be successful with all students.The project proposes to establish a comprehensive Waldorf teacher training program for public school teachers.The program will include extensive training, for new teachers and those unfamiliar with Waldorf education,leading to Waldorf certification. In addition, the program will provide ongoing assistance to already Waldorftrainedclassroom teachers though school-wide and classroom-based systems of support, includinginstructional coaching, establishing and maintaining professional learning communities, and managing anonline clearinghouse of curriculum, instructional materials, and formative assessments. It is expected that thesefully trained Waldorf teachers will prove to be highly effective and that their students will be on track forcollege and career readiness and prepared to lead successful lives.Research studies and the evaluation process built into this project will document and measure the success of thisprogram with all students, including students at high risk. The measures of success will include thestandardized measures of student achievement used for accountability purposes, but will be expanded toinclude the measurement of student growth in the dimensions commonly described as 21st century skills."

Project Title: First Teachers@home
Project Description: "RUSH Initiative, a 501 ( c )(3) non-profit organization, is applying for a i3 Innovation Grant for First Teachers@home, its highly effective parent-centered education program for high-need families with prescihool children.  Tihis innovative program will partner with three Alabama LEAs to implement a new model that increases kindergarten readiness of high-risk children, which will in turn transform tihe oiutcomes at persistently low-performing schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Rutgers Early College Humanities Innovation Project (REaCH/i3)
Project Description: "REaCH is a highly innovative and possibly unique early college/dual enrollment program created by Rutgers University in 2008 to address the problem of access to and success at college by high-need students from low-income communities. REaCH provides its participants with an early college/dual enrollment experience, that is, the opportunity while they are still in high school to earn college credits by taking a college-level course in a variety of humanities disciplines presented as a sequence of modules. Participants study with college professors (who come to their schools to teach the course), read college texts, complete college assignments, and participate in thought-provoking discussions. Participants can earn both college credit from Rutgers and high school credit as well. 	Rutgers proposes the creation, operation and evaluation of thirty REaCH Courses to be offered in partnership with five eligible LEAs in New Jersey during the three year period September 2010-August 2013. Each of the five LEAs will offer two REaCH courses per year during this period. Some of these courses will be during-school-hours, some will be after school (depending on the needs of the participating high schools) and some will be intensive summer courses. The project also includes: development and implementation of evaluation instruments; publicizing the project in learned forums and journals as well as internally and externally through Rutgers newsletters and its various other (e.g. magazine) publications; preparation of dissemination materials, including a manual, to guide other interested educational institutions; and a one day culminating conference at which project participants make presentations to invited guests from school systems and other college/universities."

Applicant: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey - Camden Campus
Project Title: Rutgers/LEAP Academy Model: Promise Partnership
Project Description: "The work described in this application targets two key goals: demonstrate the LEAP model in Camden City in 3 new schools; and evaluate, document and codify the LEAP model for dissemination/replication purposes. Program objectives are: Increase the high school graduation rates of participating Camden City students; Increase the college enrollment rates of participating Camden City students; Increase college completion rates of participating Camden City students; Establish and implement a process for collecting data on academic performance in college, as well as other indicators such as employment, post graduate plans; and, Disseminate data and replicate model through various means, including, publication of studies, hosting meetings and symposia, training, specialized degree programs, and programs for practitioners, scholars and other stakeholders. The expectation is that by the end of the grant period 2,134 students will be reached."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Sacramento City Promoting Effective Teachers Project
SpringBoard
Project Description: "Sacramento City Unified School District (SCUSD) will work together with the College Board to implement the SpringBoard?  to College, 7-12 Program (a Development project). This project will Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments and Support College Access and Success. College Bound will: (1) increase the successful participation of low-income students in college preparatory courses and tests, (2) expand opportunities for low-income students to take college-level classes and earn college credit while still in high school, and (3) raise the rigor of the academic curriculum for all students attending high-poverty, underperforming middle and high schools. The District will build this inclusive college preparatory program at 5 middle and 2 high schools (6,931 students over 5 years) and will facilitate high levels of cooperation among teachers, administrators, students, and their parents. College Bound is an innovative program that will provide all students with an engaging, rigorous educational program and ensure the following objectives and outcomes:?	     Provide SpringBoard ELA curriculum to middle and high school students and training for teachers?	     Provide an incentive program for teachers ?       Increase AYP scores ?	     Increase number/diversity of students enrolled in AP courses/exams and taking the SAT?	     Increase pass rates in AP courses and SAT exams?	     Increase number of AP courses available to students?	     Increase number of high performing teachers at grades 7-10"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Engage, Reflect, Adapt and Align: A Regional Roadmap for 21st Century Success
Project Description: "The ERAA project's goals are 1) increase graduation rates, 2) increase student academic success, 3) increase student connectedness and sense of belonging to school and community and improve relationships between home, school, and community, 4) increase college and career readiness and 5) increase regional capacity and commitment to increasing graduation rates throughout Sacramento County.  Partners in this project include Sacramento County Office of Education, six Sacramento County school districts, the Parent Teacher Home Visit Project, Sacramento Area Congregations Together and the Youth Development Network.Because engagement of families and students is such a strong indicator of student success, ERAA intends to meet these goals through the integrated use of two highly successful engagement strategies:  parent teacher home visits and service learning.ERAA will work with six Sacramento County districts serving 93,008 students over its five-year pilot period.  The Parent- Teacher Home project will build teacher-parent relationships through asset-based conversations.  Teachers will gain insights about students to support differentiated curriculum and parents will gain access to knowledge of school expectations, community opportunity and student progress. Service Learning, a community project-based teaching strategy, works in conjunction with the home visits to develop teacher understanding of student and community needs.  Teachers will become proficient at embedding curriculum in projects that meet student needs/interests and serve to address a community issue.  This form of integrated teaching and home-teacher-student community engagement not only makes learning relevant, but empowers young adults with a sense of hope and equips them with the 21st Century skills to address academic, life and social challenges as well as to enter well-prepared into the arena of college and work."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Capital Region Career Academy Initiative
Project Description: "The Sacramento County Office of Education in partnership with LEED - Linking Education and Economic Development, will create and sustain a region-wide educational and civic initiative to serve up to 35 school districts and county offices of education in the six-county Sacramento region of Northern California, which includes: El Dorado, Placer, Sacramento, Sutter, Yolo and Yuba. Called the Capital Region Career Academy Initiative (CRCAI), this effort will unite education, business and civic interests to acquire and direct additional dollars and resources to support local educational efforts to transform area high schools through the development and expansion of 'academy/multiple pathway' programs. For the purposes of this initiative, Career Academies are defined as 3 to 4 year comprehensive high school programs of academic and technical study organized around a career/industry theme. Anticipated outcomes for this proposal are increased graduation rates, further development of integrated curriculum that better prepares students for success in college and careers, virtual academy programs, and a new Regional P-16 council to govern and insure that these programs are viable and sustainable.  The CRCAI education partners will be offered a variety of professional growth services, new technology platforms, industry/employer partnerships and convening expertise to achieve these outcomes. A strategic, systemic and regional approach to provide local district with additional funding, expertise, and efficiencies will create a distinct competitive edge for the region, local districts, employers and students.  The track record of cross-county collaboration and the active engagement of area employers, post-secondary partners and civic leaders make the six-county Sacramento region better positioned than any other region in California to implement a region-wide initiative as proposed in the following Investing in Innovation submission."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: SAY IT TO CHANGE IT
Project Description: "Arizona, as well as many other states have made important strides in class - size reduction, higher academic standards, greater accountability and improved teacher preparation.  The important missing link in these initiatives to improving student learning is the need for more school counselors and other students support services, such as school psychologists, and school social workers.  School counselors and psychologists; provide counseling programs in three domains: academic, career and personal social.  Often, providing counseling in the school context can be challenging, especially given time constraints and the limited number of sessions.  Counseling services and programs help students resolve emotional, social or behavioral problems and help them develop a clearer focus and sense of direction.  Effective counseling programs are important to the school climate and a crucial element in improving student achievement.      We hypothesize when implemented school wide, Program Say It to Change It, utilizing a comprehensive counseling approach will decrease discipline, while increasing problem solving skills, academics, and student retention.      Program Say It to Change It, a development grant, seeks to address student's needs while providing a school wide approach to the most pressing issues students and families face today. By providing an effective and comprehensive counseling model, professionals will employ a wide variety of age appropriate techniques and services to students, which will ensure equitable distribution of counseling programs to all students and their families.     Through our program Say It to Change It, students who are most at risk for academic failure will be supported in the missing link of school services, their social, academic, and emotional well being, which will translate into academic success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Systemic Improvement through Teacher and Administrator Feedback on Effectiveness: 

A Reflective Cycle
Project Description: "Michigan's Educational Effectiveness Collaborative will implement a comprehensive, reflective system of feedback, in 50 rural, urban, and suburban schools, pre-K through grade 12, that shifts learning, teaching, and leading relationships from a compliance framework to a problem-solving one. Built upon a sound and shared theory of effectiveness wherein individual problems of practice become public problem-solving opportunities, this system will shape educators' capacity to continuously improve through clear, objective, and timely feedback. The system will connect professional learning with student achievement and differentiate support and response to individual teachers and instructional leaders based upon need."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Leadership Lab: A New Perspective on the Internship in Educational Administration
Project Description: "The student teaching component of teacher credential programs allows prospective teachers time to ?experience? real life situations in the context of his or her learning in the preparation classes. However, there do not appear to be comparable preparation programs that do the same for prospective principals.The Leadership Lab Intern Experience will provide Saint Mary's College Tier I administrative credential students an opportunity to work at a school site as an administrative intern, under the guidance of a mentor principal and field experience supervisor, before they become principals of their own schools. Interns will be able to apply their learning in the classroom to the daily challenges at the school site. The Investing in Innovation Federal grant will provide the funding for substitute teachers for the classrooms of the administrative interns as well as stipends for partner mentor principals."

Applicant: Saint Paul College - A  Community & Technical College
Project Title: Power of YOU II
Project Description: "In 2005, the Power of YOU was launched in collaboration with the Saint Paul Public and Minneapolis School Districts. Saint Paul College and its partner colleges built a program that: Guaranteed up to three years of tuition free, lower division college, for urban high school graduates and supported students success in college with special services.     Based on the research to date and the Wilder Foundation's external evaluation of the pilot program, the Power of YOU is strongly correlated with raising awareness and expectations among underrepresented students.  POY seems also to have contributed to increased college enrollment and once enrolled, increased academic success of underrepresented students.      In order to sustain and continue increasing enrollments and graduation rates at the levels achieved by this project, additional resources are needed to continue the promising program as the Power of YOU II. These funds will be used to scientifically test and validate the research hypotheses.      In this second phase of POY, Saint Paul College proposes to better its  knowledge and understanding of what specific support strategies are effective in helping underrepresented students succeed.  Power of YOU II will control for specific variables by holding constant the quantity and quality of awareness methodologies and support strategies.  Beginning this second phase of POY with a scientifically designed and rigorous, Saint Paul College will be able to demonstrate statistically significant results with high internal validity upon which future research and student access and success interventions can be based"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Twin Cities Pre-K Partnership
Project Description: "The Twin Cities Pre-K Partnership project will implement the next phase of a Saint Paul Public Schools (SPPS) literacy-based preschool educational framework proven through independent research to improve the school readiness of high-need children at risk of academic failure, by bringing the model into additional SPPS classrooms and expanding the model into Minneapolis schools.  An independent, quasi-experimental regression discontinuity design study will validate the effectiveness of the model in other classrooms and in this second, different urban setting. TCPKP's overarching aims are to address the persistent achievement gap for high-need students, to increase children school readiness, and to transform early childhood education models.  The project's four key goals are: 1). Every child who participates in the program will be ready for Kindergarten; 2). The families of participating students will be effectively supported through multiple strategies; 3). Teachers who participate in the project will increase their instructional effectiveness; and 4). Participating schools will transform their academic structures into fully-aligned pre-K through 12th grade systems that allows for seamless, effective transitions from preschool to elementary and beyond.  The project will serve 8,760 over 3 years (2,920 each year). Special project features:  Required principal leadership at the pre-K level, weekly content coaching, ongoing assessment coaching, and fidelity to TCPKP's academically-focused Early Childhood Workshop framework.  Applicant Organization: Saint Paul Public Schools; Official Partners: Minneapolis Public Schools; Other Partners: Minnesota Reading Corps (trained literacy classroom assistants); Adria F. Klein (professional development consultant); Wilder Research (evaluation consultant)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: INNOVATIONS FOR LOW PERFORMING RURAL SCHOOLS
Project Description: " This project will embrace these strategies for improving low performing schools:  1) 'Giving teachers professional development to ensure delivery of a specific curriculum' 2) committing them 'to data driven decision-making and instruction' and 3) providing incentives for skilled administrators and teachers to transfer to or stay at 'low-performing schools' (Snipes, Doolittle and Herlihy 2002, 5 and 7). These strategies accomplished through a professional development program with Harvard Graduate School of Education.  The third strategy accomplished through increased compensation for individuals who work in the tutoring and summer school.This project seeks to improve instruction in basic skills by increased instruction time in basic skills (reading/English and math/science) during after-school tutoring and summer school for rising third through twelfth graders.  These strategies accomplished through an after-school tutoring program for one and one half hours per day, four days a week, from September through May, increasing instructional time by twenty-seven hours a month and through a month long, five hour a day, summer school in July of each year increasing instructional time by twenty-five hours.  This project provides its own transportation for the students involved due to the limited resources of the rural school district.This project will strive to prepare students at our low-performing, rural schools for their increased instructional time by investing in their physical health.  This project accomplishes this by: 1) Providing proper nutrition for students that are involved in the tutoring program and summer school and 2) by providing physical education teachers for each of the low performing schools covered by the grant to meet the standards set by U.S. Department of Agriculture's Healthier US Schools Challenge Program and First Lady's, Let's Move Campaign.This project seeks to establish a school-based mentoring program in each school."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: St. Vrain Valley School District i3 Project
Project Description: "Saint Vrain Valley SD is proposing a development project which is an exceptional approach to priority four through a multi-faceted comprehensive strategy to address the unmet needs for the targeted high-need students; specifically Hispanic and ELL students at Skyline High School and it?s feeder schools.  The project will benefit 3,800 students.  Our proposed strategy is to provide students with a sequence of focused interventions to reduce the achievement gap and to make significant improvements.  We have designed a system that brings focused supports and an augmented school year for elementary students to build a literacy foundation.
