The system then shifts focus on the Mathematics foundation in Middle School Students, with math labs and an augmented school year to build stronger mathematics skills. At the high school level we provide students with a science focus through a Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics certification track which provides students with an alternative in high school.  We have designed supports in the program that brings Data-Driven Decision Making and Information Technology supports to bear through-out the K-12 system of the targeted schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Developing Highly Effective Principals Capable of Sustaining Highly Effective Leadership Pracrtice and Performance
Project Description: "The initiative is designed to create an innovative, robust strategic network of highly effective principals from 75schools, 25 schools from 3 states: New Jersey, New York, and Virginia. The schools range from small to large,rural to urban, with a total of approximately 37,500 students. All include high-needs students. This selfsustainingactive network of principals will have all developed the capacity for innovation in day-to-daypractice focused on learning for sustained student growth and achievement. The work is structured aroundthree focal points: leadership performance, evidence-based practice, and strategic networking.The work involves: job-embedded (70%) activities with network colleagues, coaches, and mentors, ?learningrounds? within and across regions and ?case-in-point inquiries? into practice-based evidence (including data)and the design of learning; off-site (10%) activities, including active participation in three network colloquiaeach year; and Web-based (20%) learning and networking, supported by specialist software, piloted withprincipals working in similar circumstances in the UK, and including developing personal, school, andnetwork growth plans, along with implementing practices for sustained innovative leadership, and participatingin Web-based coaching and support, including audio and videoconferencing, webinars, and the use ofcustomized podcasts, with other principals, coaches, and mentors.Objectives and outcomes for the project include: (1) Objective: Principals will together develop and implementinnovative, learning-centered leadership standards, assessments, and practices; (2) Objective: Principals willdevelop evidence-based practice that includes practice-based evidence throughout the school; and (3)Objective: Principals will develop and learn to sustain strategic networks with other schools statewide andnationally."

Project Title: Oregon Center for Effective Teachers and Leaders
Project Description: "The Oregon Center for Effective Teachers and Leaders (OCETL) will develop a formal structure and coherent system of research-based support for beginning teachers and administrators working in this state's diverse rural, suburban, and urban PK-12 public schools. For the past two years, the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) has partnered with the New Teacher Center (NTC) to provide in-depth training for mentors working in pilot projects involving 87 school districts. Data from these pilot projects indicate the potential value of mentoring; the projects also confirm research suggesting that more work is needed to develop a comprehensive mentor model as part of a well-aligned continuum of professional development and support. OCETL will be developed through collaborative agreements among school districts organized as three regional consortia, in partnership with ODE, Education Service Districts, higher education, education unions, and other stakeholders. The goals are to improve new teacher/principal efficacy; enhance recruitment/retention of educators from traditionally underrepresented multicultural backgrounds; raise student achievement; and develop a sustainable infrastructure to support replication and scale-up. Key elements are use of the NTC induction continuum and formative assessment system; carefully selected full-release mentors to provide at least 90 hours of direct support annually for new teachers/principals on a 1:15 ratio; and ongoing mentor training totaling 224 hours over two years, including a focus on equity, English language learners, and differentiated instruction. Other components will focus on using Web 2.0 technologies into the model and alignment with pre-service programs. OCETL will involve an estimated 360 new teachers/principals (two-thirds at the elementary level), benefiting approximately 25,500 students annually; the program will be expanded to other rural Oregon districts in years 4-5."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Inquiry-based Science Laboratory Activities Project
Project Description: "Salve Regina University, in partnership with the Central Falls, Woonsocket, and Newport school districts, requests a Development Grant to address Absolute Priority 3--Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments. Through the Inquiry-based Science Laboratory Activities (ISLA) Project, in-service science teachers will develop laboratory curricula with incremental inquiry content aligned with the Rhode Island (RI) K-12 Grade Span (GSE) and Grade Level Expectations (GLE) in the Sciences. The ISLA Project will commence with the implementation of the Guided Inquiry Based Interdisciplinary Science (GIBIS) Center in a dedicated space at Salve Regina University. During the first three years of the Project, teachers working in teams will develop a curriculum consisting of 12 activities in Chemistry, Physics, or Biology/Environmental Science at three different inquiry levels, with four labs developed and classroom-tested each year. A two-step assessment with an associated rubric will be developed by each team. Using the GIBIS Center, the Salve Regina Department of Education will implement workshops for pre-service science teachers to train them to develop and use inquiry based materials and the necessary technology. During years four and five the GIBIS Center will be made available for teacher quality improvement programs for teachers from other school districts within RI.The ISLA project has received the enthusiastic support of the three partner school districts. As a result, we expect 18 teachers to participate in the project. This will provide the project with teams of experienced and dedicated teachers for the curricula development effort. Students at all high school grade levels in all three districts will be affected by this project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Rural Schools and Bearkat Partnership for Excellence in Teaching and Learning
Project Description: "Design, implement, and assess a governing and management structure among the partnership members forconsistent and effective collaboration among elementary and secondary inservice teachers and principals,university administrators and faculty, and baccalaureate preservice and resident teachers. They will share theresponsibility in designing, implementing and assessing a Professional Development Schools evidence-basedprogram in the partnership schools and undergraduate teacher education program at SHSU. The RS-BPProfessional Development School evidence-based program will locally identify, recruit, develop, place,reward, retain, and increase the percentages of highly effective teachers in the Elementary 4th-5th grades andSecondary 10th -12th grades in identified core academic content areas of teacher shortages needed in the highneedrural partnership schools.Assess the effectiveness of the Professional Development School evidencedbasedprogram to increase the percentages of highly effective teachers that will result in improving theachievement for mathematics and reading of 4th -5th grade students and mathematics or other identified coreacademic content areas of 10th-12th grade students in the high-need rural partnership schools."

Project Title: Comprehensive Analytical Data Directed Approach (CADDA)
Project Description: "The CADDA initiative Comprehensive Analytical Data Directed Approach (CADDA) is an exceptional format for data collection and analysis.  The data review is both quantitative and qualitative ; however, what makes this practice unique and innovative is  that it not  only considers test data but also data related to (1) personal pain, (2) family failure (3) family socioeconomic situation, family instability, and  family tragedy. Academic and social interventions are utilized for individual students.  The consultant provides participants a focused reflection of current instructional practices along with a customized plan that will include an identification of individual strengths and weaknesses in both instructional practice and the ability to implement benchmark and formative assessment as diagnostic tools. Additionally, a check and balance system that has been developed to ensure that every identified student is on target to be academically proficient.  It is projected that 1914 will be served in the first year and additional 1500 in the subsequent years of the program. The goal is to validate a practice which increases academic achievement among high need students. Other partners include the North Carolina Department of Instruction Middle School Section, Clinton City Schools, East Carolina University and Rural School and Community Trust."

CREATE will expand the program to the general education, special education, and Limited English Proficient students to reach a total of 54,762 and in five rural school districts that will reach 500 students for a a total of 55,262 students.  To achieve the Absolute Prority #3, we propose to impliment the El Paso ISD Curriculum (EPISDC) along with the Renzulli Learning Sysyem (RLS) in elementary to middle school and develop a curriculum for the G/T students that incorporate?.TRUN"

Project Title: The i3 Spark Project
Project Description: "In deep South Texas there is a small city by the name of San Benito, TX. This city is located in Cameron County (one of the poorest counties in America), shares a border with Mexico and has a Median household income of $26,290 (U.S. Census). The San Benito CISD currently serves a 2009-10 student population of 10,983 students, of which 98.6% are Hispanic and 81.1% are Economically Disadvantaged, as defined by the Texas Education Agency (TEA). The SBCISD has considered the strength of national, regional and local moderate evidence, including the internal and external validity of the effects reported in prior research that there is a need and that the program will improve student achievement and student growth, close achievement gaps, and decrease dropout rates. Although Ninth grade has grown to be known as 'The Dropout Year' for many American schools, this dreadful title is supported by research indicating that Ninth grade serves as a bottleneck for freshmen students lacking the sufficient academic skills to merge into high school level work (Balfanz and Legters 2006). This suggests there is a rift in the vertical alignment of elementary to secondary transitioning and that students are entering high school unprepared from years prior to 9th grade, not in 9th grade. The program proposed by SBCISD impacts students from 5th grade through their 9th grade years. The i3 Spark Project is to provide San Benito CISD elementary schools with funding necessary to immerse their upcoming 5th Grade student population with on-demand technology access at school and at home. San Benito 5th graders will have access to productivity, communication, and presentation software for use as learning tools paired with online instructional resources that support the state curriculum in English, Language Arts, Mathematics, Science, and Social Studies."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Latino/African American Male Involvement Project (LAAMIP)
Project Description: "The San Bernardino City Unified School District  (SBCUSD) (Lead Applicant), in collaboration with community based organizations Project Life Impact, the BLU Educational Foundation, the Inland Empire Concerned African American Churches (Official Partners), and Congregations Organized for Prophetic Engagement (COPE) (Other Partner) propose the Latino/African American Male Involvement Project (LAAMIP), as an innovation that turns around persistently low-performing schools and supports college access and success.  The project is a targeted approach, over five years, to increase college enrollment among Latino and African American male students by addressing both academic and non-academic barriers in culturally appropriate ways.  Programs offering families food, clothing, school supplies, job training, and housing vouchers will be provided.       Through LAAMIP, SBCUSD's current Targeted Instructional Improvement Policy will focus on 1,000 Latino and African American male middle and high school students in Title I Program Improvement Schools.  The project will provide equity and diversity training to increase cultural responsiveness of SBCUSD counselors, teachers, and administrators.     Official Partners will provide academic (enrichment and academic prep, summer support academies, on-line tutorials, and college readiness) programs.  Non-academic support will include afterschool interventions, case management for students and families, and developmental experiences outside of school.  COPE will support LAAMIP through a parent engagement initiative to strengthen the number of parents engaged in advocacy and training to increase college preparedness, retention, and college graduation rates of Latino and African American males."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: San Bernardino County Superintendent of Schools
Project Title: Promoting A STEM Culture for Advanced/Applied Learning (PASCAL)
Project Description: "The Promoting a STEM Culture for Advanced Learning (PASCAL Project) will serve directly approximately 240students, with a potential to impact up to 7,000 students, indirectly, in San Bernardino County. The Investingin Innovation Funding Development Grant for the PASCAL project will focus on Absolute Priority Three:Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments; andCompetitive Preference Six: Innovations that Support College Access and Success. The project objectives arethree-fold: (1) enhance Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) teaching and learningcapacity; (2) provide a STEM foundation for all students; and (3) build a culture for STEM success. Ourexpected outcomes are to: (1) create six P-16 STEM model school districts that have vertically articulatedSTEM programs of study, grades 6-16; (2) attract and retain students in STEM disciplines through aprogression of educational opportunities for students, teachers, parents, and counselors; and (3) through STEMformal/informal education providers, promote STEM literacy, awareness, and engagement. Activities include:1) Partnering with institutions of higher education in providing curriculum development and teacherprofessional development in mathematics and science; 2) addition of a STEM middle school course; 3)summer ?bridge? program; 4) contextual learning opportunities with business partners (ABLE Program); and5) after-school STEM/robotics camps. Partners with the Alliance in this project include: University ofCalifornia, Riverside; California State University San Bernardino; Kelly Space and Technology; and fourfeeder community colleges."

Project Title: i3 K-16 Collaborative
Project Description: "The goal of the project will be to improve learning outcomes and the academic performance of Basic Skills and limited English Proficient high school students by providing college programs and resources that address the non-academic as well as academic barriers to success. Further, the program will provide services to help prepare Basic Skills and limited English Proficient high school students to enter and graduate from college. The following innovative strategies will be used to achieve the goals: High School outreach services and activities; transitional program and services, and college retention programs. These goals will be addressed through the following activities: (1) Transitional Services and Resource Center on the City College Campus to manage existing and foster new partnerships between San Diego City College and San Diego Unified Partners.  The Center will provide a powerful transitional resource for students moving from High School into college as well as students who are dual-enrolled, or who are a part of any High School/College program (2) College Readiness and Outreach program to provide information and assistance with college application and assessment as well as other resources to help high school students prepare for college( e.g. mentoring and tutoring, after School programs on the City College Campus, etc) (3) Transitional and College Retention Programs to assist students in their transition from high school to college such as: Summer Readiness Program, and the First-Year Experience program which provide services and support to ensure the retention and overall success of first-year college students. Sample of key measures: 30% of all juniors and seniors at the seven feeder high schools will be provided assistance with completing college application and assessment including financial aid and scholarship applications.  30% of first year students will be better prepared for their first semester because of services provided by the project. Applicant: San Diego County Superintendent of Schools
Project Title: College and Career Readiness Initiative
Project Description: "The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) in partnership with Equity in Learning (EiL), Education Trust West (ETW), the College and Career Readiness Committee of the Economic Development Commission (EDC) Foundation, and 8 San Diego school districts will develop a model for district data collection, analysis, planning and implementation to increase student college and career readiness. The CCRI model is an ongoing data-driven cycle to continuously assess and advance rigorous college and career preparatory coursework for all of the participating districts? 49,176 high school students. The process begins with a collection and analysis of a variety of indicators to provide a foundational understanding of a district?s current practices, policies, and beliefs with respect to college and career readiness. Based on the data analysis, each district, with the assistance of SDCOE, will create a detailed action plan to better support to college and career readiness for all students. SDCOE will develop, leverage and/or broker resources for districts to support the implementation of their action plans."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: SAN DIEGO COUNTY SUPT. OF SCHOOLS
Project Title: San Diego K-12 Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) Model Schools Collaboratory
Project Description: "In a strategic partnership to foster innovation in K-12 STEM teaching and learning, the San Diego County Office of Education, fourteen independent school districts, the San Diego Science Alliance, and a representative cross-section of industry sectors known for innovation have established a collaboratory, an innovation center without walls that relies upon accessing people and sharing information to support collaboration. The STEM Collaboratory will to create an interdisciplinary community of practice among teacher leaders of science, technology, mathematics, English language development, along with academic support providers, principals and STEM industry professionals to meet the goal of increasing capacity for innovative 21st century teachers and learners.The program design will be constructed around three key design principles: real-world authentic challenges, realworld STEM partners, with a real and virtual collaborative structure. The STEM Collaboratory will align content standards, assessments, curriculum, instructional practices and professional development around the Grand Challenges for Engineering developed by National Academy of Engineering (NAE, 2010). The infusion of STEM professionals from the local community (secured as Private Sector matching) into learning opportunities for teachers and students will illuminate and promote college and career readiness in STEM disciplines for all students, especially under-represented student populations."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Business Intelligence for Achievement Project
Project Description: "The Business Intelligence for Achievement Project (BIAP) is designed to bring together all pertinent data relative to student achievement, business, and operations of SDUSD and make it accessible in one searchable data warehouse, with attention to using data to improve student achievement. San Diego Unified School District (SDUSD) is a large urban district serving 132,000 students from preschool through grade 12. The student population is extremely diverse, with more than 15 ethnic groups and over 60 languages and dialects. The amount of data collected each year on all these students is staggering. The BIAP is designed to gather all data into one data warehouse and create means for users to search that data in order to understand the factors leading to individual student achievement, as a way of evaluating the effectiveness of educational programs and practices. 118,000 students will be served by the BIAP by the end of the project, all students except those in charter schools.SDUSD currently has a Business Intelligence Initiative underway to gather substantial data from human resources, operations, finances, and student services. The BIAP will expand the breadth, depth and accessibility of the student information and student achievement data in the data warehouse. Project development activities include: 1) integrate student information databases such as DataDirector?, ERO?, Naviance?, and EXCEED?; 2) validate all data; 3) expand the infrastructure of the data warehouse; and 4) design and deliver new dashboards (reporting structures). Implementation activities include: 1) identify pilot schools; 2) develop training; 3) train users at pilot schools; and 4) revise training; 5) train users at all sites over project years 3-5. The goal of the BIAP is to use data on student achievement and other operational data to evaluate educational programs and their effectiveness as way of making positive change in education. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: San Francisco Coalition for Essential Small School (SF-CESS)
Project Title:
California Mentor School Project:
An Equity-Centered Professional Learning Network for Public Charters and District Schools
Project Description: "The California Mentor School Project is a four-year project that will deliberately build relationships and disseminate knowledge among and between persistently low-achieving district schools and highly effective public charter school educators who are using research based practices.  SF-CESS and CESN will create and facilitate a California state-wide professional learning network that ultimately will include 15 effective public charter and charter-like schools and 15 district schools that have consistently underperformed. The project will begin by working with 10-12 schools in the Bay Area and expand statewide.  Schools receive school-to-school mentoring, external coaching, and professional development, including workshops, school visits, and Equity-based Critical Friends Group training.  Schools will build their capacity to implement the following broad strategies that have compelling research-based evidence that they increase, school-wide, the achievement of high need students:o	Function as sustainable equity-centered, professional learning communities dedicated to lifelong learning.o	Prioritize personalization so that every child is known well, ando	Base their practices in data-driven inquiry, explicitly focused on equity and achievementThe California Mentor School Project expects to see change in school organizational practices, classroom practices, and, ultimately, student outcomes.  Through our activities, we expect schools to create Equity Centered Professional Learning Communities and increase each school's ability to employ and apply research-based strategies in individual contexts and improve alignment of strategic curriculum with instructional practices across team/grades and within the school/district strategic plan. These changes both within classroom practice as well as through integrating student supports into the school model to address non-academic barriers to student achievement, support the kinds of practices that lead to accelerated achieveme"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The New Data Frontier: Applying Predictive Analytics to Individualize Student Success
Project Description: "Predictive analytics is a critical practice used in industry, medicine and law enforcement to analyze data, combining information on past circumstances, present events, and projected future actions. The use of predictive analytics in education that is described in the following project narrative uniquely positions San Jose Unified School District to address the learning needs of students with disabilities and English Learners. Data identifying these subgroups are routinely available in most district systems. However, the complexity and accuracy of data collection, synthesis, and analysis prove challenging. Comprehensive analyses are often limited by lack of data quality and availability, and additional sources of information about the quality of programs serving these students are rarely collected systematically. Using the District's data warehouse to support the predictive analytics proposed in this project will increase SJUSD's understanding of the complex needs of these diverse learners. Predictive analytics will help us discover unknown relationships, confirm known or suspected relationships and leverage those relationships for better decision making and student support. Such analytics, for example, could help discern which environments and curricula better optimize language acquisition and content mastery for ELs or how to match interventions to the individualized needs of special education students at various levels of intensity. Beyond quantifying EL and disabled student performance, we will be able to identify potentially causal relationships between students' characteristics, their experiences in the academic and social environments of schools and their successful completion of rigorous courses of study. This approach would describe students and their schools in sufficient detail to model solutions at multiple levels, set the stage for educators to develop targeted solutions for individual students and develop coherent, system-wide improvement efforts. SJUS"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Date with Data
Project Description: "It is the goal of San Leandro Unified School District to significantly decrease the achievement gap by facilitating collaboration between families, students, and teachers. Through ongoing data analysis, families of high school students will use data to inform decision-making and partnership with the school. We will target at-risk students and prepare their parents to fully partner with the school for academic success. Parents will work together with their child to create and implement a plan that will not only guarantee high school graduation, but also prepare their child for entry in a 4-year college. Program components and activities include, Parent Liaisons to support each family, ongoing data analysis workshops over the course of five years, the development of a Parent Center, incentives and recognition for achievement, ongoing case management, student tutoring and teacher training. In five years, 1,350 students will be supported in their efforts to attend a 4-college or university. Our expected outcome, starting in 2010, is 100% of 2010 ? 2011 9th graders will graduate in 2014 and we will increase the enrollment in courses required for UC/CSU by 20%."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Creating Tomorrow's Students Today
Project Description: "Creating Tomorrow's Students Today entails the creation of a pilot school that will provide an environment for the integration of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM); project based learning (PBL); biliteracy; and one-to-one technology access. It will prepare underserved students for college and beyond by weaving successful strategies into a powerful model.  These components have been used successfully as independent initiatives with very promising results. Through collaborative environments, ready access to 21st century resources and tools, and an engaging curriculum, students will learn from carefully selected teachers who have demonstrated their commitment to form this innovative learning community.The goals of the project are to 1.) create a pilot school to be a model of educational innovation and to serve as a research and development site for a blended approach to education, 2.) increase students' interest, attitudes toward, and achievement in STEM fields, and 3.) accelerate students' acquisition of 21st Century skills and preparation for college, careers, and the global society.The CTST project will initially serve a single pilot school in the San Marcos Unified School District (SMUSD), a district of more than 18,000 students, predominantly Hispanic, with a high percentage of English learners. The school will start with 630 and expand to 930 by Year 5. The ultimate goal is to disseminate the program, expanding within the district, to other school districts in San Diego County, and beyond with support from university and private sector partners."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Sandpoint Charter School Bonner County Communiversity
Project Title: Sandpoint Charter School Bonner County Communiversity
Project Description: "Bonner County Communiversity is a collaborative consortium of educational entities and government agencies focused on improving local opportunities for secondary education in our rural county and North Idaho.  This project brings together the existing college/community partnerships in the Communiversity and links the concept with Sandpoint Charter schools innovative project-based high school program.   This project will provide opportunities for college access and success for all students in our rural area, whether they are at risk students, underrepresented, or adults who need to retrain and keep up with a rapidly changing economy. We envision using the Communiversity concept as a tool to reshape the educational future of our town and demonstrate the validity of this concept nationally.  Project Activities include construction of a physical space for the Communiversity, local college classes, development of a 21st Century, internet driven library  and supported access to online learning and virtual classes, a credit recovery program for at risk students, college and career counseling and a research component.Project Objectives: Decrease dropout rates, increase college enrollment and completion and demonstrate that we can close the achievement gap that exists in rural America.Specific goals- Decrease dropout rates,  increase number of students choosing to college, increase number of high school students who choose 4 year over two year college, increase achievement levels of college students, increase number of students who graduate from college on time. Expected outcomes:Measurable increase (10% or more) in specific listed goals. (see above)Students will show increased self efficacy as a result of this project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Sangamon County Regional Office of Education
Project Title: Continuum of Data for Education & Services (CODES)
Project Description: "The Sangamon County Regional Office of Education will build upon the countywide preschool data system that was piloted in February 2010.  The proposed project will integrate student academic performance data and community prevention/intervention data to positively impact student achievement.  Activities include developing a robust centralized database to track student involvement in extra-curricular activities and community-based programming from birth to high school graduation; identifying trends that suggest which activities have the greatest impact on student achievement; and directing funding to those programs/activities that demonstrate effectiveness.  As a result of the project, we anticipate that (1) student achievement will increase at the cohort level; (2) the quantity and quality of collaboration between schools and community-based agencies will increase; and (3) access to prevention and early intervention programming will increase in rural districts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Sanger District Turnaround Project
Project Description: "The proposed project intends to develop strategies to replicate Sanger's successful District Turnaround Model in two Central Valley districts, Dinuba and Firebaugh. The project also will further validate Sanger's model internally as well as externally in the two districts. The project embodies Absolute Priority 2: Innovations that Improve the Use of Data; and Competitive Priority 7: Innovations to address the unique learning needs of English Learner students. Sanger has shown that a data-based, student-centered approach to reform can transform an entire school district, but the question remains: Will the same strategies have a similar impact in other districts? It is this question that motivated the proposed project. The project will test the hypothesis that Sanger's successful reform model can be replicated in other Central Valley districts through a combination of guidance, mentoring, external consultants, and sharing of materials."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: SAUSD / El Sol Innovation Initiative
Project Description: "The Santa Ana Unified School District (SAUSD) and El Sol Science & Arts Academy (El Sol) 'Innovation Initiative' is seeking a development grant to promote school success among Limited English Proficient students and to address problems of low achieving schools.   60% of SAUSD students and 69% of El Sol students are English Language Learners (ELL).  In this Initiative, SAUSD, a preschool-12th grade district, and El Sol, a preschool - 8th grade charter school, will team up to develop and test a service model aimed at turning around low-achieving schools in the District. The partnership between SAUSD, a public district, and El Sol, a publically chartered school, is a unique and strong one.  Because of the outstanding academic performance of El Sol's mostly low-income, at-risk Latino students and the significant academic outcomes for the entire school, the Innovation Initiative, if funded by the i3 Grant and using lessons learned from El Sol, will be able to help increase the performance of  Santa Ana's  persistently low-performing schools and children, particularly for ELLs.According to expert observation and analysis, El Sol's academic successes have resulted, in part, from the development and use of several strategies.  These strategies will be applied either comprehensively or selectively (depending on school characteristics) to two nearby SAUSD schools through the i3 project-Lowell Elementary and Willard Intermediate Schools. The collaboration between SAUSD and El Sol will also be supplemented by evaluation services from the Department of Education at the University of California, Irvine.  The evaluation will examine the implementation of the identified reform strategies and examine the extent to which students receiving this comprehensive program show the positive impacts shown at El Sol."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: "Get Focused-Stay Focused" Dual Enrollment Freshman Transition Project
Project Description: "DEFT is an innovative adaptation of the Freshman Transition Initiative designed by George Washington University to improve college preparation of high school students and promote higher success rates of college students. Addresses Absolute Priority #3 and Competitive Priorities #6 and #7 and begins with a 9th grade dual enrollment (college credit) freshman transition course to engage students to complete high school with the competencies required for college. Student progress is monitored by employing a 10-year online educational and career plan. Allows students to earn up to 12 units of Dual Enrollment courses while still in high school. Professional development is provided to high school district teachers and community college faculty delivered by the Career Ladders Project, Cal-PASS and the textbook publisher."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Santa Clara County Construction Careers Association (S4CA)
Project Title: Construction Careers Educational Pipeline
Project Description: "S4CA is applying for an I3 Development grant for $2,311,470 over 5 years that will serve approximately 2,000 students at the K-12 level, and another 8,000 students at the college level through our Construction Careers Educational Pipeline project. The priority project goal is to construct and demonstrate a fully articulated career technical education ladder including K-12, college and adult learning components. Project objectives include the development of each component of the pipeline, for both public school students and adult learners, to demonstrate an effective process for attracting students to quality education and training preparation for the construction industry, and also provide career advancement and sustainability toward increased career longevity within the industry. These components include working directly with educators, students and parents from San Jose, CA area school districts in conducting outreach and engagement services to increase awareness of educational and career opportunities within the construction industry; and coordinates numerous project services, such as an annual career fair, student internship/placement opportunities, professional development for educators, enrollment in summer concurrent credit courses and a pre-apprenticeship program for high school career technical education students; organized around and supportive of specialized construction education pathways offered through our partner K-12 school districts, with articulation to apprenticeship-training and college degree programs, and an industry-approved pathway for existing construction industry workers to prolong and advance their careers."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Santa Clara County Office of Education
Project Title: SJ2020 Initiative
Project Description: "The SJ2020 Initiative is a Development grant application by the Santa Clara County Office of Education(SCCOE) and its official partner, WestEd. The project is a ?whole systems? approach to eliminating theachievement gap in San Jos
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Santa Cruz County Regional School District
Project Title: Santa Cruz County Teach For Success
Project Description: "Through the Santa Cruz County Teach For Success Project 563 teachers and their 26building administrators will be trained in researched-based effective instruction andclassroom supervision strategies using the WestEd T4S Program as the core model, aresults based compensation system based on effective teaching and student outcomes willbe implemented, and more effective teachers will be retained. In addition, T4S willprovide a framework for similar communities. T4S proposes to significantly improve theacademic performance of students by developing rewarding, and retaining high qualityand effective teachers and principals. The goals of T4S are to: 1) Develop highlyeffective teachers that incorporate best instructional practices ; 2) Establish a coachingand support system that will result in continuous renewal and improvement;, 3) Raise theachievement level of Santa Cruz County student; & 4) Demonstrate it is cost effective ona large scale ."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Linking Innovation and Knowledge Work for 21st Century Success
Project Description: "The Santa Monica-Malibu Unified School District will partner with the Santa Monica College and the Boys and Girls Clubs of Santa Monica to implement a project entitled, 'Linking Innovation and Knowledge Work for 21st Century Success.' This project will serve four of the district's high needs schools serving a total of 88 teachers and 4,600 students.  The goals and objectives are to 1) increase student achievement, in particular, in math and science for all students whil closing the achievement gap for students of color, low-income students, English learners, and students with disabilities; 2) establish a college-going culture among underrepresented students and their families beginning in the elementary grades; and 3) increase participation and retention of underrepresented students in rigorous STEM couresework, early college, and 21st century career preparedness through career technical education pathways.  The project will provide professional development activities for teachers in collaborative instructional leadership teams with district and outside expertise, obtain support from the Santa Monica College and enhance afterschool activities at the Boys and Girls Clubs of Santa Monica. The project will also develop two career pathways in environmental studies and computer engineering technology for the high school students. The district will conduct a rigorous evaluation of the project working with independent evaluation partners.  The district expect significant improvement in school leadership and climate, teacher attitudes and behavior, parent/community engagement, student achievement in core academic subjects especially in math and science, motivation and engagement, self-esteem and confidence, and college and career ready for the 21st century."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: Savannah Chatham County Public School System
Project Title: ENHANCED: Exploring New Heights And New Challenges Embracing Diversity
Project Description: "The ENHANCED project will provide all high schools: Freshman Academy, career pathways, transition activities, advisories, intensive academic support, rigorous academic courses, and activities to increase participation in advanced courses and postsecondary education. The ENHANCED goals are: (1) Academic Rigor: Increase educational expectations and requirements for all students while engaging and motivating them to maximize their full academic potential; aligned with Absolute Priority 3 and (2) Student Achievement: Prepare all students to succeed in postsecondary education, aligned with Competitive Preference Priority 6. The project will examine whether there is a statistically significant relationship to academic achievement, graduation rate, and post secondary success in students who participate in a specific pathway as compared to students who do not participate in a specific pathway. The Savannah-Chatham County Public Schools will continue working with many dedicated community partners: Gulfstream, Georgia Power, and Learning for Life, to name a few. This program will develop stronger partnerships to ensure that all students are prepared for the future."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Save the Children's Rural Literacy Initiative
Project Description: "Save the Children (STC) is one of the largest and most highly regarded organizations in the world devoted to helping children in need.  In the United States, we have developed a targeted literacy intervention that accelerates children's reading achievement.  Working in partnership with rural schools, our Rural Literacy Program provides in-school, afterschool and summer programming to 15,000 children in nearly 150 of the nation's poorest and most remote rural communities.  During the 2008-09 school year, children participating in these programs made growth equivalent to attending an additional 3 months of school.  Just as important, we have built an infrastructure that enables our program to be replicated in hard to reach rural communities.Through a Validation Grant, STC will address Absolute Priority 4, 'Innovations to Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools,' by implementing a targeted intervention which expands and augments the school day and school year.  Over a four-year grant period, we will implement the Rural Literacy Program at 88 Priority 4 Schools in Arizona, Arkansas, California, New Mexico and South Carolina. STC's researched-based intervention is designed to meet the needs of below grade-level readers in kindergarten through grade 6.  By targeting struggling readers - the population that prevents schools from making Adequate Yearly Progress in English Language Arts - STC's Rural Literacy Program will affect school turnaround in persistently low achieving rural schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Say Yes to Education: a City-wide Turnaround Model of Project Design
Project Description: "Say Yes to Education (Say Yes) is proposing to validate and take to scale a replicable model to efficiently and effectively organize people, time, and money, to support breakthrough outcomes at the child, classroom, school, district, city, and county levels. Building on a 23-year track record of dramatically increasing high school and college graduation rates for urban youth, the Say Yes City-wide Turnaround Model is offering a research-based path to college and productive citizenship for over 50,000 students in New York State within the next five yaers. The model is demonstrating how to organize an entire city to commit to a postsecondary completion goal for all students, partner with higher education, develop an efficient public-private service delivery model, and manage transparent fiscal and student outcome accountability systems. The model includes five critical components: 1) collection and use of objective data for continuous quality improvement at the student, school, district, agency, city, and county levels; 2) implementation of research-based whole school reform programs system-wide that result in the delivery of rigorous and engaging college preparatory programming for all students; 3) efficient delivery of comprehensive community services that are proven to minimize and/or remove the barriers to post-secondary access ( physical and mental health, legal, family counseling, social services, etc.); 4) creation and institutionalization of a new municipal governanace structure that results in high levels of transparency and broad-based community and political commitment  to a universal college access agenda; and 5) long-term availability of student-centered scholarship incentives for all students within a defined economic development zone. Over a  four-year period of time, a comprehensive school and student assessment system and aligned college-preparatory program is being rolled out across the entire city of Syracuse. Say YEs proposes to fully implement and... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: SCCC/Schenectady CSD/Shenendehowa CSD i3 Initiative, An Urban/Surban Educational Collaborative in the Era of Emerging Technologieis
Project Description: "This project focuses on the provision of innovative STEM-based learning activities for high needs students delivered continually from elementary through high school, and resulting assessment tools and standards that can be utlized across various settings. Key elements of the project, delivered through a unique urban-suburban partnership include:o	Integration of non-traditional experiences into the elementary math and science curriculum, introducing this generation of students to the real life application of STEM skills. o	Reinforcement of the potential for technology based careers via Middle School student participation in hands on, engaging science, math and technology based activities. o	Rigorous high school level science electives including pre-engineering tracts and biotechnical courses to lay the foundation for high growth career paths. o	Implementation of a Smart Scholars Early College High School and its expansion over the next 5 years to provide the opportunity for high need students to achieve success in an academically rigorous, student-focused, contextual, and integrated learning environment.o	Use of a twelve month 'Learning is anytime, anywhere, anyone' approach providing extended day or out of school programs, technology industry field trips, MST programs specifically targeted at girls, and academically based summer camps.o	Teacher training to align current technology equipment and advances with everyday teaching methods and subject matter.  o	Student and family support mechanisms that address barriers to educational success and build a well-rounded student.o	Workforce development connections provided through visiting lecturers from local emerging technology industries, and on site staff-development for teachers.o	Implementation of a multi-phased data collection and project evaluation protocol providing practice analyses and assisting with potential scalability decisions. "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Schools for the Future
Project Description: "Schools for the Future is a small learning community model designed to serve over-aged, under-credited, and high schools students significantly below grade level in reading and math proficiency. Each SFF school/small learning community will serve 240 students, all of whom are at least two years behind academically because they have been repeatedly retained in earlier grades. In partnership with Duval County, New York City Public Schools, and a proposed charter school in Lawrence, MA, SFF will provide its students with a fully performance-driven route to a high school diploma, postsecondary education, and career. SFF integrates cutting edge practices in five different domains: rigorous proficiency-based progression to graduation, acceleration curriculum for ELA and math, an explicit affective program to build cognitive confidence and self-efficacy, real-time student performance analytics, and a 'limitless campus' of extended online and community-based learning opportunities. As a result, SFF students will be able to achieve an average of 2 years of academic gain for every 1 year in the program, regardless of entering skill level, and graduate with a regular high school diploma in 5 years or less, ready to succeed at the post-secondary level, with no need for remediation.Over the course of the i3-supported stage of the project, SFF will serve 2880 high need disconnecting/disconnected youth in 12 schools/pathways in Florida, New York City, and Massachusetts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Investing In Innovation... In Iowa (i5)
Project Description: "The proposed i5 project is designed to further develop and support drop-out prevention and intervention services in the State of Iowa within the state-wide Learning Supports Framework by developing a district and state-level early-warning system that monitors on-track indicators for all students. Critical elements of the project design include:o	District-level early warning system monitoring student-level on-track indicators for i5 districts that aligns with state-wide longitudinal data systems and reporting requirements. o	High need school districts selecting or expanding research-based strategies to serve student needs and tailored to each community's strengths, resources and partnerships.  o	Professional training and coaching provided by School Administrators of Iowa staff and regional coaches to support district planning, implementation, monitoring and sustainability.o	Sub-grants to provide resources for participating districts while they transition and redesign use of state and local resources, such as Allowable Growth and At-Risk Supplemental funding.o	Coaching, community partnership and state-wide private sector coordination to leverage new funding and resources at the community level toward a common, sustainable education goal o	High quality evaluation design and rigorous research protocols followed under the leadership of University of Iowa's Center for Evaluation and Assessment"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: School Association for Special Education in Du Page (SASED)
Project Title: PBIS Advanced Application for All to Achieve (PBIS-A4)
Project Description: "The purpose of the Positive Behavioral Interventions and Supports Advanced Application for All to Achieve (PBIS-A4) Project is to validate and expand implementation of the standard and already tested components of the PBIS framework with attention to expediting outcomes for students in high-risk groups (e.g. low social-economic status, ethnic minorities and students with disabilities). The School Association for Special Education in DuPage County (SASED), the LEA/fiscal agent for the Illinois PBIS Network, is the official applicant, in partnership with the National PBIS Center at the University of Oregon. Primary components of the PBIS-A4 model are: 1) Data-based decision making by school teams; 2) An advanced data solution with a data warehouse component; and 3) The use of field-tested strategies specifically designed to address disparities in academic outcomes and disciplinary practices. To achieve these outcomes, 400 Illinois schools during a five-year period will receive access to an advanced data system, training and technical assistance in implementing and sustaining this model. PBIS-A4 partners include 25 Illinois school districts which are already implementing the PBIS framework in their schools. The project includes a) a pilot phase (with 30 schools) during years 1-2; b) an embedded randomized, waitlist-controlled (RCT) study in 150 schools in years 3-4; and c) a sustainability component which will be culminate in replication in 220 schools, and d) national dissemination strategies.  Results from the overall evaluation plan, including the RCT study, will provide evidence of the effectiveness of PBIS-A4 to increase facility in the use of teaming, data, and strategies, thereby reducing achievement gaps and increasing behavioral and academic competence for all students, including those at highest-risk for school failure. An estimated 250,000 students will be impacted by the project which will be supported by a network of private funders."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Florida Teaching and Learning Communities Project
Project Description: "The Florida Teaching and Learning Communities project will provide cutting edge professional development to 540 teachers in 68 low performing schools in 28 small and rural districts. These teachers will mentor 2,160 other teachers with the goal of improving student achievement for these schools which enroll more than 51,000 students. An additional 188 schools in the total of 32 rural school districts will be impacted, which enroll 156, 607 students, and for continued scale up, all schools in the state of Florida.   Teacher effectiveness will be improved by providing cutting-edge professional development and mentoring for teachers who desire to become National Board Certified Teachers (NBCT), creating increased technology capacity in these schools, and supporting principals as instructional leaders. A unique web-based instructional tool will guide teachers through the development of high-quality courses, lessons and assessments using an extensive repository of media and content to be shared with other teachers. The professional development will be delivered through summer institutes, then school year follow-up through  teacher learning specialists and  teacher mentors.  The technology infrastructure of the schools and districts will be enhanced to ensure access to the Internet. The result will be an 8% improvement in student achievement. The project applicant is the Highlands School District, representing a partnership of 32 small and rural school districts  and the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, our non-profit official partner. This validation grant will address Absolute Priory 1-Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals and Competitive Preference Priority 8-Innovations that serve schools in rural LEA's."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Schools of Innovation
Project Description: "Miami-Dade Public Schools, in partnership with The City of Hialeah, Univision, Big Brother Big Sisters of Greater Miami, and other local municipalities, seeks a Validation Grant to implement a ?Schools of Innovation? project designed to measurably improve student performance and promote an environment that fosters preparedness for and graduation from two- or four-year colleges for students at four (Absolute Priority 4) senior high schools. These schools have been identified as persistently low-performing schools. The approximately 7,480 students who attend these schools exemplify students at risk of educational failure (high-needs students).Project objectives include: decreasing the number of chronically absent students; increasing the number of students earning five or more credits and passing Algebra 1 by the end of grade 9; increasing the number of students showing reading and mathematics learning gains on State assessments; increasing promotion and graduation rates; increasing the number of students achieving postsecondary readiness; increasing the number of students participating in internships and capstone experiences; increasing the number of students earning college credit and industry certifications in high school; and increasing the number of students who transition to postsecondary institutions and earn Florida Bright Futures and Gold Seal Scholarships. The objectives, goals, strategies, and activities included in this proposal are consistent with contextual learning/curriculum alignment and secondary school reform research that promotes the Career Academy model as a method of improving multiple areas of student performance. Restructuring these low-performing schools around the academy model has the potential to turn them around by improving student achievement, increasing graduation rates, and revitalizing the culture and climate of the school.Project"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: SCHOOL BOARD OF MIAMI-DADE COUNTY, FLORIDA
Project Title: BRIDGING THE GAP THROUGH EDUCATIONAL EXCELLENCE
Project Description: "The proposed project, Bridging the Gap through Educational Excellence (BGEE), represents a collaborative effort through the Education Compact between Miami-Dade County Public School and the City of Miami Beach. By providing in-depth, highly structured professional development to the teachers, principals and administrators who will incorporate the rigorous International Baccalaurete Primary Years and Middle Years Programmes within the feeder pattern in the City of Miami Beach, the District will be able to integrate high-quality education that articulates from Kindergarten to 8 grade, while effectively preparing high-needs students from a diverse minority population towards career-college readiness and global awareness"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: School Board of Miami-Dade County, Florida
Project Title: Learning on Demand 24/7
Project Description: Learning on Demand 24/7 is designed to increase student achievement by changing the entire instructional delivery of core courses for students in two struggling Miami-Dade middle schools. This project demonstrates the efficacy of ?digital immersion? by replacing traditional textbooks and providing students with: mobiledevices for class and home use; free Internet connectivity; and access to a web portal with digital texts and courseware closely aligned with state standards. Teachers benefit from rigorous summer and job-imbedded professional development on the use of technology and data driven differentiated instruction. Families sign contracts regarding their understanding of program and requirements.
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: School Board of Miami-Dade County, Florida
Project Title: Florida Master Teacher Initiative
Project Description: "Miami-Dade County Public Schools (M-DCPS), the University of Florida, and The Early ChildhoodInitiative Foundation, in partnership with the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, propose to enhance early learninginstruction to high-need students by 1) developing an early childhood specialization within the existing jobembeddedmaster?s program and offering the program to 100 early childhood teachers (grades pre-K-3), 2)replicating the successful Teacher Fellows model within the same schools to help 1,125 teachers across all gradesimprove their instruction through an inquiry-based approach by participating in learning communities led by themaster?s students, 3) providing support to principals through the Principal Fellows model to enhance their abilityto facilitate change within their schools, and 4) using an experimental design to rigorously evaluate the model anddocument quantitative and qualitative outcomes on school culture, teaching efficacy and effectiveness, andstudent achievement. The project will address Absolute Priority 1 (Innovations that Support Effective Teachersand Principals) and Competitive Preference Priority 5 (Innovations for Improving Early Learning Outcomes).The proposal builds on cutting edge research, best practices in teacher and leadership professional developmentand the grounded, front line experience of the partners in the nation?s most diverse community. The modeloutlined in this grant proposal shows initially promising results of improving student achievement, increasingteacher commitment and teaching skills, and enhancing overall school culture. Through the development of thenew specialization within the job-embedded master?s degree, rigorous evaluation of the overall school reformmodel that includes Teacher and Principal Fellows, and improvements to this work through feedback from theevaluation, the partners will be positioned to codify and scale these promising practices widely throughout theUnited States."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: School Board of Pinellas County, FL
Project Title: Center for Climate, Community, and Prosocial Learning
Project Description: "Pinellas County Schools in partnership with Community Tampa Bay, Multi-Dimensional Education Inc., and the Pacific Institute of Research and Evaluation (PIRE) is requesting a five year development grant to create a data driven Center for Climate, Community, and Pro-social Learning (CCCPL) that will address non academic barriers to learning to improve academic achievement, increase graduation rates and decrease achievement gaps between subgroups. The center will utilize multidimensional data and evidence based programming to accelerate success for all students and promote a climate of college readiness and success. Absolute priority two?s requirement to create ?innovations that improve the use of data? will be met with the development of the Integrated Non-Academic Barrier Data System (IN-ABDS) housed within and sustained through the CCCPL. The project will directly serve 53,000 students, with all 103,000 Pinellas students ultimately benefiting from the project activities including professional development, data collection and analysis, creation of a data system, and development of community partnership to deliver social emotional learning programs. The development of CCCPL and IN-ABDS will link existing data to new non-academic barrier data in a system making the data readily available, understandable, and useable by educators. The center and data system will increase the use of multidimensional disaggregated data to inform decision-making and planning efforts toward improved student achievement and student growth. The development of this center and implementation of a more robust data system will provide the tools to measure and disseminate how a broader focus on the needs of the whole child and learning environment can compliment and inform efforts to stimulate student achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Focus on Transition to High School
Project Description: "Focus on Transition will apply promising strategies focused on transition into high school for 30,000 studentsover four years. The exceptional approach in Focus on Transition is to address barriers that have been found inimplementing transitions strategies, particularly small learning communities, with the packaging and deliveryof these strategies in a model that schools can grasp, focus on and implement. Our project will do so by:A. developing small learning communities for all first-time 9th graders within comprehensive high schools.B. pursuing sound instructional strategies which small scale uniquely positions teachers to carry out: primarilyrigor and relevance in curriculum/instruction/ assessment and relationships that enhance learning. Suchpersonal relationships, the key advantage of small scale, are built in this model by? building a culture where every student is known, valued, engaged, supported and kept safe, inspired andexpected to succeed;? students are taught by a core team of teachers with administrative support that regularly meets to identifyproblems, study solutions, discuss students, improve instruction? students work together cooperatively over extended periods and discuss their concerns about the schoolenvironment.1. Improve school climate and remove barriers to learning as measured by the Successful Practices Network?sWe Survey Suite capturing the opinions of students, teachers and leaders, and tracking discipline referral rates.2. Increase attendance rates3. A. Increase academic rigor and relevance in the classrooms as measured by the use of Gold Seal Lessons.4. Increase student performance levels on state exams.5. Increase the number of students completing Advanced Placement, International Baccalaureate and dual creditprograms.The partnership includes the Florida Association of School Administrators and the Successful Practices Network,and affiliate of the International Center for Leadership in Education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: School Board of St. Lucie County
Project Title: Project BRIDGE
Project Description: "The purpose of St. Lucie County School District?s this project is to refine and implement a comprehensive, integrated instructional system comprised of three intervention strategies: 1) a comprehensive formative assessment system for progress monitoring with a robust data reporting system to drive curricular, instructional, and professional development decisions (including the development of a data warehouse and data dashboard); 2) common core standards that are aligned with the state of Florida Next Generation Sunshine State Standards (NGSSS); and 3) a professional development system aligned with the common core standards, students? performance data, and teacher effectiveness. The four goals of this project are to: (1) provide teachers and school administrators with aligned tools for instructional decision-making; (2) increase student learning and achievement for all students and subgroups, and increase graduation rates for high schools; (3) close the achievement gaps amongst ethnic and socio-economic subgroups; (4) Increase student learning and achievement for all students and subgroups, and increase graduation rates for high schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: School Board of the County of Spotsylvania
Project Title: OnCOMPASS Academy: Charting Successful Futures
Project Description: "Spotsylvania County Schools (SCS), located in Virginia, has a growing population of high-need students who are at risk of failing, unprepared for college, or in danger of not graduating from high school. OnCOMPASS Academy is designed to achieve the overarching goal of providing programs and resources that increase the likelihood that area secondary students will graduate high school and be better prepared for further education and careers. OnCOMPASS Academy is comprised of a number of complimentary components: OnCOMPASS Academy Learning Labs - online learning environments; OnCOMPASS Academy Support - specialized support interventions; and OnCOMPASS Academy Connections - community outreach and professionaldevelopment opportunities. These components will provide an alternative for high school students whose needs are not being met in traditional settings. With $4.3 million in Investing in Innovation (i3) Fund Development Grant support, OnCOMPASS Academy will enhance the development of 4,000 or more high-need secondary students toward college and career readiness.Over five years, OnCOMPASS Academy will serve high-need students from both Spotsylvania and Caroline County Public Schools, an official partner. Germanna Community College (GCC) and the North TIER Consortium are other partners who will provide professional learning for Academic Coaching Teams that will provide academic support to the students. Professional learning activities for the Coaching Teams will include coursework, seminars, cyberconferences and video conferences. SCS and GCC will partner to develop college readiness activities for students as they study in the OnCOMPASS Academy. The Academy will begin in five high schools and, in year three, add a middle school in SCS and a high school in Caroline County Schools. An independent research team will be responsible for the measurement of program outcomes that will provide data for developing next steps based the program goal."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: School District No. 1 of the City and County of Denver, State of Colorado
Project Title: Literacy Squared Colorado
Project Description: "Literacy Squared Colorado (Lit
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: School District No. 1 of the City and County of Denver, State of Colorado
Project Title: Collaborative Strategic Reading Colorado (CSR-CO)
Project Description: "Collaborative Strategic Reading Colorado (CSR-CO) is designed around the CU BUENO Center literacy intervention, Collaborative Strategic Reading, used successfully in linguistically diverse classrooms to address the linguistic and academic needs of ELLs and students with disabilities.CSR-CO focuses on Collaborative Strategic Reading professional development for teachers in high-need middle school classrooms. CSR-CO also provides students with opportunities to work in small cooperative groups in which each student plays a role associated with effective reading comprehension (e.g. brainstorming, monitoring understanding and summarizing). CSR-CO is built on a foundation of reciprocal teaching and effective instruction features such as collaborative group work, interactive dialogue, and procedural strategies."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: College and Career Readiness Academies
Project Description: "As one of the top performing districts in the State of Florida, the School District of Clay County, in collaboration with the Schultz Center for Teaching and Leadership, in Jacksonville, Florida, will implement 'College and Career Readiness Academies' (CCRA),  a comprehensive approach to increase college access and success amongst 'at-risk' students.           By creating wall-to-wall academies at two of the seven high schools in the Clay County School District, CCRA will track student indicators for college readiness, provide an opportunity to earn college credit while in high school, offer after-school and summer remediation and tutoring, student internships, and service learning opportunities.  Career Specialists will work with students to provide assistance in the completion of their college application and obtaining scholarships and/or financial aid. Teachers will receive on-going professional development through their participation in professional learning communities and lesson studies. All student at the selected high schools will be placed in an academy, have a mentor and receive appropriate career and college readiness counseling and support from the faculty and staff.  CCRA students will show an increase of 10% in the at-risk graduation rate, college readiness rate and attendance rates at the selected sites."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: McCaskey on the M.O.V.E.
Project Description: "The School district of Lancaster is proposing McCaskey on the M.O.V.E. (Make Opportunities, Viaje a Exito), a three-pronged approach to reform our high school that encompasses a full service community school, satellite computer labs throughout the city, and our own Cyber School.In the name of our program, McCaskey on the M.O.V.E. 'Move' stands for 'Making Opportunities, Viaje a Exito,' which translated means 'travel to excellence.'  This dual language titling is meant to appeal to all McCaskey students and to especially target our ELL population.  It is hoped that by providing student/family supports via full service community school, access to academic supports via off campus learning facilities during non-school hours, and graduation support via an alternative to tradional school, we will encourage students to 'make their own opportunities' that will lead them to success, both in school and in life."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: School District of Palm Beach County
Project Title: Learning Team Meeting Model
Project Description: "T The School District of Palm Beach County (SDPBC), Florida is seeking support to develop and implement the Learning Team Meeting (LTM) Model, a unique and exceptional approach using the Learning Team Meeting as the innovation to improve the use of data (Absolute Priority 2) to increase achievement for high needs students. The project will be scaled up to include Winston-Salem/Forsythe County Schools and Ashe County Schools in North Carolina. Over the three year project period, 48,840 students in 61 high needs schools will benefit from this model.The SDPBC has developed a Professional Learning Communities (PLC) framework with three distinct evidence-based protocols, utilized in the venue referred to as Learning Team Meetings. Teachers at high needs schools use this forum to systematically analyze student data and improve instructional practices in order to increase student achievement. Along with this innovative PLC framework, the district has developed an advanced Data and Assessment System. By using the evidence-based protocols and the Data and Assessment System, the LTM Model was created. The LTM Model takes high quality assessment data to make school-based decisions that benefit all stakeholders. LTM protocol training, implementation assistance, and monitoring for fidelity will be provided to all three districts using distance-based learning, video conferencing, observations and on-site training services. Houghton-Mifflin Harcourt will provide a match through its Learning Village instructional resources. CORE K12 Education will provide in-kind match in its web-based testing platform. Program impact will be measured by increases in academic achievement and growth."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: 1-to-1 Computing to Improve Student Achievement
Project Description: "The School District of Random Lake proposes to conduct a program that provides a computing device (tablet, laptop, or netbook computer) to each student in a class to determine and measure the positive impact on student achievement in classroom tests and other assessments."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: School District of the City of Battle Creek
Project Title: Expansion of BCAMSC Kit Program

Applicant: School District of the City of Detroit
Project Title: Detroit Public Schools: Engaging in Education a PK-14 Model
