Project Description: "With our academic and foundation partners, Detroit Public Schools will create an accessible and secure model PreK-14 facility in Detroit that will provide a stable, enriching environment for every child while emphasizing academic achievement and post-secondary education at all grade levels.  This facility will also support a high school educational program allowing students to move into college level courses, while remaining in the familiar and supportive high school environment.  PreK-8 and Early College High Schools (ECHS) have each shown to be effective for improving educational outcomes for at-risk students. Detroit Public Schools will partner with Wayne State University, University of Michigan and Michigan State University to design a program and facility to support a high school and a two year post-secondary educational program to be housed on a campus shared with a new PreK-8 school. The combined facilities will provide a seamless transition for the children of Detroit beginning with PreK and ending 15 years later with college credit or an Associates Degree. The campus will also provide easily accessible health care, summer school, athletic and after school activities.  Detroit?s first model PreK-14 program will be housed in the new MLK High School. The campus will boast a LEED Silver Certified facility. It is designed with flexible learning spaces with cutting-edge technology.  Its curriculum focus will be STEM."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: School District of the City of Detroit
Project Title: Detroit Public Schools: Leadership Academy
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: School District of the City of Erie
Project Title: iSTEM
Project Description: "iSTEM will create a systemic change in education; embedding academics into C.T.E. programs, using 21st century technology tools, using project based learning, to address Science Technology Engineer and Mathematics (STEM)career pathways."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: School District of the City of Pontiac
Project Title: PEACE--Promoting Equal Access for College Entrance
Project Description: "Pontiac School District proposes an innovative project that starts with one primary purpose ? to encourage all students to enroll in postsecondary education ? and applies Backward Design principles to create academic pathways that lead students to college. The project replicates a strategy designed by Dr. Thomas Maridada, Superintendent of Pontiac School District, and piloted with tremendous success at a small, extremely low-performing school district in a neighboring metropolitan Detroit community (Inkster Public Schools, Inkster, Michigan). The fundamental design of PEACE applies Backward Design strategies (Wiggins and McTighe, 2001) to build a project that promotes attainment of positive and rigorous student postsecondary education outcomes. The strategy links all grade levels through the singular purpose of preparing high-risk, urban, minority students to overcome persistent cycles of academic failure, graduate from high school and enroll in and succeed in postsecondary education. While implementation of PEACE may generate numerous desirable student outcomes, all efforts are clearly linked to postsecondary education enrollment. The core component of the project ? College Pathways ? can serve as a stand-alone implementation model. To best meet the specific needs of Pontiac students and schools, PEACE includes supplementary layers of support that promote success of the core approach to college enrollment ? school preparation and student preparation. The PEACE initiative ? as proposed for Pontiac School District ? includes the following key elements: 1) School Preparation; 2) Student Preparation and 3) College Pathways."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Middle School Reform: Focused on What Matters Most, the Instructional Core and Students' Affective Needs
Project Description: "What Matters Most is a total school, total student approach to successful learning in a diverse urban St. Louis area district. It focuses on four domains in which students must become competent in to be successful in life: 1) the intellect, 2) the self, 3) the world, and 4) healthy/safe decisions. What Matters Most will develop project based units that link essential learning to career awareness and skills bridging all four of these critical areas. We hypothesize that these activities will lead to increased preparation for high school, for college, and for further success."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: SUNRISE INVESTMENT IN INNOVATION
Project Description: "The 'Sunrise Investment in Innovation Program'  proposes to boost the math achievement of our students so they may compete to enter any college program they choose.   Poor achievement in math in the elementary grades sets a pattern of failure when in high school. Paired with the instruction offered by the classroom teacher, an online program, Stanford University EPGY Mathematics Program, will engage students from K-8 in their math,The proposed program seeks to raise the achievement on the state exam, by increasing time spent on mathematics through the use of the Stanford EPGY.             The Sunrise i3 partnership will employ a Response to Intervention Specialist and a Program Director for a three year period. The (NWEA) evaluations , the EPGY licenses , training and support , and mobile carts with netbooks will be purchased. An independent study will be designed and led by the University of Maine."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Defining the Digital Identity of a Learner
Project Description: "A true educational transformation is emerging from a 'perfect storm' of activities never seen before in the United States.  The components of this storm includes the American Reinvestment and Recovery Act, a Blueprint for Reauthorization of ESEA, the National Broadband Plan, a new National Education Technology Plan, the Race to the Top Program and the Statewide Longitudinal Data Systems Program and can allow for unparalleled change for our nation.  Through all of these initiatives and programs, a need to create a framework for a Digital Identity of  a Learner exists.  Without providing an open, technical standard to exchange data about a learner, content and assessment, educational stakeholders will not be as effective; suppliers will not easily align content, resources and assessment to student learning and achievement; and personalized and individualized data about a learner will not be taken into account in the education process.	For over 12 years, the SIF Association brings together the education community to develop open, technical standards for interoperability between educational applications. These standards provide opportunities for all students - high-need, students with disabilities and Limited English proficient students - to increase their achievement and growth.	The SIF Association and assembled project team base all of the work for this development grant on the hypothesis that when an open, interoperable framework is defined based on the three elements of the Digital Identity of a learner, individualized student data can be provided seamlessly to students, teachers and administrators to inform decision making, ultimately improving teacher effectiveness leading to increased student achievement and growth.	This project will develop the framework and conduct the necessary software and technical development to support the outlined hypothesis and project research and evaluation."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Development of High School STEM Clubs in Rural Arizona
Project Description: "An innovative extracurricular Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics 'STEM Clubs' model is proposed that will engage high school (HS) students in STEM learning after school leading to improved college and career STEM readiness. STEM Clubs provides a robust platform of activities in an informal setting that will interest a wide range of students and help them identify the relevance and reality and applicability of STEM in formal teaching and learning environments. The proposal builds on the belief that high school students operate at a higher level and with greater success in a social environment that recognizes STEM stars as equals among sports and rock stars. The STEM Clubs model can be tested and validated, shared and replicated, and taken to scale, especially for rural, Native American and other underserved populations.Science Foundation Arizona (SFAz), a non-profit dedicated to enhancing STEM capacity and achievement for all students leads this collaborative effort. Partners include a large school district, a rural district and a Native American community HS with a combined population that is 35% Hispanic, 4% Native American and 11% African American. Additional district and HS partners will be added over the period of the grant resulting in 120 STEM Clubs and 6300 students impacted over 5 years.Projected outcomes include a marketable and measureable template for STEM Clubs demonstrating reproducibility of the model in diverse and remote settings. A dedicated web portal enabling communication among students and teachers and community stake-holders will link the STEM Clubs. Participating students represent each school's demographics and Career Technical Education (CTE) populations; half will be women. STEM teacher professional development will be provided for 240 teachers; and half of will be CTE teachers. Engaging parents will encourage students to pursue STEM-related activities and career choices.  "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Science Olympiad Urban Schools Initiative
Project Description: "Science Olympiad, a national after-school program, will bring a multi-discipline team STEM club and competition to 224 new schools, 6,720 students, 13,440 parents and 1,120 teachers in Illinois, North Carolina, Hawaii and Maryland over a three-year period. A collaborative partnership including the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign's I-STEM Education Initiative, Chicago Public Schools and the Office of Science, the Midwest Alliance for STEM, and four state Science Olympiad organizations will sustain this program.  Budget OverviewThe total cost of the project is $1.45 million over three years.  Each state Science Olympiad will receive the bulk of the funding, about $213,000 each spread over three years.  Science Olympiad, I-STEM and CPS will share in funding for administration, meetings, research and evaluation, development and production and dissemination of resources, and travel.  Many services will be donated. Science Olympiad will also invest in a technology purchase of Texas Instruments equipment for schools in each target area. The cost to reach each student is about $215 for three years, or about $6 per month. However, the indirect impact of a Science Olympiad program is that the entire school population is invited to participate in the Science Olympiad club or experience.  We include teachers, parents and students reached in our estimates, bringing the total reach of the program to 21,280, lowering the average per person cost for three years to $1.90 per month.Founded in 1984 and currently serving 6,000 school teams in 49 states with 320 academic tournaments a year, Science Olympiad is dedicated to improving the quality of K-12 STEM education, increasing, male, female and minority interest in science, creating a technologically literate workforce and providing recognition for outstanding achievement by both students and teachers through competition and professional development."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Innovating Education in Rural Appalachia
Creating a Digital Learning Ecosystem on the Campus of Scotland High School
Differentiate!
Project Description: "Differentiate! responds  to the urgent national need for students with limited English proficiency to master rigorour English Language Arts common core standards and achieve high levels of academic writing that ensure college and career readiness.Differentiate! expands, studies, and validates the work of two innovative and highly complementary California initiatives of the San Diego County Office of Education: Standards-based Differentiated Instruction: Side by Side and the WRITE Institute in collaboration with private sector partner, Imagine Learning.Differentiate! directly addresses Absolute Priority #3: standards and assessments to measure students' progress towards college and career readiness, and Competitive Preference Priority #7: unique learning needs of limited English proficient students.Differentiate! proposes the reasonable hypotheses that: IF teachers of limited English proficient students are provided with a comprehensive professional development system for standards-based differentiated instruction and assessment, THEN limited English proficient students will increase college and career readiness as evidenced by increased student achievement, increased enrollment in College Prep & AP courses, and increased graduation rates.Differentiate! Goals: promote college and career readiness by increasing the success of under-represented students in rigorous courses and programs through differentiated standard-based instruction and assessment; develop and expand formative assessments aligned to rigorous academic standards and differentiated levels of language proficiency; and increase student achievement in writing as a result of improved teacher knowledge and skills to interpret standards and assessment data to inform differentiated classroom practices."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Building Assets-Reducing Risks Program: Replication and Expansion of an Effective Strategy to Turn Around Low Achieving Schools
Project Description: Search Institute is applying for a development grant to replicate and expand the Building Assets-Reducing Risks (BARR) Program. BARR is a promising strategy with a focus on the first year of high school with intentionality on high-need students, student achievement and student growth. The goal of the BARR is to increase student achievement for all first year high school students using asset building and improving school climate as the means for these changes."Search Institute is applying for a development grant to replicate and expand the Building Assets-Reducing Risks (BARR) Program. BARR is a promising strategy with a focus on the first year of high school with intentionality on high-need students, student achievement and student growth. The goal of the BARR is to increase student achievement for all first year high school students using asset building and improving school climate as the means for these changes.  This will be achieved by meeting these objectives: reduce academic failure; increase student attendance, decrease disciplinary incidents; and decrease alcohol, tobacco and other drug use. BARR has been implemented and evaluated and has demonstrated results in reducing risk behaviors (i.e. failures, illegal substance use, truancy) and increasing thriving behaviors. It is listed in the National Registry of Evidence-Based Programs and Practices (NREPP).     We will achieve the goal of turning around persistently low-performing schools through integrating student supports into the school model to address non academic barriers to learning (Absolute Priority 4). BARR will be expanded to include 10th-12 grade students at the site it was developed (St. Louis Park, MN) with innovations that support college access and success (Competitive Priority 6) while replicating the initial BARR program at three other low-performing schools across the nation including rural LEAS (Competitive Priority 8) Innovations that Serve Schools in rural LEAs.    We will be partnering with the highly recognized program, Admission Possible, to develop our college and career readiness components.  School district partners include St. Louis Park, Minnesota; (District 283); Madison Area District, Maine (MSAD 59); Bucksport District, Maine (RSU 25): and Hemet Unified School District in Hemet, California.     BARR implementation will impact 7500 students from 2010-2014."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Waldorf Methods in the Public Sector
Project Description: "The proposed project will create and assess a public Waldorf curriculum that ensures 90% of graduates meet UC admission requirements. The project also seeks to improve student achievement, close achievement gaps, and quantitatively and qualitatively measure the effectiveness of 9-12 Waldorf-based education in the public sector. The project will create and test a replicable, developmental, and experiential Waldorf-based high school curriculum that meets or exceeds California state standards and ensures that all graduates develop capacities for lifelong success in the 21st Century. The Waldorf curriculum is designed for kindergarten through twelfth grade. The success of the North Bay, California K-8 Waldorf public schools and their proximity to one another provide the opportunity for a regional public Waldorf high school that will serve hundreds of students and test the efficacy of this model on graduation rates, college preparedness, and closing the achievement gap. Waldorf methodology employs a holistic approach to education and, is therefore, well equipped to serve students who have tended to fall into the underserved demographic as well as mainstream students. The project features a community-centered approach, experiential education, integrated curriculum with an emphasis on a developmental approach, and organizational sustainability."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: SECME Integrated Interventions Impacting STEM (SECME I3 STEM)
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Deploying "Possible Selves" Theory to Motivate Students
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Youth Potential Realized at Jefferson High School
Project Description: "The Self Enhancement and Jefferson High School Youth Potential Realized program will provide support for college access and success for students starting in 9th grade and extending through age 25. Each student on entering 9th grade will be assisted by their Youth Coordinator working with a school counselor to develop an Individual Success Plan including courses needed to meet their post-high goals. College support activities will be woven into the In-School, After School, Summer, and Parent Involvement programs at each grade level, including career assessment (in grades 9 and 11), career exploration (including visits to businesses and career-related community college classes), financial aid and scholarship workshops, visits to regional and national colleges, academic support for core college prep subjects, and SAT/ACT preparation.Jefferson HS will partner with Portland Community College to make a Middle College program available to students at the nearby Cascade campus in which students can accumulate dual credits and explore career options while attending high school. Each student will be supported by their Youth Coordinator with wrap-around services to help ensure success.In their senior year, students will be guided through college admission and financial aid processes, provided information about scholarship programs and assisted with applications, and helped to write application essays. After graduation, all students in Youth Potential Realized will be assigned to a Post-High Coordinator. Students in college will have 24/7 access by phone to their coordinator, who will help with academic advising, finding financial aid and scholarship assistance, accessing mentors if needed, facilitating opportunities to network with other students in the program, and any other assistance needed to help them succeed."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Closing Achievement Gaps through Data-Based Writing Instruction
Project Description: "Brief Project Description (including project activities): Seminole County Public Schools (SCPS) will implement The Writers? Express (WEX), a data-driven, fully differentiated, innovative curriculum and teacher training program for improving outcomes in writing achievement. Evaluators from Learning Point Associates will conduct an independent RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial) evaluation of WEX in SCPS to estimate the causal effect of WEX on student writing abilities as measured by FCAT.  Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: This project will close the achievement gap in writing by establishing a seamless data-driven writing initiative across all schools in Seminole County and study itsimpact. The goals are:1. Teachers and administrators will use data to differentiate instruction and close the achievement gap between 2 underperforming subgroups in Seminole County: African American students and Economically Disadvantaged students.2. The partners will work together to scale up a data-driven approach to literacy instruction and measure itsimpact on student writing performance in grades 4, 8 and 10 on FCAT.3. The study will measure the implementation fidelity in high poverty schools vs. more heterogeneous schools to see if the data-driven approach enables the district to reach students in underperforming sub-groups wherever they are found in the district.  Target Number of Students Served: 41,750 Special Project Features: 1. The expertise of SCPS in use of data at scale; 2. WEX?s proven approach to using data to maximize the impact of instruction and professional development. List of Official Partners and Other Partners: Official Partner: Seminole County Public Schools (SCPS); Other partner: The Writers? Express (WEX), a division of Wireless Generation, Inc, Learning Points Associates."

Project Title: Achieve K-12 Transition Model
Project Description: "Seminole County Public Schools proposes to implement the Achieve: K-12 Transition Model. Building onpromising practices within the district and in partnership with Seminole State College, the program intends toclose the gap of achievement for sub-groups across the target population through the implementation of amodel which focuses on improving student achievement through a teach-forward model, as well asconcentrating on the ?whole-student?, to include a multitude of intervention strategies based on student data.Focusing on three areas of transition, the project addresses the needs of students in Elementary: 3rd to 4thgrade; Middle: 5th to 6th grade; and High: 8th to 9th grade. Achieve will be implemented in 21 schools, toinclude 9 high schools, 9 middle schools, and 3 elementary schools. The total target population per year is1,260 students. Program components include a Summer Transition Program, Transition Seminar,individualized interventions, and parent outreach. The purpose of the project is to provide low-achieving,high-need students early intervention through innovative, individualized educational programming intended toimprove academic performance, enhance personal and social functioning within the educational setting, andincrease the ability for students to successfully transition between grade levels, thereby increasing graduationrates of high-need students. The projected outcomes include: (1) increased student achievement; (2) increasedtransitioning between grade levels at age-appropriate intervals; (3) the acquisition of a foundation for social,emotional, and personal growth through interventions; (4) improvement in the rate of participating studentsdeemed college-ready; (5) improvement in parental involvement in participating students? academicprogression; and (6) the completion of a rigorous study of the Achieve interventions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Age 3 to Grade 3 Reading Proficiency: A Scalable Model for Individualized Interventions Harnessing the Power of AmeriCorps to Deliver Accelerated Results
Project Description: "This project seeks to validate the unique potential for the expandable people power of AmeriCorps -- as demonstrated by the Minnesota Reading Corps (MRC) -- to serve as the vehicle for implementing the use of an individualized data based problem solving model as a proven, effective methodology for helping age 3 to grade 3 children achieve reading proficiency by 3rd grade on a national, unprecedented scale."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Sesame Street World of Words
Project Description: "Sesame Workshop, in collaboration with the University of Michigan and the Educational Development Center, respectfully requests a grant of $19.5 million from the Investing in Innovation Fund for a Validation Grant under Absolute Priority 2 and Competitive Priority 5. We propose to implement Sesame Street World of Words (Sesame Street WOW), a comprehensive 'response to intervention' integrative curriculum and data system targeted to improve and accelerate learning for economically disadvantaged children, in partnership with LEAs in Nashville, TN; Newark, NJ; New York, NY; and Allegheny County, PA.  Sesame Street WOW is designed to increase student achievement utilizing an innovative comprehensive data system and multimedia curriculum resources featuring Sesame Street's research-based content. The program integrates digitally-enabled data assesment and ongoing multilevel monitoring to support differentiated classroom instruction and family engagement, thereby maximizing children's achievement and reduce reading difficulties early on. This program builds on and extends the WOW program, which has demonstrated moderate evidence of impact in several trials, and provides a potent model for closing the achievement gap. We propose to scale Sesame Street WOW to help districts, states, and schools respond tot he new Common Core early literacy standards, using cutting-edge tools and a higly replicable model. Over the proposed five-year period, the Sesame Street WOW project team will reach a total of 5,640 kindergarten and pre-K students in three locales, while conducting independent summative research to assess impact. Beyond the grant period, Sesame Workshop will grow and sustain the program on a national scale to prepare the high-needs students for academic success. By investing in the next generation at the critical time of school entry, we expect to set the nation on a trajectory toward educational competence and future economic growth."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Schol Innovation Program
Grow Your Own Rural Educator - i3 Development Grant
Project Description: "ABSTRACT:The Sevier School District ? on behalf of a coalition of nineteen rural districts, official partner Northwest Evaluation Association and partners Southern Utah University, and Utah Education Network ? submit this $5 million request under the Developmental fund: Absolute Priority #1 Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and School Leaders and all four competitive priorities. The project will benefit about 34,000 students, 1,314 teachers, and 134 schools each year for three-years in a rural area that covers more than 68 percent of acreage in Utah. This includes some of the most impoverished and geographically isolated areas of the state.We are confident the project is in full accordance with the U.S. Department of Education?s design standards and that past practices meet the i3 innovation requirements. This i3 grant will expand a rural ?Grow Your Own? (GYO) model developed by Sevier District that will identify, recruit, develop, place, reward and retain effective and highly effective teachers in 19 adopting districts throughout much of rural Utah. The project will address the critical shortage of quality rural teachers and principals by 1) paying tuition costs for paraeducators to obtain teaching degrees, 2) offering tuition reimbursement for teachers to acquire advanced degrees and endorsements, 3) transitioning academic coaches to principals, 4) offering a teacher induction course to increase retention of new teachers, and 5) using assessments to inform instruction and measureteacher and principal effectiveness.Outcomes: 1) Participating schools will increase the number and percent of effective and highly effective teachers in K-8 reading and K-10 mathematics and language arts by 10 percent each year in years two and three. 2) Those schools will increase the number and percent of effective and highly effective principals by 10 percent each year in years two and three."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Coalition of Utah Rural Education (CURE)
Project Description: "ABSTRACT: Sevier School District - requests on behalf of a coalition of 18 rural districts, two urban elementaryschools and three charter schools - $30 million under Absolute Priority #1 of the Validation category. Theproject will benefit about 37,000 students per year in a rural and metropolitan area that includes about 67percent of Utah (coverage area is 56,785 square miles). This includes some of the most impoverished andgeographically isolated areas of the state.The project is in accordance with required grant standards, and past practices show at least ?moderate? evidenceof validity and efficacy. From 2007-2009 this project increased the percent of effective and highly effectiveteachers in reading from 13 to 54 percent, language arts from 21 to 89 percent, and math from 40 to 90 percent.The following outcomes are expected:1) Further increase the percentage of effective and highly effective teachers and principals, especially in highneedareas and new partner schools2) Improve educational opportunities for at least 37,000 students per year for four years3) Increase student test scores and assessmentsThe project improves educational practices by improving daily instruction, subject collaboration, targetedinterventions, extended learning, professional development, and goal-setting conferences with families. Thisproject uses ?Blended Assessment, an innovation of national interest that allows student evaluation with onecombined test. Blended Assessment uses computer adaptive testing along with fixed form questions tomeasure grade level proficiency and growth. Department of Education approval is anticipated, so the BlendedAssessment will likely replace current CRTs (criterion referenced tests) for project schools.The Sevier School District has extensive experience serving as a lead agency for U.S. Department ofEducation grants. Among recent successful endeavors is a collaborative project that helped teachers in 27rural Utah districts"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: This development project tests the hypothesis that one-to-one mentoring increases disabled participants? self-esteem, personal well-being and ability to stay in school and add to efforts to turn around the effects of persistently low-performing schools.
Sharyland Independent School District Assessment Solution
Project Description: "Sharyland  ISD would like to implement a project that addresses the need for a formative assessemnt process fpr our ELL population. The project  activities will include implementing a state-of-the-art, award-winning formative assessment solution from our i3 partner, CTB/McGraw-Hill, world renowned and well respected publisher.  SISD assessment solution will include on-going professional development to ensure teachers understand using data to drive instruction providing every opportunity for meeting the needs of approximately 9,500 students. The project will also include an intervention math progam  from a well-researched company that will address the foundations skills needed to successfully close the academic gap."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Innovation Through STEM Education
Achievement Equals Access Institute
Project Description: "Siena College requests a development grant from the U.S. Department of Education under the Investing inInnovation (i3) Fund for a new, high potential summer institute to support academic success and to developinterest in college access for rising seventh and eighth graders from Myers Middle School, a local, publicschool in the City School District of Albany, New York serving disadvantaged students. The AchievementEquals Access Institute (AEAI) will be a five week, commuter program modeled after our highly successfulHigher Education Opportunity Program?s (HEOP) pre-freshmen summer program.The AEAI participants will be identified by the middle school administrators: low achieving students, whostruggle in their classes. All AEAI instruction will be student-centered to maximize the students? opportunitiesto develop a sense of mastery of the course content and to develop their oral presentation skills. The summerinstitute students will be provided with developmental instruction in Math (leading to and including Algebra);the Language Arts (including English as a Second Language); and a course in Logic, which is key to theacquisition of all mathematical and critical thinking skills. Non- classroom activities will be done in smallgroups and based on an interactive, problem solving model. Career exploration projects, including resumewriting, and college admissions and financial aid workshops will be offered. These activities will give thestudents a sense of empowerment: they will be able to make choices and decisions and to discuss and toconvince their peers of the same.Success will be measured by student program completion, acceptable passing rating on the New York Statestandard Mathematics and English Language Arts performance tests and verification of pursuit of futurecollege admissions plans."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: One-on-one Online Academic Mentoring for High Need Students
Project Description: "For high school students, getting one-on-one personalized academic help outside the classroom, even at an informal level, is critical to their academic success. But this help is not readily available for high-need students.  Traditionally mentoring has required in-person, face-to-face interactions which are costly and difficult to implement in the frequency desired. Silicon Valley Education Foundation (SVEF) proposes an innovative approach to provide informal one-on-one academic mentoring to under-served students. Students will have online one-on-one real-time assistance from qualified mentors, when and how they want it, without being constrained by location or time of day. This is feasible through a specialized web application platform, built for the needs of high school students and one-on-one learning interactions between trusted connections. SVEF proposes to use volunteer mentors and the platform and services offered by Meemli Inc., whose business is providing online access to quality one-on-one academic mentoring to all students who need it.  The volunteer mentors will also offer students access to role models in various professions and increased interest in college.The program components include developing a network of academic mentors in core subjects, developing software capabilities to accommodate high need/ESL students, providing online communication, monitoring and assessment tools and establishing a sustainable model for widespread long-term use. ."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Silicon Valley STEM Teacher: Effectiveness, Digital Media, Career-Focus
Project Description: "Silicon Valley Education Foundation (SVEF), East Side Union High School District and NBC Learn propose to bring the authenticity of the workplace to high school teachers to support and enrich their instruction and knowledge base in science, math, engineering and technology. SVEF and NBC Learn propose to work with high school teachers in East San Jose to establish agreed measures for STEM teacher effectiveness, to provide support for multiple pedagogical approaches, to build effective and rigorous lessons integrating media that reveals the careers in STEM fields and provides connection to the world of work, to implement STEM lessons in class, to measure and review effectiveness, to monitor and adjust our approach. Teachers will choose the most challenging topics, media from the NBC archive will be integrated in lessons to address those topics. Further, for critical topics, we will use NBC production capability to create new segments bringing Silicon Valley industry and museum resources into the classroom. The scripting and production experience itself will be instructive for teachers and students.  With a focus on 'Backward Design' methodology, teachers will plan curriculum backwards through the online scaffolding we create, with a focus on deeper understanding and assessments.  Our goal is to improve teacher effectiveness by providing teachers with the tools and resources to improve instruction in STEM, which will enable them to encourage more students to become capable of engaging in rewarding and useful STEM careers."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: A Comprehensive Project-Based Learning Model for 21st Century STEM
Project Description: "We believe project-based learning (PBL) holds the potential to dramatically improve student engagement and academic performance in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) subject areas while at the same time fostering 21st century skills.  Despite being at the heart of Silicon Valley, Santa Clara County many students are not taking part in rigorous STEM courses.  Silicon Valley Education Foundation (SVEF) and NBC Learn propose to work closely with teachers to develop a comprehensive model of PBL with necessary supports that will enable all teachers to successfully plan and implement rigorous PBL within any STEM course.  The goal of this work is to increase the prevalence of PBL within STEM courses, and thereby increase the proportion of Silicon Valley students who leave high school college- and career-ready and who choose to pursue careers in STEM related fields.  This comprehensive PBL model includes a synthesis of '21st century standards' essential to college- and career-readiness, practical methods for assessing the attainment of defined 21st century standards within a PBL context, effective tools and methods for teachers to use to assess the academic content knowledge students acquire while engaged in PBL experiences, and effective methods for enhancing PBL with online media resources and modeling and simulation software.  We will develop two interrelated forms of support to increase the chances teachers are able to implement comprehensive PBL successfully.  The first will be a scaffolded online planning environment.  Second, we will encourage and support the development and growth of a community of practice.  We will train 110 teachers over 5 years to become PBL experts."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Fast ForWord: Using Computer Technology and Neuroscience Research to Improve Learning in South Dakota
Project Description: "Neuroscience research conducted over the past 30 years shows that the brain can be retrained through exercises developed specifically to build the cognitive, oral language, and reading skills that struggling students lack.  This project will target 9,360 elementary students and 3,650 high school students whose reading scores are in the lowest quartile.  Many of these students are English Language Learners or Students with Disabilities.  Students will use Scientific Learning's Fast ForWord language products for 6-12 weeks.  Evaluative studies of Fast ForWord, including one approved by the What Works Clearinghouse, show that students who complete a 30-90 minute protocol for 6-12 weeks show a gain of 1-2 years in language development and reading.  Longitudinal studies show these gains continue for years after the students complete the protocol.  Startup cost of the project is about $100 per student."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Starting Strong: Early Childhood Initiative for Children Living in Poverty
Project Description: "Education doesn?t start in kindergarten. Children are born ready to learn and their brains develop with astonishing speed. Brain development is the product of ongoing complex interactions between the environment and the child's active mind. With advancements in science and brain study, documentation of the explosive growth in the brain occurs in the early years and that stimulation acts as a catalyst in the development of the brain. Providing children a nurturing and stimulating environment in the early years enhances their development. This project will provide a high-quality experience each of the five year for 366 three and four-year old children whose families have socio-economic challenges at the Federal poverty level and who reside in the Sioux Falls School District. The project will include classrooms in a school setting and private partnerships with licensed childcare centers."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: The Quest For Excellence Project (QFE)
Project Description: "The SKY U Quest For Excellence (QFE) is a dynamic internal motivation and success skills training program that combines exciting live events, classroom tools, online learning, parent workshops, and professional development for teachers to equip high need elementary school students to excel academically in school and achieve success later in life.With the Quest program, students learn the skills needed to achieve academic excellence by enhancing their motivation, organization, focus, and accountability skills.The SKY U QFE targeted approach integrates 'student supports' into the school model to address non-academic barriers to student achievement.  The 2011 SKY U Quest for Excellence Program will be delivered in partnership with the SKYSHAPERS Foundation and a consortium of 25 New York City public elementary schools with approximately 7500 students in grades 3, 4 and 5 and 250 teachers in 250 classrooms in the South Bronx, New York, one of the poorest communities in the U.S. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title:
ARISE: A Systematic Study of the Physics-Chemistry-Biology High School Science
Course Progression
Project Description: "Most American high school students take biology in grade 9, chemistry in grade 10 and those that remain inscience, physics at grade 11. This outdated sequence is a remnant of early 20th Century science education whenbiology was mainly descriptive. Modern biology is built around a core of a molecular understanding of lifeprocesses and some schools have begun to adopt a new sequence that better fits the new paradigm, that ofphysics-chemistry-biology. The American Renaissance in Science Education (ARISE) claims that adoptingthis sequence (sometimes known as 'Physics First') makes fundamental improvements in the quality of highschool science learning. However little strong evidence exists that confirms this statement. The objective ofthis five-year study is to ascertain whether these claims have any validity. The three partners in this study (theNational Science Resources Center, the Concord Consortium and the East Bay Educational Collaborative) willstudy the impact of implementing an obligatory ARISE sequence in five high schools--urban and rural. Thestudy will compare control (approximately 1500 students) and treated groups (approximately 3000 students) asthey move through the old and new learning progressions. It will provide the schools with laboratory,computer software, and teacher professional development and planning resources to facilitate the study. Thestudy will examine changes in student ability at generating accurate scientific explanations, learning gaps,impact on scores in high-stakes testing, and enrollment in advanced STEM courses. Data will be analyzed bysubgroups including by gender, language, ethnicity and socioeconomic status. Existing courses, tools, andprotocols will be refined to facilitate the project and provide a foundation for scaling the ARISE approachshould its validity be confirmed."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The LASER Model: A Systemic and Sustainable Approach for Achieving High Standards in Science Education
Project Description: "In 1985, the Smithsonian Institution and the National Academies took a bold step and established the National Science Resources Center (NSRC) to assume a leadership role in transforming K-12 science established the National Science Resources Center to assume a leadership role in transforming K-12 science education. To achieve that vision, the NSRC developed a systemic reform model now referred to as Leadership and Assistance for Science Education Reform ? The LASER Model. The purpose is to help district and school-based leadership teams create the infrastructures that are required to support and promote high-quality, inquiry-oriented science instruction in every classroom.The LASER Model is being successfully implemented in hundreds of districts in numerous states (including Alabama, Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Mexico, Rhode Island, and Washington State), impacting tens of thousands of teachers and hundreds of thousands of students. Previous research studies provide at least modest evidence that inquiry-oriented science instruction, supported by research-based materials and professional development, leads to improved student learning?and that LASER has been successful at promoting the state- and district-level supports that make this kind of instruction possible. A Validation grant will allow us to further test and refine the LASER Model in Indiana, North Carolina, and Texas by (a) refining existing research instruments and replication protocols; (b) stress-testing the model in a range of sites, including high-poverty urban and rural schools, that are known to be resistant to change; (c) conducting a rigorous, cross-state evaluation consisting of a carefully-designed, randomized controlled trial complemented by multiple case studies; and, most importantly, (d) gaining a better understanding of the constellation of factors at every level of the system (from the statehouse to the classroom) that will be critical to the success of subsequent national scale-up."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Improving Acquisition of Mathematics (iAM) K-3
Project Description: "The Somerset Academy, Inc. development proposal, Improving Acquisition of Mathematics, Grades K-3 (iAM ) seeks to expand on the success of a promising mathematics program and develop a similar approach for K-3 students. In 2007, Somerset implemented Carnegie Learning, Inc.?s Cognitive Tutor? in their middle and high schools with success and believes that this approach would also be successful at lower grade levels. Somerset will work with Carnegie Learning and use the Cognitive Tutor technology to create a curriculum for young children that successfully impacts early acquisition of mathematics concepts and skills and provides a strong set of formative assessment tools. The project has chosen: Absolute Priority 2: Innovations that Improve the Use of Data, and Competitive Preference 5: Improve Early Learning Outcomes.The overall goal of the project is to ensure that students have the best possible early experience with mathematics and that teachers have the information and tools to make it happen. The intent is to obtain better data earlier and improve use of data and to maximize the impact of instruction. Expected outcomes are: ? Improved performance by K-3 students on the chosen measures? Improved instruction through the use of data-driven decision-making? Greater ability to differentiate based on student needs? More accurate and useful information to share with stakeholdersThe project will develop a Cognitive Tutor program for K-3 students using Carnegie Learning?s development process of formative research and field testing. Teachers will learn to use and implement the program across the Somerset Academy?s system in grades K-3. An outside evaluator will study program effectiveness and participants will share the results through multiple channels. To determine the approach?s effectiveness, a true, group-randomized experimental design will be used to control for most threats to internal validity (Cook & Campbell, 1979; Murray, 1998)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Somerset Academy, Inc.- Development Proposal: Safer Internet for Students
Project Description: "Somerset Academy, a non-profit educational organization serving over 6,700 students in 20 charter schools in south Florida, requests an i3 development grant to help make web and e-learning tools safer for K-12 students through the development of 'Safer Internet for Students' security and identification software for use by schools nationwide.  The software platform will enable safer collaborative online communication between students, teachers, and parents through unique features such as utilizing bio-metrics to positively identify users and capturing and transferring all communications logs to student information system for monitoring and record-keeping.  The software platform has considerable benefits, including exam proctoring, restricting access to inappropriate content, and overall reducing cyber-predation, cyber-bullying, cheating, and other inappropriate online activities occurring in schools. The project is aligned with the U.S. Department of Education's Absolute Priority 3: 'Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments.'"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Cultivating Continuous Collaboration (c3)
Project Description: "The proposed Cultivating Continuous Collaboration(c3)- An Innovative, Data Driven Partnership to Increase Instructional Effectiveness is based upon highly trained teams of teachers collaborating on data warehouse generated reports that integrate teacher practices data with student performance data. Significant success has been realized by one Somerset County site that has optimized teamwork around data driven instructional decision making using hand calculated common assessment scores of students with descriptive recalls of applied teacher strategies and practices preceding the assessment administration. The c3 Project is designed to replicate the innovative model of applying the power of two combined processes (collaboration and data analysis) to the data of two interrelated functions: student performance and teacher practices. The broad components of the project have been identified in Maryland?s 2009 Best Practices research based release, but never woven into a single comprehensive model such as put into practice by the Somerset site over the past two years. The project addresses Absolute Priority #2: Innovations that Improve the Use of Data and places a particular priority on applying findings to high need students? academic growth. The c3 Project, as an innovation in development, will directly impact 2900 Somerset students as well as 12,275 regional partner counties? students and possibly influence instruction of 74,000 students in a dissemination county partnership. The c3 Project has an extremely high probability of significantly influencing many more students and systems through its data warehouse linkage of teacher practices and student performance being developed by c3 Project partner, Performance Matters a national company currently serving 46% of Maryland?s public school systems. The continuing development of the c3 Project promises rigorous practice and high standards for validation and reliability ."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Financial Incentives for Keeping Teens in School
Project Description: "The Development Grant proposed project is designed to address our drop out, graduation, and preschoolers not ?school ready? rates. The facilitation of financial and other resources for pregnant and teen parents will encourage attendance and graduation from high school, followed by enrollment in college, as a means of increasing employment and earnings and reducing welfare dependency. The Program Director, a licensed school social worker, will assist pregnant and teen parents in securing resources needed to allow them to stay in school and graduate. Services provided to children ages birth to three, will improve school readiness of our high-need preschoolers and allow a smooth transition between preschool and kindergarten.Objectives:? Increase potential drop outs staying in school and graduating? Increase number of pregnant and teen parents staying in school and graduating? Increase percentage of students staying on target and graduating on time? Increase number of teens receiving support services? Increase availability of educational programs for children birth to threeOutcome:? Decrease Drop Out Rate? Increase Graduation Rate? Decrease the number of preschoolers entering not ?school ready?"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Aiming High Early Learning Project
Project Description: "Aiming High/Aspirando a lo Mejor is a countywide commitment to close the achievement gap for English learners. There are an estimated 10,250 children 0-5 living in five Sonoma County 'low-performing' school attendance areas. As a group, these schools have a student population comprised of 40-84% English learners and 51-92% eligible for the National School Lunch Program. By implementing the Aiming High Early Learner Project, SCOE and its school and community partners, will address the largely unmet need for children in these school attendance areas to enter Kindergarten 'school ready.'The Project will be based on several innovative strategies that have been implemented by varying degrees and in different contexts but show promising results. These include an education-focused weekly radio show, early outreach to English learner families through school-based play groups and 'jump-start' kindergarten preparation programs, ear-bud telepresence coaching of teachers working with English learners, and the use of graphic organizers to support higher order thinking and language acquisition in grades K-3. The Project will be complemented by United Way of the Wine Country's implementation of a large scale tutoring project. The  i3 grant funding and time period will be used to further develop and coordinate these strategies into a continuum of interventions focused on early learners, birth to grade 3. As the strategies and interventions are refined, project staff will develop methodologies to increase their implementation and bring them to scale. Expected out comes will affiliated and sustainable early learner programs at K-3 schools in the five low-performing school attendance areas; highly trained staff working with English learners birth to grade 3; standardized program strategies and assessment tools; and increased academic achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Closing the Achievement Gap Through Scaling-Up A Successful Title 1 Intervention Program Using a Response to Intervention Model
Project Description: "Soquel Union Elementary School District in Santa Cruz County, California, proposes to utilize the grant funds to develop a model for integrating the various general education, Title 1 and Special Education intervention systems into one seamless and fiscally efficient intervention system. The project is to scale-up its current research-based intervention systems, most notably as implemented at its Title 1 Achieving School, into a unified general/special education Response to Intervention (RtI) systemic change effort. The RtI model closely resembles the excellent Title 1 intervention programs that have been implemented in the general education program.The district has a track record of providing excellent academic intervention systems.  As an academically high achieving small district, with significant populations of English Learners and Socio-Economically Disadvantaged students, but without large state and federal grants, we are in a position to provide a model of how gains in closing the achievement gap can be made with the careful use of limited, realistic resources. "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Beating the Odds: Turning Around a Citywide School System Through a Data-Driven, Mastery-Learning Approach
Project Description: "National City is an impoverished border city in San Diego, California. For 7 years, South Bay Community Services (SBCS) has worked with the city's 2 middle schools to design and implement a research-based academic model, known as the Granger Model. The Granger Model is framed by 4 basic principles: it is directed, timely, targeted, and systematic. The model incorporates weekly formative assessments in all core subjects, immediate, data-driven interventions at multiple levels, and mandatory after-school instruction provided by credentialed teachers and AVID-trained college tutors. The schools have instituted a 6-step folder distribution system that automates referrals to the after-school program and is teacher-friendly, flexible, and productive. The 2 middle schools, previously the worst-performing schools in the district, now have the district's highest attendance rates, have pulled out of Program Improvement and increased their API scores by almost 200 points. SBCS, the Sweetwater Union High School District, and the National School District now propose to develop a citywide initiative that will inspire all children in NC to stay in school, aspire to a college track education, and reach their full potential, by applying age-appropriate components of the intervention model in all 13 public schools in National City (K-12). Primary elements of the project are to institute regular, formative assessments and data-driven academic rigor in all of the schools that will prepare students to be college-ready, show students and their parents the path to attending college or university, and provide support and resources to assure success. Our hypotheses is that students who attend a school that is implementing the Granger after school model will be better prepared for college than students at comparison school sites. SBCS will hire an external evaluator to conduct a rigorous evaluation of the project."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: South Carolina Business Center for Excellence in Education Foundation
Project Title: Personal Pathways to Success
Project Description: "In 2005, the South Carolina state legislature passed the Education and Economic Development Act (EEDA).EEDA is commonly called Personal Pathways to Success (Pathways). A ?development?-level Investing inInnovation (i3) grant will provide resources we need to conduct a rigorous quasi-experimental study ofPathways. Results could more conclusively demonstrate its efficacy. Pathways helps all public school studentsin South Carolina explore career options and develop an education plan that is aligned with their career goals.Pathways helps students focus their career goals and see connections between what they do in school and whatthey hope to do in the world of work when they graduate. Pathways also provides students with firsthandexperiences in authentic work settings. Current evidence supporting the efficacy of Pathways is circumstantial.The South Carolina Chamber of Commerce (?the Chamber?) is leading a consortium of LEAs and nonprofitentities in applying for this grant to enable formal, quasi-experimental research on the Pathways program. Wehypothesize that rigorous scientific research will provide direct evidence that Pathways is causally linked toincreased graduation rates and postsecondary enrollment rates. Pathways serves all (n=250,000) SouthCarolina students in grades 8-12. Partners in this i3 grant effort will include a consortium of twelve LEAs fromacross South Carolina, the state?s twelve Regional Education Centers, and the South Carolina Department ofEducation, and many local businesses."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: South Central Kansas Education Service Center
Project Title: STEM + i3D = Student Achievement
Project Description: "The project proposes to increase STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) learning outcomes for K-12 student population in rural south central Kansas.  The proposed project is expected to be particularly beneficial to two under-represented populations in the STEM fields ? female students and limited English proficient (LEP) students. This development grant will utilize innovative 3-dimensional (3D) technology to create interactive 3D (i3D) learning objects for STEM courses that can be utilized for K-12 students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: South Central Mississippi Consortium for Educational Excellence and Development (SCMCEED)
Project Title: Mississippi Achievement Project (MAP)
Project Description: "The MAP project will implement practices, strategies and technology tools designed to: increase the academic success of under-represented minority and rural student populations as they move from Kindergarten to high school graduation; increase the development and use of unit and lesson plans, formative assessments and  interim assessments that are aligned with high student content and academic achievement standards; and translate standards and information from assessments into classroom practices. The project support Mississippi's efforts to adapt/further develop SundRy Education Inc's AlignedoByoDesign technology system to transition K-12 Math and English Language Arts (ELA) to the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) and track student achievement at the content item level.This project will use an aligned education model supported by advanced technology tools to implement standards-aligned curriculum. The project will demonstrate a systemic process for implementing high quality, standards-aligned taught curriculum using the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) in a 5-school, K-12 feeder system in Hinds County Mississippi. The project involves 152 teachers and administrators and 2,332 students and their parents. The district's goal is to close gaps, increase student achievement and reduce dropout rates of this low performing and impoverished rural district.The project spans four school years and begins with reconciling the Mississippi Standards with the CCSS and building a definitized, sequenced content list with cognitive levels. Year 2 develops and uses standards-aligned curriculum developed from that list. Year 3 implements classroom management of the teaching/learning process and tracks student achievement at the content item level. Year 4 begins a statewide scale up by extending the use of the model and tools to the entire Hinds County School District - 500 teachers and administrators and 6,663 students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Rural School Effectiveness Model (RSEM)
Project Description: The goal of the Rural School Effectiveness Model is to implement a research based?.. Truncated Notes
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Digital Teaching Platforms: Enhancing Teacher and Student Performance
Project Description: "SSAISD, an LEA, is seeking funding for a four year I3 Development Grant addressing Absolute Priority #3 and Competitive Preference Priorities #7 and #8. Through our partner, Rockman et al, we will measure the impact of a rigorous technology-based academic program in core subjects aligned to the Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills Standards (TEKS) and delivered using a teacher-oriented Digital Teaching Platform (DTP). Research and evidence from pilot studies in two Dallas, Texas, area school districts, as well as two years of pilot testing in schools in Israel, indicates that using the innovation enables superior quality teaching and dramatically improves student academic performance.The DTP was developed by our partner Time To Know, Inc. and will cover mathematics, reading/language arts and science in grades 3, 4 and 5. The DTP provides the primary instructional environment in classrooms that are equipped with one-to-one computing. It supports the teacher with digital tools for teaching and learning and standards-aligned content for instruction in technology-intensive classrooms. We will implement the innovation in selected classrooms in SSAISD (2,376 students) and our partner rural district Natalia ISD (528 students) and systematically evaluate the impact of its use on learning. We will focus in particular on LD and LEP students, and through our partner, Natalia ISD, on the special requirements of rural districts.Expected outcomes include: Increased student achievement in Reading/Language Arts, mathematics and science; Greater student engagement; Improvements in teacher behavior and attitude; and a more student centered learning environment."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Beacon mentoring for High School and College Success Program
Project Description: "South Texas College is currently proposing its Beacon Mentoring for High School and College Success Program as an innovative, ?light touch? intervention that was rigorously evaluated and proven to be successful with part-time and developmental students at a predominately Hispanic (95%) community college serving a region characterized by high poverty and low literacy as identified by the Educational Needs Index (ENI). The proposed program will test whether this intervention will be effective when adapted to a high school population that mirrors the previously studied population. Key components of the project will include in-class contacts and case management practices and strategies designed to support efforts to transition to standards and assessments that measure students? progress toward college and career readiness, and increase college going rates. South Texas College will partner with PSJA and La Joya school districts to implement the Beacon Mentoring Program on campuses serving a high number of economically disadvantaged students, which range from 85.79% to 97.21% percent of their respective high school student populations. These same districts serve a significant number of limited English proficient students who represent 15.05% to 23.11% of the high school student population in those districts. The Program design includes purposeful practices, strategies and programs designed to improve academic outcomes, close achievement gaps, and increase college and career readiness, including increasing high school graduation rates for these groups of students who represent a significant percentage of the partner districts high school student population."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Experience School
Project Description: "The Experience School program models next-generation education by creatively blending the following elements: 1) Standards-Based Non-Graded Multi-aged Instruction, 2) Project-Based Learning, 3) Service-Learning and Adventure Education, 4) Innovative Use of Technology, 5) 21st Century Skills Instruction, and 6) Professional Development for Teachers.  An innovative curriculum structure will create pathways to graduation and college-readiness for high-need students. Extended instructional periods at the Experience School allow for individualized instruction, diverse teaching styles and curriculum acceleration/deceleration to fit student needs, and project-based service-learning that meets authentic community needs, supported by technology-based social networking and computer-assisted instruction.  An educational Student Action Plan will be developed for each student, incorporating family and community support network and based on individual educational and developmental needs.  We will contract with local and regional experts in diverse fields to provide in-depth educational experiences for students and to connect students with resources.   The Experience School (ES) will serve high-need and mainstream students in grades 7 and 8.  The program will expand in year 2 and each subsequent year to serve graduates as they move through 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th grade to graduation and beyond.  When students graduate from the Experience School and enter high school, they can continue in the Experience School Program at Bayview School, our district's alternative high school.  In program year 2, one ES teacher will transfer from the Experience School to Bayview to guide ES programming.  The Experience School will continue to serve students in grades 7-8, while providing professional development to district teachers."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: STRADDLE-Student Triumph Requires Abundant Data-Driven Learning Environments
Project Description: "STRADDLE will give the South-Western City School (SWCS) district the resources needed to fulfill its Continuous Improvement Plan (CIP) and increase achievement and graduation rates in our high-need student populations.  SWCS is the 6th largest urban district in Ohio with 12.4% Limited English Proficient, 14.3% Students with Disabilities, 49.7% Economically Disadvantaged. It will move teachers and students into a 21st century learning environment and better prepare students to use the technology they will need in college and work. We will partner with Nationwide Insurance and their Learning Circle program which will include: 1) an Assessment Inventory (AI) that will collect high-quality questions for all grade-level indicators in all academic content areas, 2) software to score and aggregate student data from all assessments & 3) a collection of Resources for Student Intervention (RSI) to meet students 'where they are' and move them towards classes that will allow them to achieve their post-secondary goals.  Extensive research and professional development (PD) will allow SWCS to explore options for using 1-1 computing devices to administer & score assessments by building, grade level, and/or subgroups then access intervention opportunities based on the results. Virtual machines and cloud computing for students will allow tiered intervention at all levels. Ongoing, extensive job-embedded PD will give teachers the support needed to successfully create a data-driven learning environment in their classrooms.  As all Ohio districts are held to the same state standards, this Learning Circle partnership will allow SWCS to provide feedback and PD to other districts interested in this program.  Secondary benefits will include students' ability to access Web 2.0 tools for research, collaboration & communication and an increased ability to keep the students, parents, and community informed & updated electronically."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Southeast Alabama Education Outreach Center, Inc.
Project Title: Innovative, Individualized Instruction for Graduation and Career Planning
Project Description: "We are proposing to create an innovative high school to support the disengaged student population who are in danger of dropping out and not graduating, let alone going to college.  They fit many descriptors:  overage and under credited, bored by the regular classroom setting, need to work to supportr their families, teen parents, aversion to normal high school setting.   These students may be at risk for numerous reasons.We want to start an alternative high school to address the needs of this group of students.  We will call it the i3I Institute which will be housed in a separate facility with its own flexible schedules, exceptional faculty and staff, and flexible attendance policies.  Students will be able to finish their education in a shorter period of time lbut still complete rigorous standards.  Daycare will be available for teen parents.  This school will require student career exploration and planning expedited by the SAEOC Educational Talent Search staff and mentors recruited and identified by the Dothan Area Chamber of Commerce.  Hands on internships and job shadowing activities will be facilitated through the Chamber and mentos.  SStudents can dual enroll whil at the i3I so that they could graduate from high school and enter college as a sophomore.  Flexibile i3I scheduling with 3 daily sessions will provide needed flexibility for students's diverse needs.Students will be expected to complete a ten year career plan and update it regularly as they visit postsecondary education institutions, business sites for internships and shadowing opportunities, and virtual career and college experiences.  Students will develop a portfolio fo their own as well as a portfolio for the 'Wall of Success' to be publicly displayed.  On the wll will be student pictures, assignments, high scores of achievement, lists of accomplishments, pictures with mentors and business people, and their family.  We intend to expect a  'College Going' culture to evolve."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Leaders Engaged in Academic Decisions (LEAD)
Project Description: "The Leaders Engaged in Academic Decisions (LEAD) will improve student success and achievement via enhanced teaching and learning with support for Parents/Community, Teachers and Administrators through the innovative combination of research-based and documented programs as described:- Prichard Committee for Academic Excellence ? 6-Day CIPL Parent Leadership Program with a ?Data Component? (In March, 2010, CIPL was Honored by Harvard's Family Research Project CIPL is listed as 1 of 12 examples of leading innovations in the family involvement field to enhance student achievement in a new report from the National Family, School, and Community Engagement Working Group.)- Using Data Program ? 6-Day Data Institute building data-use capacity in each partner district and contributes information for design, implementation and monitoring for PEPs (Ref below and NSF Evaluation Report)- Facilitated Data Team meetings ? external facilitation is slowly phased out as local capacity is built. (Ref ETnSP and ETnMSP State Reports)- Program Improvement Profiles (PIPs) in SCIENCE/MATH/ELA ? 3 Curriculum Audits/Partner with Full PIP Report and prioritized recommendations contributing data for PEPs. (now used by NSTA and ASCD)- Validation of Improvement Profiles (VIPs) ? leaders confirm and locally validate UDP and PIP findings for use in PEPs- Leadership Support Network (LSN) for Teachers and Administrators provides leadership training for district leadership and builds capacity through enhanced skills as well as to build the next generation of local leaders for sustainability. (Ref PIMSER, UKY)- Partner Enhancement Projects (PEPs) ? Provides funds to Parent Leaders and Education Leaders to target the unique and site-based data-informed professional development and programs. (Ref NSF AMSP)The LEAD staff are confident that other Competitive Priorities will be impacted through this work. For example,in the ETnSP and ETnMSP projects, there have been significant academic gains for S... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Kansas Web-based Evaluation System Project (KSeVALS)
