Project Description: "The Southeast Kansas Education Service Center, in conjunction with Netchemia, LLC, The Center for Learning Tree Institute, and a consortium of 23 rural high-need LEAs in Northeast Kansas present this project to address Absolute Priority 1 and Competitive Priority 8. The Kansas Web-based Evaluation System Project (KS eVALS) will develop a comprehensive evaluation and incentive process utilizing a web-based data management system to efficiently and reliably assess and improve teacher and principal effectiveness. The project is based upon an immediate need in Kansas for a standardized administrator and teacher evaluation system that utilizes research-based best practices as a means for improvement of teacher and principal quality.  The proposed system will be based on the Interstate School Leaders Licensure Consortium (ISLLC) Standards, Interstate New Teacher Assessment and Support Consortium (INTASC) Standards, and the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards (NBPTS)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Recruitment and Retention Solution and Support Network for Northeast Kansas (RRSSNNKS)
Project Description: "The Southeast Kansas Education Service Center, in partnership with The Haberman Educational Foundation; Netchemia, LLC; The University of Kansas; and Pittsburg State University, is applying for an Investing in Innovation Development Grant. This project would be an Absolute Priority 1: Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals and Competitive Preference Priority 8: Innovations that serve schools in rural LEAs.RRSSNNKS will provide school districts approximately four years with the necessary technology, research based tools, professional development, and support to increase teacher quality and lower teacher turnover.  School districts will have access to Netchemia?s SchoolRecruiter program and Haberman?s Start Teacher Evaluation System."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Speech Now: Meeting Speech Therapy Needs Via Online Therapy
Project Description: "Every U.S. public school is required under the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act to provide speechlanguage therapy services to the 4 million eligible children who need these services. Unfortunately, a critical national shortage of speech-language pathologists (SLPs) is preventing schools from meeting this obligation. This has exacerbated the achievement gap between typically developing students and children with identified special needs, especially in our most under-served rural and urban school districts across the country. By integrating web-based video conferencing technology, high quality SLPs and an extensive network of diverse educational settings, our project aims to create the first nationally scalable, evidenced-based solution to reverse these gaps and inequities in speech-language service delivery.We have assembled a national consortium of LEAs from nine different states, all of whom are struggling due to the shortage of SLPs available in their districts, to implement an online speech therapy platform (?telepractice?) as an effective and scalable method for attenuating persistent personnel gaps. Our consortium has created a public-private partnership with Presence TeleCare, an organization that specializes in connecting schools with qualified SLPs via telepractice. The development of our telepractice service is informed by two decades of empirical research, identifying the essential systemic features of a successful web-based intervention format across diverse educational and geographic contexts. Key project activities will include: developing the web platform, recruiting, training and supervising tele-SLPs, providing services via telepractice, and a comprehensive large scale evaluation tracking students? progress longitudinally using a mixed-methods quantitative andqualitative analysis design."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: First Things First
Project Description: "First Things First uses a variety of instructional methods to provide ?blended? job-embedded professionaldeveloped to K-8 math teachers throughout Alaska. Activities address professional learning communities, virtualinstruction with an online learning platform, and on-site coaching. First Things First (1) fosters teacherparticipation in online professional learning communities to improve K-8 math teacher effectiveness; and (2)enhances math skills and provides a focus for the learning communities with access to a customized onlineversion of Carnegie Learning?s K- 8 Math Academies. Expected outcomes will include: (1) enhanced teachercontent knowledge and instructional practices in math; and (2) resulting student achievement gains in math,especially among low-performing, rural Native American students across the state of Alaska. Each component ofthis innovative professional development model has shown promise. Bringing them together creates an exciting,new approach to enhancing and sustaining teacher effectiveness. First Things First will serve 350 K-8 matheducators, benefitting 5,180 students, especially in remote communities. Alaska?s Southeast Regional ResourceCenter (SERRC) is the lead applicant, in partnership with the Klawock LEA. Other Partners are the Alaska StaffDevelopment Network, (ASDN), Alaska Pacific University, 20 LEAs, Carnegie Learning, Inc., and the SchoolImprovement Network PD360."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Connecting Middle School Students to a World in Transition
Project Description: "Connecting Middle School Students to World in Transition is an initiative to address the urgent need in Georgia's middle schools to elevate the instruction and learning experience of social studies.  In 2008 there was an alarming 70-80% failure rate among middle school student in social studies.  This was largely due the new, rigorous Georgia Performance Standard in the subject.  Unfortunately, teachers were not given the resources  nor the materials necessary to teach to these standards.  The Southern Center proposes to take its existing World in Transition multimedia teaching materials, and tailor them to the middle school level where Georgia's need is most urgent.  In this process, these materials will receive any needed updates, and be put into a digital format that is adaptable to a variety of delivery formats and technologies.  Teachers will be introduced to the materials by way of multi-day professional development workshops.  Students will receive individual regional activities worksbooks  that are companion pieces to the teacher's Learning Activities and Assessments teaching materials and video.   This initiative will first be evaluated among the teachers in our Official Partners' school districts.  Any changes deemed necessary will be made and the remaining school districts in Georgia will receive student and teacher materials and professional development training for the teachers."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Integrated Curriculum and Assessment for Mathematics (ICAM) Program
Project Description: "Integrated Curriculum and Assessment for Mathematics (ICAM)The focus of the present proposal is the improvement of math education for pre-algebra and mathematics students in Grades 5 through 8. This i3 Development Grant application is a response to Absolute Priority 3, which requires ?innovations that complement the implementation of high standards and high-quality assessments.? We propose to research and develop a pioneering, high quality, and computer-based mathematics educational program that drives learning with a richly-animated graphics interface and state-of-the-art instantaneous data reporting?features which enhance learning with minimal personnel costs. The program utilizes a standards-based computerized adaptive assessment integrated with a differentiated curriculum program. We call our proposal the Integrated Curriculum and Assessment for Mathematics (ICAM) program.The primary purpose of ICAM is to optimize student mathematics achievement, attainment, and college-readiness in urban minority and rural populations by facilitating a teacher?s ability to provide instruction tailored to the needs of individual students, focusing on high-needs students but applicable to all students. A child entering ICAM receives an engaging and age-appropriate formative assessment followed by richly-animated mathematics intervention targeted to the child?s specific needs. The software for the proposed mathematics program will be implemented from an existing client-server architecture, which is currently being used to deliver early reading curriculum and assessments to over 500,000 students in a variety of learning environments, including urban, suburban, and rural districts. Both the assessment and curriculum will be aligned with the current state achievement standards for Ohio, New Jersey, Texas, and Florida, the standards developed by the National Council of Teachers for Mathematics (NCTM), the Common Core State Standards, and Race to the Top criteria.The proposed proje... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: e-Learning Universe: Integrating Middle School Literacy and Science Instruction Infused with the Arts
Project Description: "Recent attention in education has focused on enhancing the quality of science instruction in our nation?s schools. What has not received as much attention is the reality that low achievement in science is often linked to low performance in literacy. Problems of low literacy and science performance are especially apparent in schools that serve primarily students from low-income families.  Since literacy proficiency in our information driven society largely determines a child?s academic, social, occupational, and health trajectory for the rest of his or her life, it is critical that low literacy be addressed.  Likewise, with increased emphasis on science in the career sector, poor scientific performance reduces a student?s career choices. To address both low science and literacy skills, we propose to build an integrated 8th grade curriculum built within the e-Learning Universe., that links literacy instruction and science instruction using themes derived from 8th grade integrated physical science.  The center piece of e-Learning Universe will be a multi-player virtual environment (MPVE) featuring an epistemic game that students will be able to access both within and outside of school. We will call this game 2060.  It will be based on the premise that Sir Isaac Newton predicted that world will come to an end in 2060. As the year 2060 approaches, the world is faced with increasing earthquakes, weakening magnetism, and dramatic climate change. Students are charged with examining the forces behind these changes in order to design solutions.  As part of the curriculum and game, students will be asked to complete missions to solve problems based on their current understanding of physics. Missions will be competed in collaborative groups, with each member on the mission team having a specific career role on the mission.  To achieve our vision for e-Learning Universe, we have assembled a multidisciplinary team of educational researchers, reading and science experts, curri... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Highland Rural Media Initiative
Project Description: "The Southern Ohio Educational Service Center (ESC) is applying for a five-year i3 development grant on behalf of the five LEAs in Highland County, Ohio; Bright Local Schools, Fairfield Lical Schools, Greenfield Exempted School Village, Hillsboro City  Schools, and Lynchburg-Clay Local Schools.??.Truncated"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: YO NOLA
Project Description: "Southern Rep and New Orleans Charter School KIPP: McDonogh 15, based in the French Quarter district, are joining forces to create an arts and life-skills building program for a diverse population of traditionally under-served youth.  YO NOLA (Youth Onstage New Orleans, LA), to be launched in our 2010/2011 season, will be a theatre company that is run via an after school program for a diverse population of urban youth, ages 8 to 12.  Each YO NOLA Member will serve the company in multiple, rotating rolls, responsible for the running, operating, and creative output of this junior theatre company. Along with daily mentor supervised operations (including meetings with staff, board, and topic specific committees), Members take classes in acting, writing, directing, design, stage management, marketing, fundraising and theatre business management.  Mentors are local and national theatre and business professionals as well as local university graduate students, with visits from special guest artists. Not only are we nurturing future artists and audience members, but Company Members of YO NOLA gain valuable communication and life skills that build self esteem, and invaluable real life tools that can be applied to any path of learning or future employment."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Data Warehouse Predictive Analytics:  LHRIC - IBM - eScholar Partnership
Project Description: "The purpose of this Development Grant is to develop an effective predictive analytics program that will extend the capabilities of the regional data warehouse at the Lower Hudson Regional Information Center (LHRIC) to help 60 pubic school districts in three metropolitan counties north of New York City.  Our partnership will draw on the IBM Business Analytics statistical platform, a best in class suite of tools that will be integrated with the existing regional data warehouse housing over 200,000 student records.  This four year development project will work first on predictors of high school graduation and college success, drawing on data from the New York State data warehouse platform and supplemented by links to local district student information systems that will enhance the data elements available for model development.  In succeeding years, additional models of success at key points in students' lives, such as the transitional year into middle school and then again into high school, and the effectiveness of instructional and intervention programs and services, will be developed.  In addition to the analytics reports, outcomes will include professional development assisting districts to use the resulting data for improved instructional and program planning.  With a focus on English Language Learners, low income students, and students with disabilities, this work builds on 12 years of LHRIC warehouse development.  Beginning with a pilot involving four local districts, the ensuring years will add districts from our own region and provide support for dissemination and scaling of the use of the models among the 12 Regional Information Centers that support data warehousing throughout the State.  With models that accommodate the demographic mix of student and districts in this region, we will produce results that should be scalable to the variety of districts found throughout New York and the nation.  ????"

Project Title: Southfield Public Schools Comprehensive College Support System
Project Description: "The goal of this project is to build a complete, effective, systematic K-12 process to prepare all district students for enrollment and success in institutions of higher education.  Grant funds will provide for the initiation and expansion of programs and high quality assessments that complement innovative programming currently in place in the district.   The program is built on three pillars:  High quality curriculum and standards; high quality assessments; and high quality support services.    There are four major objectives.  1.  Institute new strategies needed for a comprehensive college support system.2.  Expand current strategies to benefit additional students.3.  Increase the percent of students who enroll in, and successfully complete, AP courses.4.  Increase the percent of graduates who enroll in two and four-year colleges."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Where Kids Make History:  A Model for Small School Performance and Accountability with High-Need Urban Students
Project Description: "Southside Family Charter School (SFCS) seeks a 5-year Development Grant to enhance, evaluate and refine its educational program that has demonstrated success with urban high-needs students and disseminate it as a model for small schools (up to 250 students) and programs within larger districts. For nearly 40 years, SFCS has pioneered a program for economically disadvantaged students in grades K-8. Our program combines social justice curriculum, family involvement in school governance and children's education, small class sizes and community engagement that connects students with the real world as learners and as leaders. 	Our program demonstrates distinct promise as a model for high-performing, accountable charter schools. In standardized tests, SFCS students-a majority of whom are low-income students of color-score among the highest and post smaller achievement gaps than elsewhere in the district. A 10-year in-house survey indicated that 93% of SFCS students finished high school and 53% went on to post-secondary schooling.  SFCS partners with Hamline University and other organizations throughout our region and the U.S. to conduct its program. Funding will enable us to achieve three outcomes: document and evaluate program components; document student academic performance (at SFCS and in high school, as well as in post-secondary options graduates choose); and develop and pilot a teaching apprenticeship program to teach others our methods. We will work with an independent evaluator to design and conduct evaluation which will include measuring success in closing achievement gaps, identifying quantifiable indicators of student achievement that go beyond test scores, documenting SFCS graduates' access to college preparatory courses in high school, high school graduation and post-secondary admission."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Leader for Life

Applicant: Southwest Florida Workforce Develpment Board, Inc.
Project Title: Constellations of Innovations
Southwest Licking Project K-Nect Plus
Project Description: "'Southwest Licking Project K-Nect Plus.'  This project requests ~ $2.5M grant funding to validate the successful trials of the mobile learning initiative 'Project K-Nect'.  This investment is offset by a $720k contribution of the Project partners (Qualcomm and Sprint) representing a 26% match from program participants.  This Grant will extend K-Nect services (originally implemented in NC school systems) to a population of 190 (8th through 10th grade) students enrolled in Southwest Licking schools.  It builds upon the original K-Nect model through development of new curriculum resources and strategies targeting special education students.  The project asserts that mobile devices optimized with instructional content will yield positive instructional gains for even its most disadvantaged students.  Development emphasis will focus around the following areas:-   Instant Messaging and Blogs for students with behavioral or social anxiety issues in order to solicit student feedback and collaborative work,-   Interactivities/Multimedia for attention deficit students that make content more interactive and demonstrate cause and effect relationships associated with mathematics,-   Support for individualized learning plans so that IEPs are more fully integrated into curriculum maps for students and for ease of performance data aggregation and reporting. The project will provide for the development of Algebra 1a and Algebra 1b curriculum resources (infused with game based learning strategies) optimized for delivery on 3g enabled smartphones provided to each teacher and student participant.  The instructional intervention includes the appropriate scalable technology tools (mobile devices, wireless broadband internet access, a Mobile Learning Management System, communication, blogging, and instant messaging services), professional services for educators and students, and comprehensive research framework, the blend of which will result in irrefutable evidence as to gains made b"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: South West Kansas English Language Learners--Math Coaching
Project Description: "The Project Title is SWELL-MC (Southwest Kansas English Language Learners-Math Coaches).  We are proposing a Development i3 grant to develop a Kindergarten-12th grade math curriculum that integrates Kansas mathematical standards with ESL instructional techniques including using Thinking Maps (a graphic organizer system) and visualization to increase ESL student math achievement.By creating an easily accessible curriculum and providing in-class coaching to support teachers as they implement the curriculum, we expect ESL students' math scores, as recorded by the yearly Kansas State Assessments, to approximate those of their native English-speaking peers.We anticipate directly working with 18,750 rural Kansas students over the five year grant period."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Southwest New Mexico Regional i3 Demonstration Grant
Project Description: "The Southwest New Mexico consortium consists of five districts: Cobre Consolidated Schools, Deming Public Schools, Hatch Valley Public Schools, Lordsburg Municipal Schools and Truth or Consequences Municipal Schools The consortium represents over 10,000 students and 658 teachers.  The districts are extremely rural and isolated with high percentages of minority and at-risk students and a high mobility rate due to the high proportion of migrant families in the area.  The districts recognize the need to implement an integrated, comprehensive and systematic model for total school reform, whose focus in professional development designed to increase principal and teacher efficacy.  The vision is a tightly coupled system around an aligned guaranteed and viable curriculum, alignment of instruction through the instructional model, development of a system of formative assessments, a standards-based record keeping and grading system, and building background knowledge.  The outcome will be an aligned and consistent curricular and instructional model across the consortium that will have a positive impact on student achievement. The project goals are:  o	Goal 1: To significantly increase the  teaching skills and understanding of the learning process among 658 teachers in five NM districts using the Marzano theory of 'Best Practice', thereby measurably increasing student understanding and academic achievement for 10,550 students.o	Goal 2: To develop a comprehensive data collection and analysis system for districts, schools, educational service agencies and states which will provide administrators and teachers data with which to make sound instructional decisionso	Goal 3: To establish a complex evaluation system focused upon improving the expertise of teachers across the system and providing a clear mechanism for instructional improvement and increased academic achievement among students"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: SWYC Interactive Learning Centers
Project Description: "The Southwest Youth Collaborative (SWYC) is partnering with Gurdon S. Hubbard High School and Gage Park High School and its feeder schools John F. Eberhart Elementary School and Marquette Elementary School respectively, to implement the SWYC School-based Interactive Learning Centers Project. We respectfully request $4,884,497 in Development funding to work with 2100 students under the U. S. Department of Education Office of Innovation and Improvement i3 Grant Program. The purpose of this collaboration is to improve student achievement and academic performance by way of innovative practices for student matriculation to secondary and post-secondary educational and career options.Our primary program goals, objectives and activities focus on enhancing technology innovation usage in the classroom that impact student academic success in the following 6 areas: 1) Academic Enrichment and Support, 2) Continuing Education and Awareness, 3) Career Exposure and Interest and Professional Development, 4) Parent Support and Involvement, 5) Community and Civic Service, and 6) Cultural Competency and Awareness. Our expected outcomes include:o	Increase school attendance by 3%o	Incremental grade improvements over three yearso	Increase college enrollment to post-secondary institutions by 80%o	Increase post-secondary preparedness by increasing FAFSA completion rates to 85% and college application completion rates to 85%.The following documentation will be used to collect base-line and comparison data for the duration of the grant period:o	Grade report reviewso	Individual Assessments for IEPso	Pre/Post tests for workshopso	Consumer surveys regarding need-to-service match and effectivenesso	College Acceptance letterso	FAFSA completiono	Class promotion and graduation rates."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: K-12 Creative Collections
Project Description: "The K-12 Creative Mobile Media Collections validation grant project proposes innovations in the creation, alignment, and dissemination of open education resources (OER), specifically Mobile Education Media, that support the effective practice of teachers (Absolute Priority 1) and validates the effect use of these resources for increasing student achievement.     Co-applicants to this proposal include 10 state education agencies and their corresponding Local Education Agencies (LEAs), Higher Education Institutions (IHE), and non-profit organizations. Corporate sponsors include Apple, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (PBS), and State Educational Directors Association (SETDA).     Activities include: (1) working with Marzano Research and RMC Research to validate the impact of teacher-created, teacher-aligned mobile media impact on student achievement in and beyond the classroom. 2) Extending eTech Ohio's mobile media content repository to provide creative space for a growing national education repository to easily align existing rich educational media (REM) in support repositories (i.e., Apple's iTunes U, PBS Digital Learning Library, and YouTube) to common core and STEM standards in order to support the continuity of learning beyond the traditional school day and year. (3) Expand the Virginia Mobile Learning Apps Development Challenge for teacher-developed in 10 states that uses 'micro-awards' for the development of 10,000 mobile media assets and applications to close gaps in content coverage determined by an in-depth analysis of open education resource repositories currently available. (4) Enhance the comprehensive professional development programs in participating states to train 15,000 teachers on how to properly create and use REM to increase student achievement, which will generate an additional 30,000 education media assets. ?????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: WHES Success Model
Project Description: "The proposed grant will replicate the WHES Success Model of teacher and principal effectiveness for all other Title I schools in the district to increase student achievmeent for all students but especially for high-need students.  Activities will include professional development for principals and teachers, strategies to improve student achievement, and a plan for creating a principal and teacher incentive plan to reward professionals who might meet high levels of expecations.  Objectives will include increasing the number of effective teachers, increasing principal effectiveness, increasing student achievement for high-need students, and an equitable plan for compensating and rewarding teachers, principals, and school support staff when high expectations are met by all member of the school community."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: The Compact Connection
Project Description: "The COMPACT CONNECTION is a Validation grant aimed at 1) increasing high school graduation rates and 2) increasing college enrollment and completion rates. Inspired by the visionary Spartanburg County Compact: College Degree Obtainment in Spartanburg County South Carolina, the overall objective of this grant is to increase the percentage of Spartanburg County students graduating from high school, entering college, and obtaining a baccalaureate degree. The COMPACT CONNECTION seeks to achieve this objective by enacting initiatives that improve college awareness and preparatory strategies throughout the educational system, increasing student competencies as they navigate the college selection process, and providing ?bridge? scholarships for identified students. Each of these strategies is empirically based and paired with measurable benchmarks and expected outcomes in order to ensure effectiveness.Although the entire program described herein truly has the potential to transform the entire county, this grant immediately targets an estimated 25,000 students, a group comprised of all of Spartanburg County?s middle school and high school students and college freshmen and sophomores. The grant takes up where programs in place for children from birth through sixth grade leave off, building on the extant momentum of those efforts and providing a crucial piece to the ?birth through 16? conduit. The long term effects of this grant will be a consequential rise in the mean educational level of residents of Spartanburg County, resulting in more 21st century jobs, decreased poverty, improved public health outcomes, and numerous other important tangential benefits.This proposal represents a partnership between all seven of the county?s public school districts, the county?s five colleges and universities, and many of the area?s private schools, businesses, foundations, and governmental entities."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Making Minneapolis a Mecca for Great Educators/Great Schools
Project Description: "Working closely with community and national partners, Minneapolis Public Schools (MPS) aims to dramatically raise achievement by making Minneapolis a magnet for great educators dedicated to building significant numbers of high-performing new public schools.  Great schools begin with great leaders and great teachers.  MPS will deploy i3 and matching private support to develop a world-class pipeline of carefully vetted teams of school builders who will open and operate the next generation of life-transforming, gap-closing MPS schools. MPS embraces U.S. Secretary of Education Arne Duncan's i3 vision to expand the use of innovative and evidence-based practices, programs and strategies that significantly improve K-12 achievement and close existing achievement gaps.   Learning from recent work led by New Schools New Orleans and 'Portfolio Districts' nationwide, MPS will focus its i3 efforts on creating an innovative and evidence-based new schools talent pipeline that recruits, trains, and supports outstanding school builders.With the support of i3, MPS and its partners will aggressively and systematically recruit school builders from local, regional and national talent pools, with the goal of assembling full teams of leaders - school heads, boards, mid-level leaders and teachers - prepared to launch K-12 schools based on proven models.   "

Applicant: Sponsored Programs, The Regents of the University of California (University of California, Davis)
Project Title:
Creating a Blueprint for History and Social Science Education:
Advancing Instruction, Assessment, Student Learning and Engagement
Project Description: "The California History-Social Science Project  (CHSSP), in partnership with the Library of Congress, SRI International, and a consortium of schools from the Long Beach, Oakland, Mount Diablo, Santa Ana, Orange, ACCESS, and Saddleback Unified School Districts, seeks an Investing in Innovation (I3) Development grant to implement a program entitled Creating a Blueprint for History and Social Science Education: Advancing Instruction, Assessment, Student Learning and Engagement.  This program will will address I3's absolute Priority Three-innovations that complement the implementation of high standards and high-quality assessments-- and a competitive preference priority:   students with limited English proficiency.  We are undertaking this dynamic program of curriculum enhancement and alternative assessment to offer realistic, scalable, and sustainable innovation which will inform public policy at the national levels.The Blueprint project aims to design a state-of-the-art program for teaching history in California that can serve as a model for national innovation.   The Blueprint proposal has three goals: to increase student achievement and engagement in history-social science; to improve student academic literacy and critical thinking in order to address the achievement gap; and to provide formative and summative data on student content knowledge, critical thinking, reading and writing.  In order to achieve these goals, the program contains four components: a comprehensive 4-12 standards-based curriculum for History-Social Science, a discipline-specific approach to student literacy development, innovative online assessment tools, and professional development for teachers.	Over the five years of the grant period, the Blueprint team will serve 220 teachers, teaching approximately 22,000 students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: "Linking teacher Evaluation, Professional Development, and Effective Classroom Instruction as a United Front to Address the Reading Achievement Gap"
Project Description: "This project includes implementing an intentional strategy of collaboratively engaging three essential teacher processes that have potential to increase student learning and achievement: teacher evaluation, professional development, and effective classroom instruction.  The activities of the project include: an extensive teacher and principal study and implementation of danileson's (2007) Enhancing Professional Practice: a Framework for Teaching; partnering with the local university to support teacher portfolio development to use as a growth/reflection tool and as a part of a meritorious compensation system for teachers; providing rigorous professional development for teachers and principals on reading practices to address the reading gaps among Affrican American and Low Income students; and creating a coaching model that connects reading professional development to classroom practice through the use of classroom walkthroughs.  The proposed project framework objectives include: (1) increasing teacher and principal effectiveness by focusing professional goal setting, on-going reflection, and evaluations on student learning needs; (2) developing focused teacher professional development that is based upon teacher professional goals and student needs and directly connected to the focus of classroom instruction; (3) improving classroom  instruction by creating an on-going process of examining the implementation of professional learning daily in classroom instruction using classroom walkthroughs; (4) evaluating effectiveness of professional development and classroom instruction using the school's teacher evaluation system, which is based on the Danielson (2007) framework and the schol's research-based focus areas (literacy, numeracy, multiage education, and professional development)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Reading Success by 4th Grade Initiative
Project Description: "Springfield Public Schools (SPS) in Springfield, Massachusetts, proposes a development grant to demonstratethe effectiveness of the Reading Success by 4th Grade Initiative (RS4G), an early literacy learning system.RS4G?s objectives are to align early childhood literacy strategies from birth to age 8, increase the number ofhighly-effective teachers in Pre-K through grade 3, implement a research-based curriculum in Pre-K, increasekindergarten readiness, and increase reading proficiency by the end of grade 3. From birth to 3, RS4G willteach pre-literacy development strategies to family care providers. The outcome will be an enriched orallanguage environment and an increase in child pre-literacy skills. This component will serve approximately250-450 children. Within preschool and K-3, RS4G?s strategy is to increase the number of highly-effectiveteachers who are Instructional Leadership Specialists (ILSs), who must demonstrate their ability to positivelyimpact student growth and other teachers whom they have coached. RS4G will expand the ILS model,currently used in K-12, into the preschool level, both in SPS Pre-K classrooms and in the city?s privatepreschools which educate most of the 3-4 year olds in the city. ILSs/coaches will provide literacy developmentto the other teachers, and all Pre-K classrooms will implement a scientifically-based literacy curriculum. Theoutcomes will be increased teacher effectiveness in literacy instruction, increased student growth in Pre-K, andimproved readiness for kindergarten. Approximately 1460 Pre-K children will be served. Within grades K-3,continued coaching and redesigned literacy instruction will increase teacher effectiveness, student literacygrowth, and levels of reading proficiency. Approximately 400 K-3 students will benefit."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Evidentiary-based Classroom Assessment Systems for Teams (eCAST)
Project Description: "This project is a collaborative effort between a consortium of thirteen Oregon school districts, four research groups associated with the College of Education at the University of Oregon, the University of Washington?s Center for Educational Leadership, and the Oregon Business Council. The primary goal of this project is to develop and implement a classroom-based assessment system fully articulated from grades six through twelve and anchored to college and career readiness standards. The system would incorporate evidentiary-based design principles and would be utilized to inform instructional and curricular decisions as students move toward becoming college and career ready and toward graduation. The ultimate student level outcome would be increased achievement across multiple measures to include grades, statewide assessments, and various assessments linked directly to college and career readiness. The project design will allow the following outcomes to be achieved: Alignment of core outcomes within an assessment framework to college and career readiness standards; the design and use of an evidentiary-based assessment system designed to measure proficiency specific to the aligned outcomes; the merger of multiple measures of student progress (academic skills, academic achievement, academic behavior, etc) into a comprehensive college and career readiness data warehouse complete with specific reporting tools; the focus on proficiency-based instructional practices to include the use of intervention strategies and structures at the student, classroom, building and district levels; the implementation of a regionalized network of secondary schools, supported by the various centers focused on assessment driven, proficiency-based practices; and the movement of districts and buildings toward secondary structures providing for teaming, intervention, and embedded collaboration."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Capital College Preparatory Academy
Project Description: "Springfield School District 186, serving the city of Springfield, Illinois, will open the Capital College PreparatoryAcademy in September 2010 to the first cohort of sixth grade students. Each year, the Capital Academy willenroll a new cohort of 120 students?60 females and 60 males?who will remain in the program through highschool graduation. The Capital Academy aims to graduate 100 percent of its students from high school andcollege. This unique program provides students with a rigorous, college-preparatory educational program,coupled with comprehensive student supports, designed to prepare all students for success in college, work,and life in the 21st century. Intermediate outcomes include annual academic improvement in core subjects forall students; increased ACT scores; and increased number of students that successfully complete advancedplacement courses."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: SunBay Mathematics: Advancing High Standards Through Integration of Technology, Curriculum, and Professional Development
Project Description: "SRI International and its partners will validate and scale the SunBay Mathematics program to tackle the criticalchallenge of Algebra for high-need students in Florida. SunBay Mathematics will emerge from this validationprogram with integrated research-based solutions for urgent local and national needs to dramatically improvemathematics education. We will enable Florida schools to (1) transition to classroom practices that enable allstudents to succeed with high standards, with most students taking Algebra I in the 8th grade, and (2) employvalue-added models of teacher effectiveness that identify teaching practices that maximize the impact ofinnovations. SunBay Mathematics integrates technology-based dynamic representations that deepen learningin standards-based curriculum units and provides necessary teacher professional development. Theeffectiveness of the SunBay Mathematics system has been established in randomized experiments conductedin over 100 schools and in a recent Florida replication. Project activities include establishing a St. PetersburgOperations Center for scale-up efforts; deploying an infrastructure for distribution, coordination, andmonitoring; tailoring materials to fit Florida?s evolving high standards and high-quality assessments;developing local trainers and coaches; and providing university-based program certification of school-basedmathematics leaders. Dr. Larry Hedges of Northwestern University, a respected educational statistician, willevaluate two validation questions: (1) What student outcomes can Florida schools that adopt SunBayMathematics expect? (2) What instructional practices and policies should Florida schools emphasize in orderto shape the development of a mathematics teacher workforce that can use innovative materials to raise studentachievement to higher standards?This project will build the capacity needed to scale SunBay Mathematics to over 100,000 students and 780teachers in Florida within 5 years."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Differentiated Accountability Specialists Helping Educate Students (DASHES)
Project Description: "Based on the demonstrated success that St. Johns County School District (SJCSD) has in using disaggregated data to differentiate instruction for the most needy students, the SJCSD plans on bringing to a district-wide scale the innovative best practices that it has demonstrated in the Title I schools that have piloted a successful model of using data to direct teachers' instruction. In partnership with the private sector, state and local legislators, and the philanthropic non-profit community, the SJCSD will use the Investing in Innovation funds to better position its Title I schools to serve as models for best practices throughout the rest of the district and potentially the entire State of Florida. The model will create a seamless integration on how to use progress monitoring, the Florida Continuous Improvement Model (FCIM), Positive Behavior Supports (PBS), and Response to Intervention (RtI) to serve the challenging needs of subgroups not making Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP) while also preparing students for college and career placement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: St. Clair County Educational Cooperative Board (dba St. Clair County Regional Office of Education)
Project Title: Leteracy Excellence for All Pupils (LEAP)
Project Description: "Literacy Excellence for All Pupils  (LEAP) Leap is project to improve student reading scores throughout St. Clair County, IL (approximately 45,000 students).  The program design involves specific activities at three levels.Early Childhood:  Aligin Illinois Early Childhood standards with the Common Core Standards; providing professional development for pre-school teachers and day care workers in literacy instruction, Social Emotional Learning (SEL) and Response to Intervention (RTI).Elementary:  Provide professional development for classroom teachers in small group instruction, RTI/differentiated instruction, and Universal Design of Learning (UDL) strategies.  Provide literacy materials to each elementary building (109 buildings).  Align local curiculums to Common Core Standards; develop lessons and assessments to be posted on LEAP website.  Provide at least one literacy coach per district (23 districts).  Provide professional development for principals to enhance their evaluation skills regarding literacy instruction.  Two community college level courses addressing literacy instruction for teachers aides will be developed and implemented.Middle & High School:  Continued alignment of local curriculum to Common Core Standards along with lessons and assessments to be posted on LEAP website will occur. Develop a for-credit English course to help students achieve satisfactory scores on college placement exams.  Provide districts (7 districts) with a .25 FTE to teach this prep class.  Support students with disabilities in transitioning to high education and careers.  Provide professional development for principals to enhance their evaluation skills regarding literacy instruction.By the end of this project, every grade level across the county will have high effective teachers delivering literacy instruction to meet the needs of our diverse student population along with effective principals to evaluate this process."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Minnesota Educational Digital Instruction Utilization Movement
Project Description: "The MEDIUM Project Goal is to provide students one-to-one mobile computing devices, online learning environments, and capacity building for teachers/administrators that offers students opportunities for experiential, inquiry-based, highly engaging learning (based on Minnesota Academic Standards in Science) that effectively advances student academic progress in science as measured by reliable and validated science assessments.The hypothesis for the program is that the combination of the one-to-one iPad mobile computing, in conjunction with student and teacher participation in an online, collaborative learning environment, with access to Web and digital tools, will result in increased levels of engagement (cognitive, social-emotional, and behavioral), increased complexity and authenticity of learning, shifts in teacher instructional style toward coaching or inquiry, and increased levels of collaboration, will result in higher achievement and critical thinking in science - leading to college and career readiness and STEM preparedness."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Personalized Learning and Data-based Decision-Making: Redesigning Schools using an Response to Intervention Framework
Project Description: "Schools have embraced Response to Intervention (RtI) to identify at-risk students, monitor progress, provideevidence-based interventions, and as part of the entitlement process for Specific Learning Disabilities. The St.Croix River Education District (SCRED) is applying for an I3 development grant to focus on data-baseddecision-making within an RtI framework with its? official partner ServeMN and other partners TIES andCenter for Learning Solutions. SCRED has utilized an RtI framework for 15 years, and in 2007 received a 2-year allocation from the state legislature to form a statewide RtI Center to scale-up effective practices. Theproposed project seeks to expand and continue the work of the RtI Center. Through coaching and high-qualityprofessional development, this project will assist PreK-Secondary educators in the effective use of universalscreening and progress monitoring in basic skill areas, creating multi-tiered system of instructional supports,and utilizing a problem-solving model of decision-making. The goal is to improve student achievementthrough quality professional development and coaching around data-based decision-making and to close theachievment gap between students with disabilities and their typical peers. Coaching will be provided todistricts using a web-based format to increase the participation of rural schools and decrease travel costs fordistricts. Students and teachers will partner to create personalized learning plans and monitor progress towardgoals. Expected outcomes include (a) 390,000 students served, (b) increased teacher and principal proficiencyin databased decision-making, and (c) increase in student achievement for all students, including student withdisabilities and ELL populations."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Moving to College Success: Whole School Reform at Sacramento Charter High School
Project Description: "The Investing in Innovations Project - St. HOPE i3 Project sponsored by St. HOPE Public Schools will expandSacramento Charter High School?s whole school reform model by developing a series of well coordinatedservices that close the achievement gap by increasing grade level proficiency, high school graduation and collegeadmission and attendance rates of high need students.Summary of Project and Expected Outcomes:St. HOPE i3 Project?s objectives, activities, services and outcomes align with student grade levels and overallgoal of the project. Two thousand (2000) high need students and others (over the life of this grant) will participatein services that will encourage students to meet or surpass the California Standardize Tests requirements,complete the A-G California College Course Pattern, gain rigorous course experience through the expansion ofAP classes and Economic/ Financial Literacy coursework, develop leadership skills, acquire effective studentdevelopment skills, and actively participate in college counseling sessions and activities. To facilitate effectiveimplementation, the project will focus on professional development to ensure that teachers and project staff usethe most effective methods to instruct and work with high need students. In addition, St. HOPE?s i3 Projectlooks to increase active parent and community member participation in the school community to ensure greaterprogress towards reaching the school?s goals.The outcomes include 80% of students: improve grade level proficiency on state standardized tests; improveknowledge and skills in Algebra, English and Science courses resulting in raised GPAs; proficient on the Mathand English portions of the CAHSEE (California High School Exit Exam). In addition, outcomes focus onincreasing AP enrollment by 60%; increase AP course offerings by 2 subject areas each year; addEconomic/Financial Literacy course for grades 9-12 and facilitate two teacher trainings on student skillsdevelopme... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Project DASIE: Developing and Supporting Innovative Educators
Project Description: "Project DASIE is aimed at the professional growth of teachers by preparing them to utilize data to inform instruction and differentiate instructional strategies to enhance existing programs resulting in improved achievement of LD and ESL students in grades K-5. The project will be conducted over a three year period. Teachers' participation will afford them an on campus graduate course. Furthermore, supportive supervision in the form of coaching will be provided to the principals to facilitate the alignment of their classroom observations with the instructional strategies introduced to their teachers. The project will include: a) an ongoing series of classroom demonstrations offered by university faculty in ELA and ESL based on the data from pre-tests; b) ongoing teacher focus groups networked across the schools to enable the teachers to share lessons, experiences and insights; and, c) an opportunity to bring students, teachers and parents to the university to participate in demonstration lessons modeling the strategies and co-taught by faculty and classroom teachers to enable parents to learn techniques that will provide reinforcement at home."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: St. Landry Virtual School
Project Description: "St. Landry Virtual SchoolThe goal of the St. Landry Virtual School (VS) Project is to develop and disseminate an innovative, comprehensive strategy to increase the academic achievement of at-risk and impoverished rural students of the district. The project objectives will be accomplished through learner-centered technology, using virtual-based engaged learning techniques to immerse students in their studies. Through engaged, experiential, and self-directed learning methodologies supplemented by advanced interactive technologies, VS students will be empowered and will be provided opportunities to bridge knowledge and meet their personal achievement goals. Whether struggling to get back on an age-appropriate track or enrolling in advanced studies in preparation for college, the St. Landry VS will provide technology-based innovative experiences to enhance student success. The St. Landry Parish School District will collaborate with partner entities, such as the International Academy of Science and the Louisiana State University (LSU) Gordon A. Cain Center for Scientific, Technological, Engineering and Mathematical Literacy, technology providers, and community organizations to implement the project, providing innovative opportunities for success to the high need, at risk students of the rural school district. The project will have the following, wide-reaching educational and environmental benefits: advanced engaged learning methodologies and technologies will be implemented; VS students will become self-directed, lifelong learners; the VS will export an innovative model of educational excellence and cooperation; an extensive framework will be implemented to increase at risk and impoverished student motivation for learning through student-centered, engaged learning; and a comprehensive virtual program will be introduced into the district."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: St. Mary Parish School Board - See E3 and E4 of the i3 FAQs
Project Title: I3: Innovative Teachers, Leaders, and Tools
Project Description: ".  The project, i3: Effective Teachers, Leaders, and Tools, combines 21st century tools of TetraData? and Fast ForWord? with the Teacher Advancement Program (TAP) model for building teacher and leader effectiveness providing a comprehensive plan to increase student achievement and close achievement gaps. The project partners the Follett Software Company, Scientific Learning Corporation, Louisiana Department of Education, and the National Institute of Excellence in Teaching with the St. Mary Parish School Board. The development grant utilizes the Teacher Advancement Program (TAP) to increase teacher and leader capacity through high quality professional development. Collegial coaching, a component of the TAP model has been shown to be of the most effective means to improve practice that leads to student learning. Teachers and leaders follow a TAP rubric and receive performance-based pay for student learning.  Teachers are equipped with 21st century tools for data analyzation (TetraData?) and student intervention (Fast ForWord?), both of which have demonstrated usefulness in increasing academic achievement for students in the district. Project evaluation includes monitoring for fidelity of TetraData?, and Fast ForWord? use as well as TAP implementation. Annual evaluation seeks to report the increase in teacher effectiveness as evidenced by observations of teacher practice, by increases in teacher perceptions of the effectiveness of PD they receive, and by the increase in student achievement and narrowing of achievement gaps for the two-thousand, one-hundred, fifty-five students in the project.  Combining the TAP model with proven 21st century tools presents an innovative project to ensuring student achievement growth in the rural public school district."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: College Access for Everyone
Project Description: "Stereotype Theat has been identified by researchers as a likely explanation why minority students performance often falls behind majority students' performance. Stereotype Threat occurs when students who belong to a group feel as though they may perform poorly, thus confirming the stereotype about their group. It is theorized that the fear of confiming the stereotype causes the students to perform at a lower level. This project will combat stereotype threat by holding weekly sessions at lunchtime to remind students of their strengths and abilities. The lunchtime sessions will focus on getting Junior and Senior high school students ready for college, teaching them the skills they need, when they need them. By continuously helping students plan for college, they are receiving affirmations, which have been shown by researchers, even when only provided once per semester, to dramatically increase student performance. There are thousands of  college access programs across the U.S., however, this new design should vastly increase the success of the programs. This program has a two year curriculum that will serve Juniors and Seniors. We have searched, but not found anything similar. This program teaches students the skills they need at the exact time when they need them. They learn about and practice college interviews just before they have interviews, for example. Other programs may be drop-in, may be off-site, or may pull students out of other classes. CAFE will also work with Freshmen and Sophomore in their English classes with a focus on teaching them about the benefits of a college education and convincing them that it is important for them to take the most challenging classes possible. Partners will work with the program to remove the barriers that keep students from pursuing a college degree. BECA will raise $30,000 for scholarships, and will also provide a Common Scholarship Application. Booz Allen Hamilton will contribute $6000 and much employee time."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Passport to Success Program for High School Aged Foster and Congregate Care Youth.
Project Description: "St. Vincent?s Services, Inc. is requesting a Development Grant through the USDOE I3 Grants Program to support activities affiliated with our project entitled The Passport to Success Program for High School Aged Foster and Congregate Care Youth. The Passport to Success (PTS) program is designed to ?close the achievement gap? for adolescents in foster care through the provision of appropriate educational and mental health assessments and interventions. Grant activities will include intake Education and Mental Health assessments; the creation of a Student Academic Plan (SAP); Academic Interventions (after-school tutoring, standardized test prep, and interactive educational software combined with in-class activities); Mental Health interventions (individual and group therapy); College Bound Mentoring; Job Club employment/internship activities; and a Parent Component. Our target number of students to be served includes 100 youth in Year One, 200 youth in Year Two, and 1,950 youth in Year Three.We anticipate the following positive outcomes: increases in academic achievement; gains of 3-5 credits toward graduation requirements; an increase in self-assessment of academic skills and potential; compliance with Mental Health treatment plans; a 50% reduction in school suspensions; a 50% decrease in lateral moves (i.e., moving from one Group Home to another or moving from one Foster Boarding Home to another); increase in Average Daily Attendance at school from a current average of 80% to an average of 85%; and 100% of participating youth will receive exposure to college/career readiness activities.Our official partners are Susan E. Wagner High School and Port Richmond High School (both on Staten Island, NY). Other partners include our Academic Services Partner, Brienza?s Academic Advantage."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title:
The Project GOT-iT (Goal Oriented Teens in Teams)/DATA (Data Analyzing Teachers for
Achievement) program
Project Description: "The overall goal of Project GOT-iT/DATA is to increase student success and achievement. High school studentsin five high schools will use an interactive online credit-recovery program. Teams of ten high school studentsfrom each high school will also develop a mentoring program for 100 elementary school students. In addition,teacher teams in two elementary and five high schools, for a total of 70 annually, will analyze data fromstudent-centered computer programs and develop instructional units to improve learning for all high-needstudents. Also, all the high school teachers will use PSAT data to improve instruction.The project objectives and outcomes include the following: 1.) teacher teams will analyze student achievementdata and develop effective instructional units, 2.) high school students will get back on-track to graduate byparticipating in a credit-recovery program, and teams of these students will implement an elementarymentoring program, 3.) elementary students will participate in a mentoring program, 4.) elementary studentswill improve their reading and math scores, 5.) high school students will improve SAT scores, and 6.) thegraduation rate will improve.A Development Grant award of one million, seven hundred thousand dollars over three years is being requestedfrom the Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Grant Program (USDOE). Approximately 15,000 students ingrades K-3 and high school will benefit. Considering the unique challenges of our school system andcommunity, this funding would give us the best chance of increasing student success and closing theachievement gap."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: California Reading Improvement Network-CalRIN
Project Description: "Description for the California Reading Improvement Network (CalRIN) -  i3 Validation Grant	The purpose of CalRIN is to establish and validate a statewide regionalized system of training and support focused on providing effective web-enabled, research-proven reading instruction that is guided by the use of student performance data. The State's existing high-speed network will provide access for rural and urban schools to an online reading program selected because it addresses the needs and criteria established for CalRIN.  The project will use model demonstration sites in each region combined with training for teachers using a tiered training-of-trainers model whereby selected regional education agencies in the north, central, and south will train regional and district level model program site leaders to facilitate local adoptions of both the web-based reading system and use of student data to inform online instruction. The needs assessment justified the selection of Absolute Priority #2, innovation that improves the use of data, and Competitive Preference Priorities, #5, improving early student learning, # 7, innovations to support unique learning needs, and #8, innovations that serve schools in rural areas. The expected outcome is that student mastery of reading will increase as a result of their participation in a data-driven, web-enabled, reading system facilitated by teachers and supported by administrators who are in turn trained and supported by CalRIN. The targeted number of grades K-3 students follows: Year 1=4,000, Year 2 = 51,380, Year 3 = 72,480, Year 4 = 79,500. Special features of the project include: expansion of the role of regional service agencies, instruction delivered over the Internet, and combining data informed instructional practice with a web enabled, research-based reading program. Partners include: Stanislaus, Los Angeles, and Sacramento County Offices of Education."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Stanly Arts Community
Project Description: "Stanly Arts Community will contribute to achievement because it will make school a more enjoyable place;   students will develop a positive attitude toward learning and become more engaged.  Students who are connected to school are more likely to make better grades, graduate from high school and thus, be better prepared to enter the workforce or post-secondary institution of higher learning.  Instruction through the arts (Instrumental Music, Vocal/Handbells, Visual Arts and Theatre Arts) may be uniquely effective in raising the achievement of at-risk learners because it enables students to express themselves, to do real work for real audiences, and as a result, students put their hearts and souls into learning.	The objective(s) of SAC is to close achievement gaps, increase graduation rates, and increase the percent of at-risk students taking college level coursework by providing students opportunities to express themselves through the performing arts.  The project will provide an equitable pathway for students in a rural setting such as Stanly County to develop talents in the areas of the arts.  The project will be implemented over a five-year timeframe and have the capacity to impact every student in our system.       Organizations and institutions supporting this grant proposal are Stanly Community College, Pfeiffer University and Stanly County Arts Council.  ?????"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: I Want to Go/Went to College in High School
Project Description: "Stark County Educational Service Center (SCESC) for 17 school districts (high school population 19,754) in partnership with 6 local colleges and six colleges (Stark State College of Technology, Walsh University, Mount Union College, Malone University, Kent State Stark University and Akron University) propose a Developmental i3 Grant for five years,  to address Absolute Priority 3--Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments  by our early college innovations ? Canton City Schools Early College (CCSECHS) and  Stark County High School Based Dual Credit ( SCHSBDC.  We also address Competitive Preference Priority 6-Innovations that Support College Access and Success.  Our quasi-experimental study will test the reasonable hypothesis suggested in the research by Adelman (2006) , Swanson (2008) , and Karp (2007)  that our promising early college credit innovations?CCSECHS with 1,000 enrollments and SCHSBDC with 2,350 enrollments will increase college access, persistence and success for low income, minority, and/or first generation college going students in Stark County, Ohio.Our objectives:  Growing CCSECHS from 250 students to full capacity of 400 and increasing SCHSBDC enrollments from 2,350 to around 10,000 over the grant period; and designing a comprehensive data system tracking student high school and college outcomes. Our strategies: to increase the number of high school teachers who qualify as college adjunct professors; to improve the quality of supports by counselors, teachers, tutors, mentors and other adults by designing and implementing instructional modules; to design data feedback loops for high school and college staff; and to institute the Student Tracker system. We have a large population, and are developing capacity to track each student through four years of college. We?re moving toward our goal of ?Becoming the best educated county in the country.?"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Using Learning Progressions to Facilitate Middle School Science Teaching and Learning: A Development Project
Project Description: "Over the past three years, the Strategic Education Research Partnership (SERP) has worked in partnership withthe San Francisco Unified School District (SFUSD) to address a pervasive problem in middle school scienceeducation: instruction which is a 'mile wide and an inch deep.' The need to cover the broad range of statescience standards led the district away from the inquiry instruction of an earlier era, toward traditionaltextbooks that provide a roadmap through the standard's content. In partnership with the nationally recognizedBerkeley Evaluation and Assessment Research (BEAR) Center directed by Professor Mark Wilson at UCBerkeley, and with Stanford University Professor Jonathan Osborne, the SERP-SFUSD team proposes to: a)identify the four core concepts that are of greatest importance to the area of science covered in each of themiddle grades; b) construct learning progressions that chart typical student thinking about each concept,ranging from the most naive understanding to the scientifically accurate; c) develop and validate assessmentsthat teachers can use in the classroom to understand where students' thinking falls along the progression, and tochart their learning as instruction progresses; and d) develop instructional supports for teachers aimed atmoving students to higher levels of the progress map through carefully designed classroom discourse."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Word Generation for the Next Generation of English Speakers: An English Language Learner Program Development Project
Project Description: "Middle-grades ELLs working to become proficient English speakers need intensive, efficient instruction to bring them to grade-level reading skills before they fall disastrously behind age-mates in content knowledge.  States and school districts need supported access to high-quality materials that are research based, aligned with appropriate high standards, and flexible enough to use in the heterogeneous environments of ELL classrooms.  This project will develop and test new approaches to making academic language accessible to ELLs; in doing so it will provide a source of evidence and a bank of research-based and reality-checked resources in a field where both are scarce.  To accomplish this, we will adapt Word Generation, a widely used evidence-based academic language program developed in a partnership with Boston Public Schools by SERP Institute with Catherine Snow of Harvard University, so that it meets the unique needs of the targeted ELL population. The project work model will follow SERP's co-developer approach with researchers and educational professionals working closely to create the materials using an iterative R&D process.  Project participants will include senior researchers, teachers, administrators, SERP staff with experience in developing effective curricular materials, and leaders in ELL standards and assessments. The adapted program will engage middle school teachers across the content areas in teaching academic vocabulary to ELL students through a highly motivating, language rich program. Our committed district partners in Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey, Wisconsin and Missouri will select the middle schools that we will work with.  Another official partner on the project is the Harvard Graduate School of Education. The adapted classroom and professional development materials will be freely available via the www.serpinstitute.org/wordgeneration website along with a description of the independent evaluation results documenting program effects."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: School Transformation through StrengthBuilding
Project Description: "StrengthBuilding Partners (SBP) proposes to work in partnership with an LEA and the University of Arizona - Southwest Institute for Research on Woman (UA-SIROW) to create a sustainable transformation of  low performing schools into schools which are performing or higher. The strategy that will be used to accomplish this goal is StrengthBuilding? Training and Coaching (SBTC). Based on related research in education and other sectors, SBTC is an innovative practice that builds and sustains a firm foundation and strategy for success in which the entire school community (teachers, administrators, staff, students and families) is trained and has on-going coaching in StrengthBuilding (SB). SBP has provided SBTC in Tucson schools with encouraging documented results. SBTC, as the foundation for School Transformation, is designed to be customized to each unique site/district. The power of change lies in the restructuring and reculturing of school communities into a StrengthBuilding environment where students can and do achieve.The three high schools of The Chicanos Por La Causa Community Schools (CPLCC)  (official partner), each of which has a School Improvement Plan under NCLB, are our initial experimental schools being matched with three control schools. There will be a total of 10 schools in the project. Although the focus will be on schools serving a specified demographic associated with greatest risk of poor student achievement and dropout, the model will include a variety of school cultures to demonstrate the replication potential.  The research design for this project will be a mixed methods approach. It is expected that by the end of the project a total of 1,145 students will have had at least two years of schooling in which their education was driven by SB. Sustainability is embedded in all aspects of the project and it is expected that by year three of this project, SBP will be providing SBTC to schools outside the project design."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Reading Proficiency for all Student Subgroups
Project Description: "The project is based on the model that Strong Foundations Charter School has used to achieve its high percentage of reading proficiency for students with disabilities, students at risk, and typical learners. 1,125 students in grades K-5 from two rural schools (825 students) and one urban school (300 students) in need of improvement in reading for two years or more will be served. The hypothesis of the study is that, regardless of demographics, between 80% and 90% of the student population will read proficiently in grades K-5 when an Orton-Gillingham approach  is used consistently with all students for three years. Data will be collected by subgroup using three different meaures to determine the effect of the intervention among subgroups.The study is experimental using a carefully matched comparison group.All staff in the partner schools (regular and special education teachers, and paraprofessionals) working in grades K through 5 will be trained in the structure of the English language and how to teach it using the Orton-Gillingham (O.G.) approach. All students will receive O.G. instruction. All staff will have a consistent body of knowledge about the English language and a framework for teaching it effectively in their instructional context. Observations and conferences with mentors will help to ensure fidelity of implementation. The project will begin developing teacher leaders and trainers in each school by month 20. This will promote sustainability by providing a way to train and mentor newly hired staff. Planning for scale-up will incorporate technology and online resources to provide ease of access to resources teachers can use for review and classroom teaching."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Raising Student Acheivement Through Project SUCCESS
Project Description: N/A

Project Title: Project Rigor
Project Description: "Success Charter Network (SCN) has developed an innovative school model that independent research has shown increases student achievement by 13-20%.
