SCN's Project Rigor seeks to expand its program to 19 schools educating over 6,600 students over the next 5 years and to 40 schools serving over 20,000 students over the next 10 years. Each school will be opened in a community serving high-need students in New York City and will prepare its scholars to be college and career-ready.SCN will achieve this goal through its innovative school design and its strategic growth plan. SCN has developed a unprecedented school model that combines rigorous standards, whole child curriculum, yearly targets, on-going assessments that inform instruction, a professional learning environment where teachers are held accountable, robust performance management system, a revolutionary approach to principal and teacher training, and a blended instructional environment that leverages technology. Its strategic growth plan allows SCN to expand while never taking its eye off quality. The tenets of its strategy include its laser-like focus on becoming self-sustaining by 2017 and its unparalleled investment and focus to get the model right upfront. 	While SCN needs the initial upfront investment provided through this grant to fund the scaling of Project Rigor, each year its funding request is a smaller percentage of the total project cost as its student enrollment, and therefore its per pupil revenues, increases.  At the conclusion of the grant, SCN will be able to continue operating its existing schools and opening additional schools solely on its per pupil funding and without any additional federal grant funding."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Success for All Interactive: Development and Evaluation of a Comprehensive Multimedia Approach to Early Reading
Project Description: "We propose to develop and evaluate Success for All Interactive, adding multimedia content on interactive whiteboards to the proven Curiosity Corner (Pre-K) and KinderCorner (K) programs and revising Reading Roots Interactive (1). The embedded multimedia will include brief video content, including puppet skits, animations, and live action, as well as pictures, words, and other content related to developmentally appropriate themes and objectives. It will use content from the award-winning PBS series Between the Lions, as well as much original material. Development and piloting will take place in collaboration with partners in five states (TX, LA, KY, AK, WY). A 3-year cluster randomized experiment will evaluate program outcomes from Pre-K to first grade."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Cooperative Middle School: Turning Around Struggling Middle Schools
Project Description: "We propose to develop and evaluate The Cooperative Middle School, a turnaround model for struggling middle schools. Proven cooperative learning methods will be implemented throughout the school, and we will emphasize a schoolwide norm of responsibility of all students for each other. Further, we will develop motivating, fast-paced lessons in math, English, and reading to ensure high-quality, exciting instruction every day. These will include interactive whiteboards, electronic response devices, and extensive video. A cluster randomized experiment will evaluate program outcomes."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Cooperative Learning and Multimedia: Accelerating Learing of Grade 3-5 Mathematics
Project Description: "We propose to develop and evaluate PowerTeaching Math, an approach to mathematics instruction in grades 3-5. PowerTeaching Math will use cooperative learning, embedded multimedia on interactive whiteboards, and electronic response devices to ensure high-quality, exciting instruction every day. A cluster randomized experiment will evaluate program outcomes."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Scale-Up and Evaluation of Success for All in Struggling Elementary Schools
Project Description: "Success for All is an extensively evaluated whole-school turnaround model for elementary schools. In partnership with several school districts, we propose to substantially scale up Success for All to serve many more students by creating local coaching support centers in high-poverty districts. We will provide credits to qualifying schools to help them with first-year costs, a key barrier to scale-up. An independent evaluator will carry out a large-scale, 4-year cluster randomized evaluation of Success for All. Objectives and Outcomes:1.	Expand Success for All to approximately 1100 additional elementary schools. 2.	Create a sustainable, LEA-managed network of qualified coaches. 3.	Improve the availability of high-quality coaching for SFA and greatly reduce its cost.4.	Commission a large third-party, cluster randomized evaluation of Success for All in high-poverty elementary schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Leading for Solutions/SECURe Intervention Program
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Camp Success
Project Description: "In order to reduce students that are labeled  'risk factors', and or high needs and promote student achievement and social success, we are seeking funds from the i3 Validation Grant to implement our locally developed ?Camp Success? Project. If funded, this grant will allow us to offer up to 2700 students in Northeast Ohio an extended school day/year 'menu' of expanded 'learning opportunities' in a safe, drug free environment which will support and encourage their efforts to improve their academic achievement and enhance their physical, mental, and social well being. ?Camp Success? will provide ?extended day/year? programs/services daily, after school, on Saturdays, and during the summer. Success Images-The Program Inc..and Camp Tech Inc. two successful enrichment programs with proven track records that have help increased graduation rates and successfully help next grade promotion join together with New Visions Unlimited, PSW Consulting (IPATHTM) partners with East High School and Euclid High school to offer an holistic organic approach to helping youth 6-18 to succeed through our collaborative project efforts of ?Camp Success?.Camp Success expected outcomes:?	Increased graduation rates and next grade promotion?	Develop self-management techniques?	Engage students with life skills to apply knowledge to solve problems?	Decrease at risk youth to becoming risk free individuals?	Development of emotional  regularity abilityCamp Success objectives are for students to become active learners and doers who take responsibility to complete projects. They learn to handle long, complex tasks and manage their time. They are assessed on their skill in working in teams and creating products such as presentations, designs, plays, short stories, and prototypes. Students acquire not only subject-matter knowledge, but also the skills they need to thrive in college, career and life.Camp Success facilitates a process for teachers to transform themselves into project-based coa... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title:
Data Assessment Resource Tool (DART): a Web-based Student Assessment System for
Rural School Communities
Project Description: "Through this Development grant, the project will create the Data Assessment Resource Tool (DART), a webbasedstudent assessment system and provide professional development training on utilizing the DART systemand utilizing assessment data to increase student achievement in rural school communities. The DARTproject is specifically designed to address the unique learning needs of students with disabilities or limitedEnglish proficiency and the project will facilitate the evaluation, analysis, and use of student assessment databy educators to inform data-driven decision-making. Evaluation data will be reviewed monthly to driveprogram improvement, and will be used for continuous program improvement even after the term of the grant.This will be accomplished through a partnership of SuccessLink, MORENet, Missouri ASCD, Bright Tree,and a consortium of Missouri school districts, and will involve collaboration with representatives from theMissouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education and the School Counseling Department of theUniversity of Missouri at Columbia.Through DART, educators will be provided a unique way to access and analyze data to drive instruction. Theproject will include a portal for student-teacher interaction through questionnaires, a student record-keepingsystem, strategies to reduce paperwork, and data visualization tools that provide a whole child overview of theindividual student. As a result, educators will be able to better identify and target the needs of students, assessstudent outcomes on a wider variety of variables, improve communication between faculty and staff, andreduce duplication of effort in collecting and analyzing data. The project will include a beta-test, pilot, andefficacy trial of the program. Participating educators will also provide feedback for improvement of thesystem. The final goal of the DART project will be to demonstrate increased student achievement in ruralschool districts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Connections and Transitions to Learning
Project Description: "Students at Sugar Creek Charter School, grades 1-8, have many of the social demographics associated with poverty and school failure including: 99.9% are members of an ethnic minority group; 81% qualify for free/reduced lunch; 65% live in a single parent home or with someone other than a biological parent; 18% of our parents did not graduate from high school; 12% are identified exceptional; and 9% qualify for onsite county mental health services.  We currently serve 615 students in grades K-8.  The North Tryon corridor, which is the community where the school is located, is a neighborhood in flux.  It has been primarily commercial, (our school is a renovated Kmart) but is part of a city plan for revitalization which includes a transfer station for the new Light Rail system. Due to a holistic approach to education and a unique feature of instruction where students are assigned to reading and mathematics classes according to content mastery level, not age or grade level placement, SCCS has been able to make progress from a low performing school to meeting AYP in 2007. Our goal is to become a 90-90-90 school - a school that has a 90% minority population, 90% free/reduced lunch and yet 90% of its students are achieving at or above grade level. In order to reach this goal, the school administration has determined that not only does it need to continue what it is doing, but to multiply the beneficial effects of its instructional model by offering extensive after school and summer programs. Titled Connections and Transitions to Learning, our project will serve 200 students grades K-8 during the first year, with a yearly increase of 20% to reach over 400 students by year 5 of the project. The project will be administered by the school leadership in partnership with Urban Restoration, a collaboration of twelve outreach programs devoted to serving some of Charlotte's poorest and most at-risk citizen.?????"

Project Title: Kaleidoscope: Transforming Teaching for Math Success
Project Description: "This $5 million project will improve student achievement in mathematics by pairing the latest tools in instructional technology with the highest-need schools in Sumner County, the seventh largest district in Tennessee. The project will provide resources to over 350 teachers, to help meet the needs of over 11,000 students in 18 targeted schools. The research-based technology chosen for this grant proposal is proven to enhance the quality and effectiveness of learning for all students and to encourage a variety of instructional approaches by the teacher. Kaleidoscope will provide auditory, visual and kinesthetic support to meet the needs of diverse learners, including ELL and special needs students. The overall project will be supported by a broad plan of self-sustaining district-wide professional development that builds a community of experts and ensures continued success beyond the scope of this funding.GOALS AND OBJECTIVES:1)	Install interactive whiteboards, response systems, audio enhancement, document cameras, calculators, and desktop computers in 350+ classrooms.  2)Using a ?train-the-trainers? approach to professional development, establish a district-wide core team of experts, certified in the appropriate audio-visual technology and proficient in delivering best practices math instruction.  The core team will train teachers in each of the 16 targeted schools via job-embedded collaboration, hands-on workshops, professional learning communities, and on-line resources. SPECIAL FEATURES1)Distance Learning ?the latest in two-way video-conferencing equipment will be installed into ten district high schools and a location at the Board of Education. This will give students access to college-level and advanced placement courses not currently available in each individual school. In addition, this resource may also be used to deliver professional development to improve teacher effectiveness.2)Resources for English Language Learners/special needs ? an interac... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Instructional Improvement Systems
Project Description: "It is the desire of the applicant to implement a comprehensive instructional improvement system linked to the current assessment system based on clearly-defined performance measures. The instructional improvement system will be used to assess student performance on expectations for student learning, identify gaps between expectations for student learning and student performance, evaluate the effectiveness of curriculum and instruction, and determine interventions to improve student performance. The instructional improvement system will yield timely and accurate information that is meaningful and useful to system and school leaders, teachers, and other stakeholders in understanding student performance, system and school effectiveness, and the results of improvement efforts."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Little Cities As  A Classroom
Project Description: "Sunday Creek Associates, in partnership with two rural LEA?s in Ohio, will plan and implement a sustainable Place-Based, Learning for Public Purpose (PBPP) curriculum in each district?s middle and high school.  The project will span 5 years and involve at least 650 students, of which 20%  have special needs.   LCAC will improve achievement via rigorous and relevant instruction and assessments; increase enrollment in college and career prep programs; and increase student motivation by connecting students with relevant knowledge about, and hands-on improvement of, the remnant mining communities and national forest lands that make up the Little Cities microregion.   LCAC will recruit and match teachers to community resources; be driven by curriculum alignment and community improvement; and build school and community capacity for PBPP learning.  Common spaces in the community for exhibits, programs and joint projects with local organizations and higher education will strengthen community and parental support.  High quality professional development and a disciplined commitment to specific time limited support contracts will contribute to PBPP sustainability."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project Graduation: the Digital Advantage Phase II
Project Description: "Project Graduation ? the Digital Advantage Phase 2 (DAP2) will be implemented over a three year period. This will involve extending the scope of the project from 1,232 students to 11,680 students across a wider range of grades 5th ? 12th. SUSD will continue to build upon their already successful program DAP that has shown to improve student achievement, graduation rates, promotion, attendance, and reduce dropout rates. SUSD will explicitly focus on student achievement to improve Mathematics and Language Arts scores, increase college entry rates, through the development of DAP2 and the expansion of DAP1 in these areas: Freshman Academies with extended learning opportunities, web-based instruction, 1:1 computing for all 9th graders, and a flexible and innovative school week which allows for one day of service learning within the SUSD community. Developing these education goals will be an innovative technology strand including i) widening the scope of 1:1 computing and online learning grades 5 through 12, ii) delivering RM?s transformational Learning Platform for all students, staff and parents providing web 3.0 collaboration tools, Individual Learning Plans (ILPs), ePortfolios and Assessment services; and iii) initiate a highly structured, data management, change management and PD program to improve teacher technology proficiency and fundamentally transform teaching and learning."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: GETGO: Growing Educators Through Growing Outreach
Project Description: "Susquehanna County is located in rural Pennsylvania with nearly half of the children under the age of five living in low income families.  Pennsylvania's latest Reach and Risk Report identifies children in Susquehanna County as moderate to high risk for school failure.  To address that problem, Susquehanna County Literacy/CARES, a 501-c-3, is partnering with three school districts in order to create GETGO (Growing Educators Through Growing Outreach)By working with Blue Ridge School District, Forest City School District, and Susquehanna Community School District, teacher-family-child connections will be strengthened, enhancing school success.  It is the mission of Literacy/CARES to advance quality early education and literacy in Susquehanna County. The GETGO model includes developing teacher home visits for children in Pre-K through 3rd grade, hiring Parent Partners to act as liaisons between the teacher, family, and schools, and installing observation classrooms by using audio/visual equipment and monitors.The goal is to help at-risk students achieve academically, socially, and economically while also connecting with families.  Surveys and reports by an independent grant evaluator will help determine GETGO's impact."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Changing Overrepresentation of Minorities in Special Education to Success in Challenging Courses
Project Description: "We have been successful in dramatically reducing the number of students identified with disabilities, including a disproportionality of Native American students, and have increased the number of students in academically rigorous classes and activities, increased the number of students graduating, and decreased behavior issues.  Gathering and analyzing data highly effective teachers will use data-driven teaching strategies and 21st century technology to demonstrate our project objectives and expected outcomes that determine student academic and social success and decreases the need for special education services for at-risk students.  We hypothesize that schools with an over representation of ethnic diverse students identified for special education services can decrease the special education population and enroll more students in academically rigorous classes where students use 21st century skills through early and continuous progress monitoring, data analysis, and data-driven interventions in a technology-rich environment."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: WNCEdNET IMPACT
Project Description: "The IMPACT model is a tool that helps administrators, teachers and students work together to plan and build effective, comprehensive teaching and learning environments for the 21st century. It supports student achievement, motivation and involvement. Throughout the model's implementation, teachers are surrounded by a support team that includes a technology facilitator (licensed teacher with instructional technology certification,) media coordinator, computer technician, and media assistant. This team ensures all teachers and students receive educational and technical support as well as materials and equipment needed to provide a high quality education.  The purpose of this proposal is to further develop the IMPACT Model for public schools in Western North Carolina which include the counties of Haywood, Jackson, Swain, Clay, Macon, Graham, Cherokee and the Cherokee Central Reservation Schools. Based on the needs of the school system, funds will be allocated in a variety of ways. These include professional development, equipment and personnel. A major goal of the proposal is for each school to become independent and self sustaining."

Project Title: Sweetwater Union High School District--Investing in Innovation Development Grant
Project Description: "Sweetwater's Hybrid Online Class (S.H.O.C) model is designed with student engagement in mind. Students quickly grow tired of traditional drill and kill online classes. SHOC is designed to engage and motivate students through all of the learning modalities; reading, listening, speaking, and writing. This program encourages higher order thinking skills because interactivity is built into the program. The progression of the grant over a five year period will allow the Sweetwater District to systematically develop and pilot classes so as to evaluate and modify components and test for their effectiveness. This approach will result in methodologies for the development of future on-line classes whose effectiveness has been determined.The Sweetwater District intends to serve a minimum of 500 students per year, for a total of 2,500 students reached over the five-year grant period.In partnership with Revolution, a software company, and Houghton Mifflin, an education services company, the district will offer online courses for academic credit for the first time in its history."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Sweetwater Union High School District--Investing in Innovation Development Grant
Project Description: "Located in the urban corridor between the city of San Diego and the international border with Mexico, theSweetwater Union High School District is California's largest secondary school district and one of its mostdiverse. The Sweetwater District serves 42,000 students in grades 7 through 12 in 24 schools.     Sweetwater's Investing in Innovation Development Grant seeks to increase the percentage of studentsqualified for postsecondary success by developing a coherent and aligned secondary curriculum. Sweetwaterseeks to expand three pilot programs that have shown statistically significant increases in student achievement ondistrict and state assessments. By year three of the grant, 800 district teachers will be trained in the RhetoricalApproach, 580 teachers will be trained in Structured English Immersion pedagogy, 750 core content teachers willbe trained in Quality Teaching for English Learners (QTEL) and 450 district teachers will be trained in inclusionstrategies for special education students.    Objective 1: Explicitly teach and assess the Rhetorical Approach across the curriculum by implementing acommon set of essential skills aligned to college entrance requirements. The District's innovative Curriculum,Instruction and Assessment (CIA) teams will serve as the foundation for implentation of all grant activities.    Objective 2: Increase student engagement in rigorous, standards-based learning activities by providingrelevant, real-world classroom experiences in the core curriculum.    Objective 3: Implement and monitor a systematic approach to master learning of content standards thatdifferentiates curriculum and instruction based upon student needs.    Through program activities the Sweetwater District will address Absolute Priority #3 and CompetitivePreference Priorities #6 and #7.    More than 50,000 students over 3 years will be changed by these reforms."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Swope Out-of-School Time Project
Project Description: "Swope provides high quality academic programs for low-income families in the urban core of Kansas City, Missouri and Kansas City, Kansas. By significantly increasing the hours of core learning instruction through both after school and summer programs for 700 students at two chronically low-performing elementary schools in Kansas City, Missouri, Swope plans to turn around these schools academically over the next three years, if it receives a development grant.In addition to academics, Swope plans to balance these out-of-school programs with music, art, and dance, and other enhancement activities. Currently only 25% of students are proficient in reading or math in the two low-performing schools. Swope has as its expected outcome to have these schools reach a level where 80% of the students are proficient in reading and math.In addition to the effort by Swope, the Institute of Urban Education at University of Missouri Kansas City will provide professional development training for all the staff at these schools. Some special features of our model are that we operate out of churches, we have our own fleet of buses, we use hundreds of one-on-one reading tutors, and have many community stakeholders involved."

Project Title: Team College Bound Deans of Student Services and Educational Planners Extended Day
Project Description: "Tacoma Public Schools proposes a promising intervention program to motivate and prepare students for graduation and postsecondary education.  A Dean of Student Services will coordinate services for targeted students with outside providers and school staff to support students at risk of failing or dropping out. Interventions such as extended days, enrichment events, college visits, tutoring, home visits, and collaborating partners/programs will keep students engaged in school, close achievement/skills gaps, and prepare students for college and career readiness.    Number of students to be served:  1,500 (7,500 over five years)    Special project features:  A three tier model of intervention identifies students' needs and provides appropriate staffing and resources to assist students to get the focused help they require. An extended day model offers compelling enrichment activities such as college visits, cultural activities, tutoring, and guest speakers to broaden student experiences/skills."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: College and Career Counseling Collaborative: The 4C Project
Project Description: "The 4C Project will engage a Persistently Low Performing high school, a Rural and Low Income high school and a high performing high school to develop an innovative approach for serving high-need students and returning drop out students. The districts will create a 4-member College and Career Counseling Collaborative (4C) team among the three districts. This counseling team will receive technical assistance from Education Service Center Region XIII (RESC XIII) to develop a new model for secondary counseling that is aligned with the College and Career Readiness Standards as well as the American School Counselor Association National Model for School Counseling Programs. By working with the three schools, RESC XIII will develop a 'Counselor Coach' professional development model which will be disseminated through the Southern Regional Education Board Enhanced Network of High Schools That Work (HSTW) at the state and national levels. Expected outcomes are tied to improved academic achievement, reduced dropout, college and career readiness, and college success.The unique design of the 4C Project is its counselor-based connections to student's needs as the basis for designing programs. Students participating in the 4C Project will complete a series of assessments of academic and non-academic needs that will serve as the basis for students' individualized plans for graduation and beyond. Students will not be limited to a set of existing programs. Rather, the 4C College and Career Counselors will design an academic program specifically to meet each student's needs, using all of the resources of the three districts and the IHE partners and finding new partners as needed.Evaluation will be completed by Edvance, which operates the Regional Education Lab, Southwest. Community partners have committed match that is approximately 80% of the grant request; state and federally funded partners will contribute approximately 40% of the grant."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Classroom 10: 21ST Century Curriculum for 21st Century Learners
Project Description: "Classroom 10: 21st Century Curriculum for 21st Century LearnersDevelopment GrantToday?s schools do not prepare students with the life skills they need to operate successfully in the globalcommunity. Commercially available curriculum focus on content standards but do not help students developthe thinking skills and ?habits of mind? needed during their lifetime. The Tahoma School District near Seattle,WA has developed a ?Classroom 10? curricular model that uses standards-aligned content to develop literacyskills, thinking skills, habits of mind, and workplace outcomes. Students who have these skills and habits arebetter prepared for college and the workforce. Students in elementary and middle schools that haveimplemented this curricular model have achieved remarkable success. The project will help Tahoma expandthe available curricular materials in language arts and social studies into the high school grades and begindeveloping science materials. Teachers and administrators will receive training so they can use their materialseffectively. New assessment tools will be developed to measure student and staff progress in learningClassroom 10 concepts. A pilot program with a local university will provide pre-service training that is alignedwith Classroom 10 concepts. Leaders will be trained in systems thinking so they can operate more effectivelywithin a learning organization. The model will be replicated in eight schools in Hawaii to see if the newcurriculum has the desired impact in schools with higher levels of low income and ELL students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Leadership Develoopment through Systems Thinking for Sustainability
Project Description: "Using content and pedagogical tools and the theories of Systems Thinking (ST), and Education for Sustainability(EfS) that have been developed and applied for close to two decades in diverse localities, this three-yearproject is designed to move innovative practices from periphery to mainstream, enabling more school leaders ?teachers and administrators -- in diverse settings to learn and work together in service of creating the types ofschools and learning our children and young adults deserve to prepare for a sustainable future that will requireradically different educational approaches than those of the past.With the mission of creating ?learning communities? within a national learning infrastructure, our plan will buildand reinforce new knowledge and leadership capacities at multiple local and state levels: among teachers andstudents: principals, administrators, and school board members; and the larger body of stakeholders withincommunities.C"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Facilitating Long-Term Improvements in Graduation and Higher Education for Tomorrow
Project Description: "Take Stock In Children, a 501(c)(3) non-profit with 15 years of success in narrowing educational attainment gaps for low-income, mostly minority students in Florida, will officially partner with three LEAs (Broward, Monroe, and Highlands Counties) to create FLIGHT: Facilitating Long-Term Improvements in Graduation and Higher Education for Tomorrow.We will address Absolute Priority 2 and Competitive Priorities 6, 7, and 8 as we pursue our goals to: 1) Increase utilization of student data by school/district partners and stakeholders to identify high-need students and implement timely interventions to increase their academic success; 2) Increase the high school graduation rate for low-income and minority students; 3) Increase college access and success for low-income and minority students.  Project Activities:  Student Advocates embedded in schools willmonitor participating students? academic and behavioral records through a data platform integrating state, district, and school-level information to ensure timely interventions for high-need students. This innovative early warning system will provide real-time student data to all key stakeholders. At-risk student participants will receive wraparound supports including ongoing, intensive academic and behavioral monitoring, case management, in-school community-based mentoring, and individualized interventions; College Enrollment and Retention Specialists will provide postsecondary preparation, transition services, and support during the first three college semesters. Each participating student is guaranteed a four-year college scholarship provided by our network of corporate, business, and private donors.  Outcomes:  FLIGHT will enhance data utility for program monitoring; improve academic and behavioral student outcomes; improve postsecondary matriculation; and reduce college remediation.Other partners are the State University System of Florida, the Florida Prepaid College Foundation, and the Florida DOE."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: i3e3: Exceptional Educational Engagement
Project Description: "For four years the Talladega County Schools have made significant progress in improving student achievement levels through the utilization of school reform and restructuring measures, proactive response to student data analysis, and intense targeted professional development. Bold measures in selection of key instructional leaders in low performing schools, quality teacher performance incentives, and strategic professional development have been essential to the progress.  These measures have been closely aligned with the goal of preparing students for the 21st Century with digital age skills for highly desirable success as high school graduates.  To accomplish this, much research and stakeholder planning have resulted in one of the LEA's schools being reformed into a 21st Century 1:1 computer:student project-based learning initiative. This initiative has encompassed all of the 'bold measures' of the LEA into a highly effective learning and instructional model.  The LEA and its partners propose utilize i3 funding to expand this into the other 16 schools in the LEA and work with other LEAs throughout the state and region that are planning to utilize the model components of this successful initiative.  The project will support the expansion of the model learning initiative and highly desirable professional development strategies by reaching 8000 students and 450 educators annually in the LEA.  The existing school model for 1:1 computer:student and related professional development that utilize 21st Century technology for teachers and students, has been showcased to over 600 people from other LEAs throughout the southeast.  The proposed project will fund appropriate levels of quality technology tools in 364 classrooms for digital age 21st Century learning and teaching in rural America schools.  The project will provide for closely align quality professional development and expert trainers to assure excellence in teaching with technology and authentic student engagement."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Taos Academy's STEM Institute
Project Description: "Taos Academy, a 21st-Century Learning Community, is a state chartered school, therefore its own LEA. Our vision is to be a model 21st-centruy learning community developing strong leaders who have the academic and social skills necessary to succeed in the modern world. We are applying for the i3 grant to fund the STEM Institute. STEM Institute proposes to instruct students in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) concepts through project-based activities. All course offerings are aligned with New Mexico Standards and Benchmarks and Performance Standards. High school students have the opportunity to gain marketable skills and dual credit to help them achieve their post-secondary goals. The STEM Institute program includes four sections: STEMArts, Business and Software Applications, iMuseum, and Alternative Energy. Each section will provide 21st century learning skills and is replicable on its own. Two pilot progranms were funded during the 2009-2010 school year by a grant from Los Alamos National Laboratory Foundation. Students who participated in the STEMArts program have shown an increase in understanding of STEM concepts as well as an increase in self-esteem. In the Business and Software Applications portion of the STEM Institute program, students who participated have written a business plan and are running a successful entrepreneurial enteprise on Toas Academy campus. The i3 Development grant will build on these two successful programs and fund the next two stages of the STEM Institute program. The second phase will be to expand the two pilot programs while securing instructional space, technology, and training for the other two sections. The third phase implements both iMuseum and Alternative Energy components of the program and includes evaluations of the first two programs. In the fourth and final stage, Taos Academy takes over all funding and operations of the program and completes evaluative efforts."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Scaling Teach for America: Growing the Talent Force to Ensure All Our Nation's Students Have Access to a Quality Education
Project Description: Through this project, Teach for America - in partnership with 148 LEAs nationwide and with broad support from public and private sector championships - will grow our teacher corps by more than 80% by September 2014."Through this project, Teach for America - in partnership with 148 LEAs nationwide and with broad support from public and private sector championships - will grow our teacher corps by more than 80% by September 2014. Over the course of four years, more than 28,000 talented, young leaders will enter high-need classrooms as new teachers via Teach for America, and we will acheive the following outcomes: : Grow annual placements to 13,500 first and second-year teachers reaching nearly 850,000 students in high-need schools; 2) Train and support the majority of teachers to earn the rating of 'highly effective' during their first or second year of teaching; and 3) Establish proven pipelines for recruiting, training, placing, and devloping 'highly effective' teachers in 52-54 regions across the country, spanning at least 35 states and DC and accounting for over 20% of new hires in high-poverty schools in these regions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Next-Generation Student Achievement Measurement System
Project Description: "Through this project, Teach For America - currently in partnership with 5 LEAs - will develop a next-generation Student Achievement Measurement System (SAMS) that aims to:o	Support classroom instruction - providing teachers with information to help set ambitious goals and provide high quality data on the progress their students are making to help them make the right adjustments with support from their mentors;o	Drive Program improvements - identify which supports and interventions are most useful for improving teacher effectiveness;o	Help evaluate our impact - giving Teach For America confidence in the impact corps members have on their students, thus enabling further organizational improvements.We are currently piloting this new approach with just 4 program staff and 80 corps members in Eastern North Carolina (ENC) and, with support from the Investing in Innovation Fund and in partnership with external researchers, plan to further develop, test, refine, and expand it over the next five years.In the near term, by 2014-2015, we aim to:o	provide tailored benchmarks (customized goals based on subject, grade level, and student starting-point) for 60% of our corps members nationwide o	use a continuous measure to track the progress of 100% of all corps members nationwideo	increase the percentage of corps members and program directors reporting that they have confidence in classroom-level student achievement data and were able to utilize it effectively to set goals, prioritize their work, and improve student learningo	increase staff's confidence in and utilization of aggregate student achievement data to improve Teach For America's program"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Principals Supporting Continuous School Learning
Project Description: "The focus of this project is to further develop an innovative practice for leadership development and evidencebasedschool inquiry and improvement, known as the Principals Supporting Continuous School Learning(PSCSL) through refining the inquiry process already used by the Cahn Fellows Program at Teachers Collegeand scaling up through the NYC DOE and the NYS Leadership Academies. This university-based fellowshipprogram for principals and their leadership mentees has served over 326 school leaders in New York City overthe past 7 years. The school leaders participate in a year-long series of professional development activities(including a two week summer intensive), conduct a data-based school inquiry project, and continue to connectwith each other and the university via their alumni organization. Evidence thus far indicates that thisfellowship program is associated with higher rates of leader retention, satisfaction, and effectiveness, andimproved student outcomes in their schools including higher ELA and math scores, graduation rates and betterschool climate according to the NYC Quality Review and school environment surveys. Since many of ourleaders serve in schools with significant numbers of ELLs and disadvantaged students, these population will bea key beneficiary of this program.We will work with the New York City Department of Education and NYSED over a five-year period. Theimmediate impact of the project will be on the 20-25 principals in the program, the 20-25 aspiring principalsthat they mentor and the 17,000 students they serve. Eventually, it will grow to support the 1500-plusprincipals and 1.1 million students in NYC as well schools and students throughout the state."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Thinking to Learn: Learning to Think
Project Description: "Thinking to Learn: Learning to ThinkTeachers College, Columbia University (TC) submits this proposal in response to Absolute Priority 3:Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments andCompetitive Preference Priority 6: Innovations that support college access and success.Critical thinking skills are fundamental to meeting College and Career Readiness standards. Thinking to Learn:Learning to Think (TL:LT) is a pioneering approach to addressing the achievement gap by developing inquiryand argumentation skills among middle school students in high poverty urban schools to establish a trajectorytoward college and career access and success. It is grounded in cognitive science research and based on solidempirical evidence.TL:LT aims to produce new, high quality curriculum and assessments of thinking and writing skills that are fullyaligned with proposed Common Core Writing Standards for History/Social Studies and Science in grades 6-8.It will provide teacher professional development that fosters integration of thinking skills into the core middlegrades instructional program, and an innovative parent engagement program that will help parents supporttheir children?s access to post-secondary opportunities.It is hypothesized that participating students will demonstrate higher levels of inquiry and argumentation skillsthan non-participants, making them better prepared to meet Common Core Standards. They and their parentswill also show a deeper understanding of and commitment to the intellectual skills needed for college andcareers.TC and its partners, The Workplace Center at Columbia University School of Social Work, AbyssinianDevelopment Corporation, and a consortium of four public schools in New York City, will collaborate inreaching up to 450 middle grade students and their parents per year, with a cumulative impact on 1,750students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Academic and Health Efforts for Achievement and development (AHEAD)
Project Description: "Over the past 5 decades school reforms, including intensified, lengthened, or improved instruction, teacher training, supervision and coaching, charter schools and accountability tied to standardized test scores, have been implemented in an attempt to close the achievement gap. The achievement gap, however, persists, disproportionately threatening the quality of life and social mobility of urban minority youth. The effectiveness of previous reforms has been undermined, in part, by parallel, largely unaddressed disparities in educationally relevant health factors. These health factors disproportionately affect urban minority youth and strongly affect both motivation and ability to learn. We propose to compare the effects of evidence-based academic interventions when implemented alone and when complemented by a strategic set of evidence-based health innovations in 8 persistently low performing schools in New York City. Priority health factors have high prevalence, strong effects on educational outcomes, and feasibility for being addressed in schools: poor vision; asthma; ADHD; aggression and violence; physical inactivity; skipping breakfast. More than 300 current peer-reviewed empirical studies unequivocally demonstrate how these health factors impede motivation and ability to learn. These health factors affect millions of urban minority youth, have powerful effects on student achievement, and are amenable to change; yet there is no U.S. Department of Education initiative that targets them as part of a strategy to close the achievement gap. While most schools currently address some health problems, efforts are too often of poor quality, and are neither strategically planned noreffectively coordinated to influence educational outcomes. Specific evidence based school health programs exist that can, indeed must, be implemented in a coordinated and strategic fashion if we are to have any hope of closing the achievement gap. The approach has never been tried."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Academic Literacy Project in Social Studies
Project Description: "The Academic Literacy Project in Social Studies, a development grant co-directed by Lucy Calkins and Tom Corcoran, draws on the complementary strengths of the Teachers College Reading and Writing Project (TCRWP), the Consortium for Policy Research in Education (CPRE)  and the New York City public schools to bring the high expectations for academic literacy embedded in the Common Core standards to high poverty social studies classrooms (Absolute Priority #3). This initiative will help 6,900 children in 20 randomly chosen NYC Title I elementary schools by transferring, extending and adapting methods fundamental to ELA classrooms into social studies classrooms. To accomplish this, the schools will be supported with summer institutes and on-site professional development and with classroom libraries of leveled books aligned to a social studies curriculum teachers will co-construct with project staff. Teachers will become part of the community of practice that works to develop hypothetical learning progressions that describe how children develop skills in content area literacy and concepts that are essential to social studies. As this community of practice tracks and supports students' progress, a map of academic literacy and concept development will be constructed, revised, and put to use, allowing teachers to design more appropriate instruction, monitor student progress, and give students more personalized feedback, and allowing the entire effort to learn effective ways of supporting academic literacy.   Brian Rowan will analyze the relationship between program implementation and students' achievement on the NY Social Studies and English Language Arts tests using a quasi-experimental design.  His feedback will enable the work to be revised until it is successful, producing effect sizes of d = 0.70 or higher for high implementation teachers.  Once the program is successful, and it will be integrated into the large-scale work the sponsoring organizations already support."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Teachers21/WGEE Comprehensive Approach Pilot Study
Project Description: "The Comprehensive Approach Pilot Study will work with to pilot a locally-driven approach to comprehensive reform of the educator workforce that will then serve as a model for other districts across the state.  The main goal of this project is to create, strengthen, and align the key policies and practices associated with the 7 local levers (Recruitment, Hiring and Placement; Comprehensive Induction; Professional Development; Supervision and Evaluation; Teacher Leadership; Organizational Structure; Organizational Culture) for improving the quality of teaching, leading, and learning in three mid-size districts.  We will provide technical assistance to all three districts that will support the needs assessment, broad-based planning, communications and decision-making protocols, redesign, and alignment of all systems related to ensuring a quality workforce.  A cross-stakeholder group will be meaningfully and deeply engaged for the entire process, from initial planning through implementation and evaluation.  In order to provide a model and method to be scaled up, thorough evaluation will be conducted through evaluation, both internally in each district and with the work of an external research group that will identify challenges and successes associated with coordinated and comprehensive reform of the educator workforce.  This will ensure that the knowledge gained will be transferable to other districts across the state and nationally."

Project Title: Making an IMPACT (Improving Mathematical Practices and Classroom Teaching)
Project Description: "Making an IMPACT will reach teachers, students, and families throughout Ohio with significant effects that will lead toward deeper understanding of assesment and in-depth teaching of early elementary mathematics. The proposed five-year project will expand and enhance a current successful program that is designed to strengthen K-3 students? conceptual understanding in mathematics and to improve the content knowledge and instructional practices of teachers through the systematic use of student achievement data by educators, families, and other key stakeholders. The new initiative will greatly expand the number of teachers reached by the program and provide mathematical support for children in areas beyond the classroom.The Teaching & Learning Collaborative, in partnership with statewide sites strategically located across Ohio, will implement the program over the grant period. Making an IMPACT will use a blended model of professional development, combining multiple face-to-face sessions with innovative, on-line learning, for sustained yearlong professional development and support. This successful format will promote and support changes in classroom practice, ensuring that all K-3 students have access to the best mathematics instruction available.A holistic approach to supporting children?s mathematical learning will occur through the following:Goal 1. Facilitate the use of student achievement data to inform day-to-day instruction.Goal 2. Develop teacher understanding of mathematics content and utilize teaching strategies that will ensure student understanding.Goal 3. Provide teachers the opportunity for sustained professional development that incorporates what they are learning into their classrooms.Goal 4. Develop resources that will enable teachers communicate with pre-school educators, after-school providers, and families in ways that will provide a more targeted and holistic approach to fostering student growth and helping all students succeed."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Team Read Growth and Replication Initiative
Project Description: "The Team Read Growth and Replication Initiative is a $3.9 million, five-year project, that if funded by the Investing in Innovation Fund will result in:  1) the significant expansion of Team Read's cross-age reading tutoring program in Seattle Title 1 elementary schools that are in corrective action; 2) the development of a 'replication toolkit' that will be tested in two additional districts, one urban/suburban and one rural.  Team Read's project hypothesis, based on more than a decade of tutoring success, is that cross-age tutoring is an effective model of reading intervention with measurable benefits for elementary and high school students with the potential for replication in urban/suburban and rural communities. Seattle Public Schools will provide significant operational, management and logistical support for the project.Team Read has the experience, capacity and skills to carry out a project of this scope.  Founded in 1998 by Seattle Public Schools and private sponsors in response to the profound reading achievement gap faced by minority, low-income and Limited English Proficient students, Team Read has since served 14,000 elementary and high school students. The program pairs carefully screened and trained high school tutors with 2nd and 3rd graders reading significantly below grade level for  structured, twice-weekly tutoring sessions that build vocabulary development, fluency and comprehension.   The elementary students increase their reading skills and the tutors gain valuable job-training and leadership skills."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: OPEN! Redefining Schools
Project Description: "Using what has been learned and developed over the last 15 iyears in Hawawaii in the area of online and blended learning  as a foiundation, the project partners will expand the existing database of online learning resources at Myron B. Thompson Academy (MBTA) into a formal Online Education Resource Portal (OERP) housing community-vetted resources for online teaching, learning and professional development.  The project will design and develop the new, expanded portal tecihnology, train a new groiup of educators in effective online teaching strategies, and develop a significant number of new online learning resources - both courses and course components.  These newly trained online teachers will become members of the OERP community and the newly developed online learning resources will become part of tihe OERP repository.In year one of tihe project these new online teaichers and resources will be used to make a wide varietyi of new online courses available to stiudents enrolled at public and charter schools in Hawaii.  In year two of the project the resources of the portal will be opened to teachers and students in Alaska and Micronesia, as well as to  Ihawaii's small independent and parochial schools.  In year tihree of the project, several 'satellite' OERP centers will lbe spun off from tihe Hawaii OERP and networked with one anotiher.The members of the OERP will earn 'points' by creating new online learning resources and by providing professional development opportunities to other members.  These points in turn may be used to 'buy' additional training and/or resources from the co-op/ portal."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Increasing Student Achievement and Teacher Effectiveness Through Learning Engineering
Project Description: "In partnership with the Federal Way Public School District (Federal Way, WA), the Renton School District (Renton, WA) and the Washington STEM Center, the Technology Access Foundation (TAF) is submitting a proposal for ?Increasing Student Achievement and Teacher Effectiveness through Learning Engineering? for which we are seeking a Development Grant. This proposal specifically addresses ?Absolute Priority 1?Innovations That Support Effective Teachers and Principals? through the development and implementation of a professional development plan based on National Board Professional Teaching Standards (NBPTS) and teacher-focused cycles of inquiry. This proposal also addresses ?Competitive Preference Priority #6?Innovations That Support College Access and Success.?TAF will provide teachers participating in this project with extensive professional development training and support as they achieve National Board Certification. This project is designed to increase teacher effectiveness and high-need student achievement at three Technology Access Foundation Academy schools over the next four years. It will serve as a non-traditional model that will inform public education reform efforts at the district and state levels through broad dissemination practices and advocacy efforts.The objectives of ?Increasing Student Achievement and Teacher Effectiveness through Learning Engineering? include increasing the number of highly-effective teachers teaching in low-income, high minority public schools, increasing student achievement for high-need students attending participating schools and graduating high school students in excess of the district averages. As a result, there will be an increase in school-wide student academic achievement as demonstrated by the fact that 90% of students will pass the required Washington State standardized tests annually and 90% will graduate high school on-time and enroll in a college or university after high school."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Children's Literacy Intervention Project (CLIP)
Project Description: "The Children?s Literacy Intervention Project (CLIP) is a model, early intervention project that addresses the early language and literacy skills of preschool and kindergarten children. CLIP is a 12-week, research-based intervention consisting of explicit, corresponding classroom and family components. The in-classroom and homebase modules follow a detailed sequence of skill development activities that address the alphabet recognition, oral language, and phonological awareness skills needed for children to become successful readers. CLIP also consists of a third module that provides intensive, on-going professional development.CLIP is proposing a rigorous experimental design with random selection and assignment of preschool and kindergarten classrooms.  The evaluation component consists of measurable objectives and explicit research questions that are concerned with the extent to which children master oral language, letter recognition, and phonological awareness standards as measured by a valid and reliable standardized instruments.  CLIP will target 2,560 preschool and kindergarten children in Northern and Southern California."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Expect More Tehama
Project Description: "Tehama County is located in rural Northern California, at the top of the Central Valley and approximately three hours south of the Oregon border. Tehama County has a population of 61,138 people (US Census Bureau), 10,887 (CDEC) of which are K-12 students. With this grant, we will serve 21 school districts and 5,885 students enrolled in 6th-12th grade (CDEC).Expect More Tehama is a community collaboration between private businesses, nonprofit organizations and the Tehama County Department of Education to increase the number of Tehama County students who enroll in and attend an institution of higher education.  The program is being driven by a marketing campaign to change community culture from one that is ambivalent about higher education to one that embraces and supports it. In a phrase, 'Expect More, Tehama!' Parallel to the campaign is a comprehensive support system to provide 6th-12th grade students with the information and support they need to pursue higher education. The project is designed along the Spectrum of Prevention to influence communitywide change. The program objectives are to increase the numbers of students academically and practically prepared for higher education through increased study of the California A-G course requirements to meet University of California and California State University admissions. Students will have increased guidance and support from College OPTIONS, a program proven to increase college going rates in neighboring counties. College OPTIONS is affiliated with the University of California, Davis, as well as several other institutions of higher education. These resources would be a boon to our rural community, which currently is home to only a satellite campus of Shasta Community College.."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Temecula Valley Middle College Academy

Applicant: Temple University of the Commonwealth System of Higher Education
Project Title: Exceptional Coaching for Early Language and Literacy-Enhanced: Refining an Effective, Research-based Teacher Professional Development Model for Scale-Up
Project Description: "Objectives. This proposed development project will create Exceptional Coaching for Early Language andLiteracy-Enhanced (ExCELL-E), a research-based pre-k through first grade professional development model.ExCELL-E will integrate web-based technology with targeted coaching facilitated by structured lesson plansto promote the school readiness of children who attend high-poverty schools serving linguistically diversepopulations. It will be adapted from ExCELL, a PreK training program, shown in three randomized controltrials (RCTs) to build teachers? instructional quality and, consequently, children?s language and literacy skills.This project, which addresses Priorities 1 and 4 and Competitive Priorities 5 and 7, will prepare to takeExCELL-E to scale through an iterative development process and an RCT pilot evaluation.Activities. In Year 1, we will develop web-based trainings, interactive videos, structured lesson plans, andcomputer-based fidelity and progress monitoring instruments, while integrating specific strategies forsupporting English Language Learners and promoting self-regulation to improve teachers? instruction and, as aresult, children?s learning. In Year 2, we will test the refined ExCELL-E in high-poverty preschool settingsand develop a kindergarten model. In Year 3, we will pilot the kindergarten model and develop a first grademodel, and in Year 4, we will pilot the intervention in first grade. Finally, in Year 5, we will conduct a pilotRCT to gauge the effects of the program on teachers? behaviors and children?s outcomes in preschool,kindergarten, and first grade.Partners. The research team, based at Temple University, will partner with the Camden, NJ and Lancaster, PAschool districts, both of which serve high-poverty, ethnically and linguistically diverse communities.Number of students. In total, approximately 2700 children in NJ and PA will be served."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Transforming Schools Initiative
Project Description: "Terrebonne Parish, located in Louisiana on the Gulf of Mexico, has joined forces with fifteen other Louisiana school districts to implement the Transforming Schools Initiative - aimed to revive persistently low-achieving schools with lasting, systems-based changesThrough the Transforming Schools Initiative, each participating school will receive weekly professional guidance through a School Performance Specialist, employed by JBHM Education Group, who will support teachers and administrators to improve the professional practice of the leadership and staff within each school.  As school personnel increase their capacity through this targeted and comprehensive training series, school performance and district's accountability will improve.  The School Performance Specialist will be held accountable for making recommendations to each school and district that will result in reaching these goals.  Annually, each school will receive 65 days of on-site consultation with a School Performance Specialist, in addition to liaison oversight and support and a license to use JBHM's School Performance Tools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Developing Strengths: Deciphering Talent and Utilizing Highly
Project Description: "The Developing Strengths project seeks to increase teacher effectiveness by guiding teachers through the development of their strengths, as well as enhancing the strengths and career choices of youth in rural Texas. Through a whole-school approach, all stakeholders including administrators, teachers, students, and parents, become part of the Affinities Program and develop a customized strengths-based culture on their campus. Students also participate in an innovative, media-driven strengths curriculum called Strong Planet. This DVDbased curriculum simultaneously serves as a professional development course for teachers modeling effective student-centered teaching methods. Strong Planet is delivered in highly engaging format that can be sampled here: http://strengthsmovement.com/ht/d/sp/i/3121/pid/3121The Developing Strengths project uses a control and two levels of treatment groups. Both treatment groups will have students participate in Strong Planet. With 50 groups receiving only the Strong Planet student curriculum, and 10 treatment groups in rural Texas receiving the entire Affinities Program, this project will reach over 15,000 students and 500 school personnel. We will examine the importance of whole-school and community involvement in the diffusion of innovative curriculum. We will prove that understanding their strengths helps all students; from learning disabled to gifted, succeed."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: ELLA/TOEC Scale-Up
Project Description: "ELLA/TOEC Scale Up is a Scale-up Grant based on three projects funded with strong evidence: 2 funded by IES, the Coaching Solution (CS) and Project English Language and Literacy Acquisition (ELLA) [combined ELLA-CS or ECS] and 1 funded by the Texas Education Agency, the Texas LEP Initiatives Online/English as a second language (ESL)/Bilingual Certificate Preparation (TOEC). Absolute Priority 1 is met via the use of all three components: (a) the CS, virtual coaching, will increase the number of teachers and principals who are effective for improving education for high needs students, ELLs via training and mentoring, (b) implementation of the ELLA model, a comprehensive K-3 early English language acquisition program, and (c) identification, recruitment, development, placement, and retention of highly effective teachers through the use of TOEC. Competitive Priority (CP) 5 is met with inclusion of K-3 grade levels annually; CP 7 includes all Limited English Proficient (LEP) students; CP 8 is met by including rural schools. Objective 1 is to increase the number of teachers in K-3 urban, suburban, and rural schools who are highly effective in increasing English language and literacy for ELLs. Objective 2a is to implement across 40 schools, Project ELLA and CS, and to observe typical practice in 20 schools as a comparison (randomized scaling experiment). Objective 2b is to certify 500 teachers in ESL/Bilingual education via TEOC. Impacted by this grant are 112,500 ELLs (75,000 in the ECS; 37,500 in TEOC), 1,340 teachers (840 in the ECS; 500 in TEOC program), 270 principals (60 from ECS; 210 from TOEC), and 4500 classrooms (3000 in the ECS; 1500 in TEOC). Partners: Texas A&M University, Sam Houston State University, Southern Methodist University; 39 Texas school districts (including rural); business partners: Agilix, Istation, Inline Resources, Dyned, Tegrity, Eagle Graphics and c-college (more are being developed)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Developing District Capacity for Supporting a Multi-tier Behavioral and Early Literacy Response to Intervention Model in K-2 (Project BEL-RtI)
Project Description: "In 2007, then U.S. Senators Barack Obama (D-IL) and Dick Durbin (D-IL), and Representative Phil Hare (D-IL)introduced the Positive Behavior for Effective Schools Act (H.R. 3407, S. 2111) which focused onimplementation of positive behavior support practices. Unfortunately the bill was not passed although thelegislation underscored the importance that behavioral and academic supports has in maximizing academiclearning outcomes, preventing problem behaviors, and closing achievement gaps. Similarly, the goal of thisdevelopment grant project: Developing District Capacity for Supporting a Multi-tier Behavioral and EarlyLiteracy Response to Intervention Model in K-2 (Project BEL-RtI), is to develop a RtI model that integratesbehavioral and early literacy supports through a partnership between the Department of EducationalPsychology?s Center on Disability and Development (CDD) at Texas A&M University, PflugervilleIndependent School District (PISD), and the National Center on Positive Behavioral Interventions andSupports at University of Connecticut. Project BEL-RtI is carefully aligned with Absolute Priority Number 2:Innovations that Improve the Use of Data which focuses on ?funding to support strategies, practices, orprograms designed to (a) encourage and facilitate the evaluation, analysis, and use of student achievement orstudent growth data by educators, families, and other stakeholders in order to inform decision-making andimprove student achievement, student growth, or teacher, principal, school, or LEA performance andproductivity; or (b) enable data aggregation, analysis, and research? (p.6). Project BEL-RtI meets this priorityby embedding formative evaluation and analysis of student growth using behavioral and early literacyscreening and progress monitoring data within a multi-tiered, prevention-oriented, problem solving approach.It is expected that approximately 10,000 high need students will be directly impacted by the projects activities"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Water as an Integrator
Project Description: "The Harte Research Institute at TAMUCC (a minority serving institution) in collaboration with The River Institute and The Texas State Aquarium (TSA) will create a large scale environmental outreach initiative to extend to the majority of South Central Texas focusing on the Nueces and Guadalupe watersheds.  The program is called Water as an Integrator.  Novel and technoligical advanced program material and curriculum will be developed byTAMUCC faculty and HRI endowed chairs.  This program will be modeled after a program developed by the Gulf of Maine Research Institute called Lab Venture!  We will positively increase success of underserved/under-represented economically disadvantaged 7th grade student populations, and positively increase/stimulate environmental literacy of general program atendees located within the watershed area by introducing STEM-related curriculum via our indoor and outdoor program that is structured to compliment Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills.  We will impact 67,197 7th grade students and 2.5 million general attendees to the Texas State Aquarium by the end of the grant period."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Driving the best practices from charter schools into public school districts: A collaborative reform agenda for four large Texas school districts and the Knowledge Is Power Program (KIPP HOUSTON) charter schools led by the Texas Public Education Reform Fo
Project Description: "This i3 Validation Grant proposal seeks to fund the replication of the Knowledge Is Power Program (KIPP) operating principles known as the 'Five Pillars' in four Texas school districts. The study group will be 22 public middle schools that serve 34,000 students. The primary goals of this work are to 1) increase student performance in underperforming middle schools consistent with the results that have been achieved using the KIPP model and, 2) develop a successful model that can be replicated in other public schools. To achieve comparable results, these schools will focus on 1) improving the quality of leadership 2) improving and supporting effective teachers 3) preparing students to enter high school ready for a college preparatory experience including improved counseling and awareness of college entrance requirements and scholarships, and 4) analyzing results using longitudinal data for students, teachers, and school leaders. High quality professional development, innovative leadership development, and an analysis of effective and efficient practices to increase time-on-task for students are key project activities. This project would be the first ever partnership to systematically introduce the best practices of a successful charter school into public school districts. This proposal includes an objective, rigorous evaluation that will document and evaluate all aspects of this initiative.    The applicant is the Texas Public Education Reform Foundation; 'official' partners are KIPP Houston, El Paso, Fort Worth, Pharr-San Juan-Alamo, and Spring Branch ISD's, the Texas Association of School Administrators, and the Successful Practices Network."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Mathworks Algebra Project
Project Description: "The Mathworks Algebra Project (MAP) is a partnership between Texas State University ? San Marcos(TXST), McAllen ISD, Midland ISD, New Braunfels ISD, San Marcos CISD, Texas State TechnicalCollege, and a consortium of schools in the Rio Grande Valley. MAP will develop a replicable andscalable model that prepares young students for success in algebra, which is an identified state andnational priority. More than 6,800 students will be impacted each school year. A holistic curriculumroll-out plan will be developed and tested that will allow the program, if successful, to be replicatedstatewide. The three pillars of MAP are:1) Junior Summer Math Camps (JSMC) adopt the nationally recognized Mathworks model thathas a proven record in preparing students for algebra and more advanced mathematics. Thesummer programs provide students and teachers a transition to the Mathworks curriculum thatwill be used during the school year.2) Teacher, parent, and administrator training is an integral part of both the summer mathcamps and school-year support. Teachers will receive professional development during thesummers and school years through Professional Learning Communities led by math peercoaches and TXST faculty. Parents and administrators will be introduced to the curriculum,establishing an engaged community. TXST faculty will support and mentor each pilot site,facilitating lesson design and incorporating feedback about the project as they revise and refinethe curriculum.3) The Mathworks School-Year Curriculum will be fully implemented in each school district in grades 6-8. These pilots will either be for all of the students at a given middle school (andassociated feeder schools if there are separate 6th grades), or for all pre-AP students in grades6-8 at a given middle school. All students participating in these pilots will complete Algebra I bythe end of 8th grade.External evaluation will analyze the implementation and effectiveness of the project through... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Texas Rural Technology Immersion Project
Project Description: "The proposed project, Texas Rural Technology Immersion Project (R-TIP), seeks a Validation Grant to expand implementation of Technology Immersion, an innovation that has evidence of having a statistically significant effect on students' mathematics achievement. Technology Immersion naturally complements Absolute Priority 3.
