R-TIP addresses two competitive priorities: (a) the project will serve high-need secondary students in small, rural, and under-performing school districts (CPP 8), and (b) the integration of Texas College and Career Readiness Standards into the secondary curriculum along with other college-ready initiatives will prepare under-represented students for postsecondary success (CPP 6).R-TIP objectives are to (1) implement the Technology Immersion model (i.e., leadership, collaborative culture, parent and community support, technology infused learning, professional development, and technical support) in middle and high schools in rural areas (about 6,000 students in 36 schools, 20 districts), (2) provide external supports for model implementation, (3) create clusters of rural districts in West and East regions of Texas that become professional learning communities, (4) increase the academic achievement and college/career readiness and success of high-need students (e.g., participation in advanced coursework, Commended and College-Ready performance on state exams, increased 4-year graduation rate, decreased achievement gaps among groups, and increased enrollment and credits earned in postsecondary institutions), and (5) develop a plan for sustaining R-TIP and taking it to scale statewide."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Promising Literacy Practices for English Language Leaerners: A validation study
Project Description: "This validation project addresses innovations that (1) support effective teachers working with the hardest to teach children from urban, suburban, and rural schools thus improving school campus outcomes and (2) innovations that address the educational need of struggling, primary grade ELL students. The backdrop for this research will be Reading Recovery and its Spanish version, Descubriendo la Lectura to establish the impact these two implementations have in closing the literacy gap for ELL students in English only classrooms and Bilingual classrooms.  A time series quasi-experimental design will be implemented.  The proposeds study consists of four cohorts of Title I teachers receiving Readig Recovery or Descusbriendo la Lectura training from 10 different school districts. The comparison group (60 first grade teachers) will be matched as closely as possible to the treatment group based on student demographics and teacher experience but these Title I schools will not be implementing Reading Recovery or Descubriendo la Lectura. Students from both groups will be ELL students identified as performing at the bottom 20% of their class. Instrumentation for the teachers will be a Literacy and Language Orientation Survey, number of students theye were able to successfully return to the classroom performing within average, field-based observations, and professional development evaluations. Instrumentation for students will consist of measures automatically given (interim assessments three times a year, oral language proficiency measures, and state assessment given in third and fourth grades.  In addition, students will be given the Observation Survey or Instrumento de Observacion for REading Recovery and Descubriendo la Lectura student selection. To obtain national norm reference assessment, the Gates Mac-Ginitie and Apenda will be given at the end of each year to measure subsequent gains."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Improving Data Use in Schools: Expanding the Achievement Network Model
Project Description: ANet requests a $5.0MM i3 Development grant to serve an additional 120 schools with over 1,000 teachers and25,200 students. We would accomplish this growth through an expansion of four of our existing schoolNetworks in Massachusetts, Washington, DC, Louisiana, and Illinois."ANet requests a $5.0MM i3 Development grant to serve an additional 120 schools with over 1,000 teachers and25,200 students. We would accomplish this growth through an expansion of four of our existing schoolNetworks in Massachusetts, Washington, DC, Louisiana, and Illinois. Expansion of these existing networks,rather than building new networks, will avoid the high start-up fixed costs associates with new networks.Combining high-quality standards-aligned assessments, educator coaching, and peer Networks, ANet currentlyenables 90 schools and nearly 18,000 students in six Networks to use data to increase high-need studentachievement. Every 6-8 weeks, schools administer two ANet interim assessments aligned to state standardsonein English Language Arts (ELA) and one in mathematics- to students in grades 3-8. ANet also provideslogistical support to score its assessments and returns performance reports to school leaders. In addition, eachyear ANet provides 4-14 school trainings and observations, two Network-wide professional trainings, and twoNetwork meetings of member schools.ANet?s i3 project aims to increase student achievement by expanding ANet?s data-driven model to new schoolswithin current Networks, validate the impact of ANet?s model on achievement through a formal independentrandomized control evaluation, and refine and share the ANet model for implementation by more schools.ANet?s high impact on student achievement gains is supported by a multitude of research suggesting theimportance of interim assessments and related supports, including an external study showing higher studentachievement gains in ANet schools as compared to gains in districts, state, and schools with similardemographics."

Project Title: The Turnaround Zone - A School Turnaround Strategy That Places Children First
Project Description: "The Turnaround Zone (TZone) addresses Absolute Priority #4 ? Innovations that Turnaround Persistently Low-Performing Schools ? to validate a reform strategy that targets 15 intervention and 15 control schools in corrective action or restructuring with two evidence-based interventions that: 1) provide more time for students to learn core academic content by expanding or augmenting the school day, school week or school year and2) integrating ?student supports? into the school model to address non-academic barriers to student achievement. The After-School Corporation (TASC), and its partners, the New York City Department of Education (NYC DOE) and Morningside Center for Teaching Social Responsibility (MC), are proposing to deliver two highly complementary and synergistic evidence-based innovations ? Expanded Learning Time (ELT) and Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) ? to turnaround persistently low-performing elementary schools. In order to test the impact of TZone?s approach, MDRC, in collaboration with the Research Alliance for New York City Schools and three university professors with expertise in rigorous and relevant research in social and emotional development and education, will design and conduct the evaluation.TZone also addresses Competitive Preference Priority #7 ? Innovations that Address the Unique Learning Needs of Students with Disabilities and Limited English Proficient Students. Both models employ universal strategies comprised of innovative practices that address the general students population and the unique learning needs of students with disabilities, including those who are assessed based on alternate academic achievement standards; and the linguistic and academic needs of limited English proficient students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Student Acceleration Initiative
Project Description: "The Student Acceleration Initiative will develop and evaluate an intervention using extended learning time in an out of school to prepare all students at Boys & Girls High School, Brooklyn, NY, to graduate from high school on time ready for college, and ready for credit-bearing college math courses.  Beginning in the 9th Grade, all students will study math in 90-minute periods daily for four years in cohorts, with support from professional development specialists and mathematicians/math educators from the Algebra Project, New York University, and Bard College.  Math for America Fellows will intern in these classes and be hired later at the school. Teachers will use experientially based instructional materials designed in by discipline specialists and teachers, and piloted in classrooms of high need students.  Teachers participate in an intensive professional development program with summer institutes and follow up classroom visits and coaching, and can later enter the 'PDPD' program to become local PD facilitators and coaches.  The New York City Writing Project is collaborating to offer ELA teachers professional development using a similar pedagogy and classroom practice.  High school and local college students will also participate in mentoring and peer/near peer tutoring of elementary and middle school students in their neighborhoods, through the Young People's Project.  The project will scale up in the school and NYC area through partnerships with two other high schools, NYU, Math for America, Bard College, the NYC Writing Project.  The project has potential to scale up nationally through participation in an existing network of additional sites, in a range of demographic niches, that are testing similar strategies.  Research conducted in this site and others will inform revisions of strategies and design of replicable programs.   "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Developing English Language Literacy Through the Arts
Project Description: "Developing English Language Literacy through the Arts (DELLTA) seeks to close the achievement gap for English Language Learners (ELLs) in English Language Arts (ELA) and in meta-cognitive thinking skills. Originally developed by ArtsConnection, a nationally recognized arts in education organization in New York City, with funding from two US ED AEMDD grants (2005, 2006), the proposed model will work in grades 3-8 through an innovative approach to supporting language acquisition for ELL students through standards-based instruction in dance and theater.  Professional development will build the capacity of teaching artists and classroom teachers to create semantic-rich contexts for learning, and to help students make connections between the arts and ELA through collaboratively designed, standards-based interdisciplinary units of study that incorporate formative assessment strategies. A Development Grant will allow ArtsConnection to refine and test the DELLTA model on a greater scale than previously implemented, conduct research to verify its effectiveness and generalizability, develop materials for the field and share them via the web, and further build capacity of the organization, partner schools, and area teachers to take the model to scale.  Over five years, the project will reach an estimated total of 10,000 non-duplicated students in grades 3-8 in 14 elementary and middle public schools in New York City. An additional 100 ESL teachers in the NYC region, who will reach a total of 3,000 additional students, will participate in a three-credit college course to learn how to use DELLTA?s innovative approaches in their teaching."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Leveraging Summer Learning to Turn Around Low-Performing Schools: How the BELL Summer Program Model Increases Student Achievement and School Performance
Project Description: "BELL proposes to replicate, scale, and validate the impact of the BELL Summer program model.  Over the course of three years, the program will serve 20,000 high-need students in grades K-8 attending low-performing schools in Detroit and Flint, MI, Boston, Springfield, and Worcester, MA, and Augusta, GA, as well as up to two additional LEA partners. This project represents a targeted approach to school turnaround that is applicable to diverse student populations, including limited English proficient students. Students participating in the program will increase their academic achievements and improve their attitude toward school and learning. Such gains will translate into improved performance in school, and help turn around school-wide achievement.  The BELL Summer model has already been shown by independent researchers to have a positive impact on students' reading skills and parental involvement. This project will build on this evidence base by incorporating a student-level experimental design and school-level quasi-experimental design, conducted independently by MDRC, to contribute strong evidence about BELL Summer's impact on school turnaround. The National Summer Learning Association and local intermediaries will disseminate outcomes and best practices. Some LEAs have already demonstrated an interest in leveraging summer learning to increase student achievement, and with BELL have successfully tested partnership approaches similar to the proposed project. Ultimately, through this project, BELL and its partners seek to establish this exceptional approach for LEAs throughout the country to adopt, scale, and sustain after the grant period."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Leading for Literacy
Project Description: "The primary purpose of this project is to develop, implement, and evaluate a systemic model for district wide professional and organizational development to improve the literacy achievement for all students, especially those who are Limited English Proficient (LEP) and create a sustainable member-led network of school districts committed to this purpose.  The overarching goals address Absolute Priorities 3 & 1 by: (a) Increasing the percentage of students who meet and exceed California and Common Core literacy standards (students overall by 15% and English language learners by 25%); (b) Increasing effectiveness of teachers and site/district staff in instructional leadership roles. This PD/OD model is built upon three key strategies:1.	Provide a minimum of 50 hours of differentiated professional development for teachers, site and district leaders leading to: (1) the translation of standards and information from assessments into instructional routines; (2) collaborative and focused practice; and (3) systemic organizational conditions that promote effective literacy instruction and continuous professional learning. 2.	Provide job embedded professional content resources to develop instructional and organizational competencies including: virtual professional resources and social networking, webinars, instructional and peer coaching, and developing a corps of retired educators who are subject matter experts to support adolescent content literacy.3.	Create and sustain a learning network which provides opportunities for both formal training about how to harvest from and disseminate best practice as well as multiple levels of support for creating collaborative partnerships across schools and districts.  The network will create exemplary models of instructional practice related to Absolute Priorities 3 and 1 that can be disseminated to new network member districts during and beyond the life of the project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: BizWorld Expansion
Project Description: "The BizWorld Foundation inspires children to be innovative leaders through the teaching of entrepreneurship, business and finance. The applicant connects students in grades 3 through 8 to the real world by providing curricula, training educators and fostering collaboration between education and business.  The importance of teaching business, entrepreneurship and finance while improving education and closing the achievement gap is simple: students learn when basic academic concepts are put into project-based learning examples. Through the delivery of Teacher Training sessions, the applicant empowers educators to guide students through the engaging BizWorld, BizWiz and BizMovie programs. The important connection between the real world and the classroom in these programs is the tool that will inspire and empower children to see beyond the classroom and to understand the reason why academics are important to their future, effectively promoting college- and career-readiness.The applicant seeks to expand its California programs, as well as to develop a strong local presence in Colorado and New York City. Through the proposed expansion, The BizWorld Foundation will target its Teacher Training and curricular program resources toward high-need students in low-performing schools in these regions. The project in particular will focus on serving students in rural LEAs, who are difficult to reach but who often can be aided by the key role of technology in connecting their learning to the real world. The applicant also has developed a new guide to facilitate instruction of limited English proficient students, whose basic need to find learning connections is more urgent as they look to relate English to real-world situations."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Board of Education of Worcester County
Project Title: This project meets several priorities of the i3 program by creating standards and benchmark assessments for Advanced Placement courses to improve student outcomes on the Advanced Placement test.
Project Description: "Investing in InnovationWaiver RequestThe Board of Education of Worcester County	The Board of Education of Worcester County is requesting a partial waiver of the 20% matching requirement in light of the fact that our primary partner, the College Board, can only commit to $2.6% of the required match.  Despite not being classified as a rural county under the guidelines of this grant opportunity, Worcester County is located remotely on Maryland?s Eastern Shore.  Most of the county is involved with agriculture, mainly poultry and grain production.  There is a seasonal tourism industry in the northernmost portion of the county in Ocean City, Maryland.  Worcester County has Maryland?s highest seasonal unemployment rate.  There are no major corporations or foundations located in Worcester County from which a 20% match could be obtained.  During the grant writing process, the Board of Education has been working diligently with the College Board as a partner, however, the in-kind services that the College Board can direct towards Worcester County only amount to $112,035 over the four year period.	Given that there are now opportunities to apply for the in-kind match through nationwide resources, Worcester County Public Schools will continue to seek the remaining required match over the upcoming months, based on the merits of its proposal and the high need of so many of our students."

Applicant: The Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin System
Project Title:
Improving Achievement by Transforming the Culture of Algebra Classrooms: Studying the
Effects of an Enhanced Academic Youth Development (AYD) Initiative in Districts Committed to Closing Achievement Gaps
Project Description: "This proposal seeks to develop and evaluate a mathematics education initiative that can improve performance inAlgebra I among minority students, thereby increasing the likelihood that they will go on to enroll and succeedin higher level mathematics courses, a gateway to college access. The Academic Youth Development (AYD)Initiative is an innovative Algebra I readiness program aimed at students transitioning from middle school tohigh school mathematics. Delivered through a summer bridge and school year program, the AYD curriculumincludes a mathematics strand that deepens students? understanding of key algebra-readiness concepts, and ayouth development strand that develops students? academic identities by drawing on recent psychological andneuroscience research findings.Over the 4 years since its inception, students who participated in AYD have shown increased levels of academicengagement and achievement. Additionally, participating teachers report that non-AYD students also showincreased levels of academic engagement in their Algebra I classes. Given these early indicators of programsuccess, the project seeks to understand (a) how to enhance and scale up the positive effects of AYD; (b) howthe academic achievement of AYD students is influenced by their participation in the program, and (c) how theengagement and achievement levels of non-AYD students are influenced when they are exposed to AYD-trainedteachers and AYD students, that is, how an infection model might produce the greatest benefit toacademic achievement. Developing an enhanced AYD program that evaluates the impact of the hypothesizedinfection model provides an innovative and research-based approach to improving student academicachievement in Algebra I and shows promise for closing achievement gaps across mathematics courses."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: The Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin System
Project Title: ONPAR Interactive Assessment Environments: A Multimodal Method of Seeing and Hearing and Supporting English Learner Achievement in Math and Science
Project Description: "?ONPAR Interactive Assessment Environments: A multimodal method of seeing and hearing and supportingEnglish Learner Achievement in math and science? proposes to expand the use of an innovative computerinteractiveassessment strategy that has been found to be successful in measuring the academic knowledge andskills of low English proficient English learners (ELs), among others. The multi-screen multi-part tasksdynamically redirect the language comprehension and production by providing experimental or authenticcontexts through simulations, animations, image rollovers, sound, text, interactive sequences, and minoramounts of remaining text. In engaging ONPAR tasks, students build, model, assemble, categorize, orproduce relational or inferential ?explanations? using screen stimuli. This project will develop and pilot a suiteof three standards-based classroom-embedded formative assessments and associated interims in mathematicsand science at each of the grades 2-8 and in high school algebra and geometry, while also developing a suite ofcurricular materials aimed at helping mainstream academic teachers learn how to build multi-modal lessonsand assessment activities that are effective for ELs. The overarching purpose of the project is to help districtsaddress the achievement gap by creating accessible pathways into demanding academic content for lowEnglish ELs by developing best-practice interactive assessment packages at each grade level, and by creatingprofessional development programs which explicitly use these models to expand how academic content ingeneral might be effectively delivered and evaluated for students with language challenges. Over the five-yearperiod, the project will impact about 1000 teachers and 100,000 students and produce and validate a total of 63interactive assessments and associated curricular packages that will be ready for use at the completion of thegrant ."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois
Project Title: ELM: Early Learning Matters
Project Description: "Early Literacy Matters is a collaboration between the University of Illinois at Chicago Center for Literacy andEvanston/Skokie School District 65 designed to develop and implement a district-wide program for all 3- and4-year-old children that results in improving children?s school readiness in social-emotional and cognitivedomains, is based on high quality standards that provide children with the foundations for the Common CoreState Standards in kindergarten, and provides a successful transition into the primary grades of schooling. Theessential elements of the program that will be implemented include: (1) comprehensive curriculum (language,early literacy, content learning, socio-emotional standards) that operates within an effective and efficient dailyschedule, (2) evidence-based classroom instructional practices, (3) teacher use of periodic, on-goingassessment child performance assessments to make instructional decisions, (4) a comprehensive, rigorous, ongoingprogram of professional development for teachers focused on all curricular areas and aimed at enhancingteacher communities of practice, (5) extensive in-classroom coaching of teachers and assistant teachers, and(6) information and hand-on strategies and materials that promote family involvement in support of children?scognitive and socio-emotional growth."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: The 2010 Brookhaven Validation Project
Project Description: "PROJECT DESCRIPTION: This project will facilitate the expansion of the Brookhaven Treatment and Learning Center to address a statewide need for access to a therapeutic learning environment and associated support services to address the unique challenges of educating high-needs children who are victims of severe abuse and trauma from Vermont's rural LEAs. OBJECTIVES: The expansion and renovation of the Brookhaven Treatment and Learning Center to serve high-needs students from rural Vermont LEAs. OUTCOME: Brookhaven teachers will have resources to teach more high-needs students from rural Vermont LEAs and reduce class size leading to greater teacher effectiveness. Provide educational sub-grants to rural Vermont LEAs to fund and facilitate access to appropriate educational resources for all of Vermont's high-needs students. Outcome: Brookhaven teachers will be able to reach high-needs students from rural Vermont LEAs lacking financial resources or the Brookhaven Initiative will fund the high-need student's access to alternative educational resources appropriate to the high-needs studen'ts situation. Creation of Crisis Response Team to provide expert assistance to teachers in Rural LEAs with high-needs students. Outcome: Early intervention will reduce the need for educating students outside the local LEA and provide teachers in rural Vermont LEAs with the tools to meet the needs of high-needs students whose issues have not risen to the level of requiring removal from the local school. TARGET NUMBER OF STUDENTS TO BE SERVED: 818 over 5 years. SPECIAL PROJECT FEATURES: Proven Array of Best Practices, Proven Record of Success, 58 Year History. PARTNERS: The Vermont Department of Education, The Vermont Department for Children and families, The Vermont Department of Health, Division of Mental Health, The Kappa Gamma Delta Society, The Council of independent schools, The Vermont Consortium of Residential Programs, Vermont LEA's."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Investing in Improving Youth Academic Achievement - A Community Based Approach:
The Brotherhood/Sister Sol, Inc. (BHSS)
Project Description: "BHSS provides comprehensive, holistic and long-term support services to the youth of New York City who range in age from six to twenty-two. We focus on issues such as leadership development and educational achievement and the development of ethical young people. We provide four-six year rites of passage programming, five day a week after school care, school and home counseling, summer camps, job training and placement, college preparation and exposure, employment opportunities, community organizing training, and a community environmental education program. We continually expose our young people to new opportunities through wilderness retreats, cultural performances, college tours, and month long intensive study programs to Africa and Latin America. BHSS publishes assorted curricula and collections of our members' writings and trains educators from throughout the nation on our approach. BHSS is an evidence-based model that focuses on outcomes and provable success. The result of our holistic approach is that 88% of our members have graduated from high school (with the percentage rising to 94% when including GED), while in their similarly situated peers in Harlem have a graduating rate of 42%. BHSS members have a teenage pregnancy rate of less than 2%, while NYC's rate is 9.4%. 85% of our members have been accepted to college and 95% are attending college and/or working full time. In the community of West Harlem, approximately 30% of youth, ages 18-25, are in college or working full time. In the USA one out of three Black men is under supervision of the prison system while no members of BHSS are in prison, or on parole and two are on probation. Our intended outcomes and objectives are that our membership do not become incarcerated, delay having children, graduate from high school, and either attend college or find long term stable employment. LEA Schools with whom we work: Thurgood Marshall Academy, Mott Hall High School, Community Health Academy of the Heights."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Teaching, Learning and Leading
Project Description: "This Development Grant proposal responds to an urgent need to improve the effectiveness of teachers and leaders in Connecticut's high-needs classrooms.  The Capitol Region Education Council (CREC), in collaboration with eleven Connecticut districts and two universities aims to increase teacher and leadership effectiveness by developing a comprehensive pathway for the development and demonstration of teaching and leading expertise. The proposed project, Teaching, Learning and Leading, is framed by three overarching goals: (1) Improve the effectiveness of teacher and administrator preparation; (2) Enact a transparent, rigorous performance-based professional evaluation system; (3) Improve the effectiveness of professional development and support.  The goals of the project will be realized in the design and delivery four development programs and a comprehensive teacher evaluation system. Individually, each of these program elements is recognized as an effective means of cultivating effective teaching.  Together, they represent a pioneering approach to improving teacher and leader effectiveness. To realize Goal 1, we will deliver and evaluate an Advanced Alternate Route to Certification for Intermediate Administrators and a Teacher Leader Institute. Both programs are intensive, job-embedded approaches to preparation, which provide mentoring by practicing leaders as well as ongoing induction support.  Goal 2's focus on teacher evaluation provides the key mechanism for demonstrating expertise necessary for professional advancement.  In accordance with recently-passed state legislation mandating a revised method of evaluating teachers, the proposed project will develop a comprehensive system that includes multiple measures of student performance as well as a professional, classroom appraisal tool.  Funding will enable the design and field-testing of the system in the eleven participating districts. Goal 3 complements the first two by providing ongoing, targeted professi"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: THE CENTER: RESOURCES FOR TEACHING AND LEARNING
Project Title: Illinois Resource Center I3 Development Grant
Project Description: "The IRC, a project of The Center: Resources for Teaching and Learning, is seeking funding under the I# Fund aimed at increasing student achievement and closing the achievement gap for high-need learners.  Project IRCI3 includes 2 innovations: 1) a professional development (PD) design and 2) data-driven PD content on differentiating instruction and assessment for ELLs/high-need students based on language proficency level.??..Truncated"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Charter Schools of Excellence, Inc.
Project Title: Teacher Residency Program
Project Description: "The Charter Schools of Excellence, Inc. (CSE), one of Florida?s most successful public charter school networks, proposes to develop and field test the Teacher Residency Program (TRP) to address the need for effective, well-prepared teachers who can increase the achievement of Florida?s high need K-12 public school students. The CSE network, in partnership with the Somerset Academy public charter school network, and two local colleges/universities with teacher certification programs, will implement the Teacher Residency Program (TRP), an Investing in Innovation Development Project over a four-year period. This project addresses Absolute Priority 1- Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Leaders.The Teacher Residency Program is based on a successful teacher preparation project that the Charter Schools of Excellence network has operated since 1998 to groom its own effective teaching staff. It also conforms with research findings that correlate effective teaching with extensive and carefully supervised and extensive clinical placement with exposure to diverse student populations.This unique two-year Teacher Residency Program (TRP) will bring promising undergraduate students majoring in education at local colleges and universities into the classrooms of high performing charter schools for an extended paid residency experience that will complement and greatly expand their academic coursework.The Charter Schools of Excellence (CSE) operates five public charter elementary schools in Broward County, Florida. Its Official Partner in the Teacher Residency Program (TRP) will be Somerset Academy (SA), a public charter school network of 20 elementary, middle and high charter schools operating in Miami-Dade and Broward Counties. The anticipated cost to fund the Teacher Residency Program is $6,037,920, of which $4,918,720 is being requested and $1,119,200 will be provided as a match."

Project Title: a3 NYC: Attend, Align, Achieve
Project Description: "The Children's Aid Society, in partnership with the United Federation of Teachers, Harlem Children's Zone, Good Shepherd Services, the New York City Department of Education and an independent evaluator, the Center for Advanced Study of Education at CUNY, is proposing to validate a3 NYC.  a3 NYC has a critically important goal: turn around elementary schools that are plagued by persistent low performance and where 30% or more children are chronically absent.  The project will do so through a community school model that emphasizes two core strategies for which partners will share accountability: Remove the non-academic barriers to learning that children face by coordinating and integrating a broad range of student and family support services into the school (such as health services, counseling, adult education, direct material assistance for families in crisis, targeted interventions for chronically absent children and after-school and summer programs that are aligned with the school curriculum); and, Provide robust, school-based professional development centered on student needs to teachers, administrators and community partners."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The African American Male Initiative: Steps to Success
Project Description: "The African American Male Initiative: Steps to Success (STS) is a program that has succeeded in helping Black male primary school students achieve school progress during its 3-year pilot phase. An i3 grant is sought to test this promising practice as a school turnaround model through an experimental trial with 4 new school partners in Harlem that serve nearly 2,000 students. All 43 boys from the pilot program in grades 2-4 have progressed in school for 3 years, while receiving supports founded upon evidence-based practices and designed by a group of national experts and community stakeholders.  Full-time Life Coaches orchestrate resources and coordinate nested relationships between home, school and community for the boys, helping them become inspired by special interests and overcome set-backs; a team of tutors provides individualized academic support; a Saturday Cultural Academy instills pride and a sense of positive group identity; volunteer Everyday Heroes expose the boys to the array of great careers that men of color assume.  For this reason, The Children's Aid Society (CAS) requests a Development grant to address Absolute Priority 4: Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools. The program will also address competitive priority 5 - Innovations for Improving Early Learning Outcomes, and competitive priority 6 - Innovations that Support College Access. The data presented from a pilot implementation of STS demonstrate promising results from this early intervention in shifting family, teacher, and youth expectations and planning for college attendance, which is important in advance of the middle school transition before students get to high school. The major partners in this endeavor are The Children's Aid Society; Frederick Douglass Academy, a public school and host of our Saturday Cultural Academy; four low performing schools in Harlem's District 5; and, an independent evaluation team from the Columbia University School of Social Work."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Level Playing Field Baselines - Real World Best Practices
Project Description: "Summary of Project:   To turn around persistently low-performing schools by ranking the of schools in Washington State, Kentucky, Virginia, and two other states to be determined, using an extraordinary analytical process which eliminates 10 demographic and other non-malleable factors while simultaneously normalizing for reading, math, writing, and science pass-rate scores on State assessments K-12. Surpassing even the most rigorous studies which control for two or three variables, this spectacular application controls for every factor for which a state tracks data.  The result is that grant providers, principals, researchers, and teachers can reliably compare growth between and among all schools within a state.  A second result is a completely bias-free listing of highest to lowest schools based on the most level playing field imaginable.  The logical outcome is that for the first time ever, we can identify where best practices may be found.  That is, after the affect of factors over which principals have little to no control are eliminated from pass-rates, what remains is the impact of best practices.  	In the second step or phase, we visit the now accurately- identified schools, contrasting the constellation of materials and adult behaviors in the highest and lowest performing schools. 	In the third and final step, we replicate in rural Kentucky and Virginia two integrated best practices, one related to school readiness and the other to third-grade reading levels, creating more robust evidence of these kinds of best practices.   "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: EarthWorks and Exchange City
Project Description: "The Cody foundation will work in partnership with schools, EarthWorks and Exchange City in Taylor, MI, and in Kansas City, and Entraprise City to give axcess to career development programs in science, civics, entraparnership, business ownership and personal and business financial managenment. The proposed program will utilize competative prorities to afer subgrants to high need students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: AP Innovation: Expanding the College Readiness of High-Need Students through AP Teacher Quality
Project Description: "The College Board is seeking a Validation grant for AP Innovation: Expanding the College Readiness of High-Need Students through AP Teacher Quality. AP Innovation is an exceptional approach to supporting educational success of high-need students by enabling states, districts, and schools to supply these students with Advanced Placement? (AP?) teachers trained to help the diversifying U.S. student population succeed in rigorous AP coursework. AP Innovation will produce measureable, significant increases in the rates at which high-need students succeed on AP Exams, earning scores which research demonstrates are closely linked to improvements in college outcomes for students of all races, ethnicities and income levels. In order to address persistent achievement gaps in AP success rates, AP Innovation will increase AP teacher quality through an innovative system of formative and interim assessments that provides teachers more frequent feedback on student learning, enabling teachers to tailor classroom instruction to their unique student populations; and technology-delivered professional development and online communities targeting the most challenging areas of content, pedagogy, and differentiated instruction. AP Innovation is a five-year project that addresses Absolute Priority 3.The College Board's three Official Partners are Hillsborough County Public Schools (Tampa, FL); Northside Independent School District (San Antonio, TX); and the North East Florida Educational Consortium (NEFEC). Through these partners, AP Innovation will serve an estimated 36,780 unique students included in the longitudinal evaluation. Building on the early outcomes of this validation project, the College Board will begin a parallel implementation of AP Innovation nationwide and will reach 186,000 unique students in three academic subject areas by the end of the grant period in 2015, and 1,695,000 unique students in twelve academic subject areas by 2020."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Making the Grade
Project Description: "The Consortium for Public Education is seeking a development grant to support a proposed project called Making the Grade.  Making the Grade will improve academic outcomes and graduation rates among economically disadvantaged students considered most at risk of failure in sixteen Title I high schools across Pennsylvania. At risk students are placed in alternative education programs because of academic, behavioral, social, or emotional problems.  Although segregating these students from traditional classrooms often is necessary, doing so poses a challenge to repatriation and graduation.  Alternative education students who remain on campus must continue to receive instruction in their core subjects, however alternative education instruction is developed by an external provider to suit a range of student ages and abilities and is not synchronized with the lessons being taught in their own classes.  Those students sent off campus can receive instruction from external providers that vary widely in quality.To lower these barriers, The Consortium, in collaboration with VLN Partners, Inc., a Pittsburgh-based developer of online education programs, will implement Making the Grade and the holistic model for blended learning to help our network of Title I high schools and their more than 400 students.  The holistic model for blended learning brings together customized lessons that are synchronized with traditional classroom instruction, taught by professional teachers, and actively engage students to create alternative education programs that really help at risk students.   With Making the Grade, each partner school will receive all of the tools necessary to establish an alternative education program that will break the cycle of repatriation, remediation and return to alternative education. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Curators of the University of Missouri
Project Title: eMINTS Validation Project
Project Description: "The University of Missouri (UM) eMINTS National Center and New Franklin R-I School District will examine the efficacy of eMINTS professional development (PD) programs on the achievement of high-need rural Missouri middle school students through a Random Control Trial (RCT). The RCT will occur in 60 school districts that qualify for the project based on the geographic and socio-economic status of their populations. Forty-eight school districts have submitted letters of interest and agreed to be randomly assigned to one of three study groups for the project. Districts will receive intensive eMINTS PD (250 hours) and classroom technology (interactive whiteboard, student computers, and peripherals). Learning Point Associates (LPA) is the external evaluator for the project. The project expects to serve 10,500 students and 240 teachers over its five-year period. Project objectives and outcomes include:o	Assessing and increasing 7th and 8th grade students' mathematics and English Language Arts (ELA) performance by their exposure to eMINTS teaching styles and technology;o	Assessing and improving 7th and 8th grade students' 21st century skills and academic orientation by their exposure to eMINTS teaching styles and technology; and,o	Understanding eMINTS PD impacts on teachers' practice.The project features intensive PD, in-classroom coaching, and technology-rich classrooms.Official partners: New Franklin R-I. Other partners: Dell, SMART Technologies, Intel, AppleBrainPOP, Tech4Learning, School Improvement Network (SINet - PD 360), and 60 Missouri school districts meeting project eligibility requirements."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Who Took My Chalk? TM
Project Description: "Who Took My Chalk?? (WTMC??) , the innovation being proposed by The EdVenture Group for i3 development funds, is a whole school reform model that aims to turn around low achieving schools by working with the entire school team to improve school culture and attitude, resulting in increased student achievement within schools of any size implementing any level of change.  The EdVenture Group, managing project partner, created WTMC??  based on the hypothesis that, 'Creating a positive school culture positively impacts whole school reform efforts and results in increased student achievement.'  Who Took My Chalk?? takes the participating school through a step by step change management model that begins at the center of the school with their culture and attitude and extends systematically outward to goals, objectives and outcomes that lead to student achievement.         The EdVenture Group has tested Who Took My Chalk? ? in fifteen schools in West Virginia and Pennsylvania.  Through this pilot process, a clear model has been developed that allows The EdVenture Group to measure specific outcomes of the program.  Since this initial work has been done, this development project will allow the group to further develop the research model and determine if similar outcomes can be expected across a wide range of school variables.            Target schools for implementation of Who Took My Chalk?? utilizing i3 development funds include elementary, middle and high schools from West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee.  Schools where the WTMC?? program will be implemented include schools in counties with a high dropout rate, low income rate, high percentage of children in poverty and a high percentage of students receiving free and reduced lunch.  In addition schools with low attendance rates and an unfavorable Adequate Yearly Progress Status will be included as schools in need of turnaround."

Project Title: Free to Be
Project Description: "i3 specifies nonprofit organizations partnering with LEA's and requires those LEA's be listed. Free to Be, 501(c)(3) nonprofit, is a national endeavor. Free to Be is organized and budgeted to reach all fifty states plus District of Columbia. Thus it is not possible to list every LEA in our application (There are 1030 in Texas alone). Free to Be partners with every LEA in the United States. We have reached four states in seven semesters, presenting to 268 schools and 93,717 students and their faculties. We have requests from nearly every state in the nation, from California to Maine, from Washington to Florida, to present Free to Be. In our application, we are organized and budgeted to reach  Our attached Student Questionnaire and Teacher Questionnaire written responses demonstrate conclusively that students learn:  Respect, pride, and love for America.America is our home - and how lucky we are that it is. The odds of being born in America are 1 in 36.The value of freedom and democracy.The cost of freedom. Over one million young people have given their lives in the name of freedom.The hope and opportunity America offers to all.The scope of success - teacher, lawyer, dentist, rancher, truck driver, senator, scientist, President.America provides all the tools for opportunity and success.Let us strive to be the Greatest Generation.Stay in school. Learn, in order to be interested, informed, involved citizens.Civic duty.Patriotic duty.Never lose our nation's freedom. Never lose your personal freedom.Be the best you can; and that is good enough.The American Dream is a good citizen, a good home, a good family, a good career, a good life.Freedom cannot be bought, nor can it be sold. But it can be lost... 97% of students confirm that FREE TO BE changed their thinking, behavior, goals, or life! Attached are student/teacher written questionnaires. We have thousands on file confirming that they get it! After decades of futile effort and expense, we have fo"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Foundation for CSU, San Bernardino
Project Title:
Utilizing a Child in Adolescent Wellness Model to Improve Student Engagement and
Acheivement in School
Project Description: "This Development Grant project proposes to build upon a one period a day model at Chino High School where articulation from middle to high school based on meeting developmental needs has been an established practice. Within the existing model, high school seniors and teacher advisors have mentored the high school freshman to provide additional assistance during their transition. The proposed activities would build upon that model by utilizing the Child and Adolescent Wellness Scale (CAWS) for building overall well-being and the Educational Planning and Assessment System (EPAS) ACT series for building academic assets. These assessments will guide the development of the curricular activities within the one period course based upon student characteristics and needs. Further, we will receive mentor training and additional mentors from ourpartner, Applied Principles for Service, Inc as well as CSUSB School Counseling and School Psychology graduate students. Consequently, through a well structured mentoring program guided by a focus on overall wellness and by reducing the ratio of ?mentor? per student and parent(s), this proposed intervention would focus on meeting both the wellness and achievement needs of the approximately 700 ninth grade adolescents participating in the intervention at Chino High School. The objectives and outcomes are to: (1) Significantly increase student wellness, specifically in those areas found to positively relate to student engagement and achievement; (2) significantly increase students? performance on the EPAS EXPLORE, PLAN and ACTthereby creating a seamless and vertical approach toward preparation for college; (3) significantly increase student engagement and attendance in school; (4) significantly decrease incidences of student referrals for discipline issues, suspensions and dropping out of school; (5) significantly increase students? application and acceptance into college; and (5) significantly increase students? persistence in college."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Academic Advocacy
Project Description: "Abstract  - The Front PorchProject Title: Academic Advocacy Type of Grant Requested: DevelopmentBrief project description including project activities: Child services are not coordinated for individual children and resources are available but not accessed. In order to effectively deliver services to children who need assistance to succeed at school, it must come through one person with whom they have a positive relationship. The solution is to provide academic advocates for individual students who form a positive helping relationship with the child and their family, help s/he access resources and services and follow up after. The advocate checks on the child and helps them in the classroom and facilitates communication between school, student, caregivers, after school and other services the youth uses (i.e. speech therapy). The benefits: Schools have improved grades and behavior. Teachers have help assisting a child who needs extra help and has issues outside of school distracting him/her. A child gets support through an adult who understands their whole life, not just school issues. Parents get parenting cheerleaders, advice, an example in advocating for their child and the opportunity to see their child succeed. Academic Advocacy is an easily replicable program that is an outstanding innovation in education, parenting engagement and social service delivery. Summary of project objectives and expected outcomes: Children will improve one letter grade in their report cards in 50% of their subjects and will self-report feeling more supported at school. Target number of students to be served in the project: 1,000: 100 per year, with some new students, some continuing.  Official and other partners: Detroit children and their parents/caregivers and individual Detroit schools that want the homework help after school program."

Project Title: Increasing the Graduation Rate Among Alternative High School Students: A Long-Term, Arts-Based Approach to Dropout Prevention
Project Description: "The HeArt Project (HP) is an 18-year-old Los Angeles-based nonprofit organization that provides a long-term arts-based dropout prevention program and non-academic support services to over 600 high-need teenagers attending 24 low-performing alternative high schools in three school districts in Los Angeles: Culver City Unified School District, Los Angeles County Office of Education (LACOE), and Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD).  LACOE, the largest public school district in the country, is HP's 'official partner' for this Investing in Innovation grant and has contracted for HP services in its schools for the past 8 years. I3 funding will enable HP and LACOE to build on the success and experience of this partnership through the creation of a 'hub and spokes' delivery model that includes an 'Alternative Arts Academy,' an alternative high school for highly creative, high-need students. In addition to being a high school site, the Academy will serve as the hub for HP's current 24 spoke sites, offering targeted professional development training for teaching artists and classroom teachers serving this teenage population, alumni and parent resources, increased student leadership training, and relevant community connections through internships.  Students attending spoke sites will continue to receive The HeArt Project's core program, a 'ladder' of arts programming, and, when appropriate, have the opportunity to transfer to the academy for an arts high school experience.  The addition of the hub will increase the quality and consistency of program delivery, provide an opportunity to impact a greater number of students through articulated professional development practices, and improve aspects of our program that address non-academic barriers.  Collectively these strategies will increase high school graduation rates at the targeted persistently low-performing alternative high schools."

Project Title: Harmony Project Multi-Year Music-Based Mentoring Program for High Need Youth
Project Description: "Harmony Project, a non-profit organization, won the President?s Coming Up Taller Award for 2009, the nation?s highest honor for an arts program targeting high need youth. We partner with Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD) Beyond the Bell (BTB) after-school branch, to improve school attendance, retention and achievement of students in groups of underperforming schools. Our professional musician mentors work closely with high need students for multiple years, providing intensive music instruction and ensemble opportunities after school and on Saturdays. Students develop commitment, discipline, persistence, time-management and accountability ? and learn to work well with others in performance ensembles. School performance improves, especially in language and math. School enrollment is required and students remain enrolled in school.Through this project we will replicate our programs at 5 more high need schools over 5 years in partnership with LAUSD-BTB. We will enroll 415 additional students and independently evaluate program impact and processes. The multi-year evaluation proposed will provide the foundation for continued program improvement and replication, both within Harmony Project, and by others.Our strategy is to build a pipeline of music-based mentoring to support high need students from elementary school throughout middle and high school. In year 1, 330 students will be enrolled, three-quarters of them from 3 elementary schools. By years 4 and 5, middle and high school students will comprise nearly half the project enrollment. We will provide:? Vocal and Rhythmic-Movement Performance Ensemble training for up to 400 students, 160 hours/year;? Instrumental music instruction for up to 180 students, 80 hours/year;? Saturday youth orchestra program for instrumental music students from all 5 schools,120 hours/year;? Peer mentor service-learning for up to 15 students/year;? Parent orientation and education;? Field trips;? Summer program."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Maximizing the Effectiveness of the Hill Reading Achievement Program (HillRAP)
Project Description: "The Hill Center, a 501c3 located in Durham, NC, submits a Development Grant proposal to expand and refine its innovative reading intervention?HillRAP?that combines teacher training with school-based intervention and has the potential to make significant and lasting impact on the reading achievement of high-need students in low performing schools. The proposed project involves partnering with local education agencies and an independent evaluator to adapt and implement HillRAP for and with fidelity in low-performing middle schools in primarily rural communities in North Carolina. The primary project objective is to turn around the participating low performing schools by (1) improving teacher effectiveness in reading instruction through participation in HillRAP training that combines ongoing professional development, a structured curriculum and instructional approach, and a formative assessment system for monitoring progress and individualizing instruction, and (2)improving student achievement in reading through participation in HillRAP instruction delivered with fidelity. Expected outcomes include (a) reduced achievement gaps between student subgroups, (b) determination of HillRAP dosage needed to maximize program effects, and (c) an estimate of HillRAP?s impact on student achievement to determine potential for validation studies. The target population will consist of high-need students reading below grade level, including those who have learning disabilities or attention deficit disorders, or who are Limited English Proficient. The target number of students to be served is 432. HillRAP is an intensive, multisensory remediation curriculum delivered on a 4:1 basis with formative assessment interwoven with instruction. Partners include The Hill Center, developer of HillRAP, the LEA of Lenoir County Schools in NC, and Mid-continent Research for Education and Learning (McREL) who will serve as independent evaluator. A matched comparison group study will be conducted."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: AchievementMakers: It's Cool to Succeed
Project Description: "The AchievementMakers:  It's Cool to Succeed program will occur in three high-need urban charter middle and high schools in Washington, D.C. and Chicago, Il over five years.   Teachers will be trained in using The HistoryMakers online digital video archive, an interactive video tool that presents life histories of accomplished African-Americans (HistoryMakers), and in teaching using the Harvard Business School case study method.  Teachers will receive ongoing support online and in periodic meetings.  Individual  HistoryMakers will interact directly with students, parents and teachers in a variety of live programs and serve as speakers and mentors.  Students will complete video oral history projects on accomplished individuals in their own community, and will share their projects online.  Throughout the program, there will be a focus on college and careers, including the college application and financial aid process.  Goals: increased teacher effectiveness, improved student performance and college application rates, and increased parental involvement.    Special project features:  (1)  The HistoryMakers online digital archive, an interactive teaching tool providing searchable video interviews of 400 accomplished African Americans.  (2) A cadre of African American HistoryMakers who will serve as mentors, speakers and advisors to these high-need students. (3) Use of the Harvard Business school case study method to teach critical thinking skills, for the first time in middle and high schools.Partners:  Official partners:  C
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Implementing an Effective, Efficient, Research -Based  System of  Literacy Instructional Practices to Increase Academic Proficiency of All Middle School Students
Project Description: "Educators from seven low performing and rural middle schools will be trained in effective, efficient, research-based literacy strategies and activities that can be incorporated into their current content area reading and writing practices and thus imbedded across their curriculum.  The goal of the project is to increase all student's literacy and academic performance in all subject areas.  All students will benefit, including those in special education, those with low level reading ability, and those with limited English proficiency.  Teacher implementation is an integral focus of the project.  All educators involved will be trained in EBLI, Evidence Based Literacy Instruction, and will be provided with intensive continuing support through ongoing professional development and modeling/coaching of the strategies with their students in their classroom.  Refinement of teachers delivery of the strategies will be ongoing.  Paraprofessionals, trained and supported along with the teachers, will be hired in each school to work individually with students who are reading among in the lowest performing 20% in each school.  There will be schools receiving the EBLI instruction and others with similar demographics that will be in a control group; the control will receive instruction in the 4th year.  All students be assessed and data compiled from the MEAP, the state exam for Michigan, as well as the EXPLORE test for all 8th graders.  This is a precursor to the ACT exam, which is required for all 11th grade students in Michigan and assesses college readiness.     During the first year, software for teacher training and student instruction will be developed.  In the following years, this software will allow educators to receive a significant amount of training information online, decreasing the cost and time needed for training and providing individualized support for students in the computer lab.     "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: A Collaborative Framework for Enhancing Instruction Through Teacher Evaluation
Project Description: "The Collaborative Framework for Enhancing Instruction (CFEI) is a comprehensive ongoing teacher evaluation process which will be used in the Kenton County School District to enhance the quality of classroom instructional practices. The expected outcomes of implementation of the components of CFEI are increased quality of instructional practices in classrooms, enhanced the attitudes and behaviors of educators, and increased student performance. The implementation of the CFEI will be conducted by a team of Kenton County School District employees which will require ongoing training with over 60 principals, more than 800 teachers and impact over 14000 students.  The requested development i3 grant will fund the implementation and evaluation of the CFEI for the next five years as the Kenton County School District 1) finalizes a collaborative research based teacher evaluation instrument; 2) revitalizes the traditional  professional growth activities of teachers and principals; 3) facilitates teachers performing self-evaluations of their own instructional practices; and 4) collects data the quality of teacher instructional practices and provides professional development based on the actual needs of teachers. The evaluation of the CFEI will include two partners, PIRE (Pacific Institute for Research and Evaluation) and NKU (Northern Kentucky University).  The evaluation will use a quasi-experimental intervention control design to compare the impact of the CFEI on teacher and student outcomes in Kenton County to teacher and student outcomes in a neighboring county where the CFEI is not implemented. All the tools and activities for the CFEI will be accessible online to teachers and principals indefinitely throughout the project and thereafter, supports an on-going continuous teacher evaluation process utilizing  a teacher growth model."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Operation Reach Every Attainable Dream (Operation R.E.A.D.): The psychology of motivation will influence positive behavior in high needs students and produce achievement in persistently low performing schools
Project Description: "Operation R.E.A.D. is a motivational program to inspire struggling students. The program will have successfulpresenters, who can identify with each student?s challenge and empower them through motivation and positivereinforcement. The particulars of the method are to visit 12 of the bottom 5% schools in Georgia twice a monthfor one hour and a half session. The program will work with one hundred students in our experimental groupper school and they will be compared against the one hundred students in the control group per school theprogram does not work with. On the first visit per month the session will include three purpose drivenspeeches, Q&A time and particular one-on-one sessions. The second visit per month will focus on small groupinteractive; writing workshops, reading/english standards sessions, math standards sessions, science standardssessions, social studies standards sessions, personal surveys, sports challenges to teams, behavior/characterworkshops and attendance importance sessions. They will also be given continuum material, which will becomprised of, a motivational manual, DVD copies of each speech and life changing reading material.The goal of this program is to bring the dynamic effect of motivation to students in some of the bottom fivepercent schools, in the state of Georgia. Our methods will produce the want to, the desire, the proactive effort,the initiative, and the passion in every student that is necessary to achieve. As a result, this program willimprove student achievement, improve the graduation rate, improve parental involvement, increase teachermorale, reduce the drop out rate, reduce the discipline referrals, improve school safety, and ultimately assistschools in making Adequate Yearly Progress. We know that when motivation engages the psyche of students,it ignites every area of performance that positively changes their approach, and ultimately changes the entireculture of the school for the better."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The LCCS Building Out the Circle of Success

Applicant: The Lincoln Foundation for Performance Excellence
Project Title: SWAT:  School Wide Accelerated Transformation
Project Description: "Numerous in-depth studies have reached the same conclusion:  Organizations that invest in leadership development perform better than those that don't.'  The Center for Creative Leadership, Driving Performance: Why Leadership Development Matters in Difficult Times. (2008)This project combines three well proven techniques:  (1) the Baldrige process for organizational alignment and quality improvement, (2) systematic leadership assessment and development, and (3) action learning to put the information and techniques into practice to drive accelerated transformation and improvement. Using a rigorous combination of assessments and tools, the project will significantly improve the leadership capability of teachers and principals and equip them to work as a SWAT team to lead ongoing change to build a high achievement learning environment.  Based on the evidence in the corporate sector, we believe that effective leadership development, combined with Baldrige organizational alignment and a highly engaging climate will result in better school operations, improved financial metrics, and most importantly, increased student achievement, attendance and graduation rates. "

Project Title: S-ke:g Ha
Project Description: "S-ke:g Ha?icu Ma:cig?The Wisdom Project is an Investing in Innovation development project proposed forthe Tohono O?odham Nation is southern Arizona. S-ke:g Ha?icu Ma:cig means ?important knowledge.? TheWisdom Project is a high school completion and college readiness initiative that will serve the middle school andhigh school students of Indian Oasis ? Baboquivari School District (IOBUSD). Through the MetropolitanEducation Commission, a city/county collaboration, Tucson and Pima County will respond to the needs inIOBUSD. Youth and young adult school dropouts will resume their studies through alternative education whileJuvenile Detention Center youth will receive education services. A total of 1,000 students will be served by thisfive-year project. Major strategies include use of the College Board?s rigorous SpringBoard curriculum,improved instructional technology across the district, and postsecondary planning for students through theRegional College Access Center.For the cohort of 2008, Baboquivari High School had a four-year graduation rate of 39 percent, whichcharacterizes why it is designated as a Tier I school (among the lowest-performing 5 percent of high schools inArizona) and therefore must reform under federal requirements. Poverty, combined with the rural remoteness ofthe community together with technological disadvantages compared to students in urban areas, describe theschool district?s student body. The Wisdom Project is designed to transform BHS together with the BaboquivariMiddle School (BMS) and the IOBUSD alternative sites (one is the Juvenile Detention Center where youth havenot had access to school for the past two years) into high-performing schools, each with a rigorous and culturallyrelevantcurriculum and a college-going culture.The Wisdom partners include MEC, IOBUSD, the Tohono O?odham Nation, the College Board, theUniversity of Arizona, Tohono O?odham Community College, and Bridges Coaching and Consulting."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Multiple Early Literacies Development (MELD) Program

Applicant: The Museum of Science and Industry and Chicago Public Schools
Project Title: Institute for Quality Science Teaching
Project Description: "The Institute for Quality Science Teaching (IQST), a professional development program to enhance middle grade science teacher knowledge and skills, will improve classroom teaching and lead to increased student achievement. The Museum, in partnership with the Chicago Public Schools as an official partner and the Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT), seeks to expand participation in IQST to reach approximately 1,600 teachers serving 70,000 students. IQST engages middle grade science teachers in sustained professional development that: improves classroom science instruction by advancing teachers? science content knowledge, use of effective classroom strategies and integration of informal learning resources into their science instruction; improves student growth and achievement by enhancing their science conceptual knowledge, attitude towards science and inquiry skills; and builds a presence for science in schools by encouraging positive science-related interactions between students and teachers, teachers and their peers and teachers and administrators. Underprepared teachers serving high-need students will explore topics relevant to their science curriculum and return to the classroom with new ideas, greater confidence and the resources they need to make science engaging. Building on the project design implemented and evaluated by MSI over the last four years, IQST will also deepen the research related to student achievement by implementing a model that assesses student and teacher performance during and following participation in the program. This will enable the Museum to build upon its internal evaluation findings and to explore the impact of this model of sustained science teacher professional development on teacher content knowledge and attitude, teacher classroom practice, student classroom practice and ultimately its impact on student achievement."

Applicant: The Na'L Ctr on Education & the Economy
Project Title: Using Board Examination Systems to Greatly Increase College Readiness Among High-Need High School Students
Project Description: "The National Center on Education and the Economy (NCEE) will assist 4 high schools serving high-need andrural students in each of 10 states to implement the best Board Examination Systems used by the world?shighest performing countries that are available in English for use in American high schools. These powerfulinstructional systems?course syllabi, instructional materials, exams and teacher training?will be alignedwith the new Common Core State Standards. The purpose of the program is to greatly increase the proportionof high-need high school students who leave high school ready to do college-level work and therefore succeedin college. NCEE will provide intense support to these states that will lead to their beginning implementationin the 2011-12 school year and continue for an additional two years. NCEE has convened a TechnicalAdvisory Committee, composed of some of the nation?s leading cognitive scientists and psychometricians,who will take on the required technical work to: insure the Board Examination standards are aligned with theCommon Core, insure the Board Examination programs prepare students for college-level work withoutremediation, and set a cut score on the examinations that meet this standard. NCEE staff will work with stateleaders to make the necessary policy decisions and build support within the states, including convening aHigher Education Task Force to guide work on the alignment of high school and college policies to allowstudents who succeed to leave high school early or to stay in high school and prepare for selective colleges.The research and evaluation design will provide the states the information they will need to implement theseprograms statewide at the conclusion of the demonstration. This project will serve 28,480 students in 40 highneedand/or rural high schools in 10 states."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: New School Scholars
Project Description: "The New School Scholars (NSS) project addresses Competitive Preference Priority 6: Innovations thatSupport College Access and Success. Students build expectations and become prepared for college through 30months of coursework using rigorous, applied academic approaches found in selective colleges, providing theequivalent of 21 hours of college-aligned coursework, 9-14 hours of which bear college credit. The program isintensive, sustained, and delivered within the context of a single university, allowing for strong alignment tofreshman year expectations. We are thus able to effectively identify and remediate academic issues beforestudents enroll in their entry-level college courses towards the end of the program.In addition to academic preparedness, students gain an understanding of college affordability, financialaid, college selection, and the college application process through a planned curriculum and activity sequenceinvolving students, parents, and guardians. This portion of the program incorporates available online managementresources to explore and manage the college application process, requires and supports completion of the FAFSAand at least one grant or scholarship application, and directly tracks and, where necessary, intervenes in eachstudent?s progress through the college application and financial aid process.Coupled with ?college knowledge? is a critical focus on career access and awareness so that students canbuild a personalized understanding of how to plan for and succeed in careers they may not otherwise haveenvisioned. Students gain experience in and understanding of options in the world of professional work throughwork site visits, seminars, and internships to help them chart their college choices with concrete goals in mind.These program elements are coupled with a peer support and tutoring network of current college students,a cohort leader with expertise in college access and success, targeted academic supports in writing, r... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: PreK-3rd Quality and Alignment Model (P3QAM) Validation Project
