Project Description: "The P3QAM (PreK-3rd Quality and Alignment Model) is an innovative and evidence-based approach to improving early outcomes by building a continuum of quality education for children from age three through third grade.  Currently in American education, preschool programs are completely disconnected from our elementary schools.  The P3QAM bolts them together by using aligned high standards, curricula and instruction with high quality assessments.  The result of this innovative reconception of early public education is improved outcomes for all children, especially those with high needs, including: increased 3rd grade academic achievement, accelerated academic growth PreK-3rd, reduced achievement gaps, reduced supplemental services for students, and improved social/emotional status for children.The P3QAM Validation Project is a multi-faceted initiative that aims to (1) complete a randomized control study of the P3QAM, producing strong evidence of its effectiveness and (2) establish practices, partnerships, and infrastructure for scale up of the P3QAM statewide. The P3QAM project design capitalizes on the assets of the individual partners while also creating an overall structure that allows for both validation and replication of the P3QAM.  Our partnership consists of The New School Foundation, a Seattle-based nonprofit that is a PreK-3rd pioneer; Bremerton School District, located in a working-class town, a thought leader and training hub for PreK-3rd in Washington; Toppenish School District, a predominantly Latino and Native American district in the center of our state, also a PreK-3rd early adopter; and Seattle School District, our state's largest district, whose leadership is deeply committed to PreK-3rd implementation, building on the success of the South Shore School. The P3QAM is grounded in evidence from the partners' work, and the Validation Project will be steered by this partnership so that P3QAM is implemented with high fidelity across our state."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Teacher Effectiveness and Certification Initiative (TEACh Initiative)
Project Description: "The research is clear ? having an effective teacher for consecutive years can close the persistent achievement gapfaced by poor and minority students. Despite the importance of effective teachers, virtually no preparationprogram requires teachers to demonstrate effectiveness based on the ability to increase student achievement inorder to receive certification and remain in the classroom. The New Teacher Project (TNTP) thereforeproposes to implement an effectiveness-based teacher preparation program, the Teacher Effectiveness andCertification (TEACh) Initiative, which draws on our research-backed Teaching Fellows Programs andPractitioner Teacher Programs to provide high need districts with a teacher pipeline that seamlessly spansactivities from recruitment to certification and only certifies teachers who have demonstrated effectiveness inthe classroom.Goal: Increase the number of demonstrably effective teachers in partner LEAs.Objective 1: By Year 5 of the grant period, recruit, select, and train 2,450 - 3,300 new teachers who have thepotential to be effective by 2015.Objective 2: By Year 5 of the grant period, prepare 1,850-2,475 new teachers using a student achievementfocused certification curriculum.Objective 3: Each year of the 5-year grant period, certify and retain only teachers who have demonstratedeffectiveness in the classroom.Outcome: By Year 5 of the grant period, an estimated 253,000- 337,000 high-need students experiencesignificant achievement gainsOfficial partners include Chicago Public Schools, DC Public Schools, Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools,and Fort Worth Independent School District. We will name two other partner districts prior to the grant award."

Applicant: The New York Institute for Special Education
Project Title: Building the Capacity of Teachers and Principals to Dramatically Improve the Literacy and Critical Thinking Skils of High-Needs Elementary School Students
Project Description: "Young children in poverty especially need both overall language skills related to vocabulary and conceptualworld knowledge and the literacy-based skills of letter knowledge and letter-sound correspondence.Cornerstone Literacy is an interactive model of reading that includes depth and focus while accommodatingstate and national standards. The NYISE Cornerstone Literacy program presently supports 40 elementaryschools in two urban districts.Our professional development model is grounded in site-based teaching and learning and follows a cycle of adultlearning opportunities. The major activities supporting the development of highly effective literacy teachersand principals are: (1) development of district communities of practice, which involves opening up effectiveclassrooms for district-wide study; (2) lesson study, which involves teachers and principals coming together toscrutinize the interaction of the children with a teacher?s lesson plan; (3) in-depth weekly coaching of coachesin the CL framework, using a variety of techniques; (4) ongoing school site visits that build the capacity ofprincipal and teacher leaders to identify the supports adults need to increase effectiveness; (5) annual schoolreviews that measure school effectiveness against a set of research-based indicators; and (6) two three-dayand two four-day Cornerstone Institutes where school staff convene in professional study informed bysuccesses and challenges.By the end of the grant period, (1) at least eight of Cornerstone?s full-time trained Literacy Fellows will remain ineach school district, supported on their payrolls, to provide ongoing support and a liaison to CornerstoneLiteracy; (2) ?Open laboratory? schools will be open to support the scaling up of CL regionally and nationally;and (3) Cornerstone Literacy will be a largely fee-driven nonprofit professional development provider."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Northern New Mexico Network for Rural Education
Project Title: Project Journey: Expanding Access and Opportunities for Transformative Learning
Project Description: "Project Journey: Expanding Access and Opportunities for Transformative LearningProject DescriptionProject Journey has been designed to move the education paradigm from teacher-centric to learner-centric to support students to learn within the contexts that are most relevant to them. Project objectives are designed to address place-, project-, and technology-based learning as individual or integrated experiences. The major activities are (1) mentoring teachers and students in complex project-based experiences at the Valles Caldera National Preserve and supporting them to implement project-based learning in local place-based settings within Northern NM school districts (29), (2) increasing teacher content knowledge and pedagogical skills, (3) developing a learner-centric Cloud that provides intelligent on demand access to ever increasing Web-based data, resources, tools, and supports, and (4) enhancing e-learning opportunities for teachers and students with the resources of the learner-centric Cloud. In five years Project Journey will scale from 16 rural school districts to 29 districts to statewide and will open portions of the project to national access. This translates to a target of more than 9,000 students in the Northern Network and 39,200 students in the state."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The High Impact Tutoring OASIS Program (HITOP) intervention for increasing academic achievement of high-need students in low-performing schools
Project Description: "The High Impact OASIS Tutoring Program (HITOP) will increase reading performance among high need k-3 students through collaboration with LEAs in six states. HITOP is a new program that uses lessons learned from OASIS' 20-year tutoring program. Through the existing OASIS program, older adults are trained and supported to provide one-on-one tutoring for one session each week for the entire school year to high-need students. The model is used by 98 school districts and has achieved positive results. HITOP will be designed to help turn around persistently low-performing schools with a targeted approach to reform by: 1) increasing instructional time for core academic subjects with one-on-one, multi-session per week tutoring, and 2) integrating student tutoring supports in the existing school model to address non-academic barriers to student achievement such as non-attendance and number of discipline referrals. OASIS and its official LEA partners will recruit, train and support 3,551 older adult tutor assignments assisting 7,102 academically high-need students 2-3 times per week. As a result, the students? reading will improve through increased comprehension, and an evidence base and model will be in place to take to schools nationwide. HITOP will use a landmark research study by Washington University in St. Louis of the Experience Corps tutoring program for the reasonable hypotheses that student achievement in the primary grades is positively impacted by a high-dosage relationship with tutor that utilizes a language-focused curriculum that is consistent across schools, districts, and states. Washington University and Battelle Centers for Public Health Research & Evaluation will conduct an independent evaluation of HITOP. The independent evaluation is a well-designed experimental (randomly assigned groups, post-test only) research model that uses alternative measures of student achievement (reading comprehension, promotion, attendance, disciplinary referrals)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Reading Recovery: Scaling Up What Works
Project Description: "Reading Recovery is a highly-effective, targeted approach to school reform focusing on first grade studentsexperiencing difficulty learning to read and write, typically the lowest 20% of the class. The overarching goalof this proposal is intensive, long-term professional development for teachers who will provide one-to-one,short-term (12-20 weeks), 30-minute lessons each day with first graders to accelerate their learning such thatthey catch up with their peers and close the achievement gap. Although Reading Recovery has over 20 years ofexperience working with struggling readers across the U.S., this proposal offers a unique and innovativeopportunity to specifically target high-need schools and provide trained Reading Recovery teachers forstudents in the lowest-achieving schools. Specifically, our objectives are to: (1) train 15 new teacher leaders inYear 1 to serve underrepresented areas of the U.S. with a high population of schools meeting the criteria forAbsolute Priority 4; (2) train 750 new Reading Recovery teachers each year for a total of 3,750 teachers; (3)trained Reading Recovery teachers will work with more than 90,000 Reading Recovery students (.5 FTE) andover 400,000 students in classrooms or Title I small group instruction during the other half of their day for atotal of nearly 500,000 students; (4) conduct a rigorous outside project evaluation including both experimentaland qualitative methodologies; and (5) provide high-quality oversight for the project orchestrating activitiesacross the 16 universities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Mathematics Coaching and Its Impact on Teacher Effectiveness and Student Learning in Low-Performing Rural and Urban School.
Project Description: "The Mathematics Coaching Program housed in the College of Education and Human Ecology at The Ohio State University is applying for a Development Grant in partnership with seven LEAs in rural settings (Rossford, Lisbon, Mapleton, Northwest, Perrysburg, Elgin and Elida), three LEAs in small city settings (Findlay, Fairfield and Bedford) and three LEAs in large urban settings (Columbus and Toledo).  The project will involve 30 coaches, 40 schools, 600 teachers and 15,000 students.  Project Objectives and Activities:  (a) provide high quality implementation data regarding the fidelity of the coaching innovation;  (b) assess the impact of the Mathematics Coaching Program (MCP) on mathematics teachers' knowledge of mathematics and instructional practices; (c) assess the impact of the Mathematics Coaching Program on students' academic achievement in mathematics; and, (d) design, develop, and determine the efficacy of technological enhancements in teaching, learning and coaching, and promote scalability and sustainability in the program elements after the program support is completed.  Project Outcomes:  (a) increase the percentage of effective teachers of mathematics in participating LEAs;  (b) increase student mathematics achievement in participating LEAs; and, (c) decrease the achievement gap in each LEA's subgroups of poverty, minority, disability, gender, and limited English proficiency; and, (d) increase accessibility to and use of the coaching model and decrease costs with technology.	Official partners include the OSU Office of Technology and Enhanced Learning, the Ohio Resource Center, OSU Regional Campuses, the Battelle Memorial Institute, Metro Early College STEM High School and the Ohio Department of Education."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Partnership for Los Angeles Schools
Project Title: Partnership for Los Angeles Schools: Transforming L.A.
Project Description: "The Partnership for Los Angeles Schools (Partnership) is applying for $3.86 million i3 development grantfunding to transform two of L.A.?s persistently low performing schools, position the Partnership for growthover the next three years by adding 6-8 low performing schools within our three Family of Schools, and tovalidate the effectiveness and scalability our transformation model which will facilitate replication in otherlarge urban school districts.Objectives and Outcomes:1. Transform Florence Griffith-Joyner Elementary and Carver Middle School     a. Implement the six components of the Partnership?s comprehensive Transformation Model. This includes     dramatically improving the quality of the school?s culture, leadership, classroom instruction, interventions and     acceleration, family and community engagement, and school design and operations.     b. Dramatically increase the proficiency rates of all students in English language arts, mathematics, science,     and history-social science.2. Grow the # of schools and students the Partnership serves over the next 3 years of the grant.     a. Through the LAUSD Public School Choice Initiative, increase the number of school we serve in our three     Family of Schools from 15 to 23 and increase student enrollment from 19,500 to approximately 30,000.     b. Improve the graduation rate of students in our Family of Schools and increase the percentage of students     prepared for college and career.3. Validate our Transformation Model     a. WestEd will evaluate the effectiveness of our transformation model by documenting and assessing each     component of the model.     b. Utilize evaluation documentation and results to demonstrate scalability and replicability in other large     urban school districts."

Project Title: Southwest Excellence in Literacy Leadership (SWELL)
Project Description: "The Pinon Project will be the lead applicant for the Southwest Excellence in Literacy Leadership (SWELL) partnership whose mission is to narrow the achievement gap between struggling high-need children and families and those who are thriving in this vast remote region known as the Four Corners (Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, and Arizona) . The SWELL project will utilize 28 Literacy and Academic Coaches to serve 100 teachers who will in turn serve 3,015 children in year 1 and as many as 4,500 within the 5-year grant period. This will include 20 Head Start and pre-school classrooms, and 80 K-6th grade classrooms.SWELL Project will improve student academic growth and narrow the achievement gap by addressing Absolute Priority 1?Innovations That Support Effective Teachers and Principals. This will be accomplished by providing intensive professional development to existing teachers, teacher aides, and principals in a three-level model. Principals will be actively involved in all training to ensure they also are knowledgeable and skilled in providing highly-effective support and supervision of these teachers in servicing this high-need population. Participants will enter at their current level of education and be given the chance to move up the ?Pathway of Highly Effective Educators,? to becoming a highly-effective educator. Individual Professional Development Plans (IPDP) will determine a baseline level for each teacher or teacher aide, including novice, becoming skilled, and skilled. Multiple measures of effectiveness will determine progress on the Pathway, with data on student growth as a significant factor."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: The Pathway to The Promise
Project Description: "The Pittsburgh Promise (The Promise), in conjunction with its partners at the Pittsburgh Public School District (PPS) and the Community College of Allegheny County (CCAC) will create The Pathway to The Promise (The Pathway) designed to improve PPS' low-performing schools, close achievement gaps, decrease dropout rates, increase graduation rates, and improve college access and completion rates.  The Pathway is a bold initiative to ensure that PPS students can fulfill their dreams of completing high school and pursuing further education at a college, university, or trade school. The project has three components:  increase student achievement and prepare them for college, eliminate financial burdens for post-secondary education, and ensure that students have the necessary supports in college to graduate.  PPS will has created Promise Readiness Corps (PRC), a team of highly-effective teachers collectively responsible for supporting students transitioning into high school and ensuring their achievement in 9th and 10th grades.Next, after the students enter 11th grade, they are introduced to The Pittsburgh Promise; a scholarship program that commits to pay for qualifying graduates' college experience.  The lure and promise of such support is great incentive for college completion.  The scholarship program is available to all graduates of the PPS and charters, regardless of financial need or income.  The Promise will pay up to $10,000 per student each year for up to four years to help with expenses related to tuition, fees, books, dorm, and meal plans. Finally, once students enter college, an immersion program helps buttress the students' experience by aligning them with similarly situated students and gives them necessary guidance and support to follow through on their post-secondary opportunity."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Reframing Access and Equity: A Proposal to Expand Posse's Impact in America
Project Description: "Posse is requesting a $10,000,000 5-year validation grant to allow it to grow to scale and serve thousands more students from the public school districts in its 7 current cities (Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, D.C., L.A., Miami, N.Y.) and expand to 2 new cities. Posse is currently speaking with Houston Independent School District, and hopes to solidify this partnership by July. HISD will likely be Posse's official partner. Between 2010 and 2015, Posse will assist about 75,000 students across the country in their pursuit of a college degree. Each year, Posse identifies hundreds of underrepresented students for admission to selective institutions using its distinctive Dynamic Assessment Process (DAP). Using nontraditional forums to evaluate potential, Posse expands the definition of student achievement and preparedness to include non-cognitive traits. Once students are selected, Posse supports its Scholars throughout college and into the workforce through its Pre-Collegiate Training Program (PCT), Campus Program and Career Program. To grow to scale and expand its data set, Posse is working to attain the following. Goal 1: Increase college access for underserved youth by expanding its program and sharing data with educators on the use of non-cognitive data in identifying student potential. Posse will expand DAP and Posse Access (PA), which gives partners access to applications of unselected finalists to consider for admission. In 2010, DAP and PA will serve 480 and 1,000 high school seniors, and by 2015, those numbers will grow to 600 and 5,000 respectively. Goal 2: Increase college completion rates for underserved groups by expanding the program and sharing best practices to increase success rates for urban youth. By 2015, Scholars participating in PCT will be 640 and the number on campus will be 2,240. As Posse grows, so will its data set, which represents a student population that is 80 percent black and Hispanic and 80 percent high need."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: The Regents of New Mexico State University
Project Title: Scaling Up Mathematics Success
Project Description: "The purpose of the SUMS project is to validate a university-public schools partnership model that hassuccessfully built the capacity of a small number of high-need districts in New Mexico to produce increasedand sustainable mathematics achievement for all students.SUMS is based on 10 years of fundedresearch, beginning with an NSF-funded Teacher Enhancement grant which resulted in dramatically increasedmath achievement in a 94% Hispanic,100% free lunch district with 60% LEP/ELL students.Later fundingprovided opportunities to address all levels of two additional districts? organizational system and enhanced theSUMS model and tools. Activities include learning to use high-quality standards and assessments, translatingstudent learning data into classroom practice, augmenting teacher knowledge of mathematics content andprocesses, and providing support and protocols for teacher and leader Professional Learning Communities(PLCs).This proposal expands this promising model to rural districts in a state which is 53% Hispanic,34%ELL,11% Native American and first in rural child poverty. SUMS expected outcomes include:Successfulvalidation of the SUMS model through an extensive external evaluation and verified by three outcomemeasures 1)statistically significant increased student achievement and growth in mathematics learning andnarrowing of the achievement gap; 2) increased effectiveness of teaching practice,and 3) demonstratedinstructional leadership in math education by principals and administrators. These outcomes will be obtained bya capacity building model that supports: 1) improved alignment and quality of standards-based curriculum andassessment, 2) enhanced teaching quality and intentional teacher collaboration in learning mathematics contentand standards, pedagogy, and assessment through Math and Content Specialists, and 3) administrative andcommunity involvement activities focused on meaningful support of student mathematics achievement."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California
Project Title: Developing and Supporting Innovative Assessments for College and Career Readiness
Project Description: "The UCLA National Center for Research on Evaluations, Standards and Student Testing (CRESST) is submitting a Development Grant proposal to the Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Program in partnership with the Los Angeles Small Schools Center (LASSC) and Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD) Local District 4 (LD 4) to address Absolute Priority 3 ? Innovations That Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments.This project supports college access and success through the development and use of an innovative, standards based assessment system to measure and support student progress toward college readiness. Principal project activities include: a) Establishing end-of-course and high school graduation portfolio requirements as the conceptual foundation for an integrated, coherent assessment system; b) Creating instructional/assessment pathways through the development and use of high-quality, content-rich, formative assessments that systematically measure and support grade 9-12 students? development of expected end-of-course and high school graduation capability; c) Demonstrating replicable strategies for building community-based, support networks; d) Developing and implementing accessible formative assessments and supporting the learning needs of limited English proficient students and students with disabilities.The project will directly impact over 8,200 students in 20 small high schools and learning communities within larger school complexes. These schools are all situated in areas of high crime and poverty."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California
Project Title: Improving Students' Academic Writing: Building a Bridge to College and Workplace Success
Project Description: "Project Title: Improving Students? Academic Writing: Building a Bridge to College and Workplace SuccessThe California Writing Project is seeking a Development i3 grant to build on its classroom-tested, results- basedprofessional development and research program?Improving Students? Academic Writing (ISAW)? toexpand support to 42 low-performing urban and rural schools across California. ISAW has four overarchinggoals: (a) demystifying the teaching and learning of analytical writing and critical reading, the currency ofcollege success; (b) strategizing how teachers can make analytical writing an integral component of a highschool curriculum by focusing on student improvement; (c) accelerating the analytical writing improvement ofall students grades 9-12, especially under-represented students and English learners; and (d) fosteringcollaboration among high school, community college, and four-year university teachers to move students alonga pathway of academic preparation that leads to success in and beyond high school. Professional learning willinclude summer institutes, school year inservice and study groups, embedded assessment, and curriculumdevelopment. Participating teachers will learn to make effective of the ISAW Analytical Writing Improvementassessment tools and map their instruction and lesson design to College- and Career-Ready Standards.Teachers and students will make strategic use of technology?for composing and revising writing, for creatingmultimedia, multimodal projects, for researching and evaluating sources, and for creating local, regional, andstatewide learning and publication communities. Expected outcomes include improved teaching andassessment of analytical writing across grades 9-12 and improved student performance as measured bypre/post essays on a recognized assessment of analytical writing, the University of California?s AnalyticalWriting Placement Examination."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA
Project Title: LEAP (Learning through Explorations Applications and Practice)
Project Description: "The University of California at Berkeley and Arizona State University and consultants propose to develop an 8thgrade Algebra-based, Earth-Space-Physical Science Course. This project entitled ?LEAP -- Learning throughExplorations, Applications and Practice? -- will utilize award wining Modeling Instruction, Hands-OnUniverse, and will explicitly and carefully integrate Algebra in the science course and science in the algebracourse. The proposal is to the Development Program of the I3 program, and addresses absolute priority?Innovations that support Teachers and Principals,? and competitive priority ?Innovation that serve schools inRural LEA's.? We propose to develop and assess a system that will significantly improve the contentknowledge and pedagogical knowledge of teachers in schools, from rural to urban settings, with pairs of mathand science teachers from each school in the development phase. Approximately 30 teachers and 3600students will be served in this development effort. We hypothesize that this improvement will significantlyincrease student achievements, in 8th grade science and math. The target students/teachers are a sample inmostly Title 1 schools of rural and urban Arizona, Mississippi and Texas, and in suburban schools in the SanFrancisco Bay Area.Teachers of math or science in the middle schools often lack majors in either of these subjects. and tend todepend almost exclusively on the adopted textbook. . The math textbooks rarely demonstrate that math isinteresting, useful and applied to solving problems of science. The science textbooks in the middle schoolsusually avoid mathematics and therefore avoid involving students in important steps of solving problems ofscience. Few of these teachers are aware of how to implement ?How People Learn? (Modeling is one of theinputs into the NRC document). Modeling Instruction improves students' test scores. LEAP endeavors to be atransformative system for US education."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California
Project Title:
The STEM Career Development Exploration System: Building Student Knowledge and Skills
for STEM College and Career Success
Project Description: "This proposal for a Development Grant, submitted by the UCLA Center for Research on Evaluation, Standards,and Student Testing (CRESST) focuses on The STEM Career Development Exploration System (SCDEX), aninnovative virtual tool to provide career information, guidance, and support integrated with targeted skillsinstruction and practice. The project will meet absolute priority 3 by implementing standards-basedinstructional and career/college exploration activities to support both content areas learning and college-goingoutcomes for all students.SCDEX is a computer-based system designed to support interacting levers to student STEM success and access.Components include: virtual career exploration, video mentorship, STEM learning games, and interactivecommunication platforms. The goals of the project are (a) continue to expand the tool?s development andrefine its components, (b) pilot test the refined system, (c) implement and empirically field test its use in alarge-scale afterschool program, and (d) to scale up the system to broader use. Beyond the broad project goals,the specific objectives of the SCDEX system are increased: student interest/engagement in STEM learning,majors, and careers; student self-efficacy in STEM areas; knowledge of STEM career pathways; studentmath/science learning and achievement; and student selection of STEM majors/career paths.A total of 2000-2300 grade 5 students will use SCDEX during the field test phase, with it made available to anadditional 40,000 students during the final scale up year. Partners include LAUSD?s LA?s BEST afterschoolprogram and UC Davis (Professor Jamal Abedi ? external evaluator)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California
Project Title: UC Creating Access through Records Evaluation and Services
Project Description: "A transcript can be a powerful tool for improving student readiness for college, particularly when coursetakinginformation is evaluated for all students against a set of common, grade-level benchmarks. However, ascurrently conducted in schools, transcript evaluation is laborious and seldom completed for all students. Thedearth of high-quality, easily accessible, consistent information for all students hampers efforts by schools andpolicymakers to increase access by more students to the kind of high quality, rigorous coursework necessary forcollege preparation. As a result, families and students face significant barriers in understanding and accessing thecoursework that will prepare students for a range of postsecondary options.In partnership with a consortium of 19 public high schools and a number of college preparation programs,the University of California proposes to improve schools? and programs? use of the unique college preparationand course completion data supplied by the University?s Transcript Evaluation Service (TES) so that morestudents are aware of and prepared for college, and so that schools can address systemic barriers guided by theTES data and through robust data partnerships with higher education institutions. Our hypothesis is that if allstudents ? particularly those with high needs and those attending rural schools - have access to authoritativeinformation about their progress toward college eligibility, and if school personnel can effectively integrate thisinformation into their student advising and course-planning activities, then approximately 34,000 more studentswill be prepared for college, despite the barriers imposed by school budgets and the decline in the number ofschool counselors."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California
Project Title: iSTEM:  Innovating STEM education through real science
Project Description: "The key innovative aspects of the University of California, Davis (UCD) iSTEM project at West Sac Prep are:o	Inspiring all learners through rigorous project-based science investigationso	Engaging all learners through the provision of ubiquitous technologyo	Developing 'connected teachers' and increasing parental 'digital literacy' through an integrated change     'eCapability Management' Program.  Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: o	Increasing high school completion rate from 75% in surrounding community to 100% at West Sac Prepo	Increasing college eligibility rates from 22% in surrounding community to 100% at West Sac Prep  o	Increasing participation in real-life, hands-on science from 10% to 100% Targeted number of students:  420 of whom 95% qualify as 'high need' students Special Project Features: Achieving real-world learning via 4G connectivity; a pioneering 'College Entry Tool', transforming physical spaces through an 'iSTEM Innovation Hub'"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California
Project Title: Meeting High Standards in Science and Literacy: Extending the Seeds of Science/Roots of Reading Curriculum to Middle School
Project Description: "In this Development Grant proposed to the I3 fund, the Lawrence Hall of Science at the University of California, Berkeley, along with a consortium of partner school districts, will field test, implement and evaluate a year-long middle school, inquiry-based Earth and Space Science curriculum focused on learning deep science content while supporting students' disciplinary literacy abilities (science reading, science writing, and scientific discourse). This project addresses the urgent need for middle school curriculum materials that (a) support the implementation of high standards in science and literacy; and (b) support access to deep science content for all learners, in particular English language learners and students who are reading below grade level. The Earth and Space Science curriculum will be the first year of a three-year middle school program that extends from the effective Seeds of Science/Roots of Reading elementary curriculum, an innovative integration of science and literacy."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California Berkeley
Project Title: I3: Informed, Involved, Inspired
Project Description: "This five-year I3 Development project will increase the success of high school students, particularly underrepresented students and English learners, in the academically rigorous courses required to be admitted to California Post secondary education.  Five schools with more than 2,400 students will be served.  Hispanic and African-American students comprise more than two-thirds of the student body population in these schools.  A majority of the student body population is socio-economically disadvantaged and three-out-of-ten are English language learners.This project is a collaborative effort of the University of California at Berkeley's Academic Achievement Program, Educational Guidance Center, and Professional Development Program who have more than ten years experience working individually with a few of the identified schools.  This project provides an opportunity to bring together college counseling, teacher coaching, tutorial support, outreach, and enrichment activities together in a coordinated effort that will change the culture of the schools, particularly the culture of the academically rigorous courses - so that underrepresented students will be full participants in these college-track classes.  Additionally, the project will focus attention on courses that prepare students for success in courses relevant to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Participating schools have predominantly African American and/or Hispanic student body populations with significant numbers of English Language learners and students on reduced/free lunch programs.  Schools will provide opportunities for teacher coaches to work closely with teachers in their classrooms and provide incentives for their students to attend after-school tutorial sessions.  Schools will also work closely with project college counselors to identify potential college-going students as well as students needing additional support to meet the high standards in academically rigorous courses."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of California Santa Cruz
Project Title: UC CollegePath
Project Description: "The University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC), Division of Student Affairs, presents this Development proposal with the goal to test the effectiveness, scalability, and sustainability of successful face-to-face college preparation programs when replicated in blended virtual learning environments. Using UC online mathematics and college/career knowledge courses-housed at UC CollegePath?-adding CyberTutors, academic coordinators, and student iPortfolios, we hypothesize outcomes in mathematics achievement and college/career knowledge to be measured at least equal to face-to-face environments. To achieve the objectives, we will work with 400 students (200 treatment, 200 comparison) to increase instructional time in mathematics; improve grades; increase CST math scores; increase self-regulated learning; increase college/career knowledge; and provide support to students from knowledgeable adults. To this end, activities include providing services for 400 students for four years (9th -12th grade); beta testing an upgraded UC CollegePath? as an open resource site; distributing current and new content via the California K12 High Speed Network; and exploring scalability and sustainability options to reach 500,000 students. As a special project feature, we seek to disrupt the pattern of descending achievement rates and college preparation outcomes for the hardest to serve by investing directly in students, connecting them to high quality open resources to use independently, regardless of the socio-demographic and achievement profiles of their families, schools, or communities. The official partner LEA is Independence High School, East Side Union High School District. The Program Improvement technical partner is the California Department of Education. The scalability partners are the public California K12 High Speed Network (K12HSN) and private sector Learning Mate Pvt. Ltd.."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: The Regents of the University of Calilfornia
Project Title: Scaling Up Success: Raising Academic Achievement through Integrated Science and Literacy Instruction for Elementary Grades
Project Description: "This Validation Grant proposed to the Investing in Innovation Fund will support implementation of the Seeds of Science/Roots of Reading integrated curriculum in upper elementary grades 4-5 in Massachusetts. The project will invest in teacher professional development and supply science curriculum materials for classrooms in order to raise the academic achievement of participating students, particularly English language learners. This project addresses the urgent need for provision of science curriculum materials that (a) support the implementation of high standards, including the new Common Core Standards for English Language Arts and Literacy (released in draft form, March 2010) and the National Academy of Science's forthcoming Conceptual Framework for New Science Education Standards; and (b) support access to deep science content for all learners, in particular English language learners. The project focuses on Absolute Priority 3 and Competitive Preference Priorities 6 and 7."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: The Regents of the University of Michigan
Project Title: Youth Empowerment and Equitable Mathematics Literacy Instruction as Organizing Tools for Changing Regional Cultures Around STEM
Project Description: "Educators from University of Michigan and Washtenaw Intermediate School District, in partnership with theAlgebra Project (AP) and the Young Peoples? Project (YPP), propose building a regional network?asystem? of nationally-networked, diverse learning communities focused on equitable instruction inmathematics. The group intends to utilize a newly established Secondary Mathematics Laboratory, initiallytaught by Bob Moses, founder of the Algebra Project, and unpacked by Dean Deborah Loewenberg Ball, anoted mathematics education researcher, as a site for cross-role and cross-age collaboration. The group plansto support equitable and innovative mathematics instruction conducted by teams at three restructured settingsthat have emerged after two local high schools did not make AYP for six consecutive years through thedevelopment of teachers, youth leaders, and ?postbaccalaureate fellows?? new mathematics teachers placedon innovative instructional teams, and apprenticing with a focus on equity, innovation, and leadership. Thegroup will also expand and strengthen Young People?s Project after-school efforts in order to mobilize localcommunities around quality education and mathematical literacy. The proposal includes participation in aETI-led national-level evaluation of the Student-Driven Learning Culture network?including Algebra Projectsites across the nation, as well as evaluation by a local university-based team. The proposal arises out of afour-year regional conversation. Project Title: Reinvesting Intellectual Capital in Higher Education (RICHqE)
Project Description: "We propose a new paradigm for addressing current problems in education drawing on knowledge of the natural world and envisioning schools as 'super-organisms,' communities of adaptive individuals who have diverse skills and perspectives and who share a common goal.  Our organic model relies on the collective intelligence of all members of the community and allows everyone to contribute to overall solutions.The RICHqE (Reinvesting Intellectual Capital in Higher Education) project will recruit second-career STEM professionals from business, industry, military and government sectors, and offer four options to contribute to school reform: 1) licensed secondary school teachers, 2) student advocates, 3) content experts, or 4) data specialists.All participants will complete introductory classes and field experiences during their first semester to provide a common knowledge base.  They will participate in specialized training tailored to their chosen option.  For participants seeking teaching credentials (Option I), there is a streamlined route to teacher licensure including extensive co-teaching in partner schools coupled with graduate-level coursework.  Participants in Option 2 will receive training and engage in field experiences that prepare them to support and advise high school students to increase graduation rates and prepare them for college.  Option 3 will prepare participants to use their STEM expertise to enhance extant high school courses, create new curricula, and design summer enrichment academies for high school students.  Participants in Option 4 will expand  their abilities to analyze and interpret data, and assist schools in data use for decisions-making and program development.  All participants will become part of the collective cohort, who will provide an opportunity to participate in an online community where best practices can be shared, problems can be discussed and solved, and ideas can be incubated.  This online community will include both alumn... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"

Applicant: The Regents of the University of New Mexico
Project Title: Data Matters: Innovations for Student Success
Project Description: "We propose a two state initiative that provides training and support for principals and teachers in rural school districts to access, understand and use their achievement data in ways that impact the belief systems and instructional practices in the classroom to improve student outcomes.The focus of the project is rural districts and schools in New Mexico and Georgia that serve significant numbers of students with disabilities (SWD) and limited English proficient (LEP) students.Goal 1: Increase school principals' ability to access and  use student achievement data from multiple assessment sources.Goal 2: Increase principals' capacity to work with teachers to access and use student achievement data from multiple assessment sources.Goal 3. Increase principals' capacity to work with teachers to examine belief systems regarding expectations for achievement for SWD and LEP students and develop expectations for achievement for all students that will be provided to staff, parents and community.Goal 4. Increase principals' capacity to work with teacher teams to use their data to change practices that result in increased achievement.Partners in this project will be the Georgia Leadership Institute for School Improvement, the NM Office of Education Accountability and rural districts in NM and GA.This project includes an evaluation plan and two value-added results are expected. The first is the development of a system of measuring how rural principals and teachers collaborate to design and implement a blueprint to close achievement gaps; the second is the development of measures of impact of instructional change in classrooms.This project combines data analysis with two key school improvement levers - changing beliefs about student achievement and changing instructional practices. We use technology to bridge distance and we challenge the status quo by strengthening the human capital in rural districts. When we are successful we will change outcomes for students."

Project Title: Academic Coaching: (Re-) Centering Resilience for High Risk, High Need Students
Project Description: "The Renaissance Education Group, Inc. seeks to establish Academic Coaching: (Re-) Centering Resilience for High Risk, High Need Students Project with the US Department of Education as a demonstration  project to support the needs of high risk and high need youth. The proposed  project  provides program  participants with academic skill development that is focused on the targeted areas of mastery for the NC battery of End of Course exams, test preparation for college entrance exams and testing simulation, and a program of academic coaching. As such, the coaching program is to include career development, test strategies and study skills, and persistence skills to promote academic resilience. In addition, as the results are evaluated for effectiveness, a training program for educational support staff is deduced and a training program for use with high risk students is developed. The proposed project will advance a structured, research-based coaching methodology, tailored for use with high school students. This development grant proposal responds to the invitational requirements: Absolute Priority # 3: Innovations that complement the implementation of high standards and quality assessments, and its activities address Competitive Preference Priority # 6: Innovations that support college access and Competitive Preference Priority # 8: Innovations that serve schools in rural LEA's.Project objectives involve a regional partnership with a consortium of schools and using the coaching model of academic intervention, this project seeks to develop, test, and disseminate an evidence based strategy for educational practitioners in faith-based and community-based organizations to increase their ability to provide educational support that is aligned with state standards."

Project Title: The Future Leaders Institute: (Re-) Creating the Road  to Mastery for High Need, High Risk Male Students in Rural Communities
Project Description: "The Renaissance Education Group, Inc. seeks to establish The Future Leaders Institute with the US Department of Education, as a demonstration project to support the needs of high risk and high need youth, specifically male students, in rural communities. The proposed project provides program participants with a program of leadership development, career exploration, college knowledge, and financial literacy training, with a character education and service learning component, and a work experience opportunity that mirrors the career assessments provided to program participants in their Personal Futures Plan. Finally, participants work on experiential learning projects to increase critical thinking skills, teamwork skills, project management skills, and communication skills - to foster leadership. The project goal is to create a program of leadership development that promotes resilience, as measured by an  increase in academic performance, persistence to graduation, and intent to engage in post secondary options for male participants in economically distressed rural communities. The proposed project will advance a structured, research-based leadership training program tailored for use with high school students. Formal leadership development training has gained popularity for some time, yet, systematic approaches to foster leadership and measuring its impact on academic and social integration has yet to be applied. More especially, its benefits and usefulness as an approach, along with specific content driven activities, has yet to be measured for effect on academic performance. As such, this project is proposed as a development project for consideration, and includes a rigorous evaluation strategy to deduce the same. "
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Turnaround through Charter Impact: Its Not a Coin Flip
Project Description: "For the last six years, the Renaissance Schools Fund (RSF) has been the joint partner to Chicago Public Schools (CPS) on its overall turnaround strategy.  We have designed the CPS new schools selection process and have invested more than $30 million to launch 67 new public schools. Through this work, we developed a methodology for selection and investment that has led us to launch high performing school operators and grow them into multi-school networks.  Going forward, with i3 funds, the Renaissance Schools Fund will leverage best practice from the fields of academia, authorizing, and private investment to take our methodology to the next level.  The implementation of this methodology will prove that charter performance is not a ?coin flip,? but rather, that we can actively grow a consistently high-performing, sustainable charter sector.The methodology will involve four phases: 1) a right-to-compete screen: preliminary academic performance review; 2) extensive due diligence and authorization (academics, financials, management team, business plan); 3) initial investment decisions and establishment of performance milestones; and 4) annual performance-based actions (investment releases/adjustments/closure recommendations.) In the course of our five year grant, we will prove this methodology through the launch of a portfolio of 40 consistently high performing, sustainable schools serving 20,000 students in the city?s high-need communities.  We will integrate our method seamlessly into the CPS authorization system.  In partnership with our project evaluator, CREDO, we will codify the methodology to create a useful tool for charter authorizers and investors that will raise the quality bar for charter and other public schools across the country."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: The Research Foundation of State University of New York
Project Title: Early College High Schools

Applicant: The Research Foundation of State University of New York @ SUNY College of Technology at Canton
Project Title: Liberty Partnership Program (Dropout Prevention) Enhancement
The Expeditionary Learning Model
Project Description: "A growing body of research demonstrates that students learn more deeply if they are engaged in activities that require applying classroom-gathered knowledge to real-world problems, and when they take part in projects that require sustained engagement and collaboration (National Staff Development Council, 2002; Center for Research on the Education of Students at Risk, 2002).  After concentrated research, interviews, and surveying, the Expeditionary Learning Model demonstrated this practice as well as demonstrated a track record of success in improving reading and math proficiencies among minority sub-group learners, learners from low-socioeconomic backgrounds, and English Language Learners (ELL), as well as exceeding rigorous state academic standards.  TRS believes that the successful implementation of the Expeditionary Learning (EL) Model will be an effective intervention for struggling students that will serve as a catalyst for creating a new culture at The Rhodes School, where failure will be the exception rather than the norm, and where problems can become opportunities for students to construct meaning and gain a deeper understanding of themselves and their world."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Applicant: The School Board of Broward County, Florida
Project Title: World Class Instructional Leaders Residency Program
Project Description: "Every Child, Every Chance is our excellent approach in Broward County, Florida if our ?World Class Instructional Leaders Residency Program (WCILRP)? catches your eye. Their quality staff development will consist of intensive strategies in improving students' achievement in ELL and ESE. They will be required to conduct Professional Learning Communities (PLC) and Japanese Lesson Studies with assistant principals who work in our 54 most needy schools. The expected outcome will be an increase of students scoring level 3 or above in reading and math for 67,663 students involved in this program. The overwhelming support for this endeavor is based on our previous ability to produce 'outstanding principals'. As our proposal unfolds our ?Passion for Principals? will be contagious."

Applicant: The School Board of Broward County, Florida
Project Title: Star Teachers to Inspired Leaders (STILE)

STILE emerged fromobservations of strong peer-facilitated teacher teams in three local schools, the District?s successful LINGOPLC for ninth grade administrators, dialogue with LINGO participants regarding the STILE design, and thefindings of Saunders et al. (2009) related to the success of elementary teacher teams with a strategic focus onstudent learning."

Applicant: The School Board of Broward County, Florida
Project Title: Transforming Schools to Student-Centered, Inquiry-Based Learning Environments
Project Description: "This proposal will transform two elementary, three middle and one high school into project-based, inquiryoriented,student-centered learning environments. Next Generation Sunshine State Standards andproject based learning (PBL) form the core of the program. The School Improvement process, SchoolLeadership, community buy-in, and professional development are integral to change. PBL units aligned tocontent standards will be created. Data on student progress will be analyzed for achievement. Students willhave mobile learning devices for research, productivity and communication and interact via collaborativetools. Reading and writing skills will be targeted. Partners will contribute digital content, discounts on digitaltools, video distribution system, student email and professional development. Internal and external resources will sustain the project."

Applicant: The School District of Osceola County, Florida

Project Description: "The School District of Osceola County's Investing in Innovation project,  Prisms of Innovations and Research (PIR)  is a scale-up project of national importance that is designed to utilize data, research-based programs and hypotheses, innovative teaching strategies and structural changes to re-set the delivery of academic content for high need student populations.  As the ingredients of success are blended and focused, similar to light through a prism, specialized program interventions emerge to support the learning needs of each student.The project begins by investing in the success of the district's growing ELL and Hispanic population as an essential element to the short and long-term success of the school district.  By fusing data-informed model programs in the areas of early learning, mathematics, science, technology, college readiness and access within a framework of effective ELL strategies and gifted learning approaches measured by a multi-layer impact assessment analysis, the school district will create new validated teaching and learning tools, curricula, programs, assessments and templates for high need students that will be adopted by school districts nationwide.The Prisms of Innovation and Research project addresses the absolute priorities of data collection and utilization focused on turning around low-performing schools.  The PIR Investing In Innovation project offers numerous replicable and adoptable strategies that will collectively be shared with school districts with combined populations of over one million students throughout the project period.  The PIR school district partners include Los Angeles Unified School District, Albuquerque Public Schools, New York City Public Schools.  The innovative elements of the PIR project include: (1) the fusion of distinct research pools to create new and innovative program designs; (2) a complex multi-tiered analysis of the combined, partnered and isolated impact of these pools; (3) the design of inn?????"

Project Title: Re-Tooling Data Driven Leadership in Philadelphia Schools
Project Description: "The School District of Philadelphia?s Re-Tooling Data Driven Leadership in Philadelphia Schools Initiative isgrounded in a wealth of research indicating that integrated data systems?when implemented in a collaborativestandards-aligned process and when accompanied by well-structured professional development designed to buildcapacity of leaders to effectively use the data?can have a positive impact on teaching and learning. In alignmentwith Absolute Priority #2 under the U.S. Department of Education?s Investing In Innovation (i3) grant program(?Innovations that Improve the Use of Data?), the proposed initiative will be a three-year Development project todemonstrate a model for transforming the way data is used for school improvement efforts in a struggling urbanschool system. Project Title: Launch of The SEED School of Cincinnati

We also plan to bring up to $40 million in additional privateinvestment and $10 million/year of additional public dollars to the successful education of very high-risk andchallenging students. Project Title: SEED School Model Dissemination and National Replication

Project Title: The STEM Academy i3 Development Project
Project Description: "The STEM Academy mission is to prepare all k-12 students to be competent, capable citizens in a technology-dependent society through comprehensive student assessments including traditional tests; project based learning presentations and portfolios. STEM Academy content and structure has been designed to address the unique challenges of 62,203 high-need students in rural and suburban LEAs. Of the 22 partnering public school districts that have letters of commitment in this application, 10 are Rural as defined by the Small Rural School Achievement (SRSA) Program or the Rural and Low-Income School (RLIS) program. Concrete evidence can be provided that STEM Academy practices, strategies and programming can improve rural student achievement or student growth, close achievement gaps, decrease dropout rates, increase graduation rates and improve teacher effectiveness. This evidence can be provided through the combined use of student outcomes data captured by STEM Academy Learning Management System  and LEA data systems and reports. STEM Academy curriculum is standards based and assures high-quality content exchange and flexible enough to allow for school districts and states to modify to meet their particular needs. The curriculum culminates with students applying real-world application of their STEM education with hand-on activities and maps to the following national standards: International Technology Education Association - ITEA; Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology - ABET; National Science Teachers Association - NSTA; National Council of Teachers of Mathematics - NCTM. The STEM Academy mainline education approach will create engineering pipeline which is prepared to meet the demands of industry today and tomorrow. Students will be prepared for post-secondary engineering education, internships and career opportunities. The STEM Academy's content and structure has been designed to address the unique challenges of 62,203 high-need students in rural LEAs."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The College Success Academy Development Program
Project Description: "The Steppingstone Foundation (TSF) and Boston Public Schools (BPS) propose the College Success Academy (CSA) Development Program to complement the implementation of high standards and assessments in BPS district schools that will measure and foster high-need student progress towards improving academic proficiency, closing access and achievement gaps, and improving college and career success. The CSA will be modeled after Steppingstone Academy, which prepares and places students on pathways to college by providing after-school and summer programming for high-need fifth-seventh-graders that enable admission to and success at independent and public exam schools. Unlike Steppingstone Academy, the CSA will fill a critical gap in the academic, support, and assessments that students are receiving within BPS schools, rather than striving for independent or exam school placement. A total of 210 high-need students will be admitted as rising 5th graders over three years from three targeted BPS district schools through a two-staged moderate scale up. These scholars will then obtain a combination of: rigorous academic preparation, designed to enrich skills in key content areas, as well as those not addressed through their regular school curriculum, and reduce summer learning loss; individual academic support mechanisms focused on academic competency, course selection, and personal motivation; and continuous assessments of progress in meeting state achievement standards, as well as other middle-grade indicators of high school, college, and career success. It is anticipated that this program will have a profound impact towards improving student achievement, attainment, and retention as measured by the magnitude of effect in relation to research supported indicators of future success for the target population, as well as the significance of effect in relation to prior implementation of these approaches, which will warrant further development and scale up of the CSA program.?????"

Applicant: The Studio in a School Association, Inc.
Project Title: Arts Achieve: Impacting Student Success in the Arts
Project Description: "The Studio in a School Association, Inc.; Weill Music Institute at Carnegie Hall; ArtsConnection, Inc.; 92nd Street Y / Harkness Dance Center, Dance Education Laboratory (DEL); and Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution are partnering with the New York City Department of Education to create Arts Achieve. The goals of the proposed project are to:? Improve student achievement in the arts through the development and implementation of balanced arts assessments that are aligned to high student content and academic achievement standards.? Translate the standards and information from assessments into classroom practices that support improved arts achievement for all students.? Promote innovations in student and teacher access to content and assessment feedback through the use of technology.Arts Achieve will result in the creation of on-line / open educational resources that have been validated and informed by the results of the assessments and made available nationwide. This grant will also enable technology to be introduced into arts classroom practice to facilitate art creation, documentation, research, feedback, reflection, collaboration and file-sharing within and beyond the schools: Student-to-student, student-to-teacher, student-to-parent, and student and teacher to partnering arts institution. As such, Arts Achieve puts formative and summative assessment to work to empower students to reflect, direct and enhance their experience and performance in the arts and to connect to resources that these high-need students could not otherwise access. The project will also produce objective measures by which the partners can assess what they believe to be the significant correlation of arts achievement on improved English Language Arts performance. Arts Achieve will involve 7,200 students during the term of the grant, and has the potential to impact the more than 1.1 million children who attend NYC Department of Education schools."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Reaching Academic Potential (RAP) through the Arts
Project Description: "California State University, Northridge (CSUN) proposes to launch an innovative initiative designed to turnaround persistently low-performing schools (Absolute Priority #4), by targeting early learning outcomes(Competitive Preference Priority #5) of English Learners (Competitive Preference Priority #7). RAP willactively target the neediest students, at the onset of their education (PK-3), through the deployment of anintegrative arts curriculum designed for implementation within regularly scheduled classroom instruction.Specific measurable objectives are to: (1) improve at-risk students? ELD, literacy and numeracy skills ELs andtheir inner circle of learning community members, e.g., parents, teachers, and principals; and (2) strengthenand institutionalize ongoing teacher professional development in the arts.Partnering with the Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD), Local Districts 1 and 2, which serve 82 and62 elementary schools respectively, CSUN, and its community based partners, Boeing, the Volunteers ofAmerica of Los Angeles, and the Los Angeles County Arts Commission, intend to conduct the program in amanner that not only generates the anticipated improvements in teaching and learning outcomes, but that alsoresults in empirical evidence upon which to further develop and expand the program. During the grant period,the project will engage teachers of Pre-K through Grade 3 in LAUSD Districts 1 and 2, and reachapproximately 7,600 students, 400 teachers, and 40 principals.The special features of the project include a) daily intensive arts education integrated into the state-adopted coresubject area texts, b) implemented by the general education classroom teachers throughout the instructionaldays, c) incorporates an intergenerational model, and d) a unique long-term sustainability plan that includes abroader community of partners comprised of both public and private non-profit organizations, and for-profitpartners."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Closing the Algebra Achievement Gap through the Responsive Teaching Cycle
Project Description: "RTC focuses on generating greater student success in Algebra?a gateway course that impacts students? ability tograduate high school and complete a college preparatory curriculum. Already in its fifth year of operation infive Los Angeles Unified schools, RTC is demonstrating amazing results. In 2008, 90% of the students whohad been taught by teachers who engaged in RTC subsequently passed Algebra 1 with a ?C? or better as eighthgraders in the fall semester following their participation in a summer intervention program (participatingstudents were low performing seventh graders who were below ?proficient? on the California Standards Test).This is in contrast to a 55% pass rate for eighth graders in LAUSD (with the pass rate for ninth graders evenlower?at 39%). RTC achieves its outcomes by providing teachers structured opportunities to developstrategies to support student learning through meaningful, professional collaboration."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Principal Data + Design Studio Project: Studio D
Project Description: "The University of Akron in partnership with the Canton City School District seeks to advance K-12 principals' knowledge and skills in data-based decision making for school improvement through a Development grant.  Fifty principals serving over 10,000 students in the Canton City School District will participate in this project. Many preparation programs prepare principals for resource management and human relations, but few provide training in how to 'connect the dots' and strategic thinking to the particular needs of schools, teachers and students. How to interpret data, design instruction based on data, implement data-based decisions effectively and flexibly, and evaluate educational results are processes that remain ill-defined. 	To deepen the impact of data-based decision-making on classroom practice, principal professional education programs need to develop candidates' skills both in using new analytic tools to improve data quality and in engaging the integrative, creative, strategic style of analysis inherent to design thinking. The Studio D project is situated at this interface of data interpretation and data use in schools, offering new opportunities for principals to improve their data-based decision making strategies	The goals of the project are to 1) Educate principals using online professional development in the science and art of data use in schools. 2)  Design software for practical technological tools in data use management and design thinking in schools. 3) Use Progress monitoring tools for formative assessment of learning targets. We will meet these goals through several components: (1) Data At Work in Schools-an online principal professional development curriculum that supports systems thinking and 'higher order leadership' by deepening understanding of scientific data analysis, data interpretation, and data-driven design of innovative solutions;  (2) software applications that support situated use of data in school contexts by improving access."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Expanding the Use of STEP Literacy Assessment Data to Improve Student Growth and Teacher Performance Nationwide
Project Description: "The University of Chicago Urban Education Institute has developed STEP (Strategic Teaching and Evaluation of Progress) as an early literacy assessment and professional development tool. STEP is a scalable tool for improving literacy student achievement in grades pre-kindergarten through third and also serves as a powerful catalyst for improving instructional practice and shapes the work of teachers, school leaders, and literacy coaches at the classroom, school, and district level.This proposal seeks to expand the use of STEP to all states nationwide in support of the effective use of data to foster student learning growth and enhanced professional capacity of teachers. To fulfill this goal, STEP proposes a collaborative, multi-city undertaking in Chicago, New Orleans, and the greater New York City area with the Consortium on Chicago School Research (CCSR) and Wireless Generation to develop an evidence-based data-use guide, test and produce nonfiction texts to accompany current fiction texts, and make STEP more accessible in all 50 states. The culmination of these three objectives would expand the use of the STEP assessment to 1-3 million students.Project"

Project Title: Keeping Students On-Track to High School and College Success: Developing an Early Indicator and Response System in Grades 9 and 10
Project Description: "The Consortium on Chicago School Research (CCSR) at the University of Chicago, in partnership with the Everyone Graduates Center at Johns Hopkins University (JHU) and the Academy for Educational Development (AED), are seeking an i3 Development Grant to develop and test a comprehensive Early Indicator and Response System (EIRS) for grades 9-10 in several large school districts throughout the country. The goal of this project is to measurably reduce the number of ninth and tenth grade students who fall off the path to high school graduation and college readiness by helping districts and schools develop relevant and actionable early warning data and providing the tools and training needed to increase the capacity of educators to effectively respond to this data. This project directly addresses Absolute Priority 2: Innovations that Improve the Use of Data and Competitive Preference Priority 6: Innovations that Support College Access and Success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: University of Chicago -Center for High School Leadership
Project Description: "The University of Chicago, in partnership with the Chicago Public Schools, will launch a school leadershippreparation and development program to train exemplary school leadership teams to transform Chicago?s lowperforming high schools. The proposed School Leadership Preparation Program, a component of theUniversity of Chicago?s Center for High School Leadership at the School of Social Service Administration,leverages a combination of research-based practice, leadership training and ongoing support for Chicago?sschool leaders. Leadership teams will include a Principal and four Directors. Each Director will haveresponsibility for a discrete area of the schools? functions: a Director of Operations (will oversee technology,budget, facilities, safety , security, human resources, food services, and procurement); a Director of Students(will be responsible for counselors, social workers, psychologists, post-secondary work, discipline, attendance,and freshmen and student academic support); a Director of Instruction (will oversee the schools? instructionalleadership and teacher collaboration teams, curriculum and assessment, academic programs, and recruitmentand professional development of teachers); a Director of Student Life, Family Engagement and CommunityPartnerships (will be responsible for extracurricular activities, student development, family engagement,athletics, and community partnerships). After training and placement, each team will receive one year ofinduction support followed by three years of ongoing coaching and support with the Center?s Network forCollege Success (NCS). Grounded in the actual work of the principalship, NCS will provide leaders withtoolkits to effectively use research and data, develop successful program and instructional strategies, and planand manage school-wide change. We expect that SLPP teams will dramatically improve student learning,graduation and college enrollment rates in the high schools they lead."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Essential Supports School Improvement System: Improving urban schools through organizational and student data
Project Description: "The University of Chicago Urban Education Institute (UEI), in partnership with a consortium of charter schools, is seeking an i3 Development Grant to develop and test a comprehensive system for improving schools through the use of data. This project will use the Essential Supports for School Improvement-a set of empirically validated metrics for identifying the specific areas of organizational culture, climate, and capacity that schools need to improve to be able to increase student achievement growth-as a framework for improving schools. The goal of this project is to develop systems to dramatically improve student achievement growth in high need, urban areas through the use of the Essential Supports. This project has two explicit mechanisms for achieving this goal, 1) developing an automated, web-based tool for measuring and reporting school performance on the Essential Supports, capable of scaling to schools across the United States (the Essential Supports School Improvement Survey - 'The Survey'), and 2) developing a three phase training system for training school leaders to use the Essential Supports to improve student achievement (Essential Supports School Improvement System). We will develop and pilot this Essential Supports School Improvement System (ESSIS) in six high-need charter schools in Chicago (comprising the application's consortium of schools).
