We will rapidly scale The Survey to public schools in Chicago within the grant period and develop a training package for scaling the other elements of the system nationwide. This project directly addresses Absolute Priority 2: Innovations that Improve the Use of Data and also addresses many of the objectives described in Absolute Priority 1, pertaining to increasing the effectiveness of teachers and principals."

Project Title: Grow Your Own Iowa: Boosting College Access, Developing Teaching Excellence, and Building Educational Leadership for Iowa
Project Description: "Introduction: Grow Your Own Iowa: Boosting College Access, Developing Teaching Excellence, and Building Educational Leadership for Iowa?s High-Need Schools (GrowIowa). is a new partnership between The University of Iowa (UI) College of Education (UI), William Penn University (WPU) and 14 LEAs in Iowa. GrowIowa is a comprehensive ?Grow Your Own? project that will: 1) increase underrepresented rural Iowa high school students? access to postsecondary education through the development of an innovative career intervention and, 2) identify, train, and retain highly effective teachers and leaders from Iowa?s high need and/or rural school districts. GrowIowa targets: 1) rural students who demonstrate an interest and talent for teaching, 2) underrepresented and /or rural paraeducators with an interest in becoming teachers, and 3) underrepresented and/or rural teachers who demonstrate an interest in becoming leaders. Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT) drives GrowIowa ; SCCT posits that the career choice process occurs as a result of an individual?s exposure to a variety of activities and people that have career related value. We believe that individuals who identify career goals early and can link those goals to postsecondary opportunities will achieve greater academic outcomes. This project will tap into a base of teacher education candidates in communities often missed by traditional recruiting methods and provide them with academic and professional supports that will lead to a new pool of effective teachers and leaders. These new teachers and leaders will be encouraged to remain in their communities where they have the critical connections among families, schools, and communities to succeed."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Promoting STEM Education in Iowa through Project-Based Curricula (IaSTEM)
Project Description: "The widely reported underperformance of US students in international science and math competitions and achievement, coupled with a projected shortage of employees to fill the expected need for new hires in engineering and other STEM related careers, has lead to a nation-wide emphasis on STEM related educational programs. In 2005 the Iowa Department of Education selected the Project Lead The Way (PLTW) curriculum to create a seamless transition for students from secondary school into science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Initial studies we have carried out on the students taking PLTW courses indicate a significant increase in ITED math scores compared to non-participants with similar demographic data. In addition, 71% of PLTW transition to higher education vs. 50% of non-PLTW students. The primary objective of the proposed program is to expand our initial studies to a more complete assessment of the impact of the PLTW curriculum on student performance and attitudes. In addition, in the schools taking PLTW has been largely in larger urban schools. While 145/360 school districts in Iowa are small rural schools, only two small rural schools are participating in PLTW. Secondary goals of this project are to provide effective, sustainable models that allow expansion of the PLTW program into small rural school districts, and to improve the college readiness of Iowa students. Funding will support 85 new sites involving more than 100 LEAs. We will introduce the PLTW Gateway to Technology curriculum in the middle schools of 50 school districts. A key hypothesis is that project-based curricula increase student performance in STEM fields. This project will expand studies we have already conducted examining the impact of PLTW courses on student performance on the math and science sections of standardized tests (ITBS and ITED). The long-term goal is to determine the impact of the PLTW curriculum on students' eventual career choices."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project C4 (Caring, Communities, Colleges, & Careers)
Project Description: "Davenport C4: Caring, Communities, College & Careers (C4) partners the University of Iowa (UI), Davenport Community School District (DCSD), Davenport Education Association, City of Davenport, Big Brothers Big Sisters, the Iowa Quad Cities Chamber of Commerce and Scott Community College (SCC) in an effort to increase student achievement through the development of a PK-14 model of education in the DCSD. C4, a college ?Promise? model of education, seeks to validate that the provision of early learning and postsecondary education options to every student increases student achievement and improves college access. Project objectives: 1) provide a PK-14 program in DCSD, 2) provide academic and career support in middle schools and extended school day options, 3) engage a broad-based partnership of educational and private-sector stakeholders to oversee the implementation and dissemination of the C4 model serving high need students in DCSD, 4) research, utilizing a quasi-experimental design, the efficacy of the C4 model to ascertain impact on a) student achievement, and b) college access. Validation will be achieved through an independent evaluation that will examine the impact of the C4 activities on the achievement and attainment outcomes of students as they progress through high school. The 5-year evaluation will address: 1) impacts of the C4 activities on student academic achievement, measured by assessments such as ITBS, 2) nature of the relationship between the project?s impacts on academic achievement and their impact on other outcomes including retention and graduation rates, closing achievement gap of subgroups of diverse students, and access to college, 3) effectiveness of C4 activities with respect to subgroups of students 4) factors that promote or impede implementation of the project C4 activities, and 5) levels of implementation fidelity and quality associated with program impacts (or lack of impacts) on academic achievement and other outcomes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Advancing the Integration of Museums into High and Junior High Schools (AIMHIGH!)
Project Description: "The AIM-High! (Advancing the Integration of Museums into High and Junior High Schools) Programis a pilot project between the University of New Mexico, the University of Alaska, and Local AreaSchools in both states, in which we will develop and implement new ways of strengthening andsupplementing existing high school science curricula and standards by adding a place-basedculturally relevant research experience (biodiversity inventories) in a community and place-basedcontext. The research component will be modeled into existing biology curricula to develop collegereadiness skills and enhanced by online learning modules and broad dissemination of researchexperiences using the latest online communication technologies. The AIM-HIGH! Program targetspredominantly Native-American Indian and Native Alaskan high-need high school biology studentsas well as providing a teacher training component to develop science teacher content knowledgeand research skills. Furthermore, the program will provide participating teachers with college creditcourses and AP training to scale up for developing future AP and/or dual enrollment scienceclasses. The researcher/ teacher/ student connection will bridge directly toward college and developa sustainable learning community between local universities, museums and area schools. Inaddition, this collaboration will familiarize high school students with college requirements, and buildpersonal relationships with university professors that may mentor future career choices and thecollege application process."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Project Title: Integrated Personal Transformation Leadership Program

Applicant: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Project Title: Evaluation System and Professional Development for PreK-3 School Reform: Re-Imagine and FirstSchool Collaboration
Project Description: "This Development grant is in response to the Investing in Innovation Grant Application from the U.S. Department of Education. The purpose of this grant proposal is to use a school improvement and evaluation system that includes a research-based observation tool, Emerging Academic Snapshot (Snapshot) in conjunction with student achievement data to broaden teachers? and school leadership?s lens of how to examine and support effective teaching practices. This grant proposal is a systematic evaluation of the FirstSchool process with collaboration with Michigan Department of Education and to-be-selected local education agencies (LEAs)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Project Title: ELEVATE: A Technology Mediated Professional Development Program in Literacy: Helping Teachers Close the Achievement Gap for High Needs Children in Low-Wealth Rural Communities
Project Description:
The grant proposes to increase the literacy instruction of K-3 classroom teachers in low wealth rural schools through evidence-based interventions that provide teachers with the skills and resources necessary to provide effective instruction, particularly for struggling readers. The ELEVATE program has demonstrated moderate evidence for successful teacher and student outcomes through recent experimental and quasi experimental studies. The 4 year intervention is delivered via webcam technology so that literacy coaches can see and talk to classroom teachers working with struggling high needs readers in live web sessions in the regular classroom. Training for teachers includes: (1) intensive summer institutes, (2) weekly webcam coaching sessions and (3) specialized two-hour workshops twice each semester. An outside evaluation will collect teacher and student data to assess whether the intervention produces highly effective teachers and sustained student reading growth through 4th grade.
Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes include increasing the effectiveness of K-3 classroom teachers in low-wealth rural school districts by providing intensive professional development via webcam technology. It is expected that teachers with the intervention will improve their knowledge of literacy practices and improve their instruction compared to teachers in control schools. Both struggling and non-struggling readers will demonstrate dramatic growth in literacy and sustained growth through 4th grade in comparison to students in control schools.
Target Number of Students Served will include children over 4 years in 22 schools and 248 classrooms. Over 5,000 children should benefit from the intervention during the grant.
A special feature of this program is the use of highly cost effective live webcam literacy coaching to classroom teachers via laptop computers in remote rural schools.
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Project Title: A Partnership between Low-Performing High Schools and the National College Advising Corps: Testing the Model and Evaluating the Impact
Project Description: "The National College Advising Corps (NCAC) requests $5 million in i3 funding to support and expand its placement of college advisers in persistently low-performing high schools in corrective action (Absolute Priority Area 4) and to continue its rigorous, randomized program evaluation. This funding will allow NCAC to 1) support its advisers in 28 low-performing schools in corrective action; 2) expand to serve an additional 10 low-performing schools in corrective action; and 3) support and expand a rigorous, randomized evaluation of the program to inform programmatic design and increase scalability. With this funding, NCAC anticipates that it will be able to help 117,000 low-income, first-generation-college, and underrepresented high school students apply to, matriculate at, and succeed in postsecondary education over the grant period. Partners include a consortium of 28 low-performing high schools in corrective action in 12 states with expansion to ten additional schools for a total of 38 high schools in corrective action by 2015 as well as 13 universities (Brown, Franklin and Marshall, Penn State, Tufts, University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, University of Utah, University of Virginia, University of Missouri, University of California-Berkeley, University of Illinois, University of Georgia, University of Texas, and University of Michigan.)???"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Project Title: Innovation, Access, and Success in Rural Areas: A Partnership between the National College Advising Corps and High Schools
Project Description: "The National College Advising Corps (NCAC) requests $24.9 million in i3 funding to support and expand its placement of college advisers in low-performing rural high schools in corrective action (Absolute Priority Area 4) and to expand its innovative college access and success model into additional rural schools. These funds will allow NCAC to 1) support its advisers in 54 rural schools, including ten low-performing schools in corrective action and 20 schools in the Rural and Low Income School Program (RLIS); 2) expand the Corps to 104 rural schools in Year 2 and 144 rural schools in Years 3-5; 3) support and expand a rigorous, randomized evaluation of the NCAC program to inform programmatic design and increase scalability. With this funding, NCAC anticipates that it will be able to help 218,000 low-income, first-generation-college, and underrepresented rural high school students apply to, matriculate at, and succeed in postsecondary education over the grant period. Partners include a consortium of 54 rural high schools including ten in corrective action and twenty in the RLIS in 9 states (54 of these high schools are currently being served; 90 more will be selected as part of the grant) as well as 9 universities (Franklin & Marshall, Tufts, University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, University of Virginia, University of Missouri, University of California-Berkeley, University of Georgia, University of Texas, and University of Michigan)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Project Title: Promoting Statistics and Probability in the Middle Grades through Games and Simulations
Project Description: "Many middle school students lose interest in mathematics. This is compounded by overall poor conceptualunderstanding of ?big ideas? including the underpinnings of rational number ideas. An elective middle gradessemester-long mathematics course will be developed through the support of this project and implemented inschools that are members of a regional collaborative. The course will use games and simulations to reinforceimportant mathematics concepts and motive learners to explore probability and statistics topics. The projectwill address central content needs as outlined in national curricular documents including the Core Standardsand those from the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. The activities from this project, includingassessment tools, will provide substantive direction relative to the central role of probability and statisticstopics in middle grades mathematics while providing data about the impact of games and simulations inteaching and learning mathematics."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Applicant: The University of Texas at  San Antonio
Project Title: innovation in Math Achievement and Performance (iMAP) Project
Project Description: "iMAP is designed to improve Hispanic high school students? performance in upper division math courses and to respond to recent systemic assessment changes in Texas demanding end of course exams. Hispanic students, especially those who are first generation to attend college, generally do not perform well in rigorous, upper level high school math courses that prepare them for college and STEM careers. Thus, there is a critical need to improve high school math curricula and its delivery. We propose to achieve this goal by developing a unique blend of culturally and socially relevant instruction and interactive project-based modules shown by research to improve learning. iMAP proposes to increase the number of students successfully completing Algebra II and Precalculus classes at the high school level which will improve success rates in college math courses by: 1) Engaging 22 high school math teachers and 5 university faculty to make teaching and learning in the Algebra II and Precalculus courses more reflective of students? real life experiences; 2) Using a team approach to develop model-based culturally relevant content for high school Algebra II and Precalculus serving 400 students; 3) Designing culturally responsive teaching strategies for the new curriculum models; 4) Developing end-of-course assessments of student outcomes; 5) Implementing math and engineering college readiness activities for 400 high school juniors and seniors; 7) Evaluating outcomes in college Calculus for 100 students taking the new curricula compared to outcomes of students not participating in iMAP. In iMAP, the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) will actively partner with 9 San Antonio Independent School District (SAISD) urban high schools, KIPP San Antonio (high school), as well as National Instruments, Stanford Research Institute, Pearson Test Developers, and others to improve the success of Hispanic students in high level math courses."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: The University of Texas at Austin
Project Title: Bringing the Excitement of Deep Ocean Exploration to Classrooms with No Ocean in Sight: A Validation Grant addressing priorities 3, 6, and 8
Project Description: "This 5-year validation grant is a partnership among a University, a Private Trust, a Junior College, and 22 School Districts in Central Texas.  It focuses on bringing high quality Ocean Science education to underserved populations, with the primary goals of improving achievement in science, enhancing awareness of scientific careers, increasing high school graduation and college matriculation rates, and ultimately, increasing diversity in Earth and Ocean Sciences.  The project will: 1) install the technology needed to receive live ocean-discovery content at 29 high schools, 3 junior college campuses, and the University of Texas, all of whom are partners in this proposal; 2) provide standards-based curriculum to be used with it; 3) provide teacher training; 4) bring 35 teachers on-board the scientific ocean exploration ship; 4) take 200 students on week-long field trips to explore ocean science technology, education, and careers; 5) strengthen college preparation and mentoring in the high schools; 6) deliver a dual-credit Earth Science class to participating high schools; 7) provide content for community science events.   Participating partners are: University of Texas at Austin, GeoFORCE program, Ocean Exploration Trust, Robert D. Ballard, President, Southwest Texas Junior College, Houston ISD, and 21 other ISDs in rural towns in SW Texas.  Partnering schools are over 90% minority, and nearly 80% economically disadvantaged. Each school in the partnership will receive a high-tech ocean-exploration discovery console that includes a large flat screen LCD monitor, 2 computers with dual display, video integrated receiver decoders, intercoms, speakers, and other parts, all of which will allow students to receive high definition video from the sea-floor, and associated content, and to communicate with the scientists on the ship and monitoring the expedition from land.  To accommodate the large amount of data streaming, Internet2 will be connected at all of the schools.... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The University of Texas at El Paso
Project Title: Project IDEELL (Innovative Dual Language Education for English Language Learners)
Project Description: "The goal of Project IDEELL (Innovative Dual Language Education for English Language Learners) is to identifyand develop measures of the characteristics of teacher and principal ?effectiveness? that lead to greater studentachievement in dual language middle school programs. The project is a collaborative design developedbetween the University of Texas-El Paso, an Hispanic-serving Institution with a strong history of teacher andadministrator training for success with high-needs students, and the Ysleta Independent School District, a largeurban school district that has demonstrated success for ELL students in their dual language programs.Research has shown that dual language programs are the most successful in ensuring the achievement of ELLstudents, and Ysleta?s dual language students have demonstrated this success by consistently outperformingtheir Ysleta peers on state exams and on national Spanish AP exams. The partnership creates optimalconditions for research leading to meaningful, replicable instruments that measure ?effectiveness? in duallanguage classes. UTEP will create courses in degree programs, at both the undergraduate and graduate levels,based on the theoretical foundations of dual language education and strategies for teaching or leading in thesesettings. Furthermore, they will provide ongoing professional development training for yearly cohorts of in-serviceteachers and principals in dual language middle schools in the YISD. Student outcomes measures willbe correlated with teachers? and principals? ?effectiveness? measures to establish a replicable model for use inother ELL settings across the country."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: The University of Texas at San Antonio
Project Title: Prefreshman Engineering Program (PREP-USA)
Project Description: "PREP-USA identifies middle and high school students with an interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) areas and strengthens their potential for college degrees in these fields. PREP-USA is a collaborative effort of colleges and universities and is offered during the course of four summers. Students completing PREP I, II, III, and IV receive one high school elective credit for each summer successfully completed and they qualify to enroll in University/College PREP for college credit once they complete PREP I, II, and III.The program consists of academic, career and mentoring components. The academic component includes science, problem solving and emphasizes mathematics with classes such as logic and its applications to mathematics. The career component includes field trips and daily presentations from STEM career professionals. The mentoring aspect involves hiring college students majoring in STEM fields to mentor, tutor and serve as role models for the PREP-USA students.PREP-USA is requesting a Development Grant addressing Absolute Priority 3 and Competitive Preference Priorities 6 and 8 to continue to scale-up the program nationally with a focus on high need students (including high-need students in rural areas) traditionally under-represented in the STEM fields. PREP-USA?s objectives include adding about 5,000 students over the next five years (bringing the total served to about 9,000 students during the summer of 2015), completing an ongoing systematic program evaluation by the end of 2010, obtaining bridge funding until more permanent funding is identified, and increasing the number of under-represented students who graduate from college and the number who graduate with STEM degrees.PREP-USA currently has 35 official college/university partners and the list of these can be found in Applicant Information Sheet."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The University of Texas at San Antonio
Project Title: Digital-Age Learning Communities: Equity in Enrollment and Success in College
Project Description: "UTSA, in collaboration with three partner school districts in Texas: Southwest, Edgewood, and Harlandale will tackle the issue of inequity, high drop-out and low graduation rates, and create an action plan to create a seamless pathway and raise post-secondary readiness for ALL students, particularly underrepresented students. This project is unique in its college access approach because it addresses a critical transition point (9th grade) where many underserved high school students, including English language learners (ELLs) and students with disabilities drop out of school. It catalyzes lessons learned and successful practices of various college access programs at UTSA into a comprehensive program that embraces the concept of collective learning generated through an Interdisciplinary Community of Practice (I-CofP) including university representatives, students,school administrators, parents and the private sector in an advisory capacity. This project will impact 150 teachers, 20 administrators, and 3000 students. The project has three goals: (1) Increase the effectiveness of culturally efficacious teachers and administrators in catalyzing action for school reform, (2) Increase the number of students who are college ready, particularly students who are traditionally underserved, and (3) Increase in the number of parents who are knowledgeable of college eligibility requirements and pathways to college. Major objectives include: 80% of participating students demonstrate 75% core competency proficiency on a state standardized test; 80% of participating teachers demonstrate competency in integrating college readiness standards into instruction as demonstrated through classroom observations; 75% of participating students demonstrate an increase of at least 50% in levels of resiliency, persistence, and selfefficacy as measured through a Self-Efficacy for Learning instrument developed by Zimmerman et al (2002);"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston
Project Title: Development of the School Readiness Curriculum Based Measurement System
Project Description: "There is unmet need for efficient, psychometrically sound, and instructionally useful progress monitoring tools(CBMs) for preschool and kindergarten, especially for high-needs students and English language learners.Thus, we propose an innovative solution to develop a computer adaptive assessment tool that facilitatesteachers? analysis and use children?s test data to inform instructional decisions and improve studentachievement. Grounded in developmental and experimental research, the School Readiness Curriculum BasedMeasurement system (SRCBM) will assess the most predictive school readiness domains of vocabulary, letterknowledge, phonological awareness, and mathematics in English and Spanish. Incorporating large item pools,item response theory statistics, adaptive testing procedures, and computerized administration, the SRCBMwill optimize standardization, precision, sensitivity, reliability and validity, yet minimize administration times,complexities, and errors. Interactive reporting features will include choice of referent groups (e.g., small group,classroom, grade, age peers, NCLB categories, etc.), recommendations for ability groupings, instructionalchanges consistent with a tiered service delivery model, and professional develop needs of an LEA. Reportswill be customizable to the resources, needs, and guidelines of a given classroom, school, LEA or stateeducation agency. SRCBM systems architecture will allow it to work on variety of platforms (netbook, tablet,web, iPad), will allow continuous piloting and calibration of new items, and will offer expandability to serve asan integrated screener, progress monitoring tool, and diagnostic outcome measure across the preschool andearly elementary school years for a variety of populations. Phases of delopment include (1) constructing itempools, (2) piloting assessment methods with alpha version, (3) scaling items with beta version, (4) a reliabilityand validity study, (5) and a usability study."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston
Project Title: Linking Data and Instruction to Improve High Risk Children's Outcomes in Pre-K, Kindergarten, and First Grade: An Integrated System to Enhance Language and Literacy Learning
Project Description: "The L3 system is an integrated early education program for enhancing language and literacy outcomes. Thecomponents include TEEM, a comprehensive early education model for pre-k; Building Vocabulary forEmerging Readers (BVER), an oral language and vocabulary for kindergarten and first grade; Recognition &Response (R&R) for pre-k and Response to Intervention (RTI) for kindergarten and first grade, which offertargeted instruction for children who require additional supports to learn; and Raise-a-Reader (RAR), a familyinvolvement program for pre-k, kindergarten, and first grade. The proposed 5-year project will examine theimplementation of the L3 system and its effects on children?s language and literacy learning. Independent andcumulative effects will be evaluated within and across pre-kindergarten, kindergarten, and first grade."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Summoning the Village to Raise the Child
Project Description: "This proposal is based on the hypothesis that in order to be effective teachers and principals, teachers and principals must become community organizers, leading the effort to bring those who historically have been excluded as full participants in formal schooling (here, economically marginalized African Americans) centrally into the school as fully enfranchised team members. We are using existing institutional structures?graduate education, undergraduate education, and afterschool programs?to do this in a well organized, sustainable, yet highly innovative way.The project has three work streams: Teacher-Principal Graduate Studies Cohort; Parent-Community Educator GED-Undergraduate Cohort; and Community Nonformal Learning Environment (afterschool programs). SV hypothesizes that if these populations?teachers, principals, parent-guardians, community leaders, and university researchers?align their efforts for sustained, purposeful work toward the common causes of increasing literacy, school achievement, and college aspirations, then student achievement will increase.The innovation is that the project turns course meeting times for graduate education into arenas for teachers and principals, as students pursuing masters and doctoral degrees, to interact with parents and community educators?parents in the undergraduate coursework they are taking, simultaneous to the teachers? and principals? graduate coursework, and community educators in the nonformal learning environments which they run (afterschool programs) and which serve as ?labs? for teachers and principals to observe their K-5 students interacting with different pedagogies and curricula."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Urban Alliance:  Increasing High School Graduation and College Enrollment for At-Risk Youth
Project Description: "Urban Alliance is a non-profit organization with a proven track record of engaging high-need students at risk of dropping out of high school and not only fostering high school graduation, but  also increasing enrollment in college.  Integrating four program components (paid internships, mentoring, training, and case management), all of which have documented impacts on high school retention, Urban Alliance has uniquely combined the benefits of each with outstanding results - over the last two years, 100% of Urban Alliance participants have graduated high school with 93% attending college.  Through i3, Urban Alliance seeks to:  (1) conduct a high quality, experimental design study to measure the impact of the program on participating youth; (2) partner with DC Public Schools and Baltimore City Schools to grow the program to serve an additional 119% youth annually by the end of the grant period; and (3) create a purposeful, strategic replication plan to extend the programs' benefits to youth across the country. Objectives include:1.	A definitive evaluation of the impact of the Urban Alliance program through a sound experimental design study;2.	Retain 90% of UA youth in high school in their senior year, resulting in on time graduation;3.	Enroll 80% of UA youth in college at the completion of their senior year of high school;4.	Increase the number of youth served annually by 119%.As a result of this project, 1,400 young people will receive high-quality direct services through the Urban Alliance model, with more than 1,120 of them going on to attend college.  These results, coupled with the anticipated empirical data documenting the impact will poise the program for replication in school districts across the country, to transform the lives of thousands of youth who may have dropped out of high school but will instead enroll in college."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: 21st Century Arts Integration Resource Curriculum and Support Initiative
Project Description: "The Center for Arts Education, together with its school and organizational partners propose an ambitious andinnovative curriculum expansion through the arts initiative, that will improve student achievement, attendance,and overall school environment for high -need urban public school students, K-12. The 21st Century ArtsIntegration Resource Curriculum and Support Initiative is a radical rethinking of the very standards,assessments, curriculum, delivery, design, and supports necessary to meet the great challenge/opportunity ofthe arts in the 21st century, including addressing the deep knowledge gap of administrators and teachersregarding what they need to know and be able to do, the kaleidoscope of options for how the arts are definedand delivered in schools today, and the profoundly changed nature of the arts as they are classified, created,disseminated, and engaged with.The project design calls for flexible, comprehensive arts integration resource curriculum that is driven bycurricular crosswalks across domains, arts disciplines, and grades by topic, subject area, and specific content,with a special focus on integration with the draft ELA Common Core Standards, while also including othercore subjects. Supporting and expanding the resource curriculum will be a wide range of tools including newperformance-based student assessments, tools to evaluate principal and teacher effectiveness, and more. As awhole, the wide range of key information, resources, tools and materials will be highly customizable accordingto the needs of students and supported widely through national dissemination with the project's partnerorganizations and key allies."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: DP21 - Diploma Plus Next Generation: Blended Learning Model Serving Back-on-Track Youth
Project Description: "Diploma Plus 21st Century (DP21) represents an ambitious plan to accelerate work at Diploma Plus schools and forge a next-generation school model serving back-on-track youth in NYC and across the country. First-generation blended online learning models are limited in their ability to meet the educational requirements of young people who need youth development, adult mentoring, wrap-around services, and hands-on learning supports. DP21 explicitly connects the DP model's Four Essentials with innovative information and educational technology by (1) delivering new open online course content designed to support learning and assessment through authentic challenge based investigations, (2) leveraging online content, tools and experts designed to support 21st century college, work, and life readiness, (3) extending evidence-based brick-and-mortar youth development supports online so that all youth form nurturing relationships with adults and peers in the school community, and (4) creating the conditions for anywhere/anytime learning through home-broadband access, virtual classrooms and innovative models for credit accumulation that are made possible through next-generation learning management systems. The DP21 effort strategically aligns multiple one time/non-recurring investments designed drive low-cost sustainability and scale of the effort. Specific outcome targets over four years include: a) Increasing high school completion rate for student participants, b) Increasing student participants? academic achievement, c) Increasing student participants' 21st century college- and career-readiness, and d) Exploring and documenting all factors related to positive DP21 outcomes."

Project Title: Transforming Education for High Need Students: Competency and Performance-Based Learning
Project Description: "Diploma Plus (DP) is applying for a $5 million i3 Development grant focused on turning around lowest performing schools and providing pathways to graduation for high-need students. Our proposal aims to accelerate and deepen DP's competency and performance-based system; validate the system's effectiveness at raising student achievement; replicate the competency and performance-based model to additional and varying sites; and prepare for large-scale model replication across all settings. Key to the success of DP is the innovative competency and performance-based model in that DP schools use competency-based and standards-aligned curriculum, instruction, and assessment to support a performance-based promotion and graduation structure that allows for individualized student pace and progress linked to standards and competency attainment and not measured by seat time. This focused and comprehensive approach seeks to provide the educational community with one pathway that can be effectively replicated in order to reengage additional numbers of over-aged and under-credited students to earn regular high school diplomas. In addition, the proposed strategy enables Diploma Plus to help support the turnaround of underperforming high schools, contribute to the overall success of district school turnaround plans, raise graduation rates, and increase student achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: South Georgia Rural Schools I3 Project
Project Description: "The national Talent Search model is the innovation that the South Georgia Rural Schools project will use to turn around persistently low-performing schools. The Absolute priority addressed is Priority 4, 'Innovations that turn around persistently low-performing schools'. Two of the Competitive Priorities will be addressed, which are numbers 6 and 8, 'innovations that support college access and success' and 'Innovations that serve schools in rural LEAs'. Fourteen middle and high schools and 1300 participants will receive a variety of services that will achieve the following goals: improve student achievement and growth; close achievement gaps; decrease drop-out rates; increase high school graduation rates; and increase college enrollment and completion rates."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Thompson School District (TSD) Three-Year Improved Mathematics Education Sequence: Algebra 1, Geometry and Algebra 2 Contextualized with Career and Technical Education (CTE).
Integrating Computer Based Technology into the More Effective School Model for Increased Student Achievement Project
Project Description: "The TICSD plans to implement the Integrating Computer Based Technology into the More Effective School Model for Increased Student Achievement Project.  The primary goal of the project is to decrease non-completion rate by at least 10% annually for five years for students with disabilities so that all entering 9th grade will earn all necessary core content credit for graduation with their cohort.  A secondary goal is to increase student SAT and ACT scores for all students in order to assist in increasing student attendance at 4 year colleges and universities.  Lastly, the project also strives to increase the graduation rate at THIS for general education students with New York State Regents diploma by 5% annually for the five year project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Mentoring for Success
Project Description: "Our intent is to answer Absolute Priority # 4: 1.	Decrease dropout rate/increase graduation rate2.	Increase college and career readiness3.	Close achievement gap with high needs & disadvantaged studentsUsing a program of embedded professionally led, for fee mentorship utilizing proven training and doctrine in leadership, motivation, life skill development and college & workplace readinessThis Core concept is based on our Learning for Life Mission Statement.  It is the mission of Learning for Life to enable young people to become responsible individuals by teaching positive character traits, career development, leadership and life skills so that they can make moral choices and achieve their full potential.CORE OPERATIONAL CONCEPTS:1.	Utilize professional core of for fee mentors applying proven training and doctrine in leadership, motivation and team building to provide continuous, scaleable mentoring following students through the education process.2.	Augment resources consistent with AVID programming.3.	Provide resources and programs for college & workplace readiness, high school- career planning, focused programs of studies through private partnerships -i.e. industry certifications, middle school-exploration and elementary school-awareness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Serving Students Through Partnerships
Project Description: "An innovative dual credit secondary/higher education program for high needs students including: dual High School and College credit for courses, developmental and foundation college preparation courses offered on secondary school campuses, wrap around dedicated intensive support services for each student, cohort model with students beginning in cohorts within the secondary school setting and moving onto a college campus as a cohort in junior year, and parental involvement across districts through meetings and open forums. The Resiliency Foundation will provide professional development on working with high need students and families. This project will support college access and success (Competitive Priority 6) and include innovations that serve schools in rural areas (Competitive Priority 8).  Project Objectives and Outcomes:   Project objectives include collaborative planning across partners; hiring staff; selection of student cohorts; professional development and course development involving LEA teachers and college instructors; providing college credit-bearing courses at LEA sites; providing intensive student support services; and offering parent workshops.  Expected outcomes include decreased high school dropout rates, increased high school graduation rates, students earning twenty college credits by the time of high school graduation, increased access to coursework and services for students in rural areas, and increased parent understanding of the value and requirements of college. Special features: dual enrollment for high need students in three districts and tribal nation; supportive student cohort model with wraparound services; professional development in working with high needs students; cross-district parent education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Farmington Students Will Succeed
Project Description: "This proposal is requesting funding for embedding new teaching strategies in 763 classrooms for 10,087 students over a five-year period. A research model has been developed to track progress and results in each of these instrucitonal units. These strategies have been developed by Dr. Robert Marzano over a thirty-year period. It will be shown in this project that intense training, mentoring, and monitoring using data will increase achievement in reading and mathematics and close the gap between Caucasian students and Hispanic, Native American, Handicapped and Poverty level students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Power Up 21
Project Description: "Power Up 21 brings the work of two previous successful Title IID grant projects to a new level focused on the development and institutionalization of 21st century professional practices.  The project incorporates and extends all of the core elements of success delineated by the South Dakota Department of Education (SDDOE):  sustained and ongoing professional development on 21st century skills and technology tools, collaboration and participant coaching in learning communities, reflective practices, and core content development throughout the grant with a train-the-trainer component for sustainability. This project features professional development for current and future teachers through face-to-face events, online learning opportunities, cognitive coaching and the development of a teacher virtual network. Teachers and administrators in the partner districts will participate in a blended model of ongoing staff development whose structure and content solidly promotes 21st Century learning. In Phase 1 (Year 1) of the project 21 schools will come on board. In Year 2, 25 schools will be added. Both sets of schools will continue in Year 3 and 4."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Literacy on The Rise
Project Description: "Literacy on the Rise is a Response to Intervention (RTI) projected Development Program. This program will consist of several components to bridge the gap in an under performing urban school.  The goal is to provide teachers with early identification and intervention programs and strategies to prevent students' under achievement in literacy. To address the prevention of poor academic success, the Literacy on the Rise program will incorporate the following screening, benchmark, and RTI activities: DIBELS - The Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skills (DIBELS) - a set of procedures and measures for assessing the acquisition of early literacy skills from kindergarten through grade six. Orton Gillingham - a program that provides intervention strategies for struggling readers. Fountas and Pinnell - a comprehensive assessment system that is a reliable and specific benchmark system for matching students' instructional and independent reading abilities. Fast ForWord - a computer and Internet based program that focuses on early reading and cognitive skills that promote data to differentiate instruction. Write Brain - an interactive computer based program to enhance writing skills.  The projected objective is to provide intensive reading strategies that address the needs of struggling readers through the use of multi-sensory learning and technology.  The projected outcome is to increase students' abilities to read by at least one grade level within one academic year. At Thurgood Marshall Elementary School approximately 270 students of our 416 students read below grade level. This represents 65% of our Pre-K through grade 5 student population which will be the target for this project. This project will partner with Dr. Concetta Russo and Scientific Learning Corporation/Fast ForWord."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Full Circle Teacher Preparation Model
Project Description: "Today's Students Tomorrow's Teachers (TSTT) and its school partners are seeking a Validation grant to expand TSTT's Full Circle Teacher Preparation model. TSTT's Full Circle Teacher Preparation model is exceptional in that it supports high need students academically, financially and socially at every point along the teacher preparation pathway. Thus, it ensures that students graduate from high school, enter college with scholarships, graduate from college, and return 'Full Circle' to their communities as highly qualified teachers. While other teacher preparation programs operate in silos or just stop at key benchmarks -- leaving youth to navigate their own transition to the next step -- TSTT offers on-going mentoring, tutoring, instruction in educational practices, scholarships, career counseling, personal development, community-building, service opportunities, summer bridge programs and other supports over eight years of secondary and post-secondary education.  The TSTT program has five goals, all aligned with moving minority youth along the pathway toward becoming teachers:(1)	To improve student academic achievement. (2)	To increase the rate of high school graduation among program participants. (3)	To increase the rate of college enrollment (during the grant period) and graduation (after the grant period). (4)	To increase the number of minority youth participants staying on track to enter the teaching profession. (5)	To support effective teachers who can improve student achievement in high need schools. By the fifth year in this grant, TSTT and its partners expect to be serving 2,700 students in four states, and to be poised for further expansion. Based on TSTT's success in the past 15 years, this program is expected to raise student grades by 1 to 1.5 grade points and to result in a 90% high school graduation rate for participants."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Improving Early Learning Outcomes through Data Collection & Analysis
Project Description: "Project Title:  Improving Early Learning Outcomes through Data Collection & Analysis The Torrington Early Childhood Collaborative (TECC) in partnership with the Torrington Public School System requests consideration for a $30,000 Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Development Grant to further develop TECC's early childhood education data systems.   The Torrington Public Elementary Schools has an established relationship and success rate for creating positive outcomes for Torrington's children with TECC, a non-profit collaborative that strives to ensure that 'All of Torrington's children from birth though age eight are healthy and successful learners.'  Tracking data outcomes for an average birth cohort of 400 children centered on strategies in its comprehensive birth through eight community wide plan will help TECC evaluate the effectiveness of its outreach to high needs students and their families and make enhancements as needed to ensure they are healthy and successful learners.  With TECC's plan already grounded deeply in early childhood data through its Results Based Accountability framework, the project's one absolute priority will be Absolute Priority 2 - Innovations that Improve the Use of  Data with competitive preference priority 5 - Innovations for Improving Early Learning Outcomes as its focus.   TECC's official partner is the Torrington Public Schools along with over 20 other partners including agencies that support disadvantaged children.  The project objectives will include the following:  1.  Create a system to collect birth - 5 data   that is not currently being tracked that impacts positive outcomes for Torrington's English Language Learner and special needs population2. Implement a sustainable, community-wide, cross agency data collection system to track TECC's birth through eight strategy plan outcomes3.  Develop program measures for community outreach organizations that impact Torrington's high needs children to determine 'How well are we doi?"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Parent Impact and Effectiveness: How Improving the Knowledge and SKill Base of Parents Affects Student Educational Outcomes.

Too Good To Do Bad in School: Improving academic performance by preventing
antisocial behavior of high-need students in Phoenix Union High School District
Project Description: "Touchstone Behavioral Health (TBH), the lead applicant, is a non-profit, 501(c)(3) organization that provides evidence-based prevention and early intervention programs and behavioral health services to youth and families in Maricopa County, Arizona, has partnered with Phoenix Union High School District (PUHSD) to apply for a Validation grant under the Department of Education's Investing in Innovation Fund (i3). Since an application for a Validation grant must be supported by moderate evidence, the proposed project will implement the Too Good for Drugs & Violence (TGFD&V) High School intervention - a comprehensive prevention education program for high school students designed to equip students with the knowledge, skills and attitudes they need to remain safe and drug free in school and at home. The What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) has identified two well-designed and well-implemented studies conducted in Florida with approximately 700 high school students.  Both studies demonstrate the intervention's positive effects on student knowledge, attitudes and values, but less is known about the program's impact on academic performance and related outcomes for 'high-need' students from a large urban high school district (PUHSD), which our proposed evaluation study aims to learn more about. Touchstone's highly qualified prevention staff have six years of experience implementing TFGD&V High School and began implementing the program in PUHSD two years ago. In addition to the TGFD&V High School intervention, TBH will recruit especially vulnerable students (e.g., juvenile substance abuse and violent offenders, students with learning disabilities or limited English Proficient students, refugee students) and their families to participate in Brief Strategic Family Therapy (BSFT).   Moreover, an educational training workshop will be offered to parents and caregivers whose child(ren) participate in the TGFD&V High School intervention."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Braintree Alternatives
Project Description: "Abstract	The Braintree Schools is applying for Development grant to fund an Alternative Program that addresses Absolute Priority 3 - Innovations that complement the implementation of high standards and high-quality assessments.  In addition to meeting the Absolute Priority of the Investing in Innovation grant, Braintree Alternative Programming meets two competitive preference priorities: 6) Innovations that support college access and success  and 7) Innovations to address the unique learning needs of students with disabilities. 	The Braintree Schools Alternative Programming is designed to improve student achievement for high need students, and this project's focus is improvement in the state mathematics standards as evidenced on the Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System. Tenth grade students at Braintree High School have shown significant gains in closing the achievement gap between students with disabilities and students from low income backgrounds and their peers, and, in addition, the Braintree Schools has successfully reduced its dropout rate to .1%.   The Braintree Schools holds the hypothesis that these successful trends are attributable to a number of interventions and structures, particularly the Alternative Program at Braintree High School.   The programming, which includes five separate programs that apply behavior modification, community service learning and work experience to promote student success, serves approximately 140 students grades 9 - 12 has yielded a current dropout rate of .1%.   		While remaining in school to earn a regular high school diploma is a demonstrated positive outcome of the Alternative Program students, expansion and enhancement of the program will promote the successful transition of students from middle school to high school and from high school to postsecondary education and work. The I(3) fund will allow the Braintree Schools to add a middle school component to address the needs of a growing population of students g"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Equity, Access and College Readiness
Project Description: "This project is designed to provide our 'at-risk' minority and low-income students with access to the most rigorous courses that are currently offered in our district with the support necessary to ensure academic success and matriculation to college. All incoming eighth graders who meet the requisite demographic will be placed in a cohort of twenty students. Each cohort will be assigned an advisor who will stay with them throughout their entire high school career. The advisor will be responsible for making home visits; coordinating the student's schedule of classes (along with the high school counselor) and monitor the students' progress using data from both grades and standardized tests. The faculty mentor wil also coordinate and monitor the students' participation in Homework Club (an after school program designed to provide homework support daily) and the Summer Academic Institute (a mandatory summer program for all students in the project) and Community Service.       The project will support all teachers in our district as they develop curriculum and common assessments that are tied to the ACT College Readiness Standards. Additionally, this project is consisitent with our District's Equity Access Plan that is designed to eliminate systemic barriers for our 'at-risk' students and provide them with acess to our most rigorous courses."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The ABCiCis (Collaborative Interdisciplinary Curriculum Initiative) of College and Career Readiness (ABCs of CCR)
Project Description: "The ABCiCis of College and Career Readiness (ABCs of CCR) is a collaborative effort among partnering Illinois school districts. This program delivers standards through content-based skills instruction in the areas of reading, writing, critical thinking and integrations. This project serves as a prototype and makes use of an integrated instructional and assessment model that reveals ten years of demonstrated success with academically at-risk learners to Advanced Placement students from grades 9-12. The program practice and strategies to be deployed are designed to improve academic outcomes and to increase college and career readiness by ensuring all students are academically prepared for college (AP3).  Core content area teachers will collaborate in horizontal and/or vertical Professional Learning Communities on the development of instructional materials addressing the academic needs of all levels of learners, with productions of adapted materials for use with all students from challenged learners through AP students.This model will be validated and replicated district-wide.  There are two program goals associated with this project.  Goal 1 objectives include teachers learning to develop curriculum products that adhere to ACT skill bands; provide rich curriculum content; and develop assessments in the areas of reading, writing, critical thinking and integrations as evidenced by an improvement in students' academic performance on college readiness assessments. This deliberate scoped and sequenced curricular approach will result in increased student achievement and vertical course movement at each school across the district. The implementation will occur with fidelity, as modifications are made based on formative assessment data.  Goal 2 objectives are to build capacity to implement the Collaborative Interdisciplinary Curriculum Initiative model through a Learning Academy which creates systems that pre-assess and diagnosis school readiness for customized services."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: T.R.A.C.E.(The Race to Achieve Continued Excellence)
Project Description: "The T.R.A.C.E. (The Race to Achieve Continued Excellence) afterschool program will provide academic enrichment in reading and math for students in grades K-8 that live in high-poverty areas and those who attend low-performing, high priority and Title I schools in five (5) counties in the eastern region of the state of North Carolina. T.R.A.C.E. will operate Monday through Thursday for forty (40) weeks during the school year and 20 hour a week summer component. The T.R.A.C.E. program will serve 400 students for each year of funding."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Academy For Transforming America
Project Description: "ATA will be a hybrid institution, combining an online Virtual World and face-to-face engagement. Four hundred K-12 students throughout Michigan will attend full-time via high speed, DSL-Internet access, using laptop computers provided by ATA, and will not enroll elsewhere. Students and teachers will connect to a private, three-dimensional, Virtual World; ATA Campus built on the OpenSimulator computing platform, and have their own controllable avatar that is fully interactive in the scenes, and able to actively participate in an interactive/social environment that helps foster teaching and learning based on constructivist, active learning theory. Full-size buildings, classrooms, meeting halls, and interactive simulations will be realized as places on a ?260-acre? virtual campus, designed specifically for ATA. A complete educational program, meeting national standards will be presented. We stress that this is not the type of online teaching where an individual student takes 'computerized courses' that are simply repackaged classroom material, There will be physical, Internet Cafes in major cities where students meet for school-related activities, facilitated by teachers on the premises. Every student will have an accomplished, adult mentor in their locality, drawn from business, industry or research facilities, who will regularly meet the student in structured sessions--similar to an internship. This is intended to ground all student work in the practicalities of real world vocations, either immediately upon graduation, or after further higher education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Collective Intelligence
Project Description: "Triangle High Five (THF), a 501(c)3 in North Carolina, submits this proposal for a Development grant in partnership with 14 school districts to foster the development and evaluation of professional learning communities (PLCs) in our schools. The Collective Intelligence project will expand upon and evaluate the work that THF has been carrying out with PLCs since its inception in 2004. Educational reform activities in the project include effecting structural and cultural changes in school operations through, a) assisting school leaders to organize and institutionalize job-embedded PLCs for instructional staff, b) facilitating the interpretation of student achievement data to inform decision making, c) providing guidance on the frequent use of teacher-developed formative assessments, and d) supporting PLC team dialogue around lesson study and effective instructional strategies. The PLC ?treatment? will involve centralized, large-group professional development (PD); small-group PD to district Leadership Councils; coaching sessions for both the project?s Advisory Council and district Leadership Councils; provision of a PLC Implementation Matrix that informs PLC development and monitors fidelity to the model; access to an anonymous teacher survey; and facilitating ?affinity? groups (i.e., staff in similar positions such as principals) to discuss project implementation. Our hypothesis is that high-functioning PLCs effect positive change in teacher and student outcomes, and we will evaluate as the independent variable the set of PLC practices, training activities and resources that most beneficially contribute to this change. As dependent variables, our outcomes include teachers? use of student achievement data, teachers? use of formative assessment, and measures of student achievement. Based on the findings, THF has the capacity to sustain grant operations beyond the period of grant funding and scale up and replicate operations with other school districts across the state... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Diagnostic Mathematics Assessment System Project
Project Description: "This proposal seeks development funding from the Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) grant program to developand deploy an online formative and cognitively diagnostic assessment system for middle school mathematics,the Diagnostic Mathematics Assessment System (DMAS). The DMAS will address students? misconceptionsin middle school algebra, geometry, proportional reasoning, probability, and statistics, and contain onlinesupport and instructional training for teachers. The DMAS has three components: 1) diagnostic test itemstargeting common mathematical misconceptions; 2) online performance reports that provide teachers with botha student ability estimate and a diagnostic report identifying students likely operating under a misconception;and 3) an online suite of instructional resources targeting each misconception. The DMAS project respondsdirectly to Absolute Priority 3 by both developing formative assessments and training teachers to translate theresults of those assessments into modifications of their instructional approaches. The DMAS project respondsto Competitive Preference Priority 7 by providing instructional resources for working with students withlimited English proficiency. The DMAS project responds to Competitive Preference Priority 8 because theprovision of instructional resources through the free-standing DMAS, a system that can be accessed anywhere,and requires only an Internet connection, is especially powerful for rural districts. In support of this work, theresearchers provide theoretical hypotheses and moderate evidence from a well-designed and well-implementedrandomized controlled trial with limited generalizability (high internal validity and low to moderate externalvalidity)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: City Connects: A Systemic Approach to Student Support
Project Description: "City Connects (CCNX) is an evidence-based, effective and innovative student support approach.  CCNX addresses the strengths and needs of every student in a school across academic, social-emotional, health and family dimensions.  CCNS: 1) identifies key areas of strengths and needs across the four dimensions; 2) connects students to a tailored set of community-based support services and enrichment opportunities; 3) documents and tracks the service plan for each student; and 4) follows up to assure service delivery and assess effectiveness.In a quasi-experimental study of student data from 12 treatment and 7 comparison high-poverty urban schools, CCNX has demonstrated positive impacts on academic achievement.  More CCNX students achieve at MCAS Proficient & Advanced categories that Boston Public Schools as a whole, by 10th grade scoring similar to the state average.  CCNX has improved grades in Language Arts and Math.  The probability of being retained in grade, a dropout predictor, is smaller for CCNX students.  Students in CCNX schools also do better on other measures, e.g., classroom behavior, effort, and work habits.  Benefits are often largest for those at risk for academic failure (e.g. English Language Learners).This study will expand CCNX to the regional level and validate the positive effects.  This Validation grant will address Absolute Priority 4 by: 1) Extending CCNX to eight persistently underperforming, turn-around schools in Boston; 2) Confirming past findings of positive CCNX effects by analyzing data from Boston Public Schools' randomized school lottery selection system; 3) Implementing CCNX at a regional level and rigorously testing program effects through a randomized controlled trial with 34 (17 treatment, 17 control) elementary schools in tow new school districts (Worcester and Brockton Public Schools); and 4) Addressing sustainabililty and scale-up by designing and implementing standard practices, training protocols, and data collection systems"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York
Project Title: New York Collaborative of Science Educators and Resarchers (NYCSER)
Project Description: "The New York Collaborative of Science Educators and Researchers (NYCSER) will provide intensive, hands-on laboratory research experiences, sustained professional development, and focused in-school academic year support for New York City public high school science teachers. The partnership between two long-established (Columbia University and Rockefeller University) and one nascent (New York University) science teacher professional development programs brings to the cause of pre-college STEM education the human and physical resources of three of the world's most renowned research institutions, and a track record of proven success in providing STEM teacher professional development that significantly improves student performance in science in a cost effective manner. A principal purpose of this project is to determine whether the improved student science achievement and teacher retention reported by Columbia University's Summer Research Program for Science Teachers can be replicated and expanded.The proposal describes a manifestly successful approach to improving STEM achievement of historically under-achieving, largely low income, predominantly minority, New York City public high school students through increased teacher effectiveness. It identifies specific measurable goals, describes how these goals will be met; and uses established methods and measures to document success. This partnership will catalyze expansion of the Columbia University and Rockefeller University programs; enable New York University to found a new program; and enrich and improve STEM professional development at all three institutions. Assuming success, the programs' leaders anticipate expanding their partnership to form a New York City-wide consortium of science-rich cultural institutions that will have the capacity to provide similar professional development for more than a third of New York City's public high school science teachers every 5 years.NYCSER will use a rigorous quasi-experiment"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The IN-AACR Project: Facilitating Indiana Teachers' Access to Assessment Data, Analysis Tools, and Innovative Curriculum Resources
Project Description: "The overall goal of the IN-AACR (Assessment Data, Analysis Tools, and Innovative Curriculum Resources) project is to develop and implement resources, tools, and a support structure to facilitate the implementation of data-driven decision making (DDDM) among teachers and school leaders throughout Indiana. To accomplish this, we will focus this five-year project on the following objectives: (1)Implement and enhance online, single-point access to student assessment data, (2) develop simple, dynamic online data analysis and synthesis tools, (3) develop a database of curricula resources and 'best practice' strategies linked to the data analysis tools that teachers and students can access and utilize in multiple ways, and (4) implement a holistic professional development and ongoing support program that assists teachers and school personnel with implementing DDDM."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania
Project Title:
Using Student Data to Improve Student Learning:  A Strategic Partnership 
between Schoolnet, Corporate University Exchange and the University of 
Pennsylvania
Project Description: "The University of Pennsylvania is proposing an innovative certification program for new teachers.  Through a cohort-based online certification program in data-based decision making, this initiative relies on the use of actual student data from the enrolled teachers' classrooms in order to enhance teacher practice and ultimately improve student learning. This program is based in an action research model and borrows from the medical field the concept of 'grand rounds'. In other words, throughout the 18-month program, teachers will present their data to their online inquiry community in order to better understand their students and improve their teaching practice. For the purposes of this grant, we will be partnering with two school districts, which together serve students from a diverse range of contexts, in order to pilot the certificate program.  We strongly believe, however, that this certification process can easily be expanded across the United States, to rural and urban areas alike. "

Project Title: Improving English Language Fluency Through Teacher Effectiveness in Thirty-Five California Schools
Project Description: "California?s Tulare and Kings counties have large populations of limited English proficient students and schools are struggling to meet their needs. A 2004 report by California?s Legislative Analyst?s Office found that developing English fluency is taking too long: if students are not fluent in English by the fourth grade, they risk falling behind in the core curriculum and never catching up. The need for improved English language (EL) instruction is critical, but Tulare/Kings districts face an added barrier: they are small and lack the resources brought by scale, particularly in the area of data analysis.In this program, we focus on fluency at the school and teacher levels, measuring teachers? effectiveness in developing fluency and high performance in English Language Arts and Mathematics in 35 small schools serving 7,000 students. We use targeted professional development and peer coaching to turn ?ineffective? and ?emerging effective? EL teachers into ?effective? and ?highly effective? teachers. Provided with sophisticated yet user-friendly data reports on their own students, teachers learn to examine their students? performance and use that data to make changes in their classrooms. Principals will also use the data. This program includes a large amount of EL expert coaching time (for teachers and administrators) to ensure that teachers identified as needing targeted professional development get the training they need. Program outcomes include: improvedstudent performance (English language fluency, English Language Arts, and Math), a decline in the number of ineffective EL teachers, improved Title III compliance, and increased use of student data in principal feedback to teachers. This program will be implemented by an LEA experienced in implementing large grants that have yielded significant and sizeable improvements in student performance."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Validation of the Tulsa Pre-K Model
Project Description: "The Project's Overall Goal is to significantly improve young children?s development and learning, as well as their readiness for long-term academic achievement, in both the urban setting of Tulsa and the rural setting of Northeastern Oklahoma, through developmentally appropriate, standards-based strategies targeting 3 yo Pre-K  to K (?3 yo Pre-K ? K?) students. The i3 'Practice, Strategy, or Program' proposed by the Partners to meet their overall goal is the Tulsa Pre-K Model. The Partner?s i3 Plan is to:1. Formalize the Tulsa Pre-K Model for expansion and implementation fidelity.2. Update the Model?s curriculum standards, assessments and mastery criteria to align with the Common Core state Standards K-12.3. Implement and rigorously study the Model?s efficacy in:? 20 TPS-located CAP Pre-K classes serving 3 year olds? 186 TPS 4-year-old Pre-K classes? 180 TPS kindergarten classes.? 3 Pre-K classes (4-year-old) and 3 kindergarten classes in Caney Valley Public Schools.? 1 Pre-K (4-year-old) and 1 kindergarten class in Barnsdall Public Schools.4. Create a plan for scaling up the Model for implementation in the region and statewide"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
