Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project INSPIRE
Project Description: "Project INSPIRE, a Development i3 grant, will meaningfully impact student outcomes by improving the quality of teaching practices in the Tupelo Public School District (TPSD), with potential benefits to the region, through the use of a rigorous staff development process as well as enrichment opportunities.   Addressing both Absolute Priority 1 and Competitive Preference Priority 5, the project is designed to impact the learning outcomes of Pre-K through 3rd grade high-needs students by delivery of programs that support, increase and retain the percentage of teachers who are highly effective in the early elementary and lower elementary grades.  The project has two overarching goals:  improve the quality of instruction and improve the quality of learning.   Components involve the delivery of individualized professional development through the CLASS (Classroom Assessment Scoring System), offering distance staff development, establishing a laboratory school, summer enrichment programming and classroom expansion.  Accomplishing these will involve collaboration with other community partners including the Family Resource Center, Itawamba Community College and Head Start.  Also collaborating will be the Early Childhood Institute, nationally recognized for its commitment to improve early learning throughout the state.  Efforts will begin at the district's Early Childhood Education Center (ECEC), a Title I Pre-K school which serves 220 high-needs four-year old students.   Ultimately, the goal is to impact student outcome of 2,600 PreK through 3rd grade TPSD students by improving the teacher effectiveness of 232 teachers and by increasing their retention.  Furthermore, the initiative has the capacity to affect 338 licensed child care centers and over 26,000 children in a 22 county region.  This initiative has received broad-based and sustainable private sector support."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: TFC Partnership: Transformation through Systems, Skills and Services
Project Description: "Turnaround for Children, Inc. (TFC), with the New York City Department of Education as LEA partner and American Institutes for Research as independent evaluator, submits this request under Absolute Priority 4, 'Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools,' section (b) 'Targeted Approach to Reform,' subsection (2) 'integrating student supports into the school model to address nonacademic barriers to student achievement.'  By methodically addressing the adverse impact of poverty on schools, TFC builds school capacity to confront nonacademic and academic barriers and create a positive climate and culture to foster student achievement.  This model is a scalable, cost-effective and critical foundation for the transformation of chronically underperforming schools in high-poverty communities.  The main goal of this project is to demonstrate the effectiveness of TFC's intervention model through a rigorous independent evaluation of the model's implementation in eight New York City middle schools, with 24 control schools.  The proposed project will not only demonstrate the effectiveness of TFC's intervention in helping schools meet students' nonacademic needs, it will also show how an intensive focus on the creation of a positive school climate and culture provides the missing piece of the school transformation puzzle."

Project Title: Turnaround Leadership Institute
Project Description: "Turnaround Leadership Institute (TLI) is an integrated program of coursework and mentoring specifically designed to equip school leaders with the skills and knowledge needed to turn around low-performing, high-needs schools.  Designed by the Mosaica Leadership Institute, TLI's programs are both research-based and school-proven.  The program is built on the PD and mentoring programs that led to the successful turnarounds of the four charter schools/LEA's participating in this application (see Official Partners, below).  TLI brings together best practices in student-centered curriculum delivery and business-enterprise turnaround leadership techniques that have been proven effective.  Unlike other leadership programs, TLI offers principals the opportunity for extensive and focused professional development in a time frame suited to the rapid pace of school turnaround initiatives.  The TLI program is individualized to meet the needs of each principal, with coursework differentiated by their schools' grade levels, job-embedded learning, and ongoing hands-on training, as well as  mentoring of each principal by school turnaround experts over the three-year term of the grant.  Objectives:  To provide new school turnaround principals with: 1) Instruction in 'best practices' for turnaround management, 2) Support/mentoring from experienced turnaround leaders, 3) Effective turnaround tools that have been shown to produce results in both school- and business-turnaround environments, and 4) A network of supportive colleagues with whom they can share experiences and obtain advice and support.    Outcomes:  The Turnaround Leadership Institute will increase the number of principals well-equipped to improve the performance of high-needs schools by 1) Engaging in effective instructional leadership practices, 2) Using data to effectively instruct, evaluate, and develop teachers, and 3) Inspiring cultural change to develop highly effective school communities. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Tuscarora Digital Initiative
Project Description: "	This project deploys a one-to-one laptop, or ubiquitous digital access, to the 850 high school students and 50 teachers of James Buchanan HS, with the necessary server infra structure to support access from home as well as in school.  The major activities of the project aim at professional development of teachers and staff to elevate teaching practices toward the 21st Century Learning Skills.  Initial training is provided by Apple, Inc. and subsequent follow through is derived from the LoTi Connection resources for assessment and training.  Key school staff become certified LoTi Mentors, each school department establishes a Learning Community, and teachers undergo intensive training during the summers and supplemental training during the school year.	The project anticipates gains in computer classroom integration and adoption of challenge based learning practices as measured by LoTi assessments.  Further, gains are expected among the more traditional indicators of educational achievement such as performance of NCLB standardized tests, college enrollments, etc.  	The project also aims to promote increased use of hybrid coursework and the de novo development of hybrid coursework by existing teaching staff.	The partners for this project include Apple, Inc. and Temple University.  The former provides tech hardware and support as well as professional development support.  The latter serves as external evaluator.  The LoTi Connection is enlisted to provide a substantial portion of professional development and assessment tools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Biomedical Leadership Academy of Science and Technology B.L.A.S.T
Project Description: "Funding is requested under the development category. BLAST uses research-based instructional strategies,STEM curriculum materials and real-business experience (internships) to educate a portion of the futureworkforce in Orange County and in California. Our overall program approach is based on the highly successfulProject Lead the Way (PLTW) Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) education program. Theintense 'Academy' program will be comprised of a sequence of four biomedical-focused STEM courses, witheach building on the skills and knowledge students gained in the proceeding courses. BLAST will targetapproximately 2,200 students over the five-year project period. Our overall program goal is to offer OrangeCounty students a comprehensive program that will prepare them to further their education in the Biomedicaland Biotechnical fields, for the purposed of securing gainful employment in these industries. BLAST programobjectives include: Increase the number of students in Orange County prepared to enter the Biomedical orBiotechnical fields and success; Increase the number of students in sub-populations pursuing education in theBiomedical field; Increase the number of Orange County schools offering Biomedical courses; and Providestudents with a work-based experience in the Biomedical field. Year one BLAST outcomes will include: Atleast 100 students will be enrolled in either of the two programs offered; Enrollment of BLAST will becomprised of at least 40% students who are members of sub-populations; At least three Orange County schoolswill be offering Biomedical courses; At least 50% of participating students will participate in a work-basedexperience in the Biomedical field; and At least 50% of feeder middle school students will develop a career ineducation plan. We expect to serve approximately 2,200 students over five years."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Validation of extended day and targeted instruction to improve student achievement
Project Description: "The need for scalable strategies that rapidly boost student achievement is a critical issue facing thousands of low-performing schools serving disadvantaged students. Our project is designed to address the growing emphasis on aligning student improvement with high achievement standards and college- and career-readiness?and on mandating core testing in reading and math. The main goal is to validate the efficacy of ILS-based targeted instruction in Title I schools. That instruction will be delivered via an extended school day with the goal of significantly increasing K-8 achievement in reading comprehension, literacy, and mathematics. Our vision integrates multiple Project and Program goals and milestones with specific objectives under Absolute Priority 3 to attain the overall DOE i3 validation goal.Tutor Hawai?i proposes to demonstrate the effectiveness of its ILS-based targeted instruction program for all students. It will do so through a validation research and program development study involving a consortium of 30 Elementary and Middle/Intermediate Hawai?i schools, representing a sample group of ~15,000 K-8 students. Tutor Hawai?i has assembled an expert R&D team consisting of internal staff, expert consultants and advisors, and subcontractors. The team?s goal is to show that we can significantly increase measurable student achievement for all students and to demonstrate the efficacy of Tutor Hawai?i's unique ?TIED? (Targeted Instruction, Extended Day) Program.We believe the TIED model will be easily replicated nationwide. To support that deployment effort, during this R&D project we intend to identify a broad range of best practices and develop a TIED Program Guide for use by diverse schools for adopting this model and using it to increase student achievement and reduce achievement gaps. Tutor Hawai`i will use the results obtained via the TIED project as an impetus to facilitate schools? shift toward a 21st century focus."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
Realizing the Power and Promise of School Reform for High Needs Students in Low
Performing Schools: Addressing Non-Academic Barriers to Learning & Instruction
Project Description: "Realizing the Power and Promise of School Reform for High Needs Students in Low Performing Schools:Addressing Non-Academic Barriers to Learning & Instruction (Development Award)Efforts to turn around low-performing schools commonly focus on strengthening two components: 1)leadership and 2) curriculum and instruction. However, school reform must take into account readiness to learn,to teach, and to address systemic issues that sacrifice the academic and life success of youth. The Center forHealthy Schools, Families & Communities, the Statewide Parent Advocacy Network, and Jersey City PublicSchools aim to build the capacity of school administrators and staff, parents, students, and communitystakeholders to develop, implement, and sustain a comprehensive, integrated, evidence-based, culturally-sensitivecontinuum of policies, programs, services, and practices that address non-academic barriers to learning andinstruction across six domains: problem prevention/ wellness promotion; home outreach, education, andinvolvement; student/family assistance; service linkages; community partnerships; and infrastructure support.The plan involves a quasi-experimental design; the project will be implemented in one high school and onemiddle school that meet the criteria of being ?low performing? schools; two schools matched on keycharacteristics will serve as no-intervention comparisons. Approximately 3500 students across schools willparticipate. The evaluation will include an assessment of outcomes on intermediate (e.g. attendance, suspensions,parental involvement) as well as key variables of interest (e.g. academic success, achievement gap, drop-out,graduation). The inclusion of technology-based interventions, emphasis on strengthening family support,intensive technical assistance, a participatory research component and creation of a tool-kit will enhanceoutcomes and the potential for the project to inform public policy and school transformation practices."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Preparing College and Career Ready Students: Removing Barriers to Success
Project Description: "The project builds on USD 233's successful 21st Century High School (21st CHS) programs, which were initiated seven years ago. These programs have re-created the high school experience for hundreds of students, engaging their passions during and BEYOND the school day and increasing post-secondary and career readiness. While 25% of our current high school students are enrolled in these programs, we must engage more students, especially under-represented students.  For example, while district diversity is growing, diversity enrollment in the 21st CHS programs is nearly negligible. This proposal maps a pathway for more students from all demographic groups to participate. Four barriers exclude under-represented students: 1) poor literacy skills impacting all content areas, 2) lack of experience with post-secondary possibilities and career options, especially in the areas of science, technology, engineering, and math, 3) lack of adult advisors and mentors; and 4) the lack of 21st CHS programs aligned with student interest and the community's economic drivers. To increase enrollment, interventions begin at elementary, continuing through middle and high school. Curriculum will be re-aligned with the Core and Career/Technical Education Standards, comprehensive literacy strategies taught, home and college visits conducted for students and families, adult advisors and mentors provided, and 21st CHS program options increased to match student and job market needs. Data will enhance decision-making, with a focus on increased formative assessment measures. Financial support for dual enrollment classes and high stakes tests (ACT, SAT, AP) will be provided to students in need. This grant will prepare students for college and careers by removing the identified barriers for all students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Unified School District 259 dba Wichita Public Schools
Project Title: Suporting Student Success (s3)
Project Description: "Student Success (s3) is a district-wide project to provide increased support for high need students to assure their growth and eventual graduation into post-secondary education or successful career placement. The project will be an innovative combination of programs and services to support students from middle school through graduation from high school. s3 will coordinate the successfully established AVID program as a means of student support with the emerging SpringBoard program that will provide rigor in classroom instruction of English language arts and math under an effective administrative structure devised for the successful provision of all program services and for the continuation of s3 after grant funding. Student support services will be provided to assess barriers to learning and a Multi-Tiered System of Support (an adaptation of the Response to Intervention or RtI mosel for assigning students who are struggling to receive more adequate instruction) will be employed to assure their ability to master core subjects. As designed, the project will not only increase students' ability to score well on assessments, but will provide instruction and practice with 21st century skills that are important to employers.The project will directly serve 3,410 new students in each of seven feeder pattern each year as the project is phased into all WPS comprehensive high schools and their feeder schools with a cumulative total of 22,470 students being served during the fifth and final year of the project. With professional development in AVID and SpringBoard, Advanced Placement, and pre-AP, instructors will enhance and refine their pedagogical skills for facilitating learning in all students. An outside evaluator will assess progress toward meeting project objectives of increasing measures of student achievement, increasing graduation rates, and preparing students for post secondary academic pursuits and / or entry into a chosen career field. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Whole Wichita: District-wide System of Supports
Project Description: "Wichita Public Schools, an urban district serving nearly 50,000 students is investing in the innovation of systemic change through literacy and behavior supports throughout the school district. In addition to these supports, implementation of a comprehensive assessment system will be implemented to include universal screening and progress monitoring, critical components to the state's Multi-tiered System of Supports (MTSS). The MTSS Configuration matrix will be used as a guide and measure for implementation with fidelity of literacy supports, behavior supports, and the effective use of data to enhance decision making. The SchoolStat process will be used at the district an school levels to monitor fidelity to implementation and manage accountability systemically in making decisions programatically and instructionally for student achievement purposes. All teachers and students in the district's 106 schools, district administration, and personnel involved in all aspects of operations will participate in this systemic process, creating a district-wide culture of mindful learning for all to improve instructional practices and academic outcomes toward learning for life."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: United Way of Greater Los Angeles
Project Title: Fremont Family of Schools Data Project: Systematic School Improvement through the Use of Data
Project Description: "The innovation proposes a comprehensive multi-tiered approach to develop the capacities of an entire school community, including parents and community leaders, teachers and school and district staff and administrators, to inform decision-making through the effective use of data. The project will be piloted in the Fremont family of schools, one of Los Angeles Unified School District's highest needs communities, and used to inform not only classroom instruction in the Fremont family of schools, but also district-wide policy and accountability measures. The Fremont Family pf Schools Data Project takes aim at shifting from a culture of data-based compliance to one of continuous data use, inquiry and improvement that will: (1) leverage the assets of parents and the wider community to prevent and solve problems; (2) help educators and the community better align school and district resources; (3) enhance teachers' and other school staff members' pedagogical repertoires; and (4) inform policymakers in enhancing district-wide accountability measures.The L.A. Compact, an unprecedented and diverse collaborative of 18 major Los Angeles institutions, whose members include Official Partners (UNITE-LA and the Los Angeles Education Partnership) and Other Partners (City of Los Angeles and the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce) will help to suport the project, ensure transparency and accountability and look to scale the project district-wide."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Complementary Learning Environment for Academic Readiness
Project Description: "United Way of Metropolitan Atlanta is partnering with the Gwinnett County Public Schools to propose CLEAR,an i3 Development initiative designed to level the playing field for high-need children. Focusing on parentengagement and early learning through effective, academic-based school transitions, we will ensure the 6,151children served have access to the same learning supports that are the norm for middle-class children.Implementing CLEAR in the catchment areas of 27 target elementary schools, we will create complementarylearning communities to facilitate family empowerment and improve student achievement which will lead toclosing achievement gaps. The key program components are: (1) School Transitions, to PreK, K, and grades 1,2, and 3; (2) Parents as First Teachers with full model PAT services for high-need families of birth-5; (3)Parent Leadership via Parent Leadership Institutes and Parent Caf
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: United Way of Miami-Dade, Miami, FL for the Center of Excellence in Early Education
Project Title: SELECT -Scaffolding Early Learning by Effective Classroom Teachers
Project Description: "SELECT -Scaffolding Early Learning by Effective Classroom Teachers  project that partners Miami-Dade Public Schools, a high needs school district, and United Way of Miami-Dade, with Mid-Continent Research for Education and Learning (McREL) to develop and pilot test an innovative professional development program.As its name emphasizes, Scaffolding Early Learning (SEL) professional development model focuses on scaffolding; it is designed specifically to help early childhood educators understand how to first build and then gradually withdraw instructional support so that children move from teacher-directed to independent activity.  SEL helps teachers master three critical components of effective scaffolding: (1) understanding developmental trajectories for literacy and math competencies as well as the trajectories for developing social-emotional and self-regulation skills; (2) designing instructional supports that fit the skill or concept being taught as well as individual needs of young learners; and (3) knowing how to 'delegate responsibility' for the learning to children by 'arming' these children with 'tools' that allow them to eventually become independent learners.   Teachers who know how to successfully scaffold children's learning would be able to maximize student engagement in learning and thus ensure their attaining of critical foundational competencies and their success in kindergarten and beyond. With appropriate scaffolding, all children, including students with disabilities and limited English proficient students, are able to develop academic skills for school success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: An Early Warning and Response System in a Southern Urban Public Education  System
Project Description: "Duval County (Jacksonville, FL) has wide gaps in public high school graduation rates, including in student sub-groups, where it consistently ranks near the bottom in Florida. The Learning To Finish (LTF) Collaborative started building an Early Warning and Response System (EWRS) this school year by identifying high-risk students by name and then starting to focus school and community resources on those students.  The LTF i3 Project will build on this initial work as well as research from other urban districts using EWRS strategies.  LTF will fully develop, implement, and evaluate an integrated school-community EWRS. Annually about 950 participating students will be identified for EWRS participation.  They will be attending a high school or middle school that meets qualifying criteria for low-performing schools as defined in i3 guidelines and will exhibit early warning indicators, identified in local research as leading to dropping out.  EWRS strategies include frequent student data analysis, student engagement, family engagement, extended learning opportunities, and additional academic and community supports.   ??????????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: United Way of Pitt County Inc.
Project Title: The Middle School Collaborative
Project Description: "The Middle School Collaborative is a comprehensive partnership between non-profit educational providers and Pitt County Schools LEA to support high needs students from middle school through successful graduation. The program began in 2006 and has served 307 students and over 600 families with early academic interventions, supplement educational programs, and family engagement courses. The Collaborative combines university specialists, the LEA, and community partners to weave a unique net to catch at-risk youth in elementary school and carry them through successful graduation and beyond.The Collaborative has three main components: the Student Success Academy (SSA) beginning in 5th grade and continuing through graduation; a Family Engagement Pathway (FEP) with emphasis on college readiness; and a 21st Century Leadership Academy (21LA) which gives high-needs youth guidance and support for college and career success.Success and significance are the guiding principles and vision for every SSA student. Our project goals are: 1) increased commitment to learning measured by attendance rates, grades, and attitudinal surveys. 2) school success measured by promotion standards, attendance, suspensions, and involvement in extracurricular activities. 3) college readiness is measured by EOG tests, four-year graduation rates, graduation surveys, and a developing set of career- and college- metrics aligned with the developing North Carolina standards.This strategy will allow the LEA to implement research-based measures, interim assessments, and deliver a co-curricular leadership experience that translate to college and career readiness with the goal of preparing high-need youth for advanced courses, careers, and college.Over the next five years, the Collaborative will serve 900 high-needs students with intensive math and reading interventions, career and college opportunities, and tutorial and leadership development to prepare them for academically rigorous courses.The Middle S... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: A Network of Global Education Schools (NGES)
Project Description: "Type of Grant Requested: DevelopmentProject description and activities: NGES will be focused on those schools referred to as Investing in Innovation Fund Absolute Priority 4 schools. Project innovative approach is targeted to implement innovative educational model, practices and strategies designed to enable K-12 students, particularly high school students, to successfully prepare for, enter, and graduate from a two-or four-year college. The project activities includes: Establish ten (10) learning centers in the network; apply the global education experience for students who will be participating in the program; provide teachers, parents and community members with network experiences; develop Spanish and English Language Curricula and Materials for the different school levels; and tracking of students from the schools identified in the network: pilot Elementary School to Intermediate School;Intermediate School to High School; High School to college.Summary of project objectives and expected outcomes: The project objectives are:1. To create the technological infrastructure in the schools participating in UNE-NGES.2. The 100% of students under NGES Project scores will improve to proficiency level in Math, Spanish, and English to comply with NCLB 2014 goals.3. To implement in UNE-NGES the global education professional development plan for teachers, parents and community members.4. To increase college admission in 70% in the schools identified in the network.Target number of students to be served: 9,912 up to 16,660 during the first four years.Any special project features: N/AList of official and other partners: NGES is a partnership between the Puerto Rico Department of Education (representing LEA), and Universidad del Este."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Alaska Educational Innovations Network, Phase 2
Project Description: "Project Description: The project will expand the Alaska Educational Innovations Network and focus on using data to make informed educational decisions. We will hold face to face institutes and facilitate ongoing, job-embedded professional learning, synchronously and asynchronously, with school, district, state, and university educators.Summary of Objectives and Outcomes: To enhance and evaluate a systemic approach to building the professional capacity of teachers and school leaders around a validated data literacy model which is aligned with instructional practices and a distributed leadership infrastructure to produce statistically significant gains in student growth, as measured by the student engagement in their schools and their gains in academic achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Alaska Sattewide Mento Project - Innovation in Education
Project Description: "The Alaska Statewide Mentor Project proposal will expand the intervention, in this case full-release mentoring and its effect on Early Career Teachers as measured by student achievement gains, teacher quality and teacher retention. The priorities will focus on expanding the program to a statewide level at the same time ensuring the project evaluation utilizes a third party research association to conduct a rigorous experimental design study. Thus, absolute priority and competitive priority preference include: o	Absolute Priority 1-Innovations That Support Effective Teachers and Principalso	Competitive Preference Priority 7- Innovations To Address the Unique Learning Needs of Students With Disabilities and Limited English o	Competitive Preference Priority 8- Innovations That Serve Schools in Rural LEAs (Up to Two Points)"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of Arkansas at Little Rock
Project Title:
Partnerships in Comprehensive Literacy: A Systemic Approach for Turning Around Low
Performing Schools
Project Description: "Project DescriptionThe proposed project, Partnerships in Comprehensive Literacy: A Systemic Approach for Turning Around LowPerforming Schools, is designed to improve the literacy achievement of Investing in Innovation Fund AbsolutePriority 4 schools through whole school reform and effective interventions. The University of Arkansas atLittle Rock (UALR), in collaboration with partnering universities, a consortium of schools, CISCO/Tandberg,and other private/ philanthropic organizations; proposes to study, refine, document and disseminate (a) bestliteracy practices; (b) model classroom and school structures; (c) data systems; (d) standards and assessments;and (e) professional development delivery systems that contribute to improving students? literacy achievementin high need schools.Project Objectives and Expected OutcomesThe objectives and expected outcomes for the proposed project are as follows:1. decrease the number of students scoring at ?below basic? and ?basic? levels;2. increase the number of students scoring at or above the ?proficient? level;3. reduce the number of students currently identified as learning disabled.To accomplish these specific aims we have identified the following goals for the project:1. All K-3 students are provided with excellent classroom literacy instruction.2. A Comprehensive Assessment System (CAS) that provides systemic as well as individual student data isprovided for all.3. If students are not making progress in the classroom, a comprehensive literacy diagnostic (CLD) isadministered in order to gather more information about the students.4. Teachers providing interventions and special education services to students struggling with acquiring literacyskill are, or are becoming, literacy experts who know how to differentiate and design instruction to acceleratestudent learning.5. School structures are in place that focus on student data, are self-sustaining, and encourage and support theprofessional growt"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of Arkansas at Little Rock
Project Title: Partnerships in Comprehensive Literacy: A Systemic Approach for Turning Around Low Performing Schools
Project Description: "Project DescriptionThe proposed project, Partnerships in Comprehensive Literacy: A Systemic Approach for Turning Around Low Performing Schools, is designed to improve the literacy achievement of Investing in Innovation Fund Absolute Priority 4 schools through whole school reform and effective interventions.  The University of Arkansas at Little Rock (UALR), in collaboration with partnering universities, a consortium of schools, CISCO/Tandberg, and other private/ philanthropic organizations; proposes to study, refine, document and disseminate (a) best literacy practices; (b) model classroom and school structures; (c) data systems; (d) standards and assessments; and (e) professional development delivery systems that contribute to improving students' literacy achievement in high need schools.Project Objectives and Expected OutcomesThe objectives and expected outcomes for the proposed project are as follows:1.	decrease the number of students scoring at 'below basic' and 'basic' levels; 2.	increase the number of students scoring at or above the 'proficient' level; 3.	reduce the number of students currently identified as learning disabled.To accomplish these specific aims we have identified the following goals for the project:1. A Comprehensive Assessment System (CAS) that provides systemic as well as individual student data is provided for all. 3.	If students are not making progress in the classroom, a comprehensive literacy diagnostic (CLD) is administered in order to gather more information about the students. 4.	Teachers providing interventions and special education services to students struggling with acquiring literacy skill are, or are becoming, literacy experts who know how to differentiate and design instruction to accelerate student learning. 5.	School structures are in place that focus on student data, are self-sustaining, and encourage and support the professional growt"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of California - Berkeley Extension, Department of Education
Project Title: Charting the Course for the Next Generation
Project Description: "Using an 'Adopt a School' model, multi-disciplinary resources are combined to leverage reform and student achievement.  These resources are brought to support and enhance teacher effectiveness, principal effectiveness and to substantially increase the performance of high-needs students.  Resources, critical to creation of an effective school will include implementation of the most effective research-based models of instructional practice, the most effective design and model of professional development and teacher support, an articulated intervention and after school program, the most effective 'best practices' of leadership coaching, the collaboration of college access programs with proven success:  Upward Bound and the Puente Project."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: UCF STEM-Focused Early Upward Bound Program
Project Description: "The UCF STEM-focused Early Upward Bound program is an Absolute Priority 4, targeted approach to?turn around? persistently lowest-achieving middle school students in lowest 5% Title I schools by implementinga ?school within-a-school? model of intervention strategies. This model provides over-aged students with theopportunity to remediate deficiencies and accelerate to grade level without the restrictions of a traditionalcurriculum. The project will serve a cohort of over-aged sixth graders (up to 66) and over-aged eighth graders (upto 75) for three consecutive years. Intervention strategies integrate a high level of student support througheffective teacher training, tutoring and mentoring, a social-work model of family advocacy and parent supporteducation, creative use of technology and information fluency, increasingly rigorous coursework to the level ofcollege prep curriculum, personal finance and college financial aid literacy programs; as well as develop a?college-going culture? by equipping students with skills to navigate the application and enrollment process, andadditional activities, as needed to overcome individual obstacles to college and career readiness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: University School Learning Partnership: An Innovative 21st Century Model
Project Description: "The University of Central Florida (UCF) proposes a development grant, the University School Learning Partnership: An Innovative 21st Century Model. This replicable and sustainable model is hypothesized to improve effectiveness of current and future teachers and administrators, as well as student performance by leveraging the partnership capacity of UCF, Seminole County Public Schools (SCPS), the Children?s Home Society, and Seminole State College (SSC). Through measureable improvement of teacher effectiveness, administrator effectiveness, and student performance, particularly of target students who are economically disadvantaged, who are English language learners, and who have identified disabilities, college access and success will be improved. In addition to improving teacher and administrator effectiveness, this replicable model will utilize relationships among partners, College of Public Health, College of Nursing, College of Education, Seminole State College, Children?s Home Society, and Seminole County Public Schools to provide a range of school-based student and family health and social services as well as student academic intervention and enrichment activities."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Building 21st Century Skills through Civic Epistemic Gaming: Meeting New Standards for All Florida Students
Project Description: "Building 21st Century Skills through Civic Epistemic Gaming: Meeting New Standards for All Florida Studentsis a Development Project in answer to Absolute Priority 3, and Competitive Priority 6. Two epistemic gamescreated to teach civics while developing 21st Century skills will be modified to meet new Florida Statestandards and tested in 25 geographically, socio-economically and culturally diverse school districts.The non-profit lead for this grant is the University of Central Florida; Principal Investigator Dr. Douglas Dobsonis the Executive Director of the Lou Frey Institute at UCF and co-Director of the Florida Joint Center forCitizenship. Subcontracts will be awarded to Community Knowledgebase, LLC for software development(under the direction of co-PI Dr. Lewis Friedland) and to The Center for Information & Research on CivicLearning & Engagement (CIRCLE) at Tufts University (Dr. Peter Levine, project co-PI) for furtherpedagogical development. Project evaluation will performed by Dr. Liliana Rodriguez, Director of the Centerfor Research, Evaluation, Assessment and Measurement at the University of South Florida. Additionalassistance will be provided by Dr. Michael Berson, Professor of Education at the University of South Floridaand a Senior Fellow in The Florida Joint Center for Citizenship. The project will run for three years. Weanticipate a scalable model of the two civic-epistemic games to result from the work.Based on previous limited tests of the games, CivNet and Legislative Aide, we expect to achieve gains in civicknowledge and skills as well as gains in measurable academic outcomes beyond civics, such as the ability tocommunicate complex concepts in writing. Translating Florida?s rigorous new State civics standards intoengaging, academically-rigorous games will, we anticipate, give Florida schools an effective tool capable ofincreasing the success of under-represented student populations in high school and college."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: UCM
Project Description: "Brief Project Description Including Project Activities: Five certified math teachers and five certified Englishteachers will be placed in seven technical career centers to team teach with career instructors. They will allwork together to instruct students with contextual integrated curriculum that provides students with careertraining and core academics simultaneously.Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: Objective 1: Students will remain in school andgraduate. Objective 2: Students will demonstrate individual growth toward core course proficiency. Objective3: Students will demonstrate retained technical skills knowledge. Objective 4: Teachers will have leadership,faculty and resource supports to provide core course content within career-technical schools.Project Outcomes: Attendance and graduation rates will increase; students will score higher on core subject tests;students will demonstrate knowledge of technical skills attainment; students will experience an easiertransition from secondary to postsecondary education; and teachers will be successful in an integratedcurricular team teaching environment.Target Number of Students to be served in the Project: (2,500)List of Official Partners:University of Central Missouri (UCM), with seven school districts: Fort Osage-Independence, MO; State FairCommunity College Technical Career Center-Sedalia, MO; North Kansas City-Kansas City, MO; Clinton-Clinton, MO; Herndon-Raytown, MO; South Central-West Plains, MO; and Northland-Platte City, MO."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of Central Oklahoma/OK A+ Schools
Project Title: Oklahoma A+Schools
Project Description: "Although Oklahoma has made important progress in education reform, significant challenges remain in improving the effectiveness of teachers and principals, especially for high-need students in secondary and early education and in rural communities. This is why the scaling out the Oklahoma A+ Schools network is so crucial. In order to ensure that teachers and principals have meaningful professional development and access to an effective collaborative network, Oklahoma A+ Schools? proposes to expand to 80 new schools in a statewide effort to connect learners to creative and successful arts-based reform strategies. The plan proposes to: first use existing OK A+ research to deepen quality of services and prepare the existing network for expansion (year 1), and then systematically scale out to the four state quadrants over time (years 2-5). Oklahoma A+ Schools is requesting a $12,845,051 Validation grant. Officially partnering with 6 A+ Demonstration Schools to specifically research the OK A+ impact on school improvement, and working with Westat and the University of Central Oklahoma and Oklahoma University?s Research Team for continued improvement of services and program validation. There are two project goals, wrapped in a continuous feedback loop that includes learners from birth through higher education.1. Build the OK A+ Network to reach 80 new Schools, 1600 teachers, 90 principals, and 48,924 students. Attract rural and early childhood schools through an awareness campaign, build partnerships with Institutions of Higher Education and teacher preparation programs, use Demonstration Schools as open door living laboratories, and use technology more creatively.2. Operate within a Culture of Evidence through continuing research. Provide evidence of effectiveness and ability to transplant; validate replication tools and a school self-assessment rubric, and steadily contribute to the countries educational success."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: STEM Transformative Professional Development
Project Description: "This project is to implement the STEM Transformative Professional Development program in five school districts located in urban, rural, and suburban locations across three states. The program will involve 38 schools in a randomized control study of the effectiveness of TPD on improving science teacher quality and student achievement in science. We have moderate evidence of the ability of this program to significantly impact both teacher quality and student achievement in two previous small scale studies. We believe that this validation study will provide the necessary data to warrant scaling up the program on a state or national level ."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Latino Educational and Professional Pathways to Success (LEAP2Success)
Project Description: "The goal of LEAP2Success is to build pre-collegiate pipelines into teaching for Latino/a high school students,build the capacity of schools districts to serve ELL?s through highly quality paraeducator training, to build thecapacity of current and aspiring paraeducators, teachers, counselors, school psychologists, principals and highereducation administrators to effectively serve Latino students and their families in a P-20 educational system bybuilding on existing successes in these areas, and in addition, creating a nine credit hour certificate/concentrationarea, applicable across all SEHD programs. The certificate will include an internship component,coaching/mentor supports, observations, and a capstone project. Three major pathways organize the design andwork of the project: Teacher Pipelines: pre-collegiate pipeline s for future Latino teachers - support students at 5 highschools (n=500) to complete a concurrent enrollment course as well as build a paraeducator (n=160)career ladder teacher training pathway Highly Effective Personnel: Train in service school personnel ? 200 paraeducators, and 160 others(teachers, counselors, related service) who demonstrate a commitment to effectively serving Latinostudents and families (total 360). Leadership Development: Train leaders in higher education and public schools to serve the increasingnumber of Latino students in the P-20 educational system ? principals and education leaders, n=120."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: GLISI's i3 Cohort: Building District Capacity to Sustain School Improvement
Project Description: "The Georgia Leadership Institute for School Improvement (GLISI), in partnership with the Center for the Study of Education Policy at Illinois State University (CSEP), the South Carolina Department of Education (SCDE), the New Mexico Leadership Institute (NMNI), and Learning Point Associates, will develop and test comprehensive school leadership evaluation and support strategy, called the Base Camp/Leadership Summit (BCLS). The BCLS model has been developed over the course of eight years and $12 million investment by public and private funders, and the program has been implemented in 70% of Georgia districts with results.   Under this grant, the BCLS model will be extended to include new coaching for district leaders to ensure fidelity of implementation and the curriculum will be customized for states outside of Georgia.  The proposed project will operate in four states and be piloted in 42 districts.  BCLS is a two-pronged strategy: (1) school-level leaders receive ongoing, engaging professional development to ensure that they are highly effective, and (2) participating local education agencies (LEAs) improve their human capital management systems for leaders to include a common performance assessment that drive professional development decisions."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: An RTI Approach Integrating Reading, Math, and Behavior Supports (rti3)
Project Description: "The University of Hawaii?s Curriculum Research & Development Group will develop, implement, andevaluate a Response to Intervention (RTI) curricular approach integrating reading, math, and behavior supportsin 10 Hawaii elementary schools through a collaboration with the Hawaii Department of Education andleverage i3 grant funds by partnering with an existing Native Hawaiian Education Program (NHEP) grant.Building on the NHEP grant, the i3 grant will substantially expand and strengthen the math component andfully incorporate School-wide Positive Behavior Support into the RTI framework, which integrates general andspecial education and emphasizes high-quality instruction in tiers based on students? needs. The net result willbe a unique robust RTI approach.Project objectives: Annually, the percentage of project Grade 3 students meeting the Adequate-Yearly-Progress reading standard will increase 10%, and the percentage of students meeting DIBELS benchmarkperformance in Grades K?2 will increase 10%; Annually, the percentage of project Grade 3 students meetingthe AYP math standard will increase 10%, and the percentage of students meeting math fluency benchmarkperformance in Grades K?2 will increase 10%; Annually, the percentage of students being referred forbehavioral problems at each school will decrease from pre-project levels by 10%, with referral rates at projectschools lower than the state percentage; and annually, referral for special education services will decrease,with referral rates at project schools lower than the state percentage.Target number of students: 4,000Official partner: Hawaii State Department of Education (LEA and SEA)"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Increasing Student Enrollment & Success in Rigorous Courses
Project Description: The Advancement Via Individual Determination (AVID) Path program will be implemented in six high schools on the Big Island of Hawaii.  A total of 192 teachers will receive the Path training.  Administrators and councelors will also be trained.  A total of 846 students will enroll in riorour courses taught using the AVID strategies and management approaches.  College students will tutor in these courses.  Those students who do not have skills needed to be successful in these rigorous courses will be enrolled in the AVID elective support class which will help them develop those skills.??..TRUNCATED
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Performing Arts for Creative Education (PACE)
Project Description: "University of Houston School of Theatre & Dance (UHSOTD) in partnership with Houston Independent School District (HISD) will offer Performing Arts for Creative Education (PACE) a comprehensive Arts Education Initiative for PK-8 in the HISD Wheatley Feeder Pattern located in the improvished 5th Ward, Houston neighborhood.  PACE will provide quality theatre arts education during the regular school day for 3 fifth grade classes of approximately 20 students, 6 fourth grade classes of approximately 20 students each, 1 PK class of approximately 15 students, and 2 Special Ed/Life Skills classes of approximately 5 students each.  In addition, PACE will offer a select number of students from the PACE student population additional after-school enrichment in theatre arts three days per week for one hour each day. All classes will be taught by a team of professional teachers and BFA undergraduate students in training to be teachers in theatre arts with an emphasis on at-risk students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Augmenting College and Career Readiness Using Evidence-based Strategies (ACCRUES)
Project Description: "The model used to implement evidence-based strategies is a unique application of the ProfessionalDevelopment School model, where student interns will be paired with practicing teachers (mentors) for anentire school year. These ?teacher pairs? will enroll in linked courses where pedagogy and subject area facultywill guide the development, implementation, and reporting of rigorous classroom-based research projects. Thefindings of these projects will be shared with principals, teachers in the department/cluster, students andparents. Community leaders and organizations will be involved in end-of-semester presentations of thefindings, and also engage in financial literacy/aid fairs that educate students and family members regardingfunding opportunities available for college education. In addition, a DVD guiding students and familymembers in making financial decisions will be available for them to view at their convenience. The expectedoutcomes from this project are: (a) improved evidence-based decision making; (b) interventions to improvecollege readiness for minority and English Language Learners; (c) improved college readiness andparticipation, particularly for minority and English Language Learners; and (d) improved collaborationbetween K-12 and higher education institutions. The target number of students to be served by this project is16,000 over 5 years, though the impact beyond the participating school districts is high given that acompendium of best practices in teacher education and college readiness will be developed and successfulstrategies/interventions will be shared annually at professional meetings."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Creating a Blue Wave in Science Education:  Bringing Computational Resources and Tools to Students Who Will Shape the Future of Illinois and the Nation
Project Description: "The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and its official LEA Partners from 5 Regional Offices of Education, and other official partners intend to improve student achievement in rural high schools for multiple science disciplines to validate the Institute for Chemistry Literacy through Computational Science (ICLCS) model of professional development. The ICLCS demonstrated that using authentic computational science tools to deliver chemistry content to high school chemistry teachers; (i) increased student achievement as measured; (ii) increased teacher chemistry content knowledge; and (iii) increased professional networking and peer support among isolated rural science teachers through the project's on-line professional learning community. Most importantly, we have developed a robust cyberinfrastructure that makes available high quality, freely accessible computational tools and teaching resources that will be leveraged for the Blue Wave project. The Blue Wave will reach over 108,000 students in Illinois, additional students in Kentucky over 5 years, and eventually the nation. We will provide each teacher with content knowledge, computational tools and pedagogical instruction through intensive Institutes and academic year activities for 3 years; access to experts in the field serving as instructors, and mentors; access to a virtual community of practice; and advanced content and National Board Certification training. Students will have access to computational tools and resources, and materials targeting college readiness and advanced courses. By project's end, we will revolutionize science teaching in Illinois and Kentucky through a scalable, sustainable online ecosystem of computational tools, vetted curricular materials, materials for national board certification support, AP training materials, entrepreneurial activities, expert mentors, and an interactive community of practice with the potential to scale the program  nationwide. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of Kansas Center for Research, Inc.
Project Title: Instruct4Success: A Standards-based Approach to Improving Math Achievement for All Learners
Project Description: "A development proposal addressing Absolute Priority 3 with implications for Priority 2 and CompetitivePreferences 6, 7, and 8 will be addressed. An intense evaluation of the Blending Assessment with InstructionProgram (BAIP) in mathematics, developed at the University of Kansas and now identified asInstruct4Success, will be the focus of this project. The program translates curriculum standards into research-basedteaching lessons for teachers, online assessment-based instructional tutorials for students, and parentresources. Instruct4Success is aligned with the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM)standards along with the soon-to-be released National Common-Core Curriculum Standards. Instruct4Successinstructional components are under girded by a management system that provides immediate feedback insupport of timely instructional decision-making. Over 100 master teachers and four mathematiciansparticipated in its development. The program has been pilot tested for the past two years in over 150 schooldistricts within inclusive classrooms in grades 3 through high school. Data based evidence has been collected.The primary focus of this project will be to conduct an intensive evaluation and research validation of theeffectiveness of the system in grades 3 through 6 under high fidelity controlled conditions with twenty partnerconsortium districts (largely rural) in Kansas and Nebraska. Research will be limited to a minimum of 1600students per grade level, however all students in the districts will have access to the system."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of Kansas Center for Research, Inc.
Project Title:
Content Enhancement Routines Validation Project: Aligning Instruction with Standards and
Assessments to Increase Achievement for All
Project Description: "The purpose of this study is to validate the use of sets of Content Enhancement Routine (CER) materials andprocedures in middle school and high school content classes to positively affect performance of all students.The need for this project is based on current reports showing that teachers and students need more support asteachers implement instruction based on rigorous standards and high-quality assessments. Project activitieswill involve working with teachers and administrators to adopt Common Core Standards and state-by stateassessment strategies, support the use of integrated sets of CERs based on those standards and assessments,and assess the power of the interventions. The objectives and outcomes will include assessing goals, planningfor use of the materials and procedures, reviewing and revising performance tasks and assessments, supportingthe use of CERs, facilitating communication to students and parents about how to use the routines, anddeveloping structures to sustain the intervention implementation as part of a long-term plan for school reform.The project?s experimental-control design and analysis, conducted by an external evaluation group, will assurethe objective of collecting evidence in support of integrated sets of CERs across major content areas and gradelevels with students of diverse abilities. The students will include over 48,000 students across all five years in40 schools in the states of Minnesota, Missouri, New York, and South Carolina. The schools will be randomlyassigned to experimental and control conditions at the outset of the study. Special features will include the useof standards regarding rigorous research evidence for the intervention, such as the What Works ClearinghouseStandards (2008) in the selection of CERs and the use of both ongoing live and distance-based supports as wellas professional development institutes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Compiling Evidence to Support the Partnership Enhancement Project Program
Project Description: "The Partnership Enhancement Program (PEP) was created as a pilot program by the Appalachian Math SciencePartnership (AMSP) with National Science Foundation?s approval in Year Two of the five year project. Theapproach of this trial program contrasted starkly with large ?top down? PK-12 STEM education reformmodels. It arose from the AMSP?s effort to establish working partnerships across all grade levels and wasbased on the recognition that smaller ?micro-investments? might be an effective means of empoweringpartners in the PK-12 schools districts to initiate partnerships with higher education (IHE) faculty. The firstconcern is that due to significant differences in the degree of development and support of mathematics andscience education reform in the districts, a primary feature of the PEP concept is the recognition that thedistrict is best suited to address specific STEM needs in the district. A second and related element is that theseneeds might be identified more effectively by the teachers and administrators at the local school and districtlevel than by generic national studies or the literature on mathematics and science education reform. The thirdelement is that in order for the partnership to be viable, the school and the IHE partner(s) must contribute bothmeaningfully and effectively to the design, implementation and evaluation of the mathematics and/or sciencereform activity. The latter characteristic of this trial program was viewed by AMSP?s external evaluators asproviding ?empowerment? in the form of a voice and role for the PK-12 teacher partner(s) that was oftenlacking in the U.S. primary, middle and secondary school system. While it is logistically easier to implementcertain well-established standards-based curricula in most regions, the trial projects differ in meeting the localneeds in the diverse and isolated districts of central Appalachia."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Peer Education Engagement and Readiness Strategy (PEERS) Project
Project Description: "The University of Maryland College Park, along with its official partners - the Baltimore City Schools and the Algebra Project, Inc. - and unofficial partners  - the Baltimore Algebra Project and Safe Healing Foundation  - seek a $4,629,072 Development Grant from the Investing in Innovation Fund.  Project partners propose to raise student achievement in three tested subject areas, decrease drop-out rates, improve graduation rates, and boost college enrollment.  These outcomes will be achieved by radically changing the student learning culture within three ninth-grade and one tenth-grade classroom (80-100 students total).  The targeted students will have previously scored in the bottom quartile on reading and/or math tests.  The students in each of these four classes will stay together for that one class (Mathematics, English, or Science) as a cohort throughout their high school careers.  Our strategy involves the intensive practice of employing Near Peers as co-teachers both inside and outside the classroom and inside and outside the traditional school day and school year.  A Near Peer is a recent graduate from Baltimore City Public Schools who attends a local college or university - typically as a first-generation college student - and is employed on a part-time basis by the school system as a non-certified peer educator.             Anticipated outcomes are that cohort students will develop a positive, productive learning culture and 80% will meet the state's minimum testing requirements for high school graduation, graduate on time, perform sufficiently well on college entrance exams (SAT or ACT) to gain admission into college, and test out of remedial courses to enroll in courses for college credit."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Southeastern Massachusetts Talent Search Initiative
Project Description: "UMass Dartmouth, working in collaboration with the LEAs of Brockton, Fall River, and New Bedford, Massachusetts, and other partners from higher education, have formed a regional coalition in order to work collaboratively to increase the high school graduation rates of our students and their participation in post-secondary education. We plan to accomplish this by implementing a project modeled on the federal Trio program called Talent Search and taking the array of best practices from that model and applying them across grades 8-12 with a particular effort at identifying and serving high-need students in non-traditional settings. Activities include identification of low-income students and first-generation college attendees; development of an Individual Plan of Service for each student; academic counseling; career counseling; introduction and access to rigorous coursework in math, science, and language skills; implementation of dual enrollment activities; financial aid and college application counseling; mentoring; access to long-distance learning; and an introduction to information about college and college settings. We expect to serve 1800 students a year over five years with the expectation of accomplishing the following: increasing graduation rates and rate at which students are promoted from one grade to another; increase the number of our students applying for and enrolling in college; increasing applications for financial aid to college to ensure greater college access; increasing the number of underrepresented groups graduating from high school and enrolling in college, particularly students with disabilities and those that are limited-English proficient; bringing back those that have left before graduation and putting them on track for graduation and college; and increasing access to rigorous coursework and dual enrollment programs as a preparation for a successful college experience."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Community of Learners
Project Description: "This unique partnership of UMass Dartmouth, the New Bedford Public Schools, the Global Learning Charter School, the Community Foundation of Southeastern Massachusetts the Remediation and Training Institute and the Eisenhower Foundation, will accelerate transformation of New Bedford schools to student-centered learning and the transformation of New Bedford into a ?learning community? that puts education first.  We are focused on ?Absolute Priority 4?   Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools. We will enable and provide 100 hours of extra learning outside of school hours for every at-risk pre-school, elementary, middle, and high-school student, as well as dropouts and college remedial students.  Ultimately, we will deploy a unique University WI-MAX asset to provide every student and teacher with free, ?anywhere, anytime? access to the comprehensive online courses and resources. Every Learning Center will have unlimited 4G access for learning and teaching."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Promoting Science Among English Language Learners (P-SELL) Valdiation Study
Project Description: "The purpose of the project is to evaluate the effectiveness of our curricular and professional development intervention to develop highly effective teachers who can improve science achievement along with English language and math achievement of all students, especially English language learners, in elementary schools  within the context of high-stakes testing and accountability policies. After the first year of planning, the project involves close to 2,000 teachers (1,000 in the treatment and 1,000 in the control) and over 40,000 students for grades 3, 4, and 5 (20,000 in the treatment and 20,000 in the control) during each of its four years of implementation in Duval (Jacksonville), Lee (Fort Myers), and Osceola (Kissimmee) Counties in Florida. The students are drawn from a random sample of 90 schools (45 in the treatment and 45 in the control) across the three districts. The third-party project evaluation examines the impact of the intervention on student achievement and growth and teachers? science knowledge and instructional practices. The project also examines whether the intervention improves student outcomes differentially by demographic subgroups."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: University of Notre Dame du Lac
Project Title: Grand Rapids
Project Description: "We are seeking an i3 Development grant to develop a sustainable data sharing system that will empower familiesand community-based organizations to support economically disadvantaged Limited English Proficiency(LEP) middle school students? academic needs outside of school time and help them enter high school on acollege-readiness trajectory. The project will develop College Readiness Reports (CRRs) that synthesizeacademic and programmatic data to communicate students? academic needs to students, parents, teachers, andout-of-school providers. Specific collaboration protocols between teachers, students, families, and out-ofschoolpartners will be used in conjunction with the CRRs. These data collaboration tools and activities aredesigned to accomplish three goals: (1) improve data-based decision-making; (2) align out-of-schoolinstruction with students? college readiness needs; (3) empower parents to support their students? collegereadiness. By accomplishing these goals, we expect to see an increase in the number of LEP middle schoolstudents that are on a college-ready trajectory upon transitioning into high school.In the pilot phase (years 2-4) the project will serve approximately 350 LEP middle school students. In year 5, theproject will be scaled up to approximately 1,100 middle school students (including non-LEP students) in thedistrict. The long term plan is to expand the data collaborative activities to upper elementary and high schoolgrades and serve over 9,000 students in the district.This project will be conducted by nonprofit/LEA partnership. The official partners on the project are theUniversity of Notre Dame?s Center for Research on Educational Opportunity and the Grand Rapids PublicSchools. Other partners include Grand Valley State University?s Community Research Institute and BasisPolicy Research. Matching funds will be provided by the Douglas and Maria DeVos foundation."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: University of Notre Dame du Lac
Project Title:
NEW TOOLS TO ASSIST TEACHERS IN THE USE OF CLASSROOM AND ASSESSMENT
DATA
Project Description: "In response to the Request for Proposal for i3 grants from the U.S. Department of Education's Office ofInnovation, the research team of University of Notre Dame, the University of Wisconsin-Madison, NorthwestEvaluation Association (NWEA), and Johns Hopkins University propose a five-year development project tocreate new tools to assist teachers in the use of classroom and assessment data.This project?s main hypothesis is that when teachers have ongoing professional development to examine theirstudents? test score information and their instruction (content, cognitive complexity, and alignment tostandards and assessments), then they can modify teaching to improve students? performance over time. Wewill focus on reading and mathematics instruction and assessments in Indiana elementary schools (urban, ruraland suburban) with these activities:? Design Year 1?orient 6 schools to project; create professional development model and reports for teachersand schools, merging assessment and instructional information? Pilot Years 2 and 3?increase school participation to 12 schools; further develop and implement professionaldevelopment model; report development; project evaluation? Rollout Years 4 and 5?increase school participation to 40 schools; further develop and implementprofessional development model; report development; project evaluationThe project aims to:? Further school improvement by creating an ongoing professional development and data-based decision makingmodel that merges NWEA and Indiana ISTEP assessment information with instructional data (Surveys of theEnacted Curriculum [SEC])? Increase ISTEP pass rate and student growth by designing a system that aligns instruction with Indiana?scurriculum standards and assessment? Enable teachers to use project tools to adjust classroom teaching to better educate studentsKey outcomes that this development project aims to improve include:? Improved instruction and alignment to standards and ass"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Process Engineering for Educational Results (PEER): Supporting District Decisions for
Instructional Improvement
Project Description: "This development project involves implementing the PEER process to improve two urban LEAs, PrinceGeorges County Public Schools and one to be named. Our overarching goal advances in these districts the sixattributes requisite of high performing districts: 1) high expectations and instructional program coherence, 2)human and social capacity at the district and 3) at the school level, 4) a culture of improvement and internalaccountability, 5) high quality of leadership practice, and 6) organizational capacity and coherence forinstructional improvement. We do this by routinely assessing key processes utilizing instruments based onlearning research; and from the results, facilitate developing professional learning around critical elementsessential for instructional improvement. This work supports Absolute Priority 1. To do this, we establishPEER for two particular goals (mathematics and science). For each goal, there are three primary objectives: 1)Denoting and increasing district expectations, 2) Improving school leadership, and 3) Increasing quality ofteaching. Each year of the project addresses a particular objective; and often the fourth year serves asverification for objective three. Activities associated with each objective are comparable. Elements thatproduce student learning are foci at the particular objective and level. Data instruments are administered to allinvolved personnel. From the results, reports are created, specific to the objective, along with a theory ofaction graph depicting how the district is performing along the primary attributes of high performing districts.Suggested areas of improvement are provided to district officials. Finally, as annual outcomes: 1) pertinentresults are incorporated into the district?s data use plan for dissemination; 2) two to three elements are selectedfor next year improvements through professional learning; and 3) improvement metrics are targeted formonitoring."

Project Title: Translating the Common Core Standards into ELA Curriculum: Enabling Schools to Create Their Own
Project Description: "The Institute for Learning (IFL) proposes a development grant to create an instructional system of a high school curriculum spine keyed to the Common Core Reading, Writing, Language, and Speaking and Listening Standards that addresses Absolute Priority #3 and Competitive Priority #7. This system will support states? efforts to transition to the new standards and assessments that measure students? progress toward college- and career-readiness. We will work in the Newark Public Schools over four years to introduce the curriculum spine and the professional development to support it to the teachers in the district, as well as provide training on how to use the routines and protocols built into the units to adapt and customize the units. The project goals are: (1) an English language arts (ELA) curriculum for grades 9-12 that is rigorous and accessible for all students, including LEP students, and results in improved student achievement ? all high school ELA teachers in Newark Public Schools will use it and any new texts that are needed will be provided; (2) the development and piloting of a web-based tutorial to modify curriculum to fit the needs of a district?s or school?s student needs; and (3) the development and use of an onsite and web-based professional development course with teachers, lead teachers and principals. The final activity is the implementation of a scale-up plan. An evaluation will be done which will include student achievement data, including student work, and will also include surveys, site visits, interviews and focus groups of principals, lead teachers and teachers. In the course of this project, 15,144 students will be served in our partner districts, the Newark Public Schools and the Paterson School District."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Accountable Talk
