Project Description: "The Institute for Learning proposes a validation study on the creation of a scalable, online translation of its Accountable Talk ? program.  The proposal addresses Absolute Priority 3 and Competitive Priorities 7 and 8.  This program will be an integrated, practice-based online learning system for teachers and principles in urban and rural LEAs will participate.  Middle school teachers in the four core content areas as well as their principals will be trained.  The program will scale to high school by year 4.  The program builds both human and social capital.  It is designed to be capacity-building, scalable, and sustainable both within a district, and in regions and states."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Highly Effective Peer-Mentoring Strategies to Transform High School Education
Project Description: "The work proposed here, stands of the hypothesis that an expository peer mentoring model, based on effectiveteachers, principals, professors and graduate students will transform a cohort of less effective high schoolsteachers and principals and significantly improve high school student achievements and retention.Consequently, the University of Puerto Rico, as a nonprofit organization, represented by the Mayag
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras Campus
Project Title: Innovation Founds I3
Project Description: "Abstract NarrativeUPR-RP i3 Project proposes a development grant under Absolute priority 4: Innovations that turn around persistently low-performing schools and Competitive Priorities 6: Innovations that support college access and success, and 7: Innovations to address the unique learning needs of students with disabilities and limited English proficient students. Results of academic achievements on standardized tests, grades, need surveys and research indicate that students in the target schools in Rio Piedras, Fajardo and Vieques are performing below proficiency levels in English, Spanish, Science and Math. The Project in partnership with 9 schools, and 3 additional private entities will provide services that include after-school tutoring; Saturday enrichment courses; orientations and assistance in preparing and filling applications for post-secondary education and financial aid; extra-curricular activities to strengthen knowledge and critical thinking skills; reading comprehension; writing and study skills, among others. The proposed numbers of students to be served are 600. The objectives and expected outcomes include: the significant enhancement of achievement performance scores and grades of participants en the basic subjects at least one grade point and one level in tests. Improve growth achievement in reading and comprehension skills in English and Spanish, increasing the number of books they read and the proficiency levels in comprehension tests. Increase school attendance, high school graduation and post-secondary enrollment rates above current target schools rates. And finally, improve attendance rates in the standardized achievements tests with appropriate test taking skills. Partner schools included are 5 high schools (GR, MS, JPL, ADF and DVC); 4 intermediate schools (20 de Sept. 1988, AVB, JAC and IM) and 3 private partners: Vieques Historical Museum;"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Southeastern Alliance for the Improvement of STEM Education
Project Description: "The University of South Carolina, University of Kentucky, Duke University, Orangeburg-Calhoun Technical College, Piedmont Technical College, and a consortium of 54 rural/high need high schools join in a regional multi-state application involving 6,480 SC, KY, and NC students. The project will validate the PLTW program?s impact on student achievement, college readiness, student attainment, and instructional capacity, especially in math/science, in the region?s rural/high risk schools. Research supporting partner efforts has high external validity and moderate internal validity. USC (the Higher Education ?Non-Profit? partner on behalf of a Consortium) will implement Project Lead the Way curriculum and validate it as a standards and problem-based program improving achievement and attainment for rural/high-need students. The evaluation has a quasi-experimental study design using control comparison groups matched with the assistance of ACT, Inc., a formal ?Other? partner. USC?s independent Office of Program Evaluation and the South Carolina Educational Policy Center will conduct the study. (Absolute Priority 3; Competitive Preferences 3 and 5)"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: USC Hybrid High School: Changing the Game for Urban High School Students
Project Description: "i3 funds are sought to support planning, infrastructure development, and rigorous, multi-method evaluations ofthe development phase of the USC Hybrid High School project. USC will open and operate a scalable hybridcharter high school pilot that provides high-need urban students with customized academic and social supportprograms through the combination of the virtual delivery of rigorous and college preparatory, standards-basedacademic instruction by online master teachers and personalized support of local administrators, counselors,project teachers, ELL and remedial specialists, and learning coaches in a repurposed commercial space.Operational funds are being sought from philanthropic and corporate sources.Summary of Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes: Hybrid High will seek to achieve 0% dropout rateamong high-need students and a 100% rate of enrollment and success in post-secondary education and/orcareer-preparation programs. The project tends to model credibility, replicability, scalability, and sustainabilityas a basis for a future, conditional scale-up to urban centers throughout the country.Number of High Need Students: 1000 in the beta-school over 5 yearsSpecial Project Features: 10hrX7dX year-round operation ; differentiated staff composition; virtual digitalcurriculum and project-based learning tasks; integrated social support services; data-driven, customised studentlearning plans.Partners: USC Rossier School of Education and Hybrid High School; WestED"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Building Math Literacy Beyond the Classroom Walls
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Living Classroom : Data-Driven Differentiated Learning
Peer Assessment and Review: Teacher-Novice Excellence to Realize Student Success (PARTNERS)
Project Description: "This project will implement the award winning peer review and assessment (PAR) program developed by Dal Lawrence and used in Toledo Public and Rochester Public Schools to provide mentoring and oversight to new and weak teachers in 12 partnering public school districts (Toledo, OH; St. Louis, MO; Escambia County, FL; St. Paul, MN; Detroit, MI; Pickerington, OH; Niles Township, IL; Oklahoma City, OK;  Anderson, IN; Peoria, IL; and the Coalition of Rural and Appalachian Schools (southeast OH). While there is moderate evidence that PAR is effective in removing incompetent teachers and thereby improving the overall quality of teachers within a district, rigorous experimental design in a variety of  settings has not been conducted. PARTNERS will incorporate an experimental design with random selection and assignment from the population of new and referred teachers from these 11 school districts representing a cross-section of our country. The addition of a data collection specialist in each district to work with the project evaluation team will provide consistent and high quality data to establish both internal and external validity and establish PAR generalizabiltiy. By the conclusion of this five year project, 120 master teachers will be trained as consulting teachers (mentors), 3300 new and weak teachers will have completed the PAR program, and the results will affect approximately 178,200 students. In addition to our goal to validate the PAR program, this project plans to reduce the percent of teachers who are ineffective (based upon rigorous PAR criteria) in the participating districts and transform school and district workplace culture from adversarial to cooperative. Measures of outcomes include: percent of ineffective teachers terminated from participating districts, teacher value-added scores for student achievement scores, student attendance, graduation, and disciplinary rates, and interviews and surveys of teachers and principals."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: University of Vermont and State Agricultural College
Project Title: American Mathematics Initiative: Raising Mathematical Achievement in Rural and Urban Schools
Project Description: "The very successful University of Vermont (VMI) program to upgrade the mathematical concepts and skills of K-8 teachers through a Master?s program will be expanded to five other states or cities. The content courses areaugmented by teacher leader workshops at the LEA and school level. The major objective of the AmericanMathematics Initiative (AMI) is to validate VMI in five distinct urban and rural settings and bring the programto scale in at least five additional locations. The highest priority of the AMI is to raise mathematicsproficiency of low achieving students, serve underperforming schools, and substantially increase the contentknowledge of teachers who will close the achievement gap in schools that range from the most rural to themost urban. The impact on student achievement reached in classrooms (schools) of teachers trained in thisprogram will be a projected gain of 20 percentile points in mathematics proficiency, and a narrowing ofachievement gaps (low income, minority, limited English proficiency) from a gap of 30 (national average) ormore percentile points to 10 points or less.? Target Number of students served: 270,000Special features: Recruitment of university mathematics professors, strong support from American MathematicsSociety, Mathematical Association of America and National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, SummerInstitutes and academic year courses, quasi experimental evaluation designs provide evidence of success inVermont and Massachusetts.Official Partners: University of Vermont, University of Wyoming, University of Utah, University of Chicago,Cincinnati Public Schools and Mayerson Academy (Cincinnati). The project also has the active support of theVermont NEA, the Wyoming NEA and the Vermont, Utah, and Wyoming state education agencies."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Increasing College Readiness: Research on Project-Based Learning Approaches to Advanced Placement (AP) Courses
Project Description: "For over 50 years, Advanced Placement courses have been a national benchmark for rigorous high school curricula. Today, education reformers look upon AP as one piece of the puzzle for developing a ?Common Core? system of high-quality standards and assessments across states (National Governors Association, 2009). Many urban and suburban school districts alike are encouraging and even requiring students to take one or more advanced courses in the name of ?equity? and ?access? to college pathways and life success. Yet many worry that AP is too memorization focused and lags behind modern research on how people learn (2002). Initial work by our group shows that, with appropriate innovation a much broader array of students can take challenging courses and find fertile grounds to succeed. To build on these findings, we seek additionalfunding over four years from the Investing in Innovation (i3) Fund.We will further develop and assess the effectiveness of rigorous PBL approaches to AP courses, with particular emphasis on working with students in schools with large percentages of low-income students. Specifically, we will investigate across three different school system settings (urban, suburban, urban public charter) whether our project-based learning approaches to AP can yield (1) same or better pass rates on the AP Exam, (2) same or better pass rates on a test of applied reasoning in the subject (Complex Scenario Test), and (3) higher student engagement in the courses. Working with Rockman Evaluators, we seek to show both what works and why it works, and how to help others adapt the work to their particular settings. Key features of our investigation are teacher development and design principles with an eye toward scaling in ways that helpothers convert rigorous but relatively memory?oriented courses into socially relevant experiences that help all succeed."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: University of Washington Rural Schools Consortium
Project Description: "The University of Washington, in partnership with a Consortium of Rural High Schools and business partners, is proposing to validate Project Lead the Way (PLTW) in 13 small rural high schools with a high-need student population of minorities, low-income and English Language Learners experiencing low-academic achievement. The proposed UW i3 Schools Consortium will implement and study PLTW in small rural high schools and its effect on increasing student academic achievement, high school graduation, interest in STEM fields and college first-year entrance/retention rates for Latinos, Native Americans and Females. RGI Research Corporation will lead the research study while the schools implement the program in their high schools. The PLTW has moderate evidence in large urban schools and this promising program will be tested in small rural schools with minority students. If validated, the project will be replicated in 33 rural schools statewide. Over the five years, the project will serve 21,080 students.Project Lead the Way (PLTW) Engineering and Biomedical Sciences programs offer students an array of advantages, from career readiness and hands-on experience to college preparatory?level classes, labs, and creative exercises at their high school. As an integrate high school program, PLTW is designed to appeal to all students, from those already interested in STEM-related fields, to those whose experience in the sciences and math has been less comprehensive or who find themselves uninterested in traditional STEM curricula. PLTW classes are hands-on, based in real-world experience and fun for students and teachers. PLTW sets the highest standards for rigorous, focused, and engaging study, and develops students? innovative, collaborative, cooperative, and problem-solving skills.The goal of the project is to ?Validate and Scale-Up a program (PLTW) that will prepare and increase interest in STEM fields while increasing academic achievement in math and science."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Escambia Engaging in Excellence
Project Description: "Escambia Engaging in Excellence (E3) represents a unique framework for building principal and teacher leaders whopositively impact student achievement. Our team includes two official partners (Escambia County School District and theUniversity of West Florida) and two corporate partners (Studer Group and Apple). The objectives of this i3 Developmentgrant are to improve leader effectiveness as measured by student achievement, employee satisfaction, and parentsatisfaction and to improve teacher effectiveness as measured by student achievement, student engagement, teachersatisfaction, teacher engagement, and parent satisfaction. To achieve these objectives we will apply tested leader andteacher effectiveness frameworks that include (1) proven leadership techniques from healthcare and business, (2) bestpractices in formative assessment, and (3) learning environments that promote teacher and student engagement. Theparticipants in the study are 4 principals, 200 teachers, and 1200 students from a feeder pattern of schools (two elementary,one middle, and one high school) in a high poverty district in Northwest Florida. Unique to the E3 project, the professionaldevelopment/learning model applies in a similar manner for leaders, teachers and students. They all have learning goals,have specific strategies to achieve goals, are coached to continuously improve, and are evaluated after having learning andpractice opportunities. An external evaluator will conduct a comprehensive program evaluation using a quasi-experimentalrepeated measures designed to judge the impact of leader and teacher effectiveness."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Innovations and Partnerships that Improve the Use of Data in Early Reading Intervention Programs in Northwest Florida
Project Description: "Improving student performance for rural and high-need student populations by improving the use of data in decision-making for early reading intervention programs in Northwest Florida is the primary goal of the proposed regional level validation grant project.  The proposed project will empirically validate the infusion of a Relational Feedback Intervention (RFI) Database Model into early reading intervention programs (Differentiated Reading and Response to Intervention) across seven public school districts in Northwest Florida to examine impact on student achievement, student growth, closing gaps, and teacher/principal effectiveness.  The proposed project is empirically based on the moderate evidence and findings from the 2008-2010 Early Reading Intervention and Response to Intervention Research Project that is on-going in the research partnership between the University of West florida (UWF) Community Outreach Research and Learning (CORAL) Center and Santa Rosa County School District, Florida.  The innovative use of data that identifies the current research efforts between UWF and Santa Rosa county Schools relative to the RFI Database Model is the use of trained classroom observers (UWF graduate education students) who perform 30-minute observations twice a week in randomly selected reading (K-3) classrooms in all schools using a quantitative observation tool that depicts 85 strategies reflected in differential reading and response to intervention conceptual frameworks.  The RFI Database Model matches teacher professional development data to classroom observation data to student achievement data in a cyclical pattern with feedback interventions provided to schools throughout the cycle.  Anticipated outcomes include increased student achievement, closing of achievement gaps, reduced ESE referrals, increased informed decision making and improved communications about early learning for teachers, principals, stakeholders, and parents."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Achieving Nationally Competitive College Readiness for Low-Income African American Children
Project Description: "We intend to achieve competitive college readiness for urban high school students through the use of high standards and high quality assessments in order to support greater college access and college success for Detroit students.   Our goal is to graduate the UPA class of 2015 college ready as measured by the ACT College Readiness standards.  We will do this by implementing the International Baccalaureate middle years program into the middle and high school as a means for dramatically elevating academic outcomes and expectations for students and staff alike.  IB uses International standards to student assessment and offers an academicallly challenging curriculum that builds connections between traditional courses and real world learning. We will also implement the full ACT Quality Core Program.  Based on national research about preparing college ready students, the ACT Quality Core provides tools for aligning middle and high school curricula with the ACT college readiness standards and supportive resources to help improve the quality, consistency and rigor of core courses.  Finally, we will extend the school day by 90 minutes at both the middle and high school.  This will permit double scheduling of math and reading for students not yet on college readiness path, and time for more advanced classes for those who are ready. Program success will be meaured by % of seniors in 2015 who score at or above the College Readiness standards on Reading, English and Math, the number of students entering college in the fall of 2015 requireing remedial courses and the number of 8th graders scoring at or above college readiness on the ACT EXPLORE test."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: STEM in the Middle
Project Description: "STEM in the Middle (SIM) is a 4-year project involving Arizona State University, three urban school districts, two charter schools, and with support from the Helios Education Foundation, addresses the high ?turn-off? rate of student interest in mathematics in the middle grades and failure in Algebra I.The goals of STEM in the Middle are to design, implement and evaluate a scientific village strategy to: 1) promote grades 5-8 students? success with the study of math and sciences by developing their algebraic reasoning and problem solving abilities, engaging them in activities and projects like those carried out by STEM professionals and having them communicate regularly with scientists; 2) develop middle school teachers? knowledge of key concepts of math and science, how student understanding of those concepts can be nurtured to become more robust, instructional strategies that promote perseverance behaviors, techniques for designing and constructing integrated projects, methods for assessing and assisting students with varying talents; and 3) educate families about STEM career paths, their children?s talents related to those careers, and ways to support and counsel their children about course selection in high school.Components include 2 years of Saturday and Summer Programs for each of three cohorts of teachers, Saturday Club STEM lab for teachers where they can work with middle-grade students with assistance from high school and college students, 4 years of Algebra Prep for students in grades 5 ? 8, and an intergenerational STEM program to engage families in support of their children?s learning.SIM will serve 120 grades 5 ? 8 teachers in high areas of poverty and the students in their classes (3,000 to 15,000/year), and 180 grades 5-8 students in Club STEM lab for teachers along with the 60 mentors."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: KidSTEM
Project Description: "KidSTEM, a 4-year project involving Arizona State University, three urban school districts, and one charter school, is a Development Grant addressing Absolute Priority 1-Innovations that Support Effective Teachers and Principals, and Competitive Preference Priority 5-Innovations for Improving Early Learning Outcomes. KidSTEM addresses the need to better prepare teachers to engage young students in math and science explorations to increase their chances for success with later school learning. Major KidSTEM activities: 1) Summer Institutes (2 weeks/summer for 2 summers) to develop teachers? understanding of a) key mathematical and science concepts, and how students? understanding of them can be nurtured to become more robust. b) effective and developmentally appropriate pedagogical and assessment strategies; and c) techniques and resources to engage families in support of their children?s learning of mathematics and science. 2) Saturday Workshops (3 weekends/semester for 3 semesters) focus on strategies for assessing student?s math/science understanding, reasoning and problem solving talents; the design, conduct and interpretation of results of interviews and observations; and ways to adapt instruction to identified needs. 3) In-School Program focuses on implementation of explorations, instructional approaches and assessment techniques. Teachers will meet regularly with teammates and other teachers in professional learning communities to hone their craft to improve student learning.KidSTEM products: 1) At Your Fingertips, at-home family STEM activities; 2) KidSTEM Projects activities that integrate STEM topics for student explorations; 3) Stupendous STEM Story Prompts to enhance communication and use of math/science vocabulary; and 4) KidSTEM in the News, a monthly classroom newsletter to update families. KidSTEM will serve 120 teachers 7,200 students over the course of the grant funding."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning

Project Title: Institute for Teachers of English Language Learners
Project Description: "The Institute for Teachers of English Language Learners (ITELL) represents a collaboration led by University Public Schools, Inc. in partnership with Arizona State University, the Navaho Nation, Cartwright, Murphy, Phoenix, Balsz, Roosevelt and Wilson elementary school districts. The goal of ITELL is to improve academic achievement for ELLs by integrating teacher professional development, parental involvement, capacity building, and summer and afterschool programs in a state policy context that is highly restrictive.Specifically, ITELL will 1) Restructure the current curriculum to embed instruction regarding the 'mechanics' of the English language into academic content; 2) Provide teachers of ELLs professional development that combines state-of-the-art technology with progressive teaching methods that reflect best practices in the area of English language development; 3) Increase opportunities for ELL children to participate in afterschool instruction and/or summer school programs; and 4) Implement programs independently evaluated to produce an increase in parental involvement.To accomplish these goals, ITELL will focus on four primary objectives: 1) While adhering to the policies mandated by the state of Arizona, restructure the current 4-hour block to include instruction that embeds instruction regarding the 'mechanics' of the English language into academic content; 2) Provide professional development combining state-of-the-art technology with progressive teaching methods that reflect best practices in the area of English language development; 3) Increase opportunities for children at the participating sites to participate in afterschool instruction and/or summer school programs; and 4) Implement programs whose effectiveness in promoting parental engagement is well documented."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Transforming Dallas Schools through Strategic Talent Management Programs and Practice
Project Description: "Project AbstractThe NeedDallas, like many urban centers, faces huge challenges in public education. Despite academic gains on state assessments over the last decade, students, particularly at the secondary school level, are not being adequately prepared for post-secondary success.  Although there have been a number of point solutions launched with limited pockets of success, there continues to be a need for a systemic approach to ensure that principals and leadership teams are well-trained and able to fully and strategically manage the teacher talent for success on their campuses so that this critical lever, Teacher and Principal Effectiveness (Absolute Priority 1), is fully addressed.  There is strong evidence that the Talent Management capacity in both districts and charter management organizations is lacking.  Both systems are affected by:1. Shallow pipelines of talent: Growing demands on secondary principals and a lack of early talent identification practices limit quality applicants for leadership openings2. Ineffective traditional preparation programs and professional development: Current offerings are disconnected to the realities of the work with entry requirements that are not aligned with the skills and competencies required leave candidates ill prepared for the rigors of the job.  3. Limited building of Talent Management capacity within schools: Leadership development has begun to focus on instructional leadership but there has been insufficient focus within schools and central offices on aggressively identifying, recruiting, developing, supporting and retaining the most effective talent on a campus.  The Solution:In response, two North Texas Local Education Agencies (LEAs)?Dallas Independent School District (Dallas ISD), the largest traditional public school LEA, and Uplift Education (Uplift), the largest open enrollment charter operator, are collaborating as Official Partners on this grant. This unique partnership will both build upon the stren... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"

Project Title: Improving Academic Achievement of High-Need Students: RTI in a Freshman Academy
Project Description: "Improving Academic Achievement of High-Need Students: RTI in a Freshman Academy:Upper Darby School District proposes to expand the Response to Intervention (RTI) framework to its 1,000-student, highly diverse Freshman Academy.  The high school is in its seventh year of not making Adequate Yearly Progress.  The hypothesis is that the RTI process will accelerate achievement in reading and math among high-need 9th graders as it has in the district's 11 elementary and 2 middle schools.  In the 9th grade, 52% are low income, 5% ELL, 45% minority and 18% special education.  Over the past five years, double-digit gains in math and reading proficiency among 2,700 district middle school students, along with promising results in the literature, suggest the efficacy of the RTI framework.  Upper Darby is applying for a development grant under Priority 2 - Improved Use of Data Systems (a) because, in the district's experience, data-based decision making was the single most important RTI component contributing to student gains.  The district has developed RTI protocols, fidelity checklists and standard operating procedures, and will adopt them in the Academy utilizing professional development.  The evaluation will measure outcomes in five goal areas: 1) increased proficiency in reading and mathematics among 3,000 freshmen over three years including 450 special education students and 150 English language learners, 2) incorporation of six RTI components in the Academy infrastructure, 3) faculty implementation of RTI practices with fidelity, 4) increased parental understanding of their child's learning strengths and needs through the lens of RTI, and 5) dissemination of project results and products to educators, researchers and educational systems.  Partners include Indiana University of Pennsylvania, the Pennsylvania Training and Technical Assistance Network, the Delaware County Intermediate Unit, and the Upper Darby Arts and Education Foundation. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: UIU-METL
Project Description: "This exciting project will impact 100 percent of the official partner teachers/instructors, all 10,920 students within the P-12 LEA systems will be impacted by technology integrated curricula.  The UIU-METL project provides an instructional model that meets individual student learning styles by offering technology enriched curricula via multiple modalities (on-site, online and hybrid), to instill in students an intrinsic motivation to learn.  This project provides teachers/instructors the tools to teach to students? multiple intelligences, which in addition to verbal and quantitative intelligences, includes visual/spatial, bodily/kinesthetic, musical/rhythmic, interpersonal and intra-personal (this is equivalent to emotional intelligences) naturalistic, and environmental intelligences.  The train-the-trainer model utilized in the UIU-METL initiative enables teachers at every academic discipline the opportunity to focus on their content and tailor it to various student learning styles using multiple modalities because they will have been trained on the use of technology, it?s capabilities, and how to apply the technology to best employ teaching strategies to address students? multiple intelligences."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Fresh Ed Project
Project Description: "Urban Arts Partnership (UAP) has provided exemplary arts-integrated education programs in Title I New YorkCity (NYC) public schools since 1992. In 2009 the organization piloted the Fresh Ed Project, a music, mediaand Hip Hop based curriculum and teaching model linked to core academic subject areas. The Fresh Ed pilotprogram was successful with 80% of participating students passing their New York State Global StudiesRegents exam for high school students (each student had failed previously between 1 and 5 times) and 94% ofstudents passing the English exam ? including 100% of special needs students in both subjects. Five of theseexams are required to graduate from most high schools in New York State. UAP will expand the project?scurriculum development and professional development series through the i3 Development grant. UAP willdevelop and provide Fresh Ed to a consortium of seven schools in year one, reaching 1,156 students as well as68 teachers, increasing the Fresh Ed network successively in each year of the i3 grant that, by year five, willhave reached a total of 43,840 students and 2,240 teachers. The Development Grant will enable UAP tofurther close the ?achievement gap? for ?high needs? youth, addressing Absolute Priority 3 and CompetitivePriority 7 through clear outcomes to be measured by independent evaluator Philliber Research Associates.Expected outcomes include statistically significant increased percentages of students passing NYS Regentsassessments, as well as English Language Arts and Math assessments in elementary and middle schools,increases in graduation rates, and indicators of higher student engagement. The Fresh Ed project features aninnovative model of teaching and learning supported by the online site www.myfreshprep.org, and is poisedfor expansion through partnerships with the NYC DOE and private foundations, with a potential magnitude ofeffect for urban communities nationwide."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
Implementing the College-readiness Performance Assessment System and 
Instructional Supports
Project Description: "The Urban Assembly (UA) is a non-profit organization dedicated to breaking the cycle of poverty by managing 21 small New York City public middle and high schools that empower every student to succeed in college. Since 2006, The Urban Assembly has collaborated with Dr. David Conley and the Education Policy Improvement Center (EPIC) at the University of Oregon to implement the College-readiness Performance Assessment System (C-PAS). C-PAS is a landmark series of performance tasks designed to measure college-readiness by assessing student achievement in the five key cognitive strategies necessary for success in college. C-PAS and the innovative instructional and curricular supports UA has developed to scaffold it have reached more than 10,000 students and contribute to UA's impressive student outcomes, which are significantly higher than New York City averages for math and ELA proficiency, high school graduation, and college enrollment and persistence rates. The Urban Assembly seeks a five-year Development grant to accomplish three primary goals: (1) systematically implement C-PAS and its related instructional supports in ELA, math, social science, and science in our 21 schools; (2) continue to improve student academic proficiency, high school graduation rates, and college enrollment and graduation rates; and (3) develop and validate tasks, implementation strategies, and assessment tools that will allow the work to be taken to scale. Our intended outcome is a replicable assessment and instructional system that provides a clear measure of college readiness while providing students with the key cognitive skills they need to be successful in college and career. We will serve more than 21,000 students between 2010 and 2015. Our key partners will be the New York City Department of Education, which will pilot our program in 2013-2015 and prepare to scale the work out should it prove successful, and EPIC, which will collaborate to develop, implement, and validate C-PAS."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Neighborhood Environmental Education Project
Project Description: "The Neighborhood Environmental Education Project (NEEP) strengthens STEM education by removing the constraints that slow the implementation of an inquiry-based teaching approach. NEEP, with its instant access to a standards-based curriculum, including all materials, a team of trained educators, professional development, acres of natural space, laboratories and classrooms, is the whole package. With this model, schools can immediately incorporate rigorous contextual learning experiences that boost student performance. Through a series of standards-based field excursions that use the environment as the learning context, NEEP is able to meet many objectives, including: raising standardized test scores, increasing student excitement about study in the STEM fields and improved overall school performance for high-need students.      By participating in NEEP, schools  immediately add the following components to their STEM program:           -24 Field Trips Annually: The Urban Ecology Center, with help from the Milwaukee County Parks and                private funders, transformed a 15-acre space along the Milwaukee River and 125-acre Washington Park into permanent outdoor classrooms for schools that have no natural space of their own. We also own a 20,000 square foot educational facility that is designed to support scientific inquiries. We have developed 70+ classes that use the environment as the learning context and are aligned with Wisconsin's learning targets.       	-A Team of Professional Educators & Working Professionals            - Transportation              -Teacher Professional Development"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Action Debating: A Strategy for Youth Leadership of Civic Dialogue
Project Description: "Action debating is a strategy for empowering students to first develop reading, writing, speaking and listening skills through structured classroom debating exercises and guided research. The strategy's action component enables students to subsequently hone civics and government skills by organizing and convening public debates on salient topics of local community concern and student interest. This proposal aims to study the strategy by expanding an existing University of Pittsburgh - Urban Youth Action (UYA) pilot project to reach approximately 150 high school students enrolling in UYA's after-school action debating classes offered during 2011-2014. Program objectives include implementation of a powerful assessment instrument, establishment of sustainable network infrastructure capable of supporting possible project scale up, and contribution to civic dialogue through student-driven public debates. Expected outcomes include improvement in debate students' high school graduation rates, higher scores in ACT benchmarks for college readiness in English and reading, and improved scholastic achievement. Unique program elements include development of debate pedagogy geared specifically for youth leadership of civic dialogue and integration of program activities within University curricula. Joining project applicant Urban Youth Action, Inc., as official partners are the University of Pittsburgh, and two local high schools, The Northside Urban Pathways Charter School and University Prep at Milliones 6-12."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Professional Growth Through Educator Collaboration
Project Description: "Urbana School District?s unique professional collaboration model will increase teacher effectiveness through job embedded professional development coaching within the framework of a Professional Learning Community.  Building on the successes of the school district?s current small Instructional Differentiation Coaching Program, along with the successes of the Professional Learning Community approach to school improvement, Urbana School District will work with the National Staff Development Council to create a replicable model for increasing teacher effectiveness and improving student achievement. They will implement a district-wide Professional Learning Community supported by building-based instructional differentiation coaches in all ten of Urbana?s EC-12 schools, which serve 4000 students in total.The hypothesis driving the Professional GrowthThrough Educator Collaboration Project is that instructional coaching and other professional collaboration within a Professional Learning Community framework can increase teacher effectiveness and eventually increase student achievement. To test that hypothesis, the project has three goals:1. Ensure the fidelity of implementation of the Professional Learning Community framework through buildingbased instructional coaching.2. Improve individual teachers? instruction, data-based decision making, and assessment skills and practices.3. Improve student achievement in math and reading.The Educational Psychology Department of the University of Illinois will be responsible for the formative and summative evaluation of the project to determine the fidelity of implementation, the changes to teacher effectiveness, and the effect on student achievement."

Project Title: Promoting Efficacy: Parsons Teachers & Principals
Afterschool & Community Education (ACE)
Project Description: "We propose to implement ACE in 10 cities, establishing partnerships in each city with LEAs and 30 persistently underperforming middle schools in those cities.  An average of 40 kids per school will be recruited for ACE, 1200 students in all.  Programming will occur twice weekly for two hours each day, for 40 weeks per year.  Where appropriate, there will also be an Intermediary who will coordinate across schools in a particular LEA.  Local NJTL Chapter personnel will recruit, train, and employ proven high-school students as junior instructors to help deliver after school tennis and life skills programming.  NJTL staff will work closely with the Local Coordinator from the LEA/School District or Intermediary partner to coordinate logistics of after school programming and also rosters, attendance, grade and behavior issues from in-school to after school and vice versa. The Local Coordinator will oversee all three schools in her respective city. Kids will be recruited at the school level by school staff.  Once identified, a needs assessment will be conducted for each youth so that a tailored approach for that particular youth can be created.  Some kids, for instance, may be having trouble with school attendance while others may be unable to pay attention in class.  Each will need a different approach, and this will be identified by the needs assessment.  In addition to programming, a learning community will be supported across all 10 sites and with all personnel involved in managing the project.  We will convene as a group twice annually, and have local site visits as needed.  Pre and post test data will be collected for the five project goals of student academic improvement, and formal reports will be created and shared annually"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: New Mexico K-3 Plus Extended School Year Validation Study
Project Description: "This proposal is for a randomized control trial (RCT) to conduct a cost-effectiveness analysis (CEA) of anextended school year (ESY) intervention known as the K-3 Plus Program, which is currently being pilotedwith approximately 7,000 high need students (students served in schools with 85% or more free reduced lunch)each year in New Mexico. Funding from this grant will pay for K-3 Plus services to students randomlyassigned to the intervention in four New Mexico LEAs. The proposed study will measure the impact of theincreased instructional time on costs and resources as well as on the literacy, numeracy, and social skills ofstudents. K-3 Plus learning opportunities will be provided to ELL and students with IEPs under IDEA. Theintervention will be implemented, consistent with K-3 Plus legislative intervention requirements, with 570students enrolled in persistently low-performing schools in Gallup-McKinley (a rural low-income schoolaccording to 2009 criteria), Albuquerque, Gadsden, and Las Cruces school districts in Year 1, 1140 students inYears 2, 3, and 4 and 570 again in Year 5. A comparable number of students will be enrolled each year in thecontrol group.The K-3 Plus intervention is a targeted approach to educational reform and provides significantly more time forstudents in kindergarten to third grade to learn core academic content by expanding the school year. Theproposed evaluation is a cost-effectiveness analysis of K-3 Plus. Service costs and student outcomes will becompared for students in and out of ESY to evaluate the efficacy, efficiency and feasibility of replication andscale-up of the K-3 Plus program."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Academic Growth and Retention: Securing the Future of High Need Students through an Online Expert System
Project Description: "The Academic Growth and Retention Consultant (AGR Consultant) represents an exceptional approach using expert system and online real-time data base technologies intended to empower counselors, teachers, mentors and parents to identify needs, establish individualized goals and incentives, match interventions to specific needs and implement them with fidelity, track academic growth and retention, provide professional development, and coordinate the intervention process."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovative Practices in Education
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Washington MESA 9th Grade Bridge Initiative
Project Description: "The Washington MESA Ninth Grade Bridge initiative will take a promising practice from one region and test itsvalue in four additional areas of the state. MESA designed and implemented a pilot program in Seattle PublicSchools in the 2003-04 school year. Now in its seventh year, MESA Ninth Grade Bridge has resulted in nearly70% of participants finishing their freshman year with a 3.0 or higher GPA (in all subjects), compared to only20% of their peers.MESA Ninth Grade Bridge will provide personalized academic support through an intensive three-week SummerMath Scholars program, followed by Academic Year Tutoring and Mentoring, and monthly SaturdayAcademy project-based enrichment. MESA Ninth Grade Bridge will provide strategies and activities forstudents, for teachers, and for parents and families. Professional development for 25-50 teachers in fourworkshops per year is vital to program success, and will impact over 6,000 additional students in classroomsacross the state. Parent workshops and field experiences will assist parents to engage with school staff andhelp to keep their children on track for college. The primary goals of the program are to:1. Substantiate the efficacy of MESA Ninth Grade Bridge as a successful model for increasing achievementamong underrepresented minority high school freshmen to improve the likelihood that they will complete highschool prepared for college;2. Expand and replicate the Ninth Grade Bridge model in four additional MESA Centers, in regions of the statethat range from urban to rural and with distinctive populations.Expected outcomes for students include:? Student college enrollment yield is greater than state averages for targeted races.? Participants score above state and national averages on standardized tests.? Participants? scores on the General Math Placement Test (MPT-G) allow them to register for collegefreshman-level math courses with no remediation."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Beyond Textbooks: Standards-Based Curriculum, Instruction, Assessment, and Intervention
Project Description: "Between 2002 and 2010, Vail Unified School District developed, implemented, and evaluated BeyondTextbooks, a comprehensive, district-wide approach to developing and implementing standards-basedcurriculum, implementing effective classroom management and instruction, developing and utilizing commonassessments to improve instruction and learning, and identifying and intervening with classrooms and studentsat risk for poor performance. We propose a randomized controlled trial of 24 underperforming Arizona schooldistricts and charter schools to evaluate the efficacy of Beyond Textbooks in improving student achievementfor all students and in narrowing student achievement gaps for at-risk student subgroups as measured by theArizona Instrument to Measure Standards. Through this project, we propose to implement Beyond Textbooksin 12 school systems over a four-year period and examine the effect of the program on the learningenvironment and student achievement. Project activities include 1) developing updated curriculum based onthe new, soon-to-be-adopted common core standards; 2) updating curriculum-aligned assessments; 3) trainingproject personnel and personnel at participating sites in instruction, curriculum implementation, assessment,and intervention; and 4) evaluating project implementation and outcomes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Valdosta Early College Academy: A Model Intervention Program
Project Description: "The Valdosta Early College Academy (VECA) is a partnership between Valdosta State University (VSU) and Valdosta City Schools with a mission to reduce dropout rates, close achievement gaps, and increase college attendance. VECA was formed two years ago and currently has 6th and 7th grade students. This Development Proposal builds on the established foundation and expands the school to 6-12 grades with 250 students. Thirty-six underperforming 6th grade students will be admitted each year. These students will have multiple risk factors for not completing school; low socioeconomic status homes, minority, first generation high school or college, English language learners. Despite these potential impediments to success, statistically significant improvements were obtained after one year on English/Language Arts standardized assessments for VECA students with higher trends in achievement in all other content areas when compared to a matched comparison group of students. Plans include hiring a Guidance Counselor, Instructional Technologist, and Community Involvement Coordinator. Additionally, dual enrollment courses at VSU will be available free to students beginning in 11th grade with all tuition, fees and books paid through Accel funding. Students will be immersed in a technology rich environment with highly skilled teachers, support from university and community resources, summer programs, and travel experiences. This program will test the following hypotheses: Hypothesis I. Students attending VECA will graduate at high rates and be more likely to attend postsecondary education; Hypothesis II. Students entering the early college experience in the 6th grade will demonstrate an elimination of racial achievement gaps during high school; and Hypothesis III. There is a critical period for initiating the early college experience which will maximize improved educational outcomes such as standardized testing performance, graduation rates, dual enrollment, and success in post-sec... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Vancouver Public Schools Science, Technology, Engineering & Math (STEM) Magnet School
Project Description: "Vancouver Public Schools in Vancouver, Washington will create a new 6-12 'school of choice' open to all district students and dedicated to teaching STEM subjects, but also strong core academics and arts. The school will be modeled on the highly successful High Tech High schools in San Diego, California. The first grant year will be dedicated to planning, curriculum development, teacher recruitment and training. The school will open in year 2 with 100 students each in grades 6, 7, 9 & 10. The third year will add grades 8 & 11 and the fourth year 12th grade. This will allow two years of graduating classes during the grant period to track and evaluate after graduation. Students will apply and be chosen by lottery, geographically weighted to match district socioeconomic and ethnic demographics. The STEM school will be a small school, with 100 students in each grade, for a maximum student body of 700 and will serve a total of 800 students in the grant period. Project objectives include: All students meet or exceed Washington State test and curriculum standards; All graduates meet Washington State university entrance requirements, are academically prepared for college and understand college application process and financial aid.  Project outcomes include: All graduates are college and career-ready, eligible to enroll in a public college in Washington and understand issues of college affordability, financial aid, and the application processes; All students feel supported by one or more adults at school; The percent of educationally disadvantaged students who succeed in high school and college matches or exceeds district demographics; Increased number of college-bearing credits earned; SAT scores exceed state averages; 90% on-time graduation rate and 100% extended graduation rate; and satisfaction of parents, students, businesses and college partners."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Aspirnaut K-20 STEM Pipeline: Connecting a Research University with Rural Schools
Project Description: "The Aspirnaut K-20 STEM Pipeline is designed to increase the achievement of rural, economicallydisadvantaged, and ethnic minority groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM)subjects, and increase the number of these underrepresented students who pursue postsecondary education andenter the STEM workforce. The pipeline brings an integrated set of STEM educational interventions from aresearch university to rural schools (non-charter and charter). The interventions include: 1) Wi-Fi enabled buses;2) videoconferencing of hands-on real-world STEM labs and interactive discussion with Vanderbilt faculty andstudents; 3) accelerated online STEM courses, expansion of College Board Certified online Advanced Placement(AP) courses, and dual enrollment of AP courses; 4) summer research internships at Vanderbilt University inTennessee or Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory in Maine; 6) mentoring relationships; and 7) collegeplanning guidance. Individually several of these interventions have been used with success in urban settings, butthis pipeline innovation brings them into a synergistic set for rural students where the whole is greater than thesum of the parts. Expected outcomes include increases in the quality of STEM curriculum and in student STEMaspirations and achievement. The Center for Evaluation and Education policy at Indiana University will workwith the Aspirnaut team to gather and utilize formative and summative evaluation data. Vanderbilt Universitywill partner with the Arkansas Public School Resource Center and 10 Arkansas districts for implementation,impacting at least 11,800 students over 4 years."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Assessing Teacher Effectiveness to Improve Student Achievement
Project Description: "Vanderbilt University, Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools and Stanford University will complete a $6 million Development Grant, 'Assessing Teacher Effectiveness to Improve Student Achievement'. This project will pilot, field test, and measure the effects of a portfolio-based teacher assessment for initial licensure. The Teacher Performance Assessment (TPA) focuses on the teaching of a brief 3-5 lesson learning segment, and includes evidence of teachers? practices on content-specific tasks of planning, instruction, assessment, and reflection. The evidence collected includes teaching artifacts (lesson plans, video clips, student work samples) plus commentaries that require the candidate to explain teaching decisions and results in terms of expected or actual effects on student learning. Twelve rubrics give candidates and programs feedback on outcomes along five dimensions of teaching (planning, instruction, assessment, reflection, academic language development).We will follow a sample of two cohorts of candidates from the pilot and field test years into their first year of teaching and perform a value-added analysis to see if the assessment scores predict which candidates achieve higher student outcomes. A second set of validity studies will examine the underlying assumptions critical to the TPA's meaning as an assessment, and collect qualitative and quantitative evidence from teacher preparation programs and within Nashville and other districts to identify factors that may facilitate or inhibit the assessment's effects.We believe the TPA can become a nationally available tool that will provide useful information about specific areas of skill both to individual pre-service candidates and to districts and schools that wish to hire teachers that are likely to be effective in classrooms. This project is part of a larger ongoing effort by these partners to develop the TPA and expand its use from 5 to 20 states."

Project Title: Aspiring Greatness: The Implementation of Two Instructional Coaching Models to Determine the Influences on Teacher Effectiveness and Student Achievement
Project Description: "The purpose of this proposal is to gain funding of a Validation grant to support the implementation of two models of instructional coaching in two school districts. The project will aid in determining the advantages and disadvantages of each model plus the effects on student achievement. The implementation model will involve 30 schools (eleven middle schools in one district, and all nineteen schools PreK-12 in the other school district) and will impact approximately 750 teachers and 15,000 students over five years. This project will determine the advantages and disadvantages of two coaching models: 1. the implementation of site-based instructional coaches in eleven middle schools in St. Landry Parish, and 2. the implementation of district-based instructional coaches in nineteen schools PreK-12 in Vermilion Parish.The project will utilize a Professional Learning Communities model that will be offered to all teachers regardless of their level of need in terms of the Louisiana Coaching Cycle.The project will include a qualitative investigation and two quantitative evaluations including: 1. a qualitative analysis of teachers receiving support from instructional coaches in regards to the effects of instructional coaching; 2. a quantitative comparison between site-based instructional coaching and district-based instructional coaching; and 3. a quantitative analysis of the impact of instructional coaching on student achievement."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: VermontFutures School Program
Project Description: "The Vermont Youth Conservation Corps (VYCC) aims to expand a highly promising, innovative, work-based learning program, called VermontFutures, to ten of Vermont?s persistently low achieving high schools. In partnership with the Vermont Principals? Association, sixteen hundred students will earn academic credit taught by talented Instructors in a personalized program. VermontFutures creates alternative pathways to graduation during the traditional school day, in paid after-school internships, and in summer credit recovery programs. The VYCC will also implement a robust and highly effective professional development program that will fund 30 Instructors as they successfully work to obtain Vermont licensure. Furthermore, 10 low achieving schools and the principals of these schools will benefit from mentorships with experienced and accomplished former principals. At the end of the grant period, the VYCC will have reduced the dropout rate of approximately 1,600 participating high-need students; improved student performance; trained principals and teachers to be highly-effective principals and teachers; and established a common body of knowledge that strengthens schools and technical centers? long-term ability to deliver a more practical, career-oriented, and inclusive approach to 21st century education."

Project Title: Online Sciences Career Academy
Project Description: "The Online Sciences Career Academy will create, offer, evaluate and sustain career-oriented programs of study in energy and biotechnology using a progression of deeply digital courses. Each program of study will consist of semester-long courses based at each grade for a total of 14 unique course titles, plus 2 middle-school course modules, and 3 career awareness modules. Each OSCA course will be designed using a Deeply Digital Specification that is intended to increase student access to these courses. All OSCA courses will be offered by participating school teachers, trained by VHS to teach online and to use the Deeply Digital resources to individualize student instruction."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: iTeach and iLearn: A 21st Century Blended Teaching and Learning Model
Project Description: "The iTeach and iLearn program provides teachers and school leaders with professional development, mentoring, and collaboration through a user-driven, sustainable blended learning web-based portal system. The program will expand teachers' abilities to use blended learning pedagogy and produce an increase in student success in core content and 21st century skill acquisition. Activities will include: web-based professional development courses on blended learning pedagogy for teachers and school leaders; delivery of collaboratively developed blended courses to school students; development and maintenance of a web-based professional learning community portal that will support continuation and expansion of the iTeach and iLearn program.Teachers will develop blended teaching instructional skills, school leaders will develop skills that enable them to effectively evaluate blended learning instruction, and students will increase core content knowledge. Project outcomes will include: 148 teachers complete professional development courses in blended learning; 56 administrators complete professional development courses on blended learning evaluation; 30,920 students complete a course of study (Digital Literacy for a Digital Age) in a blended learning format."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: A+ Writing Promise Prototype
Project Description: "The intent of the proposed five-year Development Grant is to take a standards-based writing prototype that is exhibiting promising potential for high needs students at grades two and five, expand upon this at grades 6 and 9, and disseminate research and writing products across the nation.  The Vigo County School Corporation (VCSC), located in Terre Haute, Indiana, in partnership with Indiana State University Professional Development Schools, Vigo County Teachers Association, Covered Bridge Special Education District, Vigo County Education Foundation, CTB/McGraw-Hill, The College Board, and Indiana AdvancED sets forth this prototype.  The project will serve 4,717 students in grades 6-9 yearly, for a five year total of 23,585 students.     VCSC and partners are coupling the Absolute Priority 3-Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments with Competitive Preference Priority 6-Innovations that Support College Access and Success to expand upon a proven writing prototype.   Three goals serve as guides to meeting both priorities:  Goal One:   Increase the development and use of formative assessments and other performance-based tools that are aligned with rigorous academic achievement standards; Goal Two:  Translate the standards and information from assessments into classroom practices that meet the needs of all students; and Goal Three:   Increase the success of VCSC high needs students in academically rigorous courses and college readiness.      The VCSC and partners have developed an explicit strategy to fill the gap within curriculum, instruction, and assessment for improving writing achievement that includes four synergistic elements: award-winning writing standards, embedded English content experts, formative assessments, and college readiness.  A web portal of research and products, as well as opportunities for local visits, will disseminate the results and findings."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Let's Invest in Neighborhood Kids (LINK)
Project Description: "LINK (Let's Invest in Neighborhood Kids), at the Village Learning Place and Margaret Brent Elementary/Middle School, provides Kindergarten through 8th grade students in Baltimore's Charles Village/Barclay neighborhood with the academic tools and the community support they need to succeed in and stay in school. LINK's after-school and summer programming addresses critical needs for academic instruction, enrichment opportunities, character development, and family and community involvement. In the past three years, LINK has successfully helped students attain higher MSA scores, increased family involvement significantly, and built a culture of safety, respect, and engaged learning.The goals of this project are to help high-need K-8th grade students improve Maryland State Assessment (MSA) scores, to help under-represented 8th grade students gain admission into competitive or mission-specific high schools, and, ultimately, to prepare high-need students to successfully enter college or the workforce. In the five years ahead, programming will expand to serve students at Barclay Elementary/ Middle School and to include early childhood and high school students. The VLP's education team has envisioned this strengthened and expanded LINK as a 'cradle to gown' initiative. In this approach, LINK will guide learners from before they enter Pre-Kindergarten until they graduate from high school ready to confidently enter college or the workforce, pursuing a lifetime of learning. A rigorous and thorough evaluation will gauge LINK's effectiveness and capacity to scale up. By the grant's fifth year, if the model is determined to be successful, LINK will have an Operating Manual and training program for other out-of-school-time service providers, allowing the LINK Initiative and its component programs to be replicated elsewhere in the city and beyond."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title:
Developing a Statewide Mentorship Program to Improve the Quality 
of Family- and Center-Based Preschool Settings in Virginia
Project Description: "The Virginia Early Childhood Foundation (VECF) proposes to use this i3 research grant opportunity to expand and enhance the statewide Quality Rating and Improvement System for preschool programs. The Virginia Early Childhood Foundation proposes expand and enhance the state's preschool Quality Rating and Improvement System (QRIS). This project will further develop a mentorship program for center-based settings and expand the system to include family-based sites. The purpose of the project is to advance the quality of Virginia's preschool system to prepare children for success in school and in life. This Development Project addresses Absolute Priority 1 to improve teacher effectiveness by developing practices that increase the number of teachers who are highly effective in family and center-based early care and education settings.  It also addresses Competitive Preference Priority 5 to create innovative strategies that improve early learning outcomes for high need students who are young children.  Further, the project addresses Competitive Preference Priority 8 by developing a mentorship program that is feasible to implement and addresses the unique challenges across the state, and in particular, within rural local education agencies-two of which are partners in this development project. A total of 375 classrooms will be rated and mentored over the five year project, impacting teacher performance for an estimated 5600 students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The K-16 Model - Developing an Effective School, Community and University Coalition to Improve College Readiness
Project Description: "This 5-year proposal will involve the development of a ?K-16? model to enhance evaluating student achievement and college readiness in the Petersburg City Public School District. This proposal is designed to develop an effective coalition of community partners to work with the Petersburg City Public School District, including: 1) Virginia State University; 2) The SAVY coalition; 3) The Algebra Project, Inc.; and 4) The Petersburg Bureau of Police. This coalition will allow for the development of both academic and non-academic interventions that will help to move students successfully along the path to college readiness upon graduation.The coalition partners have already had great success in bringing schools up to minimum standards represented by the Virginia Standards of Learning benchmarks. This project marks the next step in improving student performance by instituting both academic and non-academic interventions at key grade levels to significantly increase the number of students who are college ready at the time of graduation, and who successfully transition into an institution of higher education. The primary approach for reaching this goal will be through strengthening and expanding science, English and mathematics programs for students, providing teacher development, implementing effective strategies to reduce substance abuse and violence among youth, addressing psychosocial issues arising from the disadvantaged backgrounds of the majority of students, and reinforcing, enhancing, and extending current community efforts to support the Petersburg City Public Schools."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Virtual Enterprises
Project Description: "Virtual Enterprises International (VE) has created this project to address Absolute Priority 4 of the i3 Grant?Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low-Performing Schools. Specifically, this project is intended to focus on targeted approaches to reform that increase graduate rates and attack the dropout problem by engaging students in simulated businesses. VE?s simulated businesses are created and run by students, with the guidance of a teacher/facilitator and a business partner. In this model, student-employees work in teams, serving as members of the human resources, accounting, product development, production, distribution, marketing or sales departments. VE firms in one school do business with other student firms around the world. Participating in this simulation conveys the expectations of the workplace as students engage in hands-on applications and problem solving, using written and verbal communication. Ultimately, students learn about a variety of careers associated with business, acquire global economic knowledge, and use technology as applied in business."

Project Title: VTS-DATA Project
Project Description: "Visual Understanding in Education, Inc (VUE) and its partners, New York University (NYU)?s Metropolitan Center for Urban Education (Metro Center), South Dakota State University (SDSU), working with LEAs in South Dakota, and LEAs in New York, New York propose the Visual Thinking Strategies ? Data Analyses for Teaching Achievement (VTS-DATA) Project, a program that combines two methods of inquiry ? VTS and Action Research Cycles (ARC) ? which will encourage and facilitate educator?s process of collection, evaluation, and use of student achievement data. This process will inform educators classroom instruction decisions and improve student, school staff, and district performance and achievement.The VTS-DATA Project seeks a Development Grant.  VTS is a pedagogy and program that increases students? achievement and improves cognitive, critical thinking, oral language, and writing skills through facilitated discussions of visual images. VTS-DATA offers an innovative and transformational strategy that uses the VTS professional development and classroom curriculum integrated with the Action Research Cycle process to empower teachers with field researchers? skills. This will increases the teacher?s capacity to diagnose specific gaps in students? knowledge and skills; identify and select instructional strategies and resources to address those needs; implement those strategies; monitor and evaluate the effects; and then revise instruction again as new data emerges. The VTS-DATA project will provide teachers and administrators with training in a variety of strategies for the collection and analyses of data, including a web-based data system that allows teachers to enter, query, and share data. Working individually and in teams, teachers and administrators will apply VTS-DATA methods to actively utilize data to better classroom instruction and ultimately, improve student performance and growth. Simultaneously, students will also receive the VTS classroom curriculum which will p... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: From "Beating the Odds" to "Changing the Odds" - Using Interdistrict Integration Programs to Improve Educational Outcomes for High-Needs Students
Project Description: "This grant will enable our organizations to work together in a more systematic fashion in order to improve the services we provide, through sharing of strategies as well as applied assessment of our programs.  For more information, please see the detailed grant application."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Volusia Proficiency Model (VPM)
Project Description: "The focus of the Volusia County Schools (VCS) i3 Development Grant proposal is the Volusia Proficiency Model (VPM). The study examines four research based hypotheses that demonstrate potential to improve student learning: 1) formative and interim assessment aligned with well-designed curricular learning progressions and grading scales increase learning and student engagement; 2) teachers with strong content knowledge and ability to assess understanding at the conceptual level are more likely to implement instructional change strategies that improve student achievement; 3) an integrated data system increases capacity for instructional decision making, intervention, and progress monitoring; and 4) collaborative practices transform instruction and increase rigor and consistency of instructional practice.Volusia County Schools is a central Florida school district comprised of 77 schools with more than 60,000 students. The project will initially impact eleven schools including 400 core teachers serving 11,000 students from three high schools and feeder patterns. All of the Schools are Title I eligible. SynapticMash, Inc., developer of educational data systems; and Solution Tree, Inc., professional development and assessment consultants will provide the 20% match as private sector partners. Volusia Teachers Organization, the local teacher union, is a collaborative partner.  The grant also has the support of The Innovation & Education Alliance, a non-profit professional group, which will provide opportunities for the applicant to collaborate with business leaders and other LEAs in the region. The outcomes of the study include a system of interim assessments reflecting high level content standards, a standards-based grading system, increased teacher capacity in data analysis and differentiated instruction, and a seamless data system designed to maximize student achievement for all students. The  plan builds capacity gradually expanding to all schools in 5 years."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: VSA Arts-Integrated Learning Initiative
Project Description: "VSAM will implement a project to improve access to the general curriculum by all students, including students with disabilities, by employing arts-integrated instruction techniques to accomplish the goals of UDL."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: 90+Celebration
