Project Description: "With funding from the U. S. Department of Education's i3 Competitive  Development Grant, Priority 4, the Du Bois Society will collaborate with 12 persistently low performing schools in a feeder pattern in the Atlanta Public School District on its 90+Celebration program. Over a 36-month project period, we propose to expand the number of students available to participate in the 90+Celebration program from the 500 students at 3 schools in our pilot to a little more than 2,000 students at 12 schools by the end of the project period. The proposed project will seek to attract lower performing or 'at-promise' students and will use of immediate, extrinsic rewards that we believe can inspire academic ambition among more African American students and connect them to the intrinsic motivation needed to learn and to achieve. The desired outcome of this project to move participants from extrinsic to intrinsic motivation through participation in the program by challenging students: a) to accomplish new tasks by challenging themselves and other students; b) to take control over their lives by making positive choices; c) to collaborate with the peers and in their communities; d) to recognize them for meaningful work academically, socially, and community-wise; and to e) trust and believe in the schooling process and community. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Waconia Investing in Innovation Network (Wi3N)
Project Description: "Waconia Investing In Innovation Network (Wi3N) will provide a comprehensive and integrated approach to ensure that all students at various levels of 'high need' will participate in more rigorous academic courses, and prepare them to succeed in the 21st century.  Wi3N will focus on Absolute Priority 3; Competitive Preference Priority 6; Competitive Preference Priority 7.  Wi3N will enhance existing academic resources, implement the nationally recognized 'Project Lead the Way' curriculum, expand Advanced Placement and Post-Secondary Enrollment Options (PSEO), integrate evidenced based Solution Focused Practices, utilize the acclaimed 'Naviance' academic and college planning system,  and engage students in 'real world' project based learning opportunities.Please note: The Budget Amounts listed below represented grant requested amounts (not matching funds)."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Rural Children's Achievement Zone
Project Description: "The Rural Children's Achievement Zone is a development proposal addressing Absolute Priority 4. The project has been designed to turn around five low-performing rural elementary schools.  We seek to demonstrate that when a 'critical mass' of optimum learning conditions is put into place in the home, school and community, children experiencing the disadvantages of poverty can overcome their circumstances and routinely attain grade level academic standards. We hypothesize that the current level of performance of this group of children reflects an existing status quo; a balance resulting from the set of forces currently operating in their homes and schools that push both 'for' and 'against' high academic achievement. This balance can be upset, 'tipped,' if a 'critical mass' of optimum conditions for learning is put into place.     Together with our partners in this effort, the National Black Child Development Institute, the School of Education at UNC-CH and the Rural School and Community Trust, we have crafted interventions designed to alter critical variables associated with student achievement. Our major initiatives (1) Alter the variable of time by lengthening the school year (2) Alter expectations and aspirations of  parents and the business community so that they imagine their children as high school and college graduates    (3) Alter the impact of parent education level by providing 'Parent 'U' a classroom experience where expectant parents learn the importance of literacy (4) Provide 'wrap-around' services in schools (5) Increase the number of effective teachers through the provision of longer employment contracts and a new philosophy and approach to professional development (6) Provide quality preschool for every three and four year old and (7) Provide powerful instructional practices aimed at preventing early school failure."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: WCSD Hiring for Learning in the 21st Century (HL21)
Project Description: "Hiring for Learning in the 21st Century (HL21) is a systemic plan for hiring, evaluating and building culturallyresponsive teachers and principals who will effectively use new policies and practices to address achievementgaps. The Absolute Priority 1 Innovations that support effective teachers and principals are: 1) recruitment andhiring; 2) professional development; and, 3) evaluation. The goal and objectives for this project encompass asystemic reform initiative for our human resources which includes: a) defining and supporting teacher andprincipal effectiveness through a rigorous recruitment and pre-screening initiative leading to a pool of highlyeffective, qualified professionals; b) providing ongoing professional learning focused on inclusive, culturallyresponsive policies and practices; and, c) creating a rigorous, transparent and equitable evaluation process thatdifferentiates teachers and principals based on effectiveness and provides feedback and progress monitoring onpersonal professional development. The principle innovation of this proposal is the creation of new policiesand practices (e.g. new tools and processes for recruiting and hiring, new forms of professional learning andschool leadership development to support the change in the vision of teaching, and new evaluation tools andmethods) with special emphasis on recruiting minority teachers as part of a set of strategies to better addressthe needs of the diverse student populations of Washoe County School District (WCSD). Partners for thisgrant include: The New Teacher Project, Equity Alliance of ASU, Pacific Education Group, WashoeEducation Association, Washoe School Principals Association, University of Nevada, Nevada Department ofEducation and district departments including: The Principal?s Academy, New Teacher Induction andMentoring, Instructional Coaches, Diversity and Equity, and Public Policy and Accountability. Externalevaluator will be WestEd."

Project Title: WCSD i3 AVID Pipeline for Success
Project Description: "The AVID Pipeline for Success Project addresses Absolute Priority 3 Innovations that complement theimplementation of high standards and high-quality assessment, specifically through efforts to measurestudents? progress toward college- and career-readiness. The innovative AVID (Advancement Via IndividualDetermination) program will be implemented with fidelity in 11 WCSD traditional high schools, to serve17,600 students in the first five years. AVID provides direct student support services through collegeadmissions preparation, academic support, tutoring, parent education and advising services as well as academicand social support to AVID students, with access to rigorous curriculum, including Honors and/or AdvancePlacement classes, and the expectation to graduate and successfully enroll in and complete college. Researchin 2010 by our external evaluator, Dr. Karen Watt, has shown students were better prepared for college due toparticipation in AVID and being exposed to rigorous curriculum. Our goal is to increase student readiness forcollege and/or highly skilled careers, and increase the graduation rate from one of the nation?s lowest,currently at 56%. Professional training and staff development is key to AVID implementation and AVID teamsmentor and train others to move AVID methodologies school-wide. More than 225 teachers, principals, andadministrators will be trained in AVID through this grant and WCSD will become a Center for Learning AVIDstrategies for the entire state of Nevada. With our Official Partners, The AVID Center, Education Alliance ofWashoe County, Sparks Chamber of Commerce/Hispanic Business Network, Reno-Sparks Chamber ofCommerce, we will sustain the AVID program in our secondary schools."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: IgnitED
Project Description: "Project IgnitED is a consortium of regional education service agencies (ISD/RESAs), public K-12 school districts, the New Tech Network, and the Michigan Department of Education to provide a statewide network of technical assistance, financial support and professional development supporting the implementation of New Tech High Schools. This proposal requests funding to continue the consortium for a three year period, provide a total of $500,000 each to six districts serving high need students who seek to open New Tech High Schools in September 2011, and provide for intense evaluation of the efficacy of the statewide network to support struggling districts to implement a fundamental change in the delivery of high school education that emphasizes student achievement, college readiness and success in post-secondary learning environments.This proposal builds upon the establishment in fall 2009 of the IgnitED consortium and the support provided to six diverse Michigan school districts to open New Tech High Schools September 2010. We believe that the promising practice of a model proven to increase student attendance, achievement and graduation rates (New Tech High School) coupled with ongoing support for the district to plan, implement, fund and evaluate systemic change to the instructional practices of a traditional high school will prove to be both effective in supporting change within these districts, but also provide a sustainable route to large scale change and scale-up of the programs statewide.IgnitED has been successful in receiving Title II, D Education Technology funds from a competitive grant through the Michigan Department of Education to provide technical assistance and partial financial to support Holland, NICE, Westwood, Ypsilanti, Pinckney and River Rouge in opening New Tech High Schools fall 2010. And it has been successful in assisting these districts to make funding requests from their local community foundations."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: The Waterford Vocabulary Project
Project Description: "The Waterford Vocabulary Project (WVP), a Development GrantThe Waterford Vocabulary Project will use technology to increase the effectiveness of vocabulary instruction for high need students over a four year period (K-3) by providing a 15 minute daily intelligent multimedia whiteboard lesson delivered by the teacher. An enriched version of the vocabulary program on a computer attached to the Internet will also be available to each student at home for year-round usage supported by Waterford. The program's goal is to provide a solution to the problem of providing an adequate vocabulary for high need students from lower SES families, the lack of which initiates the 4th grade 'slump' growing worse each year and leading many students to drop out despite receiving an excellent early reading instruction and learning to decode. Scholars have shown that high need students from limited vocabulary families know only 4,000 root words entering the 3rd and 4th grade when the books they will be reading require 6,000. Waterford has developed a program that will enable the students to learn an additional 500 words a year for 4 years to arrive at the 4th grade having made up the 2,000 words. This program could reduce the pressure and expense on schools and teachers and provide summer instruction to try to make up the vocabulary shortfall. Until this problem is solved, high need students will continue to drop out in droves. The programs utilize the most successful model of vocabulary instruction that scholars prototyped but have been unable to scale because of the unusual demands of having to teach 25-50 new words a week. Waterford will demonstrate that its technology program will provide at least 60% retention and scale quickly to the eight hundred students in the project and then to millions of children. Partnering schools will be from urban and rural districts, and partnering consultants are Dr. Herb Walberg, (evaluation), Dr. Marilyn Adams, Dr. Hollis Scarb"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Working with Utah School Districts to Scale UPSTART, Waterford Research Institute's
Home-Based, Technology-Delivered Pre-School Program
Project Description: "Waterford Research Institute (Waterford) proposes to improve school readiness preparation and reading development for students in Utah through a validation grant to scale up Waterford's home-based, technology-delivered pre-K program, UPSTART, in six Utah school districts- Box Elder, San Juan, Tooele, Uintah, Wasatch, and Ogden.  Five of the districts are rural districts and traditionally have had less access to educational resources; all of the districts have a majority of ELL students and students from homes that represent the lowest SES in Utah.  Waterford has piloted the UPSTART program and has impressive data from the program and extensive experience implementing it.  But, the distribution of participants has been statewide, without a sizeable impact on individual school districts and without working with district personnel to capitalize on the UPSTART experience to significantly impact district-level achievement.	Over five years, the project will: serve 8,094 children in six Utah school districts; work with districts to transition children into kindergarten; and provide an independent evaluation of the program.  Expected results are:  gains similar to those from the statewide UPSTART pilot program; a blueprint of ways to work with Utah's school districts to improve outcomes for participating children as they enter kindergarten; and information for Utah legislators to consider as they deliberate broadening the scope of UPSTART.	The software for the program is comprised of Rusty and Rosy Learn with Me? (reading); Waterford Assessments of Core Skills?; and Camp Consonant? (reading intervention).  Together, they provide a strong, individualized academic program for preschool children.  For academic supervision, UPSTART draws on the home's resources-available time and the presence of a concerned parent or caregiver.In addition to the six districts, the project has support from the Utah State Office of Education and key leadership in the Utah Legislature."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title:
Regional Scaling of the Use of Waterford Research Institute's
Waterford Early Reading Program
Project Description: "Waterford Research Institute (Waterford or WRI) proposes to place the Waterford Early Reading Program? (WERP) in 32 failing charter schools in eight states.  The software will be used to improve early reading development by teaching pre-literacy and early literacy skills to beginning readers in kindergarten and first and second grades.   The purpose of the three-year project is to determine the correlation between time using WERP and reading skill gained when prescribed usage standards are met.  WERP is computer-adaptive software, and its theoretical framework and results from a  battery of empirical testing show it to represent an immediate and sizable opportunity for effecting change in the classroom.  But, after nearly two decades of work with traditional public schools, it is apparent that teachers often face challenges finding time in their day for students to use educational technology frequently enough and long enough to reap the software's benefits.  Waterford's partnership with charter schools is key because charter schools offer teachers more authority to make classroom decisions than most traditional public schools.  In addition to their flexibility to manage their time, charter schools frequently make more time for learning by lengthening the teaching day with morning and afternoon programs added to the regular school-day schedule and by doubling up instruction in core subjects.   The partnership will add to the understanding of and appreciation for the validity of using software in early education as a tool for helping children reach their learning potential.  At the same time, the project will support the partnering charter schools' goal of providing additional access to education for their students.  Computer labs and lab personnel will be provided to partnership schools in exchange for meeting program usage requirements.  1,440 students will be served over three years."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Innovation  in Education
Project Description: "Watts Willowbrook Boys & Girls Club (WWBGC) plans to utilize the funds received from the Department of Education's Investing in Innovation Fund (i3) Development Grant (CFDA 84.396C) to establish a program entitled Innovation in Education.  As an agency with over fifty years of experience working with high-risk, socioeconomically disadvantaged youth in South Central Los Angeles, WWBGC currently serves approximately 2,500 unduplicated students through its various programs and partnerships with local schools.  With assistance from the Department of Education, WWBGC has developed a plan to increase the number of youth served to 5,000 by the end of the program period.    Under this program WWBGC plan to accomplish the following goals and objectives: (1) improve students' academic outcomes; (2) increase student growth; (3) close achievement gaps; (4) decrease dropout rates; (5) increase high school graduation rates; and (6) increase college enrollment and attrition rates.    WWBGC plans to achieve these goals by implementing the following activities: (1) Early Childhood Development (ages 0-5); (2) Internship opportunities (ages 14-18); (3) Money Matters / Career Launch focusing on education, investments, savings, entrepreneurship, work readiness (ages 13-18); (4) Colleges courses provided in partnership with El Camino Compton College (grades 11-12); (5) Reading program to teach and develop skills (all ages); and (6) Parent Empowerment Training.  In addition to these programs, WWBGC has also developed a plan to increase the percentages of highly effective teachers in South Los Angeles as evidenced through rigorous studies and evaluations."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Community Approach for Renewing Education
Project Description: "The Waukegan Public Schools (WPS), in partnership with National-Louis University (NLU), and in collaboration with the Coalition of Community Schools (CCS), will establish the Community Approach for Renewing Education (CARE) Project. The project will expand and evaluate two innovative projects implemented in WPS: (1) Webster School Renewal Project, recognized as one often Breakthrough Schools by the National Association of Secondary School Principals, and (2) Waukegan Arts Integration Project, funded by USDE and designed to improve achievement of students at-risk. Both projects yielded promising results that warrant further study and development before they can serve as models of best practices and scale up. The CARE project is a school improvement, arts integration model designed to support school reform, improve teaching practices, and increase achievement of students at risk of academic failure. The project will systematically study the effectiveness of the model and its viability for dissemination and scale up. It will be implementation in five ofthe lowest performing WPS schools, with high rates of students from low income families: Carmen-Buckner 91 %, Glen Flora 90%, Glenwood 82%, Clearview 90%, and Lyon 85%. The CARE project represents an exceptional approach to school improvement, involving the whole community and supporting teachers in taking collective responsibility for student learning. The project is guided by the Bryk et.al. (2010) landmark research which identified essential features needed to improve lowperforming schools. These are reflected in the goals ofthe project: (1) Establish a system of collaboration among partners to implement a systemic, comprehensive, community approach to school reform for improving teaching and learning, (2) Create school-based professional learning communities to support school reform and increase best practice teaching to improve achievement of students at-risk. (3) Increase student achievement and engaged learning th... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"

Applicant: Wayne County Regional Educational Service Agency (RESA)
Project Title: A Model for Promoting Evaluation-based Reform in Education: Project AMPERE
Project Description: "Project AMPERE proposes to validate a model for the delivery of inservice training for teachers that has been proven effective in changing teacher practice and increasing student achievement. Piloted with elementary and middle school mathematics, AMPERE validates this model by (1) replicating the model with mathematics content in five addition high-priority, high-needs school districts and (2) modifying the model to deliver science content in (a) six high-needs districts and using five districts as a comparison group and then, after the delivery of 180 hours of inservice training, coaching and monthly grade-level meetings, to (b) implement the model using science with an addition five high-needs school districts. It is hypothesized that if the validation of this model proves to be effective when replicated and duplicated with a different curriculum content, that it will be effective with all curriculum content and the entire preK-12 continuum."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: Wayne State University Research and Technology Park in Detroit
Project Title:
Turning Around the Nations Dropout Epidemic by Improving Teacher
Effectiveness
Project Description: "Our Project raises teacher effectiveness by providing classroom tools, technology and professional developnWe will address the dropout rate for at risk students with 1-2-1 classrooms and e-learning curriculum. Ourcommunity is plagued by an Epidemic of dropouts. This project shows that more effective teachers can mak<significant difference.Our attached research (appendix F) shows how effective teachers can be working with an extreme at risk groistudents that had previously dropped out of another adjacent district.Our project Goals are:? Raising teacher effectiveness? Reduce the suburban urban graduation gap? Improve teacher effectiveness to 1.5 yrs advancement per studentOur preliminary results are very strong showing that it is possible to eliminate the graduation gap by improviteacher effectiveness."

Project Title: ACE (Alternative Classroom Experience) Program in Northern Indiana
Project Description: "The Webster Foundation proposes to replicate the ACE (Alternative Classroom Experience) program from the Joseph Pfeifer Kiwanis Camp in Little Rock, Arkansas. Started in 1988, the Arkansas ACE program is a 30-day residential, educational and wilderness experience for 165 at-risk third, fourth, and fifth-graders. With an emphasis in reading comprehension and math, certified teachers will implement a similar experiential learning program on an isolated wooded peninsula surrounded by wilderness lakes in Northern Indiana. Start-up funding for Webster Foundation's ACE program would be for five years and - at capacity -- serve 200 to 300 children per year.	        In Little Rock, the ACE program is a cooperative venture with the Little Rock School District and the Pulaski County Special School District. Duplicating this extensive field trial, the Webster Foundation proposes a similar cooperative partnership with local education agencies (LEAs) in northern Indiana. For participation in the program, area school teachers, counselors or principals select students from the third, fourth and fifth grades who are considered at-risk for failure socially and educationally. Not working up to their potential, these at-risk students are defined as: poor academic performance in class; poor economic status at home; single parent home; parent in prison; exposed to violence; sexually or emotionally abused; or low self esteem.	        ACE students arrive on Sunday afternoon and stay until Friday afternoon for five weeks. During this time they are housed in cabins with 8-10 other students and two adult counselors. This group becomes like a family. Classes are held in camp classrooms where two certified teachers and several counselors test, teach, guide, discipline, and support these students in learning. Students start at their present capable level and work toward attaining their current grade level."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Idaho Gateway to College Initiative: At-Risk and Rural Students To and Through College
Project Description: "The Idaho Gateway to College Initiative: Rural and At-Risk Students To and Through CollegeProject Description:The project is designed to prepare students for college through the development of academic and life skills.  The skills will be delivered on parallel 'tracks' targeting academic support, through a 3 year summer program designed to address the issue of 'summer academic loss', and life/financial skills required to effectively compete in college. The program will: leverage peer group support for families, provide oversight by school districts, offer online technologies designed to extend learning opportunities, and utilize data analytics. 3,000 9th and 10th grade parents and students will commit to a 3 full-year program of preparation. Onsite program 'coaches' will oversee participation and support the long-term success of each student and family.  Students will go through three phases: College Life Skills Education, Intensive Math and Writing Instruction for college readiness, and data analytics that provides an opportunity for parent engagement."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Comprehension First for All Learners Across the Curriculum
Project Description: "West Allis-West Milwaukee School District will implement an innovative, high quality literacy model,?Comprehension First for All Learners Across the Curriculum? supporting the rigor of the Common Core StateStandards in Reading/Language Arts, that will increase background information for 8,800 students in Pre Kthrough grade 12. This model will amplify the literary practices of all teachers so that children of poverty,limited English proficiency, minority ethnic groups and students with special education needs are betterprepared for learning through an increased connection of learning and thinking to all content areas.Preliminary results have shown that increasing reading of non-fiction materials in an active literacy andinquiry based environment will help students become better prepared for the world of work and post secondaryopportunities. The Stephanie Harvey Consulting Group will provide innovative staff development utilizingmodel lab and incubator classrooms to train all teachers in an active literacy comprehension model. The modelprovides a framework for inclusion of all students while parents and families are trained to actively participatein their child?s development of background knowledge. Project goals and anticipated outcomes include: 1)Provide ongoing staff development to increase expertise of PreK-12 teachers in teaching comprehensionstrategies by building students? background knowledge through active, inquiry-based learning; 2) Work withpreschool children and their families on reading skills through the Thinking First Literacy Center to preparethem for a successful start in school; and 3) Increase student achievement of all students and reduce theachievement gap amongst economically disadvantaged, minority and limited English proficient students.Project Partners include Stephanie Harvey Consulting Group; UWM-Milwaukee Center for Urban Initiatives& Research, WAWM Recreation Dept. and West Allis Health Department."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: RISE PreK-12 Comprehensive Student Services Program
Project Description: "West Allis-West Milwaukee(WAWM) School District will deliver a high quality, replicable PreK-12Comprehensive Student Services Model that will assist districts across the nation in increasing academicsuccess and career readiness for all students. The RISE initiative enables full scale district-wideimplementation of a PreK-12 Comprehensive Student Services Delivery Model. The RISE acronymencompasses the four components of a comprehensive student services model which include ResponsiveServices; (I) Individual Planning; (S) System Support and (E) Educational Counseling Curricula. Building on athree-year program pilot, through an enhanced focus on Pre-Kindergarten children and at-risk youth, RISE willultimately provide a PreK-12 Comprehensive Student Services Model with training, curriculum and programdelivery tools. Project goals include: Responsive Services to address student?s immediate social-emotionallearning concerns; (I) Individual Planning with Academic, Personal/Social and Career Goals; (S) Systemsupport to implement a PreK-12 Comprehensive Student Services Program; and (E) Educational CounselingCurricula delivered to all students.Anticipated outcomes for 8,800 students in the district include include reduced behavioral referrals;increased social-emotional and academic readiness for Pre-Kindergarten children; reduced Achievement Gapamongst minority, economically disadvantaged, Limited English Proficient and at-risk youth; increasedacademic achievement and career readiness for all students; and publishing of a replicable model, curriculumand program delivery tools. Partners who provide services include WAWM Recreation Department;WAWM Health Department, Wisconsin Planning Council for Health & Human Services; University ofWisconsin-Milwaukee Center for Urban Initiatives & Research, WAWM Chamber of Commerce andMilwaukee Area Technical College ."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Applicant: West Contra Costa Unified School Distri
Project Title: The ET Hunnters:  A Virtual STEM Module for Elementary Students
WKEC Math Improvement Project
Project Description: "Project Description, Including Project Activities and Special Features:  The WKEC Math Im-provement Project will serve 50,433 students and encompasses four key activities: 1) In partnership with Texas Instruments, implementation of TI's MathForward? and Math Nspired? to incorporate technology to enhance instruction and motivate middle and high school students; 2) In partnership with ACT, utilization of the EPAS system at the 8th, 9th, 10th, and 11th grades to chart student progress, assess college readiness, and identify students with STEM related career preferences; 3) Mentoring for middle school math classrooms by college students majoring in STEM-related fields, as well a E-mentoring for high school math students; and 4) Continuous professional development for middle and high school math teachers from national experts on research-based best practices."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Multimedia Ed-Tech Centers (METC)
Project Description: "This innovative project,a collaborative project between (1) West Los Angeles College, (2) Heart and SoulDesign Communications, (3) the Youth Development Program of the Los Angeles Unified School District, and(4) the After School Education & Safety Program of the Inglewood Unified School District, addresses studentsuccess by overcoming current barriers such as the lack of access to technology-based educational and broadcultural resources and the inadequate instructional staff training and technical support for available technologies.The partnership will demonstrate how the integration of telecommunications and multimedia technologies inthe learning experience of students significantly contributes to their academic and social success.METC will explore new approaches to learning at 110 schools in the Los Angeles Unified School Districtand 21 schools in the Inglewood Unified School District (USD). It will pursue learning as a continuousprocess of educational enrichment that extends beyond the traditional school day.Students are surrounded by media all day----on television, phones, DVDs, computers, at movies, stores, evenplaces of worship-it is how the world communicates. Young people, particularly those from the extemelydiverse populations in Los Angeles County, need to be more than just consumers of information; they mustbecome critical evaluators of multimedia information and they must develop the skills needed to be contributorsto and developers of multimedia-formatted information. And they must communicate with peers around the city,state, nation, and world. To do this, they must apply the skills they are learning in school-English, reading,writing, critical reasoning/thinking, math, science, social studies-to creating multimedia applications.This process builds on and reinforces the in-class teaching and learning processes, strengthening knowledge, anddemonstrating to the students to applicability of classroom learning."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Applicant: West Valley Arts and Technology Academy dba Riverbend Preparatory Academy
Project Title: The Riverbend Leadership Initiative Partnership
Project Description: "The Riverbend Leadership Initiative Partnership currently represents a coalition of seven schools, including four urban ? core charter schools in metro Phoenix, Arizona (Ahwatukee Foothills Prep, Ahwatukee College Prep, Phoenix Advantage Charter School and Riverbend Academy) and three additional charter schools in Colorado Springs and Fort Collins, Colorado (Banning Lewis Ranch Academy, STAR Academy, and the T.R. Paul Academy of Arts & Knowledge). These seven schools have joined the Riverbend Leadership Initiative Partnership in an effort to improve student performance by providing more effective professional development and mentoring for their teachers and principals. To provide these services, the Riverbend Leadership Initiative Partnership will be supported by Mosaica Education, The Arizona Charter School Board and the University of Southern California. The overarching goal of the Riverbend Leadership Initiative Partnership program is to increase the number of highly effective principals schools.The focus of this program will be to equip school principals with the ability and insight to meet the of needs for effective High Performance High Poverty Schools, helping them to operate schools ?where students are ready to learn, teachers are ready to teach and leaders are ready to act? by guiding them in the nine key areas defined by Mass Insight: establishing effective safety, discipline and engagement, approaches for action against adversity, close student-adult relationships; shared responsibilities for achievement, personalization of instruction, a professional teaching culture; and authority, ingenuity and agility in leadership."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Transformative Assessments for Science
Project Description: "The shockingly low performance of US students on national and international science tests highlights the needfor a major transformation of science assessment to measure understanding of complex systems, model-basedreasoning, and inquiry practices. A new generation of technology-based assessments is revolutionizing thewhat, how, when and where of testing (Quellmalz & Pellegrino, 2009). With the Race to the Top Assessmentinitiatives focusing primarily on mathematics and literacy, the need for the transformation of scienceassessment is profound and urgent.WestEd proposes this development project to create transformative simulation-based science assessments toaddress Absolute Priority 3--High-Quality Assessments, and Competitive Preference Priority 7--Innovationsfor Students with Disabilities and Limited English Proficient Students. They will harness the power of sciencesimulations to make the invisible visible, test inquiry, offer accommodations, and provide formative andsummative assessments.Project goals are to develop and validate nine suites of simulation-based embedded formative and benchmarksummative science assessments of middle and secondary level standards. This development project will buildon evidence of technical quality, feasibility, and utility from three SimScientists projects funded by NSF andIES (www.simscientists.org). The project assessment design includes alignment with national sciencestandards, templates, simulation shells, and external quality reviews by AAAS. Data collection involvesstudent and teacher cognitive labs, pilot tests with 1500 students and field tests with 6000 students to documentthe technical quality, usability, and feasibility of the assessments. Partners include Washoe (NV), Tooele (UT),and Washington (UT) Country School Districts and the states of Nevada, Utah, and North Carolina."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Validation of the Effectiveness and Sustainability of An Innovative Early Mathematics Intervention for High-Need Students
Project Description: "The purpose of our application for a validation grant is to evaluate the effectiveness of a two-year mathintervention using research-based preschool (Pre-K Mathematics) and kindergarten components (EarlyLearning in Mathematics), when implemented on a regional scale under rigorous experimental conditions. Theproject goal is to determine whether, and to what extent, public schools can prepare high-need children forworld-class math standards by the end of K and close the SES-related gap in children?s early mathematicalknowledge. A 2 X 2 factorial design will be used to randomly assign 256 school to one of four conditions: (1)a two-year treatment condition, in which both the pre-K and K components of the math intervention areimplemented, (2) a one-year treatment condition, in which only the pre-K component of the intervention isimplemented, (3) a one-year treatment condition, in which only the K component of the intervention isimplemented, and (4) a two-year control condition, in which neither component of the math intervention isimplemented. We will use a hierarchical linear modeling framework to address research questions about theeffects of the pre-K component alone, the K component alone, and the effect of the two components whencombined. Student performance will be measured on proximal and distal measures of math achievement at pretestand post-test during both pre-k and kindergarten. Long-term student outcomes will also be assessed at theend of first grade. Classroom observations will be conducted on three occasions per year to determine ifvariables related to instructional effectiveness mediate student learning. In addition, variables associated withfidelity of implementation, student- and school-level characteristics hypothesized to moderate treatment impactwill be collected. WestEd and its official partners, University of Oregon, Westat, and a consortium of LEAsfrom California, Nevada, Oregon and Washington will serve 32,512 students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Scaling Up Content-Area Academic Literacy in High School English Language Arts, Science and History Classes for High Needs Students
Project Description: "Scaling Up Content-Area Academic Literacy in High School English Language Arts, Science and History Classes for High Needs Students addresses Absolute Priority 3 and Competitive Preference Priority 7. This validation project will expand the Reading Apprentice-ship (RA) model of academic literacy instruction that has been proven to transform subject-area instruction and increase adolescents? literacy engagement, academic identity and achievement with a Consortium of LEAs in four states: Indiana, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Utah.Key project activities include: 1) providing 60 hours of professional development to nine teachers (three English Language Arts, three biology and three U.S. history teachers) in each participating school; 2) selecting and developing RA leaders in each LEA; 3) creating a web portal to provide RA teachers and  leaders a media rich and highly interactive learning environment to reinforce face-to-face training experiences; 4) conducting a rigorous, random assignment evaluation to assess the project?s impact; and 5) documenting and disseminating information about the scale-up of the RA program, including the identification of barriers to as well enablers for successful implementation.The goals of the project are to: 1) transform academic literacy teaching and learning in high school subject areas so that students are able to achieve high standards and 2) build LEA capacity to disseminate, support, and sustain academic literacy improvement in high school subject areas. We expect that students at RA sites will have greater gains in reading comprehension as well as English language arts, history, and biology achievement compared to students at non-RA sites. Across the four states, we plan to work with approximately 300 schools, reaching 410,000 students.Official partner LEAs - Ogden City Schools, UT; Indianapolis Public Schools, IN; Livingston and Washtenaw County Intermediate School District, MI; Intermediate Unit 20, PA - serve div... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title:
Understanding Science: Improving the Science Achievement and Literacy Skills of Middle
School Students Through Proven Professional Development and Collaboration
Project Description: "?Understanding Science: Improving the Science Achievement and Literacy Skills of Middle School StudentsThrough Proven Professional Development and Collaboration? is a five-year validation project with afundamental goal of improving the science achievement and college/career preparation of more than 150,000students as they progress through middle school by strengthening the content knowledge, pedagogicalreasoning, and instructional practices of their grade 6th, 7th, and 8th grade teachers. This project builds localinfrastructure and expertise to support regional, rural, and districtwide use of WestEd?s Understanding Scienceprofessional development courses at eight sites across multiple states. These courses incorporate a model forteacher learning with a proven track record of strengthening teachers? content knowledge, transformingclassroom practices, and boosting student achievement in science ? especially for low-achieving students,English learners, and students with poor literacy skills. Understanding Science professional developmentsupports teachers? effective use and implementation of their existing standards-based curricula by focusing onthe intersection of knowledge about science, literacy, and teaching. The implementation model has two stages.The first stage provides direct support resulting in more than 240 trained facilitators (e.g., staff developers,university partners) who lead courses for more than 1800 middle school teachers. The second stage supportssustainability and horizontal scale-up, as regional networks extend their reach. This work will offer animportant contribution to the research base by studying the supports and obstacles related to scale-up, as wellas documenting key elements of the approach that may facilitate replication. A randomized controlled trial(RCT) will measure the impact of districtwide Understanding Science professional development with regard tostudent achievement and teacher competencies."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Real-time Longitudinal Data Driven Decisions=Teacher & Learner Success (RLD3=TLS)
Project Description: "Western Heights Public School District in Oklahoma City in a regional collaboration with its official district partners, Porter, Wister, Arkoma and Coweta in Oklahoma; Denton, Texas, and Fort Smith, Arkansas proposes an i3 development grant to help partnering districts develop innovative data systems similar to the nationally recognized Western Heights? data warehouse that includes near real-time and longitudinal data. The ultimate goal is to place meaningful data in the hands of all key stakeholders to improve teaching and learning, in particular with high needs students. The project proposes a quasi-experimental matched comparison design to demonstrate that when districts implement data systems with interoperability accompanied by intense professional development improved teaching and learning occur. Summary of Goals: to research the impact of near-real-time and longitudinal data systems on teaching and learning, create an understanding about data use and its application for teaching and learning, reduce gaps in achievement, build communities of practice on data use, and develop a tool for interpreting standards across districts and states. Outcomes are greater gains in student achievement than in comparable districts without innovative data systems, all partners have data systems with interoperability and systems that have in place the 10 elements identified by the Data Quality Campaign, reduction in achievement gaps among subpopulations, enhanced understanding about data use and its application; Impact Approximately 100,000 students will be served over five years. Special features-true enterprise-based data system with effective rules for data management, which also provides for the creation, storage, and use of data from multiple disparate sources -Other partners: Technical/Career Centers, United Way of Oklahoma, and Oklahoma Education Association (teacher?s union)."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education
Project Title: Western Scholars
Project Description: "The Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education (WICHE), a nonprofit organization, and a consortium of schools including Wagner Community School and Sturgis Brown High School in South Dakota, Hillcrest High School in Utah, and others yet to be identified, propose a continuation and expansion of the pre-existing federally-funded State Scholars Initiative (SSI) through Western Scholars. Funded through a validation grant, Western Scholars will serve 2,800 high-need students, within a cohort model from 9th grade through their first year of college. Twenty high schools will participate, from Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, South Dakota, and Utah. Western Scholars will build upon research developed through SSI. In conjunction with strategies incubated by Colorado GEAR UP, Western Scholars will increase the number of high-need students who: 1) complete academically rigorous coursework; 2) enroll in dual-enrollment courses, remedial courses, and credit-based testing options; 3) graduate from high school; 4) complete a college portfolio, enroll in college and succeed in their freshman year, and move on to the sophomore year; and 5) use Gallup's strengths assessments to understand how their talents align with potential majors and careers. Fifty-two jobs will be created in the participating schools and supporting organizations."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Improving Principals
Project Description: "Western Michigan University and its partners propose to provide training on Improving Principals? Data-Informed Decision-Making on High-Impact Strategies to Enhance Student Achievement for 60 principals fromeligible, high-need Michigan schools. The project focuses on the nexus of three streams of literature?(a) datainformeddecision-making, (b) the role of principalship, and (c) high-impact strategies for raising studentachievement?and emphasizes how principals can use data to make decisions on school factors associated withstudent achievement. This application is submitted under the category of ?Development? and addressesAbsolute Priority 2.The proposed program is research-based, job-embedded, and results-oriented. Marzano (2003) identified 11school factors that are empirically associated with higher student achievement, such as (a) guaranteed andviable curriculum and (b) challenging goals and effective feedback. The training is centered on how to use datato make informed decisions along these important factors to improve student achievement. Eleven modulesbased on each of those 11 factors will serve as the basis for an intensive 30-month program. For each module,each participant will attend two days of face-to-face learning activities, receive two days of mentoring, andwork with the school?s stakeholders and the mentor to plan and implement at least one renewal activity.Participants will also engage in learning community activities that focus on how principals can use data tomake data-informed decisions on high-impact strategies. With the sufficient level of quality, intensity andduration, the proposed project will have a significant impact on principals, teachers, schools, and studentachievement.The project will conduct both traditional evaluation activities and an experimental design. The expectedoutcomes include enhanced data-informed decision-making by principals and improved student achievement."

Project Title:
Learning-Centered Leadership Development Program for Rural Practicing and Aspiring
Principals
Project Description: "Western Michigan University (WMU) and 21 eligible, high-need, rural school districts in Michigan propose toconduct the Learning-Centered Leadership Development Program for 60 practicing and 60 aspiring principals,with each pair of practicing and aspiring principals recruited from the same school to facilitate the projectimplementation activities. The proposed project focuses on those important leadership dimensions that areempirically associated with higher student achievement. Submitted under the category of Development, thisproject not only identifies, recruits, and develops highly effective principals, but also implements a system ofmeasuring principal leadership that has implications for rewarding, retaining, and placing highly effectiveprincipals.The proposed project is research-based, job-embedded, and results-oriented. Based on empirical research on therelationship between principal leadership and student achievement?by Waters, Marzano, and McNulty (2005)and more than 20 other high-quality empirical studies?the proposed project focuses on seven dimensions ofprincipals? work that are empirically associated with higher student achievement: (a) inspirational agency forschool renewal, (b) orderly school operation, (c) high, cohesive, and culturally relevant expectations forstudents, (d) coherent curricular programs, (e) distributive and empowering leadership, (f) real-time andembedded instructional assessment, and (g) data-informed decision-making. Seven modules, based on each ofthe seven dimensions, will constitute an intensive 30-month program. With the sufficient level of quality,intensity and duration, this project will have a significant impact on principals, teachers, schools, and studentachievement. The proposed project will conduct both traditional evaluation activities and an experimentaldesign."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Once and For All: Transforming Mathematics and Science Learning K-16
Project Description: "Once and For All unites six school systems urban, suburban, and rural districts, Western Washington University, Seattle Pacific University, the Math Education Collaborative, and the Washington STEM Center around the shared goal of transforming the professional preparation and support of current and future math and science teachers to ensure that every student achieves at high levels and is ready for college and work. It works on all the high leverage parts of the educational system at the same time in one coherent program to transform the system of teacher professional preparation, support, development, leadership, and accountability by engaging all forces that determine student achievement in math and science. This broad public/private partnership will provide, evaluate, and continuously improve a proven, coherent set of learning experiences by supporting incorporation of new ideas into classroom and administrative practice K-16. We will validate multiple documented successes through a three-pronged strategy, replicating proven work in new settings, scaling from a few to all math and science teachers in buildings, and adding new partners in years 3-5. Our objectives are to increase achievement for all students, especially high-needs students, through enhanced content knowledge and skills for teaching math and science, reformed structures of learning experiences in math and science, enhanced administrator knowledge and skills in evaluating and supporting effective math and science instruction, and increased community demand and support for high quality math and science instruction K-16. The expected outcomes are schools and universities where math and science are taught effectively to each student every day, and teacher preparation programs (including math and science university departments partnered with K-12 schools) which recruit, prepare and support the next generation of teachers to ensure all students achieve at high levels and are college and work ready."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: WIILC provides cost-effective customizable professional development and family education to improve, encourage and facilitate evaluation, analysis, and use of student growth data to improve student achievement, school and LEA performance and productivity.
Project Description: "WIILC will provide cost-effective customizable professional development and family education (PD/FE) toimprove the use of data to increase student growth for high-need students in our partner areas. WIILCaddresses Absolutely Priority 2 to improve the use of data, and will (a) encourage and facilitate the evaluation,analysis, and use of student growth data by educators and families in order to inform decision-making andimprove student achievement, student growth, and school and LEA performance and productivity; and (b)enable data aggregation, analysis, and research. Data will be disaggregated by ESEA-designated studentsubgroups. We have intentionally chosen a diverse group of high-need LEAs, in terms of locations in the U.S.,student demographics, and urban/suburban and rural to test the design of the WIILC to ensure it can bringcritical services to the widest group of participants serving and supporting high-need students."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Design21 - Developing 21st Century Skills in Weymouth, Massachusetts
Project Description: "The Weymouth Public School Department (WPS) is pleased to submit this proposal as a Development Project for funding under the Investing in Innovation competitive grant program (i3).  Design 21 - Developing 21st Century Skills (D21) represents a focused, innovative, instructional approach to preparing students for high school graduation and their future success. Our vision is a redesigned model of school where the focus will be on the development of core 21st century process skills, expressed through the creation of written and oral products.  Our hypothesis is:  Students who participate in high-quality, on-going learning experiences designed around defined 21st century process skills will achieve measurable success in school by graduating high school prepared to succeed in postsecondary endeavors. Our project builds on the current WHS21 model at Weymouth High School, a model we believe has the potential for efficacy when replicated in additional settings.  Our challenge is to replicate and expand the model to existing schools K-12 in Weymouth and Southeastern Massachusetts. The D21 model will be introduced across all schools in Weymouth during the first year, with a focus on communication and education at all sites.  Project implementation will continue at the district middle schools (two) during years 2 and 3; and at district primary schools (eight) during years 3 and 4.  The fifth and final project year will be devoted to dissemination outside the district, creating a Coalition for P21 schools on the South Shore in Massachusetts. At the conclusion of the five-year project, we will have developed a fully scalable model for implementation across district lines."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Rigor, Relevence and Relationships: Assessment FOR Learning (A4L)
Project Description: "WUHSD's Assessment FOR Learning (A4L) is a collaborative cycle of inquiry using formative assessment to increase students' mastery of California standards while supporting college access/success and addressing the unique needs of LEP students. Two beliefs underlie A4L. (1) All teachers can teach to high standards, given the right conditions and assistance. (2) All students can learn high standards, given the requisite time and support; therefore, high expectations and early intervention are essential. This requires feedback and supports to get students 'back on track' relative to standards, course completion, and college preparedness. Training addresses content, pedagogy, and technological tools. Teacher Leads develop high functioning course-alike teams that collaboratively create common assessments; analyze student performance data; and plan instructional improvements. Leads are provided continual training team-building skills and are supported by other Leads with expertise in specialized programs or technologies, creating a strong base of distributed leadership.."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Whatever it Takes: Using Data to Connect All Students to Systems of Support
Project Description: "WUHSD's Whatever it Takes improves the use of data, supports college access/success, and addresses unique needs of LEP students. Through a phased implementation based on data, continual training assists schools in the development of support systems that help high-need students overcome barriers. Phase I addresses the conditions for change by developing data skills and exploring philosophies of student learning. Phase II applies the new knowledge and attitudes to ninth grade interventions with the addition of on-site teacher Lead positions. Finally, Phase III connects all students to systems of support, expanding the focus with the corresponding growth in capacity. Given that all students can learn with the requisite time and support, a tight-but-loose framework allows schools the needed flexibility to respond to local conditions while maintaining fidelity to the guiding principles: (1) Intervention rather than remediation; (2) Intervention that is systematic; (3) Intervention that is provided in a timely manner; (4) Intervention that is directed rather than invited; and (5) Prevention is the best intervention."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The iCAN Project
Project Description: "Wichita State University (WSU) in partnership with West High School (USD 259) and Apple Inc. seeksfunding through the Investing in Education Grant Opportunity to establish an iPad and Computer AssistedEducational Neighborhood (iCAN) program.The project seeks a Validation Grant to validate the impact of one-to-one computer assisted learning/teachingto turn around a low-performing school, and to increase academic development, high school retention,graduation, and post-secondary education for all students including students with disabilities.The iCAN project seeks to purchase and provide iPads with WiFi to all students (1200) and allteachers/instructors (100) of West High to integrate technology into classrooms. The project activities includetechnology based professional training and development of the teachers/instructors, curriculum design andreviews, iPad based instruction and academic activities, residential summer enrichment programs for studentswith disabilities and with special education, and a quasi-experimental evaluation study of the project.The project seeks to enable West High make the Annual Yearly Progress (AYP) by achieving State assessmentstandards in key areas of Math and Reading, and increase its student retention, graduation, and post-secondaryenrollment, especially for students with disabilities, and special education.The project seeks to serve about 1,200 students each year as a cohort. One of the group of students will beprovided services through five years as a cohort. The project is unique in trying to adapt state-of-the artinformation technology device while providing for future development and integration as a key element oftechnology based education."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Books Alive: Reading and Writing through Dramatic Art
Project Description: "Wild Swan Theater (WST), a professional theater for families, is partnering with the Ann Arbor Public Schools to bring its award-winning literacy program to the early elementary curriculum for Title 1 schools in Washtenaw County, MI. WST piloted Books Alive (BAP) through Head Start with over a dozen Detroit area schools and libraries in 2001-2002, and is seeking to develop the program locally with underperforming schools where achievement gap issues have been persistent. BAP is designed to inspire a lifelong love of reading and writing. Drama workshops for children enable them to bring 'books alive' and learn about the basic components of a story. This kinesthetic and abstract learning is reinforced with classroom activities and live performances by Wild Swan artists. BAP also trains teachers how to use drama as an ongoing part of their curriculum. Independent evaluation  (see Appendix H) has shown the early model of the Books Alive program to be highly effective in introducing and reinforcing literacy skills. The new program will be residency-based in three core schools in Ann Arbor where WST will train teachers, perform stories, and lead workshops where children will create their own dramatic works.  Through the BAP, youth will improve skills in literacy, story creation, cause-effect awareness, creativity and imagination; improve reading proficiency; increase quality and quantity of writing; increase involvement with and attractiveness of literature.  Teachers will increase kinesthetic activities; increase experimentation with drama and student participation; increase effective teaching of reading and writing.  In a 3-year period, Wild Swan will develop a core team of skilled teachers in each school who are then able to train subsequent faculty in Books Alive methods.  BAP addresses needs of high-risk students; uses innovative methods with good initial results and its lead project team has decades of experience with literacy skills development."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Leveling the Playing Field
Project Description: "The Wilkes County Schools (WCS) strives to provide opportunities for our students which will encourage and motivate them to become life-long learners as well as successful and productive citizens in our community.  Most of our students are digital natives, coming into our schools having spent hours immersed in the digital world of television, computers, video games, cell phones, and the Internet.  We must supply learning opportunities attuned to their learning styles.  We also understand the socio-economic divide among our students.  We must bridge the gap, providing all students with the access to resources and knowledge that will be vital to their success in a global society. This project is part of our technology plan consisting of 1:1 laptop initiative at our five high schools and four middle schools.  We believe our student motivation, academics, and overall desire to learn will be positively impacted by these initiatives.  We also believe we will attract and retain the best and brightest educators in our school system by providing the educational tools, resources, and professional development essential to create dynamic, technology-rich classrooms."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Wilkinson County i3 Great Beginnings
Project Description: "Wilkinson County [WC] proposes a development grant, i3 Great Beginnings, to build on information garneredfrom the interrupted time series design of Great Beginnings [GB], an Early Reading First grant. i3GB?s projectdesign is grounded in scientifically based reading research as defined by Section 1208 of ESEA. We propose to implement a forward design and expand GBs proven strategies up to Grade 5 by: using data to support a stardards-based instructional program; providing additional instructional support for Tier 2 & 3 students based valid and reliable assessment measures; leadership training for administrators in data driven reform; and providing technical support to Wilkinson County's private PreK providers in standards-based instruction using data during scare up. I3 Great Beginnings will serve 1056 high needs students in 44 classrooms.Professional development lies at the heart of effective education reform, particularly when it is firmly rooted in research. The i3GB professional development model will focus in four areas: training administrative leadership (principlas, direcgtors) in beocming data driven; training staff in the how's and why's of data driven instruction and SBRR strategies; training literacy coaches in coaching strategies for adult learners; and training parents to be their child's first teacher.At the end of the grant cycle all staff will increase their knowledge base of SBRR content and be proficient indata driven instruction. It is anticipated that by providing added supports for K-5 will further close theachievement gap. WC is committed to demonstrating that the i3GB grant strategies will improve studentachievement for high needs students and will address the short- and long term performance measures designedby the i3 notice.Wilkinson County Board of Education is the lead applicant."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The Algebraic Thinking Project
Project Description: "The Algebraic Thinking Project (ATP) DEVELOPMENT Grant will use the successful Cognitively GuidedInstruction model to develop a comprehensive professional development program for teachers that emphasizesresearch on students? algebraic thinking, new technologies for instruction, and teacher learning communities.Our primary OBJECTIVES are to increase high needs students? achievement on the Oregon state mathassessment and decrease failure in Algebra courses, particularly in rural schools and with LEP students. Basedon over 600 research studies describing students? struggles in algebra, ATP will establish a Center forAlgebraic Thinking: a hub for professional development, an online encyclopedia of research on algebraicthinking, a catalog of formative assessment problems, and a matrix of technological tools that enhanceconceptual development in the algebraic cognitive domains of the state standards. Initiated by a summerinstitute and followed with monthly meetings in professional learning communities, teachers will work in webbasedteams of two pairs to use their understanding of students? algebraic thinking to assess and meet students?needs. Lastly, new technologies, such as virtual manipulatives on handheld devices, will be powerful tools fordeveloping students? comprehension of algebra. Using a reiterative process of design, implementation, andrefinement, we will pilot our project with 24 teachers and then with 96 teachers to develop this research basedapproach, ultimately impacting approximately 15,000 students across Oregon."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: William Floyd Union Free School District
Project Title: The William Floyd School District will turn around our persistently low-performing high school by enhancing Alternative Learning through 21st Century Technology to Increase Student Engagement and Achievement.
Reform and Innovation for college Excellence - the RICE Initiative
Project Description: "Rice University is pleased to submit this i3 validation grant proposal to the U.S. Department of Education. TheReform and Innovation for College Excellence (RICE) Initiative is designed to improve the quality of, andincrease access to, the Advanced Placement (AP) Program for the 198,168 secondary students enrolled in thefollowing 14 public school districts in the greater Houston area: Alief, Alvin, Clear Creek, Danbury, Deer Park,Fort Bend, Friendswood, Humble, Klein, Lamar, LaPorte, New Caney, Pasadena and Spring Branch. The districtconsortium educates 9% of all 11th and 12th grade students in the state of Texas and employs approximately5,200 secondary teachers. Other grant partners include the College Board, a contractual partner, and theUniversity of Houston, independent evaluators.The consortium is committed to helping underrepresented students prepare to succeed in academically rigorouscourses. The RICE Initiative represents a three-pronged approach that will engage educators - including teachers,administrators and counselors, parents and students in navigating the path toward postsecondary success. Theinitiative seeks to empower teachers to take ownership of their student?s readiness to succeed in rigorouscoursework via their participation in sustained, results-driven, high quality professional development that willhold members of teams accountable for success.We will achieve our goals by 1) maximizing the use of formative assessments to appraise and monitor student?sprogress towards meeting Texas college readiness standards, and 2) interpreting the data to guide the design andexecution of high quality, sustained, results-driven, team-focused, AP/Pre-AP professional development whichwill impact classroom practices and ensure that all students, especially high-need students, are prepared forcollege success. The initiative will help close achievement and equity gaps and ensure all students are graduatingfrom high school prepared for acade"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Project ASPIRE
Project Description: "The purpose of Project ASPIRE is to develop 450 teachers who are able to tailor instruction and assessment for ELLs/high-need students. These teachers will serve approximately 57,600 students during the grant period. Objectives include developing materials, delivering training, and analyzing implementation study data (for Goal 1); developing an Advisory Committee, hiring coaches, and development a national dissemination plan (Goal 2); and examining the impact of the data-driven PD model on teacher and student outcomes. During both 2.5 year cycles (a pilot with 2 schools and a later refined implementation with 6 additional schools), teachers and principals from a total of 10 schools will study the 5 levels of English language proficiency defined by the national PreK-12 English Language Proficiency Standards. They will then implement strategies designed to teach and assess students at each level. Data collected during the Project Model's continuous cycle of improvement will inform the PD and impact teacher practice. Expected outcomes are that data-based differentiation will facilitate increased student achievement and will help to close the achievement gap. "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Stepping It Up-Innovations in Transforming Low Performing Schools by providing innovative approaches in education.
Building Student Success from the Ground Up
Project Description: "'Building Student Success from the Ground Up'(BSSGU) is a program designed to implement an effective means of identifying and supporting students at high risk of failing to meet State proficiency standards in core content subject matter. Through interventions at key transitional periods in a student's educational life, the infrastructure provided by our partner, the Southern Regional Education Board, has been proven to improve student performance on internal and State mandated evaluative measures.Additionally, BSSGU will provide the Willingboro Public School District with the training, equipment and resources needed to provide students with a comprehensive STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics) Program to prepare them for real-world experience in technology-based fields."

Project Title: SOUTHEASTERN  CONSORTIUM OF US ONLINE COMMONE CORE CONTENT
Project Description: "Wilson County DOE in Lebanon, Tennessee, FL, NC, SC, LA, KY, TN, GA and Gwinnette County in GA, along with Apple, AT&T, ETLO, and Randa Solutions will conduct an i3 project that is a multistate consortium of online curriculum comprising STEM, college preparatory, common core curriculum aligned standards in a metatagged repository that is accessible and searchable by standard. Each participating state will be trained by a nationally recognized online professional development training program for online teachers. e4TN and Florida Virtual School will provide online curriculum. The central focus of the project is to provide effective teachers to students in online environments. Tennessee leads the nation in the Value-Added Model. The OC3 proposal offers a plan for Tennessee to coordinate an effort to build a model and measure teacher effectiveness in the online medium developing sustainability for the online learning instructional model in partner states while expanding existing capacity and building scalability through embedding field experts, curriculum, and a consortium of experienced expert state leaders in a project that will change the face of online education.OC3 willo	Build math, science, Spanish and ACT prep courses aligned to Common Core standards and accessible to multiple states.o	Increase the number of HQ teachers by allowing under-qualified teachers, or those adding a certification, access to these online courses to strengthen knowledge in content and good pedagogy.o	Increase the number of highly-effective teachers through professional development for online teachers.o	Provide online courses for up to 52,000 underserved, rural, and other students in math, science, foreign language and ACT Prep.o	Create a quasi-experimental study resulting in a model for teacher effectiveness based on student performance.o	Form a multi-state consortium to allow collaboration from strengths and experience of each contributor resulting in increased student achievement... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Windham Regional Collegiate High School
Project Description: The mission of the WRCHS project is to offer qualified juniors and seniors in Vermont affordable access to college level courses and the opportunity to earn college credits while in high school. We also plan to create a model which can replicated in other states.
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: WINGS for kids, Inc.
Project Description: "WINGS for kids, Inc. is an elementary education program that teaches students social and emotional skills so thatthey behave well, make good decisions, and build healthy relationships. Our carefully constructed 15-hour-aweekcurriculum instills 30 learning objectives into everyday activities that develop self-awareness,relationship skills, social awareness, self-management, and responsible decision-making. WINGS studentsdemonstrate better behavior, higher school attachment, and improved academic outcomes when compared tosimilar non-WINGS students. Over the course of the i3 grant, WINGS will expand into 6 new schools serving2,660 students and participate in formative and summative research studies by outside evaluators to prove thefollowing hypothesis of the WINGS program: Students will demonstrate improved social and emotionallearning (SEL) skills and increased school engagement and attachment by attending a sequenced, active,focused, and explicit research based after school program. Those students who exhibit increased SEL skillsand school engagement and attachment will demonstrate higher student achievement and lower drop out rates.Objectives:?
