Students will develop high social and emotional skills; measured by 90% being able to recite the WINGSCreed, 80% pass weekly SEL skills tests.? Students will demonstrate high attachment to school and increased student achievement; measured by 95%with average or higher attendance, 100% promotion to the next grade, 90% with C grades or higher, 90% withincreases of 8 points or more in standardized test scores.? Students will utilize social and emotional skills in everyday life; measured by 85% positive rating on socialdevelopment grades from report cards, less than two office disciplinary referrals per student.? Students will graduate from high school, stay out of jail, and avoid teenage parenthood; measured by higherhigh school graduation rates, lower delinquency and teenage parenthood rates."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: C.A.T.
Project Description: "   The goal of the C.A.T. Program is to provide the tools and skills that participants need to build a successful future through career preparation, guidance and support for pursuing and completing a college degree. Early childhood and school age programs will be provided with the basic information of the many career opportunities available, and to prepare students for individual career paths. The program activities that we will be supplying are dual enrollment classes for current high school students, Adult GED classes, alternative school, ACT prep classes and ACT testing. Activities will also include the use of technology, by using our bespoken computer system, to include the merging of the Moodle. College classes will be offered locally by our partner Mineral Area College and by our Interactive internet training courses. The C.A.T. program will assist students already perusing a particular career, evaluate their current status and develop long-term plans for their ongoing career development. Transportation will be provided to and from classes, after school and work hours. The C.A.T. program will also provide a safe and structured environment for child care while participants are involved in the academic classes/activities and assistance for high school parents as well as community members will be provided."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: CareerStart: A Regional Validation Strategy to Promote Middle Grades School Success
Project Description: "CareerStart is a principal leadership and teaching program that increases the career relevance of lessons within the core curriculum in the middle grades. In this proposal we intend to take a school-wide intervention that has shown interval validity in an experimental pilot in one school district and build the capacity of that intervention for scaling up and complete a large two state evaluation in order to demonstrate external validity. This proposed project will include LEAs in both North Carolina and Maryland, and will train 120 principals in leadership skills around CRI, train 4,000 teachers in strategies to deliver CRI lessons, who will ultimately teach 35,000 students. However, training school professionals and serving students while important for the evaluation of this proposed project, is not the final goal. The ultimate goal over the five year project is to fully manualize the principal and teacher training materials, build an extensive library of lessons infused with career content across all four core subjects, align those lessons to the coming common core curriculum, and make those training materials and lessons available to any LEA by posting them on an open access CareerStart web portal. The CareerStart strategy has a number of characteristics that make it a very effective, easily implemented and scalable intervention. First, CareerStart puts no extra burden on teachers, as it does not require that teachers change their teaching style, teachers simply use the CareerStart lessons and learn to infuse career information into what and how they are already teaching. Second, CareerStart is an intervention that works for all students, including high needs students at risk for poor school outcomes. Third, the project has an experienced team including the original developers of CareerStart Drs. Dennis Orthner and Don Martin at the Winston-Salem/Forsyth County Schools; LearnNC who has been posting the CareerStart lessons on the web; the University of Maryland Ba... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project ICE
Project Description: "Project ICE (Improving Climate through Empowerment) intends to prove that professional learning communities(PLCs), which include a student voice, are an effective vehicle to generate a collaborative response to schoolclimate issues. As school climates improve, so will student achievement. This developmental i3 project isaligned with Absolute Priority 4 (Innovations that Turn Around Persistently Low Performing Schools).The thirteen targeted schools involved in Project ICE will receive intensive professional development instimulating organizational change and creating a positive school climate that fosters student achievement.Targeted schools will each use a PLC, also known as a climate team, to analyze school-wide climate data todevelop a comprehensive school safety plan. The teams will be led by a trained facilitator. Schools will alsoimplement the Safe School Ambassador program to engage students in reducing bullying and mistreatment.Effective implementation will lead to shared leadership, increased collaboration among stakeholders, andincreased efficacy of administrators, teacher leaders, climate facilitators, and students. Project ICE sites willexhibit improvements in school climate indicated by reductions in bullying, increased reporting of bullying bystudents and adults, and reductions in put downs, harassment, and gang activity. Students and staff will reportgreater confidence in their ability to successfully intervene and address inappropriate situations. Theseintermediate outcomes will lead to measurable increases in student achievement. Over the 3-year period, over7,000 students in ten elementary schools and three middle schools will be impacted by Project ICE.Winston-Salem/Forsyth County Schools (WS/FCS) will create a community of learners, including Peter Senge?sSociety for Organizational Learning, Community Matters, Wage Peace Today, and the Alliance for the Studyof School Climate to effectively implement the strategies."

Project Title: Innovative Practices Academy at Winton Woods City School District
Project Description: "The Winton Woods City School District seeks to develop an Innovative Practices Academy (IP Academy) - an instructional team that will improve learning for all students in the district, and specifically address the district's three main challenge areas: academic gap in performance in students with disabilities (SWD), limited English proficient (LEP) students and those of economically disadvantaged background. The purpose of the collaborative i3 grant project is to build systemic instructional capacity of teaching staff in Winton Woods District and increase the achievement level of all students, and specifically those students who have not met Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP). The Innovative Practices Academy will consist of five educators working with the current curriculum leader.  This team will function as a professional research and practice team, that will, over a course of two years, develop innovative content delivery techniques and instructional strategies that can be aligned to the mandated curricular requirements. The IP Academy members will work as a professional team whose purpose will be to identify specific obstacles in learning for all students in the district and especially focusing on SWD, LEP students and students of disadvantaged economic background.  The members of the Academy will research, test, implement and help evaluate those instructional strategies, programs, best practices, that have the highest potential to support and improve the overall learning environment in the district and eliminate the gap in academic achievement.  This IP Academy team will participate in site-based research and practice in collaboration with classroom teachers to find potential solutions that will improve both teaching practices and learning outcomes."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: The WISACH Project
The Triad Project
Project Description: "The Triad Project consists of five schools, in California, New York, Maryland, and Florida that are dissimilar, except they are located near Northrop Grumman offices and have NG employees working with them. Each school has some STEM focus, each has equal opportunity for students to self-select the program, and each has some level of PBL in their curriculum. The only difference between the students in the study and their larger school group is their desire to be in the STEM academy (self-choice). No decisions of inclusion were based on gender, race, national origin, color, or disability.  Age is a definition of the student?s grade.  Additionally, the schools do not impede access to the program based on past courses or grades in junior high or middle school (although students must not have D or F grades in HS). California, New York, and Maryland schools have a high percentage of students from underserved populations.Working with the Project Director, NG will jumpstart a program with analysts and planners to interview and determine what needs to happen to ensure that all schools have roughly the same beginning point. The product of this assessment will be a Long-term Strategy Plan for each STEM academy with the first three years fleshed out. Based on the results of the NG jumpstart assessment that will take place in Fall of 2010, the first stage of the Triad Project will be initiated in Spring of 2011. Each school will have deeply involved industry professionals working with them throughout the Fall semester to align the Spring projects with STEM objectives. Depending on the school?s current curriculum, college courses will begin in the Spring if they are not already in place.  Our first assessment measure will assess the impact of the Triad Project on the students in the area of career and work readiness.  The CWRA will be implemented with the entire school population?performed during the freshmen year and the senior year.  By testing the whole school of which th... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Innovation in Digital Media: Achieving High Standards in Global History and Geography
Project Description: "WNET.ORG proposes to apply for a three-year I3 development grant entitled Innovation in Digital Media: Achieving High Standards in Global History and Geography. Partnering with 5 Local Educational Agencies in New York State, WNET will address Absolute Priority 3, Innovations that Complement the Implementation of High Standards and High-Quality Assessments, and intends to improve lagging student achievement in high school Global History and Geography courses by developing digital media resources for educators who serve high need students. WNET will also create a model of professional development ensuring effective use of the digital resources in classrooms. A scientifically-based evaluation will assess the impact of the curriculum and professional development intervention on student achievement as measured by the standards and assessments associated with those curricula. Private sector partnerships have committed a variety of innovative technological resources that will complement the implementation and impact of WNET's initiative."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments

Project Title: Montana Family & School Partnership
Project Description: "The Montana Family & School Partnership will partner with 20-25 low-performing rural schools that serve ~8,000 students from preschool through grade twelve, with the goal of effecting targeted reform that will lead to increased student achievement.  The project will provide services to some of Montana's most challenged schools through a comprehensive approach that incorporates two tested interventions: 1) Solid Foundation, a program that engages parents and community members with school personnel in a process of assessing and strengthening their schools partnership model; and 2) The Parent Teacher Home Visit Project, through which schools build important family connections through strategic home visits.  In addition, the project will provide ongoing technical assistance, training, and support to partnering schools throughout the planning, implementation, and operational stages. This project meets absolute priority 4 by providing strategies and programs designed to turnaround persistently low performing schools though strengthening non-academic student supports that have been shown to increase academic gains.  It meets competitive preference priority 5 by addressing pre-school to kindergarten as a critical transition year for home visits and including the involvement of K-3 teacher and staff in critical interventions. It meets competitive priority 8 by specifically targeting schools in rural LEA's that serve high-need students including 25-50% American Indian students, with some schools well over 50%.The design of this project comes out of what has proven to be highly adaptable and effective strategies to engage parents in Montana's most isolated and poorly performing schools.  The evaluator for this project is Education Northwest which has extensive experience in the area of evaluation of family/school/community partnerships and effective educational interventions.  "
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: The Development, Implementation, Scaling, Sustainability, and Evaluation of an Enhanced Dual Enrollment System
Project Description: "The proposed Enhanced Dual Enrollment System (EDES) builds upon the deep knowledge of two lead organizations, the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation and the Middle College National Consortium, both of whom have extensive experience in the development of early college high schools and supporting organizations that specialize in crucial components of the model. Early Colleges (ECs) are small high schools that serve traditionally underserved students and provide the opportunity for them to graduate from high school with an associates degree or 1-2 years of transferable college credit. The main reasons why these schools are successful are because they 1) help students prepare for college-level coursework, 2) provide dual enrollment courses (for which students earn both high school and college credit) and 3) support students in the hard work of preparing for, and doing, college-level work. This means that the schools must provide not only exemplary academics and instruction, but the appropriate feedback for students and staff to understand student progress in relation to postsecondary standards; non-academic supports (such as emotional and behavioral); and the key cognitive strategies necessary for college success. One limitation of ECs is that they are difficult to scale; the model requires small schools that, in this economic climate, are expensive to replicate. Therefore, for this project, we will apply the knowledge gained in creating and developing ECs to a much broader range of high schools by replicating the core components?the components of the work that make the most difference on students? educational trajectories?in other types of secondary schools. This will allow for a greater reach and, ultimately, this work will provide opportunities for larger numbers and percentages of underserved students enroll and succeed in postsecondary education."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Teaching and Learning Lab Model School of Education
Project Description: "The Teaching and Learning Lab will be a model education school that will prepare ourstanding teachers and administrators for New York City schools.  It will be embedded in two public schools--Generation Schools in Brooklyn, and Quest to Learn--and connected to a university--Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.  The Woodrow Wilson State Teaching Fellowship, now in Indiana, Ohio, and Michigan, requires participating universities in those states to make significant changes to their education schools.  In order to be eligible to receive Fellows, the education schools must make changes based on Woodrow Wilson standards.  A consistent issue has been that the universities have not had a model to look to that illustrates and demonstrates the changes they must make.  The Teaching and Learning Lab will serve as that model.  Its development will flow from the findings of Arthur Levine's six-year study of education schools.  It will be evaluated based on its graduates' impact on student achievement.  As the Teaching Fellowship expands to additional states, the Lab will serve as a model for improving education schools beyond Indiana, Ohio, and Michigan."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Expansion of Indiana Teaching Fellowship to Special Education
Project Description: "The Woodrow Wilson Teaching Fellowship is operating in the state of Indiana at four universities, including Ball State and the University of Indianapolis.  The program recruits, prepares, and retains outstanding STEM high school teachers for the state.  In addition, participting universities are required to make significant changes to their STEM teacher education programs.  These changes include establishing close collaboration between the college of arts and sciences and the eduaction school, and designing and evaluating the new program such that achievement of the students taught by graduates is the key component.  This proposal seeks support to expand the Fellowship at these two universitities to include special education.  Teachers would be prepared for and placed in the Indianapolis, Muncie, Anderson, and Wayne school districts, all of which are high need and suffer from shortages of special eduacation teachers."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Investing in Innovations Grant
Project Description: "Woodward Schools will increase access, equity, & performance in Advanced Placement (AP) through o	SpringBoard, the official Pre-AP curriculum, including sustained professional development, student & teacher editions, & online learning options. This English & math curriculum will enable rigorous instruction that will pipeline students into more AP courseso	Building greater access & success in AP English Language, AP English Literature, AP Calculus AB, AP Biology, AP Spanish Language, & AP U.S. History through professional development & SpringBoard. Customized teacher professional development for three consecutive summer institutes will teach best practices & form vertical teams to enable consistent, efficient yet rigorous curriculum for each of the 6 focused AP courseso	A system of online AP courseso	Targeting English Language Learnerso	Becoming a lighthouse for similar rural Oklahoma LEAso	Expanding the rural LEA partnership with the OKDoE & College Board to manage the growth plan"
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Developing a Model of School Improvement around ASSISTments
Project Description: "Abstract for ?Developing a Model of School Improvement around ASSISTments?Type: Development GrantPI: Neil HeffernanCo-PIs: Ken Koedinger (CMU), Matt Militello (NC State), Louis Gomez (UPittsburgh), Cris Heffernan (WPI), Nina Arshavsky (SERVE Center), and John Pane (RAND)School Partners: 21 school districts in MassachusettsPrivate Partners: WPI itself will provide ASSISTments as a cost share as well as IBM, Intel and EMCSecretary Arne Duncan has called for teachers and schools to use data to drive instruction and drastically raise student achievement, but also pointed out that teachers are not taught how to do this. We propose to develop a training model grounded in Professional Learning Communities to help teachers use an intelligent tutoring system called ASSISTments in order to drive reform and improve student learning. The funding has been successful as ASSISTments has proven to be a valuable tool to enhance teaching. Currently ASSISTments is in schools that receive direct support from the PI and his staff. Can this invention be given to schools where the creators are not doing one-on-one training of teachers? We think we first need to develop a model for how to train schools.We propose that to develop this model we will iteratively deigns, test, and re-design this model for 4 years, making it better each year. Our model of training should be able to be used to train a number of schools effectively. The training model will harness the proven impact of Professional Learning Communities (PLC) in the diffusion of the ASSISTments innovation. These schools will undergo an extensive and intensive set of professional development actives based upon the previous years design.The deliverables at the end of this grant will include books, paper materials, and videos so that new schools can quickly learn how to use ASSISTments in meaningful ways. And perhaps our most compelling deliverable of all, we will a set about a dozen high-implementing schools that hopefully wi... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: DATA-ASSIST - Improving Student Achievement through Online Nightly Homework
Project Description: "According to the National Assessment of Educational Progress only 32% of American public school student are at or above ?proficient? in mathematics. The state of Maine is representative of this trend with only 35% of students at or above ?proficient? according to NAEP. In fact, Maine?s math achievement scores have remained flat despite being the only state in the country that leases laptops to every middle school student in the state. This lack of improvement may be due to the fact that Maine did not buy any educational software for math. We propose to remedy this by giving all 45,000 middle school students in Maine a well-developed computer-based intelligent tutoring system so students can get feedback on their homework while at the same time, their teachers get reports on how students are doing. Two rigorous studies, with high internal validity, showed that using ASSISTments for homework leads to more learning than a traditional control group where student got feedback the next day in class. Each student gets individualized help, right when they make a mistake, rather than waiting until the next day in class. The RAND Corporation, a trusted name in objective analysis, will conduct an external evaluation to see if, in fact, student test scores do go up. Initially 60 schools will participate in the randomized controlled trial. By the end of the grant, all the schools in the state will get access to access to ASSISTments. This grant is proposed by an interdisciplinary team of nationally renowned experts in cognitive science, intelligent tutoring systems, mathematics education, teacher training, educational leadership and psychometrics. The team has extensive support throughout Maine from many partners. Improving homework so that kids get immediate feedback might sound mundane to some, but cognitive science tells of the importance of immediate feedback for learning. This grant has the potential to prove a very important point to the nation. When kids have access well ... [Truncated, 2000 Character Length Exceeded]"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Globaloria West Virginia
Using The RULER Approach to Support Effective Teachers and Principals and Increase Achievement among  High-Need Student
Project Description: "The RULER Approach to Social, Emotional, and Academic Learning (?RULER?) provides evidence-based,whole-school prevention programming that fosters effectiveness in principals and teachers, leads to academic,social, and emotional improvements for students, and enhances learning environments. This project seeks toadapt systematically RULER (developed by the PI?s team) to meet the unique needs of principals, teachers,and students in schools for children with special learning needs, including those with autism spectrum disorderand with emotional disturbances. This 5-year development project will ready RULER for validation andnational scale-up using a 3-prong approach: (1) embed RULER into a large, urban school district serving over23,000 high-need students; (2) develop a cost-effective, technologically-advanced implementation strategyusing a site-based train-the-trainer model to ensure long-term program sustainability with minimalinvolvement from the development team; and (3) use technology, protocols, and data derived from the projectto scale-up national delivery of RULER . A team of seasoned researchers and program developers from YaleUniversity (nonprofit applicant) will continue their existing partnership with District 75 of New York City(LEA) and officially partner with leading education technology developers at the Columbia Center for NewMedia Teaching and Learning to achieve this objective. The Yale team will be advised by renowned clinicaland educational experts in order to adapt RULER to meet both the unique learning needs of students withdisabilities (to improve their growth), and the unique leadership and professional development needs of theirprincipals and teachers (to make them more effective at improving student growth). In Years 1-3 we willdevelop and field test RULER and the innovative the technology platform in special education settings, and inYears 4-5 we will test refinements and ready RULER for validity testing and scaling-up."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Yale National Initiative to strengthen teaching in public schools
Project Description: "Yale University, in partnership with the New Haven Public Schools, has developed an exceptional approach to strengthen teaching and learning in the nation?s public schools and has demonstrated its ability to assist other communities in implementing that approach in diverse high-need school districts around the country. Over five years, Teachers Institutes will be established, sustained, and evaluated. With other partners, the League will disseminate its work widely, targeting high-need school districts and nearby colleges and universities that could join them in adopting the Institute approach. The Initiative offers an annual cycle of national seminars for teachers and conferences and programs for school officials and college and university faculty members and administrators; organizes site visits and information sessions; hosts a Web site; and publishes a periodical, 'On Common Ground'?.Teachers Institutes that are members of the League will enlarge their work to reach more students and become more cost effective, and will further develop ways they support school reform in their districts and states in order to institutionalize their work. Other school districts will plan and begin to implement new Teachers Institutes. An evaluation of the efficacy of these Institutes will help persuade additional school districts and states to adopt the approach. The work will thus begin to be institutionalized in existing Teachers Institutes, sustained in new Institutes, and eventually undertaken by school districts around the country by tapping public funds for professional development. In these ways, the Teachers Institute approach will provide an innovative, viable, and appealing alternative to ineffectual and unpopular but widespread professional development practices."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Center for Research and Innovation in Teaching Excellence
Project Description: "Brief project description, summary of project objectives and expected outcomes:Through a multi-state partnership, the Research and Innovation in Teaching Excellence Center (RITE Center) project brings together large urban public school district, four high-performing charter school systems, and leading entrepreneurs in education. The Investing in Innovation (i3) Development grant will launch the RITE Center to achieve the following:(1) Increase the number and percentages of highly effective teachers;(2) Increase student growth and achievement, and(3) Serve as a model for other charters and districts establish a learning environment where experienced teachers can receive ongoing, content-specific skills enrichment and engage in research that will drive high standards of practice.Each of the partners possesses proven strengths in these project areas that will lead to the Center?s success both locally and nationally, which includes dissemination of Center results and guided replication in a consortium of Nashville, Tennessee charter school districts.Target number of students to be served in the project: 209,376 students from five LEAsSpecial project features: Two high-performing Charter Management Organizations and a large urban school district partnering with the leading thinkers and education entrepreneurs to redesign what it means to create effective teachers, thereby bringing about even greater measures of student success. Project is expected to have revenues beginning in year 2 via ACP tuitions.Project partners: YES Prep Public Schools, KIPP (Knowledge is Power Program) Houston, Houston Independent School District, KIPP Nashville and LEAD Public Schools."

Project Title: YMCA Multicultural Achievers
Project Description: "The YMCA Multicultural Achievers is a college readiness program . The goal is to bring Hispanic youth to the successful completion of a college degree leading to meaningful career of their choosing. Our program is designed in several components designed to remove the barriers to successful participation in gaining an education . Our program works with participants from school age youth on up to college age, to ensure proficiency in English Language skills, to attain success at school leading to a diploma, to offer opportunities to explore various career options, obtain on the job training and to assist the participant gain entry into an institution of higher learning."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Yolo County Closing the Achievement Gap (YCCAG) Initiative
Project Description: "Yolo County Office of Education, in collaboration with all five public school districts in Yolo County, Woodland Community College, and University of California at Davis, has developed the Yolo County Closing the Achievement Gap (YCCAG) Initiative as an innovative approach at closing the achievement gaps between limited English proficient and English proficient students?.TRUNCATED"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Pioneer Teacher/Principal Training to Close High Needs Achievement Gaps
Project Description: "The LEA partners with New York State Middle School Association and Cattaraugus-Allegany BOCES toprovide teacher/principal training to test the hypothesis that, because of early success at the LEA's middleschool, implementation of Essential Elements of Standards-Focused Middle-Level Schools and Programs andTheir Rubrics and PBIS (Positive Behavioral Interventions and Supports) at the two elementary schools andthe high school will close academic achievement gaps for high needs groups and increase overall studentgrowth. The high needs groups are students with disabilities - 16.4% - and economically disadvantaged - 50%.Training of teachers and principals prepares them to implement Essential Elements protocols involvingcollaboration, data collection, feedback, reflection and consensus aimed towards school improvement.Training for PBIS best practices focuses on the behavioral side following a similar collaborative, problemsolving approach that engages students in learning what acceptable behaviors look like and receiving multiplepositive reinforcements for desired behaviors. The learning environment becomes safer and more supportive.Over four years experience at Pioneer Middle School has demonstrated that teacher/principal effectivenessincreased as measured by results of ELA and Math state tests. Middle School student performance wassuperior to outcomes at the other three schools, including for gap closing.During Years 4 and 5, scale up begins using BOCES component schools as the vehicle to engage moreteachers/principals and to impact more students. C-A BOCES serves generally rural school districts.Although the LEA is not considered 'rural', most of their 2,718 students are bussed from rural areas of the 250square mile school district. Adjacent districts within the C-A BOCES service area are coded 'rural'. Up to 14rural districts will benefit from scale up during the project period."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Young Playwrights' Theater - In-School Playwriting Program Development Project
Project Description: "Young Playwrights' Theater (YPT) teaches underserved students throughout the DC metro area to express themselves clearly and creatively through the art of playwriting.  With support from the Investing in Innovation Fund - Development Grant Program, YPT will evaluate and deepen the value of its flagship In-School Playwriting Program, in collaboration with Powell, Watkins, and Tyler Elementary Schools, George Mason University's School of Education and outside evaluator Dr. Barry Oreck.  Over the course of four years, YPT will design and conduct a comprehensive, scientific outside evaluation of its programs' impact on student reading, writing and academic engagement at the third grade level, in order to demonstrate and disseminate a national model for advancing student learning of traditional classroom content in the English Language Arts through an interactive, innovative, arts integrated approach. By the end of this project, in spring 2014, YPT will have a complete and replicable model for arts integration in the 3rd grade of public schools throughout the U.S."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: YPI PK-20 School Transformation Model
Project Description: "The PK-20 YPI Schools Transformation Model will partner with the Los Angeles Unified School District, model charter schools, and multiple other public and private partners to saturate ten low-performing (in corrective action or restructuring) LAUSD schools with education and supportive services. Over 37,600 students over five years (7,520 each year) will receive direct program services including, case management, early childhood education, afterschool, tutoring, teacher professional development, college preparation, parenting education, online resources, services for EL students and a rage of supportive services to transform these schools, while all 15,593 students attending these schools will benefit from these transformative efforts. Students and their families will receive services to tackle the root causes preventing students from achieving in school, while the program will transform school culture by working with staff and administration to offer services and resources in and out of the school day. This will include options for charter, iDesign, and Pilot school models within the framework of the groundbreaking Public School Choice initiative of the Los Angeles Unified School District."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs

Project Title: Student Achievement Through Social Entrepreneurship
Project Description: "Ashoka?s Youth Venture (YV) and the United Way (UW), in conjunction with over 100 LEAs and 1901 Group,are partnering to offer the Department of Education the opportunity to invest in a new approach to supporthigh-needs students in improving academic achievement, increasing college enrollment, and enhancing careerreadiness. The goal of our proposal is to use YV?s social entrepreneurship program as a vehicle to alignstudent-led community initiative with academics in an effort to motivate and guide our nation?s youthpopulation, in particular at-risk youth, toward realizing their potential in school, work, home and civic life.This will be achieved through student-led civic ventures that provide hands-on, experiential training in math,writing, public speaking, leadership, teamwork and problem-solving to improve communities. Given initialYV results that show a correlation between the students launching ventures and higher graduation rates,coupled with the new nation-wide goal in the UW system to improve high school graduation rates, the UWYVrelationship (which began in 2002 in NH) has quickly multiplied. Currently, the YV program is beingimplemented by eight UWs across the country. This I3 Development Grant will allow YV to expand theprogram to six new UWs while also deepening the program in six current UW regions. Over 100 LEAs willpartner with YV and UW in a regionally and ethnically diverse array of high-need communities across theUnited States. This I3 Development Grant will allow YV to collect evidence of how the YV program hasimpact in various regions and school settings, and will provide further evidence to our strong hypothesis thatthe venturing experience of YV contributes to students? increased high school graduation rates, lowerdetention and suspension rates, better focus and engagement in the classroom, greater interest in college, andenhanced career readiness."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: YouthBUILT (Building Unique Instructional Leadership Teams) for Success
Project Description: "YouthBUILT (Building Unique Instructional Leadership Teams) will deliver an innovative teacher development system focused on instructional excellence for a national network of YouthBuild charter and alternative schools. These schools serve youth who have previously dropped out of traditional high schools. The pilot innovation will recruit, develop, reward and retain educators who will ensure that more low-income young people previously failed by public school systems achieve postsecondary credentials and career and life success. The instructional strategies in which teachers will be coached are organized around literacy, numeracy and youth development practices demonstrated to significantly improve student achievement and postsecondary readiness for an over-aged, under-credited population. Instructional strategies will be supported with a new teacher mentoring system and a performance compensation model to reward exemplary teaching. The innovation will serve as a national model for how YouthBuild schools, alternative high schools and high schools serving low-income students build highly effective teaching systems."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: "Digi-Know"
Project Description: "The overall goal of YISD's 'Digi-Know' project is to improve college readiness of students, most of whom are minority and disadvantaged.  Strategies include providing 21st century classrooms at a brand new elementary school and its vertically-aligned middle school; integrating technology into instruction and shifting to project-based learning as the primary model for instruction; ensuring that students use advanced technology both inside and outside class to build information and communications technologies (ICT) literacy as well as content knowledge; linking and assessing grade-to-grade improvements in ICT literacy and foundation skills as well as content knowledge, guided by the new Texas College and Career Readiness Standards; and using technology to build understanding of college processes and behaviors.  Apple Professional Development and LoTi Connection, Inc. (both private-sector entities) will provide extensive professional development and consulting services and match support for the project."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success

Project Title: Rural Alaska School Improvement Model
Project Description: "The Rural Alaska School Improvement Model focuses on the unique challenges of high-need, Native Alaska, low-income students in remote Alaskan schools. This program is designed to support the 'whole child,' by improving student achievement and social-emotional learning. This proven and promising model is currently implemented in the Yukon-Koyukuk School District (YKSD). The project intends to provide longevity of this model within the YKSD, and to expand the model to Copper River School District (CRSC).	This comprehensive model measures success through student achievement, defined as academic success and improved social-emotional capacity. The model integrates the following methods:o	Assessment and data-driven intervention system responding to academic and behavioral needs by implementing YKSD district-wide Response to Intervention (RTI)o	Intensive professional development and coaching in instructional design, delivery methods, and assessments supporting the intervention systemo	Technology to efficiently plan, deliver and track high standards-based instruction and quality assessments and to facilitate (RTI) activitieso	Professional development in social-emotional learning and positive behavioral supportso	Collaboration among schools to disseminate and share 'best practices' to facilitate a replicable rural school model supported by an Online Community of Practice	The Rural Alaska School Improvement Model 's project expected outcomes include the following Performance Measure 1a: 80% of all YKSD students are proficient in Language Arts by 2012.   Performance Measure 1b: 80% of all YKSD students are proficient in Math by 2012 	Objective #2 Increase the social emotional capacity of YKSD students through the use of Positive Behavioral Supports. Performance Measure 2a: 5% decrease in participation in risk behaviors annually.  Performance Measure 2b: 10% increase in adult connectedness of YKSD students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project PWR4: Project Western Power in Rigor, Relevance, Relatinships, Rigor
Project Description: "Project PWR4 is a regional initiative in Yuma and La Paz Counties to implement the AVID elementary model, preparing students in grades 4 through 8 for college success, and the AVID post-secondary model preparing cohorts of pre-service teachers to sustain AVID in local schools. PWR4 partners include 5 public school districts, one non-profit school, one community college, one university branch campus, AVID?--a non-profit, and multiple private-sector donors. PWR4 harnesses Power in Western Arizona with Rigor, Relevance, Relationships and Relentlessness to implement AVID for high-needs students, impacting 21,453 students in 22 elementary schools over 5 years. Together with existing and planned middle- and high-school AVID programs, this project will serve whole communities with a full-circle program to ensure that our youth are?college-, career-, and citizenship-ready.?Goals: provide professional development so sites meet AVID and Innovation Configuration quality standards; translate rigorous standards into instructional practices to assist high needs students, so that all sites attain and maintain AVID certification and show increases in student achievement and college expectations; assess student progress toward college-and career readiness by designing and using formative assessments in core subjects; provide sustainability by piloting and evaluating a model to embed AVID in pre-service teacher training; and implement a quasi-experimental study to validate the AVID model in a range of contexts.Project activities include extensive AVID professional development; AVID site visits; vertical teams to develop standards-based formative assessments; and an AVID college class for pre-service teacher cohorts. An external evaluation will answer key questions about model effectiveness in a range of settings through a quasiexperimental study and interrupted time series and Growth Mixture Modeling methodologies, supported by Innovation Configurations training."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Project PWRRRR: Power through Western Rigor, Relevance, Relationships, Relentlessness
Project Description: "Project PWRRRR is a regional initiative in Yuma and La Paz Counties to implement the AVID secondary model,preparing students in grades 6 through 12 for college success. PWR4 partners include 6 public school districts,one non-profit high school, one community college, and multiple private-sector donors. PWRRRR harnessesPower in Western Arizona with Rigor, Relevance, Relationships and Relentlessness to implement AVID forhigh-needs students, impacting 77,033 students in 17 secondary schools over 5 years. It provides intensiveservices through an AVID elective class and whole-school reform through embedding AVID strategies in allcore classes. This project will serve whole communities, ensuring that our youth are ?college-, career-, andcitizenship-ready.?Goals: provide professional development so sites meet AVID and Innovation Configuration quality standards;translate rigorous standards into instructional practices to assist high needs students, so that all sites attain andmaintain AVID certification and show increases in student achievement and college expectations; assessstudent progress toward college-and career readiness by designing and using formative assessments in coresubjects; and implement a quasi-experimental study to validate the AVID model in a range of contexts.Project activities include extensive AVID professional development; AVID elective classes with tutoring forhigh-needs students; vertical teams to develop standards-based formative assessments; and a college class totrain AVID tutors. An external evaluation will answer key questions about model effectiveness in a range ofsettings through a quasi-experimental study and interrupted time series and Growth Mixture Modelingmethodologies, supported by Innovation Configurations training."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Journey to College and Career Program
Project Description: "College enrollment and persistence rates have increased for all groups in the past half-century.  However, gaps in educational attainment by race and income persist today.  Pre-collegiate outreach programs are designed to provide underserved students with additional support to prepare for and succeed in higher education.  Researchers consistently cite the need for high quality data collection and rigorous evaluations of these programs to better identify elements of effectiveness for program participants.  Evidence from the few programs that have undergone such evaluations suggests that these programs can increase access and persistence in higher education for low-income and minority students.  Successful programs generally target students early and coordinate with systemic school reform efforts.  The Zachary Community School District Journey to College and Career (JTCC) initiative aims to implement this successful program model in an effort to provide additional, rigorous research and evaluation data regarding the effectiveness of pre-collegiate academic outreach programs for all subgroups of students."
Absolute Priority: AP3: High Standards and High-Quality Assessments
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success, CP7: Unique Learning Needs, CP8: Rural LEAs

Applicant: ZERO TO THREE: National Center for Infants, Toddlers and Families
Project Title: Project Click-ABC
Project Description: "This project will serve 24 early childhood educators serving children birth to five years, within early learning programs administered by each LEA, along with 79 Kindergarten through 3rd grade teachers.   In total these teachers serve approximately 1,543 children birth to 8 years of age annually.  ZERO TO THREE and our partners will:  1) Provide high quality, intensive and interactive training and mentoring that will result in increased teacher knowledge and use of effective teaching pedagogy in supporting early language and literacy and effective literacy instruction. 2)  Support collaboration and transition activities between early learning programs that service children birth to age three, preschools, and Kindergarten through third grade classrooms. 3)  Align teacher competencies that positively effect language and literacy outcomes and achievement for teachers serving children birth to 8 years of age; 4) Develop an evaluation system to measure teacher effectiveness in nurturing language and literacy, and to identify, recognize, and reward highly effective teachers; and 5) 	Support activities targeted to engage families in nurturing early language and literacy and in K-3rd grade school curricula.  ZERO TO THREE's Cradling Literacy:  Building Teachers' Skills to Nurture Early Language and Literacy from Birth to Five (Cradling Literacy) will be used as the core content basis for training to help teachers understand the vision and philosophies of a continuum of learning that begins at birth through the end of 3rd grade.  Teachers will participate in 12 half-day trainings over the three years, and receive 6 hours a month of mentoring.  Researchers in the Department of Child and Family Studies at the University of Tennessee-Knoxville will conduct an independent evaluation that will provide both formative feedback and outcome evaluation data related to project goals and objectives."
Competitive Preference Priority: CP5: Early Learning, CP8: Rural LEAs

Project Title: Ensuring College Readiness and Equal Access for All
Project Description: "Zion-Benton Township High School District 126  is applying for an i3 Development Grant in order to support a continuation of the District's focus on improved student learning.  Three years of planning, one year in implementation, intense reflective discussion, focused staff development and extensive data analysis have guided the District's school improvement efforts thus far.   The proposed model is one that has been tested in numerous school districts for the past ten years and demonstrates it can turn around failing schools through increasing academic achievement for all students, particularly at-risk students. The ultimate District 126 outcome is to foster an environment in which students can and will grow: cognitively, affectively, and social-emotionally.  For the purpose of this grant, District 126 intends to focus first on the cognitive piece, ensuring college readiness for all , and second, on the affective and social-emotional pieces, preparing students to encounter real-world challenges in college and beyond.At the heart of this model is a rigorous core curriculum infused with scaffolded skill building that allows students additional opportunities for increased access to higher level courses as they become skill ready.  This design demands intense, focused staff development to equip teachers with better skill-sets to meet the needs of a diverse student population with ever-increasing academic and social-emotional concerns.The application for the Investing in Innovation Grant is the logical next step to accomplish instructional and learning transformations within Zion-Benton classrooms as well as increase student learning and performance.?????"
Competitive Preference Priority: CP6: College Access and Success College Access and Success
